site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on US stimulus
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.72% on Thursday as investors considered the US$2 trillion spending plan and US economic data. The Nikkei 225 index ended at 29,388.87, while the Topix index advanced 0.19%. Toshiba jumped 4.54% after reports of a potential deal for Kioxia. Meanwhile, US stocks edged higher, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Got your ticket for Berlin play? You'll need negative coronavirus test result too
summary: Berlin's cultural venues are reopening with pilot programs despite a surge in coronavirus infections. To attend live performances, attendees must provide a negative coronavirus test result, a new requirement. This follows tougher restrictions as a third wave of the pandemic grips Germany. The reopening allows for the first live stage production in the city in about five months.

site_title: Former HK leader signals housing as next big issue to tackle
summary: Former Hong Kong leader Leung Chun-ying has stated that the new electoral system will aid in addressing the city's housing issues, which he believes are a root cause of social and economic problems. He emphasized the need to create more land for housing units to tackle the shortage.

site_title: Seats filled for first all-civilian spaceflight crew
summary: SpaceX has named a four-member crew for its upcoming all-civilian spaceflight, dubbed Inspiration4, scheduled for no earlier than September 15. The crew includes college science professor Sian Proctor, aerospace data analyst Chris Sembroski, physician's assistant Haley Arceneaux, and entrepreneur Jared Isaacman, who is funding the mission as a charity drive. The crew will undergo extensive training and conduct science experiments during their three- to four-day journey, with the mission aiming to raise awareness and support for St Jude Children's Research Hospital.

site_title: More returning to the office - but also to a new future of work
summary: Singapore is shifting from work-from-home to a more flexible and hybrid work arrangement, allowing up to 75% of employees to return to the workplace, with no cap on working time. This change may force employers to re-evaluate their long-term stance on flexible work arrangements, considering the benefits of remote work, such as increased productivity and employee morale. The shift may also impact office design, furniture, and the future of business districts, potentially leading to more mixed-use spaces and a greater residential population.

site_title: H&M says 'dedicated to regaining trust' in China after boycott
summary: H&M is working to regain trust in China after a boycott was sparked by its decision to stop sourcing cotton from Xinjiang due to forced labor concerns. The company, which generates 6% of its revenue in China, has faced criticism from Chinese celebrities and tech firms, resulting in partnerships being pulled and the brand being erased from Chinese shopping apps. H&M stated it is "dedicated to regaining the trust and confidence of our customers, colleagues, and business partners in China" as it works to resolve the issue.

site_title: SBF unveils MAP initiative to help transform wholesale, retail trade businesses
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) launched the MAP (Mastering Adaptation and Pivot) initiative to support wholesale and retail trade businesses in post-pandemic recovery. The pilot stage aims to benefit at least 500 companies, offering guided assistance and pathway assignments through three stages: mindset change, analysis, and pathway assignments. Supported by various partners, the initiative provides funding, webinars, workshops, and partnering programs to help businesses streamline problem statements, boost productivity, and explore digitalization and design thinking.

site_title: Oyika raising US$100m to roll out greener rides in Asean
summary: Singapore startup Oyika is raising US$100 million to roll out greener rides in Asean by bundling e-bike subscriptions with fully-charged battery packs. The company aims to electrify mobility in the region by targeting cities with high numbers of petrol-guzzling motorbikes. Oyika also plans to bring power to those off the grid using the same battery packs. The venture-backed company plans to offer leases on battery packs, providing an alternative to traditional fossil fuel-powered vehicles.

site_title: India rolls back decision to cut interest rates on small savings
summary: India has reversed its decision to cut interest rates on its state-backed small savings programme by up to 1.1% due to an oversight. Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman announced that interest rates will remain the same as those in the last quarter of 2020-2021. The decision was reportedly made to avoid a potential backlash from voters in state assembly elections, with two eastern states already voting. The rollback comes after India cut interest rates on small savings just a day earlier, citing a need to link rates with government bond yields.

site_title: Dozens of Hong Kong-listed companies suspend trading
summary: Dozens of Hong Kong-listed companies had their shares suspended from trading due to failing to publish their 2020 full year results by the end of March. The suspension affects over 70 companies, primarily due to Hong Kong's listing rules. This is the latest in a series of actions taken by the Hong Kong Stock Exchange to enforce compliance with reporting requirements. The exact number of companies affected is not specified.

site_title: Keppel to explore creating value with extra funds unlocked from asset-light strategy: CEO
summary: Keppel Corporation's CEO, Loh Chin Hua, plans to explore creating value with the surplus funds unlocked from the company's asset-light strategy. This could involve returning capital to shareholders, particularly during periods of fewer growth opportunities or when growth is priced inappropriately. The strategy aims to maximize shareholder value while minimizing risks.

site_title: Canada's Westons trade food for real estate
summary: The Weston family, Canada's third-largest billionaire, is shifting focus from their food business to real estate. After selling its commercial bakery business, Weston Foods, the company will focus on its real estate portfolio, growing in value as Canadian property prices boom. The company plans to redevelop shopping malls into mixed-use developments, including residential towers, and is already working on several projects, including a $1.5 billion redevelopment in Toronto. This new strategy aims to increase the company's weight within the group and generate more income, but also carries risks as it moves away from a recession-proof business.

site_title: Great exSPACtations - the advent of blank-cheque companies in Singapore
summary: Singapore is considering introducing Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPAC) listings by the end of the year, aiming to become a premier Asian venue for such IPOs. The move follows the US's success with SPAC listings, which have raised US$87.9 billion in the first three months of 2021. The introduction of SPACs in Singapore is also seen as a response to Chinese companies seeking a neutral listing platform due to arctic Sino-US relations. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has issued a consultation paper on the proposal.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up on Biden infrastructure plan roll-out; oil drops
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as President Biden unveiled a $2 trillion infrastructure spending plan, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite advancing. The Dow, however, ended lower. Investors welcomed the plan but expressed concerns over a proposed hike in corporate taxes, which could impact earnings. World oil prices dropped after a choppy session, and London stocks declined due to Deliveroo's disastrous initial public offering.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at Thursday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.76% higher on Thursday, following a positive lead from New York, as investors welcomed the US$2 trillion infrastructure spending plan. The Hang Seng Index rose 216.20 points to 28,594.55, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also edged up. The rally came despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed, with Singapore's STI rising 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: South Korea to foster local development of next-generation power chips
summary: South Korea's government aims to foster local development of next-generation power chips, particularly non-silicon semiconductors for electric vehicles and new technologies. The goal is to develop five or more types of power semiconductors by 2025, using compounds such as silicon carbide and gallium nitride, which are more efficient, durable, and miniaturizable than silicon. This move joins other countries like the US, China, and Japan in promoting native chip industries. Private sector cooperation is expected to be key to achieving this goal.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars lean on support as US dollar barges ahead
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced volatility, with the Aussie easing to US$0.7584 and the kiwi falling to US$0.6975, as the US dollar advanced. Despite a surge in home prices, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) remains committed to super-loose policy, with expectations of keeping interest rates at 0.10% and extending its quantitative easing program. Yields on 10-year bonds have risen, with the Aussie gaining on the yen and euro, and analysts predict a mid-year A$1.51 and year-end A$1.49 for the currency.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.95% and the Topix index advancing 0.96%. The gains follow a mixed close on Wall Street, with investors assessing the impact of a US$2-trillion US spending plan on the global market.

site_title: Greensill as a cautionary tale
summary: Greensill Capital's collapse has further complicated the supply chain finance industry's reputational issues, particularly for SMEs. The fintech pioneer's alleged role in a Singaporean commodity trade finance fraud case, involving a purported S$3.85 billion exposure, highlights structural problems in the trade finance industry, including transparency and risk mitigation controls. Despite the market's expected growth to US$10,427 billion by 2026, banks and credit insurers remain the fundamental players, with alternative providers like Greensill using receivable securitisation to make the asset class more accessible to private investors.

site_title: Keeping alive hopes of 1.5°C limit will spur climate action
summary: The 1.5°C global warming limit, set by the Paris climate summit in 2015, remains achievable, but its success depends on two uncertain factors: climate sensitivity and emission-cutting speed. Despite this, many countries have pledged to reach net-zero emissions by mid-century, potentially halving the gap to the target. The UN report shows that only 40% of countries have set new emission-cutting targets for 2030, and collective pledges are below the 45% needed to meet the 1.5°C limit. The future of the 1.5°C target depends on decisions made in the next few years, with the IPCC's sixth assessment report and the UN climate summit in November set to provide further guidance.

site_title: Wilmar obtains US$150m sustainability-linked loan from OCBC
summary: Wilmar International has secured a US$150 million, three-year sustainability-linked loan from OCBC Bank. The loan is tied to Wilmar's inclusion in an external benchmark index and achievement of ESG targets. If met, the interest rate will be reduced on a tiered basis. This is Wilmar's second sustainability-linked loan with OCBC, following its previous agreement.

images.alt_text: The loan is pegged to the agribusiness group's continued inclusion in an external benchmark index, among other sustainability targets.

site_title: Female attacker shot dead at Indonesian police HQ
summary: Indonesian police shot dead a 25-year-old woman who opened fire at the national police headquarters in Jakarta, inspired by the Islamic State, according to police chief Listyo Sigit Prabowo. The woman, identified as ZA, had posted an ISIS flag on her Instagram account hours before the attack. The incident came three days after a suicide bombing in Sulawesi, and authorities have arrested at least 13 people suspected of involvement in the attack.

site_title: Allure of condo living stimulates demand for mass market homes
summary: Singapore's private new home sales in 2020 reached 9,982 units, a 0.7% increase from 2019, with the majority sold in the mass market or outside central region (OCR). The OCR accounted for 45% of total new private home sales, with 4,481 units sold, led by lifestyle preference, legacy planning, and wealth preservation. Mass-market homes priced below S$1.5 million remained popular, with a 76.3% market share. The demand for OCR homes is expected to remain healthy, driven by low interest rates and household savings, with prices expected to stay relatively stable.

site_title: Japan business mood improves to pre-pandemic levels on global recovery hopes
summary: Japan's business mood improved to pre-pandemic levels in the first quarter, with big manufacturers' sentiment rising to plus 5 and non-manufacturers' sentiment improving to minus 1. The Bank of Japan's "tankan" survey showed companies plan to increase capital expenditure by 3.0% this year, exceeding market forecasts of a 1.4% increase. The solid recovery in global demand and fading pandemic strains suggest the export-reliant economy is benefiting from the global recovery, offering some relief for policymakers.

images.alt_text: Japanese big manufacturers' sentiment improved to pre-pandemic levels in the first quarter as companies planned to increase capital expenditure this year, suggesting the export-reliant economy was benefiting from a solid recovery in global demand.

site_title: The future for offices in Singapore
summary: Singapore's office sector is expected to remain central to a firm's identity, talent attraction, and productivity despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact. Flexible working arrangements, including hybrid office-based and remote working, have become the norm. Leasing activity has picked up, driven by the technology and asset management sectors, as well as displacement from redeveloped CBD buildings. With cost efficiency a priority, corporates are recalibrating occupation planning and lease commitments, indicating a shift towards a future where the physical workplace remains vital.

site_title: Archegos fallout: global banks could lose over US$6b
summary: Global banks face multi-billion-dollar losses after Archegos Capital Management, run by former hedge fund manager Bill Hwang, failed to meet margin calls on speculative stock and derivative positions. The failure, which occurred in 2021, has resulted in losses of over US$6 billion for major investment banks worldwide. The incident highlights the risks associated with speculative investments and the need for banks to closely monitor their clients' positions. The incident's impact is still being felt, with ongoing implications for the global banking sector.

images.alt_text: Securing a three-year deal for the world's most lucrative soccer tournament would show the U.S. social media giant is serious about grabbing global sports rights.

site_title: Suu Kyi 'looks healthy', lawyer says
summary: Myanmar's deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi appeared in good health in a video meeting with her lawyers, according to one of her lawyers. She did not agree to a wide discussion in the presence of police, and only the legal cases against her since the coup were discussed. Suu Kyi faces charges including illegally importing radios and breaching coronavirus protocols, with her lawyers dismissing these as trumped up. At least 521 civilians have been killed in protests, and fighting continues between the army and ethnic minority insurgents.

site_title: A year of recovery and transformation
summary: The Singapore property sector has emerged as a bright spot during the pandemic, with demand for private homes remaining resilient. Prices in the mass market private residential segment are expected to remain stable this year, possibly even rising slightly, driven by healthy demand and easing inventory. En bloc sales may also experience a revival as developers look to replenish their land banks, with several sites being placed on the market.

site_title: Australia's March home prices surge at fastest pace since 1988
summary: Australia's home prices surged 2.8% in March, the fastest pace in three decades, driven by record-low interest rates and a shortage of available property. The national home value rose to A$7.7 trillion, with detached houses seeing a 3.0% gain. Sydney led the charge with a 3.7% increase, while apartments saw a 1.9% gain. The low interest rates and limited supply have fueled buyer demand, with inventory levels 25.5% below the five-year average, according to CoreLogic.

site_title: US plant ruins 15 million J&J coronavirus vaccine doses: report
summary: US pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson reported that 15 million doses of its single-shot coronavirus vaccine were ruined in a factory error at a Baltimore plant. The error occurred before the doses were filled and finished, with quality and safety remaining the company's top priority. The company identified the affected batch but did not confirm the specific number of doses impacted.

site_title: BBC reporter leaves China, says 'too risky to carry on'
summary: A senior BBC correspondent, John Sudworth, has left China for Taiwan after nine years, citing "too risky to carry on" due to increased threats and pressure from authorities over his reporting on Xinjiang rights abuses and the coronavirus pandemic. Sudworth relocated following intensified threats from Chinese authorities in recent months.

site_title: Investigation begins into how ship got stuck on Suez Canal
summary: Investigations into the grounding of the Ever Given ship in the Suez Canal have begun, with the Suez Canal Authority suggesting weather conditions and human error may have played a role. The investigation will examine the ship's seaworthiness and captain's actions. The six-day blockage disrupted global shipping, with Lloyd's of London predicting a "large loss" of up to $100 million in insurance claims. The ship's Japanese owner has not received any claims or lawsuits over the incident, which has cleared a backlog of over 400 ships waiting to pass through the canal.

site_title: Dollar to yen highest in a year on recovery bets
summary: The US dollar reached a one-year high versus the yen and multi-month peaks with other currencies on Wednesday as investors bet on a global pandemic recovery. The US dollar index rose to 93.439, with the euro trading 0.1% higher at US$1.1730. The US dollar's strength was also driven by a surge in US bond yields, making the currency more attractive as an investment. Investors will watch closely monthly US non-farm payrolls data on Friday, which could impact interest rates and the growth outlook.

site_title: Malaysia sees economy rebounding to pre-Covid levels by mid-2021
summary: Malaysia's central bank predicts its economy will rebound to pre-Covid levels by mid-2021, with a 6-7.5% GDP growth forecast for 2021. The bank has pledged to keep monetary policy accommodative to support the recovery. This is slightly slower than its earlier projection of 6.5-7.5% growth. The forecast suggests a strong recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain on upbeat trade data, Biden's infrastructure plan
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.85% on Thursday, driven by gains in chip heavyweights and foreign buying, following a double-digit expansion in exports in March. The Kospi closed at 3,087.40, rebounding from a 0.28% fall on Wednesday. The US President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan also boosted investor sentiment, with chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the gains. Foreigners invested US$497.19 million in shares on the main board, contributing to the market's upward momentum.

site_title: An appetite for luxury
summary: The Singapore luxury apartment market experienced a resurgence in sales volumes and median prices from 2018 to 2021, despite the pandemic-induced recession. The three-tier classification of luxury apartments, including compact luxury, prime luxury, and premium luxury, showed steady growth, with 423 luxury units sold in 2019. Foreign buyers, particularly ultra-high-net-worth individuals, dominated the market, accounting for over 70% of sales. Developers responded to market uncertainty by offering "star buys" and renovation packages, allowing some projects to sell well in 2020. The market outlook remains positive, with new projects and foreign investors expected to drive demand in 2021.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.43 points, or 0.60%, to 1,582.94 on Thursday, driven by gains. Volume reached 418.27 million lots worth RM160.06 million, with 296 gainers surpassing losers 130. The index has seen a 5-day rally, with Singapore stocks also experiencing a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Suu Kyi faces court as UN envoy warns of Myanmar civil war
summary: Myanmar's ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi faced a court hearing, amid a UN envoy's warning of a risk of civil war and an "imminent bloodbath" due to the junta's repression of pro-democracy protests. Over 535 people have died in daily demonstrations since the military's takeover in February. The UN Security Council held an urgent session, urging action amid the escalating crisis.

site_title: The retail scene in post-pandemic Singapore
summary: Singapore's retail sector has adapted to the post-pandemic landscape, embracing a symbiosis of e-commerce and brick-and-mortar retail. The sector was initially impacted by rising occupancy costs and labor issues, but the rise of online platforms and retailers' adoption of these channels helped mitigate losses. The Covid-19 pandemic further challenged the industry, but it has since transformed into a dynamic landscape, with retailers responding to evolving consumer behavior and adapting to new market conditions. As the industry moves forward, a balance between online and offline retail is expected to be key to success.

site_title: Suspect arrested in brutal New York assault of Asian woman
summary: A 65-year-old Asian-American woman was brutally assaulted in a New York City sidewalk attack on Monday, sparking outrage amid a surge of anti-Asian violence. Brandon Elliot, 38, was arrested and charged with felony assault as a hate crime. The attack, captured on CCTV footage, showed bystanders seemingly ignoring the assault. The victim was hospitalized with multiple injuries and has since recovered. The incident is part of a growing trend of anti-Asian violence in the US, with authorities taking steps to address the issue, including increased safety patrols and a presidential initiative.

site_title: 950,000 HDB households to get additional GST rebate in April as part of Budget support package
summary: About 950,000 HDB households in Singapore will receive additional GST rebates this month, totaling 50% of their regular rebates, as part of the Household Support Package announced in the 2021 Budget. The rebates, worth around S$460 million, will be disbursed through the GST Voucher (GSTV) U-Save and U-Save Special Payment initiatives, credited to household utility bills. The additional support aims to provide relief to households during economic uncertainty.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sembcorp Marine reported its third consecutive year of pre-tax losses, with a net loss of S$582.5 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2020. ComfortDelGro partnered French energy company Engie to bid for electric vehicle charging tenders and deploy clean energy solutions. ST Engineering's proposed buyout of Cubic Corporation fell through, with Cubic accepting a revised offer from Veritas Capital and Evergreen Coast Capital Corporation.

site_title: Saudi Aramco role in private investment drive guided by business not state, says CEO
summary: Saudi Aramco's CEO, Amin Nasser, stated that the company's role in private investments under the new Shareek initiative is guided by business criteria, not the state. The $1.3 trillion program aims to diversify Saudi Arabia's economy, with Aramco setting strict business criteria for its investments. Nasser emphasized that private companies will seek incentives from the government, and Aramco will determine which projects to partner with. The program is voluntary, and Aramco's dividend and investment plans remain unaffected, with the government promising stable dividends for existing shareholders.

site_title: Korean Air expects to take two years to integrate Asiana purchase
summary: Korean Air Lines Co Ltd expects to integrate its purchase of Asiana Airlines Inc to take two years after the acquisition closes. The airline plans to merge its three low-cost arms into one, aiming to create a top-level low-cost airline in Korea and Asia. Korean Air also expects to integrate large aircraft fleets, phase out Asiana's planes, and manage overlapping roles through attrition and retirements. The airline spent 1.8 trillion won (S$2.1 billion) to become Asiana's top shareholder, marking the biggest shake-up in South Korean air travel since Asiana's founding.

images.alt_text: Above: Dim Sum at Madame Fan.

site_title: China seeks 'democratic transition', but no sanctions on Myanmar
summary: China expressed support for a "democratic transition" in Myanmar, but ruled out imposing sanctions. China's Ambassador Zhang Jun stated that maintaining peace and stability in Myanmar is a common interest for the international community, and that one-sided pressure will only exacerbate the situation. China's stance contrasts with Western powers' calls for further economic measures. Myanmar's military, which overthrew the elected leadership, relies heavily on China as its main ally, and China seeks a peaceful resolution to the crisis.

images.alt_text: The Melbourne Hotel's verandah commands some of the best views of Perth city centre.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% at the opening of trading on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,184.83. The gains came despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, with 99 gainers outnumbering 18 losers. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: AMP hires ANZ's Alexis George as CEO in drive to break with troubled past
summary: AMP, a troubled Australian wealth manager, has appointed Alexis George, deputy chief of Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, as its new CEO, replacing Francesco De Ferrari. The move aims to distance the company from its past corporate culture issues and regulatory criticism. George, a former Credit Suisse banker, will take over in the third quarter, with AMP shares rising 4% after the announcement. The new CEO is seen as a change agent to revitalize the firm's culture, with analysts and investors welcoming the move as a signal of a new direction.

images.alt_text: Embattled Australian wealth manager AMP on Thursday named Australia and New Zealand Banking Group deputy chief Alexis George as its new chief executive officer, saying Francesco De Ferrari would retire from the role.

site_title: Hong Kong bourse proposes changes to encourage more secondary listings
summary: The Hong Kong Stock Exchange proposed changes to its rules to encourage more Chinese companies to carry out secondary listings in the city. The new proposals remove restrictions on Chinese companies with a one-share, one-vote structure and make it easier for them to change to a dual primary listing. The move aims to attract more international and Mainland Chinese companies, with about 13 US-listed Chinese firms having conducted secondary listings worth $36 billion in Hong Kong over the past 16 months.

site_title: ExxonMobil signals first profit in five quarters on price gains
summary: ExxonMobil signals its first profit in five quarters, driven by higher oil and gas prices, which boosted earnings by up to $2.7 billion. The company's refining business remains troubled, but its chemicals operation is expected to see a $600 million boost. ExxonMobil's reported first-quarter earnings could reach $2.34 billion, compared to a year-earlier loss of $610 million. The company's shares gained 12 cents to $55.95 in late trading.

site_title: Opec+ panel cuts oil-demand estimate before meeting
summary: Opec+ technical experts revised down global oil demand estimates for 2021, cutting the forecast from 5.9 million barrels a day to 5.6 million, citing a more cautious view of the market due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The revision mainly affects the next few months, with fuel demand in the US showing strong signs of a rebound but other regions experiencing a resurgence of the virus. Opec+ is expected to maintain its current production policy, defending the current oil price level of around $65 per barrel.

site_title: Citi appoints Kartik Mani as new Asia consumer bank head
summary: Citi appoints Kartik Mani as its new Asia Consumer Bank head, effective immediately. Mani, who joined Citibank in July 2020, will be based in Singapore and report to Anand Selva, CEO of global consumer bank. Mani's appointment follows Gonzalo Luchetti's move to lead Citi's consumer banking unit in the US. Mani brings experience from previous roles at American Express, Standard Chartered, and HSBC, and will oversee Citi's consumer and wealth businesses in Asia-Pacific and EMEA.

images.alt_text: Citi announced in an internal memo on Wednesday that Kartik Mani will be its new head of Asia Consumer Bank effective immediately.

site_title: Virtual AGMs now allowed in most countries
summary: Countries across the globe have largely adopted virtual shareholder meetings, with most markets now allowing listed companies to hold virtual AGMs. China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan still restrict fully virtual meetings, but permit hybrid ones. Markets like Brazil, Canada, and the US have allowed purely virtual AGMs, and online voting is widely permitted, with some markets considering making it mandatory. Experts advocate for online voting to promote shareholder engagement and better corporate governance among younger generations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SGX, Keppel, ST Engineering, ComfortDelGro
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched a consultation on Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to address risks posed by the listing structure. Keppel Corporation has secured a S$360 million separate account mandate from PGGM. ST Engineering's proposed buyout of Cubic Corporation has fallen through, with Cubic accepting a new proposal. ComfortDelGro has partnered with Engi to jointly bid for electric vehicle charging tenders and explore clean energy solutions.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: The Singapore Government has announced the quotation of taxable book-entry bonds. However, the article does not provide specific details on the quotation.

site_title: NBA superstar James joins Liverpool ownership group
summary: NBA superstar LeBron James has increased his ownership stake in Liverpool FC through a deal with Fenway Sports Group, becoming a partner alongside Maverick Carter and Paul Wachter. The investment values the group at $7.35 billion and will help the team recover from the COVID-19 pandemic and fund Anfield expansion plans. James now holds a bigger share in Liverpool and a stake in the Boston Red Sox and other sports ventures, solidifying his position as a major player in the sports world.

site_title: Shareholder engagement a victim of 2020's slew of virtual meetings
summary: Singapore's virtual shareholder meetings in 2020 saw a decline in shareholder engagement, with many meetings lacking live Q&A sessions and electronic voting. A report found that 581 companies held virtual meetings, with 581 opting for webcasts without live Q&A, and only one company, Azeus Systems, allowing live Q&A and electronic voting. The report also noted a 70-80% decline in shareholder attendance and voting in virtual meetings compared to previous years, with 186 retail investors surveyed expressing dissatisfaction with virtual meetings and preferring hybrid or face-to-face meetings.

site_title: Brisbane lifts snap virus lockdown ahead of Easter
summary: Brisbane lifted a 3-day coronavirus lockdown on April 1, 2021, ahead of Easter, ending stay-at-home orders for over 2 million people. The lockdown was implemented after an outbreak in the city, with only 14 cases reported. Masks will remain mandatory, and restrictions on gatherings and dancing will remain in place. The move is seen as a relief for the tourism sector in Queensland, but a major music festival in Byron Bay was cancelled due to a linked positive case.

site_title: Keppel's Alpha secures S$360m separate account mandate from Dutch pension fund manager
summary: Keppel's private fund management arm Alpha Investment Partners secured a S$360 million separate account mandate from PGGM, a Dutch pension fund manager. The Alpha Asia Separate Account will focus on commercial real estate investments in Japan, China, and Singapore. Alpha has executed 190 transactions with a gross acquisition value of over US$26 billion since 2004. The mandate award is not expected to impact Keppel Corporation's earnings per share and net tangible asset per share for the current financial year.

site_title: Volkswagen 'sorry' after April's Fool prank backfires
summary: Volkswagen apologized for a publicity stunt that duped major media outlets, including AFP, by announcing it would rebrand its US subsidiary to "Voltswagen" to highlight its shift to electric cars. The company initially claimed it was a genuine effort, but later revealed it was an April Fool's Day prank. The stunt was criticized as a "breach of trust" and tone-deaf, coming from a company still recovering from the 2015 "dieselgate" scandal. Volkswagen acknowledged the confusion caused and expressed regret for the deception.

site_title: Lagarde says ECB could have digital currency within four years
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde stated that the ECB could launch a digital currency within the next four years, pending approval from the Governing Council in the middle of this year. The decision to proceed with practical experimentation will be made after analyzing 8,000 responses to a public consultation process. The launch of a digital currency will not replace cash, but rather enhance the existing system. Lagarde is also monitoring the recent rollout of the Bahamas' digital currency, the Sand Dollar.

site_title: Xiaomi plans to invest US$10b in electric cars
summary: Xiaomi plans to invest approximately US$10 billion over the next decade in manufacturing electric cars, entering China's booming EV market. The company, led by billionaire co-founder Lei Jun, aims to establish a standalone division and control the car-making business. Xiaomi will invest an initial 10 billion yuan (S$2.05 billion) and may raise the rest of the funds, with the goal of contributing 60% of the envisioned sum. The company will outsource car assembly to contract manufacturers, and its entry into the market is seen as a significant move by tech giants and carmakers alike, with potential risks and costs involved.

site_title: Jurong Innovation District to bring jobs and innovation: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Jurong Innovation District (JID) is expected to create 4,500 jobs over the next 18 months, with 1,200 new and 3,300 existing workers relocating to the area. The 600-hectare district, developed by JTC Corporation, will establish companies such as Siemens and Hyundai Motor Group, and nurture partnerships with institutes of higher learning. The district is projected to create over 95,000 new jobs when fully developed. A new technical reference, TR 87: 2021, has been launched to equip local additive manufacturing companies with industry best practices, addressing safety considerations for workers handling hazardous materials.

site_title: Coronavirus pandemic to shave 3% off global output in medium term: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) predicts that global economic output will be 3% lower in 2024 compared to pre-pandemic projections, due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The medium-term impact will be less severe than the 2008 global financial crisis, but emerging economies and low-income countries are expected to bear deeper scars. The IMF warns of persistent losses in tourism-dependent and high-contact sectors, potentially shrinking permanently, and negatively affecting labor markets and productivity.

site_title: Low rates fuel biggest surge in US home prices since February 2006
summary: US home prices surged 11.2% in January, the largest jump since February 2006, driven by historically low mortgage rates. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller index surpassed the median estimate of 10.5% growth. Low borrowing costs fueled a frenzied market, with bidding wars and a record annual drop in available properties. Mortgage rates rose to 3.17% after falling to a record low in January, and home prices gained 1% in January, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The surge in home prices is expected to ease as inflation concerns rise.

site_title: Cathie Wood's ARK funds still in favour despite poor Q1 performance
summary: Cathie Wood's ARK Invest funds, led by celebrity manager Cathie Wood, have attracted significant retail investor inflows despite poor Q1 performance, with the flagship ARK Innovation fund down 10.7% through March 29. Wood's bullish outlook remains intact, with analysts predicting that technology and growth stocks in her portfolio will perform well despite rising inflation concerns. Despite short-term hiccups, Wood's adherence to her investment approach is seen as a strength, with some analysts stating she has been "dead right" in her predictions over the past three to four years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 35.68 points to 1,573.51 on Wednesday, closing lower. The index saw 8.493 billion lots traded worth RM4.226 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 858 to 304.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets open flat
summary: European stock markets opened flat on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index remaining unchanged at 6,771.88 points. Investors maintained caution due to concerns over inflation and higher interest rates. The Frankfurt DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also remained flat, with Deliveroo shares plummeting 15% in early deals despite a set price at the bottom of its target range.

site_title: X-ray scans, body checks at selected MRT stations from April 1
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) will introduce enhanced security screening at selected MRT stations starting April 1, similar to airport checks. The screening includes metal detector scans and x-ray scans, conducted at random. The rollout follows a six-month trial that ended in 2019, and is part of the Threat-Oriented Person Screening Integrated System (Topsis) programme. The equipment will be rotated periodically across MRT stations, working in conjunction with the Topsis threat assessment programme that trains over 30,000 public transport personnel to detect suspicious items and activities.

site_title: FWD Singapore offers complimentary insurance to cover Covid-19 vaccine complications
summary: FWD Singapore has launched a complimentary insurance benefit to cover Covid-19 vaccine complications. The benefit provides a one-time lump sum payout of S$5,000 for eligible customers who experience hospitalization due to complications or side effects from vaccination. This is part of a growing trend of insurers offering similar initiatives to provide peace of mind to customers.

site_title: Pandemic-fuelled demand drives EC prices to record high
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) market has seen a record high in demand, driven by millennials and first-time buyers seeking cheaper, bigger homes. Sales of ECs surged 70.5% in 2020, with resale ECs hitting a record 1,239 units sold, surpassing the 10-year average of 589 units. New EC prices have also reached a record high, with a median price of S$1,172 per square foot in January 2021. The low supply of new ECs is expected to continue to prop up prices, with three more EC projects planned for launch in the next two years, potentially leading to a price surge.

site_title: Asean+3 to rebound strongly, but recovery outlook hazy, says AMRO
summary: The Asean+3 region is expected to rebound strongly this year, with growth forecast to reach 6.7% in 2021, but the recovery outlook remains hazy due to the ongoing pandemic's long-lasting consequences. The pace of vaccine roll-out, external demand, and economic scarring caused by Covid-19 will be key factors in determining the recovery trajectory. Risks to growth are tilted to the downside, with potential risks including rising financial distress, climate change, and geopolitical risks. Policy-makers are advised to err on the side of being accommodative in the coming year to avoid triggering any cliff effect to growth and financial stability.

site_title: Residential hotspots: Districts shaping up to be interesting investment bets
summary: The Singapore residential market remains strong despite the COVID-19 pandemic, driven by positive sentiment, abundant liquidity, and low interest rates. The Master Plan 2019 highlights sustainable, green precincts and community-centric developments, offering opportunities for investors across various budgets. Policymakers have expressed concern over the disconnect between the property market's strength and the economy's health, emphasizing the need for a prudent investment strategy.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries to focus on  renewables, sustainable urban solutions businesses
summary: Sembcorp Industries is shifting its focus to renewable energy and sustainable urban solutions, driven by growing demand in Asia. The company's renewables business generated S$806 million in revenue last year, while its urban business segment recorded a net profit of S$92 million in 2020. Sembcorp aims to be a regional front-runner in renewable energy and sustainable urbanization, leveraging synergies across its businesses to meet the twin goals of clean energy and sustainable urbanization in Asia.

site_title: StanChart donates S$1m to Digital for Life movement; Keppel gives $300,000
summary: Standard Chartered Bank (StanChart) and Keppel Corporation have donated S$1 million and S$300,000 respectively to the Digital for Life movement, a national initiative supporting community projects to equip Singaporeans with digital skills. The government has matched the donations, bringing the total funding to S$7.6 million. The donations will support youths in the digital economy and senior citizens in achieving digital literacy, with Keppel's donation providing subsidized smartphones and mobile plans for over 2,000 seniors.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally after Biden's new roads and bridges plan
summary: US President Joe Biden unveiled a $2 trillion infrastructure plan, which Asian investors welcomed, driving regional markets higher. Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai led gains, with optimism boosted by a healthy US private jobs report and a positive survey on Japan's manufacturers. Analysts believe the plan's focus on infrastructure investment and job creation will outweigh concerns about higher taxes. Global markets have been recovering from government rescue packages and central bank support, with stocks expected to continue rising despite inflation concerns.

site_title: Are rising HDB prices the new normal?
summary: Singapore's public housing market, dominated by Housing and Development Board (HDB) flats, remains resilient despite the country's economic recession in 2020. The HDB resale price index increased 5% year-over-year, while the number of resale transactions rose 4.4%. This was the second consecutive year the HDB resale market weathered an economic downturn, with only two previous instances in the past 30 years. The demand for public housing is unlikely to evaporate, driven by its affordability and government regulations that treat HDB flats as a home rather than a trading asset.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up for fourth straight month
summary: Singapore's bank lending grew for the fourth consecutive month in February, driven by increases in housing and construction loans, as well as business lending. Loans to businesses rose 0.5% to S$424.76 billion, while housing loans grew 0.3% to S$202.66 billion. Consumer loans also edged up 0.4% to S$261.97 billion. However, overall bank lending slipped 0.9% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: Loans to the single-largest business lending segment, building and construction, climbed 1.2 per cent to S$152.15 billion in February.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Compass raises US$450m in downsized IPO
summary: Compass Inc, a US real estate technology firm backed by SoftBank Group, raised US$450 million in a downsized initial public offering (IPO) at US$18 per share. The IPO, which is at the lower end of its target range, values the company at US$9 billion. This is a sign of investor fatigue for new stocks, with US IPOs raising over US$36 billion this quarter. Compass, founded in 2012, works with over 19,000 agents and has raised US$1.5 billion from investors. Shares are set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "COMP".

site_title: Q1 home price data could offer view into prospect of cooling moves
summary: Singapore's Q1 2021 private home price index flash estimate is expected to reveal a substantial and sustained uptick in private residential prices, potentially strengthening the case for cooling measures. A 2.1% gain in Q4 2020 and projections of a higher increase in Q1 2021 may prompt the government to roll out additional measures. However, the government is also considering other factors, such as economic recovery and regional price increases, before making a decision.

site_title: Househunt April 2021
summary:

Key real estate news includes a report on Good Class Bungalow prices, with developers getting "real" about pricing. US mortgage rates have climbed after five straight weeks of declines. In other news, Goldman Sachs acquired a hotel and retail asset in Seoul, UK homebuyer demand rebounded to a six-month high, and New World is selling China property assets after a loan deal. WeWork secured new tenants at its Singapore location.

site_title: Here we go again: The myth of the China-Iran Axis
summary: US neoconservative media outlets are warning of a potential "China-Iran Axis" after Beijing and Tehran signed a 25-year strategic partnership, including Chinese investment in Iranian projects and oil supply. This development is seen as a threat to the US's international position, contradicting the initial strategy of using control of the Middle East's oil resources as leverage in dealings with China. This shift reflects the evolving global landscape and the growing rivalry between the US and China.

site_title: Credit Suisse outlook cut to negative by S&P as bonds tumble
summary: Credit Suisse Group's outlook has been downgraded to negative by S&P Global Ratings due to the fallout from the Archegos Capital Management crisis. The Swiss bank is potentially facing billions of dollars in losses, with total losses estimated at $5-10 billion among numerous lenders. This is the latest in a series of write-downs and scandals for CEO Thomas Gottstein, who is also gauging the financial impact of the Greensill Capital collapse. Credit Suisse shares fell 2% and bonds tumbled, with the cost to protect debt against default reaching its highest since mid-2020.

site_title: Olam secures US$1.45b loan linked to its supply chain platform
summary: Olam International has secured a US$1.45 billion loan linked to its AtSource agricultural supply chain platform. The facility, co-borrowed by Olam Treasury Pte Ltd, consists of a US$950 million revolving credit facility and a US$500 million term loan facility. The loan is used to procure agricultural raw materials under AtSource, a sustainability insights platform. The facility was participated by 18 lenders, including DBS, Standard Chartered Bank, and HSBC, which are joint AtSource programme co-ordinators.

site_title: The future of the CBD
summary: The article discusses the future of the CBD (Central Business District) in Singapore. A Q3 wave of condo launches will test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark, potentially affecting prices and market stability. Manhattan rents have reached a record high, and UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. In other news, US mortgage rates have climbed after five weeks of declines, and WeWork has secured new tenants at its Singapore location. These trends indicate a volatile real estate market with fluctuating prices and demand.

site_title: Good Class Bungalows - tracking the wealth of a nation
summary: Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore have seen stellar performance over the years, with prices rising at a compounded average growth rate of 7.5% per annum from 2001 to 2021. This outperforms landed and non-landed properties, with GCB land prices rising significantly more. The limited supply and nature of GCBs prioritize price appreciation over yield, making them comparable to fine art and antiquities. GCBs are mainly owned by ultra-high-net-worth individuals and Singaporeans, with strong holding power and low rental yields, making them a hedge against inflation and a reflection of the nation's wealth and entrepreneurial vitality.

site_title: UOB CEO's pay falls 8.8% to S$9.8m in 2020
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong's total salary dropped 8.8% to S$9.805 million in 2020, with base salary remaining unchanged at S$1.2 million. The majority of his variable pay, 60%, was deferred and will vest over three years. The bank's annual report highlighted its commitment to deepening its Asean franchise, enhancing digital capabilities, and investing in people's capabilities. UOB shares closed at S$25.83, down 0.39% on the day.

site_title: Green buildings facing frothy valuations: panel
summary: Valuations of green assets are expected to become frothy in the short run, with prices pushed up by investment flows chasing environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) assets. However, experts argue that these higher price tags are unjustified, as rents and operating expenditures for green buildings have not increased significantly. If the trend continues, property owners may end up with "climate-change stranded assets" or "brown" buildings that no longer satisfy sustainability requirements, potentially leading to lower returns and reduced property value.

site_title: Offer to delist International Press Softcom closes with 96.99% valid acceptances
summary: International Press Softcom's voluntary conditional offer has closed with 96.99% valid acceptances, representing 86.75% stake by family members, paving the way for its intended delisting. The offer price was 4.5 Singapore cents per share. With less than 10% of shares now held by the public, IP Softcom has lost its free float. The shares closed unchanged at 4.4 Singapore cents on Wednesday.

site_title: Microsoft wins US$22b US army contract for augmented reality gear
summary: Microsoft has won a US$21.88 billion contract with the US military for augmented reality headgear, known as the Integrated Augmentation System, over the next decade. The system, based on commercially available HoloLens, aims to deliver next-generation night vision and situational awareness capabilities to soldiers. The five-year production agreement has a renewal option, potentially making the contract worth over US$21.88 billion. The system will provide enhanced situational awareness, enabling information sharing and decision-making in various scenarios.

site_title: ST Engineering buyout bid fails as Cubic opts for rival proposal
summary: ST Engineering's proposed buyout of Cubic Corporation has fallen through as Cubic accepted a revised proposal from Veritas Capital and Evergreen Coast Capital Corporation. The all-cash transaction is valued at US$3 billion, including debt assumption. Cubic's board deemed the Veritas and Evergreen offer superior, citing certainty and timing of closing. ST Engineering shares dropped 0.26% on the news, while Cubic's shares rose 6.4% on the acceptance.

site_title: Mastercard to share US$44m fine over UK welfare funds
summary: Mastercard, allpay, and PFS have agreed to pay a total of over US$44 million in fines for allegedly participating in a "cartel" exploiting pre-paid cards used for welfare funds. The UK's Payment Systems Regulator found the companies engaged in anti-competitive behavior by agreeing not to compete or poach clients. The firms have accepted the provisional findings and will only face fines if confirmed. The regulator's investigation began in 2017, and the companies have implemented training to prevent similar behavior. Settlements have also been reached with two other firms, APS and Sulion.

site_title: Australia: Shares wrap up holiday-shortened week on firm note
summary: Australian shares ended the holiday-shortened week on a firm note, closing up 0.6% at 6,828.70. The gains were driven by gold and technology stocks. The market reacted positively to the end of a Brisbane lockdown ahead of Easter holidays, with only one new locally transmitted Covid-19 case easing fears of a widespread outbreak.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, marking a significant success. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo by former US President Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss issues in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore's stock market rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Analysts flag higher odds of cooling measures as Singapore private home prices rise for fourth straight quarter
summary: Singapore private home prices rose 2.9% in Q1, marking the fourth consecutive quarter of growth, with non-landed homes increasing 2.1% and landed properties rising 5.6%. Analysts flag higher odds of cooling measures, citing a stronger price surge and potential GDP growth exceeding 4-6%. Experts predict the "sweet spot" of affordable units below S$2 million, but warn of the possibility of ABSD and TDSR tightening, which could impact first-time buyers and investors.

site_title: The US president has a chance to supercharge the economy
summary: US President Joe Biden has a chance to boost the economy by delivering policies that enable all Americans to reach their full potential. Following the 2020 presidential election, Biden's administration has yet to alleviate concerns about the threat to democracy posed by the Trump-era GOP. Meanwhile, global economic trends, including companies' struggles with layoffs, are being discussed in various articles, with topics including AI talent wars, US foreign policy, and Singaporean business news.

site_title: Singapore industrial market: A pandemic winner
summary: Singapore's industrial market is expected to remain strong in 2021, driven by global economic recovery, interest in logistics and manufacturing industries, and e-commerce growth. The US$1.9 trillion stimulus package could boost demand for Singapore's industrial space, particularly in prime logistics properties and food factories. With average prime logistics occupancy rates over 90%, areas like Jalan Buroh/West Coast and MacPherson/Tai Seng/Ubi/Kaki Bukit are poised for growth. The demand for sustainable industrial buildings and data centers is also expected to rise, driven by environmental concerns and business digital transformation.

images.alt_text: With average prime logistics occupancy rates of over 90 per cent, the Jalan Buroh/West Coast logistics cluster is well sought-after by industrialists and logistics players. One major upcoming warehouse in this area is the LOGOS eCommerce Hub at 4 Pandan Crescent.

site_title: Google Maps to show more eco-friendly routes
summary: Google Maps will start showing users more eco-friendly routes, using artificial intelligence to minimize fuel consumption and reduce carbon footprint. The service will default to the route with the lowest carbon impact when it has a similar estimated arrival time to the fastest route. Alerts will also be sent when a route is heading for a low-emission zone. Additionally, Google Maps will provide users with more comprehensive views of travel options and add air quality information to some routes. The features will launch in various countries, including the US, Australia, India, and Europe, starting in June.

site_title: Tencent-backed Linklogis to raise US$1.02b in HK IPO
summary: Tencent-backed Linklogis is set to raise up to US$1.02 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, priced at HK$17.58 each. The firm, specializing in supply chain finance technology, sold 452.87 million shares. The deal, which was several times oversubscribed, will see Linklogis shares trade on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on April 9. The IPO follows a trend of successful Asian IPOs, with US$37.6 billion worth of deals in the first quarter of 2021.

site_title: Foreign worker levies for S Pass, work permit holders to be waived for SHN period
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) has waived foreign worker levies for S Pass and work permit holders, including migrant domestic workers, from January to September due to increased costs associated with the government's Covid-19 measures. Employers will no longer be required to pay the monthly levy for workers during the stay-home notice (SHN) period. This change aims to help employers manage costs, but the impact on the labour crunch faced by companies remains uncertain.

site_title: STI falls 0.8% alongside losses by regional peers
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% to 3,165.34, snapping a six-day winning streak. Despite this, it capped a strong first quarter, with an 11.3% gain year-to-date, making it the second-best performer among major global benchmarks. The index's performance was influenced by regional peers, which also fell due to quarter-end rebalancing flows, despite China's strong factory data and the US President's infrastructure plan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat with Deliveroo tumbling in debut
summary: European stocks remained flat on Wednesday, with the Stoxx 600 index down 0.1% at 430.1, as a 30% slump in Deliveroo's London debut overshadowed a fourth consecutive quarterly rise. Continental peers Just Eat Takeaway and Delivery Hero fell 1.5% and 1.0%, respectively. Other losers included H&M and Credit Suisse, while Capgemini rose 0.1% after raising margin targets.

site_title: Property fund with no property stokes anger at Commerzbank
summary: Commerzbank is facing a dispute over the management of its CS Euroreal fund, which has no properties but is holding back hundreds of millions of euros. The fund's provisions, set aside for potential losses, are deemed excessive by investors, who are seeking the return of 350 million euros. The fund's assets have dwindled to a negative yield of about 800 million euros, and investors claim the bank is continuing to charge fees for managing the remaining funds. This dispute is the latest issue for Commerzbank, which is undergoing a boardroom overhaul amid restructuring costs and elevated provisions for bad loans.

site_title: Evergrande unveils plans to halve debt after profit falls
summary: China Evergrande Group plans to halve its debt to 350 billion yuan or less by June 2023, after reporting its second consecutive drop in annual profit. The company's total debt decreased 14% from 717 billion yuan in December to 674 billion yuan in March. Evergrande aims to meet two of the "three red lines" financial metrics by the end of 2022 and achieve all three by the end of 2022, following a policy environment change in China. The move comes after the company's cash crunch in September and extensive sales promotions for its property projects.

site_title: Hitachi buys US software firm GlobalLogic for US$9.6b
summary: Hitachi acquired US software firm GlobalLogic for $9.6 billion, with $8.5 billion upfront and the repayment of GlobalLogic's debt. The deal aims to expand Hitachi's digital services offerings, particularly through its Internet of Things unit Lumada. GlobalLogic's 20,000 employees and client base will enhance Lumada's capabilities. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to capitalize on the growing demand for digital transformation and data-driven business models.

site_title: Hot stock: SPH up as much as 8% in morning trade as investors price in review
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) shares rose 8% in morning trade, reaching an intra-day high of S$1.62, before closing at S$1.53 with a 2% gain. The stock's early surge was attributed to investor pricing in a review. No married deals were recorded, and 57.6 million shares worth over S$90 million changed hands.

site_title: US private hiring surges in March: survey
summary: US private firms hired at the fastest pace since September, with 517,000 new jobs in March, according to a survey by ADP. This marks a welcome rebound after several tepid results in the pandemic recovery. The majority of jobs were in the services sector, with a surge of 169,000 in leisure and hospitality. The data slightly exceeded economists' expectations and provided a boost to the US economy after a slow February.

site_title: Huawei's quarterly sales down for first time after US sanctions
summary: Huawei's quarterly sales dropped for the first time on record, falling 11% to 220.1 billion yuan (S$45.2 billion) in the final quarter of 2020, due to the impact of US sanctions. Despite this, the company's full-year sales and profit rose 3.8% and 3.2%, respectively. Huawei is shifting focus towards new growth areas such as smart agriculture, healthcare, and electric cars, and plans to charge mobile giants a "reasonable" fee for access to its 5G patents.

site_title: China mulls tax overhaul for steel in push to meet green goals
summary: China is considering tax overhaul measures for its steel industry to meet green goals, aiming to reduce carbon emissions and curb the industry's impact. The proposed changes, including lowering export rebates and cutting import duties, would encourage imports and reduce exports, potentially altering global steel trade. The move is part of China's efforts to clean up its dirty industry, with the country pledging to cut steel production this year to reduce emissions and aiming for a carbon-neutral economy by 2060.

site_title: 120 SMEs receive S$8,000 cash grant each from Salesforce, SBF
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) and Salesforce launched the Salesforce Small Business Relief Grants Programme, providing S$8,000 cash grants to 120 small businesses. The grants aim to support SMEs' immediate cash flow needs, preserve jobs, and promote growth during the pandemic. Recipients were selected based on financial standing, hardship, survivability, and resilience. The grants will help alleviate operational costs and position businesses for recovery and growth post-Covid, according to SBF CEO Lam Yi Young.

site_title: Electricity tariff to rise an average of 8.7% in Q2, but still below year-ago rate
summary: Singapore's electricity tariff will increase by an average of 8.7% in Q2, affecting households from April 1 to June 30. The increase is mainly due to higher fuel costs, with the tariff rising from 20.76 to 22.55 cents per kWh. This remains lower than the Q2 2021 rate and Q1 2021, and only applies to 51% of household accounts. Consumers can consider fixed price plans for greater certainty.

site_title: Facebook Singapore launches digital upskilling initiative for developing tech skills
summary: Facebook Singapore has launched a digital upskilling initiative, "Upskill with Facebook Singapore", to support the country's journey towards a smart nation. The program aims to upskill 2,700 participants and 1,000 small and medium enterprises (SMEs) with four programs: Facebook Social Media Marketing Professional Certificate, Rise, Facebook Blueprint Higher Education, and Boost. The programs, launched in partnership with various industry partners, will run in staggered phases starting from March 2021 and focus on developing tech skills for emerging industries.

site_title: Best practices guide launched to help Singapore firms in additive manufacturing
summary: Singapore has launched a new technical reference guide, TR 87: 2021, to equip local additive manufacturing companies with industry best practices. The guide covers key safety considerations, including material storage, equipment requirements, workplace operations, and hazardous waste management. Developed by a working group, the guide aims to create confidence among local enterprises and help them seize opportunities in the growing sector. The government will provide assistance to smaller companies and work with agencies to encourage industry adoption, with the goal of eventually sharing the guidelines internationally.

site_title: Australia: Shares end the day higher
summary: Australian shares ended the day higher, closing 0.8% higher at 6,790.70, their best month since November. The gain was driven by strong factory data from China and investor adjustments for month-end "window dressing". The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.76% on a monthly basis, ending the first quarter 3.1% higher. Australian mining stocks, particularly BHP Group and Rio Tinto, climbed 0.3% and 1% respectively.

site_title: Two Capitol Police officers sue Trump over January riot
summary: Two Capitol Police officers, James Blassingame and Sidney Hemby, sued former President Donald Trump over the January 6 riot at the US Capitol, alleging he was responsible for their physical and emotional injuries. The officers, both 11- and 17-year veterans, claimed Trump's speech and actions "inflamed, encouraged, incited, directed, and aided and abetted" the mob that stormed the building. The lawsuit seeks compensatory and punitive damages exceeding $75,000 each. The officers suffered injuries including head and back trauma, burns, and emotional distress.

site_title: H&M swings to loss in Q1, pledges to rebuild trust in China after backlash
summary: H&M reported a quarterly loss of 1.39 billion crowns ($83.9 million) in its first quarter due to a pre-tax loss. The company is working to regain trust in China after backlash over comments on the Xinjiang region. Despite this, sales in March were up 55% measured in local currencies. H&M will not propose a dividend at its annual general meeting but expects good prospects for one in the second half of the year. The company is committed to rebuilding trust with customers, partners, and stakeholders in China through joint efforts.

site_title: US: Stocks rise ahead of Biden infrastructure roll-out
summary: US stocks rose ahead of President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan, with the Dow Jones up 0.1%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.3%. Private US employment jumped 517,000 in March, exceeding expectations. The $2 trillion infrastructure plan, due to be released later in the day, includes $620 billion in transport spending and a hike in corporate tax rates to finance it.

site_title: Deliveroo shares plunge 30% in London debut
summary: Deliveroo shares plummeted 30% on their London debut, falling to 390 pence, after major UK fund managers pulled out due to concerns over its dual class share structure and gig economy business model. The listing, valued at £7.6 billion, is London's biggest IPO since 2011 and tech float on the London Stock Exchange. The poor performance may hurt the UK's bid to attract tech companies and is a blow to finance minister Rishi Sunak's efforts. Deliveroo's self-employed drivers saw a boom in demand during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Church of England head denies Meghan had a secret royal wedding
summary: Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby contradicted Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, stating that Prince Harry and Meghan's marriage occurred on the same day as the official Windsor Castle ceremony in 2018, not three days prior. Welby personally signed the marriage certificate, saying he would have committed a crime if he signed a false document. Meghan claimed a secret ceremony with Welby took place in their backyard, but this claim was disputed. British media found a copy of the wedding certificate showing the official marriage occurred at Windsor Castle, contradicting Meghan's statement.

site_title: SGX launches consultation on SPACs, with proposals to minimise dilution and better align interest
summary: SGX launches a consultation on Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to minimize dilution and better align interest. The proposed framework includes a minimum market capitalization of S$300 million, a three-year timeframe to de-SPAC, and at least 90% of IPO proceeds in escrow. The exchange aims to safeguard investors' interests while meeting capital-raising needs. Key proposals include limiting capital redemption rights, requiring independent shareholders to vote on business combinations, and implementing prospectus-level disclosures. The consultation will run until April 28, with SGX seeking feedback on the proposed framework.

site_title: 22-year-old student is sole Covid-19 community case in Singapore
summary: A 22-year-old permanent resident studying in the UK was the sole community Covid-19 case in Singapore, announced by the Ministry of Health on March 31, 2021. He is asymptomatic, with a high Ct value indicating a low viral load, and a positive serology test suggesting a past infection. Another test was negative, suggesting he may be shedding non-infectious virus fragments. The student had previously returned to Singapore from the UK and served a stay-home notice and self-isolation.

site_title: US pending home sales fall most since April on low inventory
summary: US pending home sales fell 10.6% in February, the largest decline since April, due to rising home prices and low inventory. The median estimate was 3% lower. Severe winter weather and record-low inventory also contributed to the decline. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rate is increasing, which may affect buyer demand. Lawrence Yun, chief economist, stated that widespread demand for home purchases is present, but low inventory is hindering contract signings.

site_title: DBS launches US$625m project financing Indonesia's first high-pressure acid leach smelter
summary: DBS has led a consortium of nine banks in launching a US$625 million project financing structure for Indonesia's first high-pressure acid leach (HPAL) smelter, PT Halmahera Persada Lygend (PT HPAL). The project supports Indonesia's ambitions for the EV and manufacturing industry, utilizing HPAL technology to manufacture key raw materials for electric battery manufacturing. DBS has committed to financing S$50 billion in renewable, clean energy and green projects by 2024, with PT HPAL playing a significant role in advancing the country's EV supply chain.

site_title: Citi files winding-up petition against Sanjeev Gupta's commodity trader
summary: Citi, acting on behalf of Credit Suisse, has filed a winding-up petition against Liberty Commodities, a key commodities-trading unit of Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance. This move comes after the collapse of Greensill Capital, Gupta's biggest lender, and as Gupta's empire struggles to secure new financing. Gupta's company is in discussions with Grant Thornton to negotiate a solution, but faces the threat of insolvency. Liberty Commodities had revenue of $4.2 billion in 2020 and is one of Gupta's main trading businesses.

site_title: Seoul: Shares slip as US bond yields offset vaccine optimism
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Wednesday, slipping 8.58 points or 0.3% to 3,061.42, as rising US Treasury yields outweighed optimism over vaccine- and stimulus-led recovery. Despite a 1.6% monthly gain, chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix fell 1% and 1.5%, respectively. China's manufacturing activity expanded, but US Treasury yields rose to 1.746%, dented by a 83-basis-point increase just this quarter.

site_title: America has a ruling class though members deny it
summary: The US political elite, despite denying it, has a ruling class. This phenomenon is evident in politicians, business figures, and intellectuals who present themselves as outsiders while holding powerful positions. Strategic and generational factors contribute to this phenomenon, including a desire to distance oneself from consequences and a cultural aversion to accepting responsibility. To reconcile this performance of disruption with the demands of responsibility, Americans should stop confusing consumer preferences with power, learn from historical figures who embodied an "ethic of responsibility," and be honest about the reality of the ruling class.

site_title: Shopee to help SMEs upskill via SkillsFuture Queen Bee programme
summary: Shopee has partnered with SkillsFuture Singapore to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in upskilling their operations and expanding into e-commerce through the SkillsFuture Queen Bee programme. The partnership aims to provide training and resources to 30 SME sellers, creating a skills support ecosystem to equip them with capabilities to excel in e-commerce. Shopee will also provide an online portal with resources and courses, and select high-performing sellers to lead their communities in sharing best practices and knowledge.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on China data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking falls on Wall Street due to rising bond yields and inflation concerns. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.81% and the Topix index slipped 0.91%. Investors also focused on Chinese data set to be released later in the day.

site_title: MUFG securities unit to book US$270m loss on Archegos
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's securities arm will book a $270 million loss after closing positions with Archegos Capital Management, a US client involved in a massive leveraged bet unwind. The loss is linked to Archegos' $20 billion in liquidated positions, affecting global banks. The move could negatively impact MUFG's European operations, with pre-tax profits in the region estimated at $154 million for the last three quarters. The bank's full-year earnings will be announced on May 17, and shares closed down 3.9% on the day.

site_title: Biden says corporate tax hike will pay for US infrastructure plan
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a plan to increase the corporate tax rate from 21% to 28% to fund his $2 trillion infrastructure plan, citing the need to address the imbalance between corporate and individual taxes. The proposal aims to crack down on tax havens and raise the global minimum tax. While business groups have expressed opposition, economists argue that the plan is a necessary compromise to finance the investment and boost competitiveness. The plan is expected to raise over $2 trillion over 15 years, creating millions of jobs and improving the nation's infrastructure.

images.alt_text: The deluxe suites are currently one of three accommodation types available at Bawah Reserve.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US losses, Biden spending plan in focus
summary: Asian markets slipped on Wednesday, following a soft lead from Wall Street, amid concerns about inflation and interest rates. US President Joe Biden is set to unveil a multi-trillion-dollar recovery plan, which could lead to higher borrowing costs and inflation. China's factory activity data showed a stronger-than-expected growth, reinforcing the view of a recovering Asian powerhouse. Markets are also gearing for the release of US jobs data, which will provide a guide to the state of the economy.

site_title: Virtual AGMs hurt shareholder engagement, says report
summary: A report on shareholder meetings in Singapore found that virtual AGMs in 2020 led to decreased shareholder engagement, with many companies failing to provide live Q&A sessions and electronic voting options. Only one company, Azeus Systems, offered both. The report, authored by Mak Yuen Teen, attributed the decline to companies' lack of preparation for virtual meetings and regulators' failure to promote technology adoption. As a result, many meetings were short, with some lasting less than 10 minutes, and shareholder attendance and voting declined substantially.

site_title: Google to contribute US$25m to new EU fund to fight fake news
summary: Google will contribute $25 million to the European Media and Information Fund, a new EU initiative to combat fake news. The fund, launched by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation and the European University Institute, aims to enlist researchers and fact-checkers to help tackle online disinformation. The contribution comes amid criticism that tech giants, including Google, are not doing enough to debunk fake news. The fund has a five-year duration and will be evaluated by the European Digital Media Observatory.

site_title: Pressure for hedge fund scrutiny as Yellen leads her first US financial stability meeting
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is facing pressure from Democrats to revive tougher scrutiny of hedge funds, following the Archegos Capital Management meltdown, which inflicted losses on multiple intermediaries. The Financial Stability Oversight Council will discuss hedge fund activity and the performance of open-end mutual funds during the pandemic. The council will also hold a public session on financial system risks from climate change. Concerns rise that trillions of dollars in government aid will fuel more market risk-taking, prompting calls to revive the Treasury working group on hedge fund leverage.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 6.32 points lower, or 0.39%, to 1,602.87 on Wednesday. The market saw 429.95 million lots traded worth RM133.25 million, with losers beating gainers 188-170.

site_title: Endowus raises S$23m in Series A funding from venture capitalists
summary: Endowus, a Singapore-based digital wealth platform, has secured S$23 million in Series A funding from venture capitalists Lightspeed Venture Partners and Softbank Ventures Asia. This marks the firm's first external funding, following 100% employee ownership. Endowus plans to expand in Asia, starting with Hong Kong, with plans to hit S$1 billion in assets under advice by the second quarter in Singapore.
