The firm aims to lower investing costs for individuals with no sales charges or trail fees, and has seen "stellar" growth despite the challenges posed by Covid-19.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB lowers target price for AirAsia on deeper forecast loss
summary: CGS-CIMB lowered its target price for AirAsia to RM0.05, maintaining a "reduce" call, due to a forecasted double net loss for FY2021. The brokerage expects Q1 FY2021 core net loss to be "as bad or worse" than Q4 FY2020's RM1.1 billion loss. AirAsia faces forex translation losses and deferred aircraft leases, with the company raising RM2 billion in new equity and debt capital this year. The forecast book value per share is 0.5 sen for FY2021.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up on Wednesday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,199.09 points on Wednesday, driven by gains from Singapore Press Holdings and Singtel. The local banks, UOB and OCBC, were mixed, while DBS edged down. In contrast, European shares advanced and Tokyo stocks opened lower, tracking Wall Street's decline.

site_title: MAS to grant US$20.6m to IMF's Covid-19 support initiatives for vulnerable countries
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced it will grant nearly US$20.6 million to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for Covid-19 support initiatives in vulnerable countries. The funds will support three initiatives: the Catastrophe Containment and Relief Trust, the Covid-19 Crisis Capacity Development Initiative, and the Trust for Special Poverty Reduction and Growth Operations. The grants are subject to Parliament's approval on April 5, and will help strengthen healthcare systems in low-income countries.

site_title: Inflation not yet a worry in Asia, except for India and the Philippines: report
summary: Moody's Analytics reports that inflation is not yet a major concern in most Asian economies, except for India and the Philippines, where inflation is above comfort levels. Demand-side pressures are expected to remain subdued in the second half of 2021, but India and the Philippines face challenges due to elevated inflation, a large output gap, and limited vaccine availability. The Philippines' central bank is expected to keep monetary settings accommodative, while the Reserve Bank of India may not offer further rate cuts due to higher fuel prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) Regulation has launched a consultation on Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to minimize dilution and align interests. The framework aims to address the risks associated with excessive dilution for long-term investors and the rush for sponsors to de-SPAC. The consultation seeks feedback from stakeholders to refine the proposals and ensure a balanced approach. The move is part of SGX's efforts to promote a fair and efficient market.

images.alt_text: SGX Regulation (SGX RegCo) is seeking feedback on a framework that would attempt to reduce some of the risks of excessive dilution for long-term investors, as well as the rush for sponsors to de-SPAC.

site_title: URA, BCA announce new appointments to boards, effective Thursday
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the Building Construction Authority (BCA) announced new appointments to their boards, effective April 1. URA's board now has 12 members, including chairman Peter Ho Hak Ean, while BCA's board will be led by new chairman Lim Sim Seng and deputy chairman Professor Tan Thian Soon. The appointments are for a two-year term until March 31, 2023.

site_title: ComfortDelGro partners French energy firm Engie to bid for EV charging tenders
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore transport operator, has partnered French energy firm Engie to jointly bid for EV charging tenders and deploy clean energy solutions. They submitted a bid for over 600 EV charging points at public car parks, with successful tenderers required to install charging stations by 2022. The companies also plan to build charging farms powered by renewable energy on ComfortDelGro premises, offering fast-charging solutions. This partnership aims to drive the adoption of clean energy solutions in the transport industry, aligning with ComfortDelGro's commitment to sustainability and clean energy technology.

images.alt_text: Through JV company ComfortDelGro Engie Solar, both sides intend to electrify ComfortDelGro's fleet of vehicles with renewable power and offer fast charging solutions to drivers and public electric vehicle (EV) users through renewable energy assets.

site_title: US dollar hits new one-year high to yen on American pandemic recovery optimism
summary: The US dollar reached a fresh one-year high against the yen, trading near multi-month peaks, as investors bet on a strong US economic recovery driven by massive fiscal stimulus and aggressive vaccinations. The dollar index held above 93, and the dollar set a new one-year high of 110.48 yen. The greenback's strength is also supported by rising US bond yields and optimism about the US economy's growth outlook. Investors will closely watch monthly US nonfarm payrolls data on Friday for further direction.

site_title: SPAC listings slow to a crawl with bankers buried in paperwork
summary: A slowdown in the special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) market is causing anxiety, with over 300 SPACs launched this quarter, raising $100 billion, but four deals postponed and half trading below offering prices. Bankers, lawyers, and auditors are struggling to keep pace with the surge, with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) facing a growing pile of incomplete paperwork. Regulatory scrutiny and tougher feedback on deals are also sending a chill through the market, with liability insurance rates for SPACs skyrocketing to over $1 million.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the start of trade on Wednesday, extending their rally into a fourth day. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.79% to 28,802.53, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.13%. The gains were driven by a forecast-beating increase in Chinese factory activity in March.

site_title: Malaysian economy to grow 6-7.5% in 2021: central bank
summary: Malaysia's central bank forecasts the country's economic growth to range from 6% to 7.5% in 2021, rebounding from a 5.6% contraction in 2020. The recovery is expected to be gradual and uneven, with a potential hit from the ongoing pandemic. The central bank plans to maintain accommodative monetary policy to support the post-pandemic recovery and will focus on digital economy initiatives, including licensing for digital banks and online payment services. A return to pre-Covid-19 GDP levels is expected by mid-2021, despite downside risks.

site_title: China factory activity rises as economic recovery broadens: official
summary: China's factory activity surged in March, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 51.9, exceeding expectations. The non-manufacturing PMI rebounded to 56.3, indicating a strong service industry recovery. Officials attribute the growth to China's control over the Covid-19 outbreak, consumer demand returning, and companies, including smaller ones, performing better despite some delays in imported raw materials. This broadens China's economic recovery and suggests a positive outlook for the service industry and hard-hit sectors.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in the red, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.70% to 28,378.35. The decline follows three days of gains, as investors await the unveiling of US President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, with the latter easing 0.52%. The losses come despite a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Deliveroo set for London stock market launch
summary: Deliveroo, a UK-based meal delivery app, is set to launch on the London stock market, valued at £7.6 billion, after surging sales during the coronavirus pandemic. The IPO has been overshadowed by criticism over its treatment of self-employed riders and job insecurity concerns. Despite this, Deliveroo maintains that its riders value the flexibility of the job. The company's dual class share structure gives founder Will Shu 20 votes per share, while other shareholders get one vote. The IPO is seen as a major boost to London's financial sector, with institutional investors getting a slice first.

site_title: Indonesia recovers cockpit voice recorder of crashed Sriwijaya Air jet
summary: Indonesia's transport ministry has recovered the cockpit voice recorder (CVR) of a Sriwijaya Air jet that crashed into the Java Sea on January 9, killing all 62 people on board. The CVR was found on Wednesday after nearly three months of searching in relatively shallow but muddy waters. The recovery is similar to the Lion Air 737 MAX crash in 2018. The CVR could help investigators understand the actions taken by the pilots, as a preliminary report suggested the plane had an imbalance in engine thrust leading to the crash.

site_title: 'Optimistic' Federal Reserve policymakers see US economy about to boom
summary: Federal Reserve policymakers express optimism about the US economy, citing vaccination progress, government aid, and excess savings. Richmond Fed President Thomas Barkin expects a strong recovery, while Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic warns of "upside risks." New York Fed President John Williams also shares optimism. Despite this, the Fed remains committed to keeping interest rates near zero until the economy reaches full employment and inflation reaches 2%. The central bank will continue to buy bonds to lower borrowing costs.

site_title: Indonesia's next digital boom lies beyond metropolitan cities
summary: Indonesia's digital economy is expected to experience significant growth in non-metropolitan cities, with tier two and three cities projected to see a 3-6 times increase in e-commerce, payments, and lending gross merchandise value by 2025. This growth will be driven by the adoption of digital services, despite barriers such as understanding apps and Internet access, and concerns over product availability and quality. The sector is expected to contribute up to $77 billion to the national GDP by 2030, with e-commerce reaching $45 billion and edtech and healthtech growing three times from 2020 levels.

site_title: 34 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in the community
summary: There were 34 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore as of March 31, 2021, bringing the total to 60,381. The cases included one in the community and 33 imported ones, all of whom were placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival.

site_title: US orders departure of non-essential diplomats from Myanmar
summary: The US State Department ordered the departure of non-essential diplomats from Myanmar amid a military crackdown that has killed hundreds of protesters since the country's coup. This decision follows the initial authorization of a "voluntary departure" in mid-February. The US government has taken this step to ensure the safety of its personnel.

site_title: Singapore's arbitration centre sets record in 2020 with 1,080 case filings
summary: Singapore's International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) set a record with 1,080 case filings in 2020, surpassing the 1,000-case threshold for the first time. The centre administered 98% of the cases, totaling US$8.5 billion in dispute, with parties from 60 jurisdictions choosing to arbitrate. India, the US, and China topped foreign user rankings, with a broad spectrum of civil- and common-law jurisdictions also represented. The milestone was attributed to careful planning and hard work, with SIAC chairman and CEO expressing gratitude for the trust and support of users worldwide.

site_title: Saudi Arabia plans to invest 12t riyals to boost private sector
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to invest 12 trillion riyals (S$4.3 trillion) by 2030 to boost its private sector, aiming to strengthen the economy, create hundreds of thousands of new jobs, and support local companies. The initiative, announced by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, includes 3 trillion riyals from the Public Investment Fund. The move aims to diversify the oil-reliant economy and address high unemployment, which reached 14.9% in the third quarter of 2020.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia announced plans Tuesday to pump 12 trillion riyals (S$4.3 trillion) in fresh investments by 2030 to boost the private sector, as the Opec kingpin pushes to diversify its oil-reliant economy.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.5% in February: MAS data
summary: Singapore's bank lending rose 0.5% in February, driven by growth in housing and construction loans, according to the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). Total bank lending slipped 0.9% year-over-year. Housing loans increased 0.3% to S$202.66 billion, while business loans grew 0.5% to S$424.76 billion. This is the fourth consecutive month of growth in bank lending.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower as Archegos woes rattle financials
summary: Japanese stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 Index down 0.86% at 29,178.80, and the Topix dropping 1.21% to 1,954.00. The decline was attributed to uncertainty over the fallout from Archegos Capital's margin calls, which may result in losses for global investment banks, including Nomura Holdings and Credit Suisse, estimated to be over US$6 billion. Financial shares, such as Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, fell 3.87% and 2.9% respectively, amid concerns about further losses.

site_title: UK employers turn much more confident about hiring: REC
summary: British employers have become more confident about hiring staff, with a six-percentage-point increase in confidence to a net level of +16 in the three months to February 2021, according to the Recruitment and Employment Confederation (REC). This confidence jump, to +29 in February, comes as the country speeds ahead with its coronavirus vaccination program. Employers are relying on temporary hiring, citing caution about the economy and shortages of construction workers. The Bank of England has forecast Britain's unemployment rate to peak at 7.75% in the middle of this year.

site_title: OCBC pushes cheaper home, renovation loans for eco-friendly borrowers
summary: OCBC has launched "Eco-Care" Home and Renovation Loans in Singapore, offering cheaper interest rates to borrowers who pass the Building and Construction Authority's Tropical Home Energy Efficiency Assessment (THEEA) and demonstrate an eco-friendly approach to their homes. The loans come with lower rates, including a one-month compounded Sora plus a spread of 0.98% for the first two years. Customers who achieve an energy usage below the national average can earn reward points and redeem rewards on the bank's STACK marketplace. This move aims to encourage sustainable financing and grow OCBC's sustainable finance portfolio to S$25 billion by 2025.

site_title: Banks to cease issuance of SOR derivatives and Sibor-linked financial products by Sept
summary: Financial institutions in Singapore will cease the use of the Swap Offer Rate (SOR) in new derivatives contracts by end-September 2021, and Sibor-linked financial products by the same date. The move aims to push the industry towards the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora) as the main interest rate benchmark, addressing operational and financial risks associated with SOR derivatives. Existing SOR transactions will be allowed to mature, and a fallback rate for SOR will be published for a period of about three years following the expected discontinuation of SOR in mid-2023.

site_title: Pacific International Lines' debt restructuring plan effective on March 30
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) successfully completed its debt restructuring plan on March 30, 2021. The plan, approved by creditors, sees Temasek Holdings' Heliconia Capital Management becoming the majority shareholder and injecting US$600 million to rescue the company. The restructuring also involves the cancellation of US$60 million in 8.5% notes, and the issuance of new securities, including Option A and Option B. The move aims to rescue PIL, which had faced financial difficulties.

site_title: Archegos losses tallied up, industry regulatory scrutiny grows
summary: Archegos Capital, a US$10 billion single-family office, defaulted on margin calls by its banks, resulting in potential losses of over US$6 billion for global lenders. Credit Suisse is expected to bear the brunt of the losses, potentially up to US$4 billion, with other banks, including Nomura and Wells Fargo, also facing losses. Regulatory scrutiny intensifies, with US and British regulators discussing the fallout and potential changes in leverage for family offices and hedge funds.

site_title: Jobs Growth Incentive supported hiring of 130,000 locals over three months
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) scheme supported the hiring of 130,000 locals from September to November, with nearly all (99%) of supported employers being small- and medium-sized enterprises. The top hiring sectors were food services, wholesale trade, and professional services. The scheme, which offers salary support to expand local hiring, saw a slowing pace of hiring, with 50% of hires being aged 40 and above.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, SPH, Yinda Infocomm, Neo Group, ST Engineering
summary: Sembcorp Marine recorded three consecutive years of pre-tax losses, with its six-month average daily market cap at S$1.89 billion. Singapore Press Holdings posted a 26.1% increase in net profit to S$97.9 million for the half year ended Feb 28. Yinda Infocomm received a "trade with caution" alert from the Singapore Exchange Regulation after its review showed suspicious corporate actions. Neo Group's founder intends to take the company private via a voluntary conditional cash offer at S$0.60 per share. ST Engineering raised the offer price for its proposed acquisition of Cubic Corporation to US$78 per share.

site_title: Japan raises alert level after volcano erupts
summary: A volcano in south-western Japan, Mount Otake in Kagoshima prefecture, erupted, prompting the Japan Meteorological Agency to raise its alert level to three. The eruption, which occurred twice, flung large rocks hundreds of meters from the crater, but no immediate reports of injuries were reported. The agency warned that rocks could potentially reach a two-kilometer radius. Japan sits on the Pacific "Ring of Fire," making it prone to earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

site_title: Japan's factory output falls in Feb in worrying sign for recovery
summary: Japan's factory output fell 2.1% in February due to declines in car and electrical machinery production, raising concerns about the country's economic recovery from the pandemic. The decline was weaker than forecast, but still a worrying sign. Manufacturers expect a further 1.9% drop in March, followed by a 9.3% rebound in April. The government's assessment of industrial production remains unchanged, but some analysts fear weak spending at home and slower demand abroad will drag down Japan's recovery.

site_title: Fossil fuel subsidies up, carbon pricing too low: OECD
summary: The OECD reports that no major economy meets the Paris climate treaty goal of capping global warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius. Fossil fuel subsidies rose by 5% in 2019 to $178 billion, undermining the transition to a carbon-neutral global economy. Only 44 nations, accounting for 80% of global carbon pollution, scored 13 on average in the OECD's carbon pricing score, with European nations and the US performing poorly. China's score is expected to improve rapidly with the introduction of a national emissions trading scheme in 2021.

site_title: Sembmarine files notice of three straight years of losses
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a marine and offshore engineering group, has filed a notice of three consecutive years of pre-tax losses based on its audited full-year consolidated accounts. The company's net loss for FY2020 widened to S$582.5 million, with losses per share reaching 10.88 cents. The losses are attributed to Covid-19-related delays and higher project costs. The company still meets the financial entry criteria to avoid being placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list, with a six-month average daily market cap of S$1.89 billion.

site_title: PayPal allows US shoppers to make cryptocurrency purchases
summary: PayPal has begun allowing US shoppers to use cryptocurrency for purchases from millions of merchants. The new feature, called Checkout with Crypto, allows users to convert their digital money into US dollars at the time of sale. This move is seen as a step towards mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies. PayPal's move follows Tesla's recent announcement to accept bitcoin as payment for electric cars. The introduction of this feature aims to increase the use of digital currencies and drive mass acceptance of digital currencies.

site_title: New Zealand's business confidence slips in March
summary: New Zealand's business confidence decreased in March, according to an ANZ Bank survey, as the economy struggled from the lack of tourists and unsustainable retail spending. The headline measure showed a net 4.1% of respondents expecting the economy to deteriorate, down from 7.0% in February. This contrasts with 16.6% of respondents expecting their businesses to grow in the next 12 months, down from 21.3% last month.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's business sentiment fell in March as the economy struggled from the lack of tourists and the unsustainable bounce in retail spending started to dissipate, an ANZ Bank survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Fossil fuel stocks lost US$123b in decade: analysis
summary: Fossil fuel stocks underperformed a global benchmark index by 52% over the last decade, losing nearly US$123 billion in value, according to an analysis by Carbon Tracker. Issuance of fossil fuel offerings fell 85% from US$70 billion to US$10 billion, while renewable energy IPOs raised US$11 billion. Industry expert Mark Campanale attributed the losses to a fundamental shift in the energy system towards low-carbon technologies, rather than cyclical market fluctuations.

site_title: Volkswagen US spokesman confirms 'Voltswagen' rebrand an April Fool's joke
summary: Volkswagen's US subsidiary has confirmed that its earlier announcement of a rebranding to "Voltswagen of America" was an April Fool's joke. The German automaker had recreated its social media pages with the new name, claiming it represented its future investment in e-mobility. However, a spokesman, Mark Gillies, has denied the rebranding, stating it was a joke. The move comes after the company's earlier statement sparked widespread media coverage and public interest.

site_title: Most companies silent as pressure mounts for workforce data
summary: A US$7 trillion investor coalition's Workforce Disclosure Initiative saw only 19% of 750 companies disclose workforce data in 2020, up 20% from 2019. Despite 98% pledging to improve diversity, only 36% reported ethnic composition. 57% disclosed gender pay gap, but only 4% reported ethnicity pay gap. Companies also provided data on discrimination and harassment policies, human rights, but struggled to report incidents and resolve violations. Amazon, Google-owner Alphabet, and Walmart did not disclose information.

site_title: Japan's Feb retail sales fall for third straight month
summary: Japan's retail sales declined for the third consecutive month in February, falling 1.5% from a year earlier. The decline was driven by weak consumer spending amid the coronavirus emergency, and is expected to contribute to a sharp contraction in the first quarter. Analysts warn that the fragile economy's recovery from last year's slump may be delayed due to the ongoing lack of consumer confidence and weakening exports.

site_title: Killer T cells boost immunity to coronavirus variants: study
summary: A new study found that killer T cells, a key part of the immune response, remained mostly unaffected by coronavirus variants. Researchers analyzed blood samples from 30 people who had previously contracted and recovered from Covid-19 and found that these cells could recognize virtually all mutations in variants B.1.1.7, B.1.351, and B.1.1.248. This suggests that killer T cells can help prevent severe disease, even if vaccines are less effective against these variants. The findings are encouraging and could help explain why vaccines are able to prevent severe disease and hospitalization despite reduced efficacy against variants.

site_title: Epic Games files complaint in UK against Apple
summary: Epic Games has filed a complaint with the UK's Competition and Markets Authority, accusing Apple of "monopolistic practices" and "anticompetitive behavior". Apple's App Store rules, which charge up to 30% commission on app sales, are seen as restrictive. Epic claims this is a "clear violation" of British law. The complaint follows similar lawsuits filed by Epic in the US, EU, Australia, and other countries against Apple and Google. Epic seeks regulatory decisions, not monetary damages, to force Apple to change its practices.

site_title: Google Maps to start directing drivers to 'eco-friendly' routes
summary: Google's Maps app will start directing drivers to routes with the lowest carbon emissions, launching in the US later this year and globally. The feature uses traffic, slope, and road type data to estimate emissions and will be the default option unless users opt out. Google partnered with the US government's National Renewable Energy Lab to develop the emissions estimates, which will also be used to warn drivers of low emissions zones. The move aims to help combat climate change and is part of Google's broader climate-focused changes, including improved route comparison and low emissions zone warnings.

site_title: Counting begins in vote on first Amazon labour union
summary: Counting of votes cast by Amazon employees at an Alabama warehouse began on Tuesday to determine if it would become the first union shop at the e-commerce company. The Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union would represent 5,800 employees if a majority votes in favor. Eligibility of votes can be challenged, but Amazon has encouraged employees to vote, citing benefits such as starting wages of $15 or more and health care from day one. The outcome could open the floodgates to organizing drives at other Amazon sites and firms, amid a surge in unionization efforts under President Joe Biden.

site_title: Spotify delves into live audio with purchase of Clubhouse rival
summary: Spotify has acquired Betty Labs, a "live audio" specialist behind the Locker Room app, to develop a platform open to a wider range of creators and fans. The move follows Spotify's ambitions to expand into non-musical audio, following its investment in podcasts. This acquisition comes as competitors like Facebook and entrepreneur Mark Cuban's Fireside are also working on similar offerings. The deal is seen as Spotify's entry into the booming "live audio" sector, driven by the popularity of Clubhouse.

site_title: MoneyOwl partners Fullerton for multi-asset solution
summary: MoneyOwl has partnered with Fullerton Fund Management to launch the Fullerton MoneyOwl WiseIncome portfolio, a low-cost multi-asset solution designed for passive income and capital growth. The fund offers three income payout options (up to 8% a year) and is managed by Fullerton Fund Management. It aims to assist Singaporeans in building their retirement nest egg, with a diversified portfolio of S-Reits, Asian fixed income, and global equities. The fund has no sales charge and a platform fee is absorbed by MoneyOwl.

site_title: City of London says bulk of workers will return to the office after pandemic
summary: The City of London is expected to see most workers return to their offices after the pandemic, according to Catherine McGuinness, policy chair at the City of London Corporation. Most office workers are likely to return for three or four days a week, working different hours. This shift is expected to bring back trade for cafes, pubs, and restaurants. Developers are also revving up plans for new office buildings, with 80% of planning applications showing increased interest in office space. The return of office workers is expected to boost the City's economy, which dominates the world's $6.6 trillion foreign exchange market.

site_title: Oil falls as Suez Canal reopens, dollar rallies; eyes on Opec+ meeting
summary: Oil prices fell 1-1.6% on Tuesday as the Suez Canal reopened, erasing gains from the blockade. The US dollar rallied, making oil priced in dollars more expensive. The upcoming Opec+ meeting on Thursday is expected to extend supply curbs despite dim demand prospects. Brent crude fell to $64.14 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate to $60.55 a barrel, with analysts forecasting a build in US crude inventories. Opec+ may hold output levels unchanged, and Saudi Arabia is prepared to extend production cuts through June.

site_title: Foxconn's profit misses estimates as pivot to cars accelerates
summary: Taiwanese electronics assembler Foxconn reported a quarterly profit of NT$46 billion, slightly below analyst estimates of NT$50.2 billion. The company, also known as Hon Hai Precision Industry, accelerated its shift towards electric vehicles, citing them as a key emerging industry. Revenue rose 15% to NT$2 trillion, driven by contributions from the iPhone 12 series. Foxconn has entered partnerships with carmakers and aims to generate US$35 billion in revenue from its car businesses by 2025, with annual shipments of electric vehicles projected to reach 1.1 million units by then.

site_title: Keeping tabs on the Gwangju Biennale
summary: The Gwangju Biennale, an arts exhibition in South Korea, has been in development for over two years. Curator Defne Ayas and co-artistic director Natasha Ginwala have navigated coronavirus-induced postponements to finalize their edition. The exhibition explores themes of shamanic practices, resistance movements, and the city's history. Ayas discussed the long journey to the exhibition, which will showcase a range of art pieces. The biennale is a significant cultural event in Gwangju, a city of 1.5 million residents, and is expected to feature a diverse array of artistic expressions.

images.alt_text: Natasha Ginwala, co-artistic director of Gwangju Biennale, left, with Park Juwon, second from left, and Jeong Kwan, a Buddhist nun who will perform at the opening of the biennale ceremony in Gwangju, South Korea. The Gwangju Biennale, on tap for April 1, is the most closely watched art event in Asia.

site_title: Floods drown hopes of Australia's tourist industry
summary: Australia's tourist industry is facing a significant setback due to devastating floods along its east coast, with operators reporting a wave of cancellations and significant financial losses. The Easter long weekend and school holidays, typically a peak period, have been ruined for many tourist operators, with some losing entire seasons. Tourism generates A$61 billion annually for the Australian economy and employs about 5% of the workforce. Flood damage is expected to continue affecting the sector, with a new Covid-19 outbreak in northern Queensland further exacerbating the issue.

images.alt_text: A bar in Brisbane prepares to close after the authorities announced a three-day lockdown after a new Covid-19 cluster was detected.

site_title: Asian nations seek other vaccine supplies after India export curbs hit Covax
summary: Several Asian countries, including South Korea, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam, are facing shipment delays of Covid-19 vaccines due to export restrictions by India, the world's largest vaccine maker. India temporarily halted exports of the AstraZeneca vaccine to focus on domestic demand, leaving the World Health Organization-backed Covax programme short of supplies. The shortage may worsen vaccine inequity, complicating global efforts to combat the pandemic, and could prompt fresh pleas for a global treaty on pandemics.

site_title: Rubbish piles up as Myanmar protesters launch 'garbage strike'
summary: Myanmar's military rule has led to over 500 civilians killed in nearly two months of protests, with at least 141 deaths reported on Saturday. Pro-democracy protesters launched a "garbage strike" in Yangon, leaving trash at intersections, to oppose the military. Thousands marched in other towns, while security forces used heavy-caliber weapons to disperse crowds, killing one person. The United Nations urged the generals to stop the killings and repression of demonstrations, as ethnic minority groups have called for help in defending themselves against the military's "unfair oppression."

site_title: Rates markets turn up heat on Asia's central banks
summary: Asian central banks face pressure to raise interest rates as investors anticipate a shift in the region, following Brazil, Russia, and Turkey's recent hikes to combat inflation and currency pressures. South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, and India are expected to increase rates within the next 12 months, with investors warning of potential capital flight and currency selloffs if they don't. Economists caution that Asia's central banks need to be cautious, given the region's historically low rates and "choppy" global capital flows.

site_title: Real estate investors desperate to spend US$250b hoard
summary: US private equity funds, which stockpiled over $250 billion for commercial real estate loans, are facing a challenging situation as the expected wave of defaults after the coronavirus has yet to materialize. Despite a surge in fundraising, few deals are coming to market, leaving investors desperate to deploy their capital. Commercial real estate prices have held up, and many investors are willing to push prices up and yields down to simply deploy their capital. The window of opportunity for discounted deals is closing, and some investors may be forced to ask for extensions or seek alternative sources of distressed opportunities.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: GKE Corporation has been granted a farm licence to grow and sell agricultural produce commercially in Singapore. The company will convert its office premise into a 2,400 sq ft indoor farm for kale cultivation. GKE plans to expand the area to 12,500 sq ft. ST Engineering has raised its offer price for Cubic Corporation's outstanding stock to US$78 per share, a 11.4% premium over its previous offer. The Singapore Exchange Regulation issued a "trade-with-caution" alert for Yinda Infocomm, citing potential manipulation of its share prices by a group of connected accounts.

site_title: Pandemic delays gender parity by a generation: WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum's annual Global Gender Gap Report finds that the COVID-19 pandemic has delayed progress towards gender parity by a generation, with women losing jobs at a higher rate and taking on more childcare responsibilities. The report estimates that it will take 135.6 years to close the gender gap, up from 99.5 years in 2019, and 267.6 years for workplace equality. The pandemic has also widened the political gender gap, with women holding just over a quarter of parliamentary seats worldwide.

images.alt_text: The pandemic has rolled back years of progress towards equality between men and women, according a report Wednesday showing the crisis had added decades to the trajectory towards closing the gender gap.

site_title: US: Dow Jones retreats from record despite strong consumer data
summary: US stocks retreated from a record on Tuesday despite strong consumer confidence data, with the Dow Jones falling. The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence jumped to 109.7 in March, its best reading since the start of the pandemic. The data, however, failed to boost the market, as US Treasury yields continued to rise. The strong reading pointed to improved sentiment on business conditions and employment prospects, but was overshadowed by market uncertainty.

site_title: US dollar climbs to one-year high against yen
summary: The US dollar reached a one-year high against the yen, rising to 110 yen and a third of a percent, amid accelerating US vaccinations and plans for a major stimulus package. The dollar index surpassed the 93 mark, its highest level in four months, driven by inflation expectations and rising Treasury yields. Analysts attribute the yen's vulnerability to higher inflation expectations in the US and long-term US yields. The euro weakened to its lowest level since November, while the monthly US non-farm payrolls report will be closely watched for its impact on interest rates.

site_title: Banyan Tree shares hit 52-week high on hopes of Thai tourism rebound
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings, a Singapore-listed resorts operator, sees its shares hit a 52-week high on optimism about Thailand's tourism rebound. The Thai government has eased travel restrictions, cutting mandatory quarantine for foreign travelers to 10 days starting April 1. The company's Thailand portfolio, which includes eight hotels and six spas, is expected to benefit from the move. However, the chairman, Ho Kwon Ping, cautions that it's early days and the group's reliance on tourism hobbles its financial performance.

site_title: SGX RegGo issues 'trade-with-caution' alert for Yinda Infocomm
summary: SGX RegCo issued a "trade-with-caution" alert for Yinda Infocomm after reviewing trades that appeared to be influenced by a group of accounts. The shares of Yinda Infocomm nearly tripled in price from 5.3 Singapore cents to 14.9 Singapore cents, with a group of accounts acting as the introducer in five corporate actions. The review found that the individuals behind the accounts are likely connected to the introducer, raising concerns about market manipulation. The alert advises traders to exercise caution when dealing with Yinda shares.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record high with banks in lead
summary: European stocks hovered near record highs, driven by hopes of a vaccine-driven economic recovery, as the Stoxx 600 index gained 0.7% and traded less than 1% below its pre-pandemic peak. Bank stocks jumped 2.7% after a 1% drop on Monday, as US and European government bond yields rose. The rebound came despite a US hedge fund default that impacted banking stocks.

site_title: Asian refinery sector faces continued margin squeeze
summary: Singapore's status as a major refining hub remains intact despite the Asian refining market facing a margin squeeze due to high crude prices and weak demand amid renewed lockdowns. Analysts predict that refining margins in Asia will continue to worsen before improving in the second half of the year, driven by rising crude prices and surplus capacities. However, some analysts, such as Jeffrey Halley at Oanda, believe the worst is over and that the sector will recover, with Singapore's deep integration with petrochemicals and a supportive ecosystem helping to mitigate the challenges.

site_title: The US should tap China's inner weakness in new Cold War
summary: The US should focus on China's economic weaknesses in the new Cold War. Unlike the Soviet Union, China's communist system is unpopular and unworkable, hindering its ability to compete with free-market nations. The US-China summit in Anchorage, Alaska, highlighted clashing interests and incompatible values. China accused the US of advancing its own democracy, while the US claimed China was threatening the "rules-based order" that maintains global stability. China's recent strategic pact with Iran, including joint weapons development and intelligence-sharing, further emphasizes its challenges to the US-led order.

site_title: Xi finalises HK election changes, cementing China's control
summary: China has finalized changes to Hong Kong's electoral system, cementing Beijing's control over the city's government. President Xi Jinping signed orders to amend the Basic Law, allowing a national security committee to vet candidates for the Legislative Council based on vetting by police officers. The changes include expanding the number of seats and reducing the number of directly elected representatives, effectively preventing pro-democracy voices from entering the government. The US, UK, Japan, and EU have condemned the moves, calling them a "direct attack" on Hong Kong's autonomy.

site_title: Asian SPAC listings face test as regulators consider rule changes
summary: Asian stock exchanges are considering rule changes to allow listing of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), but industry players express concerns that the region may not attract the same level of interest as the US. Despite efforts from Singapore and Indonesia to explore SPAC listings, some executives worry about low valuations in certain markets and the need for strong investor protection safeguards. Hong Kong is leaning towards a "no" approach, while Singapore's regulatory unit is exploring a consultation on SPACs. A successful SPAC listing in Singapore could position it as an alternative to US exchanges.

site_title: Normal production at fire-hit Renesas plant to take 100-120 days
summary: Renesas Electronics, a Japanese chipmaker, expects to resume normal production at its fire-hit plant in northeast Japan within 100-120 days, after 23 machines were damaged in the incident. The company's recovery to pre-fire levels is expected to take around 100 days, and it will take a related sales hit of 19.5-26 billion yen in the next two months. Japan's government has urged Taiwanese manufacturers to help with alternative chip production to support Renesas' recovery.

site_title: Luxury sales outpace broader market in Toronto's housing boom
summary: Toronto's luxury home sales surged 157% in January and February, outpacing the broader market, with sales of homes worth over C$4 million rising by 52%. The luxury market saw five sales over C$10 million during the period, compared to one a year earlier. The pandemic has driven high earners to buy bigger homes, favoring detached properties, and accelerating price appreciation is raising concerns of a bubble. The Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation has increased its risk assessment for Toronto's market, citing vulnerability to a sharp price drop.

site_title: Eight reasons to buy shares
summary: A recent rise in bond yields has raised concerns about inflation and the role of central banks. Investors are questioning whether central banks' zero-interest policies are prioritizing inflation control over economic growth. However, a holistic view of the economy suggests that central banks should consider multiple objectives. Investing in the stock market can help protect against inflation, with companies having pricing power and the ability to raise prices when needed. Eight reasons to buy shares include: beating inflation, ease of buying and selling, access to information, investing in products you like, dividends, capital growth, diversification, and fun.

site_title: Suez incident brings seafarers into focus
summary: The container ship Ever Given, stuck across the Suez Canal since March 22, was finally pulled clear on Monday, bringing relief to the shipping industry and the global economy. The incident highlighted the crucial role of shipping in world trade, with the UN secretary-general praising the efforts of seafarers and maritime experts in resolving the situation. The incident also underscored the fragility of the "just in time" system, which relies on the Suez Canal for efficient global trade. With the canal now open, a surge of vessels is expected to arrive at European terminals, posing a handling challenge for container terminals and inland logistics systems.

site_title: Hotels in 'shoulder season' as arrivals, occupancy stagnate in February
summary: Singapore's hotel industry faces a stagnant half-year, with visitor arrivals expected to see a significant upward bump only from July. In February, visitor arrivals fell 22.5% month-on-month and 97.6% year-on-year, with occupancy averaging 41.7% and room revenue at S$58.63 million. Analysts expect travel bubble tourism in the second half of 2021 and 2022, with some hotels anticipating small increases in occupancy over the March school holidays and Easter weekend. However, the industry is expected to remain sub-par to 2019 levels, with RevPAR unlikely to recover in the near term.

site_title: Ooredoo's Indonesian unit close to selling 4,000 towers to Digital Colony: sources
summary: Ooredoo's Indonesian unit, PT Indosat, is nearing a deal to sell approximately 4,000 towers to Digital Colony for over $700 million. The deal, potentially announced this week, comes weeks after Indosat's announcement of exploring tower sales. Digital Colony, in partnership with Edgepoint Infrastructure, aims to expand its tower assets to 20,000-50,000 over five to seven years. The sale could impact Indosat's market value, currently at $2.4 billion, and follows a consolidation plan between Ooredoo and CK Hutchison Holdings in Indonesia.

site_title: Shares of office landlords surge on expected return of office workers
summary: Shares of office landlords in Singapore surged as the government's announcement of a 75% capacity return to the office from April 5 is expected to revive businesses at retail and food and beverage outlets. Analysts predict that office Reit managers will see a welcomed change in revenue, while retail Reits are expected to have neutral to minimal impact due to fair tenancy guidelines. Analysts also expect that office leasing momentum will improve, and downtown malls will benefit from the return of office workers.

images.alt_text: Shares of office landlords have been gaining since the government's announcement last week that a bigger proportion - up to 75 per cent - of staff can return to the workplace from April 5.

site_title: Neo Group founder seeks to take firm private via voluntary conditional cash offer
summary: Neo Group's founder and CEO, Neo Kah Kiat, plans to take the Catalist-listed food caterer private via a voluntary conditional cash offer at S$0.60 per share. The offer, made through Forestt Investment, represents a 17.9% premium over the one-month VWAP. The offeror believes it will allow for greater control and management flexibility, while shareholders can realise their investment at a premium without incurring brokerage and trading costs.

site_title: Singapore takes lion's share of venture dollars in South-east Asia
summary: Singapore leads venture capital dollars in South-east Asia, with tech startups drawing in S$5.5 billion of capital over the past year. This represents a decrease from 2019, but still a significant increase from five years ago. The city-state accounted for about three-quarters of the region's capital in 2019. Despite the dip, Singapore remains a hub for venture capital, with startups continuing to attract substantial funding.

site_title: When does strong US growth get too much for Asia?
summary: Stronger US growth can be beneficial for Asia's economies, contrary to market perceptions. Historically, rising US rates and a stronger US dollar have led to less attractive performance for non-US-dollar risk assets. However, the past four episodes of rising Fed policy rates and/or rising US 10-year yields, alongside benign or improving US growth momentum, have been benign for Asia. Today, Asia's macro stability indicators are better than in 2013, reducing the risk of disruptions from rising US rates. Stronger US growth is expected to accelerate Asia's GDP growth and enable growth laggards to catch up to North Asian economies.

site_title: BTxM+S podcast Ep 4: How sustainable property developments can save costs
summary: A podcast episode, BTxM+S, discusses sustainable property developments and how they can save costs. The episode, the final installment in a series on Marina One Residences, explores the advantages of inner city park-like living in downtown Singapore. Developer M+S is the sponsor. The episode aims to provide insights on sustainable development, but no key conclusions or facts are mentioned in the provided text.

images.alt_text: In the final instalment of our BTxM+S series, Ong Choon Fah, CEO of Edmund Tie & Company, analyses the advantages of living in the heart of Singapore's downtown area.
Marina One Residences boasts sustainable features that add to lifestyle and well-being choices for property investors, such as a 'Green Heart' feature within the development.
One of the bigger rooms at Marina One Residences.
A view of Marina One Residences, a prime example of a mixed-use property development in Singapore's Marina Bay area.

site_title: Bottom-up greenness powered by top-down incentives
summary: A new approach to achieving environmental sustainability, known as bottom-up greenness (BuG), is being explored. This bottom-up approach starts with individual growers and works its way up the supply chain, using real-time data from the Internet of Things (IOT) to track and verify sustainable practices. By linking greenness credentials to concessional loans, banks can incentivize businesses to adopt environmentally friendly practices without increasing costs. This approach aims to address the limitations of current top-down approaches, which often rely on subjective scoring systems and may be susceptible to greenwashing.

site_title: JP Morgan AM beefs up sustainable offerings for retail investors
summary: JP Morgan Asset Management has launched two new sustainable funds for retail investors, the Global Income Sustainable Fund and Emerging Markets Sustainable Equity Fund, as part of its Endowus ESG Portfolios. The funds aim to integrate environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles into investment decisions. The Global Income Sustainable Fund excludes 10 unsustainable sectors and has a 50% lower carbon dioxide emissions compared to its investment universe. The Emerging Markets Sustainable Equity Fund invests in companies with best-in-class sustainable business practices, resulting in 77% lower carbon dioxide emissions compared to the MSCI Emerging Markets Index.

site_title: To end pandemic, vaccines need to be distributed fairly to all countries
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is not yet over, with vaccine distribution remaining a major issue. Developed countries are stockpiling vaccines, leaving poorer nations with limited access. A recent report found that the US, UK, China, and India have secured over 3 billion doses, exceeding their population needs. The global vaccine distribution process is marred by inequity, corruption, and vaccine nationalism, hindering efforts to end the pandemic. To address this, world leaders must work towards a more equitable distribution system, prioritizing fairness and transparency.

site_title: US consumer confidence surged to one-year high in March
summary: US consumer confidence surged to a one-year high in March, reaching 109.7, driven by improved outlooks and lifted restrictions. This uptick is attributed to COVID-19 vaccinations and fiscal stimulus, boosting household spending and job market expectations. The Conference Board's gauge of expectations rose to 109.6, its highest since July 2019, and a measure of sentiment about current conditions reached a one-year high of 110. This indicates economic growth may strengthen further in the coming months, with consumers showing renewed optimism for purchasing big-ticket items.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit trust scheme court order granted; delisting expected April 14
summary: Soilbuild Reit's trust scheme of arrangement has been granted by the court, allowing for the disposal of its Australian assets and the payment of adjusted scheme consideration to unitholders. Trading in units has been suspended, and units are expected to be delisted on April 14. The disposal of assets is expected to be completed on March 31, and unitholders will receive the adjusted scheme consideration of S$0.55 per unit on April 12. This follows a vote by unitholders in favor of the proposed privatisation offer made by Lim Chap Huat and Blackstone Real Estate.

site_title: Heavyweight investors sit out Deliveroo IPO, citing gig-economy concerns
summary: Deliveroo, Britain's largest IPO in a decade, failed to attract leading investors due to concerns over its gig-economy structure. Despite strong demand for shares, heavyweight investors sat out the listing. British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak hailed the company's decision as a "true British tech success story," but the absence of major investors cast a shadow on the occasion. The company's decision to go public in London sets a stage for more listings by fast-growing tech companies, but the IPO's success remains uncertain.

site_title: S$128.8m sale of Nassim Road bungalow sets record transaction price of S$4,005 psf
summary: A record S$4,005 per square foot (psf) price was set for a S$128.8 million sale of a Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Singapore's Nassim Road. The buyer, Jin Xiao Qun, wife of billionaire Nanofilm Technologies founder Shi Xu, acquired the 32,159 sq ft freehold site, known as Ladyvale, from Sukmawati Widjaja. Analysts predict this sale will lead to an upward revision in asking prices for GCB owners, especially in prime locations, with several properties on the market in the area.

site_title: Envy director charged with cheating and fraud has links to vehicle firms
summary: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi, director of Envy Motors and Swag EV, has been charged with cheating and fraud, accused of swindling millions of dollars from Envysion Wealth Management and another company. Ng has interests in two vehicle firms and holds shares in both companies, including a 500,000-share stake in Envy Motors. He is also accused of manipulating Envy Motors' financials, with the company recording a S$52,747 loss after tax in 2019. Ng's alleged fraud is linked to at least S$1 billion invested in two firms where he was a director.

site_title: DBS to double down on China and India, grow focus on digital assets
summary: DBS, South-East Asia's largest lender, plans to double down on its presence in China and India, focusing on digital assets, consumer finance, and the Greater Bay Area. The bank's new securities joint venture in China is expected to be ready for launch in the coming weeks. In India, DBS has taken over Lakshmi Vilas Bank, which has added 2 million retail and 125,000 corporate customers to its deposit base. The bank expects to achieve a positive profit and loss statement in the next 12 to 24 months. DBS also sees opportunities in tokenisation, with plans to extend its digital currency exchange beyond financial assets.

site_title: WHO chief urges deeper probe into lab leak Covid origins theory
summary: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus has called for a deeper probe into the lab leak theory of Covid-19 origins, despite the team concluding it's the least likely hypothesis. He expressed concerns over limited access to raw data during the investigation and emphasized the need for timely and comprehensive data sharing in future studies. Ghebreyesus is ready to deploy additional specialist experts for further investigation, indicating a shift in the WHO's stance on the lab leak theory.

site_title: JPMorgan says banks may take up to US$10b hit on Archegos
summary: Banks exposed to Archegos Capital may face total losses ranging from $5 billion to $10 billion, according to JPMorgan analysts. The firm estimates losses in the range of $2 billion to $5 billion, but notes that Nomura Holdings' potential $2 billion loss and Credit Suisse's potential $3 billion to $4 billion loss are "very material" and not unlikely. The Archegos implosion has raised concerns about poor risk management, threatening Credit Suisse's stock buyback plans and reputational hit.

site_title: Travel is going to resume, but roaming revenue may not rebound
summary: Singapore's residents heavily rely on roaming revenue from travel, accounting for up to 15% of mobile service revenues before the pandemic. This is significantly higher than Malaysia and Thailand, which average 2-3%. As travel resumes, roaming revenue may not rebound, posing a challenge to local telcos.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager says going beyond 'business as usual' is outside its purview
summary: Sabana Reit's manager has clarified that activist unitholders' calls for going beyond "business as usual" are outside its purview. The manager responded to demands from investment funds Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, collectively holding 13% of Sabana Reit units, regarding the failed merger and valuation gap. The manager stated that strategic options must be discussed and decided upon by all unitholders at Extraordinary General Meetings, and will provide more information on costs and fees incurred in the failed merger in the next financial results release.

site_title: IMF to upgrade world growth outlook on US stimulus, vaccines
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) is set to upgrade its global economic growth forecast due to improved outlooks for the US and China. The fund's Managing Director, Kristalina Georgieva, announced that economic expansion this year will be higher than initially projected at 5.5%, driven by US stimulus and vaccine-fueled recovery in advanced economies. Expansion in 2022 is also expected to be higher than the prior forecast of 4.2%. However, Georgieva warned of high uncertainty and potential risks from new virus strains, interest rate increases, and uneven recovery among countries.

site_title: Thailand's key government critic charged with royal defamation
summary: Thailand's former prime ministerial candidate, Thanathorn Juangroongruangkit, was charged with royal defamation after questioning the selection of a company with royal links for vaccine supply. He faces up to 15 years in prison under Thailand's lese majeste law. The charges come as the monarchy faces increased criticism, with at least 76 individuals charged under lese majeste since November 2020. The move is seen as an attempt to discredit Thanathorn, who defended his actions, stating they were beneficial to the country and spurred the government to revisit its vaccine strategy.

site_title: Archegos debacle turns spotlight on risk-taking
summary: The Archegos Capital hedge fund's downfall has highlighted investors' continued appetite for risk-taking, despite the S&P 500's 80% year-to-date gain. This trend is evident in the robust market for special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin, and the 850% rally in GameStop shares, fueled by retail investors. Equity options trading volume has surged, with 85% growth from 2017, and many investors are leveraging their stock exposure through options. Despite concerns about potential risks, some analysts predict US stocks will finish the year higher, driven by the US Federal Reserve's growth forecast of 6.5% this year.

site_title: How Japan can escape financial socialism
summary: The Bank of Japan's comprehensive policy review has highlighted the risks of its prolonged buying of exchange-traded funds, which has de facto turned Japanese equity markets into an experiment in financial socialism. The BOJ owns nearly half of Japan's public debt and about 10% of the country's benchmark Tokyo Stock Price Index equity capitalization. Officials face the challenge of unwinding these holdings without disrupting the market, which could limit the market's upside potential. The BOJ's governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, has been a key driver of the BOJ's equity buying, but now the time to sell may be near.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: DBS Bank plans to expand its presence in China and India, focusing on a securities joint venture, consumer finance market, and the Greater Bay Area. Meanwhile, a luxury property in Singapore sold for a record S$4,005 per square foot, and hotel revenue in February stagnated due to low visitor numbers. Top Glove, a rubber glove manufacturer, was ordered to pay a US customs fine over forced labor practices, and Allied Tech's board conducted a special audit amid allegations of misappropriated funds.

site_title: BMW has got its timing right for beefing up electric cars: CEO
summary: BMW's CEO, Oliver Zipse, says the company has timed its shift to electric cars well, with plans to have half of its sales be fully-electric by 2030. BMW has signed a contract with US-based Livent to supply lithium for its electric vehicles, and will launch dedicated electric platforms in 2025, unlike Volkswagen and Daimler AG, which have already done so. Zipse expects European Union to tighten CO2 emission targets, but believes a reasonable approach is needed to keep combustion engines alive, citing engine improvements as a key to reaching climate goals.

images.alt_text: BMW has timed its shift to electric cars well and its upcoming products will upend the perception the German carmaker is behind on electrification and could make its stock compete with the likes of Tesla Inc.

site_title: Suez Canal races to clear backlog as shipping convoys resume
summary: The Suez Canal has resumed shipping operations after the Ever Given container ship was freed from a blockage, allowing 140 ships to pass through the canal on Tuesday. The blockage, which occurred on March 23, had caused a backlog of 422 ships at the canal's entrance and along its course, disrupting global supply chains and nearly doubling oil product tanker rates. Experts warn that it could take months to resolve the disruptions, while the Suez Canal Authority chairman hopes the backlog will be cleared in 3-4 days.

site_title: India freezes bank accounts of China's ByteDance in tax case
summary: India has frozen bank accounts of Chinese tech firm ByteDance in a tax case, with the company seeking to quash the directive, fearing it will significantly impact its operations in the country. ByteDance had reduced its India workforce in January following India's retention of a ban on its popular video app TikTok. The move is seen as retaliation to India's stance on the ban, which China has criticized as violating WTO rules. The company still maintains around 1,300 employees in India, primarily for overseas operations.

site_title: Nimbly raises US$4.6m in pre-Series A round led by Insignia
summary: Nimbly Technologies, a Singapore-based enterprise software startup, has raised US$4.6 million in a pre-Series A round led by Insignia Venture Partners, along with Sovereign's Capital and Saison Capital. The funding will be used to accelerate business growth across South-east Asia. Nimbly helps companies monitor, manage and evaluate operations through a mobile platform, aiming to save costs by improving human resource allocation and reducing time spent on reporting. The startup has raised US$5.7 million in funding to date, serving clients in Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, and the US.

site_title: Singapore takes lion's share of venture dollars in South-east Asia
summary: Singapore drew S$5.5 billion in venture capital dollars over the past year, with the city-state accounting for nearly three times the amount raised by startups five years ago. According to a World Bank Group study, Singapore has been the leading investment destination in South-east Asia, drawing over half of the region's venture capital and private equity dollars since 2014. However, the report also notes that the startup ecosystem faces challenges such as talent acquisition, increased competition, and funding gaps for later-stage companies.

images.alt_text: Tech startups in Singapore drew in S$5.5 billion of capital over the past year, according to figures from Enterprise Singapore.

site_title: Brazil's debt: Government inaction is not an option
summary: Brazil's debt has surpassed 90% of GDP, making it the largest in the emerging world, excluding small island states. The country's fiscal policy has been criticized for its lack of action, which could lead to a debt crisis. Despite the government's efforts to respond to the pandemic, the country's borrowing costs are rising, and the real currency has depreciated, pushing up inflation. To address the issue, Brazil needs to implement structural reforms, such as increasing tax revenue and reducing expenditure, without relying on a large fiscal stimulus. Inaction is not an option, as the poor and middle class were victims of previous fiscal crises.

images.alt_text: To limit the deficit and curb debt accumulation, President Jair Bolsonaro, early in his term, undertook a pension reform that raised the retirement age. Pension spending is extraordinarily high in Brazil, accounting for 44 per cent of the federal budget.

site_title: Virgin Galactic unveils newest spacecraft
summary: Virgin Galactic unveiled its newest spacecraft, VSS Imagine, featuring a "mirror-like" exterior coating for thermal protection. The spacecraft will undergo ground testing and glide tests at Virgin Galactic's Spaceport America facility in New Mexico. The company aims to offer daily tourism flights to space, with a target of 400 flights annually, and plans to resume ticket sales after CEO Michael Colglazier's space flight this summer. The new manufacturing process is expected to reduce maintenance and increase flight tempo, enabling the company to scale its business for the long-term.

site_title: VW confirms it will rebrand its US unit as 'Voltswagen'
summary: Volkswagen's US unit has confirmed it will rebrand as "Voltswagen of America," shifting focus to electric vehicles. The name change takes effect in May, amid a commitment to sell one million EVs worldwide by 2025. The company plans to launch 70 electric models across its brands by 2029. This move comes after a draft release was mistakenly posted on the automaker's website earlier this month.

site_title: China may boost cotton imports to cut Xinjiang fibre in exports
summary: China may boost cotton imports to replace fibre from Xinjiang, a major supplier in the global supply chain, due to the US ban on Xinjiang cotton imports and declining textile exports. The country could import 800,000 tons of extra cotton this year, up from 400,000 tons in 2020, to meet demand. This move could benefit countries like Brazil and those in Africa, while also hurting Xinjiang's textile industry, which could see a 20% drop in cotton consumption.

site_title: Market manipulation using pump-and-dump strategy
summary: A CFA Singapore article discusses market manipulation using the pump-and-dump strategy, where an individual spreads false information to artificially inflate a stock's price, then sells their holdings. This tactic allegedly employed by Steve Wong in a hypothetical scenario is deemed a violation of the Securities and Futures Act and the CFA Institute's Market Manipulation Standard. The article highlights the consequences of market manipulation, including damage to investors' interests, disruption of financial markets, and reduced investor participation. It also notes that making misleading statements or disseminating false information is prohibited under local regulations.

images.alt_text: Information-based market manipulation includes, but is not limited to, spreading false rumours to induce trading by others.

site_title: Deals of the week: Khong Guan takes a bite of SGProtein; Singapore startups take the funding cake
summary: Singapore startups secured significant funding in the past week, with Khong Guan investing S$4 million in plant-based meat startup SGProtein, and UI-licious raising US$1.5 million led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The city-state also attracted S$5.5 billion in venture capital over the past year, with Singapore accounting for well over half of the total aggregate value of deals in the Asean region.

site_title: Biggest Japan bank joins Nomura in bracing for Archegos loss
summary: Japan's largest bank, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG), has joined Nomura Holdings in warning of a potential US$300 million loss related to a US client, linked to the Archegos Capital Management's failure to meet margin calls. The unwinding of Archegos's bets has caused significant losses for global financial firms, including MUFG's European subsidiary and Nomura, which have estimated losses of US$2 billion and "significant" losses, respectively. Lenders are still tallying the impact, but losses could badly dent MUFG's European securities operations.

site_title: Ethnic Karen insurgents warn thousands of Myanmar ground troops advancing
summary: The Karen National Union (KNU) in southeast Myanmar has warned thousands of government troops are advancing "from all fronts" and urged the international community and Thailand to protect its people. The KNU called for humanitarian aid and pressure on the ruling military to cease using weapons on civilians. It also requested the world to sever economic and military ties with the junta, citing the need for protection from the escalating conflict. The statement was made amid a surge in fighting and displacement of civilians in the region.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as spike in yields pressures tech stocks
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Tuesday as a rise in US bond yields pressured tech stocks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 43.5 points, or 0.13%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The decline was attributed to a spike in yields hitting heavyweight tech stocks, while undervalued banks and industrial stocks that benefit from a re-opening economy edged higher.

site_title: Xiaomi plans US$15b foray into electric cars
summary: Xiaomi plans to invest approximately US$10 billion over the next decade to manufacture electric cars, entering China's booming EV market. Billionaire co-founder Lei Jun will lead a new division, with an initial 10 billion yuan investment. The company aims to raise the remaining funds through external financing, with plans to outsource car assembly to contract manufacturers. Xiaomi joins other tech giants and automakers in targeting the growing EV market, which is expected to see over 50% growth in sales this year.

site_title: Pandemic can't end without the vaccination of kids
summary: The US is nearing full vaccination of adults, but concerns remain about vaccination rates among children, who are less likely to be hospitalized with Covid-19 and face rare deaths from the disease. To sustainably drive down Covid-19 cases, the same urgency and coordination efforts must be applied to vaccinating children, who may initially have lower vaccination rates. Experts warn that without swift action, the pandemic may not end.

site_title: STI rises 0.48%, stays on track for best quarter in nine years
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.48% to 3,190.89, marking its sixth consecutive day of gains and on track for its best first-quarter performance in nine years. The index is up over 12% year-to-date, outpacing regional peers. Major Asian markets, including Japan and Hong Kong, also logged gains, while Australia and Malaysia bucked the trend. Despite concerns over US payroll data and economic uncertainty, analysts expect the market to remain on track.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets advance at open
summary: European stock markets opened strong on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.7% to 6,784.04 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gaining 0.6% to 14,900.33 points, and Paris' CAC 40 also increasing 0.6% to 6,050.16 points. The gains follow a record-breaking performance on Wall Street overnight and come after gains across most of Asia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Tuesday, tracking a record on Wall Street, driven by fresh economic recovery optimism. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.84%, reaching 28,577.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The gains follow a record-breaking performance on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries unit involved in development of new Vietnam industrial park
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit, Sembcorp Development, will develop a new industrial park in Vietnam's Quang Tri province, spanning 481 hectares. The project, involving a consortium with Becamex IDC Corporation, received an investment licence and is expected to be completed by mid-2021. Sembcorp Development's effective ownership will be 29.6%. The project is not expected to impact Sembcorp Industries' earnings per share or net asset value per share for the 2021 financial year.

site_title: What can SMEs learn from their larger counterparts amidst COVID-19
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can learn valuable lessons from larger counterparts during the COVID-19 pandemic. Key takeaways include: planning for every scenario, having a broad strategic plan, investing in the right technology, surrounding themselves with the right expertise, and knowing their value. SMEs can benefit from scenario mapping, having a short-term plan for cash flow issues, and seeking advice from external advisors. Having a strong plan in place that can be adapted to changing circumstances is crucial for SMEs to navigate economic uncertainty and set themselves up for future success.

images.alt_text: Ng Li Lian, Country Head of Business Banking, HSBC Singapore.

site_title: DBS to double down on China and India for growth in Asia
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, plans to double down on its presence in China and India as part of its growth strategy in the region. DBS chief Piyush Gupta outlined three key areas of focus in China, including a new securities joint venture, consumer finance market, and the Greater Bay Area. In India, Gupta assured shareholders that the bank's takeover of Lakshmi Vilas Bank was a strategic move to expand its digital banking presence. DBS expects to achieve a positive profit and loss statement in the next 12-24 months following the merger.

site_title: Hotel revenue stagnates in February as Singapore welcomes just 17,950 visitors
summary: Singapore's hotel industry experienced stagnant revenue in February, with visitor arrivals at 17,950, a 97.6% decline year-over-year. Hotel occupancy averaged 41.7% and revenue per average room fell 47.7% year-over-year. Analysts attribute the decline to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic and government demand for travelers' Stay-Home Notice facilities. Despite a possible recovery in the second half of 2021 and 2022, occupancy is expected to remain sub-par to 2019 levels, with some experts predicting a "rough ride" for the industry over the next few months.

site_title: Philippines to hasten private vaccine orders to boost supply
summary: The Philippines plans to speed up private vaccine orders to boost supply, allowing companies to import vaccines "at will" and source them from anywhere. This move aims to boost the country's lagging vaccination campaign, which is struggling with a new surge in infections and an economic recession. Businesses will be exempt from pooling orders, and vaccines will be tax-free, with faster customs clearance. The government will also provide financial assistance to 22.9 million individuals affected by the enhanced community quarantine.

site_title: SPH's H1 net profit up 26.1% as non-media segments see improvement
summary: SPH's net profit for the half year ended Feb 28 rose 26.1% to S$97.9 million, driven by improvements in non-media business segments as the economy recovers. Operating profit increased 16.6% to S$119.8 million, despite a 11.5% dip in operating revenue. Total revenue fell 4.2% to S$460.3 million, mainly due to its media segment. The company's non-media business segments contributed significantly to its recovery.

site_title: SPH undergoing strategic review to 'consider options for its various businesses'
summary: SPH is undergoing a strategic review to consider options for its various businesses, amid a challenging media environment. The review aims to unlock and maximize long-term shareholder value, with no assurance of a transaction. Credit Suisse has been appointed as the financial adviser. SPH shares closed unchanged at S$1.50 following the announcement, and the company advised shareholders to exercise caution when dealing in its shares.

images.alt_text: Singapore Press Holdings is undergoing a strategic review "to consider options for its various businesses", the firm announced on Tuesday after market close.

site_title: Tan Chong net profit down 95.5% in 2020 amid pandemic restrictions
summary: Tan Chong International, a car company, reported a 95.5% decline in net profit to HK$9.51 million in 2020 due to Covid-19 pandemic restrictions. Revenue fell 15.2% to HK$12.3 billion, mainly due to a 35% drop in sales volume for its motor vehicle distribution and retail division. The company attributed the decline to government lockdowns and restrictions in its 11 active markets, except for Vietnam operations.

site_title: OCBC, Food from the Heart open new community shop in Boon Lay
summary: OCBC Bank and Food from the Heart (FFTH) have opened a second "shop-for-free" community shop in Boon Lay, Singapore, serving 350 households. The initiative aims to provide needy families with food items, with a total of S$60,000 worth of food collected since its launch last year. The shop allows beneficiaries to collect 12 food items per month, with 98% of respondents preferring the shop-for-free concept over food packs or meal coupons. The community shop is expected to serve 1,000 needy families by the end of the year, with OCBC donating S$200,000.

images.alt_text: National Development Minister Desmond Lee (left) at the opening of the new Community Shop in Boon Lay on March 24.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as new Covid-19 cases put Easter plans on hold
summary: Australian shares fell 0.9% to 6,738.40, weighed down by mining and energy stocks amid concerns over new Covid-19 cases in Queensland, potentially extending a three-day lockdown into Easter. The S&P/ASX 200 index extended losses from the previous session. Most travel-related stocks declined, including Webjet and Flight Centre, while mining stocks, such as BHP Group and Rio Tinto, also fell.

site_title: 26 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 26 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 60,347. All cases were placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival. There were no community cases or deaths, and 15 who tested positive died of other causes. Globally, the pandemic has infected over 127 million and claimed more than 2.78 million lives.

site_title: GKE Corp to expand agriculture operations with newly obtained farm licence
summary: GKE Corp, a Catalist-listed integrated warehousing and logistics solutions provider, has been granted a farm licence for its wholly-owned subsidiary GKE Agritech to grow and sell agricultural produce commercially in Singapore. The company, which initially focused on kale cultivation, plans to expand its indoor cultivation area to 12,500 sq ft, allowing for increased production and sale of pesticide-free vegetables. Following the grant, shares of GKE Corp rose 2.3% to 13.4 cents.

site_title: 'Kill Bill' restaurant operator decries 'hypocrisy' in Tokyo's Covid-19 measures
