He has successfully accelerated the Covid-19 vaccine rollout, meeting his goal of 100 million vaccinations within 59 days, and has managed to get the $1.9 trillion stimulus plan approved by the Democratic-led House of Representatives. His "no drama" approach has restored confidence in US democracy, both at home and among foreign allies, and strategists say it may have been his most important contribution so far. Biden's popularity ratings remain high, but coming legislative fights over gun-control, voting rights, and infrastructure spending may test his ability to navigate these challenges.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) has secured a S$125 million, five-year sustainability-linked loan from OCBC Bank, with the interest margin tied to sustainability targets such as reducing energy consumption and improving property Green Mark Certification. The loan will refinance FEHT's existing borrowings.

site_title: EY Entrepreneur Of The Year open for nominations
summary: The EY Entrepreneur Of The Year (EOY) awards in Singapore are now open for nominations until May 15. The 20th annual awards recognize outstanding entrepreneurs, with a theme of "The Unstoppables". An independent judging panel will assess nominees across six globally benchmarked criteria, and the winner will represent Singapore at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award next year.

site_title: Biden needs to resist pressure from within
summary: US President Joe Biden faces pressure from within the Democratic Party's "Woke" brigade, which promotes radical social-cultural change. Despite polls showing that most Americans reject this approach, Biden must resist pressure to conform to the "woke" ideology. The "Woke" agenda, which prioritizes equality of outcome over equality of opportunity, is seen as divisive and creates resentment among white Americans. Biden's policies, such as the defunding of police and open borders, have been exploited by Republicans to polarize the debate and gain electoral support. Biden must choose between pandering to ideologues or embracing pragmatic policy approaches to avoid losing control of Congress in the midterm election.

site_title: Should the STI represent the economy or the market?
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) is being called to revamp to include more growth sectors such as e-commerce, technology, and healthcare, rather than its current focus on property and banks. Industry players suggest this could make the index more representative of the market, but it raises the question of whether the index should focus on the economy or the market. The STI's current focus on market interest, with strict liquidity and size criteria, has shifted its representation away from the economy since its 1998 revamp. Overhauling the index to represent the economy could be a challenge, but is worth exploring for the index to stay relevant and competitive.

site_title: Pertamina aims to restart Balongan refinery in 4-5 days after blaze
summary: Indonesian state oil company Pertamina aims to restart its Balongan refinery in 4-5 days after a massive blaze broke out, injuring five people. The fire was concentrated in storage tanks and did not affect the processing plant. Fuel stocks are secure, and Pertamina expects no disruptions to supply. The refinery, one of Pertamina's biggest, processes crude oil from the Duri and Minas fields and supplies fuel to Jakarta and western Java.

site_title: The swift collapse of a company built on debt
summary: Greensill Capital, a debt financing firm, rapidly collapsed due to its large debt obligations. The company had US$4.6 billion in outstanding debts to businesses worldwide and was relying on insurance policies to back these claims. A court hearing on March 1 revealed the firm's dire financial situation, with lawyers arguing that the insurance policies should be extended to avoid 50,000 job losses. The swift collapse raises concerns about opaque accounting practices, as Greensill Capital's financial state was not transparently disclosed to investors.

site_title: Bob Odenkirk's Nobody debuts at top of US box office; Godzilla vs Kong roars overseas
summary: Bob Odenkirk's revenge thriller "Nobody" debuted at the top of the US box office, earning $6.7 million from 2,460 venues. The film, directed by Ilya Naishuller, follows a mild-mannered suburban dad who becomes a vigilante after someone breaks into his house. With a budget of $16 million, the film is expected to break even and perform well due to positive word-of-mouth. In contrast, Godzilla vs Kong, a Warner Bros. film, dominated the international box office, earning $121 million from 28 countries, including a significant start in China.

site_title: Banks warn of losses after Archegos Capital stock unwind
summary: Nomura and Credit Suisse warned of significant losses after a US hedge fund, Archegos Capital, defaulted on margin calls, triggering a fire sale of stocks and sharp drops in share prices. Nomura faces a possible $2 billion loss, while Credit Suisse's loss could be "highly significant and material" to its first-quarter results. The default has caused market volatility, with Nasdaq 100 futures falling 1% and S&P 500 futures extending losses to 0.8%. Investors are concerned about systemic risks, but some believe the impact will be limited.

site_title: Suez Canal freed up, but backlog to hit producer prices, container supply
summary: The Suez Canal, a key global shipping route, has reopened after being blocked for six days by the massive container ship Ever Given. However, the backlog of vessels queuing to use the canal is expected to take at least six days to clear, causing disruptions to global trade. The delay may worsen the existing container shortage, which has been exacerbated by a surplus of exports from Asia to Western countries and the cancelling of new container orders last year due to the pandemic.

site_title: Penalising Integrated Shield policyholders an exercise in bad faith
summary: The author of a letter to the editor expresses outrage over the government's decision to penalize Integrated Shield policyholders for co-payments on rider policies, which were originally marketed to cover 100% of co-payments. The author argues that this change should only apply to new policies, not existing ones, as it amounts to an "exercise in bad faith" and unfairly penalizes innocent policyholders. The author calls on insurers to act with honour and not apply the new rule to existing policies, and for the government to ensure fair play in the insurance system.

site_title: Offer price for Jardine Strategic will not be raised: Jardine Matheson
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings has reaffirmed its US$33 per-share offer price for Jardine Strategic Holdings, despite criticism and potential legal action from some shareholders. The offer, a 20.2% premium to the closing price on March 5, has been deemed "fair value" by the company and its assessment committee. Shareholders with dissenting views can register on a platform to explore legal action, but a spokesperson for Jardine Matheson is confident that the acquisition price will be vindicated in any proceedings.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as large banks warn of losses
summary: US stocks fell Monday as large banks warned of potential losses due to exposure to Archegos Capital Management, a US fund that liquidated billions in stocks last week. Nomura and Credit Suisse, two top global banks, issued warnings of significant losses, citing their exposure to the fund. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, the S&P 500 shed 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.8%. Markets await key US economic reports this week, including the March jobs report and President Biden's infrastructure proposal.

site_title: Bilibili pouring billions into content amid streaming boom
summary: Bilibili, a Chinese video streaming service, raised $2.6 billion in its Hong Kong debut, valuing the company at $34 billion. The service plans to use the funds to enhance content and support creators, anticipating a surge in online video adoption. CEO Chen Rui predicts that internet users in China, nearly 1 billion, will eventually adopt online video, prioritizing content and user growth over profitability. Bilibili competes with social media companies and video streaming subsidiaries of Tencent and Alibaba, amidst a protracted sell-off in Chinese technology shares.

site_title: Deutsche Bank avoids Archegos loss after slow hedge fund exit
summary: Deutsche Bank has successfully de-risked its exposure to Archegos Capital Management without incurring any losses, despite agreeing to exit the business in 2019. The German lender significantly reduced its remaining client positions, avoiding a major hit. The transfer of assets to BNP Paribas is ongoing, with Deutsche Bank continuing to be liable for potential losses on holdings that haven't moved. This outcome is a relief for the bank, which had been trying to minimize its exposure to the family office.

site_title: Thai anti-government protesters defy police threat of arrests
summary: Hundreds of anti-government protesters in Thailand gathered on Monday, defying a police threat to make more arrests. The protesters, who have been calling for an end to military dominance of politics and monarchy reform, also demanded the release of jailed activists. The gathering comes after nearly 100 demonstrators were detained for breaching public health measures against the coronavirus. The situation remains tense, with the prospect of another confrontation between police and protesters.

site_title: Shen Yao to buy up to 20.25% stake in loss-making Real Estate Analytics
summary: Shen Yao Holdings agreed to buy up to 20.25% stake in loss-making Real Estate Analytics for about S$8.8 million. The deal, valued at S$8.8 million, will be funded by issuing 2.93 billion new shares at S$0.003 each. Shen Yao's management is familiar with REA's business, and the deal aims to diversify Shen Yao's investment portfolio and risk-return profile. The transaction is expected to negatively impact Shen Yao's net profit and earnings per share, pending shareholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Britain's stately homes struggling to survive
summary: Britain's stately homes, such as Kentwell Hall in eastern England, are struggling to survive due to critical repairs that cannot be afforded after the pandemic. The 450-year-old Tudor-era house has survived tumultuous history but was forced to close its doors to visitors, putting its future at risk. The UK's stately homes face an existential threat, highlighting the need for urgent funding and support to preserve these historic sites.

site_title: News Corp agrees to buy Houghton Mifflin unit for US$349m
summary: News Corp has agreed to buy the consumer arm of educational publisher Houghton Mifflin Harcourt for US$349 million, gaining access to high-profile novels from authors like George Orwell and JRR Tolkien. This is News Corp's second publishing acquisition in less than a week, following the purchase of Investor's Business Daily for US$275 million. The sale allows Houghton Mifflin to focus on K-12 education and accelerate growth momentum.

site_title: Traffic in Suez Canal resumes after stranded ship refloated
summary: Shipping traffic through Egypt's Suez Canal has resumed after the Ever Given, a 400-meter-long container ship, was refloated following a week-long blockage. The ship was partially refloated on Monday using tug boats and dredging work, and efforts to completely free it continued. The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) has said it can accelerate convoys through the canal once the ship is freed, with a backlog of 369 vessels waiting to transit the canal. The SCA estimates it could take 2.5-3 days to clear the backlog, and shipping disruptions could take weeks or months to unravel.

site_title: Why the American SPACs rocket is failing to take off in Europe
summary: European startups are avoiding special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) due to concerns over high costs and regulation. Only 10 SPAC listings have occurred in Europe in 2020 and 2021, with a total value of $1.3 billion, compared to 522 listings in the US with a value of over $300 billion. Established European companies, such as Klarna and Wise, prefer traditional initial public offerings (IPOs) over SPACs. The European market's relatively mature tech startups and stricter listing rules also contribute to this trend, with some investors warning of a potential bubble.

site_title: Singapore studying proposal from Hong Kong to re-open borders: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore is studying a proposal from Hong Kong to re-open their borders safely, following Hong Kong's successful control of the pandemic. The proposal, made by Hong Kong's Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development, Edward Yau, requires passengers to be vaccinated with two doses before taking quarantine-free bubble flights. The travel bubble was originally set to launch last November but was halted due to a spike in Covid-19 cases. Singapore will respond to Hong Kong's proposal shortly, Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung said, after Hong Kong's seven-day moving average of unknown infections dropped to fewer than five.

site_title: Newlywed suicide bombers identified in Indonesia church attack
summary: Two newlywed suicide bombers, linked to an extremist group, carried out a deadly attack on an Indonesian cathedral on Palm Sunday, injuring 20 people. The suspects, who were killed instantly, detonated a bomb packed with nails outside the church in Makassar city. Authorities have arrested others suspected in the plot, revealing the newlyweds' involvement with a pro-Islamic State group. The attack occurred during Holy Week celebrations.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust secures maiden sustainability-linked loan of S$125m from OCBC
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) has secured a S$125 million, five-year sustainability-linked loan from OCBC Bank. The loan will be used to refinance existing borrowings and is tied to sustainability targets, including energy consumption reduction and property Green Mark Certification improvements. If targets are met, interest margins will be reduced on a tiered basis. FEHT has 13 properties in Singapore and the facility agreement restricts changes to its manager and ownership. This marks OCBC's first sustainability-linked loan for a Reit.

site_title: Hong Fok says no privatisation or delisting of company planned
summary: Hong Fok Corporation has denied plans to privatize or delist its company, contrary to a previous article. The company has been making on-market trades to purchase shares, aiming to enhance earnings-per-share, manage capital structure, and buffer share price volatility. The share purchases are regulated and made in accordance with guidelines, ensuring the company's listing on the Singapore Exchange. The move follows a recent spike in the company's shares after a bullish commentary in The Straits Times.

site_title: Indonesia church bomb: explosives found in raids
summary: Indonesian police conducted raids, discovering 5.5 kg of explosives and arresting 13 suspected Islamist militants linked to Jamaah Ansharut Daulah, a group responsible for the Easter Sunday cathedral bombing in Makassar, which killed two and wounded 19. The bombers, a married couple, expressed intentions to die for their belief in a letter. Authorities believe the group was involved in a 2019 Philippine church attack, and 20 suspected members were arrested in January. The raids also uncovered ingredients for a powerful explosive, triacetone triperoxide.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.86 points to 1,611.28 on Monday, driven by higher trading volume of 6.707 billion lots worth RM 3.577 billion. The index saw more gainers than losers, with 431 stocks gaining and 654 losing value.

site_title: Partial refloating of jammed ship lifts hopes of reopening Suez Canal
summary: A partially refloated container ship, Ever Given, has lifted hopes for reopening Egypt's Suez Canal, which has been blocked for nearly a week. The 400-meter long ship was refloated after further dredging and excavation, with rescue workers using tug boats to free the vessel. The Suez Canal Authority (SCA) expects shipping activity to resume by noon on Monday, with the backlog of vessels estimated to take 2.5 to 3 days to clear. However, global shipping disruptions could take weeks or months to unravel.

site_title: Life Insurance Association warns of trade-offs in widening insurers' panel of doctors
summary: The Life Insurance Association (LIA) warns that including all private specialists on insurers' panels of doctors may drive up costs and premiums. In response to the Singapore Medical Association's (SMA) call for more inclusive panels, the LIA notes that such a move could lead to substantial cost increases and further premium increases for policyholders. The association suggests striking a balance and invites the SMA to discuss how to achieve this without disproportionately burdening policyholders with higher premiums.

site_title: Australian mall recovery bolsters SPH Reit's H1
summary: SPH Reit's first-half performance improved due to a quicker recovery in its Australian malls, with a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.44 cents for the period. Gross revenue increased 4.9% in Australia, while Singapore assets declined 6.7% due to Covid-19 rental relief. Despite this, the manager noted signs of recovery in tenant sales at Singapore malls and attributed 0.4% rent reversion to growing shoppers' confidence. The Reit's portfolio occupancy remained resilient at 98% as of February 2021.

site_title: Hong Kong to reopen pools and beaches, easing Covid rules
summary: Hong Kong is set to relax Covid-19 restrictions, allowing swimming pools and public beaches to reopen starting Thursday. The city will also increase capacity at movie theaters and theme parks to 75%, and propose easing curbs on religious gatherings. However, bars and karaoke venues will remain closed. The move comes after the city brought a recent outbreak under control, with a recent surge in cases linked to a gym largely contained through measures including testing and quarantine. This is the latest step in easing strict virus-related measures that have been in place for months.

site_title: S-Reit investors need not fear rising rates
summary: S-Reit investors in Singapore can breathe a sigh of relief despite rising US 10-year Treasury yields, as Reits still offer a decent spread to the 10-year government bond yield. Reits, such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Ascendas Reit, trade at yields of around 5% and have seen unit prices recover from lows in early March. While higher long-dated bond yields may pose a challenge, Reits can benefit from growth in the economy, increasing consumer spending, and rising business prospects, particularly in retail, hospitality, and industrial sectors. Reit managers can focus on growing net property income and making yield accretive acquisitions to mitigate the impact of higher yields.

site_title: Surging Etihad shifts fifth Boeing jet to cargo duty with demand surging
summary: Abu Dhabi's Etihad Airways is temporarily converting a fifth Boeing 777-300ER jetliner to cargo duty due to a surge in demand for dedicated air freight. The move comes as the Suez canal logjam and the COVID-19 pandemic drive a boom in online shopping, leading airlines to convert planes for cargo duty. Demand for air freight is expected to remain strong for the remainder of 2021 and into 2022, with airlines seeking to add additional aircraft to their fleets, including Boeing 747s.

site_title: China warns firms not to engage in politics over Xinjiang
summary: Chinese officials have warned foreign companies, including H&M, to refrain from making political statements about Xinjiang, amid growing tensions over human rights concerns. The Xinjiang government has rejected accusations of genocide and human rights abuses, blaming Western powers for "political manipulation." The warning comes as a wave of consumer boycotts in China targets companies that have criticized sourcing cotton from the region. The US and other Western governments have imposed sanctions on China over suspected human rights abuses in Xinjiang.

site_title: Thailand sees Chinese leading tourists to Phuket after reopening
summary: Thailand expects approximately two million foreign tourists, mainly from China and Europe, to visit Phuket in the second half of 2021 after the island reopens to vaccinated visitors from July 1. The influx of tourists is expected to generate around 105 billion baht (S$4.58 billion) in revenue. Thailand's gradual reopening of borders aims to revive its pre-pandemic tourism industry, which contributed about one-fifth of the country's economy. Phuket's plan to waive quarantine for inoculated visitors may pave the way for other popular destinations to end movement restrictions.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Asia's ESG investing outlook in 2021 and beyond (Ep 92)
summary: Fidelity International's director for Asian equities, Victoria Mio, discusses the outlook for ESG investing in Asia in 2021 and beyond. The annual global Analyst Survey 2021 shows growing sustainability awareness in Asia, with companies expected to achieve carbon neutrality in the coming decades. Key sectors, such as utilities and telecoms, are making more progress in carbon neutrality than the energy sector. Sustainable investors play a crucial role in forcing positive change in companies, and social issues may gain more emphasis in ESG investing.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Malaysia has paid S$102.8m in compensation for the termination of the High Speed Rail project. Sembcorp Marine partnered with GE Renewable Energy on a UK wind farm project spanning 593 sq km with a 1.4 GW capacity. A new code of conduct for fair tenancy negotiations in Singapore is set to be legislated. Jardine Matheson Holdings will not raise its offer price for a US$5.5 billion buyout of Jardine Strategic Holdings. Keppel and Facebook are developing an undersea cable linking South-east Asia and America, while Ascendas India Trust acquired two IT buildings in Bangalore for S$268.2m.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of High Speed Rail Terminal in Jurong East. Malaysia has paid Singapore S$102.8 million in compensation following the termination of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project.

site_title: Europe: Equities ahead at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose in opening deals on Monday, driven by a record-breaking pre-weekend rally on Wall Street and falling oil prices. The FTSE 100 index gained 0.4%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also rose 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. The positive sentiment was also influenced by progress in unblocking the Suez Canal.

site_title: Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF generates -1.8% returns in 2020, expects 2021 recovery
summary: The Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF generated a 12-month return of -1.8% in 2020, compared to the benchmark's -1.7% return. The ETF has returned 7% since its inception in 2017, slightly below the benchmark's 7.4% return. The manager described 2020 as a challenging year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but expects a recovery in 2021 as low interest rates support the sector's valuation and vaccination efforts encourage business normalisation.

site_title: High Court issues winding up order against previous EH-Reit manager; liquidators to be appointed
summary: The Singapore High Court issued a winding up order against Eagle Hospitality Reit Management (EHRM) on March 19, ordering the appointment of liquidators due to insolvency. The order follows an application by EHRM to wind up, and follows numerous breaches by the manager of Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit). The trust is now being managed by DBS Trustee after a proposed change of manager fell through. 15 out of 18 properties in the trust's portfolio are up for sale, with a stalking-horse bidder, Madison Phoenix LLC, set to act as the lead buyer.

site_title: Philippine card payments to grow 15.4% in 2021, with 12.3% CAGR through 2024: report
summary: The Philippine card payments market is forecast to grow 15.4% in 2021, rebounding from a 7.4% decline in 2020, according to a report by GlobalData. The value of card payments is expected to reach 2.87 trillion pesos (S$79.81 billion) by 2024, with a 12.3% compound annual growth rate (CAGR). The market's growth is driven by factors such as the entry of digital-only banks, favourable government regulations, and improving financial awareness, following the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the country's economy.

site_title: STI gains 0.56% on general macro optimism
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.56% on Monday, marking its fifth consecutive day of gains, driven by general optimism over global economic recovery and steady vaccine rollouts. The Straits Times Index advanced 17.62 points to finish at 3,175.57. Major Asian markets followed suit, while South Korea and Australia posted losses. Analysts attribute the positive mood to successful vaccine rollouts in the US and UK, and rising global macro optimism, but warned that sentiments could turn negative if pending data releases disappoint or if the pandemic worsens in Europe.

site_title: Laminaar Aviation Infotech to deliver new software for Changi Airport ground handling
summary: dnata Singapore has engaged Laminaar Aviation Infotech to deliver a new software system for its ground handling operations at Changi Airport. The system, based on Laminaar's proprietary ARMS platform, aims to enhance efficiency, reduce turnaround time, and enable paperless operations. The system will include machine learning-based predictive analytics to optimize resources and achieve on-time performance. Delivery is expected to occur in phases, with the base module to be rolled out in mid-2021 and final deployment by mid-2022.

site_title: Singapore minister pessimistic on Myanmar, says resolution may take time
summary: Singapore's foreign minister Vivian Balakrishnan expressed pessimism about resolving the crisis in Myanmar, calling it an "unfolding tragedy" that will take time. He urged the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) to take a unified stance and offer constructive assistance to Myanmar. The situation has resulted in 462 deaths, and Balakrishnan emphasized the need for Asean to consider a high-level meeting to address the crisis, despite divergent views among member countries.

images.alt_text: Singapore's foreign minister Vivian Balakrishnan has called the situation in Myanmar "an unfolding tragedy" that will take time to overcome, and said it was essential for Southeast Asian countries to have a position on how to respond.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide as institutional sell-off outweighs recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Monday as institutional investors sold shares, outweighing optimism over a stimulus- and vaccine-led recovery. The Kospi fell 0.16% to 3,036.04 after a net sell of $629.14 million. Despite this, South Korea's exports are expected to grow at their sharpest pace in 29 months in March, driven by semiconductor and car sales. US President Joe Biden's infrastructure spending plans and vaccinations are also lifting recovery hopes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.71% and the Topix index climbing 0.46%. The market was supported by gains on Wall Street, particularly from dividend buying and progress in US coronavirus vaccinations. Key movers included Sony, Uniqlo, and Toyota, while Nomura Holdings plummeted 16.33% after reporting a potential US$2 billion loss.

site_title: Britain's stately homes struggle to survive with Covid restrictions
summary: Britain's stately homes, such as Kentwell Hall and Powderham Castle, are struggling to survive due to the pandemic. Owners, including Patrick Phillips, have had to halt critical repairs and face financial burdens, with 90% of their 2019 turnover lost in 2020. Historic Houses, representing 1,500 privately owned homes, is calling on the government to reopen these businesses faster, citing the need to address urgent repairs and prevent a "stored-up crisis" of rot and damp. The industry employs 34,400 people, with around 3,000 facing redundancy.

site_title: Tan Ching Yee re-appointed ACRA chairman; Ong Chong Tee appointed deputy
summary: Tan Ching Yee has been re-appointed as chairman of the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) board, effective April 1. Ong Chong Tee, Deputy Managing Director at the Monetary Authority of Singapore, has been appointed as deputy chairman. Ong will leave MAS on March 31. This appointment brings Ong's board experience to ACRA, following previous roles with the Housing & Development Board, Urban Redevelopment Authority, Central Provident Fund, and Singapore Land Authority.

site_title: 21 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 21 new Covid-19 cases on March 29, bringing the total to 60,321. All cases were imported and had been placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival. This includes a Singaporean who returned from India.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.87 points to 28,338.30. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, adding 0.50% and 0.18% respectively. Traders were unable to extend last week's gains, with attention shifting to the upcoming US jobs data release.

site_title: Malaysia pays S$102.8m in compensation for High Speed Rail termination
summary: Malaysia has paid Singapore S$102.8 million in compensation for the termination of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project. The payment includes reimbursement for project costs and payment for the earlier extension of the project's suspension. The termination was due to disagreements over proposed changes, including the removal of the assets company responsible for providing rolling stock and rail assets. Both countries remain committed to maintaining good relations and cooperating on future projects, including restoring air travel and commuting via the Causeway.

images.alt_text: Artist's impression of High Speed Rail Terminal in Jurong East. Malaysia has paid Singapore S$102.8 million in compensation following the termination of the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail (HSR) project.

site_title: NUS gets S$50m from Sea for AI, data science efforts, largest corporate gift to date
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) has received a record-breaking S$50 million corporate gift from Sea Limited, the parent company of Shopee, Garena, and SeaMoney. The gift will support research and education in AI and data science, scholarships for students, and talent development. This is the largest corporate gift NUS has received to date. The partnership aims to enhance strategic initiatives and nurture future tech talent, complementing the government's efforts in the area.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall after Brisbane announces lockdown
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% on Monday, weighed down by losses in technology stocks, amid concerns of a slow economic recovery. A three-day lockdown in Brisbane, Australia's third-largest city, raised fears of a potential spread of the UK variant of the virus. Technology stocks, including Afterpay and Xero, tumbled 2.8% and 3.5%, respectively, with analysts attributing the losses to profit-taking. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,799.50.

site_title: Credit Suisse warns of 'significant' losses from exiting hedge fund positions
summary: Credit Suisse is warning of potential 'significant' losses from exiting its positions with a US-based hedge fund, which could impact its first quarter results. The bank did not quantify the loss but described it as "material." The exit is part of the bank's efforts to reduce risk and improve its overall financial performance.

site_title: Indonesia Pertamina aims to restarts refinery in days after blaze
summary: Indonesia's state-owned oil company Pertamina aims to restore operations at its Balongan oil refinery in West Java within four to five days after a massive blaze broke out, injuring five people. The fire, which started during bad weather, is concentrated in storage tanks and has not affected the processing plant. Pertamina has secured fuel stocks to supply Indonesia, including for the upcoming Islamic holidays, and will use fuel from other refineries to help provide supplies while the Balongan refinery is shut.

site_title: Keppel, Facebook to develop undersea cable linking South-east Asia and America
summary: Keppel Telecommunications & Transportation is partnering Facebook and Telkom Indonesia to develop the 15,000km Bifrost Cable System, connecting Singapore, Indonesia, the Philippines, Guam, and the US west coast by 2024. The project aims to provide low latency and competitive pricing, benefiting regional governments and businesses. Facebook is also developing Echo, another undersea cable system, in partnership with Google and XL Axiata.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start slightly lower on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks started trading slightly lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.07% to 28,317.32. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.33% and the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange increased 0.22%. This follows a strong finish to last week.

site_title: Offer price for Jardine Strategic will not be raised: Jardine Matheson
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings (JMH) has reaffirmed its offer price of US$33 per share for Jardine Strategic Holdings (JSH), stating it is "fair value" after rigorous assessment. Despite criticism and dissenting shareholders seeking appraisal of fair value in Bermuda, JMH remains confident its offer price will be vindicated. If the court values JSH above US$33, JMH will pay dissenting shareholders the difference, but if below, they'll only receive the offer price.

site_title: China's Sinopec raises 2021 capital expenditure by 23.8%
summary: China Petroleum & Chemical Corp (Sinopec), Asia's largest oil refiner, plans to increase capital spending by 23.8% to 167.2 billion yuan in 2021, up from 135.1 billion yuan in 2020. The company aims to raise refinery throughput by 5.5% and increase domestic refined fuel sales by nearly 9% this year, driven by recovering oil prices and energy demand. Sinopec expects to spend 66.8 billion yuan on upstream exploration and construction of liquefied natural gas terminals.

site_title: Vietnam Q1 growth picks up as virus is contained
summary: Vietnam's economy expanded 4.48% in Q1 2021, beating the same period last year, thanks to successful pandemic containment. The government aims for 6.5% annual growth, with vaccination efforts, business support, and public investment key to achieving this goal. Vietnam has vaccinated over 45,000 people, mostly frontline workers, and its first domestically developed vaccine is expected to be ready for use next year.

site_title: Renesas says damage from fire at chip factory worse than first thought
summary: Renesas Electronics Corp. has revised its estimate of damage from a fire at its chip-making plant in northeast Japan, stating that 17 machines are inoperable instead of the initial 11. The company expects a month to resume production and replacing damaged machines could take several months, potentially exacerbating global chip shortages affecting car and electronic device production. Renesas, which accounts for 30% of the global microcontroller market, has seen its shares rise 0.5% following the news.

images.alt_text: Renesas Electronics Corp now believes damage from a fire at its chip-making plant in northeast Japan was more extensive than first thought.

site_title: New Abu Dhabi plant to produce Covid-19 vaccine from China's Sinopharm
summary: A new pharmaceutical plant in Abu Dhabi will start producing a COVID-19 vaccine from Sinopharm under a joint venture with Group 42. The plant, set to begin production later this year, will have a capacity of 200 million doses per year. The vaccine, known as Hayat-Vax in the UAE, has already been produced in Ras al-Khaimah. The partnership aims to diversify the UAE's economy and expand Chinese diplomacy in the Gulf region.

site_title: England eases coronavirus curbs but Europe reels from surges
summary: England has eased its coronavirus lockdown restrictions, allowing outdoor gatherings of up to six people and the resumption of amateur sports. However, other European countries are struggling to contain Covid-19 surges, with France and Germany imposing new restrictions. The US is also warning of a potential surge if curbs are eased too quickly. Despite the easing of restrictions in England, the UK's Prime Minister Boris Johnson cautioned that the European wave could hit Britain. Globally, over 2.7 million lives have been claimed by the pandemic, and the UN Secretary-General criticized wealthy nations for stockpiling vaccines.

site_title: Taiwan says no progress in BioNTech vaccine talks
summary: Taiwan's Health Minister Chen Shih-chung stated that there has been no progress in talks with BioNTech for a Covid-19 vaccine deal, despite ongoing discussions. The issue began when BioNTech pulled out of a 5 million dose deal at the last minute, potentially due to Chinese pressure. With Taiwan already acquiring Moderna's vaccine and developing its own domestically made vaccines, the urgency for the BioNTech vaccine has decreased, making a final agreement less likely.

site_title: Six changes to expect with new code of conduct for fair tenancy
summary: Singapore is introducing a new code of conduct for fairer lease negotiations between landlords and retail tenants. The code includes six key changes, effective by June 1, including a single rental computation, early termination of leases under exceptional conditions, and restrictions on exclusivity clauses. Tenants can now terminate leases early under certain conditions, and landlords can only terminate leases early for substantial redevelopment or asset enhancement works. Exclusivity clauses are also prohibited, and landlords can only require tenants to have public liability insurance coverage of up to S$3 million. The Fair Tenancy Industry Committee will monitor industry compliance and provide guidance on the new code.

site_title: UK's Johnson urges caution as some lockdown measures ease
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged caution as lockdown measures in England eased, citing rising cases in Europe and new virus variants. Up to six people can meet outdoors, and outdoor sports facilities can be used with social contact limits. The government will also establish an Office for Health Promotion to tackle obesity and improve mental health. Despite a successful vaccination program, concerns remain over supplies and the emergence of new variants. Johnson emphasized the need to stick to rules and get vaccinated to prevent the spread of the virus.

site_title: More than a fifth of small UK exporters have temporarily halted EU sales
summary: More than a fifth of small UK exporters have temporarily halted EU sales, with 30 out of 132 exporters reporting the stoppage, while 5 have done so permanently. The disruption is attributed to new bureaucracy and rules following the UK's post-Brexit trade deal with the EU. The Federation of Small Businesses survey highlights the challenges faced by British companies since the agreement came into force on January 1, causing delays and disruptions.

site_title: Australia sees record A$136b of iron ore exports this financial year
summary: Australia is expected to log a record A$136 billion in iron ore exports this financial year, driven by global steel-making recovery and miners extracting more iron ore from Western Australia's Pilbara region. The country's iron ore shipments are projected to rise to 1.1 billion tonnes by 2025-26, maintaining its dominant market share despite Brazilian supply recovery. Gains from new energy materials like copper, lithium, and nickel are expected to offset lower thermal coal exports.

site_title: Japan's vaccine minister says inoculation pace to accelerate in May
summary: Japan's vaccine minister, Taro Kono, announced that the country's inoculation pace will accelerate in May, with a goal of 10 million doses per week. The Tokyo Olympics, scheduled for July, will not factor into the vaccination schedule. The government aims to have enough doses for 126 million people by June, and has arranged to buy 120 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine to be made domestically. As of Friday, over 780,000 people have received at least one vaccine dose, but concerns about a potential "fourth wave" of the pandemic remain.

site_title: South Korea's Moon sacks top economic aide for raising rent amid home price uproar
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in fired his top economic policy advisor, Kim Sang-jo, amid public outcry over skyrocketing home prices in Seoul, where rent increased by 14% in July despite a 5% cap. Kim Sang-jo's departure comes as home prices have risen over 50% since 2017, straining Moon's approval ratings and hurting his party's support ahead of a by-election. Lee Ho-seung, the president's senior economic secretary, has taken his place.

site_title: Thailand preparing for possible refugee exodus from Myanmar: PM
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha announced the country's preparation for a potential refugee influx from neighboring Myanmar amid anti-coup demonstrations. Thailand aims to balance human rights with preparedness, but the exact number of expected refugees remains unclear. This comes as violence escalates in Myanmar, prompting concerns about a potential exodus.

site_title: Chinese streaming site Bilibili sinks 6% on Hong Kong debut
summary: Chinese streaming site Bilibili sank 6% on its first day of trading on the Hong Kong stock exchange, despite raising $2.6 billion. The decline follows a global sell-off in Chinese tech shares amid US-China tensions. Bilibili's shares closed 1% below its listing price after a strong debut in the US, where the company is already listed. The company's IPO comes as Hong Kong sees a decrease in investor enthusiasm for Chinese tech firms, following last week's underwhelming debut of Baidu.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains after Wall Street record, eyes on US data
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday, tracking a record-breaking lead from Wall Street, as investors focus on the economic recovery. A below-forecast US inflation reading provided support, easing fears of tighter monetary policies. Key events this week include US jobs data and manufacturing activity figures, which may influence traders.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices rise 0.9% in Feb; fastest pace in nine months
summary: Hong Kong private home prices rose 0.9% in February, the fastest pace in nine months, driven by improved sentiment over new coronavirus vaccines and low interest rates. This is the first month of growth since May. Realtors expect a high transaction volume in March, with Cushman & Wakefield predicting a 5% quarterly rise in home prices from April to June. However, high unemployment may weigh on the market in the mid-term, with seasonally adjusted unemployment at 7.2% in the December-February period.

site_title: South Korea's expert panel says J&J Covid-19 vaccine safe, effective for approval
summary: South Korea's expert panel has recommended the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine as safe and effective, moving it closer to regulatory approval. The single-dose vaccine will be the third authorized in South Korea, following AstraZeneca and Pfizer/BioNTech, which require two doses. The country has an agreement for 6 million doses and plans to administer them from the second quarter. The final approval will be decided after two more expert committees meet.

site_title: How the American SPACs rocket failed to take off in Europe
summary: European startups are shying away from using special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) to go public, citing concerns over high costs and regulation. Despite having only 10 SPAC listings in Europe in 2020 and 2021, worth about $1.3 billion, European companies like Klarna and Wise prefer traditional initial public offerings (IPOs). This reluctance reflects the relative maturity of European tech startups before going public, with many valued at over $1 billion having years of operating history. Some investors also express concerns about the risks of untried companies merging with SPACs, potentially leading to a bubble.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE initiates 'buy' on ThaiBev on post-Covid recovery hopes
summary: Maybank KE has initiated a "buy" call on Thai Beverage PCL (ThaiBev) due to post-Covid-19 recovery hopes. Analysts expect a 6.1% compound annual growth rate from FY2020 to FY2023, driven by ThaiBev's strong presence in Thailand and Vietnam, and its diversified portfolio of spirits and beer brands. A potential initial public offering of brewery unit BeerCo could be a near-term re-rating catalyst, lifting ThaiBev's target price by 30%. Shares of ThaiBev rose 2.08% following the report.

site_title: Malaysia's Feb exports jump 17.6% y-o-y, beat forecast
summary: Malaysia's exports in February rose 17.6% year-over-year, exceeding forecasts, driven by higher shipments of electrical and electronic goods and commodity-based products. This beats the median forecast of 8.8% growth. Imports also surged 12.7% year-over-year, outpacing the 3.9% expected rise. The strong export performance is a positive indicator for Malaysia's economy.

site_title: French pharma giant faces verdict on weight loss pill deaths
summary: A French court will decide whether pharmaceutical giant Servier deliberately ignored warnings about its weight loss pill Mediator, which is linked to hundreds of deaths. The drug was withdrawn in 2009 due to heart problems, but Servier faces charges of manslaughter, deceit, and fraud. Over 6,500 plaintiffs, including France's health insurance funds, seek $1.2 billion in damages. Servier denies allegations of knowingly concealing risks, but its former executive admitted to "mistakes" during the trial. The verdict may result in criminal fines and jail time for Servier executives.

site_title: Brokers' take: Banks, Singtel, Wilmar the most negatively hit by MSCI rule change
summary: DBS, OCBC, UOB, Singtel, and Wilmar are the most negatively affected by the MSCI rule change, which allows foreign-listed shares into its MSCI Singapore Index. DBS will witness the largest impact, with its weight expected to fall 4.7 percentage points between May 2021 and February 2022. Analysts predict a higher volatility in the MSCI Singapore Index relative to the Straits Times Index, with potential for the former to outperform in the medium to long term. UOBKH has "buy" calls for OCBC, Singtel, and Wilmar, while maintaining a "hold" call for DBS.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch higher as Suez Canal blockage lifts commodities
summary: Australian shares edged up 0.1% to 6,830.40, driven by higher commodity prices and concerns over a potential Suez Canal blockage disrupting global supplies. Iron ore exports are expected to reach a record A$136 billion this financial year, boosting the mining sector. Energy stocks also rose, with oil prices spiking on Suez Canal worries, while technology stocks curbed gains due to declines in Megaport and Afterpay.

images.alt_text: Australian shares edged up on Monday, as higher commodity prices lifted miners and energy stocks on worries that global supplies of crude and refined products could be

site_title: Ever Given container ship blocking Suez Canal re-floated, undergoing checks: sources
summary: The Ever Given container ship, which blocked the Suez Canal for nearly a week, has been almost fully re-floated and restarted its engines, raising hopes for the canal's reopening. The ship had been straightened and will undergo initial inspections before being moved. The re-floating was confirmed by shipping sources and ship-tracking services, with the ship's status changed to "under way" on its website. The canal's reopening is crucial for global shipping, with 15% of world shipping traffic passing through it, and is expected to reduce costs and delays for companies.

site_title: Snap lockdown ordered in Brisbane after virus outbreak
summary: A three-day lockdown has been ordered for over 2 million people in Brisbane, Australia, after a cluster of coronavirus cases was detected. The lockdown, which started on Monday, comes after seven people tested positive for Covid-19, the first significant community outbreak in Australia in weeks. Schools, restaurants, and bars will close, but people can still leave home for essential work and medical care. The lockdown is aimed at preventing a longer lockdown and is part of the state's efforts to curb the spread of Covid-19, with the vaccine rollout also being addressed.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated bright signs in economy in March even as it reviewed policy tools
summary: The Bank of Japan debated early signs of economic recovery despite its ultra-loose monetary policy. Policymakers saw Japan's economy shifting away from a downward trend, with exports and output remaining firm. The BOJ decided on steps to make its policy tools sustainable, aiming to fire up inflation to its 2% target. The review came as the bank reviewed policy tools to weather a prolonged Covid-19 economic blow.

site_title: Two Australian Cabinet ministers demoted after dual rape scandals
summary: Two Australian Cabinet ministers, Linda Reynolds and Christian Porter, were demoted from top cabinet posts amid dual rape scandals. Reynolds, the defence minister, was removed after allegations of mishandling an investigation and referring to a staffer as a "lying cow". Porter, the attorney-general, is accused of raping a 16-year-old student in 1988, an allegation he denies. Both will remain in government but manage less coveted portfolios. The demotions follow weeks of mounting public pressure and protests across Australia calling for gender equality and an end to sexual violence.

site_title: US set for big jobs surge with more vaccinated and economy picks up
summary: The US labor market is expected to experience a significant surge in employment, with economists projecting a 643,000 increase in non-farm payrolls and a decline in the unemployment rate to 6% in March. Vaccination efforts and economic activity, including robust manufacturing, are driving the recovery. Policymakers, including the Federal Reserve and Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, express confidence in the labor market's rebound, with the goal of workforce participation expansion.

site_title: Oil edges lower as salvage operation in Suez Canal goes on
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Monday, with Brent oil down 18 cents to $64.39 a barrel and US crude falling 22 cents to $60.75 a barrel. The decline comes as a salvage operation continues to clear the blocked Suez Canal, with hundreds of ships backed up. Despite expectations of lower OPEC output, oil prices remain volatile, influenced by the ongoing pandemic and trade disruptions. The market is expected to stabilize as the salvage operation progresses, with prices potentially tightening due to increased water levels.

images.alt_text: Oil was slightly lower on Monday, relatively placid after four sessions of wild swings in price, as efforts continued to dig out the giant container ship clogging the Suez Canal and little new emerged in the demand picture.

site_title: EU condemns 'unacceptable' military violence in Myanmar
summary: The European Union (EU) has condemned the "unacceptable" military violence in Myanmar, following the killing of at least 107 civilians by security forces during anti-coup protests. EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell described the violence as "horror and of shame," calling it unacceptable on Myanmar's "Armed Forces Day." The EU's condemnation comes as the Myanmar military continues to face widespread protests and international pressure over its handling of the crisis.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 1.06 points, or 0.07%, to 1,602.48. Volume was 308.58 million lots worth RM131.43 million. Gainers outpaced losers 325 to 123.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending Wall Street's rally as coronavirus vaccines become more available. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.95% to 29,454.67, while the Topix index gained 0.72% to 1,998.40. Buying for dividends also supported the Japanese market.

site_title: Nomura flags US$2b loss, cancels bond issue; shares plummet
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc. reported a possible US$2 billion loss at a US subsidiary, citing transactions with a US client, and canceled a US$3.25 billion bond issuance. The loss is linked to Archegos Capital Management's trades, which caused drops in numerous company stock prices. Nomura's shares plummeted 16% in early trade, but analysts believe the impact on its long-term outlook will be limited. The Japanese government will monitor the situation, and the Financial Services Agency will share information with the Bank of Japan.

images.alt_text: Nomura Holdings Inc on Monday flagged a possible US$2 billion loss at a US subsidiary, prompting Japan's biggest brokerage and investment bank to shelve a hefty bond issuance and sending its stock tumbling by the most in over a decade.

site_title: Goldman Sachs' reversal on hedge fund manager puts bank at nexus of margin call mayhem
summary: Goldman Sachs reversed its decision to blacklist former hedge fund manager Bill Hwang in 2018, despite his guilty plea to insider trading. Hwang's firm paid Goldman tens of millions of dollars in commissions, leading the bank to reconsider its stance. This move has raised concerns about margin call mayhem, as Hwang's firm could be vulnerable to a massive withdrawal of funds. The decision has also sparked questions about Goldman's risk management and its ability to handle complex clients.

site_title: UAE, China launch project to produce Sinopharm vaccine
summary: The UAE and China have launched a joint project to produce the Sinopharm coronavirus vaccine, marking the first vaccine production line in the Gulf nation. The UAE, which has a high vaccination rate, has already approved multiple vaccines, including Sinopharm and Pfizer. The new project aims to contribute to global efforts in combating the pandemic. Commercial production details have not been specified.

site_title: Troops fire at funeral as Myanmar mourns bloodiest day since coup
summary: Myanmar security forces fired at a funeral on Sunday, killing at least one person and injuring others, as the country mourns the bloodiest day since the military coup. The crackdown on protests, which killed 114 people the previous day, has drawn widespread condemnation from Western nations, including the US, EU, and Germany. The UN Special Rapporteur for Myanmar called for the junta to be isolated and its access to weapons halted. The military has maintained its grip on power despite daily protests and international pressure, with the leader saying the military would protect the people and strive for democracy.

site_title: More than 360 vessels stranded in Suez logjam
summary: More than 360 vessels are stranded in the Mediterranean and Red Sea due to the Suez Canal blockage caused by the MV Ever Given. The blockage, which occurred on Tuesday, has resulted in a maritime traffic jam with estimated total value of goods stuck at sea ranging from $3 billion to $9.6 billion. Industry experts have estimated the total value of goods marooned at sea at anywhere between $3 billion and $9.6 billion.

site_title: Japan's biggest banks face climate votes at AGMs as activism grows
summary: Japan's two largest banks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group, are facing climate-related resolutions at their upcoming annual shareholder meetings. The proposals, sponsored by activist groups, call for the banks to align their investments and financing with the 2015 Paris climate accord. This follows similar resolutions at Mizuho Financial Group, where a proposal to align the company's business with the Paris accord was defeated but showed support for environmental issues was increasing. The push for climate action comes as policymakers and regulators pressure banks to accelerate the transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Suicide bombing at Indonesian Catholic church wounds 14
summary: A suicide bombing attack on a Catholic church in Makassar, Indonesia, wounded 14 people on the first day of Easter Holy Week. Two bombers detonated devices outside the church, killing themselves, and police have identified one of the attackers as part of a militant group involved in a 2018 attack in the Philippines. Authorities are investigating potential links to recent militant arrests and have condemned the attack as terrorism, urging people to remain calm.

site_title: 'Oil for vaccines', offers Venezuela's Maduro as Covid bites
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro offered "oil for vaccines" as his country faces a second wave of coronavirus. Maduro proposed that Venezuela produce and export oil to obtain the vaccines it needs. The country has only authorized the use of two vaccines, the Russian Sputnik V and Chinese Sinopharm, due to economic sanctions affecting its oil sector. Venezuela has registered around 150,000 coronavirus cases and 1,500 deaths, with concerns rising over a highly contagious Brazilian strain of the virus.

site_title: Sembcorp Marine partners GE Renewable Energy on UK wind farm project
summary: SembCorp Marine has partnered with GE Renewable Energy on a £600 million (S$1.12 billion) contract to supply a high-voltage direct current electrical system for the UK-based Sofia Offshore Wind Farm. The 1.4 gigawatt project, spanning 593 square kilometers, will power 1.2 million homes with clean energy. Construction will begin this year, with delivery and installation set for 2023. This deal marks SembMarine's largest partnership since its demerger from Sembcorp Industries last year and supports RWE Renewables' wind energy supply in the UK.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to acquire two IT buildings in Bangalore for 14.41b rupees
summary: Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) plans to acquire two IT buildings in Bangalore's Hebbal area for approximately 14.41 billion rupees, as part of a forward purchase agreement with Gardencity Realty. The acquisition will increase a-iTrust's portfolio size by 7.2% to 24.9 million sq ft. The trust will fund the project through debt in the initial stage and construction period, with the forward purchase acquisition to take place after construction completion, subject to certain conditions. This deal will establish a-iTrust's presence in Hebbal, a growing IT/ITES micro-market.

images.alt_text: The two buildings are part of a project comprising three buildings spread across two land parcels with an aggregate net leasable area of about 2.26 million square feet.

site_title: UN chief criticises wealthy countries for vaccine 'stockpile'
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres criticized wealthy countries for creating a "stockpile" of COVID-19 vaccines, calling for fair distribution to help end the pandemic. He expressed concern over the "self-interest" of rich countries and the difficulties faced by the Covax international system due to vaccine hoarding. Guterres urged a global vaccination plan, citing the need to vaccinate populations worldwide to end the pandemic. He also warned against unequal access to vaccination passports, which could exacerbate the pandemic's impact on developing countries.

site_title: Alstom makes a sustained push for green solutions in the rail business
summary: Alstom, a French multinational, is focusing on green solutions in the rail industry after acquiring Bombardier Transportation. The company sees growth opportunities in Asia and beyond, driven by governments' ambitions to invest in rail transport and reduce CO2 emissions. Alstom's Region President for Asia-Pacific, Ling Fang, believes high-speed rail will connect countries, promoting economic and social benefits. The company aims to develop new green solutions to manage passenger flow and control the spread of COVID-19. With the acquisition, Alstom has become the largest player in Singapore's rail market, and its combined group has a significant order book and revenue.

images.alt_text: Ms Fang believes that, in the longer term, high-speed rail still has a future in South-east Asia, as countries look to be more linked together for economic and social benefit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: a-iTrust, Sembmarine, Tianjin Zhong Xin, DBS, iFast, Nanofilm
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singapore companies reported new developments on Monday. a-iTrust will spend $268.2 million to acquire two buildings in an IT Park in Bangalore. Sembcorp Marine won a £1.12 billion contract to supply electrical systems for a UK-based offshore wind farm. DBS appointed a new non-executive director, while iFast launched its stocks and ETF brokerage services in Malaysia. Nanofilm Technologies was included in two FTSE indices, and Shangri-La Asia posted a net loss of $460.2 million for its full year ended December 2020. Trading halts were also requested by Soilbuild Business Space Reit and Hong Leong Asia.

site_title: Boeing resumes 787 deliveries as widespread inspections loom
summary: Boeing has resumed deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner jets, handing over one plane to United Airlines, after halting production due to structural integrity flaws found in dozens of aircraft. The company is undertaking repairs and forensic inspections, which could take up to a month and cost hundreds of millions of dollars. This move comes as the US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) tightens scrutiny on Boeing following two fatal 737 MAX crashes. Deliveries are expected to resume this month, with the goal of resuming production as planned.

site_title: Argentina president says IMF debt 'unpayable'
summary: Argentina President Alberto Fernandez stated that the country's debt to the International Monetary Fund is "unpayable" in its original form. He expressed concerns over the country's ability to pay $18 billion in 2022 and $19 billion in 2023, amidst a recession since 2018 and inflation expected to reach 48% this year. Fernandez seeks to renegotiate the debt to obtain the best advantages, aiming for macroeconomic sustainability and safeguarding the post-Covid recovery.

site_title: How to play your (credit) cards right
summary: OCBC Bank advises consumers to use banking apps to set limits and pay full sums owed to avoid debt traps and maximize rewards. Credit cards can help regulate cash flow, but instant gratification can lead to overconsumption and excess debt. With 38% of Singapore millennials paying only the minimum sum on their credit cards, it's essential to set a manageable spending limit and track finances. Mobile apps can help set limits, track expenses, and alert users when bills are due, making it easier to avoid late fees and scams.

images.alt_text: To avoid falling prey to scam activity, which tends to increase during a crisis, provide card credentials only to reputable e-commerce sites - if the site is new or unfamiliar, customers are advised to exercise extra caution, says Vincent Tan, head of cards business, OCBC.

To avoid falling prey to scam activity, which tends to increase during a crisis, provide card credentials only to reputable e-commerce sites - if the site is new or unfamiliar, customers are advised to exercise extra caution, says Vincent Tan (above), head of cards business, OCBC.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Monday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.3% to 3,166.30. Gainers outnumbered losers 113 to 25, driven by positive Wall Street leads and gains in the local market. Key movers included Jiutian Chemical, Sembcorp Marine, and Singtel, with the latter rising 1.2% to S$2.47. The local banks were mixed, with UOB and DBS edging up, while OCBC slipped 0.3%. The gains followed a broad-based rally on Wall Street, where equities rose 1.4% on Friday, and European stocks closed near all-time highs.

site_title: CapitaLand's big restructuring: Is this the deal investors have been waiting for?
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate company, has unveiled a major reorganisation plan to boost its growth and market valuation. The plan involves taking its property development business private and separating its real estate investment management activities and lodging business into a new entity called CapitaLand Investment Management (CLIM). Minority shareholders will receive a combination of shares in CLIM, units in a new trust, and cash. The reorganisation aims to position CLIM as a fully integrated real estate investment manager, potentially unlocking substantial value within the group.

site_title: American and United extend deadlines on unused flight credits
summary: Airlines American and United have extended deadlines on unused flight credits, reducing the percentage of open credits set to expire from 55% to 11% as of March 28. The extensions reflect the uncertain recovery of air travel after the coronavirus pandemic. Most credits have traditionally expired 12 months after purchase, but carriers have extended deadlines to accommodate customers in a fluid travel environment. The increased expirations in 2022 are now at 89%, up from 45% before, as millions of would-be flyers continue to stay off planes.

site_title: Five injured, hundreds evacuated after massive blaze at Indonesia oil refinery
summary: A massive fire broke out at Indonesia's Balongan oil refinery in West Java, injuring five people and forcing the evacuation of around 950 others. The fire began on Sunday evening during bad weather and was described as huge, with flames engulfing the refinery and a large explosion heard. The Indonesian state oil company, Pertamina, is trying to control the blaze.

site_title: Red lights and bathroom posters: Amazon's all-out fight to block a union
summary: Amazon is engaging in an all-out effort to block a unionization vote at its Bessemer, Alabama warehouse, where 5,800 employees are eligible to vote. Union organizers have been posting "Make sure you take care of us" signs and waving "Thanks for your courage" banners to encourage workers to vote in favor of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Amazon has held weekly "informational" meetings, sent text messages, and put up posters in restrooms to persuade employees not to support the union. The vote, which ends Monday, could be a major coup for the union movement in historic decline and potentially open the floodgates to unionization efforts at other Amazon sites.

site_title: More insurers to launch claims-based pricing for Integrated Shield riders
summary: More insurers in Singapore are launching claims-based pricing for Integrated Shield (IP) riders, offering discounts of 20-25% for those who don't make a claim, but increasing premiums by 2-3 times for those who do. The practice aims to improve underwriting results and prevent future premium hikes. Prudential was the first to introduce claims-based pricing in 2017, and Great Eastern and AIA will follow suit in April, while Aviva plans to launch in 2022. The move is also aimed at encouraging prudent use of healthcare services.

site_title: A private tech city opens for business in Honduras
summary: Private tech city Próspera in Honduras is set to begin considering applications from e-residents, the first colonists of the settlement. Located on Roatán, Próspera has its own constitution, legal code, and governing system, offering a business-friendly environment and higher minimum wage compared to Honduras. The project aims to attract professionals and entrepreneurs, providing a jurisdiction with a more liberal and effective legal system. However, local residents have raised concerns about transparency and potential human rights violations, and some have protested against the project.

site_title: Certis in tie-up with Lendlease to redevelop headquarters
summary: Certis, an integrated security services organization, has partnered with Lendlease to redevelop its ageing headquarters in Singapore's Paya Lebar area through a S$150m sale and purchase agreement. This move is seen as strategic, given Lendlease's expertise in property development and management. The redevelopment is expected to enhance Certis's operations and competitiveness.

site_title: Ensuring that shareholders are heard
summary: Companies should consider adopting a hybrid model of both physical and virtual annual general meetings (AGMs) to ensure engagement and transparency among shareholders. Experts argue that this approach allows for audience choice, maximizes reach and attendance, and provides invaluable engagement that online gatherings cannot. While there are concerns about technical issues and regulatory compliance, many companies have successfully pivoted to virtual AGMs and can adapt to hybrid models. Ultimately, the hybrid model offers the best of both worlds, enabling companies to deliver a holistic narrative of their business while respecting shareholders' views and preferences.

site_title: China sets duties on Australia wine for 5 years as ties sour
summary: China has imposed tariffs of over 200% on Australian wine for five years, effective March 28, amid worsening relations between the two countries. The tariffs, which range from 116.2% to 218.4%, were introduced after China launched investigations into Australian wine, claiming it was subsidized and sold under market value. The move follows a year of one-sided trade reprisals, with China targeting Australian commodities such as coal, beef, and lobster. The Australian government has vowed to challenge the tariffs at the World Trade Organization.

site_title: Allianz studying counter offer for Hartford after Chubb's US$23b bid
summary: Germany's Allianz SE is studying a potential counter offer to Chubb's US$23 billion takeover bid for Hartford Financial Services Group Inc, following Hartford's rejection of Chubb's proposal. Allianz views Hartford as a remaining US target with scale, but is hesitant to enter a pricey bidding war due to lack of synergies. The deliberations are at an early stage, and Allianz may decide against pursuing a deal, which would be transformational for the German insurer. A successful deal could help expand Allianz's business with smaller corporations and facilitate future consolidation.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The global shipping market experienced a softer week, with rates declining across all routes due to low activity in both the Baltic and Asian basins. Capesize rates softened, with the 5TC average falling to $19,014 from $19,437. Panamax rates also decreased, with a loss of $1,326 on the week. The Asian market showed a two-tiered structure, with north-south positions experiencing pressure due to limited activity. Ultramax and Supramax rates eased in most areas, with some period activity reported. The Suezmax market saw an improvement, driven by the Suez blockage incident. Aframax rates rose in the Mediterranean, while LR1 and MR rates improved, with the MR market into West Africa weakening.

site_title: Goldman Sachs revolt hits nerve as pandemic blurs work-life line
summary: A revolt by junior Goldman Sachs bankers over excessive work hours has sparked debate about the future of work after the COVID-19 pandemic. The bankers, who worked up to 105 hours a week, complained about the blurring of boundaries between work and personal life. Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon has urged staff to respect a policy of not working on Saturdays, while other companies, such as Citi and BT, have implemented similar measures. Experts say that addressing the issue of overwork requires a cultural shift and that employers must follow through on promises to support staff.

site_title: Defence chiefs of 12 countries condemn Myanmar for violence
summary: Defence chiefs from 12 countries, including the US, Britain, and Japan, have condemned Myanmar's military for using lethal force against civilians, killing at least 90 people, including children, in the latest violent crackdown. The condemnation comes as the country continues to be in turmoil following the February 1 coup, with the death toll now at least 423. The defence ministers urged the Myanmar military to cease violence and work to restore respect with the people.

site_title: Yeo's, Oatly in S$30m tie-up to produce oat drink for Asia in Singapore
summary: Sweden's Oatly and Singapore's Yeo Hiap Seng (Yeo's) have partnered to produce oat drink in Singapore, investing S$30 million in equipment and facilities. This will be Oatly's first Asia supplier and manufacturing location outside Europe and North America, with production starting in the second half of this year. Yeo's will operate and maintain the new facilities, producing 60 million litres of oat milk per year, with the option to scale up further. The partnership aims to capitalize on Singapore's manufacturing capabilities and tap the growing demand for plant-based milk alternatives in Asia.

site_title: Samudera spies opportunities for growth in Indonesia
summary: Samudera Shipping Line, a mainboard-listed shipping company, sees opportunities for growth in Indonesia due to the country's new Omnibus Law, which is expected to attract increased foreign investment. The law creates a more favorable environment for investors and foreign investment. CEO Bani Mulia notes that Samudera is exploring opportunities to secure logistics contracts, including shipping contracts, and is looking to invest in Indonesian ports, which could benefit from tackling port bottlenecks. The company expects to benefit from its parent company, PT Samudera Indonesia, and is cautiously optimistic about 2021's prospects, despite a tumultuous year.

site_title: Is claims-based pricing for Shield riders a double-edged sword?
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield (IP) policyholders may face higher premiums under claims-based pricing, a new strategy by insurers to manage healthcare costs. Healthy policyholders who don't make claims will receive discounts, but those who do may face increased costs. Insurers, including Prudential, AIA, and Great Eastern, are introducing the system to encourage responsible healthcare use and reduce costs. However, critics warn that the approach may penalize the unhealthy and exacerbate existing healthcare disparities, potentially pushing high-risk policyholders out of the market.

site_title: Expect a breakout as rubber consolidates
summary: The rubber market is expected to experience a breakout as it consolidates in a triangle pattern. Following a sharp decline in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the market has seen a recovery in demand and supply. Rubber prices are now trending upwards, with near-term targets at 200 and 240 US cents/kg. The uptrend remains intact, with the 50-day and 100-day simple moving averages providing support.

site_title: Tugs, dredgers still struggling to free ship blocking Suez Canal
summary: Tug and dredger teams are attempting to dislodge a massive container ship blocking the Suez Canal, with efforts hindered by rock under the ship's bow. Since the blockage, at least 369 ships are stuck, costing the canal around $14-15 million daily. The Suez Canal Authority reported that dredgers have shifted 27,000 cubic meters of sand to a depth of 18 meters, with continued efforts around the clock based on wind and tidal conditions.

site_title: Google has long way to go to becoming anti-Amazon of e-commerce
summary: Google's efforts to become an anti-Amazon e-commerce platform have shown little success, with the company struggling to compete with Amazon's $295 billion third-party marketplace. Despite eliminating fees for merchants and partnering with Shopify to make it easier for small businesses to list their products, Google's online shopping habits remain unchanged. The company has seen only $1 billion in sales, compared to Amazon's massive third-party marketplace. Google's attempt to woo sellers who feel uneasy about building their businesses on Amazon has been hindered by technical issues, such as a recent suspension of a small business's account due to shipping costs.

site_title: Here is how the world's chip shortage is playing out for stocks
summary: A global semiconductor shortage is impacting various industries, including cars and networking equipment, due to booming demand and winter weather in Texas and a fire in Japan. The shortage is expected to last into the second half of the year, affecting auto stocks, with Volvo Group and Nio experiencing significant drops. Companies supplying semiconductors, however, are expected to see strong results, with shares of Applied Materials, Lam Research, and ASML Holding increasing significantly. The shortage is also expected to impact the networking segment, with delivery lead times extending to 50 weeks.

site_title: Yanlord Land chair ups stake by 7 million shares
summary: Yanlord Land Group's founder and chairman, Zhong Sheng Jian, increased his stake in the company by 7 million shares, now holding 70.83% of the shares. The acquisition was made at an average price of S$1.19 per share. This move came after the company reported a 28.1% increase in FY20 revenue to 23.92 billion yuan. Zhong also mentioned that the group's long-established presence in the Yangtze River Delta and the Greater Bay Area will continue to drive growth and attract talent.

site_title: Facebook freezes Venezuela president Maduro's page over Covid-19 misinformation
summary: Facebook has frozen Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro's page for 30 days due to repeated violations of its policies against spreading misinformation about Covid-19. Maduro promoted a remedy called Carvativir, claiming it can cure the disease without evidence, in a video that has been taken down by Facebook. The decision follows guidance from the World Health Organization stating there is no medication to cure the virus. Maduro's account on Instagram will not be affected.

site_title: Virgin Atlantic starts digital health pass trials ahead of longed-for recovery
summary: Virgin Atlantic has started digital health pass trials ahead of its recovery, partnering with the International Air Transport Association's (Iata) Travel Pass on its London to Barbados route. The trial will begin on April 16 and will be accepted by Barbados, a key step towards resuming travel. The airline hopes the digital solution will alleviate lengthy paper-based border checks and facilitate smoother travel. With the UK set to lift its ban on non-essential travel on May 17, Virgin Atlantic aims to demonstrate the effectiveness of digital health passes in supporting travel recovery.

site_title: Dollar roughly flat but close to 4-month highs on economic optimism
