summary: The US dollar remained near four-month highs against major currencies, closing the week up 0.7% against a basket of six currencies. The dollar-yen rose to 109.64, its highest since June, driven by economic optimism, including a decline in jobless claims and President Biden's plan to double vaccinations. The euro, bruised by vaccination concerns, saw a slight recovery, while bitcoin gained 4.5% to $53,654.

site_title: Australia ends pandemic wage subsidy despite job loss warnings
summary: Australia ended its pandemic wage subsidy scheme, JobKeeper, despite warnings that up to 150,000 jobs could be lost. The program, which paid A$1,500 a fortnight to staff via their employers, was designed to be temporary and ended as the economy recovered. Unions warned that many workers would see their hours and pay slashed, with 1.1 million workers facing uncertainty. The decision was made despite a 5.8% unemployment rate in February, with officials citing the program's temporary nature and the economy's recovery.

site_title: Yeo Hiap Seng brewing up new recipes for F&B growth
summary: Yeo Hiap Seng Group, a Singaporean heritage brand, has set a new growth strategy under CEO Samuel Koh. The company aims to become the Asian leader in innovative and healthy food and beverage products, focusing on tea and plant-based dairy categories. Yeo's has partnered with Sweden's Oatly to produce oat-based drinks in Singapore, expanding its presence in the Asian market. Despite a net loss in 2020, the group is well-positioned financially and remains committed to driving growth and transformation, with a focus on its core F&B business and strategic partnerships.

images.alt_text: While the headwinds from the Covid-19 have slowed Yeo's down to some extent, the group remains "firmly on track to grow and transform", says its CEO Samuel Koh.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: iFast Corporation has launched stocks and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) brokerage services on FSMOne.com in Malaysia, allowing do-it-yourself investors to invest in unit trusts, bonds, managed portfolios, insurance, stocks, and ETFs. The new services also enable investors to create a globally diversified portfolio with plans to expand to US and Hong Kong markets. A zero-commission fee is offered for one month, with a minimum fee of RM8.80. Meanwhile, Unusual Limited has announced JJ Lin's Sanctuary Finale virtual concert to be streamed live on June 6, 2021.

site_title: Crypto shadow banking explained and why 12% yields are common
summary: US shadow banks in the $1.6 trillion cryptocurrency market are generating 12% returns by lending dollars to hedge funds to buy Bitcoin, which has a 20-40% annualized return. Non-bank firms like BitGo, BlockFi, and Genesis are stepping up to meet investor demand for dollars, despite banks' wariness of lending to Bitcoin-associated individuals or companies. This trend is driven by the shortage of traditional currencies in the market, allowing these shadow banks to capitalize on the high-yielding trade.

site_title: Funds bet on consumer boom to rival 'Roaring 20s'
summary: Top money managers are betting on a post-pandemic spending boom, expecting a "Roaring 20s" theme similar to the 1920s. Investors are pouring money into companies with face-to-face interaction, such as travel, restaurants, and off-line shopping. Cyclical stocks like travel companies, airlines, and theme parks are seeing significant gains, with Marriott and Airbnb up 11% and 19% respectively. The luxury brands sector is also expected to benefit, with premiumisation trends in food, autos, cosmetics, and apparel on the rise.

site_title: Envy Global Trading removes managing director Ng on police probe
summary: Envy Global Trading has removed managing director Ng Yu Zhi from his role amid a police probe into alleged fraud. Ng was charged with four counts of fraud over fake deals that deceived investors into putting S$1 billion into non-existent nickel deals. An independent interim management committee has been established to oversee the company. Ng has appointed lawyers to address the charges, while Envy Global Trading has appointed lawyers to protect its interests. Singapore's white-collar crime police have seized S$100 million of assets from Ng, who was released on a S$1.5 million bail.

site_title: Australia threatens WTO action as China hikes duty on wine
summary: Australia's trade minister Dan Tehan has threatened to take China to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over China's "unjustifiable" decision to hike duties on Australian wine imports for up to five years, with levies ranging from 116.2% to 218.4%. The move comes after China's commerce ministry found "dumping and subsidies" on Australian wine imports impacting the Chinese market. Australia has imposed its own tariffs on Chinese barley imports in response. Diplomatic relations between the two countries have reached a low since the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.

site_title: TPG Capital chooses banks for S$800m Asian pathology IPO in Singapore
summary: TPG Capital Asia has selected banks to facilitate an initial public offering (IPO) for its pathology business, Pathology Asia Holdings, in Singapore, with a potential raise of S$800 million. The IPO, led by Citigroup and CIMB Group Holdings, could list by the end of this year. This is part of a growing trend of companies seeking an IPO in Singapore, following Aztech Global's recent listing. The pathology business, acquired by TPG in 2018, is now valued at US$2 billion.

site_title: Janelle Monáe and Ralph Lauren make the case for clubbing
summary: Ralph Lauren and Janelle Monáe made a case for clubbing with a black-and-white concert film featuring Monáe performing at Lauren's Beverly Hills flagship. The event was part of a larger trend of designers showcasing their collections in a nostalgic and glamorous way, with Stella McCartney and Junya Watanabe also highlighting the need for dancing and experience. The fashion industry is embracing a sense of freedom and escapism, with flares, bow ties, and vintage-inspired clothing making a comeback. Designers are using their shows to create a sense of community and nostalgia, encouraging people to "go out" and experience fashion in a new way.

site_title: Back-to-office crowd a godsend to S-Reits
summary: Singapore's easing of workplace arrangements, with up to 75% staff allowed to return to the office from April 5, is expected to boost footfall and usage of existing office spaces. Six S-Reits, with a combined market cap of over S$35 billion, have significant exposure to office properties in Singapore. These S-Reits trade at an average price-to-book ratio of 0.9 times and have an average distribution yield of 5%. The relaxation of workplace arrangements is seen as a positive development for S-Reits, which are poised to benefit from increased office usage.

site_title: Bubble deniers abound to dismiss valuation metrics one by one
summary: US stocks face criticism for being "frothy" due to stretched valuation metrics, such as the Buffett Indicator and Tobin's Q. Despite warnings, many market-watchers argue that this time is different, citing the Federal Reserve's largesse and vaccine-driven recovery. However, recent market trends, including NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer and Creative Technology's revenue warning, suggest that the market may not be immune to challenges. The article highlights the ongoing debate among market-watchers and investors about the market's health and potential risks.

site_title: Netflix to launch 40 new anime shows this year after 'Blood of Zeus' win
summary: Netflix plans to launch 40 new anime shows this year, nearly doubling its previous number, in an effort to attract Asian viewers and compete with Disney+ and Amazon Prime. The move follows the success of anime series like "Demon Slayer" and "Blood of Zeus," and aims to strengthen its user base in the region. With the global anime market expected to grow to $36 billion by 2025, Netflix is investing in original content to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Netflix will almost double its number of Japanese-style anime releases this year, stepping up its fight against AT&T and Sony for original content that appeals to Asian viewers.

site_title: Global jabs pass half a billion as WHO seeks vaccines for poor nations
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has urged richer nations to donate COVID-19 vaccines to poorer countries, as the pandemic continues to surge in Europe and Latin America. Over 510 million vaccine doses have been administered globally, with the US accounting for a quarter of the total. The WHO is calling for 10 million doses immediately to help 20 countries start immunizing their health workers and older people within two weeks. Meanwhile, countries such as Brazil and Mexico are struggling with high cases and deaths, with Brazil surpassing 300,000 deaths and Mexico nearing 200,000.

images.alt_text: Health officials have rolled out more than 510 million coronavirus vaccine doses around the world, but with big gaps between countries the WHO on Friday appealed to richer nations to donate vaccines to help poorer ones start inoculations.

site_title: Biden says Xi, Putin welcome at global climate summit on April 22
summary: US President Joe Biden has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin to a global climate summit on April 22-23. The summit aims to galvanize efforts to limit planetary warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Biden's administration is expected to announce an ambitious 2030 target for reducing carbon emissions, despite potential opposition from Republicans. The event will be held virtually due to pandemic restrictions and will be live-streamed for public viewing, bringing together 40 world leaders responsible for 80% of global emissions and GDP.

site_title: Bank of England's divisions resurface on UK economic outlook
summary: The Bank of England is divided over the UK's economic outlook, with some members, including Chief Economist Andy Haldane, predicting a rapid recovery, while others, such as Silvana Tenreyro, believe another stimulus may be needed. The division reflects the uncertainty facing the economy emerging from its deepest slump in over 300 years, with doubts over the government's ability to meet its vaccine goal and a dispute with the EU over vaccine shipments. The MPC is unlikely to act until the fourth quarter, with some members preferring to wait for a sustained rise in prices before tightening policy.

site_title: Online lender SoFi to give IPO access to retail investors
summary: Online lender SoFi is allowing retail investors to buy into initial public offerings (IPOs) of companies, expanding access to everyday investors who typically only buy stock when shares start trading. SoFi's new platform, available to anyone with a $3,000 investment account, aims to encourage long-term holders and penalize short-term profiteers. The company has already obtained regulatory clearances and will act as a passive underwriter on deals.

site_title: Murdoch wants to shake up UK news with 'aggressive' TV service
summary: Rupert Murdoch's News UK TV aims to shake up the UK news landscape with an "aggressive" brand of journalism. The service, set to air for free on smart TVs and online platforms, will feature local content from Murdoch's newspapers, including the Sun and the Times of London. News UK TV president David Rhodes emphasizes that the approach will be tailored to the UK market, differing from the US model. The move is seen as a response to declining newspaper circulation, with News UK TV targeting advertising revenue from the digital TV market.

images.alt_text: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch has chosen a former Fox News executive to unleash his controversial brand of journalism on British screens. But David Rhodes insists he's not bringing the US network's brash playbook to London.

site_title: AirAsia boss says RM1b in loans pending regulator approval
summary: AirAsia Group expects to secure RM1 billion in loans from three Malaysian banks pending regulator approval, according to CEO Tony Fernandes. The airline has already raised US$82 million through private share placements and is considering a loan offer from the Thai government's Exim Bank. Fernandes estimated the airline's total funding needs to be between RM2 billion and RM2.5 billion, with enough cash to last until 2023 in the worst-case scenario.

site_title: Jeffrey Ong implicates Allied Tech executive director and investor in misappropriation case
summary: Former JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong implicates Allied Tech executive director Kenneth Low Si Ren and investor Lin Tah Hwa in a misappropriation case, alleging round-tripping and sham transactions involving the firm in 2017 and 2018. Ong claims $76 million in funds were misappropriated, with Ong himself borrowing $4 million to top up an escrow account. Ong faces 76 charges, including misappropriation of funds as a lawyer, and is deemed a flight risk by the prosecution.

site_title: Former CDC chief Redfield says he thinks Covid-19 originated in a Chinese lab
summary: Former CDC director Robert Redfield stated he believes Covid-19 likely originated from a Chinese lab in Wuhan, contradicting many global epidemiologists. He mentioned it's possible for respiratory pathogens to infect lab workers, but not saying release was intentional. This theory has contributed to tensions between China and the West, with US officials like Mike Pompeo supporting it. However, other officials like Anthony Fauci and the WHO-led team investigating the virus's origins believe bats are the likely source, ruling out a lab leak.

site_title: iFast's Malaysian unit launches stockbroking service
summary: iFast Corporation's Malaysian unit, iFast Capital Sdn Bhd, has launched its stocks and exchange-traded funds (ETFs) brokerage services on FSMOne.com in Malaysia. The new platform allows do-it-yourself investors to invest in unit trusts, bonds, managed portfolios, insurance, stocks, and ETFs listed on Bursa Malaysia. The brokerage commission fee is 0.05% with a minimum of RM8.80, and investors can enjoy a zero commission fee for Bursa-listed stocks and ETFs for a month. This move expands iFast Capital's wealth management solutions under one platform, with plans to broaden its markets to the US and Hong Kong.

site_title: Amazon's social media team bares its teeth in Washington
summary: Amazon's social media team targeted US Senators Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren in a series of tweets, criticizing their stances on labor and unionization. The company tweeted that Sanders' home state of Vermont has a lower minimum wage than his proposed $15 minimum wage, and accused Warren of being hypocritical for supporting a break-up of Big Tech while advocating for unionizing. The tweets were seen as a response to Sanders' meeting with Amazon workers in Alabama, where he urged them to vote for a union.

site_title: Bangladesh deploys border guards after deadly anti-Modi protests
summary: Bangladesh has deployed border guards to maintain order after deadly protests by hardline Islamists against Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit. The violence, which began at a mosque in Dhaka, spread to several districts, leaving five dead and scores injured. Facebook has been restricted in the country due to user complaints about sharing images and reports of the violence. The Border Guard Bangladesh has deployed troops since Friday night, with no reports of violence after their deployment, according to a senior officer. The protests were part of nationwide demonstrations against Modi's visit and police actions.

site_title: Tackling the unique demands of dementia care
summary: The OCBC Glowing Years programme at AWWA Dementia Day Care Centre is showing improvements in mental alertness and social interaction among dementia patients. Koo May Yeok, a healthcare professional, noticed her mother's symptoms, including memory loss and mood swings, leading to a diagnosis of dementia. The programme aims to tackle the unique demands of dementia care, providing a supportive environment for patients to thrive.

images.alt_text: Combining a fun exercise regime with a compelling incentive scheme, the OCBC initiative motivates the seniors to improve their motor and cognitive skills.

site_title: Britain nearing vaccine deal with European Union: The Times
summary: Britain is close to striking a vaccine deal with the European Union, with the EU removing its threat to ban Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine exports to the UK in exchange for the UK agreeing to forgo some long-term supplies of the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine. The agreement comes as the EU clears a production site in the Netherlands and a facility in Germany, aiming to boost deliveries in the second quarter and accelerate inoculations in the bloc. This deal follows tensions between Brussels and London over vaccine supply and export.

images.alt_text: Britain is close to striking a vaccine deal with the European Union (EU) as soon as this weekend that will remove the threat of the bloc cutting off supplies, The Times reported on Saturday.

site_title: Myanmar's junta says will strive for democracy after warning anti-coup protesters
summary: Myanmar's junta leader Min Aung Hlaing said the military will protect the people and strive for democracy, following a warning to protesters that violent acts could lead to being shot. At least 328 protesters have been killed since the coup, with 25% dying from shots to the head. The junta reiterated a promise to hold elections, but no date was given. International pressure on the junta has increased, with the US and European Union imposing new sanctions, and Russia's deputy defence minister offering support.

site_title: Facebook sets reopening for Silicon Valley campuses
summary: Facebook is set to reopen its Silicon Valley campuses in May, starting with 10% of maximum seated capacity, following a year-long pandemic shutdown. The company has implemented safety protocols, including physical distancing, mask requirements, and weekly testing, before gradually increasing capacity. Free amenities such as food and shuttle buses will be reintroduced when deemed safe. The reopening plan is part of a shift towards remote work, with employees having the option to work from home until early July.

site_title: Singapore Medical Association to rank IP insurers, set up complaints committee
summary: The Singapore Medical Association (SMA) plans to rank Integrated Shield Plans (IP) insurers annually and set up a complaints committee to address issues with IP insurers. The initiatives aim to increase transparency and provide patients and doctors with more information on insurers. The ranking criteria include inclusiveness of panels, transparency of doctor selection criteria, and timeliness of payment. SMA is also urging insurers to be more inclusive and transparent, and to reduce management and commission costs to enhance the sustainability of IPs. The association believes that IPs should be managed by fewer payors to prevent duplication of resources and costs.

site_title: US trade chief readies tariffs against six countries over digital taxes
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai is readying tariffs against Austria, Britain, India, Italy, Spain, and Turkey in retaliation for their digital services taxes. The move comes despite the Biden administration's efforts to pursue a global agreement on digital services taxes. Tai announced the decision, which will proceed with public notices and collect public comments, as part of an investigation begun by the Trump administration. The US has also maintained a tariff threat against French imports in retaliation for France's digital tax. The US remains committed to reaching an international consensus on digital tax issues.

site_title: Why are China's consumers threatening to boycott H&M and other brands?
summary: Chinese online activists are boycotting foreign brands, including H&M, Tommy Hilfiger, Adidas, Nike, and Calvin Klein, for joining a call to avoid using cotton from Xinjiang, where authorities are repressing ethnic minorities. The campaign, backed by the Communist Party, targets companies that have taken a public stance on China's human rights practices. The boycott has resulted in the loss of brand ambassadors and partnerships, highlighting the vulnerability of foreign companies amid worsening tensions between China and the US.

site_title: UN panel struggles to find consensus on women's issues
summary: A UN panel concluded five weeks of negotiations on the status of women with a watered-down declaration. European diplomats accused Russia of being obstructionist, undermining women's rights. The US had been expected to support a more progressive stance, but the Biden administration's impact was limited. The declaration's outcome was seen as a disappointment, following a similar outcome in previous years. The panel's struggle to reach consensus highlights the challenges in addressing women's issues globally.

images.alt_text: A United Nations (UN) panel ended five weeks of arduous negotiations on Friday with a watered-down declaration on the status of women around the world.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close to all-time highs as miners, tech shine
summary: European stocks closed near all-time highs, driven by gains in mining and tech sectors. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.8% for its fourth straight weekly gain, with chipmakers and mining companies leading the way. Despite concerns over new coronavirus infections, investors focused on a stimulus-driven recovery in the US and abundant fiscal and monetary support. Analysts see a strong economic recovery on the horizon, with some predicting Europe will outperform other markets in the next few months.

images.alt_text: European stocks ended the week close to all-time highs, with miners prominent as investors shrugged off worries about a third wave of coronavirus infections and focused on prospects of a solid global economic recovery.

site_title: Biden suggests to UK's Johnson a plan to rival China's Belt and Road
summary: US President Joe Biden suggested a rival infrastructure plan to China's Belt and Road Initiative during a phone call with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson. Biden proposed a similar initiative, pulling from democratic states to help communities worldwide in need. The plan, to be unveiled next week, aims to upgrade US infrastructure and invest heavily in promising technologies. This move comes as the US seeks to counter China's growing economic and political influence.

site_title: Coinbase users say crypto startup ignored their pleas for help
summary: Coinbase users claim the company ignored their pleas for help after their accounts were hacked or locked out, resulting in significant financial losses. The cryptocurrency exchange has faced criticism for its security measures and customer support, with users saying they received little assistance despite their concerns. Coinbase has denied being hacked, citing 0.004% of its users experiencing account takeovers, but users claim the company's security was fooled by attackers. As Coinbase prepares to go public, investors and experts question the company's ability to maintain quality customer support and align with traditional financial regulations.

site_title: Stellantis, Nissan, Nio cut more production due to chip shortage
summary: Stellantis, Nissan, and Nio are cutting production due to a global semiconductor chip shortage. Stellantis will halt production at five North American plants, while Nissan will shut down two US plants for two days starting April 1. Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, will cut its first-quarter delivery forecast by up to 1,000 vehicles. The chip shortage has cost the global auto industry 130,000 vehicles in lost production, with the heaviest impact in North America. The shortage is attributed to increased demand from the consumer electronics industry and sanctions against Chinese technology companies.

site_title: Canada watching housing markets 'very closely'
summary: Canada's federal government is closely monitoring the country's rapidly rising housing market, where home prices jumped 25% in February, reaching a record C$678,091. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland acknowledged the challenges young Canadians face in buying a home, while the Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation warned of overheating in housing markets nationwide. Policymakers have been hesitant to intervene, citing concerns about undermining the economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has presented a new bill offering C$7.2 billion in critical support to provinces and entities.

site_title: Boeing resumes 787 deliveries as widespread inspections loom
summary: Boeing has resumed deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner jets, handing over one plane to United Airlines, as the company works to address structural integrity flaws in dozens of aircraft. The delivery from its South Carolina factory comes after repairs and forensic inspections to fix the issues, which halted deliveries since October. The goal remains to resume deliveries of a few 787s this month. The move aims to restore a key source of cash for Boeing.

site_title: WeWork agrees to go public via US$9b SPAC deal: WSJ
summary: WeWork has agreed to go public through a merger with BowX Acquisition Corp, valuing the office-sharing startup at $9 billion, including debt. The deal follows a failed IPO attempt in 2019 and comes after WeWork lost $3.2 billion last year. WeWork is also raising $1.3 billion in capital, including $800 million in private investment. The company's valuation has dropped significantly since its peak of nearly $47 billion in 2019.

site_title: 'I am my biggest critic', says Tottenham's Jose Mourinho
summary: Jose Mourinho, Tottenham's manager, emphasizes the importance of mental fortitude in sports, stating he is his own toughest critic. He attributes his success to loving football and not being motivated by its benefits. Mourinho advises young players to focus on their passion for the game and notes that older players, like Zlatan Ibrahimovic, remain in love with football despite having achieved success. He believes his job is not about picking clubs but about finding the right fit, and switches off by being with his family and enjoying the sun.

site_title: Deutsche Bank can sue Madoff feeder funds over US$1.6b claims sale
summary: A US judge has allowed Deutsche Bank to pursue a lawsuit against two offshore funds, Kingate Global Fund and Kingate Euro Fund, for allegedly reneging on a deal to sell $1.6 billion in claims from Bernard Madoff's bankruptcy. The funds had agreed to sell the claims at 66 cents on the dollar in 2011, but later increased their value substantially. The judge cited a verbal agreement as "firm, irrevocable and binding", despite a lack of a formal contract. Deutsche Bank may also pursue a claim that the Kingate funds acted in bad faith by filing for bankruptcy protection in 2019.

site_title: Nationwide, Santander among UK banks to slash office space
summary: Nationwide Building Society and Santander UK are cutting office space as part of their shift to remote working. Nationwide told 13,000 staff to work from anywhere, while Santander UK will close 4 offices and switch its headquarters from London to Milton Keynes. The moves aim to reduce costs and accelerate mobile and online banking. Around 5,000 staff will be offered new working arrangements, combining remote work with local collaboration spaces.

site_title: China tech stocks down US$732b but may not have hit bottom yet
summary: China's tech stocks have fallen by US$732 billion, but may not have hit their bottom yet. Despite a brief rally, the industry still trades at high valuations, with stocks like Tencent and Alibaba fetching 23 times projected earnings. Historically, this suggests room for further downside. Investors remain cautious, citing uncertainties over interest rates, regulatory scrutiny, and earnings season. Experts warn of a possible short-lived technical rebound rather than a real rally, and advise a cautious approach when buying technology stocks.

site_title: Suez Canal steps up efforts to free stuck vessel, US watches energy market impact
summary: A 400-metre long vessel, the Ever Given, remains stuck in the Suez Canal, disrupting global shipping and supply chains. Dredging and tugging efforts failed to free the vessel, lifting shipping rates for fuel tankers. US President Joe Biden stated that his administration is exploring ways to assist, citing the US's equipment and capacity advantages. The blockage has affected the transportation of goods, including grains and baby clothes, and its resolution is expected to have a significant impact on the energy market.

site_title: Duterte backs rise in pork imports as supply crunch fans prices
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has requested an increase in pork imports to address a supply crunch that has driven up prices and inflation to a two-year high. He recommended adding 350,000 tonnes to the minimum access volume under the World Trade Organization agreement, aiming to stabilize prices and address food security concerns. The move comes after 1.9 million hogs were lost to African swine fever in 2020, and consumer prices rose 4.7% in February, exceeding the central bank's 2-4% target for the year.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has asked Congress to increase the cap on pork imports purchased under lower tariffs to address a supply crunch that has helped stoke inflation to a two-year high.

site_title: Oil prices rise on fears Suez Canal blockage may last weeks
summary: Oil prices rose 3% on Friday due to concerns that a container ship blocking the Suez Canal may take weeks to dislodge, squeezing global oil supplies. Despite the rebound, prices are still on track for a third consecutive weekly loss. The Suez Canal Authority resumed dredging operations, with 87% complete, and warned that dislodging the ship could take weeks. Oil prices were also lifted by escalating geopolitical risk in the Middle East and expectations that Opec will maintain lower production.

site_title: What next for the Singapore Turf Club?
summary: The Singapore Turf Club is facing a significant decline in horse racing due to the COVID-19 pandemic, which has reduced prize money and attendance. The club's finances have suffered, with a 50% decrease in prize money for some races and the cancellation of several events. The decline has led to the departure of several trainers, including Cliff Brown and Lee Freedman, and jockeys. The club's low payouts, lack of competitive racing, and absence of high-quality horses have also contributed to the waning interest in horse racing. The industry's future is uncertain, but some trainers, such as Mark Walker and Donna Logan from New Zealand, have pledged allegiance to the club.

site_title: Oil jumps 4% on fears Suez Canal blockage may last weeks
summary: Oil prices rose 4% on Friday due to concerns a Suez Canal blockage may last weeks, disrupting global supplies. The blockage, caused by a giant container ship, has resulted in 10 vessels waiting at the canal's entry points with 10 million barrels of oil. The Suez Canal is a critical route for 9% of global seaborne oil product trade. Oil prices also rose due to escalating geopolitical risks in the Middle East and expectations that Opec+ will maintain lower production.

site_title: Ikea's malls arm buys retail property in the centre of Toronto
summary: IKEA's shopping malls arm, Ingka Centres, has acquired the Shops at Aura mall in Toronto's centre for redevelopment into an inner-city Ikea store. The 12,000 sqm mall space will be redeveloped, with the remaining space marking Ingka Centres' entry into Canada. This is the first inner-city Ikea store in Canada and follows Ikea's strategy shift towards large cities due to online shopping and changing consumer behaviors. The new store is expected to open around the turn of the year.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies on strong recovery hopes
summary: US stocks surged on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Dow ending at record highs, driven by hopes of a strong economic recovery. Technology, healthcare, and financial stocks led the gains, while beaten-down tech shares advanced. The Nasdaq also rose, despite its second weekly decline. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 453.4 points, while the S&P 500 gained 65.02 points and the Nasdaq Composite added 161.05 points. The market's optimism is fueled by the Federal Reserve's GDP estimate of 6.5% for 2021 and expectations of faster growth, despite concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Dozens trapped in Mozambique hotel as insurgents attack town
summary: Mozambique's Palma town is under attack by insurgents affiliated with the Islamic State group, trapping over 180 people, including expatriate workers, in a hotel for three days. The military has launched an offensive to repel the extremist fighters, and helicopters have been trying to airlift the workers to safety. The attack has caused significant destruction and killed at least two people, with nearly 700,000 people fleeing their homes in the province. The situation remains critical, with the trapped workers facing a shortage of food but having access to water.

site_title: Americans' personal income dips 7% in Feb as effect of stimulus cheques fades
summary: US personal income dropped 7.1% in February as stimulus cheques' effect faded, according to the Commerce Department. This decrease was more than accounted for by a decline in government social benefits and pandemic-related restrictions. Spending fell 1% and prices grew 0.2%, less than expected. The data may ease concerns about inflation and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates sooner than anticipated. American manufacturing continues to show momentum, with factory purchasing managers reporting faster expansion, despite supply-chain woes and inflation concerns.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.69 points to 1,601.42 on Friday, driven by a gain of 696 stocks over 345 losers. The index closed with a volume of 5.959 billion lots worth RM3.238 billion.

site_title: Headwinds from the dollar and bond yields buffet gold
summary: Gold prices remained stagnant this week, trading within a tight range of US$25 due to a strengthening dollar and easing bond yields. The metal was overshadowed by rising bond yields and crude oil prices, despite the Federal Reserve's supportive comments. The European Central Bank's potential stimulus measures were largely ignored by traders. Gold needs to break above US$1,760 to move higher, but a significant collapse from its recent low of US$1,673 could lead to further price drops, potentially reaching US$1,500.

site_title: Vaccines, return of travel prompt upgrades for hotel trusts
summary: Brokerage firm CGS-CIMB has upgraded its calls on Ascott Residence Trust (ART) and CDL Hospitality Trust (CDLHT) to "add" from "hold" due to the expected rise in travel, both domestic and international. ART's target price is raised to S$1.20, and CDLHT's target price is raised to S$1.43, reflecting faster revenue recovery. The trusts' strong balance sheets and geographic presence in low-Covid-19 markets are key drivers of the upgrade. Recovery is expected to accelerate from the end of 2022.

site_title: Strong rebound ahead for short-haul, leisure travel soon: AirAsia chief
summary: AirAsia Group chief executive Tony Fernandes predicts a strong rebound in short-haul and leisure travel by June or July this year, driven by the COVID-19 vaccination programs and vaccine passports. However, business travel is expected to take longer to recover, with Fernandes stating that first-class travel is "dead" and business-class will be the new front-end of the cabin. AirAsia plans to expand its services, including air taxis and drone delivery, to capitalize on the growing demand for travel and logistics.

site_title: Stuck ship in Suez a warning about excessive globalisation
summary: A single ship, the Ever Given, ran aground in the Suez Canal, causing a massive traffic jam and disrupting global supply chains. The incident highlights the risks of relying on just-in-time manufacturing and global supply chains, which have become increasingly interconnected. The Suez Canal is a critical waterway linking Asia to Europe, with over 100 vessels stuck at either end, including those carrying oil, electronics, and other essential goods. The blockage has resulted in delays, increased costs, and potential shortages, with estimated losses of $9.6 billion.

site_title: Chinese apps join celebs in backlash against Western fashion brands over Xinjiang
summary: China's top ride-hailing app, Didi Chuxing, removed Swedish fashion retailer H&M from its listings amid a growing backlash against Western brands accused of sourcing cotton from Xinjiang, where human rights groups claim forced labor is used. Chinese celebrities, including 27 movie stars and singers, have also stopped cooperating with foreign brands, including Nike, Adidas, and Uniqlo. The move comes as Beijing denies accusations of detaining and torturing Uighurs in Xinjiang, describing the camps as vocational training centers.

images.alt_text: China's top ride-hailing app dropped Swedish fashion retailer H&M from its listings as Chinese celebrities stopped endorsing foreign labels in a growing uproar over Western accusations of forced labour in Xinjiang.

site_title: HDB and A*Star team up to advance smart-construction know-how
summary: HDB and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) have collaborated to advance smart-construction know-how, focusing on 5G-enabled technologies. They are working together to develop and adopt robotic, drone, and artificial-intelligence technologies to improve productivity and safety at construction sites. The collaboration aims to translate public-sector research and development into commercially-ready products, with trials set to begin at a selected HDB construction site. The partnership is expected to facilitate knowledge-sharing and industry partnerships, with HDB seeking to leverage innovative technologies to deliver quality homes for Singaporeans.

site_title: Suez mishap a foretaste of the new Cold War stakes
summary: The Suez Canal blockage by a massive container ship has highlighted the vulnerability of global shipping routes, a long-standing economic vulnerability that fuels great power competition. The incident has increased tensions between the US and China, with China's Belt and Road Initiative and support for Myanmar's coup being linked to the event. The US and China are vying for control of key waterways, including the Strait of Malacca and the South China Sea, as the rivalry between the two nations intensifies. This could have significant implications for global trade and security.

site_title: SPH bolsters News Tablet offering with Viu promotion, new device
summary: SPH is offering new subscribers of its News Tablet a free one-year Viu Premium 365 Days Plan, along with a Samsung Galaxy Tab A7 Wi-Fi Tablet. The new tablet features a 10.4-inch screen, improved storage, and longer battery life. Existing subscribers will also receive the free Viu access. The promotion is valid for readers of participating publications, offering a refreshed app interface and access to newspapers, magazines, and streaming of popular South Korean dramas.

site_title: The science behind investment algorithms
summary: Asia's capital markets have experienced significant volatility over the past couple of years, largely due to the COVID-19 pandemic. While markets have rallied somewhat, long-term stability remains elusive. Digitally powered asset preservation algorithms, often powered by artificial intelligence, can help investors manage their portfolios with efficiency. However, these algorithms are limited in their predictive capabilities, particularly in markets still in flux. As a result, the human element remains crucial in navigating the tumultuous landscape and making sense of markets. Investors must balance the benefits of AI-powered algorithms with the need for human intuition and judgment.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: DBS Group Holdings appointed senior civil servant Chng Kai Fong as a new non-executive director, effective March 31. Nanofilm Technologies was included in the FTSE ST Large & Mid Cap Index and FTSE ST Shariah Index, while Shangri-La Asia reported a net loss of US$460.2 million for its full year ended December 2020, citing the impact of Covid-19 on its hotel operations.

site_title: Bearer of medicine
summary: Zuellig Pharma CEO John Graham prioritizes employee safety and well-being as the largest vaccine and cold chain pharmaceutical distributor in Asia. During the pandemic, the company set up a volunteer program, ZPUnited, to support staff in critical roles and expanded its cold storage warehouse capacity to meet vaccine demands. Graham attributes the firm's success to teamwork and having a strong team of experienced people. He emphasizes the importance of adapting to change and embracing opportunities that come with it, and foresees a shift towards catering to niche healthcare needs in areas like oncology and rare diseases.

site_title: UK gets on with fast-paced vaccination roll-out, but easing of lockdowns may cause delay in achieving targets
summary: The UK's vaccination roll-out is progressing rapidly, but concerns arise about reaching initial targets due to a potential third wave of Covid-19 infections and vaccine import delays. Lockdowns are set to be relaxed, which could delay the recovery of the nation's economy. The British government must address these challenges while also dealing with people ignoring vaccination appeals and fears of a third wave spreading from Europe.

site_title: Sidelined in the workplace
summary: A common workplace issue is being sidelined, where employees feel passed over or overlooked despite their efforts. Experts suggest approaching the situation tactfully, seeking feedback from colleagues or a mentor, and gathering evidence to present a case to the boss. If the issue persists, it may be time to re-evaluate career growth opportunities and consider leaving the job. A comfortable job is not a guarantee of career advancement, and stagnant employees may actually be sliding backward. Companies must retain talent by creating a positive work environment and addressing underlying issues.

images.alt_text: "Talking to a senior colleague might help but employees need to spend some time doing some self-reflection first after talking to the boss. It is best to find out why you are being sidelined as there is usually an underlying cause." Linda Teo, country manager, ManpowerGroup Singapore.

site_title: WeWork to go public in special purpose acquistion valued at US$9b
summary: WeWork plans to enter public markets through a merger with special purpose acquisition company BowX Acquisition, valued at US$9 billion. The transaction raises US$1.3 billion for the office-sharing firm and allows WeWork to bypass a traditional initial public offering. The deal is the latest instance of a prominent company combining with a designated entity for a merger.

site_title: Shangri-La Asia reverses into losses as Covid-19 hit hotel operations
summary: Shangri-La Asia posted a net loss of US$460.2 million for its full year 2020, reversing a net profit of US$152.5 million the previous year, due to the impact of Covid-19 on international and domestic travel industries. Consolidated revenue declined 57.5% to US$1.03 billion. Hotel occupancy averaged 45% in Singapore, down from 82% a year ago. Despite challenges, the company reported a gradual recovery in some markets, including mainland China and China's consumption demand, and growth in new markets and product offerings.

site_title: US consumer spending, income fall in February
summary: US consumer spending fell 1.0% in February, more than expected, due to a cold snap and fading stimulus checks. Personal income dropped 7.1% after surging 10.1% in January. Economists had forecast a 0.7% decline in spending and a 7.3% drop in income. The decline is likely temporary, and consumer spending accounts for more than two-thirds of US economic activity.

site_title: Who owns the space behind your airplane seat?
summary: A new book, "Mine! How the Hidden Rules of Ownership Control Our Lives," by Michael Heller and James Salzman, challenges the conventional notion of ownership, arguing that our assertions of ownership are value-laden, inconsistent, and often in conflict with others' claims. The authors propose six pathways to claiming ownership, including possession and family entitlement, and suggest that recognizing underlying assumptions about ownership can lead to better advocacy for individuals, communities, and the common good.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hmlet, a co-living startup, has backed out of its expansion into Malaysia and Thailand less than six months after its launch, amid the pandemic and uncertainty about its future.

site_title: Unlocking the value of ESG data
summary: Fintech providers can play a crucial role in unlocking the value of ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) data in Asia, where the region's ESG assets reached $25.4 billion by end of 2020. However, significant barriers to adoption include inadequate access to ESG data, lack of clarity around ESG standards, and inconsistent ESG ratings. To overcome these challenges, fintech providers can offer modernized platforms embedded with enhanced data analysis and artificial intelligence (AI) technologies, enabling accurate and real-time ESG evaluation and decision-making.

site_title: Nanofilm's addition to new indices expected to boost trading liquidity
summary: Nanofilm Technologies has been included in the FTSE ST Large & Mid Cap Index and FTSE ST Shariah Index, effective March 22, 2021. The addition aims to boost trading liquidity and increase exposure to global index funds. As a result, Nanofilm was excluded from the FTSE ST Small Cap Index. The company's shares rose 1.03% to S$4.91 following the announcement.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on recovery hopes
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened higher on Friday as investors bought undervalued energy and bank stocks, betting on fast economic growth. The Dow Jones rose 61.6 points, or 0.19%, to 32,681.07, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased. Investors are optimistic about the US economy's recovery, with the fastest growth since 1984 expected. The gains come despite some uncertainty from US-EU trade talks and tariff concerns.

site_title: South-east Asia retail won't go fully online, so omni-channel strategy is needed: Report
summary: South-east Asia's retail sector will not fully transition to online shopping, with brick-and-mortar stores expected to remain crucial. An omni-channel strategy is necessary to balance online and offline business activities. The region's consumers are already 78% omni-channel shoppers, with Singapore and Malaysia driving e-commerce growth. However, high logistics costs, consumer preference for live interactions, and limited digital payment methods pose barriers to e-commerce adoption. Brick-and-mortar stores are expected to continue growing, especially in Vietnam, where alternative retail methods have low penetration.

site_title: Former BlackRock executive blows the whistle on greenwashing
summary: A former BlackRock executive, Tariq Fancy, has blown the whistle on greenwashing in the asset management industry, claiming that many funds are rebranding themselves as "green" without making any actual changes. The European Union's new Sustainable Finance Disclosure Regulation has created a three-pronged classification system, but Fancy argues that the rules are too broad and will incentivize asset managers to play fast and loose with the system. The move is seen as a major concern, with over 250 European funds changing their investment objectives to adopt an ESG stance last year, with many rebranding without actual changes.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia assigns Xinfei's debt to Chinese buyer for 48.7m yuan
summary: Hong Leong Asia has assigned a debt of 48.7 million yuan (S$10 million) to a Chinese buyer for its consumer products unit, Xinfei, which is undergoing restructuring. The debt had remained outstanding since 2018. This assignment is expected to boost the recovery rate for creditors, now at 10.9%, and result in a positive impact on the company's net asset value and earnings per share.

site_title: Porsche Panamera: Follow your basic instinct
summary: The updated 2021 Porsche Panamera has minor cosmetic tweaks, but its underlying 2.9-litre twin-turbocharged V6 engine remains unchanged, producing 330 horsepower and 450 Newton-metres of torque. The car boasts a smooth ride quality, improved damping control, and enhanced body stability, making it a comfortable cruiser and entertaining driver's car. The Panamera's interior is luxurious and upmarket, but its infotainment system can be complicated to navigate. Available in various variants, the base Panamera is a capable and well-rounded luxury performance saloon, offering a balance of performance and comfort at a relatively affordable price.

site_title: TPG Capital chooses banks for S$800m Asian pathology IPO: sources
summary: TPG Capital Asia has selected banks Citigroup, CIMB Group Holdings, Credit Suisse Group, and DBS Group Holdings to help prepare an initial public offering (IPO) for its pathology business, Pathology Asia Holdings, which could raise up to S$800 million. The IPO is planned for Singapore and could take place by the end of this year. The business, valued at about US$2 billion, has grown from 39 pathology laboratories purchased by TPG in 2018. The IPO would be the latest in a string of listings by Singapore companies this year, following Aztech Global's US$224 million offering.

site_title: US manufacturing powers on even as inflation heats up in March
summary: US manufacturing continues to grow, with the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's index of general business activity reaching a nearly five-decade high in March. The IHS Markit's preliminary gauge of US manufacturing was the second-strongest since 2007. Despite supply-chain woes and rising material costs, producers are expanding production, but shipping and port delays, as well as shortages of supplies, are driving up costs. Fed Chair Jerome Powell views the current supply-chain bottlenecks as temporary, but material inflation risks filtering through to higher prices of finished goods.

site_title: JLC Advisors Jeffrey Ong implicates Allied Tech executive director and investor in misappropriation case
summary: Former JLC Advisors managing partner Jeffrey Ong implicated Allied Tech executive director Kenneth Low and investor Lin Tah Hwa in a misappropriation case, alleging round-tripping and sham transactions in 2017 and 2018. Ong claims $76 million in funds were misappropriated, citing lack of civil litigation by Allied Tech. He faces 76 charges, including misappropriation of funds and cheating, and has been in remand for nearly two years. Ong seeks bail to pursue civil proceedings against those implicated, with a hearing set for April 9.

site_title: Why companies' 'net-zero' emissions pledges should trigger a healthy dose of scepticism
summary: Major companies, including United Airlines, BP, and Shell, have pledged to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, but critics argue these plans are problematic due to the complexity of the process and the reliance on offsets. Offsets, which involve funding projects to reduce emissions, are often unregulated and can be manipulated, raising concerns about their effectiveness. Additionally, the demand for offsets may lead to "climate colonialism," where wealthier companies force poorer countries to produce offsets. The article concludes that while net-zero is a critical step towards addressing climate change, it must be achieved smartly and not relied upon as the sole solution, with a focus on reducing global emissions and achieving net-negative emissions to effectively combat climate change.

site_title: Offer for Tianjin Zhong Xin triggered at revised price of US$0.894 per share
summary: A "chain offer" for the remaining shares of Tianjin Zhong Xin Pharmaceutical Group has been triggered following a transfer of ownership in Chinese conglomerate Tianjin Pharmaceutical Holdings. The offeror plans to maintain the listing status of the Singapore stock on the mainboard, with the revised offer price set at US$0.894 per share. The offer will close on April 29 and no extension will be given. The Singapore-listed stock closed at US$0.90 on March 25, and the chain offer is expected to impact the remaining shares held by non-offeror shareholders.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, driven by US gains. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.56% to 29,176.70, while the Topix index gained 1.46% to 1,984.16. The rises followed US President Joe Biden's pledge to boost vaccination efforts, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: Myanmar activists cited for Nobel Peace Prize
summary: Myanmar's civil disobedience movement, sparked by the military coup, has been nominated for the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize. The movement, which has used non-violent means to resist the power grab, represents an "exemplary peaceful response" to the coup, according to a Norwegian academic. The nomination comes as 320 people have been killed and nearly 3,000 arrested since the coup, which ousted Aung San Suu Kyi, who received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991. The nomination, submitted just before the deadline, could inspire other non-violent pro-democracy movements worldwide.

site_title: Down US$732b, Chinese tech stocks are still far from cheap
summary: Chinese tech stocks, including Tencent Holdings, Alibaba Group Holding, Baidu, and NetEase, have dropped 26% from their February highs, despite a recent rally, due to rising interest rates and regulatory scrutiny. The stocks still trade at valuations 23 times projected earnings, above the 18-19 times seen in 2018 and 2020. Investors remain cautious, with some cutting share-price targets and others warning of further downside, citing uncertainties over interest rates and regulatory measures.

site_title: China slaps sanctions on UK lawmakers over Xinjiang claims
summary: China has imposed sanctions on nine British politicians and four entities in the UK over their claims of human rights abuses in Xinjiang. The sanctions, which include a ban on entering China, trading with Chinese citizens, and freezing assets, were announced in response to the UK's sanctions on China. The move aims to eliminate the influence of the sanctioned individuals and entities, which China claims are spreading "lies and disinformation." British lawmakers, including former Conservative leader Iain Duncan Smith, vowed to continue exposing human rights abuses in Xinjiang despite the sanctions.

images.alt_text: China announced retaliatory sanctions on senior British politicians including the former leader of the ruling Conservative Party for "maliciously spreading lies and disinformation" about its Xinjiang region.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Ascott Residence Trust to 'add', expects faster recovery
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded Ascott Residence Trust (ART) to "add" with a higher target price of S$1.20, expecting a faster recovery from Covid-19 compared to peers. The brokerage attributes this to ART's assets in countries with low Covid-19 infections and a strong domestic market in Europe. It also highlights ART's strong balance sheet and recent acquisition of US student accommodation, which is projected to realise a 4.4% DPU accretion. The trust's stapled securities rose 1.9% following the upgrade.

site_title: Singapore shares end week in the black, STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the week on a positive note, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.5% to close at 3,157.95, driven by gains on Wall Street. Regional markets also closed higher, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index gaining 1.6% each. Despite rising tensions between the West and China, investor optimism about global economic recovery remained, with some areas of the market, such as travel and leisure, remaining susceptible to reopening delays.

site_title: Software maker UiPath last valued at US$35b reveals US IPO filing
summary: UiPath, a robotic process automation startup, has filed for a US$35 billion initial public offering (IPO) in New York, weeks after raising $750 million in funding. The company, which automates repetitive tasks for global companies, had considered a direct listing but opted for a traditional IPO. UiPath's valuation is more than three times its valuation from last July. The funding round included investors such as Alkeon Capital, Sequoia, and Tiger Global. The IPO filing marks UiPath's entry into the US IPO market, joining hundreds of other companies.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks notch weekly gain on economic optimism
summary: South Korean stocks ended the week with a slight gain, closing 32.68 points higher or 1.09% at 3,041.01, driven by optimism over improving US economic data and a forecast upgrade to 3.6% growth for 2021. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, LG Chem, and Naver also rose, while foreigners were net buyers of 296.6 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Soft drinks lose their fizz in Indonesia market as pandemic saps consumer demand
summary: Indonesia's beverage market declined 1.7% in Q4 2020 due to a 14.8% drop in soft drinks, with energy drinks and sports drinks also experiencing significant declines. Dairy products, however, saw a 7.9% rise in consumption, driven by white milk, flavoured milk, and "drinking yoghurt". Analysts attribute the decline to the COVID-19 pandemic, but expect the industry to recover as vaccine roll-outs lift the economy.

site_title: DBS adds Chng Kai Fong to boards of DBS Holdings and DBS bank
summary: DBS Group Holdings appointed senior civil servant Chng Kai Fong as a new non-executive director to the boards of DBS Holdings and DBS Bank, effective March 31. Chng joins the boards, serving on audit and nominating committees, amid an intense period of transformation in the Singapore economy post-COVID-19. He replaces three long-serving directors, Euleen Goh, Ow Foong Pheng, and Andre Sekulic, who step down on March 30. Chng brings public sector insights and is expected to deepen DBS' global banking and digital leadership.

site_title: New code of conduct launched to level playing field for retail tenants and landlords
summary: Singapore's government has launched a new code of conduct to promote fairer lease negotiations between landlords and retail tenants. The code, developed by a committee comprising major landlords and tenants, addresses 11 key areas, including rental structure and dispute resolution. The code will apply to all qualifying retail premises in Singapore and will be enforced through legislation, with the government working closely with stakeholders to turn it into law. The new code aims to address long-standing issues, such as unfair rent structures and difficulties in exiting leases early.

site_title: Thailand to reopen Phuket to vaccinated tourists from July
summary: Thailand plans to reopen Phuket to vaccinated tourists from July 1, three months earlier than the rest of the country, with a goal of inoculating at least 70% of island residents. The move aims to restart the tourism industry, which was severely impacted by the pandemic. If successful, it could add over $963 million to the economy. However, the government's success hinges on international vaccine passport agreements and negotiations with other countries for free travel.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB upgrades CDLHT to 'add', sees faster RevPAR recovery
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) to "add" from "hold" with a target price of S$1.43, citing a faster recovery of revenue per available room (RevPAR) in European and Australian markets. The brokerage expects stronger domestic markets in these regions to benefit from high inoculation rates, boosting earnings. CDLHT's strong balance sheet and acquisition of W Hotel at Sentosa are also seen as positives.

site_title: SPH bolsters News Tablet offering with Viu promotion, new device
summary: SPH is offering new subscribers of its News Tablet a free one-year Viu Premium 365 Days Plan subscription, along with a Samsung Galaxy Tab A7 Wi-Fi Tablet. The new tablet features a larger screen, better resolution, double the storage, and longer battery life. Existing subscribers will also receive the free Viu access. The Viu promotion is available to readers of participating publications, including The Straits Times News Tablet. This move aims to enhance the reading experience and provide users with more entertainment options.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended with strong gains on Friday, marking the end of a five-day losing streak. The Hang Seng Index rose 1.57% to 28,336.43, following the US economic data and Joe Biden's vaccine pledge. China's Shanghai Composite Index also increased 1.63%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 2.23%. The gains were attributed to traders' positive reaction to the US economic data and the US vaccine program.

site_title: Analysts raise Singapore manufacturing forecasts after February's output jump
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector showed resilience in February, with industrial production jumping 16.4% year-on-year, beating expectations. The electronics cluster drove growth, while transport engineering output declined for the 11th straight month. Analysts, including UOB's Barnabas Gan and OCBC's Selena Ling, upgraded their full-year manufacturing forecasts to 5.5% and 4% respectively, citing strong demand and a low base. The sector is expected to remain healthy in the first half of the year, with some analysts predicting a pick-up in transport engineering as global oil prices improve.

site_title: Malaysia mulling new taxes once economy recovers
summary: Malaysia's finance minister, Zafrul Abdul Aziz, stated that the government will focus on economic sectors affected by the pandemic and wait for the economy to recover before introducing new taxes. The government is studying the possibility of a consumption tax but has decided not to implement it now. Malaysia expects its economy to grow 6.5-7.5% this year after contracting 5.6% in 2020.

site_title: Japan approves Bill to oversee land deals near defence bases, border islands
summary: Japan's Cabinet approved a bill to oversee land deals near defense bases and border islands, reflecting concerns about overseas security risks. The bill requires planned purchases to be reported to authorities if deemed highly sensitive to national security, with deals in urban areas potentially exempt if they affect economic activity. The move follows similar regulations in the US and Britain, with a focus on addressing Chinese acquisitions in Japan, particularly in Hokkaido. Experts say the bill aims to balance government oversight with private rights, but registration of property records is incomplete in Japan, making it challenging to track landowners.

site_title: Europe: Markets advance strongly at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose strongly in early trading on Friday, following a good US jobs report. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.8%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 added 1.0% and 0.7%, respectively. The gains were attributed to a forecast-busting US jobs report, which mirrored positive performances elsewhere.

site_title: One community infection among 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 12 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 60,265, with one community case and 11 imported cases. The last local cluster was closed after a 28-day incubation period. The Ministry of Health (MOH) also reported a negative swab test result from the National University of Singapore wastewater incident, clearing all 438 residents. With 8 new recoveries, 60,071 patients have fully recovered, and 25 remain in hospital, with 112 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: Pharma, electronics propel Singapore factory output to 16.4% growth in February
summary: Singapore factory output surged 16.4% in February, driven by the electronics cluster, marking its fourth consecutive month of growth. This beat the median estimate of 15.8% expansion. Excluding biomedical contributions, industrial production increased 13.6%. The growth follows a 9.2% year-on-year increase in January.

images.alt_text: Singapore factory output jumped 16.4 per cent in February, in its fourth straight month of growth, as the linchpin electronics cluster continued to underpin gains.

site_title: Tata Sons wins legal battle over former chairman Mistry's ouster
summary: Tata Sons wins a four-year-long legal battle with the Indian Supreme Court, approving the ouster of former chairman Cyrus Mistry in 2016. The court ruled that Mistry's ouster was legal, rejecting allegations of mismanagement and oppression of minority shareholders. The verdict removes uncertainty for the Tata group, allowing it to focus on growth, while the Shapoorji Pallonji Group faces a blow as it seeks to raise money to repay debt. The court overturned a previous ruling that Mistry's ouster was illegal, affirming Tata Sons' rules on minority shareholders' rights.

site_title: Seven LNG tankers diverted after Suez Canal blockage: Kpler
summary: Seven liquefied natural gas (LNG) tankers are being diverted away from the Suez Canal due to traffic congestion caused by a stuck container ship. Three tankers are being rerouted around the Cape of Good Hope, while four others are being diverted to alternative routes, and four are not carrying cargo. The congestion is expected to affect 16 LNG vessels' planned transit via the Suez Canal, causing delays in the loading schedule at Ras Laffan for the start of April.

site_title: Allianz agrees to buy Aviva's Poland unit for US$2.9b
summary: Allianz has agreed to purchase Aviva's Polish unit for US$2.9 billion, valuing the business at 2.7 billion euros. The deal is subject to regulatory approval and expected to complete within 12 months. Aviva CEO Amanda Blanc is selling non-core assets to boost the struggling insurer's share price. The sale completes Blanc's plan to generate 7.5 billion euros in cash and make a substantial return of capital to shareholders. The deal makes Allianz the fifth largest insurer in Poland, mainly consisting of life insurance and pensions.

site_title: HDB and A*Star team up to advance smart-construction know-how
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) and Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) have collaborated on two initiatives to advance smart-construction know-how. The first is a research collaboration agreement (RCA) to develop and adopt 5G-enabled robotic, drone, and artificial-intelligence technologies for construction sites, aiming to improve safety and productivity. The second is a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to facilitate partnerships and commercialization of research outcomes, with HDB serving as the lead agency for intellectual property management.

site_title: Japan's Feb factory output to fall on global chip shortage: poll
summary: Japan's factory output is expected to fall 1.2% in February due to a global shortage of automotive chips, exacerbating the country's economic woes from the coronavirus crisis. Retail sales declined for a third consecutive month, with a 2.8% drop from a year earlier. The nation's jobless rate worsened slightly to 3.0% in February. The global chip shortage, worsened by a fire at a chip plant, is expected to put further pressure on factory output in the first quarter, potentially leading to an economic contraction.

site_title: Thailand faces meth trafficking surge after Myanmar coup
summary: Thailand is bracing for a surge in methamphetamine trafficking following a coup in neighboring Myanmar, with the UN warning of a significant increase in synthetic drug production. The kingdom has already seized over 80 million "yaba" pills in the past six months, and authorities are now facing a new threat as Myanmar's economy collapses. Organized crime groups and militias along the border are expected to exploit the situation, with the Golden Triangle region becoming a hub for the lucrative drug trade.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB reiterates 'add' on UMS, raises its target price to S$1.53
summary: Brokerage CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for UMS Holdings to S$1.53 from S$1.31, while maintaining its "add" call. This follows a report from Semiconductor Equipment International (SEMI) projecting US$80 billion in semiconductor equipment spending, driven by pandemic-induced demand for electronic devices. UMS is expected to benefit from strong spending on materials engineering solutions used to produce chips, supporting earnings expectations for FY21-23. However, downside risks include disruptions to the supply chain and higher-than-expected tax rates.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit hearing adjourned to March 30 after objection from unitholder
summary: A court hearing for Soilbuild Business Space Reit's (Soilbuild Reit) trust scheme of arrangement has been adjourned to March 30 after an unitholder objected to the use of the "one-proxy rule" for the meeting, citing concerns over unrepresented voices. The trust scheme involves the acquisition of Reit units by an entity owned by Soilbuild Group's executive chairman and Blackstone Real Estate. The one-proxy approach has come under scrutiny in recent months, with regulators and fund managers questioning its impact on unitholder representation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street following a forecast-beating US jobless claims report. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.52%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.29% and 0.36%, respectively. The gains come as investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: MND set to extend relief period for built environment contracts due to Covid-19
summary: The Singapore government plans to extend the relief period for firms in the built environment sector due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The Ministry of National Development (MND) will amend the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, allowing a six-month extension for construction contracts to Sept 30 and a three-month extension for options to purchase and sale agreements to June 30. This will help firms affected by the pandemic to seek temporary relief from legal action and negotiate mutually-beneficial resolutions. The extension aims to stabilize the industry and mitigate the lingering impact of the pandemic.

site_title: LTA awards S$604m civil contract for Cross Island Line Phase 1
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$604 million civil contract to Samsung C&T Corporation to design and construct the Hougang interchange station and tunnels as part of the Cross Island Line (CRL) Phase 1. Construction works are expected to start in Q4 2021, with passenger service slated for 2030. This phase of the CRL will be 29 kilometres long and serve 12 stations, benefiting over 100,000 households, with completion expected by 2029.

site_title: Xiaomi, Great Wall Motor shares surge after report on electric vehicle plan
summary: Shares in Xiaomi Corp surged 6.71% after a report revealed the company plans to make electric vehicles using Great Wall Motor's factory. Great Wall Motor's Hong Kong shares rose 8% and Shanghai shares gained over 7%. The news boosted investor confidence, with other Chinese companies also experiencing significant gains. The electric vehicle plan is seen as a strategic move to expand Xiaomi's product offerings and tap into the growing demand for EVs.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.90 points, or 0.12%, to 1,595.83. The market saw a volume of 238.08 million lots worth RM93.48 million. The index was affected by the overall global market trend.

site_title: Asia: Markets build on Wall Street lead after US jobs data
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, following the lead of Wall Street, as a US jobs report beat expectations and US President Joe Biden pledged to double COVID-19 vaccination targets. The gains were tempered by concerns over inflation and the potential for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. The US 10-year Treasury yield reached a one-year high, and traders are increasingly betting on an interest rate hike sooner rather than later. The positive outlook also lifted hopes for a gradual lifting of containment measures and a return to normal life.

site_title: Chinese developer Kaisa plans to partly fund HK$2.7b property buy via rights issue
summary: Chinese property developer Kaisa Group plans to raise HK$2.73 billion through a discounted rights share issue to fund a US$2 billion acquisition of a Beijing property. The move aims to partially address the company's liquidity issues amid stricter debt caps and bank loan exposure limits. Kaisa's shares fell 14% in early trading following the announcement, with Chairman Kwok Ying Shing and his affiliates set to fully subscribe to the rights issue, potentially increasing their stake to 40.5%. The company reported a 18.6% increase in 2020 net profit to 5.4 billion yuan.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened higher on Friday, rising 1.18% to 29,068.28, driven by US shares rising as investors cheered President Joe Biden's pledge to boost vaccination efforts. The broader Topix index also rose 1.01%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index opened higher Friday after US shares rose as investors cheered President Joe Biden's pledge to boost vaccination efforts.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Friday, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Friday, tracking Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.3% or 10.43 points to 3,152.14. Spackman Entertainment Group and Matex International led the day, with gains of 20% and 9.4% respectively. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose in early trade, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 0.8%. The gains follow Wall Street's higher close, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rising 0.5% and 0.1% respectively.

site_title: Myanmar's economy to contract 10% this year amid turmoil, says World Bank
summary: Myanmar's economy is forecast to contract by 10% this year due to nationwide protests, strikes, and sanctions following a military coup on February 1. The World Bank's revised forecast is a sharp reversal from its previous prediction of 5.9% growth. Protests have crippled the banking system and discouraged foreign investors, while the junta's internet shutdowns have further undermined economic activity. The economic downturn is attributed to civil disobedience, reduced mobility, and disruptions in public services, including banking, logistics, and internet services.

site_title: Young, rich and racy: South Korea's livestreamers
summary: In South Korea, young and wealthy livestreamers, known as "Broadcast Jockeys" or BJs, have gained popularity, entertaining thousands with gaming, chat, and interactive content. Top earners can make over $100,000 a month, with some earning up to $50,000 a month from platforms like AfreecaTV and YouTube. Despite controversy over lewd behavior and lack of regulation, the platform has seen significant growth during the pandemic, with mobile advertising revenue tripling between 2015 and 2019. The phenomenon has also led to mainstream appearances and new career paths for some, with "content creator" ranking as a desired job among primary schoolchildren.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CDL, Sembcorp, Genting
summary: OCBC's outgoing CEO Samuel Tsien will become an adviser to the board after retiring as director and CEO. Helen Wong will take over as new group CEO on April 15. CDL aims to become a master developer in Singapore, with its first launch this year being Irwell Hill Residences. Sembcorp Industries' unit Sembcorp Fuels was appointed as a new LNG importer for Singapore. Genting Singapore clarified that executive chairman Lim Kok Thay's remuneration more than halved last year, contrary to previous reports.

site_title: US workers enticed with bonuses, time off to get Covid-19 vaccine
summary: US companies are offering incentives, including bonuses and paid time off, to encourage workers to get vaccinated against Covid-19. Retail chains like Target and Kroger, as well as labor-intensive industries like slaughterhouses and supermarkets, are taking the lead. Some companies, like Bolthouse Farms and JBS, are also mandating vaccination for employees. Experts say while some companies may consider mandating vaccines, others may opt for incentives or soft mandates due to legal uncertainty and potential lawsuits.

site_title: Deutsche Bank CEO willing to give up investment bank oversight role
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing is willing to relinquish his role overseeing the investment bank, a move he never intended to make permanent. Pressure from regulators has driven this decision, following an overhaul in 2019. Sewing has come under scrutiny for his involvement in day-to-day operations of the investment bank. This development may lead to a reorganization of the bank's leadership structure, although no specific timeline has been announced. The move aims to address regulatory concerns and stabilize the bank's operations.

site_title: South Korea extends coronavirus distancing curbs as daily case count hits month high
summary: South Korea has extended its coronavirus distancing rules for two weeks due to a one-month high of 494 daily new cases, the highest in 35 days. The rules include a ban on gatherings of five or more people and a 10pm outdoor dining curfew. Authorities are concerned about increasing movement amid warm weather and growing fatigue among the public. The total infections in South Korea stand at 100,770, with 1,716 deaths. The government will reassess the rules in two weeks, but for now, the current distancing level will be maintained.

site_title: What next for the Singapore Turf Club?
summary: The Singapore Turf Club is facing a decline in the racing industry, with many winning trainers, jockeys, and champion horses leaving the country. The club is under financial stress, and the sport has lost its former glitz and glamour. Racing resumed last year behind closed doors due to pandemic restrictions, and it's unclear when spectators will be allowed to return. The decline is attributed to various factors, including the exodus of key stakeholders and the lifting of pandemic curbs.

site_title: Hmlet backs out of Malaysia, Thailand less than six months after launch
