summary: Hmlet, a co-living startup, has abandoned its expansion into Malaysia and Thailand less than six months after its launch, citing the pandemic and uncertainty about its future. The company had over 1,000 apartments listed in Malaysia and 2,500 in Thailand, but all property listings have been taken down from its website. This decision comes after former CEO Yoan Kamalski stated in September last year that Hmlet had more listings in the two countries.

images.alt_text: Hmlet appears to have abandoned its ill-fated expansion into Malaysia and Thailand less than six months after its launch.

site_title: Taiwan, US to strengthen maritime coordination as China looms
summary: Taiwan and the US have signed a Coast Guard Working Group agreement, strengthening maritime coordination amid growing regional concern over China's actions. The move comes as Taiwan upgrades its coast guard and deals with increasing encroachments from Chinese vessels. The agreement aims to foster a stronger partnership and promote a Free and Open Indo-Pacific region. The signing ceremony was attended by US Acting Assistant Secretary of State Sung Kim, who expressed concern about China's efforts to pressure Taipei. The move is seen as a demonstration of the US commitment to Taiwan's security.

site_title: Argentina says it will restrict flights from Brazil, Chile, Mexico
summary: Argentina has suspended flights from Brazil, Chile, and Mexico starting Saturday to prevent the spread of different coronavirus strains. The measures include mandatory testing and isolation for citizens returning from other regions. The decision comes amid concerns about Brazil's chaotic situation, with over 12 million cases and 300,000 deaths. Argentina has 2,278,115 cases and 55,092 deaths. The suspension follows a similar policy already in place for flights from Britain.

site_title: ByteDance hires CFO in a step towards IPO
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, has hired Xiaomi executive Shou Zi Chew as its new chief finance officer, a move seen as a step towards a potential initial public offering (IPO) of one or some of its businesses. ByteDance is considering a standalone public listing for Douyin, the Chinese version of TikTok, or listing some of its Chinese operations in Hong Kong or Shanghai. The company is also exploring a listing for its non-China business in Europe or the US. This hiring marks a significant development in ByteDance's IPO plans.

site_title: Europe: Pandemic worries weigh on shares
summary: European stocks ended lower on Thursday, slipping 0.3% due to fears over extended coronavirus restrictions and weaker crude prices. The Stoxx 600 index pulled back from 13-month highs as a new wave of infections and regional lockdowns overshadowed a strong March recovery. Tech stocks weighed down Wall Street, while defensive sectors like utilities and telecoms provided some support.

site_title: Mercedes to unveil flagship electric sedan with Tesla-beating battery
summary: Mercedes-Benz is set to unveil its flagship electric sedan, the EQS, on April 15, boasting a market-leading battery range of over 700 kilometers in lab testing. The model is expected to outperform Tesla's Long Range version of the Model S, with some startups like Lucid Motors and Tesla itself also releasing vehicles with comparable ranges. Mercedes aims to become a major player in the luxury electric vehicle segment, with plans to produce eight fully electric cars on three continents by 2022. The company's CEO, Markus Schaefer, expects the EQS to deliver the "physical proof points" of the company's strategy, marking a significant milestone in its transformation towards electric vehicles.

site_title: Biden says he expects to run for re-election in 2024
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed his intention to run for re-election in 2024, aiming to defy speculation that he would step down after a single term. He also criticized Republican efforts to limit voting, calling them "sick" and "un-American".

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on steady commodities, Wall Street rebound
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Friday, driven by miners and oil and gas explorers as commodity prices stabilized, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching 6,822. US stocks rebounded overnight, with the S&P 500 E-minis futures rising 0.1% in early Asian trade. Commodity prices stabilized after a sharp drop, with Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals Group advancing 1.5% each, while AMP shares rose 5% after the wealth manager reiterated its CEO.

site_title: Evergrande's 130b yuan online arm considering US IPO
summary: Evergrande Group's online home and car sales platform FCB Group is considering a US initial public offering (IPO) as early as the fourth quarter, according to people familiar with the matter. FCB Group, valued at approximately 130 billion yuan (S$26 billion), has reached out to prospective investors for a pre-IPO funding round and is working with advisers Bank of America and CLSA Ltd. This move comes as Evergrande faces pressure to slash debt under new Chinese regulations.

site_title: Fire at Saudi oil terminal after projectile hit: energy ministry
summary: A fire broke out at a Saudi oil terminal in Jizan after it was hit by a projectile, according to the energy ministry. The attack resulted in a fire in one of the terminal's tanks, but no casualties were reported. This incident comes as Yemen's Huthi rebels increasingly mount attacks on Saudi energy installations, marking the sixth anniversary of a Riyadh-led military intervention in Yemen. The identity of the perpetrator is currently unknown.

site_title: CIMB Singapore lays off staff after restructuring; Orchard branch to close
summary: CIMB Singapore is laying off staff and closing its Orchard branch as part of a restructuring exercise aimed at achieving sustainable growth. The bank's CEO, Victor Lee, stated that the move will allow the bank to optimize its functional setup, leverage group strengths through regionalization, and focus on key growth areas. Around 50 colleagues have been redeployed to new growth areas, and affected staff will receive a separation package, including one month's pay for every year of service, capped at 12 months.

images.alt_text: CIMB Singapore's CEO Victor Lee in a memo says that the bank's efforts to upskill staff since 2020, particularly in digital, data and design, have allowed it to redeploy over 50 colleagues in new growth areas.

site_title: Deliveroo strikes to precede London share listing
summary: Deliveroo, a meal delivery platform, is preparing for a major London stock listing despite facing criticism for its employment conditions, which have scared off some large investors. Disgruntled riders are planning strikes and social actions, including a strike on April 7, to protest against being classified as independent contractors and not receiving a minimum wage or benefits. The company's riders in the UK earn an average of £13 per hour, but a study found they receive less pay, with some cases below the minimum wage. Deliveroo's IPO is expected to be the biggest in London for a decade, but concerns about its financial prospects and working conditions may impact its stock performance.

site_title: Clifford Capital to embrace more new economy, green projects
summary: Clifford Capital, a Temasek-backed company, plans to focus on new economy, green, and renewable energy projects in Asia. Despite the pandemic, the company's core mandate to help Singapore-based firms secure financing remains unaffected. CEO Audra Low stated that activities have picked up in the last few months, with more deals emerging in the market. This shift is attributed to changes in demand, supply chains, ESG priorities, and technologies, leading to increased infrastructure spending in the region.

images.alt_text: Clifford Capital CEO Audra Low sees herself as both a market fixer - bridging gaps in cross border financing - and a shaper - helping shape the future of infrastructure development in Asia."

site_title: UK car output falls 14% in February amid Covid-19 hit
summary: The UK car production fell 14% in February to its lowest level since 2010, due to lockdown measures, supply chain problems, and new customs processes. A total of 105,008 cars were produced last month. Dealerships in England will remain closed until at least April 12 to combat Covid-19. The decline is attributed to a shortage of semi-conductors and Brexit deal rule changes.

site_title: New York Times digital 'NFT' article sells for US$563,000
summary: A New York Times columnist, Kevin Roose, sold a digital article for $563,000 through a non-fungible token (NFT) platform, becoming the latest example of the growing trend of NFT sales. Roose's article, "Buy This Column on the Blockchain," was initially aimed at testing the market for digital collectibles. This sale follows other notable NFT sales, including a Twitter message that sold for $2.9 million and a digital collage by Beeple that sold for $69.3 million. The proceeds will go to charities supported by The New York Times.

site_title: Most US banks can pay dividends, buy back shares in July: Federal Reserve
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced that most American banks will be able to pay dividends and buy back shares after June 30, following a relaxation of restrictions implemented during the pandemic. The restrictions, initially imposed in June 2020, were lifted in December, allowing banks with sufficient capital to resume dividend payments and share buybacks. The decision is based on the outcome of the current round of financial resilience stress tests, with banks that exceed the test limits able to lift restrictions immediately, while those below will face restrictions until September 30.

site_title: Oil prices drop 4% as new lockdowns undermine hopes for economic recovery
summary: Oil prices dropped 4% on Thursday due to renewed lockdowns in Europe and Asia, undermining hopes for economic recovery. Brent crude fell to $61.95 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude fell to $58.56 a barrel. The decline was attributed to reduced demand from Europe and Asia, as well as a strong US dollar. Opec+ is expected to roll over supply curbs into May, while US crude inventories rose to their highest since December, adding to global supplies.

site_title: Canada's biggest bank says the housing market is 'overheating'
summary: Royal Bank of Canada economist Robert Hogue warns that Canada's housing market is "overheating" due to strong demand, low inventories, and soaring property values. Hogue calls for policymakers to take action to cool the market and prevent a painful correction. He suggests local officials increase housing supply and the federal government reassess home-ownership supports, such as tax incentives and mortgage-lending rules. With interest rates expected to remain low, Hogue believes policy support for home ownership needs to be recalibrated to prevent exacerbating income inequality.

images.alt_text: Mr Hogue says responsibility to rein in the housing market could fall to local officials at the municipal and provincial level.

site_title: EU bars AstraZeneca vaccine exports until delivery 'catch up'
summary: The European Union has barred AstraZeneca from exporting Covid-19 vaccine doses until the company catches up on its promised deliveries to the bloc. EU chief Ursula von der Leyen stated that AstraZeneca must honor its contract before exporting vaccines. This move threatens to deepen a row with Britain, which relies on AstraZeneca shipments to fill a supply gap. The EU's export-authorisation scheme aims to protect international supply chains, with overall vaccine supplies expected to more than triple in the next three months.

images.alt_text: EU chief Ursula von der Leyen said on Thursday that AstraZeneca cannot export its Covid-19 vaccine doses out of the European Union until it makes good on its promised deliveries to the bloc.

site_title: US lawmakers, tech CEOs clash over disinformation
summary: US lawmakers criticized top tech executives from Facebook, Google, and Twitter for failing to prevent the spread of disinformation and calls to violence on their platforms. Lawmakers accused the companies of prioritizing profits over public interest and suggested new regulations are needed to hold them accountable. The CEOs defended their efforts to moderate content, citing the importance of free expression and the complexity of addressing extremism and misinformation. Lawmakers promised to introduce their own proposals to reform Section 230, a liability shield for tech companies, and vowed to legislate to hold them accountable.

site_title: Rare Van Gogh painting sells at auction for over 13m euros: Sotheby's
summary: A rare Vincent Van Gogh painting, "Street Scene in Montmartre", was sold at a Sotheby's auction in Paris for over 13 million euros, the highest price for a Van Gogh work in 30 years. The painting, which had been in private hands for over a century, was sold without a public exhibition since 1887. The buyer remains anonymous, with Sotheby's stating that the sale sets a new record for the artist.

site_title: The smart car buying guide
summary: This article is not about a car buying guide but rather a collection of various unrelated news articles. If you'd like, I can summarize one of the articles for you.

site_title: Temasek sees impact investing at tipping point
summary: Temasek Holdings believes impact investing has reached a tipping point, with the coronavirus pandemic highlighting deep social imbalances. Impact investments grew to $715 billion in 2019, with Temasek committing $500 million to Asia and Africa-focused Leapfrog Investments. Temasek's head of impact investing, Benoit Valentin, expects every big private equity firm to have its own impact vehicle in five years. The firm plans to take a stake in Leapfrog and is in talks to commit to other funds, citing the potential for "risk-adjusted PE-like returns" and setting clear benchmarks to sustain growth.

site_title: No simple return to old jobs, when Singapore-Malaysia land travel resumes
summary: Singapore's land border with Malaysia is set to reopen, but the resumption of travel will not automatically lead to a return to pre-pandemic employment levels. The closure has disproportionately affected non-resident workers in blue-collar jobs, with over 15% of the non-resident workforce shed in 2020. Companies may struggle to fill vacant positions, particularly in industries like retail and manufacturing, where demand for Malaysian workers has decreased due to a tightened dependency ratio ceiling and increased adoption of automation solutions.

site_title: Are buyers overpaying for freehold properties?
summary: A study by IREUS found that freehold properties in Singapore were sold 10.4% higher on average than comparable leasehold properties, despite a model ratio implying a premium of just 4%. This suggests buyers may be overpaying for freehold properties, which are scarce in Singapore due to the government's state ownership of over 80% of land.

site_title: US, UK impose sanctions on firms controlled by Myanmar's military
summary: The US and UK have imposed sanctions on conglomerates controlled by Myanmar's military, targeting conglomerates Myanmar Economic Holdings Public Company Ltd (MEHL) and Myanmar Economic Corporation Ltd (MEC). The sanctions freeze assets in the US and target the military's financial interests to help drain funding for their campaigns of repression. A UN expert on human rights, Tom Andrews, warned that the world's response to the crisis has been too sluggish and called for an emergency summit to sharpen the response, citing the need for robust action to prevent further deterioration.

site_title: US: Volatile day on Wall Street ends with indices higher
summary: US stock indices ended higher on Thursday, following a volatile session, as traders shifted into cyclical equities amid concerns about rising lending rates. The S&P 500 gained 0.5%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.1%. Stocks benefiting from an improving economy, such as Boeing, United Airlines, and American Airlines, rose 3.3%, 4.1%, and 4.4%, respectively. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged that rates will rise when the economy recovers, but signaled a gradual approach.

site_title: North Korea launch was new 'tactical guided projectile': Pyongyang
summary: North Korea launched a new "tactical guided projectile" with a solid-fuel engine, its first substantive provocation since US President Joe Biden's inauguration. The projectiles, carrying a 2.5-ton payload, accurately hit a target 600km into the Sea of Japan. The test was supervised by Ri Pyong Chol, not leader Kim Jong Un, and was deemed "of great significance" in bolstering military power and deterring threats on the Korean Peninsula. This move violates UN Security Council resolutions banning ballistic missile development.

site_title: US$2 trillion rainbow of ethical debt sows investor confusion
summary: Record demand for sustainable finance is driving a "rainbow of debt" with governments and companies issuing various colored bonds to fund climate change mitigation. Green bonds, which pledge proceeds to renewable energy projects, dominate the market. However, blue bonds (marine conservation) and brown bonds (adaptation and resilience) are gaining traction, with some labels remaining niche. The surge in sustainable finance is spurring innovation in the industry, but investor confusion remains as the various debt types are often used interchangeably. This trend is expected to continue as investors increasingly seek environmentally-conscious investment options.

site_title: Getting minimum wage right
summary: US President Joe Biden's proposed federal minimum wage increase to $15 per hour has sparked debate. Proponents argue it would raise wages for 27 million workers, but opponents worry it would lead to job losses, particularly for small businesses and industries already struggling, such as the hospitality and childcare sectors. A higher minimum wage could also reduce total worker compensation if employers cut benefits to offset the increase. Experts suggest a compromised rate above $7.25 but below $15, with exemptions for teenage and apprenticeship employment, and adjustments for cost of living differences among states, could mitigate potential negative effects.

site_title: Singapore O&G taps demand for quality confinement care to diversify business
summary: Singapore O&G (SOG) is expanding into the confinement care centre business, tapping into the growing demand for higher quality postpartum services. The firm's first overseas venture is a joint venture in Johor, aiming to diversify its healthcare services and revenue streams. CEO Eric Choo sees this move as an opportunity to capture a growing market trend.

site_title: All 20 units of luxury development sold
summary: SWIRE Properties of Hong Kong announced the sale of all 20 units at its completed freehold luxury apartment development, Eden, in Singapore for S$293 million, averaging S$4,827 per square foot. Each of the four-bedroom units, measuring over 3,000 sq ft, occupies an entire floor. The sale price reflects the project's high-end nature, with all units sold in a short period.

site_title: RCEP members want deal to take effect from 2022: China
summary: China is urging the early implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), with members aiming for it to take effect on January 1, 2022. China has ratified the pact, and 15 Asia-Pacific economies, including China, Japan, and South Korea, have formed the world's largest free trade bloc. The RCEP must be ratified by six Asean countries and three non-Asean countries before it can come into effect 60 days later. This move is seen as a bid to counter US influence in the Asia-Pacific region, following the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

images.alt_text: China is encouraging the early implementation of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), and members of the Asia-Pacific trade pact aim for it to take effect from Jan 1, 2022, China's vice-commerce minister Wang Shouwen said on Thursday.

site_title: CDL 'confident' about attaining master-developer status
summary: CDL, a Singapore property group, aims to become a master developer, planning and building entire precincts or districts instead of individual parcels. The group is confident in its chances of clinching master-development projects, particularly the 8.3-hectare Kampong Bugis site, which could yield up to 4,000 new homes. CDL is also preparing for its first launch this year, Irwell Hill Residences, with over 1,200 units across various projects. The company has called for updates to the additional buyer's stamp duty rules and more flexible housing models to ease pressure on developers.

site_title: Oil prices drop as demand concerns outweigh Suez Canal disruptions
summary: Oil prices dropped 1.8% to $63.22 a barrel for Brent crude and 2.2% to $59.83 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, as concerns about demand outweighed disruptions to the Suez Canal. A ship blocking crude oil carriers in the canal has suspended traffic temporarily, but analysts believe the incident will have a short-term impact. European demand is weak due to lockdowns, and expectations are that Opec+ will roll over supply curbs into May.

site_title: Stranded Suez ship's owner, insurers face millions of dollars in claims
summary: The 400-meter, 224,000-tonne Ever Given container ship remains stuck in the Suez Canal, with its owner and insurers facing millions of dollars in claims, regardless of a quick refloating. The ship's owner, Japanese firm Shoei Kisen KK, and its insurers could be liable for loss of revenue, and other ships affected by the blockage may also make claims. Insurance sources estimate the ship's hull and machinery damage could total $100 million to $140 million, with potential claims for loss of revenue, perishable goods, and missed delivery deadlines.

images.alt_text: The 400-metre, 224,000-tonne Ever Given ran aground on Tuesday morning after losing the ability to steer amid high winds and a dust storm, the Suez Canal Authority says.

site_title: The NFT effect on Singapore art
summary: Singapore artists are embracing the non-fungible token (NFT) market, with Speak Cryptic selling his first NFT artwork for 0.7 Eth, equivalent to S$1,485. The rise of NFTs has led to a surge in popularity, with platforms like Cargo and Mintable experiencing significant growth. Artists such as Howie Kim and Phunk are exploring the new medium, while gallerists are cautioning collectors to wait until the market stabilizes. Traditionalists argue that NFTs offer a new way for collectors to engage with art, while some critics question the value and authenticity of digital art.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's new deal is latest effort to prop up CK Asset share price
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing and his son Victor Li are attempting to boost the stock price of CK Asset Holdings with a HK$17 billion buyback of shares. Despite a HK$4.4 billion personal purchase effort, the company's share price has slumped 16% since 2019. The buyback, which includes an 8.4% premium, aims to reverse the decline and is seen as a sign that CK Asset is not abandoning its buyback strategy. Analysts expect the move to support the company's share price in the future.

site_title: Mining billionaire takes on Musk in hydrogen vs EVs debate
summary: Australian mining magnate Andrew Forrest has criticized Tesla CEO Elon Musk's view on hydrogen cars, calling them "mind-bogglingly stupid". Forrest believes hydrogen, produced from renewable energy, is a game-changer in the clean-energy transition and could be more abundant than battery materials. Forrest's company, Fortescue Metals Group, is planning to produce green hydrogen to become a major clean-energy producer. Musk has instead promoted solar and wind energy paired with stationary battery storage for green vehicles. Forrest remains optimistic about hydrogen's potential, citing China's plans to increase its use.

images.alt_text: Andrew Forrest has made hydrogen the centrepiece of a plan to turn Fortescue into a major clean-energy producer.

site_title: US dollar holds near four-month high against euro
summary: The US dollar hovered near a four-month high against the euro due to divergent recovery outlooks for the US and Europe and waning risk appetite in equities. Global stock markets fell, and the euro was down 0.1% against the dollar. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the US recovery, while analysts expect the euro to fall to $1.16 over the next month due to concerns over the EU's 'third Covid wave' and vaccine rollout issues.

site_title: Samsung unveils next-generation memory for data-hungry AI and computers
summary: Samsung Electronics has unveiled its next-generation memory chips, DDR5, promising to double speeds and offer the largest capacity yet. Developed using a High-K Metal Gate fabrication process, DDR5 will be twice as fast as DDR4, reducing leakage and power consumption. The transition to DDR5 is expected to begin in the second half of 2021, with Intel and AMD supporting the new standard. Analysts predict DDR5 chips will be 20% larger, leading to increased pressure on semiconductor supply chains, and expect a 30-40% price hike initially.

site_title: China tech giants dive as delisting threat joins crackdown fears
summary: China's tech giants, including Tencent and Alibaba, plummeted as US regulators revived threats to delist them from US exchanges, exacerbating concerns of a widening antitrust crackdown. The Hang Seng Technology Index fell to its lowest since November, wiping 20% off Chinese tech names. Tencent's market value has dropped over $200 billion since a January peak, with brokerages cutting price targets. The losses follow a warning from the Securities and Exchange Commission that it's taking steps to review financial audits of overseas companies, potentially leading to ejection from exchanges.

site_title: US GDP growth in Q4 revised up; weekly jobless claims fall
summary: US GDP growth in Q4 was revised up to 4.3% annualized, a sharp deceleration from the record 33.4% rate in the third quarter. Corporate profits contracted at a 1.7% rate in Q4, but economists forecast the economy to grow by up to 7.5% in the first quarter, the fastest growth since 1984. Jobless claims fell to 684,000, down from 781,000 the prior week, as economic activity rebounds after weather-related disruptions. The labor market is expected to take years to fully recover from the pandemic's scarring, with employment 9.5 million jobs below its peak.

site_title: Can Singapore forge a unique way to address issues facing gig workers?
summary: Singapore is exploring ways to address the challenges faced by gig workers, who are increasingly prevalent in the gig economy. The government has introduced measures such as the SEP Income Relief Scheme, but long-term challenges remain, including fluctuating income and inadequate protections. A proposed tripartite standard aims to provide guidelines for businesses engaging gig workers, but concerns exist about the impact on innovation and consumer welfare. A dialogue between stakeholders, including gig workers, businesses, and the government, is necessary to develop solutions tailored to Singapore's unique situation and mitigate potential negative effects.

site_title: Prolonged Suez blockage may delay vessels, trap goods for Singapore
summary: The Suez Canal blockage is expected to have a short-term impact on Singapore, with potential delays in arrival times and disruption to supplies. Freight rates and insurance claims may rise, while PSA may need to initiate steps to tackle backlogs. Market watchers predict a few days of delay for vessels going back to Asia, with minimal impact on Singapore specifically. The blockage may also result in higher ocean shipping costs and disrupt global trade, particularly for oil and petroleum products.

site_title: Women hold majority of seats on GM's expanded board of directors
summary: General Motors has expanded its board of directors to 13 members, with women holding seven seats. The new directors, Meg Whitman and Mark Tatum, join a diverse board that GM CEO Mary Barra believes is a competitive advantage in transforming the company's products and business lines. This move comes as the largest US automaker navigates a sweeping transformation, with Ford Motor Co also nominating a fourth female director.

site_title: US regulator looking into blank cheque IPO frenzy: sources
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Wall Street's blank check acquisition frenzy, seeking information on how underwriters manage risks involved in special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs). The SEC sent letters to banks seeking data on SPAC deal fees, volumes, and internal controls. The investigation follows a surge in SPAC deals to a record $170 billion this year, fueled by easy monetary conditions and less regulatory scrutiny. The SEC is also concerned about the depth of due diligence and transparency in SPAC transactions.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's biggest gold rush of recent years, SPACs have surged globally to a record US$170 billion this year, outstripping last year's total of US$157 billion.

site_title: Employers to get over S$3b in wage subsidies payouts from end-March
summary: Singapore employers will receive over S$3 billion in wage subsidies payouts from March 30 under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS). The payout benefits over 2 million local employees and is based on employers' mandatory Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions for September to December 2020. Employers in hardest-hit sectors will receive 50% support, while those in other sectors will get 10-30% support. The payout is part of the JSS extension announced in February 2021, which provides wage support for up to 23 months.

images.alt_text: From March 30, more than 150,000 employers will receive payouts of over S$3 billion under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) of wage subsidies. The payment will benefit over two million local employees.

site_title: Rates would move only after 'all but full recovery': Fed's Powell
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that interest rates will not rise until the economy has "all but fully recovered" from the pandemic's damage. This process is expected to occur in the "longer run," likely outside the current three-year forecast period. Powell reiterated the Fed's plan to reduce its bond purchases after the US achieves "substantial further progress" toward maximum employment and 2% inflation target. This suggests a delayed rate hike, with 11 of 18 Fed officials predicting no increase before 2024.

site_title: IMF warns of 'diverging recoveries' post-pandemic
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of "diverging recoveries" among global economies as they recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite overall improvement, many countries and people are still left behind, with the IMF predicting a strong rebound of 5.5% this year. New growth forecasts will be released on April 6.

site_title: Setback for 1MDB case as US judge rules against Dept of Justice
summary: A US judge ruled against the Department of Justice's (DOJ) attempt to seize $325 million from an oil exploration joint venture linked to the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) scandal. US District Judge Dale Fischer rejected the DOJ's forfeiture claim, finding that the government failed to make an adequate allegation between the money and any criminal offence. This setback for federal prosecutors in the multibillion-dollar kleptocracy case comes as the 1MDB scandal has sparked court cases worldwide, with Malaysian authorities seeking to track down over $4 billion siphoned off from the country's economic development fund.

site_title: Fashion forward in Singapore
summary: Louis Vuitton held its first physical fashion show in Singapore, marking a significant milestone for the brand in the region. The 19-minute show, titled the Louis Vuitton Women's Spring/Summer 2021 Spin-Off, took place at the ArtScience Museum despite heavy rain and featured 41 models showcasing bright pastel colors and graphic prints. The event was a first for Louis Vuitton in South-east Asia and highlighted the brand's commitment to local talent, with all models being Singaporean or based in the city-state.

site_title: Asean foreign ministers back summit on Myanmar
summary: Asean foreign ministers, led by Singapore and Indonesia, have backed a summit to address the crisis in Myanmar following the military coup. The summit, to be held in the "near future," aims to establish a common position and express Asean's support for Myanmar. The ministers expressed concern over the use of force and urged the Myanmar military to stop the violence and start a dialogue for democracy, peace, and stability. National reconciliation is seen as essential, and Asean is ready to help, with no foreign interference expected.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's shares rise as more poised to return to work
summary: ComfortDelGro's shares rose 2.4% to S$1.69, their highest close in a month, after higher capacity limits for group events are expected to boost passenger loads for transport operators.

images.alt_text: RHB has ComfortDelGro among its top buy recommendations, and expects the group's Singapore public transport and taxi businesses to support an earnings rebound amid normalisation of operations in 2021.

site_title: Co-living startup Hmlet loses CEO; hit by senior management exodus
summary: Hmlet, a Singapore-based co-living startup, has lost its CEO and several top executives, including its CTO and CFO, amidst a series of departures. The company's co-founder Yoan Kamalski will focus on investment partnerships and fundraising, while Peter Kennedy, a senior advisor at Burda Principal Investments, has taken over as interim CEO. The exits come as the co-living sector faces challenges due to the pandemic, and Hmlet has had to restructure its teams and operations. The company is now left with less than 90 full-time employees, but has recently upgraded its tech infrastructure, which could serve as a growth engine.

site_title: Biden's sensible stimulus makes sure that mistakes are not repeated
summary: US President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan is providing sufficient stimulus to prevent a repeat of the 2009 economic crisis, economists say. Despite warnings of overheating, forecasters expect rapid growth in 2021, with GDP returning to pre-pandemic levels soon. The plan's size is justified by pent-up demand and the ongoing vaccine rollout, and its impact is likely to be limited by a flat Phillips curve, which suggests inflation won't rise significantly. The plan aims to avoid the mistakes of the 2009 stimulus, which was deemed too small and short-lived.

site_title: French garden dining in the city
summary: Chef Louis Pacquelin's new restaurant Clos Pasoh in Singapore offers a light and satisfying French-inspired meal with a focus on Asian flavors. The menu features dishes such as bisque coco-homard, champignons au vin jaune, and trippes et caviar, all with minimal use of cream and butter. Pacquelin's ability to balance flavors and textures is evident in dishes like vegetable cocotte and French sea bass. The restaurant's contemporary French-tropical setting complements its innovative take on traditional French cuisine, making it a standout dining experience in the city.

images.alt_text: Coconut lobster bisque and mushroom comte cheese.
An excellent vegetable cocotte in a sauce of vegetable jus enhanced with just a bit of butter and agar agar.
Chocolate mousse, made to his mother's recipe, and rum baba.
A double treat of fried and braised tripe that is both crisp and unctuous.
Perfectly seared French seabass or maigre.

site_title: Hong Kong tells foreign governments to stop accepting special British passport
summary: Hong Kong's government has told 14 countries to stop accepting the British National Overseas (BNO) passport, a travel document used by many young Hongkongers to apply for working holiday visas. The move, effective January 31, demands that Hong Kong passport holders be used instead. Diplomats describe the move as a diplomatic affront, with some countries ignoring the request. The BNO passport was created ahead of Britain handing Hong Kong back to Chinese rule in 1997, and critics say it's a pathway to full citizenship for those seeking to leave the Chinese-ruled territory.

site_title: Anniversary specials at Mandarin Orchard Singapore
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore is celebrating its 50th anniversary with a Golden Jubilee celebration. The luxury hotel is offering a 50% off its best available rate for stays from April to June 2021, including breakfast for two people and 50% off meals at its signature Chatterbox restaurant. The package excludes lobster laksa, and a separate dining deal is available for those who prefer to dine at Chatterbox, with any two mains and selected local drinks for $50 nett.

site_title: Econ Healthcare files to relist on Catalist
summary: Econ Healthcare, a Singapore-based private nursing home operator, has filed to relist on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange. The group plans to expand its facilities, including two upcoming nursing homes in Singapore, and increase its total bed capacity to 2,388 by 2025. Despite a gradual decline in its top and bottom line from FY18 to FY20, Econ Healthcare generated a revenue of S$10.2 million in the first six months of FY21. The company, which was privatised in 2012, is seeking to regain its trading liquidity.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; fourth-quarter growth revised up
summary: US jobless claims fell to 684,000 in the week ending March 20, down from 781,000 the prior week, beating economists' forecasts. Economic activity is rebounding after weather disruptions in February, but the labor market is expected to take years to fully recover from the pandemic. The economy's fourth-quarter growth was revised up to 4.3% annualized, and forecast to grow by 7% in the first quarter, the fastest growth since 1984.

site_title: Econ Healthcare seeks Catalist listing, again
summary: Econ Healthcare, a Singapore-based private nursing home operator, is seeking a Catalist listing on the Singapore Exchange for the second time. The company, which currently operates 10 medicare centers and nursing homes, plans to expand its facilities and increase its bed capacity to 2,388 by 2025. Despite a gradual decline in its bottom line since FY18, Econ Healthcare reported a net profit of S$3.7 million in the first half of FY21. The company's top and bottom line have been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, but it aims to capitalize on the growing demand for healthcare services in Singapore and China.

site_title: Renewable energy firm Sunseap weighing IPO: sources
summary: Singapore renewable energy firm Sunseap is considering an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to S$600 million, according to sources. The company, backed by Thai energy firm Banpu, aims to list by the end of this year and is working with advisers on the planned IPO. A successful deal would boost the Singapore IPO market, which has only seen one new listing this year. Sunseap has a portfolio of nearly two gigawatt-peak of pending and completed solar projects in Singapore and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Xiaomi flags rising costs of chips; shares fall
summary: Xiaomi reported quarterly revenue below market estimates, with sales jumping 25% to 70.46 billion yuan, but shares fell 5% due to rising chip costs and a global shortage. The company's international business head, Shou Zi Chew, resigned after joining TikTok owner ByteDance. Xiaomi's fintech business faced regulatory challenges, and analysts predict a hit to earnings growth. Despite this, the company's smartphone sales rose 38% and it cornered 15% of China's domestic market share.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log first gain in five days on recovery hopes
summary: South Korean stocks rose for the first time in five days, with the Kospi index increasing 11.98 points, or 0.40%, to 3,008.33. The gains were driven by hopes of a faster economic rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic, following reassurance from US policymakers. The Kospi has risen 4.69% so far this year, but lost 4.0% in the previous 30 trading sessions.

site_title: PSA may face schedule disruptions if Suez Canal jam is prolonged: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's PSA International may face schedule disruptions if the prolonged blockage of the Suez Canal affects global trade. Minister for Transport Ong Ye Kung warned that a blockage akin to a tree falling across a major highway would impact multiple expressways linked to the Central Expressway. The Suez Canal, a crucial waterway for 10% of global seaborne trade, has been halted due to a 400-metre container ship blown off course by strong winds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Thursday, down 4.67 points to 1,597.73. Volume reached 6.011 billion lots worth RM3.037 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 580 to 429.

site_title: SPACS tumble on report that US regulator has opened inquiry into frenzy
summary: US regulators have opened an inquiry into the frenzy surrounding special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs), leading to a 1.8% slump in the IPOX SPAC Index. The investigation is reportedly fact-finding, but could turn into a more formal inquiry depending on findings. Over 700 SPACs have raised $227 billion in the past year, with officials anticipating letters from regulators about potential dangers. The inquiry comes as the market struggles to handle the "overflow" of new listings.

site_title: Fed's Powell: Changes to Fed policy will be gradual, transparent
summary: Fed Chair Jerome Powell stated that any changes to the Federal Reserve's policy will be gradual and transparent, and only made after the economy has fully recovered. The Fed will gradually roll back its $120 billion monthly bond purchases, and rate increases will only be considered when the economy is almost fully recovered.

site_title: Nike faces social media storm in China over Xinjiang statement
summary: Nike faces backlash in China over a statement expressing concern about reports of forced labor in Xinjiang and stating it does not use cotton from the region. The statement trended on Chinese social media platform Weibo, prompting a social media storm. Chinese actor Wang Yibo terminated his contract with Nike in response to criticism. The incident highlights Nike's reliance on China despite US tariffs and calls into question the company's commitment to human rights.

site_title: Sembcorp unit appointed as a new term LNG importer for Singapore
summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly-owned unit, Sembcorp Fuels (Singapore), has been appointed by the Energy Market Authority as a new term liquefied natural gas (LNG) importer for Singapore. This appointment will enable Sembcorp to offer a diverse portfolio of energy generation sources and supplies, including LNG, piped natural gas, biomass, and solar. Sembcorp is Singapore's largest natural gas supplier and leading solar energy provider, aiming to contribute to the nation's energy transformation with sustainable, competitive, and reliable energy solutions.

site_title: Banking on the designer touch
summary: Singapore's banks, Citibank and OCBC, have revamped their spaces to cater to affluent clients. The Citi Wealth Hub on Orchard Road features a conservatory design, while OCBC's Premier Private Client centre resembles a posh hotel lounge. These spaces aim to provide a personalized banking experience, with exclusive experiences and financial advice. According to OCBC's Sunny Quek, customers now expect a banking relationship built on trust and personalized services, moving beyond traditional banking. This shift reflects changing customer expectations and the need for banks to adapt to evolving needs.

site_title: US personal income growth highest ever last year on stimulus package
summary: US personal income grew 6.1% to $19.7 trillion last year, the highest on record, driven by stimulus checks and government aid. This translates to an additional $1.1 trillion earned, surpassing wage and property value gains. The stimulus package, including $498 billion in state unemployment benefits, played a key role in supporting Americans' finances during the pandemic recovery. Wages increased only 0.3%, with the sharpest declines in Northeastern and Midwestern states.

site_title: US: Stocks open lower, extending streak of losses
summary: US stocks fell early Thursday, extending a streak of losses, amid concerns over potential US corporate tax hikes and inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.7% to 32,189.53, while the S&P 500 fell 0.5% to 3,868.46. Despite improving economic data, including a 4.3% fourth-quarter economic growth and a drop in weekly jobless claims, investors weigh the impact of potential tax hikes on the market.

site_title: Libor transition goes on despite lack of term SOFR
summary: The Alternative Reference Rates Committee (ARRC) overseeing the US Libor transition has expressed uncertainty about meeting its plan to wean the financial system off the benchmark. The group cannot guarantee a vital last step in the process, the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) term rate, will happen by mid-2021 or year-end due to insufficient liquidity in derivatives tied to SOFR. This decision has frustrated a small group of players in the financial system, which relies on the Libor benchmark. The uncertainty has raised concerns about the Libor transition process.

site_title: Suez Canal suspends traffic while efforts to dislodge ship continue
summary: The Suez Canal suspended traffic on Thursday as efforts to dislodge the 400m-long container vessel Ever Given continued for a third day. Eight tugs are working to straighten the ship, which ran aground diagonally across the canal on Tuesday after losing steering amid high winds and a dust storm. The blockage is blocking transit in both directions through one of the world's busiest shipping channels, affecting goods and oil shipments between Asia and Europe. The operation may take weeks, with shipping firms considering re-routing vessels around Africa to avoid the delay.

site_title: Outgoing OCBC CEO Samuel Tsien to be adviser to bank's board upon retirement
summary: OCBC's outgoing CEO Samuel Tsien will be appointed as adviser to the bank's board upon his retirement. Tsien, 66, will step down after 14 years with the bank, where he led successful expansions and acquisitions. Helen Wong, former HSBC CEO in Greater China, will take over as new group CEO starting April 15, becoming the first woman to head a Singapore bank. Wong has extensive experience in investment and corporate banking, having joined OCBC in 1984.

site_title: OCBC Cycle to feature a mix of on-site and virtual events
summary: Singapore's OCBC Cycle road-cycling event is set to return in a hybrid format this May, featuring both on-site and virtual events. The traditional two-day event will be split into two segments, with teams competing in championship events on closed roads and individuals participating in virtual rides from anywhere in the country. New categories include the OCBC Cycle Speedway Club Championship, OCBC Cycle Speedway Women Championship, and OCBC Cycle Speedway Corporate Championship, with cash prizes up to S$800 for the top three winners.

site_title: 1MDB case hits setback as judge rules against US Justice Department
summary: A US judge rejected the Justice Department's attempt to seize $325 million from an oil exploration joint-venture linked to the 1MDB scandal. The ruling came after the judge found that the government failed to make an adequate allegation between the money and a criminal offense. This is a setback for federal prosecutors in the multibillion-dollar kleptocracy case, which involves the alleged theft of $4 billion from Malaysia's economic development fund. The case has sparked court cases worldwide, with US prosecutors seeking to recoup at least $1 billion in allegedly spent luxury goods.

site_title: Societe Generale joins DBS in paring Hong Kong office space
summary: Societe Generale is vacating one floor in Hong Kong's Admiralty business district due to rising staff expectations to work from home and reduced costs. The French bank is releasing space in Swire Properties' Three Pacific Place, where it previously had a seven-floor lease. This move follows other foreign banks, including DBS and BNP Paribas, in downsizing their Hong Kong offices. The trend is driven by rising vacancy rates and falling rental rates, with overall vacancy at 9.3% and rental rates expected to fall 7% in 2021.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CIMB Singapore has laid off staff following a restructuring exercise, with the Orchard branch set to close. Swire Properties sold all 20 units of Eden for approximately S$300m. Fintech firm #dltledgers secured a US$7m Series A funding round. SGProtein, a plant-based meat manufacturer, raised S$4m in a seed round led by Khong Guan. DBS introduced complimentary Covid-19 vaccine insurance, offering up to S$1,000 in case of complications. The STI rose 0.3% on Thursday, closing at 3,141.71.

site_title: CDL 'confident' in master-developer ambitions; launching Irwell Hill Residences on April 10
summary: CDL, a Singaporean property developer, aims to become a master developer, focusing on replenishing its land bank to ensure a stable launch pipeline. The company is exploring opportunities in master-developer initiatives, including the 8.3ha Kampong Bugis site, which could yield up to 4,000 new homes. CDL is "very confident" in its chances of clinching such projects, given its track record of winning tenders under the two-envelope system. The company's residential launch pipeline for 2021 includes over 1,200 units, with its first launch, Irwell Hill Residences, set for April 10.

site_title: Europe: Stocks waver at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets wavered on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.1% and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices losing 0.2% each. Despite concerns over the coronavirus, mining and healthcare stocks supported shares. The US stock market also saw a fresh record, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edging higher despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariff issues.

site_title: UK and US sanction military-owned Myanmar conglomerate
summary: The UK and US have imposed sanctions on Myanmar Economic Holdings Limited (MEHL) and Myanmar Economic Corporation Limited (MEC), a conglomerate owned by the country's military. The sanctions target the military's financial interests, aiming to drain their funding for repression. The companies dominate the economy, controlling sectors such as trade, natural resources, and consumer goods. The move comes in response to the military's actions, including the 2017 ethnic cleansing of the Rohingya. The sanctions block US property and assets of the groups, with the US urging a return to the democratically elected government.

site_title: Japanese owner of container ship stuck in Suez Canal apologises
summary: A Japanese container ship, owned by Shoei Kisen, is stuck in the Suez Canal, causing significant delays and potential losses for global trade. The ship, with 25 Indian crew members on board, lost control of steering in high winds and has resisted attempts to refloat. Shoei Kisen apologized for the incident, stating that getting the ship moving is "extremely difficult." Salvage efforts are ongoing, with the ship described as a "beached whale." Industry sources estimate potential claims totaling millions of dollars, regardless of a quick refloating.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended Thursday slightly lower, extending a recent losing streak, as tech firms tracked a sell-off in US peers and traders fretted over the suspension of the city's BioNTech vaccine programme. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.07% to 27,899.61, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.10% to 3,363.59.

site_title: US lawmakers, tech CEOs face off over disinformation
summary: US lawmakers and tech CEOs, including Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Twitter's Jack Dorsey, and Google's Sundar Pichai, faced off over disinformation and its impact on public health and safety during a remote House of Representatives hearing. The CEOs claimed they are working to combat misinformation, but lawmakers expressed concerns about the platforms' ability to stop the spread of false information, including about the Covid-19 vaccine and the January 6 US Capitol attack. The CEOs proposed systems to weed out illegal content and earn trust, but prospects for immediate regulatory action remained unclear.

site_title: Genting Singapore chairman's high pay for 2020 is conditional
summary: Genting Singapore chairman Lim Kok Thay's 2020 remuneration was reported at S$21.25-21.5 million, but a significant portion of this was due to an accounting accrual for a potential Japan Integrated Resort project. Excluding the accrual, Lim's remuneration was less than S$5 million, a 50% reduction from the previous year. The company's net profit declined 90% due to the pandemic, but it implemented cost control measures, including reducing executives' pay. The board's decision has been defended as a response to the pandemic's impact on the company's performance.

site_title: Lim Jit Poh to retire as chairman of SBS Transit, effective April 29
summary: SBS Transit announces the retirement of chairman Lim Jit Poh, effective April 29, following his 18-year tenure. Lim will step down after the annual general meeting (AGM) on the same day and will remain as senior adviser to ensure continuity. Other directors, including Benny Lim and John De Payva, will also retire. Lim cited the need for renewal and ensuring new directors can contribute actively in a changing industry. He will remain chairman of ComfortDelGro and Vicom for the next couple of years.

site_title: On the Singapore market: CBD space, shophouses, condominium retail shops
summary: The Singapore property market is seeing activity with various spaces up for sale, including a land parcel and commercial properties in Little India and Kampong Glam, and shophouses in Kampong Glam and retail shops at Parc Esta condominium. A land parcel in Little India is up for sale via expression of interest with a guide price of S$55 million, while shophouses in Kampong Glam are priced at S$11.55 million. Retail shops at Parc Esta condominium and strata-titled units in the CBD are also available for sale, with prices ranging from S$2 million to S$55 million.

site_title: Li Ka-shing's new deal is latest effort to prop up CK Asset share price
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing and his son Victor Li are attempting to boost the stock price of CK Asset Holdings, a family business, after a HK$4.4 billion investment failed to reverse slumping prices. The company will buy back shares worth HK$17 billion at an 8.4% premium to boost its share price, which has fallen 16% since 2019. The deal has raised concerns among investors about the Li family's increasing control and the dilution of minority shareholders' interests.

site_title: CIMB Singapore lays off staff following restructuring exercise; Orchard branch to close
summary: CIMB Singapore is laying off staff as part of a restructuring exercise aimed at optimising its functional setup and focusing on key growth areas. The bank will close its Orchard branch by end-June, with operations staff affected, and redeploy over 50 colleagues in new growth areas. Affected staff will receive a separation package, including a payout of one month's pay for every year of service, capped at 12 months. The bank has about 1,200 staff in the Singapore office prior to the cuts, and CEO Victor Lee expressed appreciation for the contributions made by the affected staff.

site_title: Over 150,000 employers to get more than S$3b under JSS payouts
summary: Over 150,000 employers in Singapore will receive more than S$3 billion in wage subsidies under the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) by March 30, benefiting over 2 million local employees. Employers in hardest-hit sectors, such as aviation and tourism, will receive 50% support, while others will get 10-30% support. The payment is part of the S$24.5 billion in JSS support disbursed since its introduction in February 2020, with the scheme to be extended by up to six months for hard-hit sectors.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps losing streak
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.14% to 28,729.88, snapping a four-day losing streak, driven by bargain-hunting. The index closed higher despite North Korea's launch of two suspected ballistic missiles. The broader Topix index also gained 1.40%. The market rebound was seen as a response to investor confidence, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro's shares surge 2.4%
summary: ComfortDelGro's shares surged 2.4% to close at S$1.69 on Thursday, following the government's announcement to increase workplace capacity limits to 75% from April 5. The company is expected to benefit from higher passenger loads, according to analysts RHB and Lim & Tan. RHB sees ComfortDelGro's Singapore public transport and taxi businesses supporting earnings rebound in 2021, while Lim & Tan expects transport operators and retail landlords to benefit from increased customer traffic.

site_title: Thai consumers rank 7th out of 8 emerging economies on weak sentiment: Report
summary: Thai consumers ranked 7th out of 8 emerging economies for weak sentiment, according to a Credit Suisse Research Institute report. Despite containing the spread of Covid-19, Thailand's economy has been negatively impacted by travel restrictions, with incomes decreasing by 45% over the past year. Consumer purchase intentions for discretionary items showed a slight increase, but overall sentiment remains low. Analysts attribute the increase to pent-up demand, but warn that it may take years for emerging countries to revert to pre-pandemic growth trends.

site_title: Bitcoin slide adds to signs of step back in retail trader mania
summary: Bitcoin slid 4.7% to a two-week low, reaching $52,250, amid a wider retreat in assets fueled by US stimulus checks. The cryptocurrency is in its longest losing streak since December, as retail traders' optimism wanes. Speculation suggests stimulus checks may be spent in the real economy rather than markets, contributing to the downtrend. Institutional adoption of Bitcoin remains a topic of debate, with some arguing it's expanding as a hedge against inflation, while others see it as a speculative vehicle.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Thursday; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,141.71, marking its strongest first quarter gains since 2012. The index is poised to see its best quarterly performance since 2012, with a 10.5% price gain and 10.9% total return. This outpaces regional benchmarks, with the STI close to tripling the gains of broader Asia-Pacific benchmarks.

site_title: AstraZeneca says vaccine 76% effective in updated US trial data
summary: AstraZeneca revised the efficacy figure for its Covid vaccine to 76% effective in preventing symptomatic Covid, down from 79%, following updated US trial data. The change comes after an independent panel of experts criticized the company for not including the updated data initially. The revised efficacy rate remains effective in preventing severe illness and hospitalization. The company's two-dose vaccine has been approved for emergency use in several countries, including the US.

site_title: Amazon's clean energy provider in Singapore Sunseap weighing IPO: sources
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore renewable energy firm, is weighing an initial public offering (IPO) that could raise up to S$600 million. The company, which counts Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft as customers, aims to list by the end of this year. Sunseap, backed by Thai energy firm Banpu, is the largest clean energy solutions provider in Singapore, with a portfolio of nearly 2 gigawatt-peak of solar projects. The IPO would boost the Singapore IPO market, which has seen only one new listing this year.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, edging up 0.18% in the Nikkei 225 index to 28,457.33, and 0.65% in the Topix index to 1,941.03, despite uncertainty following North Korea's projectile launch and US market falls.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Thursday's session on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday's session on a downward trend, with the Hang Seng Index falling 1.04% to 27,628.08, amid concerns over the suspension of the city's Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine rollout. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 0.36% and 0.57%, respectively. The losses follow a sell-off on Wall Street and reflect investor uncertainty.

site_title: Europe needs 300b euros for 5G roll-out, industrial study says
summary: Europe needs approximately 300 billion euros by 2025 to roll out super-fast 5G networks, boosting economic growth and tapping the technology's potential. The 5G rollout, crucial for smart factories and self-driving cars, has been hindered by massive investment costs and EU antitrust rules. A report by consulting firm BCG, commissioned by telecoms lobbying group ETNO, proposes measures to boost the telecoms industry, including new ownership models and loosening rules to allow cooperation and co-investment among operators.

site_title: Swire Properties sells all 20 units of Eden for S$293m
summary: Swire Properties has sold all 20 units of its completed freehold luxury residential development, Eden, in Singapore for S$293 million, working out to S$4,827 per square foot. The 22-storey development, completed in 2019, features four-bedroom units over 3,000 sq ft each. The deal was brokered through private treaty by Sandra Yiap of Huttons, with the sale price slightly lower than the estimated S$300 million.

images.alt_text: Photo of Eden at 2 Draycott Park.

site_title: Hot stock: Hong Fok's shares surge 25%
summary: Hong Fok Corporation's shares surged 24.7% to S$0.885, marking a 25% increase, following an article highlighting its deep value. The company's net asset value per share as of December 2020 was S$2.95, more than three times its current share price. Hong Fok has been actively buying back its shares, with 844.7 million issued shares, and its free float is now roughly 28% of the company, exceeding the 10% requirement set by the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Asia: Markets edge higher but inflation, virus fears cast shadow
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, with Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, and Sydney gaining, despite concerns over rising inflation, European virus fears, and US tax policy. Global equities have cooled after a year-long surge, with inflation and interest rate expectations casting a shadow. US markets sank, with the Nasdaq falling 2% due to concerns over a potential interest rate hike. The European economic recovery is also being impacted by vaccine struggles and lockdowns, leading to questions about its ability to recover quickly.

site_title: Three strata commercial units in CBD up for sale via expression of interest
summary: Three strata-titled commercial units in the GB Building in Singapore's central business district are up for sale via expression of interest. The units, totaling 31,086 sq ft, can be purchased individually or as a portfolio. The building, with a 99-year leasehold, is near major MRT stations and is part of the Central Business District Incentive Scheme. The sale is expected to attract strong interest from investors, particularly in the CBD commercial market, with Knight Frank noting an increase in office market activity and strata office opportunities.

site_title: Monk's Hill Ventures leads US$1.5m pre-Series A round in software automation startup UI-licious
summary: Software automation startup UI-licious has raised US$1.5 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by Monk's Hill Ventures. The new funds will be used to expand product development, customer base, and sales and marketing teams. UI-licious offers a proprietary smart testing engine that automates user interface testing without coding. The startup aims to support software teams in testing and monitoring end-to-test user journeys. With existing customers including Daimler, Jones Lang LaSalle, and Glints, UI-licious believes automation will become the norm in software testing.

site_title: Fintech firm #dltledgers bags US$7m Series A funding round
summary: A Singapore-based fintech firm, #dltledgers, has secured US$7 million in Series A funding, led by Regis and Savoy Capital, Vittal, Walden International, and other industry leaders. The funding will support geoexpansion and product development, including a migration to Corda, an enterprise blockchain platform. The company aims to digitize trade and supply chain finance for banks and corporates, offering enhanced security, transparency, and performance. Founder Samir Neji said the move will benefit current and future clients, while R3's David Rutter expressed excitement about the partnership.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as weaker Aussie dollar boosts export-reliant healthcare stocks
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.2% on Thursday, led by gains in healthcare stocks due to a weaker Aussie dollar. Export-reliant healthcare stocks saw their fourth consecutive session of gains, with sector heavyweights CSL and Sonic Healthcare rising 1.4% and 1.6% respectively. Utility stocks also rose, while technology stocks fell 1.1%. A weaker Australian dollar, at US$0.7594, benefited companies that earn in US dollars, with healthcare stocks reaching a one-month high.

site_title: Trial hearing postponed as Samsung heir Lee has fever after surgery: media
summary: A court hearing for Samsung Electronics vice-chairman Jay Y Lee, who is serving a two-and-a-half-year sentence for bribery and other charges, has been postponed to April 22 due to his ongoing fever after emergency surgery for a burst appendix. Lee, 52, has been jailed since January and is South Korea's most powerful businessman. The delay in his surgery has led to complications, but his life is not in danger. The hearing is related to a separate case involving suspected accounting fraud and stock price manipulation connected to a 2015 merger.

site_title: China says members of RCEP pact aim for deal to take effect from 2022
summary: China's Vice Commerce Minister Wang Shouwen announced that members of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) aim to take effect from January 1, 2022. China has led the ratification process and emphasizes the importance of early implementation. The RCEP, the world's largest free trade bloc, covers nearly a third of the global population and 30% of its GDP. The pact must be ratified by at least six Asean countries and three non-Asean countries before it can come into effect.

site_title: Fidelity applies to launch a Bitcoin ETF
summary: Fidelity has applied to launch an exchange-traded fund (ETF) to track the performance of bitcoin, following the surge of the digital currency to an all-time high of nearly $62,000. The ETF, Fidelity's Wise Origin Bitcoin Trust, would hold bitcoin and value its shares based on prices from major cryptocurrency exchanges. This move comes as investors, including institutions, seek access to bitcoin, and is part of a growing trend of Wall Street embracing digital currencies.

site_title: Top Amazon official swipes at Bernie Sanders over planned Alabama visit
summary: Amazon's top executive, Dave Clark, has criticized US Senator Bernie Sanders for planning a visit to meet Amazon workers in Alabama who are voting on unionization. Clark tweeted that Amazon offers a "progressive workplace" with $15 an hour and health care, implying that Sanders' proposals are unnecessary. Sanders responded, accusing Amazon's CEO Jeff Bezos of trying to prevent workers from organizing a union to negotiate for better wages and benefits. The union election has drawn attention from labor leaders and politicians, with President Joe Biden defending workers' rights to form unions.

site_title: Australia: Shares flat as tech stocks track Wall Street lower
summary: Australia's shares traded flat at 6,778.8, as technology stocks fell 1.4% following a decline in US indexes. Gains in energy and healthcare sectors offset losses, with energy stocks rising 0.9% and healthcare stocks gaining 0.4%. A weaker Australian dollar also boosted earnings of export-reliant companies. Meanwhile, ASX Ltd shares fell 1.6% after news of Cboe Global Markets Inc's acquisition of Chi-X Australia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, Penguin, Olam, SBS Transit, Khong Guan
summary: Sabana Reit saw two independent directors resign following unitholder opposition, while Penguin's private offer remains open until April 7. Olam priced US$100 million in five-year notes. SBS Transit's chairman, Lim Jit Poh, will retire in April. Khong Guan rose 1.3% after raising S$4 million in a seed round for its startup, SGProtein.

site_title: SLA appoints Colin Low as new chief executive
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has appointed Colin Low Hsien Yang as its new chief executive, effective April 12. Low previously served as the head of hotel investment properties for Europe, the Middle East, and Africa at CBRE Hotels in London. His appointment marks a significant change in leadership for SLA.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.73 points, or 0.11%, to 1,604.13. The market saw a significant increase in volume, with 336.57 million lots traded worth RM137.12 million. Gainers outpaced losers 261 to 121.

site_title: Drama in Congress as tech CEOs face fury over disinformation
summary: US tech CEOs, including Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Google's Sundar Pichai, and Twitter's Jack Dorsey, faced criticism from lawmakers over disinformation on their platforms during a House of Representatives hearing. The CEOs defended their efforts to combat misinformation, with Zuckerberg proposing a system to weed out illegal content and Pichai emphasizing the importance of trustworthy content. The hearing comes amid a growing backlash against Big Tech firms, with concerns over moderation, liability, and antitrust.

site_title: DBS offers complimentary Covid-19 vaccine insurance
summary: DBS has partnered Chubb Insurance to offer complimentary Covid-19 vaccine insurance to its customers. The policy, Covid-19 Vaccine Protect, covers unexpected complications from vaccinations or the virus, providing up to S$100 per day for 14 days of hospital confinement and a lump sum payout of S$1,000 for ICU confinement. It also includes a bereavement assist benefit of S$10,000 for both cases.

site_title: Asset manager passes on Deliveroo over job insecurity
summary: British asset manager Aviva Investors has decided not to invest in Deliveroo's upcoming IPO due to job insecurity concerns of the meal delivery platform's riders. Riders are classified as freelancers, denying them basic rights such as minimum wage, sick leave, and holidays. This decision is part of investors taking social responsibilities more seriously. Deliveroo aims for a market capitalization of £7.6 billion to £8.8 billion, but the classification risk could lead to reclassification as workers, similar to Uber's drivers.

site_title: Ex-McDonald's France directors questioned in fraud inquiry
summary: French police questioned three former McDonald's France directors, Denis Hennequin, Jean-Pierre Petit, and Salvatore Perri, on suspicion of helping shift profits to the US to cut French tax bills. The inquiry focuses on a 2009 agreement that increased royalty payments to the US headquarters, depriving French tax authorities of millions of euros. Prosecutors seek restitution of 300-600 million euros. McDonald's France is cooperating with the investigation, stating it's examining "complex questions of royalty values for the brand and its know-how."

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open, tracking Wall Street sell-off; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the opening on Thursday, tracking a weak Wall Street sell-off. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,125.26. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 40, with Imperium Crown's shares rising 30.8% after its shares were the most actively traded. The market's rally was despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Minority shareholders, independent directors can do more to oppose lowball buyout offers
summary: Minority shareholders and independent directors in Singapore can do more to oppose lowball buyout offers, experts say. Companies like Singapore Reinsurance and Penguin International are offering discounted prices, with some discounts exceeding 20%. Independent directors have accepted and recommended these offers, despite some activists pushing for better prices. To change this, minority shareholders must cast their votes and directors should take a more active role in advocating for minority interests.

images.alt_text: Many offerors have taken advantage of the pandemic to buy out companies on the cheap.

site_title: Google agrees to pay Italian publishers for news
summary: Google has signed licensing deals with numerous Italian media publishers to pay for news content, following a similar agreement with French publishers earlier this year. The deals, which include RCS MediaGroup, Il Sole 24 Ore, and others, will give Italian publishers access to the Google News Showcase programme, which pays outlets for enriched content. The agreements aim to address media publishers' concerns over lost advertising revenue and follow Australia's lead in forcing digital companies to pay for news content.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE sees positive spillover for semiconductor sector from Intel announcement
summary: Maybank KE maintains a positive stance on the Singapore semiconductor equipment sector following Intel's announcement of spending US$20 billion on two new plants in Arizona and plans to reintroduce foundry services. The brokerage has issued "buy" calls on AEM, UMS, and Frencken with target prices of S$5.05, S$1.57, and S$1.74 respectively. Intel's 2021 capex guidance of US$19-20 billion also supports the sector's growth prospects.

site_title: Europe: Stocks muted as new lockdown outweighs strong business activity data
summary: European stocks ended flat on Wednesday, despite a surprise return to economic growth in the euro zone, as concerns about new lockdown measures outweighed the positive news. The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell as much as 0.7% earlier in the day but recovered. A flash composite PMI reading of 52.5, above the 50 mark, showed economic growth separated from contraction. The lockdown concerns overshadowed the economic data, keeping stocks muted.

site_title: US: Stocks end down as investors shift to oil from tech
summary: US stocks ended down on Wednesday, with the Nasdaq falling 2.0% due to weakness in technology shares from companies like Apple and Facebook. Despite a rally in petroleum-linked equities, investors shifted focus from tech to oil, leading to a second consecutive session of losses. The S&P 500 also fell, despite reaching fresh records earlier in the week. The rotation in investor focus is attributed to uncertainty over the US-China trade relationship and the ongoing impact of the pandemic.

site_title: SPAC trading pops deflate as 'exuberance and greed' depart
summary: US stocks show signs of waning enthusiasm for new special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) as first-day trading pops have faded. All but one of 15 SPACs that started trading this week closed below their initial public offering (IPO) price of US$10 per unit. The decline in enthusiasm comes after record-breaking 2020, with 294 SPACs raising US$95.7 billion this year. Investors attribute the decline to "exuberance and greed" departing the market, with some SPACs experiencing significant share price falls after announcing merger targets.

site_title: Oil gains more than US$3/barrel after Suez Canal ship grounding
summary: Oil prices surged 6% on Wednesday after a ship ran aground in the Suez Canal, boosting crude benchmarks. US crude rose to $61.18 a barrel, and Brent crude to $64.41 a barrel. The gains followed a decline in US inventory figures, indicating a rebound in refining activity. The incident raised concerns about potential crude shipments being tied up, contributing to the price increase.

site_title: US to blacklist Myanmar military companies after deadly crackdown: sources
summary: The US is planning to blacklist two Myanmar conglomerates, Myanmar Economic Corporation (MEC) and Myanmar Economic Holdings Ltd (MEHL), over the military's deadly crackdown after a February coup. The move could freeze assets and come as early as Thursday. The sanctions follow a US executive order issued by President Joe Biden on February 11, which froze $1 billion in reserves held by Myanmar's central bank. The military controls a vast portion of the economy, and activists have called for sanctions to starve the military of revenue, targeting oil and gas projects.

images.alt_text: The United States is planning to impose sanctions on two conglomerates controlled by Myanmar's military over the generals' Feb1 coup and a deadly crackdown, two sources familiar with the matter said on Wednesday.

site_title: Robinhood, at the heart of retail trading frenzy, files for IPO
summary: Robinhood, the online brokerage firm at the center of the 2021 retail trading frenzy, has confidentially submitted plans to regulators for a US initial public offering (IPO). The move comes as the US capital markets experience a historic boom, with over $100 billion raised in the first three months of the year. Robinhood had considered a direct listing but has opted for an IPO. The company, founded in 2013 by Vlad Tenev and Baiju Bhatt, has not yet determined the number of shares to be offered and the price range.

site_title: Khong Guan investment in SGProtein is part of S$4m seed round for foodtech startup
summary: Singapore-based foodtech startup SGProtein has raised S$4 million in a seed round led by biscuit maker Khong Guan, with Khong Guan investing S$1.5 million in a 30% stake. The funding will be used to build a high-moisture extruder and set up a fully-automated production facility. SGProtein aims to become a large-scale manufacturer of plant-based food products, leveraging Khong Guan's expertise in food manufacturing and distribution. The company plans to manufacture products for clients and collaborate on research and development.

site_title: US regulator opens inquiry into Wall Street's blank cheque IPO frenzy: sources
