Despite this, Saudi Aramco's CEO remains optimistic about longer-term prospects, citing expected demand growth by the end of 2021.

site_title: Expert networks: the matchmakers behind mega-investment deals
summary: Singapore-based expert network Sealed connects institutional investors with industry insiders, providing valuable insights for due diligence. The platform, founded in 2019, has over 20,000 corporate profiles and charges clients US$10,000 for 10 hours of expert time. Sealed aims to carve a niche in South-east Asia, where global firms have yet to gain significant ground, by leveraging local connections and expertise. The startup plans to raise US$2-3 million this year to expand its team and platform.

site_title: NFTs: Another big step towards digitising our lives
summary: Non-fungible tokens (NFTs) are digital files stored on a blockchain, offering unique digital assets and authentication, allowing for the digitization of valuable items such as art, sports clips, and even real-world assets. Recent sales, including a $70 million Christie's auction, have brought NFTs into the mainstream, sparking debate about their utility and potential as a gateway to cryptocurrency transactions. NFTs could enable creators to have direct relationships with fans and participate in the long-term value of their creations, and their verification and transparency make them a more attractive option for average people.

site_title: Singapore a vital partner for Pakistan
summary: Pakistan and Singapore have reaffirmed their commitment to a meaningful and mutually beneficial economic relationship. Pakistan aims to become the world's 20th largest economy by 2030, and its economic reforms agenda is on track. The country has introduced policies to boost housing, construction, and digital payments, and has established a National E-commerce Council. Singapore, a key economic partner, has invested in emerging sectors such as infrastructure development and fintech, and the two countries will continue to work together to build a stronger economic relationship.

site_title: Connecting nationals abroad to Pakistan's financial system
summary: Pakistan's Roshan Digital Account (RDA) aims to connect overseas Pakistanis to the country's financial system, overcoming operational difficulties that previously disconnected them. The initiative, launched by Prime Minister Imran Khan, allows overseas Pakistanis to open bank accounts, invest in government bonds and stocks, and access real estate, all from abroad. The RDA offers a presence-less account opening process, repatriation of funds, and attractive investment products, such as Naya Pakistan Certificates. Since its launch, over 102,000 RDAs have been opened, with $700 million deposited, and the momentum is rising.

site_title: BP CEO Looney receives £1.74m in 2020 after bonuses binned
summary: BP CEO Bernard Looney received £1.735 million in 2020, with £1.18 million in salary and £351,000 in shares. His remuneration was reduced due to scrapped bonuses during the pandemic. In contrast, Royal Dutch Shell CEO Ben van Beurden's pay dropped by 42% to $7 million. Looney's total remuneration could have been up to £11 million, but the company's response to the pandemic and its plan to grow the renewables business led to significant losses, including a $5.7 billion loss and a 40% reduction in oil output by 2030.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AusGroup's subsidiary AGC Industries secured a 10-year maintenance master contract with Chevron Australia, valued at over A$1 billion. Sunpower Group secured a 180 million yuan manufacturing and services contract for a polycrystalline silicon industry project. Wilmar International stated it is evaluating opportunities to enhance shareholder value, including a proposed listing of its Indian joint venture. The news comes as Singapore stocks continue their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Envy director charged with fraud; at least S$1b invested in his 2 firms
summary: A Singaporean director, Ng Yu Zhi, 33, has been charged with fraud and cheating, allegedly swindling at least S$1 billion from investors in his two firms, Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading. The firms were operated for fraudulent purposes, with Ng promising investors returns of 15% on investments in nickel trading. Ng faces up to 10 years in jail and S$3 million bail, with his assets being seized and investigated. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also conducting a supervisory review of Envy Asset Management.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as bond yields pull back
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index jumping 1.2% to 13,377.51, driven by a retreat in US Treasury yields. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also gained 0.3% and 0.7%, respectively. Tech giants such as Facebook and Tesla advanced, while fears over rising yields and inflation were tempered. However, disappointing housing data and a weaker-than-expected sales of existing homes in the US weighed on the market. Analysts warned that the shift in yields may be fleeting.

images.alt_text: The tech-rich Nasdaq jumped on Monday, leading major equity indices upward, as a retreat in US Treasury yields offset disappointing housing data.

site_title: Trump to launch own social media platform: ex-aide
summary: Donald Trump plans to launch his own social media platform in about two to three months, according to a former adviser. The platform will be separate from Twitter and other outlets where Trump was banned after his account was permanently suspended due to his role in the January 6 US Capitol storming. Trump has been working on the platform at his Mar-a-Lago resort home in Florida, with the goal of attracting millions of users. The new platform is expected to "completely redefine the game" of social media, with Trump's former adviser predicting it will be a major success.

site_title: Raya and the Last Dragon tops US box office as more theatres reopen
summary: Disney's animated film "Raya and the Last Dragon" topped the US box office in its third weekend, earning $5.2 million from 2,261 theaters, a 5% decline from the previous week. The film's success can be attributed to the reopening of Los Angeles movie theaters, with most exhibitors opening their doors on March 12. Despite capacity limits, Los Angeles accounted for nearly 9% of all movie tickets sold over the weekend, demonstrating the appeal of family films in the US.

site_title: Global hedge fund investors with US$812b prefer Asia
summary: Global hedge funds with $812 billion in assets are shifting their investments from overvalued US assets to tap into the early pandemic recovery in China and Asia. This trend is expected to continue, with hedge fund companies predicting a surge of new money from North America and Europe. The GameStop investing craze may also contribute to this shift, as investors seek to avoid losses from short-selling squeezes. Asian markets, particularly China, are expected to benefit from this influx of investment, despite China's GDP growth set to slow.

site_title: Biden determined to raise taxes on the rich
summary: US President Joe Biden's economic team is pushing to raise taxes on the rich, fueled by data showing the wealthy did well financially during the pandemic. The administration is considering a tax-the-wealthy strategy, including boosting income and capital-gains tax rates, levies on companies, and expanding the estate tax. The plan aims to fund priorities such as infrastructure and climate change, with some options including eliminating loopholes and taxing capital gains at higher income-tax rates. Biden has stated that those earning over $400,000 will face a tax increase.

site_title: Costs of decarbonising UK homes higher than estimated
summary: The UK government has significantly underestimated the cost of decarbonizing heating in British homes, with the estimated cost rising to £18,000 per household, five times the current government estimate. Improving energy efficiency is crucial before replacing gas boilers with low-carbon technology like heat pumps. The Environmental Audit Committee warns that the government's indecision on how to spread the cost may delay a strategy to curb carbon emissions, risking the UK's net-zero target by 2050, which could be jeopardized if homes, accounting for 20% of greenhouse gas emissions, are not tackled.

site_title: Credit Suisse CEO hints at asset management spin-off after Greensill scandal
summary: Credit Suisse CEO Thomas Gottstein hinted at separating the asset management unit from the bank following the Greensill Capital collapse. This move is part of efforts to limit reputational damage. Gottstein stated that making asset management an independent entity is "potentially part of the plan." The bank has already replaced the head of the asset management unit and removed it from direct oversight of wealth management. This could be a strategic move to mitigate potential losses and maintain the bank's reputation.

site_title: Seven strata retail units in Orchard Rd up for sale
summary: A portfolio of seven strata retail units in Orchard Road, Singapore, is up for sale via public tender with a guide price of S$18.8 million. The units, ranging from 205 sq ft to 710 sq ft, are fully tenanted and offer competitive rental yields of 3-4%. The properties, which include units in Far East Plaza, Lucky Plaza, Midpoint Orchard, and Orchard Plaza, are eligible for foreign purchase and have no additional buyer's or seller's stamp duty. The public tender closes on May 5.

site_title: GIC-backed Korea travel app eyes dual IPO listing at US$4b-plus valuation
summary: Yanolja, South Korea's largest travel app, is in talks to go public through a dual listing in Seoul and overseas, aiming for a valuation of over US$4 billion. The company, backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC and Booking Holdings, is exploring options after e-commerce champion Coupang's successful US IPO. This move follows recent high-profile startup exits and hopes to avoid the "Korean discount" for foreign investors. Yanolja's sales are expected to grow despite the coronavirus outbreak's effects on the travel industry.

site_title: Local golf on the upswing buoyed by positive moves
summary: Singapore's local golf scene is experiencing a resurgence, thanks to the launch of the Singapore Pro Series, an eight-leg tournament featuring 18 local professionals and six amateurs. The series, backed by influential businessmen and the Singapore Golf Association, aims to provide a platform for golfers to prepare for Tour events and major Games. The event's prize money and sponsorship will help sustain the development of the game, which was heavily impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The series is seen as a positive move for the local golf fraternity, offering a bright backdrop for the sport's future.

site_title: Google's Singapore-based VP of payments to leave in April
summary: Google's Singapore-based VP of payments, Caesar Sengupta, is leaving the company in April after 15 years. Sengupta, who led Google's efforts in payments and building products for next-generation Internet users, will start a new venture. During his time at Google, he played a key role in initiatives such as ChromeOS, Next Billion Users, and Google Pay, which have contributed to over 3 billion people gaining internet access worldwide. Sengupta's departure marks the end of an era for Google's payments efforts.

site_title: Maintaining pole position along different paths
summary: Singapore and Switzerland top the Elite Quality Index, with Singapore's elites having the greatest value creation, while those in Switzerland have a more distributed approach, giving citizens a fair share of the value created. Singapore's powerful elites make decisions centrally, but the regulatory environment protects investor rights, allowing for economic value creation. Switzerland's decentralized decision-making allows for freedom and innovation, creating value in the interest of all. Both countries can serve as examples for positive change through transparency and facts, with the Elite Quality Index providing a basis for understanding where and how elites abuse their power.

site_title: Rapidly growing fintech a bright spot
summary: Pakistan's fintech sector is rapidly growing, driven by a new generation of young talented people and official support. Key players, such as JazzCash and Easypaisa, are expanding their services, while banks are focusing on building online presence. The sector is also seeing a surge in mobile wallets, with seven fintech companies in the process of obtaining the EMI license. Regulatory changes, including a landmark shift to promote fintech as a growth sector, have also contributed to the growth. Foreign interest is also increasing, with overseas Pakistanis playing a significant role in venture capital investments.

site_title: Japan carmakers scramble to assess impact of Renesas auto chip-plant fire
summary: Japan's top carmakers, including Toyota, Honda, and Nissan, are assessing the production impact of a fire at Renesas Electronics' automotive chip plant in north-east Japan. The fire, caused by an electrical fault, has halted production of 30% of Renesas' automotive chips, exacerbating a global semiconductor shortage. The affected production is expected to take at least a month to restart, potentially affecting carmakers' production and shares. The shortage has already forced Nissan and Honda to scale back production plans, and Toyota has fared better due to having sufficient chip stocks.

site_title: Digital accounts for Pakistani diaspora
summary: The State Bank of Pakistan has introduced the Roshan Digital Account (RDA) scheme, a digital account for non-resident Pakistanis (NRPs) living abroad. The scheme allows NRPs to open a bank account from their homes, operate it digitally, and have full control over their funds. Key features include attractive investment opportunities, digital access to Pakistan's stock market, and the ability to make investment transactions in real estate. The scheme has already seen over 102,000 accounts opened in the first six months and is expected to benefit Pakistan by promoting investment by overseas Pakistanis into the country.

site_title: Deliveroo kicks off £1.77 billion IPO, UK's largest in 2021
summary: Deliveroo Holdings, a UK food-delivery startup, launched a £1.77 billion initial public offering (IPO), the largest in the UK since 2021. The company is selling shares at £3.90 to £4.60 apiece, valuing it at £7.6 billion to £8.8 billion. Deliveroo is taking investor orders for the share sale, marking a significant milestone for the company.

site_title: Central London residential rents slump due to lockdown, WFH
summary: Central London residential rents have dropped by 20.4% to £43 per square foot due to the lockdown and shift to working from home. In contrast, rentals in towns and villages outside London have risen, with outer London experiencing a 5.3% increase and south-east England a 10.6% rise. Experts predict a sharp rental recovery in the second half of the year, with average London rents projected to rise by 1.5% in 2021 and 5.5% in 2022.

site_title: Man detonates explosives near Chinese city, killing four
summary: A 59-year-old Chinese man, identified as Hu, detonated explosives in the Mingjing area of Guangzhou city, killing himself and four others. Five more people were injured in the blast at a building housing a community committee. The incident was described as an act of sabotage by official news agency Xinhua. The case is under further investigation.

site_title: CapitaLand's morphing into CLIM could provide a template for others
summary: CapitaLand's restructuring into CLIM, a real estate investment manager, may provide a template for other property developers. Minority shareholders will benefit from the deal, with an implied consideration of S$4.102 per share, a 24% premium to the previous closing price. The success of CLIM hinges on the financial performance of the new entity, which may trade at a premium to net asset value, unlike some other listed property groups. CLIM's development business will be privatized, and it can leverage this to acquire assets and operate them, potentially improving valuation metrics.

site_title: US home sales fell more than expected in February
summary: US home sales declined 6.6% in February to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.22 million units, exceeding economists' expectations of a 3.0% drop. Cold weather and rising mortgage rates, along with tight supply, may limit a rebound. Home resales increased 9.1% year-over-year, with declines in the Northeast, South, and Midwest, but gains in the West.

site_title: Resetting US ties with China: Multilateralism vs protectionism
summary: The US and China failed to make progress in diplomatic talks after a testy two-day meeting in Anchorage, Alaska, due to entrenched tensions over trade, security, and human rights. Despite President Biden's efforts to forge multilateral partnerships to counter China's aggressive behavior, the US faces obstacles in forming alliances to contain Beijing. The Biden administration's approach, which emphasizes cooperation and competition, may not be effective in managing friction over trade and other economic issues, and the Sino-American rivalry is expected to dominate international relations in the coming years.

site_title: Shophouses in Bugis and Maxwell put on the market
summary: Three shophouses in Singapore's Bugis district, including one near the Maxwell MRT station, have been put up for sale by tender. The properties, which include a 999-year tenure shophouse with a potential floor area of 4,629 sq ft, are priced between S$3,750 and S$6.33 million. The sale is seen as a "highly attractive investment opportunity" in a prime location, with the potential for buyers to increase the floor area and the site's value due to the upcoming redevelopment of the area.

site_title: Most Asian currencies slip on limited impact from Turkish lira plunge
summary: Turkey's President Erdogan sacked the country's hawkish central bank governor, causing the Turkish lira to plummet 15% and sapping risk appetite. However, the impact on emerging Asian currencies was limited, with most currencies slipping 0.1-0.2% against the US dollar. Analysts attribute the limited contagion effect to Asia-specific factors, and expect Asian central banks to maintain rates unchanged in the coming weeks. Safe-haven currencies like the Japanese yen and US dollar strengthened, signaling a "risk-off" environment.

site_title: EU, US impose sanctions on Myanmar coup leaders and entities
summary: The European Union and the US have imposed sanctions on individuals linked to the February 1 coup in Myanmar, with 11 people targeted including the country's commander-in-chief, Min Aung Hlaing, and acting president Myint Swe. The EU has also announced plans to bar EU investors and banks from doing business with parts of the military's conglomerates, and the US has targeted a police force leader and military officer. The sanctions follow weeks of violence that have killed at least 250 people, with protests continuing in defiance of the military regime.

site_title: New US trade czar does not mean policy U-turn
summary: US President Joe Biden's trade policy agenda, led by new trade czar Katherine Tai, is not a significant departure from that of his predecessor Donald Trump. Both presidents aim to protect domestic industries from foreign competition, with a focus on China as the main economic competitor. However, Biden's approach is more diplomatic and multilateral, seeking cooperation with allies to modernize international trade rules. The Biden administration's "Buy American" orders and trade policies reflect a shift towards protectionism, but Tai's appointment and her emphasis on working with allies signal a more nuanced approach.

site_title: NFT digital artwork by humanoid robot Sophia up for auction
summary: A digital artwork by humanoid robot Sophia, created in collaboration with Italian artist Andrea Bonaceto, is up for auction. The NFT, titled "Sophia Instantiation," is a 12-second video showcasing the evolution of Bonaceto's portrait into Sophia's digital painting. Sophia's algorithms output unique patterns, demonstrating her ability to be creative. The artwork will be accompanied by a physical piece painted by Sophia on a printout of her self-portrait, and the successful bidder will be incorporated into the artwork through a final brushstroke.

site_title: Lazard-backed SPACs aim to raise US$500m in IPOs
summary: Two special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) backed by Lazard are planning to raise up to US$500 million in initial public offerings. Lazard Healthcare Acquisition Corp I and Lazard Fintech Acquisition Corp I aim to merge with healthcare and fintech companies, respectively. The IPOs, led by Goldman Sachs, will list on Nasdaq under the symbols "LHCAU" and "LFTAU". This follows another Lazard-backed SPAC's US$500 million IPO in January, raising concerns about a potential bubble in the SPAC market.

site_title: Meeting banking needs of overseas Pakistanis
summary: Pakistan's Federal Minister of Finance and Revenue, Abdul Hafeez Shaikh, announced the launch of Roshan Digital Accounts (RDAs), a digital banking platform for overseas Pakistanis to meet their banking and financial needs. RDAs allow Pakistanis abroad to invest in Pakistan's capital, money, and debt markets securely, and come with attractive interest rates. The government has also amended the tax regime, making investments through RDAs hassle-free. With encouraging response from overseas Pakistanis, the government aims to promote economic growth and stability, driven by Prime Minister Imran Khan's vision.

site_title: Will better US-India economic ties follow security surge?
summary: US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin concluded a visit to India, highlighting the growth of their security partnership, with defense deals worth an estimated $20 billion since 2008. The visit also marked a push for greater economic ties, with President Joe Biden expressing interest in doubling down on bilateral trade. The US and India are seeking to strengthen their relationship, driven by shared concerns about China, and are exploring joint military exercises and information sharing. A comprehensive trade deal is also on the agenda, with the US seeking to capitalize on India's large consumer market.

site_title: 73-year-old Briton among 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: A 73-year-old British man, one of 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, arrived from Indonesia on a short-term visit pass. All cases are imported, with the last case of local transmission recorded 10 days ago. The 12 cases, including the British man, tested positive after being placed on stay-home notices, with 11 being asymptomatic. This brings Singapore's total Covid-19 cases to 60,208, with 60,036 recovered and 21 patients in hospital.

site_title: Allowing unitholders more say over Reit managers would raise accountability
summary: Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (Reits) may need to review their rules to allow unitholders more say in the appointment of Reit directors and managers, as seen in the recent declaration by activist fund managers Quarz Capital and Black Crane. Currently, unitholders can only endorse the appointments at annual general meetings, but not directly vote for or against them. This can lead to misalignment of interests between sponsors, majority shareholders, and minority unitholders. Allowing unitholders to endorse or vote for managers could improve corporate governance and align interests, but sponsors may resist such changes.

site_title: US imposes sanctions on Myanmar individuals, entities
summary: The US imposed sanctions on individuals and entities linked to Myanmar's military and its repression of pro-democracy protesters, following the European Union's similar action. The US Treasury Department stated that the Burmese security forces' lethal violence against peaceful protesters must end. The move comes amid ongoing human rights concerns in Myanmar.

site_title: Hedge funds should persevere and not be daunted by imperfections in ESG standards
summary: Hedge funds should continue investing in line with environmental, social, and governance (ESG) principles, despite imperfections in ESG standards. The growth of ESG investment strategies and sustainable finance markets signals a structural shift in finance, and macro hedge fund managers must be part of this transition. Experts recognize the benefits of financing responsible and sustainable investments while generating returns. Companies are encouraged to adapt to this shift, and ESG investment is seen as a crucial aspect of responsible capital provision.

site_title: Envy companies' director charged with cheating and fraud, at least S$1b involved
summary: A director of Envy Asset Management and Envy Global Trading has been charged with cheating and fraud in a Singaporean financial scandal involving at least S$1 billion invested in nickel trading. Ng Yu Zhi faces two charges of cheating and two of being a party to fraudulent operations. He was offered bail and will be mentioned in court on May 17. The case is one of the largest financial fraud cases in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi, 33, faces two charges of cheating an individual and a fund management company of at least S$48 million and two charges of being a party to his two companies that were allegedly operated for fraudulent purposes.

site_title: China hits back at EU with sanctions on 10 people, four entities over Xinjiang
summary: China has sanctioned 10 EU individuals and four entities in response to Brussels' sanctions against Chinese officials over alleged human rights abuses in Xinjiang. The individuals include European Parliament members and scholars, while the entities targeted are EU institutions and research centers. China's foreign ministry said the sanctions "severely harm China's sovereignty and interests" and accused the EU of spreading lies and disinformation. The move escalates tensions between the two regions.

site_title: STE makes competing bid for Cubic Corp
summary: ST Engineering submitted a competing bid for Cubic Corp, offering US$76 per share in cash, a 8.6% premium over the agreed deal with private equity firms. Cubic's board deemed STE's proposal "superior" and will engage in discussions. STE plans to acquire Cubic's transportation systems business, which fits its strategy for growth in the smart city domain. The deal is subject to shareholder approval and regulatory approvals, with major shareholder Temasek planning to vote in favor.

site_title: Nestle rolls out touchless coffee machines
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, is rolling out touchless coffee machines globally to cater to post-pandemic coffee growth, with a focus on offices and at-home demand. The company plans to introduce new flavors, including cold and flavored coffee, in the US market, which has become a key target for growth. With an estimated 7 cups of coffee consumed per person per year in China, Nestle sees significant growth prospects in the country and other priority markets like India and Africa.

summary: Aztech Global, the technology unit of Aztech Group, reported an 18.1% jump in net profit to S$55.7 million and a 12.9% increase in revenue to S$484.3 million for FY20. The company's fourth-quarter revenue surged due to higher production volume and shipment of IoT and data communication products. This lifted revenue from IoT and data communication products to S$428.1 million, driving an 18.7% increase in Ebitda and 15.8% Ebitda margin. The board recommended a final dividend of 2 cents a share.

site_title: Federal Reserve will pursue digital currency only with congressional support
summary: The US Federal Reserve, under Chairman Jerome Powell, will not pursue a central bank digital currency without Congressional approval. Powell emphasized the need for legislative support in a Bank for International Settlements conference.

site_title: Singapore-Pakistan collaboration
summary: Pakistan and Singapore are exploring collaboration opportunities in the fintech sector, with Singapore offering knowledge exchange programs and investment opportunities. The annual Singapore Fintech Festival has benefited Pakistani companies, with the Pakistan FinTech Association hosting the festival in Karachi in 2020 and signing a MoU with the Singapore Fintech Association. This collaboration has led to increased avenues for experience sharing and collaboration, with the potential for more significant investments in the Pakistani market.

site_title: Singapore and UAE reaffirm bilateral relations, seek greater tech collaboration
summary: Singapore and the UAE have reaffirmed their strong bilateral economic ties, focusing on technology, innovation, artificial intelligence, space technologies, and public sector partnerships. The two countries co-chaired the 13th Abu Dhabi-Singapore Joint Forum, which aims to leverage global technology trends and areas of mutual interest. Bilateral trade between Singapore and the UAE reached S$12.8 billion last year, with Enterprise Singapore partnering the Abu Dhabi Investment Office to encourage joint innovation challenges and co-innovation projects.

site_title: CPEC a game changer for economy
summary: China's $62 billion China Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) project aims to upgrade Pakistan's infrastructure, strengthen its economy, and connect over 60 countries through China's Belt and Road Initiative. The project, initiated in 2013, involves building modern transportation networks, energy projects, and special economic zones, with a focus on highways and railways spanning the country's 220 million population. The project is seen as a game changer for Pakistan's economy, with the goal of rapidly upgrading infrastructure to support economic growth.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit achieves 0.51% pricing for 3.3 billion yen debt
summary: Parkway Life Reit successfully priced 3.3 billion yen (S$41.3 million) 0.51% six-year senior unsecured fixed rate notes due 2027 to term out maturing debts. The proceeds will be used to repurchase a 3.3 billion yen, 0.58% senior unsecured note due 2022 at par without penalty. This move validates Parkway Life Reit's growth strategy in Japan and mitigates refinancing risk amidst uncertain economic conditions.

site_title: Two Sen Yue subsidiaries shut down premises due to multiple Covid-19 cases
summary: Sen Yue Holdings, a metals trader listed on the CATALIST, has announced that two subsidiaries in Johor Bahru, Malaysia, CED System and PNE Micron Engineering, have been ordered to shut down due to multiple Covid-19 cases detected on their premises. The shutdowns, lasting 13 and 11 days, will be lifted on March 30, 2021. All employees of both entities have been ordered to quarantine at home. The group plans to cooperate with authorities and inform customers about the situation.

site_title: ST Engineering makes competing bid for Cubic Corp at US$76 per share
summary: ST Engineering has made a competing bid for Cubic Corp at US$76 per share in cash, a premium of 8.6% over the previously agreed US$70-per-share deal with Veritas Capital and Evergreen Coast Capital Corporation. ST Engineering claims its offer is superior to the Veritas/Evergreen transaction, which was announced on February 8, 2021.

summary: AusGroup's subsidiary AGC Industries has secured a 10-year maintenance master contract with Chevron Australia, valued at over A$1 billion. Both companies' contracts are expected to have a positive impact on their financial performance.

site_title: Julius Baer to claw back bonuses over Latin America scandal
summary: Julius Baer Group has announced plans to claw back bonuses for bankers involved in a Latin America money laundering scandal, following a regulatory probe by Finma. The move, announced in the bank's annual report, comes after former CEO Boris Collardi was reprimanded and Bernhard Hodler, his successor, also faced criticism. The bank's current CEO, Philipp Rickenbacher, has implemented reforms to address the issue, including cutting management layers and revamping pay structures. The bank did not specify which managers were affected or the amount of clawbacks.

site_title: Striving for success in troubled times, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise and disappointment over US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on the country. The tariffs, which were imposed without prior warning, target various Vietnamese goods including electronics, footwear, and textiles. Vietnam is seeking a reduction in the tariff rate, citing the potential economic impact on the country. The move is seen as a challenge to Vietnam's efforts to diversify its economy and improve trade relations with the US. Vietnam's government has called for a meeting with US officials to discuss the issue and explore options for reducing the tariffs.

summary: Richport Technology is expanding its surface treatment capabilities, refining its offerings to cater to diverse customer needs. site_title: Midtown Modern condo sells 90% of one-, two-bedroom units at launch
summary: GuocoLand's Midtown Modern condominium in Bugis, Singapore, sold 90% of its one- and two-bedroom units at its launch, with 340 out of 558 units sold. The average selling price was close to S$2,800 per square foot, with prices ranging from S$2,401 to S$3,501 per square foot. The project, which includes two 30-storey towers and a retail podium, is expected to be completed in 2024 and will appeal to larger families and affluent individuals.

site_title: Asia-Pacific banks to face portfolio valuation losses as yields rise
summary: Asia-Pacific banks may face near-term losses due to rising sovereign yields, particularly in Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Malaysia. Fitch Ratings found that correlations between banks' valuations of available-for-sale securities and domestic yields are strong in these markets, with losses potentially ranging from 25-40 basis points. However, the impact is expected to be minor, with regulatory capital declines estimated to be less than 20 basis points for Indian banks and 25-40 basis points for Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 9.46 points lower on Monday at 1,616.73. The index saw a volume of 7.566 billion lots worth RM3.992 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 744 to 392.

site_title: US: Tech shares bounce as investors eye end of Q1
summary: US stocks rose early Monday, with tech shares leading the way, as investors eyed the start of the second quarter. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.8% to 13,326.43, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 advanced 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively. Investors are looking ahead to the quarter end, when they typically rebalance their portfolios, contributing to the tech-heavy Nasdaq's underperformance so far in 2021.

site_title: Taiwan's export orders keep soaring on robust tech demand
summary: Taiwan's export orders rose 48.5% to US$42.6 billion in February, driven by strong demand for tech products. This marks the fourth straight month of double-digit growth, surpassing economists' median estimate of 45.4%. The tech sector, including major Apple suppliers, saw a 44.5% increase in combined revenue. Taiwan's exporters are also benefiting from a weakening currency, which could further boost export orders. The Ministry of Economic Affairs predicts growth of 35.4-39.1% in orders this month, potentially setting a new first-quarter record.

site_title: AstraZeneca hails US trials but poll shows European worries
summary: AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine showed 100% effectiveness in preventing severe disease in US trials. However, a poll indicates declining trust in the vaccine in many European countries due to blood clot concerns. The vaccine's lower cost and easier storage make it an attractive option, but its rollout has been halted in some European nations. The vaccine is crucial in overcoming the pandemic, which has claimed over 2.7 million lives.

images.alt_text: Pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca said Monday that US trials showed its Covid-19 vaccine was 100 per cent effective in preventing severe disease, even as a poll showed trust in the jab had plunged in many European countries.

site_title: EU sanctions Myanmar junta chief over coup
summary: The European Union has placed Myanmar junta chief Min Aung Hlaing on an assets freeze and visa ban blacklist due to his involvement in the February 1 coup and the subsequent crackdown on demonstrators. The EU stated that Min Aung Hlaing is directly responsible for undermining democracy and the rule of law in Myanmar, citing his role in the brutal crackdown. This move aims to hold the junta leader accountable for his actions.

images.alt_text: The EU placed Myanmar junta chief Min Aung Hlaing on an assets freeze and visa ban blacklist Monday over a coup and crackdown on demonstrators, the bloc's official journal said.

site_title: Singapore shares begin week in the red, STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares began the week on a softer note, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.2% to 3,128.08. The decline was attributed to Covid vaccine availability, renewed pandemic-induced lockdowns, and tense US-China trade talks. The bearish sentiments were evident in regional markets, with the Nikkei 225 and Hang Seng Index also falling. Despite this, local demand appears to be a significant factor, and the recovery in tourism is expected to be crucial for regional economies.

site_title: Khong Guan buys 30% stake in plant-based meat alternatives maker
summary: Khong Guan, a Singaporean biscuit manufacturer, has invested S$1.5 million in SGProtein, a plant-based meat alternatives maker, purchasing a 30% stake. The deal is expected to boost Khong Guan's value and is seen as a strategic move into the growing plant-based food market. The founders of SGProtein will oversee its operations, and the investment will not significantly impact Khong Guan's financials. The move is part of Khong Guan's broader strategy to increase shareholders' value through growth and leveraging expertise in the food industry.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks finished lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.36% to 28,885.34. This follows concerns over expected inflation from the global economic recovery. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 1.14% and the Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.27%.

site_title: Companies have more work ahead in climate push: study
summary: A study analyzing 159 companies, including major corporations such as Berkshire Hathaway and Coca-Cola, found that none achieved a "high-level" performance in climate action. The Climate Action 100+ Net-Zero Company Benchmark evaluated companies' alignment with a net-zero emissions future and Paris Agreement goals, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions, improving governance, and strengthening climate-related financial disclosures. The study's results highlight the need for companies to further prioritize climate action.

site_title: Teo Eng Cheong named next CEO in charge of Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City
summary: Keppel Corporation has named Teo Eng Cheong as the new CEO of the Sino-Singapore Tianjin Eco-City (SSTEC) Investment and Development Co, effective June 1, 2021. Teo, who joined Keppel this year, replaces outgoing CEO Tay Lim Heng. Teo has extensive experience in the Singapore government and private sector, including a stint as CEO of International Enterprise Singapore and the Competition Commission of Singapore. Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua praised Teo's experience and knowledge of the Chinese market, expecting him to lead the Eco-City's development effectively.

site_title: Tapping into ecosystem key to Omni-Plus System's business transformation, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Richport Technology is expanding its surface treatment offerings. The company, a leading manufacturer of advanced surface treatment solutions, continues to enhance its portfolio with new products and technologies. Richport Technology's surface treatment solutions are used in various industries, including aerospace, automotive, and consumer goods. The company's latest developments aim to improve surface quality, reduce production costs, and increase efficiency. With its continued innovation, Richport Technology positions itself as a key player in the surface treatment market, providing high-quality solutions to meet the evolving needs of its customers.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop at open
summary: European stock markets dropped at the start of trading on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index shedding 0.8% to 6,655.52 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 index losing 0.5% to 14,546.50 points. The decline was attributed to concerns over high inflation and possible interest rate hikes.

site_title: Wilmar says 'no assurance' that media reports of Adani Wilmar listing will happen
summary: Wilmar International stated there's no assurance its 50% owned Indian joint venture Adani Wilmar will list, despite recent media reports. The company regularly evaluates opportunities to enhance shareholder value, but no definitive agreement or listing has been reached. Analysts, including CGS-CIMB Research, are positive on Adani Wilmar's planned listing, expecting it to unlock value for shareholders.

site_title: GIC-backed Korea travel app eyes dual IPO listing at US$4b-plus valuation
summary: South Korea's largest travel app, Yanolja, backed by Singaporean sovereign wealth fund GIC and Booking Holdings, is in talks to go public through a dual listing in Seoul and overseas, aiming for a valuation of over US$4 billion. The company, founded by janitor Lee Su-jin in 2005, is exploring options and has not yet finalized the size and location of its IPO. This move follows Coupang's successful debut on the New York Stock Exchange and reflects growing interest among foreign investors in Korea's tech sector.

site_title: Britain's Kingfisher profit jumps 44% on booming DIY in pandemic
summary: Kingfisher, a British home improvement retailer, reported a 44% jump in full-year profit to £786 million, driven by the popularity of DIY projects during the Covid-19 pandemic. Sales rose 6.8% to £12.3 billion, with like-for-like sales up 7.1% for the year and 15.5% in the fourth quarter. The company expects low double-digit like-for-like sales growth in the first half of its 2021-22 year, but a dip in the second half due to tougher comparative numbers.

site_title: Fresh travel warning for Britons hits airline stocks
summary: UK government warns Britons not to book summer holidays abroad due to rising Covid-19 cases in Europe, potentially delaying the resumption of international travel from May 17. Shares in airlines such as British Airways and easyJet fell 6-7% on Monday. Despite half of British adults receiving at least one Covid-19 vaccine dose, growing infection levels in France, Italy, and Germany may lead to further travel restrictions. The warning is the latest in a series of cautionary statements from scientists, experts, and politicians, putting renewed financial strain on the airline and travel industries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: CapitaLand is restructuring by separating its real estate development business into private ownership, while consolidating its investment management and lodging arms into a new entity. Asia must build resilience to digital changes, according to DPM Heng. iSTOX has tokenised Astrea VI bonds, reducing investment minimums. Keppel-linked Floatel secured a $100m loan from Temasek's Clifford Capital amid restructuring. Meanwhile, seven strata retail units in Orchard are up for sale with a guide price of $18.8m. A UOB study found that SMEs that digitalised in 2020 saw stronger revenue growth and better 2021 outlooks.

site_title: Singapore talking to AstraZeneca about vaccine
summary: Singapore's health authority is in talks with AstraZeneca about its coronavirus vaccine, following the company's efforts to address concerns over blood clotting in Europe. The authority has also sought more information from Sinovac Biotech prior to using its vaccine in the country's immunization drive. Singapore rigorously evaluates all vaccines before deployment, according to the Health Sciences Authority.

site_title: Australia: Energy, healthcare stocks lift shares higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Monday, led by energy and healthcare stocks, with Crown Resorts closing 20% higher after receiving a Blackstone buyout offer. Energy stocks like Woodside Petroleum and Santos gained 2.8% and 2.4%, respectively. Healthcare stocks also rose, driven by a 2.5% jump in sector heavyweight CSL. Heavy flooding in Australia's east coast caused concerns about increased claims for insurers, leading to losses for Insurance Australia Group and QBE Insurance Group.

site_title: iSTOX issues digital tokens for Astrea VI bonds for the first time
summary: iSTOX has issued digital tokens for Astrea VI bonds, a private equity-backed series of bonds, allowing accredited investors to invest with a minimum of US$20,000, down from US$50,000 and US$200,000 previously. The tokens were fully taken up in a placement exercise, with Class A-2 bonds carrying a 3.25% annual interest rate and Class B bonds carrying a 4.35% annual interest rate. The digital token platform aims to democratize access to private markets and reduce transaction costs, with iSTOX chief commercial officer stating that digital tokens are transforming financial markets in a profound way.

site_title: China's former grid chief sees emissions peaking early in 2028
summary: China is on track to peak its carbon emissions in 2028, two years ahead of schedule, according to a think tank headed by former State Grid Corp of China chairman Liu Zhenya. The country's electricity sector emissions will peak by 2025, with the nation reaching carbon neutrality by 2055. A massive investment of 122 trillion yuan ($25 trillion) is required through 2060 to achieve this, with a focus on renewable energy, smart-grid technology, and energy efficiency improvements. This plan is expected to have a significant impact on coal, oil, and natural gas demand in China.

site_title: CapitaLand chases faster growth with restructuring, planned listing of CLIM
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate conglomerate, is restructuring its business to focus on strategic growth and create shareholder value. The company plans to split into two entities: a real estate development business under private ownership and a new investment management platform, CLIM, which will be listed on the Singapore Exchange. CLIM will manage listed real estate investment trusts, unlisted funds, and the lodging business. The new structure aims to drive growth in fee income and funds under management, as well as increase capital productivity and efficiency. The company's CEO, Lee Chee Koon, believes the restructuring will allow the group to better ride property development cycles and make more appropriate risk-return decisions.

site_title: Deals of the week: PatSnap snags unicorn status, EDB New Ventures funds Storms
summary: PatSnap, a patent analytics company, raises US$300 million in Series E funding, valuing it over US$1 billion. The company will use funds to invest in talent development and sales presence with SoftBank Japan. Storms, a gaming startup backed by Singtel, secures funding from EDB New Ventures to strengthen its management team and expand into new markets. Sunseap Group, a solar energy provider, raises undisclosed funds from Dubai's Dutco to support future projects. These deals demonstrate the growth and investment in the South-east Asian tech sector.

site_title: Google's Singapore-based VP of payments to leave company in April
summary: Google's Singapore-based VP of payments, Caesar Sengupta, has announced his resignation after 15 years with the company. Sengupta led Google's efforts in payments and Next Billion Users initiative, contributing to the growth of internet users worldwide. He will leave the company on April 30, but has expressed enthusiasm for his next entrepreneurial venture, stating he is "uncomfortably excited about the future."

site_title: Fuelling the growth of local SMEs: From going digital to going global with e-commerce
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can tap into the growing online market, driven by the increasing adoption of e-commerce. To support this, the government and Amazon have joined forces, with Amazon's Market Readiness Assistance (MRA) scheme offering grants of up to S$100,000 to eligible SMEs looking to sell on Amazon stores abroad. By digitizing and expanding globally, SMEs can reach a global audience, enjoy cross-border shipping, and develop a competitive edge. With Amazon's support, SMEs can upskill and access resources to strategize their e-commerce growth, positioning them to scale and contribute to Singapore's economic development.

images.alt_text: Bernard Tay, Country Leader, Amazon.sg Seller Services and Head of Amazon Global Selling Southeast Asia

site_title: A year on from lockdown, India reports worst daily rise in Covid-19 in months
summary: India reported its worst daily rise in COVID-19 cases in months, with 46,951 new infections and 212 deaths, on the one-year anniversary of a nationwide lockdown. The country's total cases have surpassed 11.65 million, with Maharashtra accounting for nearly two-thirds of the new infections and the majority of deaths. Authorities have reintroduced curbs to slow the spread of the virus, with hospitals in the worst-affected state running short of beds. India's low immunization rate, with over 44 million doses administered, has also raised concerns.

site_title: VinaCapital, GS Energy to invest US$3b in LNG power plants in Vietnam
summary: VinaCapital and GS Energy will jointly invest up to US$3 billion in a 3,000-megawatt LNG-to-power complex in Vietnam's Long An province, with the first phase expected to be operational by the end of 2025. The project aims to reduce Vietnam's reliance on coal for power generation, which is seen as a growing concern due to its emissions and climate impact. The investment is part of Vietnam's plan to increase the proportion of gas-fired electricity in its power mix to 24% by 2045.

site_title: China is investigating heaps of dead pigs along the Yellow River
summary: Chinese authorities are investigating dozens of dead pigs found along a section of the Yellow River in Inner Mongolia, amid concerns over food and water safety. The discovery is the latest in a series of dead pigs found in Chinese rivers, following similar incidents in 2013 and 2014. Authorities are checking the source of the pigs and disinfecting the area, while also investigating if the pigs carried any diseases.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares tumble after chip plant fire, car makers hit
summary: Japanese shares tumbled on Monday, with the Nikkei falling 2.07% to 29,174.15, its largest decline since March 4. A fire at Renesas Electronics' semiconductor plant and the Bank of Japan's decision to stop purchasing Nikkei-linked ETFs contributed to the decline. Car makers such as Honda, Nissan, and Toyota dropped 3-4% due to supply chain concerns. The broader Topix also fell 1.09% as transport equipment and insurance sectors were the biggest drags on the market.

site_title: Aramco aims to partner with China on blue hydrogen, CEO says
summary: Saudi Aramco CEO Amin Nasser plans to expand cooperation with China on low-carbon research, including blue hydrogen and ammonia production, to achieve long-term, low-carbon ambitions. The oil major is also considering investments in Chinese projects, despite spending constraints. China aims to produce blue hydrogen, a process capturing most carbon dioxide, and has plans to install 1,000 hydrogen refueling stations by 2025.

images.alt_text: Saudi Aramco plans to "expand and intensify" cooperation with China on research in areas including hydrogen and ammonia production from natural gas, according to Chief Executive Officer Amin Nasser.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 12 new COVID-19 cases, all of whom were imported and had been placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival. The total number of cases in the country is now 60,208. There were no community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The number of unlinked community cases has dropped to zero for the past week. Meanwhile, 16 patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered patients to 60,023, and 18 patients remain in hospital.

site_title: Asia must build capabilities to adapt to structural changes: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for Asia to build capabilities to adapt to structural changes brought about by the Covid-19 pandemic. He highlighted the region's promising prospects, including favorable demographics and a pervasive digital revolution, but warned that Asia's growth is not fore-ordained. Heng stressed the importance of navigating shifting geopolitical tides, advancing collective interests, and deepening regional integration and cooperation to achieve continued peace, stability, and growth.

site_title: Hot stock: CDL jumps more than 3% amid active trading
summary: Shares of City Developments Limited (CDL) jumped 3.39% to S$7.92, reaching an intraday high, amid active trading on Monday. The move comes after CapitaLand announced a scheme of arrangement to privatize its real estate development business. CDL and CapitaLand had reported dismal FY2020 results, but emphasized their potential for future growth. The counter saw 3.36 million shares traded, with no married deals recorded.

site_title: Malaysia sets up compensation fund for Covid-19 vaccinations
summary: Malaysia has established a US$2.4 million compensation fund to provide cash assistance to individuals who experience severe reactions to Covid-19 vaccinations. The fund will cover hospitalization costs for RM50,000 (S$16,318) or RM500,000 (S$157,180) for permanent disability or death. As of March 18, 20 adverse reactions have been reported, with no deaths linked to the vaccine. The government aims to vaccinate 80% of its 32 million population by December, increasing the immunization budget to RM5 billion.

site_title: Seoul: Shares close lower on worries over volatile US bond yields
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.13% on Monday, closing at 3,035.46, as concerns over volatile US bond yields and heightened Sino-US tensions outweighed domestic trade data. Despite a 12.5% year-on-year increase in exports, investors were cautious, with foreigners selling 546.3 billion won worth of shares. US bond yields edged down to 1.68%, but bond managers expressed concern over the recent pace of yield rises. The won gained 0.19% against the dollar, ending at 1,128.4 per dollar.

site_title: ByteDance unit to acquire video games studio Moonton Technology
summary: ByteDance's video games unit Nuverse has agreed to acquire Shanghai-based Moonton Technology, further expanding into the video games business. This move puts Nuverse in direct competition with China's Tencent. ByteDance sees Moonton's strategic support as key to accelerating Nuverse's global gaming offerings. The acquisition is part of ByteDance's efforts to grow its presence in the video games industry, which has been a significant inroad for the company.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS raises target price for FCT on growth in suburban malls
summary: DBS Research Group raised its target price for Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) to S$3, maintaining a "buy" call, due to growth in suburban malls and the recovery of retail sales post-Covid-19. FCT is expected to benefit from a potent mix of growth and stability in the medium term, with a projected 6% increase in distribution per unit in FY2021. However, a potential second wave of Covid-19 cases in Singapore poses a risk to consumer spending.

images.alt_text: DBS Research Group has raised its target price on Frasers Centrepoint Trust to S$3 while reiterating its "buy" call, on expectations of growth in suburban malls after Covid-19.

site_title: Deliveroo eyes £8.8b market cap in upcoming London IPO
summary: Deliveroo is set to go public in a London IPO, valuing the company at up to £8.8 billion. The Amazon-backed food delivery company has set a price range of £3.90-£4.60 per share, giving it a market value of £7.6-£8.8 billion. This is expected to be Britain's biggest share listing in over seven years, with the UK government citing it as a sign of the City of London's ability to attract major IPOs. Deliveroo's IPO is seen as a significant milestone for the UK's fintech sector.

site_title: Australia accelerates the pace of Covid-19 vaccination rollout
summary: Australia has accelerated its Covid-19 vaccination rollout, allowing over 1,000 general practitioners to administer AstraZeneca's vaccine to eligible populations aged 70 and above, and indigenous Australians over 55. The move, made possible by local manufacturing of the vaccine, aims to vaccinate all adult Australians by the end of 2021. The country's vaccination program has been slow, with just over 1% of the population vaccinated, but is now expected to receive 1 million doses per week, bolstering supplies.

site_title: China to rein in mobile apps' collection of personal data
summary: China's cyber watchdog has announced that mobile app providers must allow users to access their services even if they decline to share non-essential personal information. This move aims to regulate app providers' access to personal data and protect individuals' information. The regulation follows China's increased scrutiny of its technology sector, including anti-monopoly rules for tech firms. The Cyberspace Administration of China did not name any app providers in the statement.

site_title: Asian Development Bank secures US$300m funding for 'green recovery' projects
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has secured US$300 million in funding from the Green Climate Fund (GCF) to support green recovery projects in South-east Asia. The funds will be used for the Asean Catalytic Green Recovery Program (ACGF), which aims to finance green infrastructure projects worth over US$4 billion across the region. The projects are expected to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 119 million tonnes and create 340,000 green jobs over 30 years, addressing the financing gap for green infrastructure in the region.

site_title: Malaysia's Lee claims maiden All England Open
summary: Malaysia's Lee Zii Jia won his first All England Open title, defeating Danish second seed Viktor Axelsen 30-29, 20-22, 21-9. The 22-year-old Lee outlasted Axelsen in a marathon first set that reached 59 points, eventually winning after squandering nine game points.

site_title: Shophouses at Bugis, Maxwell put on the market
summary: Shophouses in Singapore's central business district, including 5 Tan Quee Lan Street and 56 Haji Lane-87 Arab Street, have been put up for sale by tender. The properties, which span over 1,000 sq ft, offer potential for buyers to increase floor area up to 4,629 sq ft. The sale price starts at S$8.25 million for the pair of shophouses at 56 Haji Lane-87 Arab Street. The properties are suitable for investment or own usage and are located near popular F&B establishments.

site_title: Half of all UK workers suffered a real-terms pay cut last year
summary: Half of UK workers experienced a real-terms pay cut last year, affecting 14 million people, according to the Resolution Foundation. This extends a decade-long decline in living standards. The crisis disproportionately impacted young workers in low-paid sectors, such as hospitality. Despite official data showing a rebound in average earnings, the foundation warns that this may not translate to improved pay for those hit hardest. Weak pay is expected to persist beyond 2021, threatening long-term prospects for young workers.

site_title: Seven strata retail units in Orchard up for sale with S$18.8m guide price
summary: A portfolio of seven strata retail units in Orchard Road, Singapore, is up for sale via public tender with a guide price of S$18.8 million. The units, ranging from S$1.48 million to S$6.28 million, are fully tenanted and offer competitive rental yields of 3-4%. The properties are approved for commercial use, making them eligible for foreign buyers, and do not incur additional buyer's or seller's stamp duty. The public tender will close on May 5.

site_title: Nestle rolls out touchless coffee machines, new flavours
summary: Nestle, the world's largest food company, is rolling out touchless coffee machines globally to cater to post-pandemic growth, with a focus on offices and at-home consumption. The company sees big growth prospects in China, India, and Africa, and is introducing new flavors and capsules to keep at-home demand high. Despite a tightening coffee supply, Nestle expects demand to rebalance as vaccination drives bring the prospect of post-pandemic life in view. The company forecasts a 4-5% growth in the global coffee market and plans to optimize its store network to keep up with changing consumer habits.

site_title: Japan carmakers scramble to assess impact of Renesas auto chip-plant fire
summary: Japanese carmakers Toyota, Nissan, and Honda are assessing the impact of a fire at Renesas Electronics' automotive chip plant in northeast Japan, which could exacerbate a global semiconductor shortage. Renesas, accounting for 30% of global micro control unit chips used in cars, will take at least a month to restart production after an electrical fault caused a fire. The shortage is expected to affect production beyond Japan, with auto shares sliding and production delays predicted for April and May. The Japanese government has promised help for the auto industry, while analysts warn of significant disruptions to chip supplies.

site_title: UK underestimating cost of making homes climate-friendly
summary: The UK government has significantly underestimated the cost of decarbonizing heating in British homes, a crucial step towards its net zero promise. According to a lawmaker report, the cost of improving energy efficiency could be as much as 18,000 pounds per household, five times the current government estimate. This delay in strategy may jeopardize the target of effectively zeroing out pollution by 2050, as energy efficiency of homes accounts for 20% of the country's greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: The UK government has "significantly underestimated" how much it will cost to decarbonise heating in British homes, a touchstone of its net zero promise.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as inflation fear tempers recovery hope
summary: Asian markets experienced volatility on Monday as inflation fears and potential interest rate hikes dampened economic optimism. The Turkish lira plummeted 17% after President Erdogan sacked the central bank chief, while the US Treasury yields rose, fueling concerns of inflation. Despite vaccine rollouts in the US and Britain, investors are worried about Europe's inoculation programme and lockdowns. Markets are now skeptical of the Federal Reserve's ability to keep interest rates low, with some predicting nominal bond yields could reach 2% or higher.

site_title: China names new PBOC policy committee members focused on jobs
summary: China appointed two new economists to its monetary policy committee, focusing on labor market and population issues. Cai Fang and Wang Yiming join the committee, replacing Liu Wei and Ma Jun. This move suggests an increased focus on boosting jobs and household incomes, amid concerns about slowing GDP growth. The appointments come as China's central bank seeks to address economic challenges and maintain stability.

site_title: Myanmar protesters hit streets at dawn as Mandalay reels from eight deaths
summary: Myanmar protesters gathered in the city of Mandalay, marking a day after eight demonstrators were killed, with over 2,600 people arrested and 250 killed according to a monitoring group. The military junta has been cracking down on protests since ousting civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi last month. Early morning rallies took place in Mandalay and Yangon, with demonstrators calling for UN intervention. The European Union is expected to approve sanctions against 11 junta officials on Monday, amid international condemnation and pressure to step up diplomatic efforts to halt the bloodshed.

site_title: Europe can achieve herd immunity by July: EU commissioner
summary: European Union Commissioner Thierry Breton says Europe can achieve herd immunity against Covid-19 by July, thanks to incoming vaccine jabs expected to speed up the continent's sluggish rollout. Over 55 factories are now producing vaccines in Europe, with 300-350 million doses expected between March and June. This optimism comes despite several European countries reimposing restrictions due to surging infections, and mixed messaging on vaccine safety. The EU has faced challenges in its vaccine drive, including halting AstraZeneca's shots due to blood clot cases, but Breton is confident more vaccines will arrive soon.

images.alt_text: "Let's take a symbolic date: by July 14, we have the possibility of achieving immunity across the continent," Thierry Breton, the EU's commissioner for the internal market told French broadcaster TF1.

site_title: Gold prices slide as Turkey upheaval buoys US dollar
summary: Gold prices slid 0.5% to $1,736.71 per ounce as investors opted for the US dollar and bonds following Turkey's surprise move to replace its central bank head, sparking financial uncertainty. The stronger dollar is seen as a major driver for gold prices, with alternative safe-haven assets like the yen and bonds losing appeal. The metal may retest a support level at $1,716 per ounce, with a break below potentially leading to a fall into the range of $1,669-$1,691.

images.alt_text: Gold prices slipped on Monday as investors opted for alternative safe-haven assets such as the US dollar and bonds after Turkey's abrupt decision to replace its central bank head with a critic of high interest rates sparked financial uncertainty.

site_title: Oil falls as European lockdowns douse recovery hopes
summary: Oil prices fell around 1% as European lockdowns doused recovery hopes, with Brent crude down 60 cents to $63.93 a barrel and US oil down 68 cents to $60.74 a barrel. Germany plans to extend a lockdown into a fifth month, while US drillers added rigs, the most since January, amid rising production. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries' production cuts aim to balance global markets after demand plummeted during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Aramco's US$75b dividend survives oil and earnings rout
summary: Saudi Aramco's $75 billion dividend for 2020 has survived a slump in oil prices and earnings, despite a 44% decline in net income to $66 billion. The company took on more debt to maintain the payout, but its gearing remains below that of comparable firms. Aramco expects capital expenditure to be $35 billion, down from previous guidance, and expects crude prices to remain around $65 a barrel. The company remains cautious but optimistic about 2021 growth, driven by improving energy consumption in Asia and a global oil demand recovery.

site_title: UK warns EU vaccine export ban would be 'counter-productive'
summary: The UK warned the EU against imposing an export ban on AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccines, calling it counter-productive. Defence Secretary Ben Wallace said halting exports would damage both British and European citizens, and undermine the EU's vaccine programme and reputation. The EU, however, is threatening the ban after AstraZeneca delivered less than 10% of its pledged doses. The dispute is over a factory in the Netherlands awaiting approval, with both sides claiming the future supply of the vaccine.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% or 3.12 points to 3,134.54. Gainers outnumbered losers 64 to 53, with OKH Global and Ley Choon Group seeing significant gains. Dairy Farm International was the top gainer, rising 0.9%, while Jardine Matheson Holdings fell 0.9%. The decline was attributed to negative leads from the Dow and S&P last Friday, following the Federal Reserve's decision to tighten capital requirements for banks.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 3.62 points, or 0.22%, to 1,622.57. Losers beat gainers 273 to 256, and volume was 617.80 million lots worth RM243.37 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares slip as Sydney faces worst floods in 60 years; insurers slump
summary: Australian shares fell 0.3% to 6,689.5 on Monday, marking its fourth consecutive session of losses, amid heavy selling in insurer stocks and losses in the mining sector. Flash floods in New South Wales caused massive damage, sparking expectations of increased claims, with insurers QBE, Suncorp, and Insurance Australia slumping 2.6%, 3.6%, and 4.1%, respectively.

site_title: Making light work of solar energy logistics
summary: Asean, the world's fifth-largest economy, is at a crossroads in its energy future, with a goal of securing 23% of its primary energy from modern, sustainable sources by 2025. As the region emerges from the pandemic, affordable, secure, and environmentally sustainable energy is crucial for its recovery. To achieve this, member states are exploring ways to scale up the use of solar energy, with countries like Singapore aiming to increase solar energy deployment five-fold by 2030. However, significant scale-up is also needed in the transport and logistics of renewable materials, and regional cooperation is essential to expand energy access.

images.alt_text: Geographical and technical conditions are some of the biggest challenges faced by renewable energy project developers in the region. Specific to Indonesia and the Philippines, the archipelagic nature of both countries results in difficulties within the transportation infrastructure and the overall solar energy supply chain.

site_title: New Zealand searches for fix as housing prices soar
summary: New Zealand is set to unveil measures to combat rising housing prices, which have surged 23% in 12 months and pushed out younger and lower-income buyers. The country's success in combating COVID-19 has attracted investors, fueling the market. The government plans to restrict loans to investors, dampen potential returns, and support other investments. Analysts warn there is no easy fix, and critics say the focus should be on boosting supply rather than addressing demand. The measures aim to tip the balance in favor of first-home buyers and improve housing supply, but experts predict a long-term solution is needed to address the country's chronic housing shortages.

site_title: Flooding stops Australian coal rail deliveries to Newcastle port
summary: Australian coal rail deliveries to the port of Newcastle have been halted due to severe flooding in New South Wales. The Hunter Valley coal rail lines, operated by the Australian Rail Track Corp, were closed until conditions are safe and water levels recede. Heavy rainfall has caused the worst flooding in half a century, affecting thousands of people and coal mines run by major companies. The Port of Newcastle, the world's largest coal export port, has two terminals with a total annual capacity of 145 million tonnes.

site_title: SMEs that digitalised in 2020 earned more, have better 2021 outlook: UOB study
summary: A UOB study found that Singaporean SMEs that digitalised in 2020 experienced stronger revenue growth and a better outlook for 2021 compared to non-adopters. Two in five digitalised SMEs outperformed non-adopters, with those who digitalised entire or multiple areas showing the greatest gains. The study also found that digitalisation helped SMEs achieve greater productivity, improve customer experience, and increase business performance. However, smaller businesses still lag in digital transformation, citing costs, cybersecurity concerns, and lack of necessary skillsets as major obstacles.

images.alt_text: Digitalisation efforts amid the Covid-19 pandemic in 2020 paid off in the form of stronger revenue growth and a better outlook for local SMEs, according to a study by UOB.

site_title: Investors urge Europe to prioritise climate in agriculture reform
summary: A US$2 trillion group of investors urged the European Commission to prioritize climate in the overhaul of the EU's farming subsidy programme. The proposed reforms should reduce direct support for high-emitting commodities, link financial support to environmental protection, and redesign incentives to prioritize sustainable agriculture. The group also recommended providing EU funds to help farmers transition away from high-emitting activities. The European Commission is committed to negotiating a farming policy that supports EU green goals, with proposals including increased funding for sustainable schemes like carbon farming and organic production.

site_title: Taiwan premier gets AstraZeneca shot as island starts vaccine campaign
summary: Taiwan Premier Su Tseng-chang received the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine shot, prioritizing health workers as the island starts its inoculation campaign. Despite concerns from European countries about the vaccine's safety, the World Health Organization has stated its benefits outweigh the risks. Taiwan has 117,000 doses of the AstraZeneca shot, with around 60,000 people in line for vaccination, and only 33 people remain hospitalized with Covid-19. The island has kept the pandemic under control due to early and effective prevention measures.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with losses, falling 0.65% to 28,801.09, following another loss on Wall Street. Inflation and bond yield fears continue to affect trading. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose marginally, and the Shenzhen Composite Index added 0.06%.

site_title: CapitaLand shareholders to hold shares in new investment and lodging entity
summary: CapitaLand's shareholders will hold shares in CapitaLand Investment Management (CLIM), listed on the Singapore Exchange, after the group's real estate development business is privatised. CLIM will own CapitaLand's investment management platforms and lodging business, with assets under management of about S$115 billion. The restructuring, involving CLA Real Estate Holdings and Temasek, aims to create the largest Asian real estate investment manager and third-largest globally.

site_title: First negative-yield quote causes flutter in India bond market
summary: India's sovereign bond market experienced its first-ever negative yield quote, with a 6.17% bond maturing in 2021 priced at around 1.5% negative yield. The quote was attributed to a manual error by a bank, which placed a wrong price quote, causing the negative yield. This could lead to higher borrowing costs for traders betting against Indian bonds, as negative rates would make short-selling more expensive.

site_title: Shares of Japan's big three car makers dip after Renesas auto chip-plant fire
summary: Shares of Toyota, Nissan, and Honda fell over 2% in early trading after a fire at a Renesas Electronics semiconductor plant disrupted automotive chip production. The fire destroyed machinery and delayed production by at least a month, affecting shipments to customers. The shortage has already forced the three car makers to scale back production plans. Toyota, which had stockpiled chip supplies, fared better than its competitors, while Nissan and Honda have had to adjust production due to the chip shortage.

site_title: Biggest floods in decades hampering Australia's vaccine roll-out
summary: Australia's COVID-19 vaccine rollout has been disrupted by torrential rain and flooding along the New South Wales coast, including Sydney. The downpour has caused evacuations, damaged property, and disrupted freight and logistics services. The government has faced criticism for its organization and slow start to the vaccine rollout. About 200,000 vaccine doses are set to be delivered to general practitioners, but some deliveries have been delayed due to the flooding. The floods come after Australia experienced catastrophic bushfires last year.

site_title: Vaccine passports not a silver bullet for tourism-starved South-east Asia: Moody's
summary: Moody's Analytics economist Xu Xiao Chun suggests that reopening to Chinese and Singaporean tourists is crucial for South-east Asia's post-pandemic recovery. However, vaccine passport schemes pose challenges due to data security and verification concerns. Xu notes that easy access to digital health records could lead to issues with authentication and confidentiality. The report highlights the need for a balanced approach to tourism recovery, considering both economic and security factors.

images.alt_text: A woman showcases the new China's international travel health certificate application example for smartphones in Shanghai, China, March 10, 2021.

site_title: Australia to evacuate thousands as Sydney faces worst floods in 60 years
summary: Australian authorities plan to evacuate thousands more people from flood-affected suburbs in Sydney's west, set for its worst flooding in 60 years, with heavy rain expected until Wednesday. The past three days of unrelenting rains have caused widespread damage, triggering mass evacuations and severe flood warnings. Nearly 2,000 people have already been evacuated, and authorities expect the wild weather to continue. The flooding is expected to be higher than any since 1961, with a severe flood warning issued for parts of NSW and neighboring Queensland.

site_title: HSBC to reopen main Hong Kong office on Monday: memo
summary: HSBC Holdings will reopen its main Hong Kong office on Monday after a one-week closure due to COVID-19 cases. Precautions, including mask-wearing and social distancing, will continue to be in place. The bank had 30,000 employees in Hong Kong, which contributed to 90% of its adjusted pretax profit last year. The reopening comes after an outbreak at a local gym and amid efforts to contain the spread of the virus in the city.

site_title: US economists see Federal Reserve hiking lending rate sooner than expected: survey
summary: US economists believe the Federal Reserve may hike its lending rate sooner than expected, with 46% predicting a rate increase in 2022 and 28% in 2023. This contradicts the Fed's stance that it won't raise rates until inflation hits 2.0%. Rising expectations for inflation, fueled by massive stimulus measures, contribute to these predictions. Economists are also concerned about the national debt, with 88% worried about the debt level.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve has vowed it won't raise its benchmark lending rate anytime soon, but US economists in a survey released on Monday believe the central bank could be forced to enact a hike as soon as next year.
