site_title: US House antitrust chairman plans multiple bills to go after Big Tech
summary: US House antitrust chairman Representative David Cicilline plans to introduce 10 or more bills targeting Big Tech companies, including Apple, Amazon, Google, and Facebook, following a 449-page report detailing market power abuses. The strategy aims to lower opposition from tech companies and lobbyists by breaking down a single piece of legislation into smaller bills.

site_title: Ecomi gains users on NFT wave
summary: Ecomi's VeVe app has seen a 11,225% surge in user base over 90 days, reaching 86,000 users across 186 countries. The online marketplace allows users to buy and sell digital collectibles. CEO David Yu co-founded the company in 2017, initially dabbling in NFTs for personal interest. The NFT market has rapidly grown, with VeVe's user base increasing by thousands daily.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, falling 1.31% or 389.41 points to 29,402.64, tracking US indexes' declines amid concerns over yields and US central bank officials' comments.

site_title: Keppel-linked Floatel gets US$100m loan from Temasek's Clifford Capital amid restructuring
summary: Floatel, a Keppel-linked company, has secured a US$100 million super senior revolving credit facility from Temasek's Clifford Capital amid restructuring efforts. As part of the deal, Floatel will retain ownership of its subsidiaries and Keppel unit FELS Offshore will forgive a US$244 million subordinated loan. Floatel's senior secured bonds will be converted into new bonds and common shares, while its second-lien bonds will be converted into warrants with a 10-year term. The restructuring is expected to complete on March 24 and is not expected to impair Keppel Corp's carrying value of Floatel.

site_title: UK to unveil global focus in defence modernisation plans
summary: The UK government will unveil its long-awaited military modernisation plans, "Defence in a Competitive Age", on Monday. The plans focus on bolstering the navy and global footprint, with promises of more ships, submarines, and sailors. The Royal Marines will be transformed into the Future Commando Force. The UK aims to strengthen its defence of British interests "across multiple domains and in all corners of the globe".

site_title: Germany poised to tighten curbs into April as virus rages
summary: Germany is set to tighten partial lockdown restrictions until April due to the rapid spread of coronavirus variants. Existing restrictions, including remote work requirements, will be extended until an unspecified date in April. Shops in worst-hit areas may be forced to close again, with companies required to provide rapid tests for employees. The decision comes as health authorities warn of a "clearly exponential" rise in case numbers, with the incidence rate reaching 103.9 per 100,000 inhabitants.

site_title: Turkish lira plunges after Erdogan sacks hawkish central bank chief
summary: Turkey's lira plummeted 16% to near its all-time low after President Erdogan sacked hawkish central bank governor Sahap Kavcioglu, a move seen as a shift towards looser monetary policies. Kavcioglu's appointment, his third tenure, was met with market expectations of a sharp lira depreciation. Analysts predicted a "dark and long day" for the lira, with some forecasting a 10-15% decline, citing concerns over Turkey's depleted FX reserves and balance of payments crisis. The move reverses the hawkish stance taken by predecessor Naci Agbal, who raised rates to combat inflation.

site_title: Indonesia grocery market to hit US$169b in 2022 but traditional retailers may lose ground to mini-marts, e-commerce: IGD
summary: Indonesia's grocery market is projected to reach $169.4 billion in 2022, with a 5.2% compound annual growth rate, making it the world's 13th-largest market. Traditional retailers may lose ground to mini-marts and e-commerce, with convenience stores expected to gain a 9.3% market share and online grocery sales rising from 0.3% to 0.5% in 2022. This shift is attributed to the increasing use of smartphones and recovery of spending power amidst the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK ministers draw up contingency plans to save Liberty Steel
summary: UK ministers are developing contingency plans to save Liberty Steel, a crucial industry job provider, amid fears of collapse. Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng and officials have held intensive discussions with steelmaker Sanjeev Gupta to secure its future. The move comes as thousands of jobs are at risk, highlighting the government's efforts to prevent a major economic blow.

images.alt_text: The British government is concerned amid fears that thousands of jobs in a critically important industry are at risk.

site_title: Protesters march against anti-Asian racism in US
summary: Thousands of Americans marched against anti-Asian racism in major cities including Atlanta, New York, and Washington, following a mass shooting at Asian-owned spas in Georgia. The shooter, Robert Aaron Long, denied racial motivation but admitted to the crime. Protests were also held in Montreal, Canada. Activists and marchers condemned years of anti-Asian racism fueled by former President Trump's "China virus" phrase. The rallies come as police in Atlanta have yet to confirm the shooting was racially motivated, sparking outrage among Asian-American communities.

site_title: First ever tweet turns 15 years old
summary: Twitter's first-ever tweet, posted 15 years ago on March 21, 2006, by CEO Jack Dorsey, is up for auction with a starting bid of $2.5 million. The short message "just setting up my twttr" marked the launch of a platform that has become a dominant force in civil society, but has also been marred by controversy, including the deletion of former President Donald Trump's account following the US Capitol insurrection. The tweet's sale highlights the evolution of social media and its impact on society.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Keppel, Lian Beng, Singapore Reinsurance
summary: Key developments in Singapore stocks include Frasers Centrepoint Trust divesting YewTee Point for S$220 million, Keppel Corporation securing a US$100 million credit facility, Lian Beng Group winning a S$131 million contract, and Singapore Reinsurance receiving a cash offer from Fairfax Asia. Trading halts were also issued for several companies, pending an announcement by CapitaLand.

site_title: Wall Street is betting billions on an EV-fuelled lithium comeback
summary: Investors are betting on a comeback in lithium, a key metal for rechargeable batteries, as automakers ramp up electric vehicle production. Major automakers such as Ford, General Motors, and Volkswagen are investing heavily in battery production, and the US administration's shift towards cleaner energy has boosted confidence in the industry. This has led to a surge in equity offerings, with lithium miners raising over $3.4 billion in the Americas this year, seven times the total amount raised from 2018 to 2020. Prices of lithium have rebounded, with a 32% increase in the lithium price index this year.

site_title: CBA and ANZ settle 2016 class action on alleged interest rate rigging
summary: Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) and Australia and New Zealand Bank (ANZ) have settled a 2016 class action lawsuit in the US, accused of benchmark interest rate rigging. The US-based investment funds and an individual trader alleged the banks made hundreds of millions in profits by manipulating benchmark bank bill swap rates. Both CBA and ANZ denied admitting liability, stating the settlements were confidential and would not significantly impact the companies. The terms of the settlements were not disclosed.

site_title: OCBC, Food From The Heart collaborate to empower beneficiaries of food programmes
summary: OCBC Bank and Food From The Heart (FFTH) have collaborated to empower low-income families in Singapore by setting up community shops that allow beneficiaries to choose the type of food they want to collect monthly. The initiative aims to minimize food wastage by providing personalized food options. With OCBC's funding, FFTH has already collected over $60,000 worth of food and plans to open a second community shop at Boon Lay to feed 1,200 households. The program aims to give beneficiaries the dignity of choice, reducing mismatch and wastage of food.

site_title: US cruises planning comeback for June with Bahamas-only trips
summary: US cruise lines are planning to resume operations with Bahamas-only trips in June, following Crystal Cruises' lead. Royal Caribbean International and Celebrity Cruises will offer itineraries from Nassau, Bahamas, to Cozumel, Mexico, and southern Caribbean destinations, respectively. These moves come as the US cruise industry looks to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Canadian Pacific Railway to buy Kansas City Southern for US$25b
summary: Canadian Pacific Railway (CP) has agreed to buy Kansas City Southern for US$25 billion, creating a 32,000km rail network linking the US, Mexico, and Canada. Investors will receive 0.489 of a CP share and US$90 in cash for each share, valuing the stock at US$275 apiece.

site_title: Rising prices can't stop US real estate boom
summary: US real estate continues to boom despite rising mortgage rates, which increased for the first time in five weeks. The housing market was boosted by low mortgage rates and the shift to remote work during the Covid-19 pandemic. Real estate was one of the few bright spots in the US economy, which has struggled after states restricted business. The trend is expected to continue, with the housing market showing no signs of slowing down.

site_title: Mapping out plans in risky territory
summary: Companies operating in markets with high risks of repression and political threats should reassess their investment strategies. Experts advise conducting thorough due diligence, mapping capacities and capabilities against changing market risk profiles, and developing contingency plans. Investing in such markets requires a long-term strategy and outlook, and companies must weigh the risks against potential economic benefits. Reputational and financial damage can arise from associations with unsavory partners and clients, and companies should uphold global norms and principles. Effective risk mitigation strategies involve timely intelligence, access to local assistance capabilities, and scenario planning.

site_title: Citi's Revlon blunder spurs new rules to handle botched payments
summary: Citi's misdirected payment of $900 million to Revlon lenders has led to a new push for industry-wide rules to handle such errors. The Loan Syndication & Trade Association (LSTA) is drafting language for credit agreements to address accidental payments, requiring lenders to return erroneous funds within two business days and notify the agent. The move aims to reduce lawsuits and promote consistency in handling such situations, following a recent court ruling in favor of Revlon creditors.

site_title: Oil still remains on a bumpy path to recovery despite price swerve
summary: Oil prices experienced a 7% slump last Thursday, but the market is expected to continue its recovery, driven by a steady rebound in demand. Global oil demand, which plummeted 30% during the pandemic, is now back at 95% of its pre-Covid high, according to the International Energy Agency. As vaccination progress and economic recovery continue, Western world oil demand is expected to bounce back, with Europe's vaccination hiccups unlikely to change the economic outlook. Despite some regional challenges, China is leading Asia's rebound, with petrol usage extending a run above pre-Covid levels.

site_title: Vaccine passports can go a long way towards reopening borders
summary: Vaccine passports could help international borders reopen, particularly for Singapore, which aims to revive its travel industry safely. The International Air Transport Association (Iata) has developed a digital certificate app, with several airlines testing it for air travel. However, medical concerns, such as the risk of transmission from vaccinated individuals, remain. The use of vaccine passports may be viewed as a layer of assurance, improving the chances of establishing travel bubbles, but may not open doors for countries with ongoing pandemics.

site_title: Retail investors not pricing in climate change sufficiently: asset managers
summary: Retail investors are not adequately accounting for climate change risks in their investments, according to asset managers. Mercer's head of responsible investments, Alexis Cheang, states that climate change is only 20% priced into global investment valuations. This lack of consideration for climate-related risks may be due to a mismatch between available data and investor demand for climate information. Experts emphasize the need for better quality climate data in the markets to accurately reflect these risks.

site_title: Kenya's biggest bank bets on digital payments for growth
summary: Kenya's largest bank, KCB Group Plc, is exploring digital payment partnerships to boost revenue, following a 22% decline in net income in the previous year. CEO Joshua Oigara aims to generate 20% of revenue from the digital platform in the next two years, after a mobile wallet partnership with Safaricom Plc saw a significant increase in transactions. The bank has lost millions due to waived charges for mobile transactions during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tremendous Entertainment, Crossroads Live in deal to bring more shows to S-E Asia
summary: Tremendous Entertainment and Crossroads Live have entered a "long-term strategic cooperation agreement" to bring more shows to South-east Asia. The partnership will also see Crossroads Live making a minority investment in Tremendous Entertainment as the company prepares for a public listing this year. The deal aims to expand Tremendous Entertainment's growth ambitions, leveraging Crossroads Live's track record of partnering with West End and Broadway creators. This agreement follows recent productions at the Sands Theatre in Marina Bay Sands, including Aladdin, The Phantom of the Opera, and Crossroads Live's touring productions of Cats and Chicago.

site_title: Strong start for Hang Seng Index in 2021
summary: The Hang Seng Index experienced a strong start in 2021, breaking out of a descending channel and reaching a new high. However, the upside move needs to be confirmed with a break above 32,255, a key price target. The index has been trending above 200 and 50 period moving averages and has found support above 29,000. There are two possible scenarios: a sustained rally beyond resistance zone 1, which could reach target resistance zone 2, or a potential head-and-shoulder top, which could lead to a break below support zone 1.

site_title: Beijing crackdown cuts Big Tech down to size
summary: China's government has launched a crackdown on its tech giants, including Alibaba, JD.com, and Tencent, amid concerns over chaotic online lending, data misuse, and industry concentration. The crackdown has resulted in billions of dollars in lost share value and is expected to lead to stricter regulations, including forcing companies to run their lending operations like banks. While some see the crackdown as necessary, others express concerns about the impact on innovation and enterprise, with many Chinese consumers shrugging off the move as a necessary step to address growing issues.

site_title: How NFT mania is a lesson on speculation
summary: OCBC Bank has partnered with Beeple to sell the artist's US$69.3 million digital photo montage, the most expensive NFT to date, to a Singapore-based investor. This sale highlights the speculative nature of NFT investments, with prices often driven by hype rather than inherent value. While NFTs offer legitimate use cases for artists, their high prices serve as a warning against fad investments. This phenomenon is reminiscent of past crypto manias, underscoring the need for caution in the rapidly evolving digital art market.

site_title: Fire and ice aggravate chip supply headache for global car industry
summary: A fire at a Japanese semiconductor factory, Renesas Electronics, has worsened the global vehicle industry's chip supply headache, coinciding with cold weather in North America and ongoing competition for semiconductors. The incident may force carmakers to hold more inventory, and some manufacturers, including Toyota, Ford, and Honda, have already warned of disruptions. Production halt announcements are expected, with Volkswagen's Autoeuropa plant in Portugal set to halt production from March 22-28 due to semiconductor shortages.

site_title: Virtual land prices are up, and there's a fund for that too
summary: Republic Real Estate is launching an invite-only fund to buy and develop virtual property, aiming to increase value among cryptocurrency enthusiasts. The fund will purchase parcels in online "metaverses" such as Decentraland and Cryptovoxels, with a minimum investment of $25,000. Virtual land prices have surged, with the average price paid per parcel in Decentraland tripling from 2020 to $2,703. The fund plans to develop virtual hotels, stores, and other uses, with the goal of attracting real-life investors seeking insulation from real-world market risks.

site_title: Is it time for Sabana Reit to be euthanised?
summary: A dissident minority of Sabana Shari'ah Compliant Industrial Reit (Sabana Reit) unitholders is threatening to withhold endorsement of two new independent directors at the upcoming annual general meeting, citing a lack of trust in the Reit's manager. The minority, backed by Quarz Capital Management and Black Crane Capital, believes the manager should focus on increasing the Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) and asset value, rather than "business as usual." The minority is demanding the manager foot the cost of a failed merger with ESR-Reit and limiting ESR Cayman's influence over the Reit's operations.

site_title: Credit Suisse plans to triple China headcount in major push
summary: Credit Suisse plans to triple its headcount in China over the next three years, aiming to gain market share as China's financial market opens. The Swiss firm aims to take full control of its securities venture and apply for a banking license for its branch. This move follows similar plans by rivals such as Goldman Sachs, with the company's Asia Pacific region seeing a 24% profit rise last year. The expansion is part of Credit Suisse's efforts to enhance its core offering and strengthen its position in the Chinese market.

site_title: New Hanwell chair, Sam Goi, ups stake
summary: Singapore Stocks: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.0% over five trading sessions from March 12 to 18, bringing its total return for 2021 to 10.5%. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, UOB, Venture Corporation, and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust received the highest net institutional inflows. 13 primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with Wilmar International leading the tally. Director and substantial shareholder transactions saw 120 changes in interests for over 50 stocks, including acquisitions and disposals.

site_title: Australia's Crown Resorts receives A$8b buyout offer from Blackstone
summary: Crown Resorts, a beleaguered Australian casino operator, received a buyout offer from private equity company Blackstone Group Inc, valuing the company at A$8.02 billion. The offer, priced at A$11.85 per share, represents a 20.2% premium to Crown's closing price. Blackstone, which owns a 10% stake in Crown, has been under pressure due to the company's money laundering and governance issues. The offer is subject to various conditions, including regulatory approvals, and Crown's board has not yet formed a view on the proposal.

images.alt_text: Beleaguered casino operator Crown Resorts said on Monday it received a buyout offer from private equity company Blackstone Group Inc that values the company at A$8.02 billion (S$8.32 billion).

site_title: Ghost of horrific Treasury auction haunts US bond market that's on the brink
summary: The US Treasury auction market is on the brink, with a $62 billion offering looming, after a disastrous seven-year auction in February sent the bond market into a tailspin. The market is anxious due to a brightening outlook for growth and inflation, and a bear market in longer maturities. The Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates near zero through 2023 has fueled concerns about the impact of higher rates on equities. Dealers are bracing for the auctions, which will test the market's end-user demand and volatility.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 19, 2021, reveals a steady build for the Capesize market, with the 5TC lifting $2,696 to settle at $19,437. Pressure on charterers continued, while smaller sizes saw significant gains. The Pacific West Australia to China C5 remained resilient, and the Brazil to China C3 saw fixtures across its loading window. Dry bulk FFA's were heavily traded, with record volumes registered. Panamax rates surged, with healthy levels agreed for period on forward delivery positions. Ultramax/Supramax sentiment was split, with Asian basin remaining firm and Atlantic softening. Handysize rates remained high, with the 3 Pacific routes seeing a surge of over $1,000 within a day. VLCC rates firmed slightly in the Atlantic and remained unmoved in the Middle East. Suezmax and Aframax markets also saw gains, with Mediterranean Aframax rates climbing 19 points to mid WS130s.

site_title: Overworked Goldman staff plead for maximum 80-hour work week
summary: Goldman Sachs employees, mostly first-year hires, are pleading for an 80-hour work week limit, citing physical and mental health issues due to their current average 98-hour work week. The proposal, made in an 11-page presentation, also states that employees are "victims of workplace abuse" and are struggling with anxiety. The bank has acknowledged the concerns and is taking steps to address them, but has not committed to the proposed 80-hour limit. The move comes as the bank accelerates its recruitment and transfers employees into its busiest divisions.

site_title: Health workers protest in Myanmar after deadly crackdown
summary: Health workers in Myanmar's Mandalay city rallied in support of anti-coup protesters, avoiding a confrontation with security forces. The rally, staged at dawn to evade security, followed a deadly weekend crackdown that resulted in the killing of four protesters. Nearly 250 deaths have been confirmed since the coup, with over 2,300 others arrested. International condemnation has failed to halt the bloodshed, and the European Union is set to approve sanctions against 11 junta officials.

site_title: Greece lifts some Covid-19 restrictions to relieve lockdown fatigue
summary: Greece will lift some COVID-19 lockdown restrictions starting Monday, including hair and beauty salons and archaeological sites, to relieve national fatigue. The government plans to provide free rapid tests and extend the nighttime curfew by two hours on weekends. Despite a surge in infections, Greece has fared better than many European countries, with hospitals under severe pressure. The government aims to gradually reopen the economy and comply with remaining measures.

site_title: UK pubs look for cheer after bitter lockdowns
summary: The UK pub industry is looking forward to a gradual reopening after a year of lockdowns, with English pubs set to resume serving alcohol outside from April 12. However, the sector has been severely impacted, with the loss of 2,000 pubs over the past year and a 56% drop in beer sales last year. Pub managers are sprucing up their establishments to attract customers, with some offering takeaway pints and food. Industry leaders are optimistic despite the challenges, citing crucial state financial support and government help, and are calling for more support to help the sector recover.

site_title: IPO mania fizzles in Hong Kong as mega first-day pops disappear
summary: Hong Kong's initial public offering (IPO) market has seen a decline in massive first-day pops, with 31% of 13 IPOs raising over $100 million posting losses on day one in 2021, compared to 17% in 2020. Volatility and concerns about policy tightening in China are attributed to the decrease in investor appetite. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic about the upcoming listings of Baidu and Bilibili, citing high-quality companies and strong investor demand.

site_title: Corporate America primed to join Buffett in buyback binge
summary: US corporations are expected to increase share repurchases this year, despite rising interest rates, as they hold large cash reserves and project strong earnings growth. With over $2.2 trillion in cash, companies are likely to follow Warren Buffett's lead in buying back shares to support the stock market. Buyback activity has already shown signs of rebounding, with S&P 500 companies buying back shares at a pace 28% higher than the previous quarter. Analysts expect a 50% expansion in repurchases if buybacks return to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Tremendous Entertainment, Crossroads Live in deal to bring more shows to S-E Asia
summary: Tremendous Entertainment (TE) and Crossroads Live have entered a long-term strategic cooperation agreement to bring more shows to South-east Asia. Crossroads Live will also invest a minority stake in TE as it prepares for a public listing this year. The partnership aims to expand entertainment offerings in the region, while TE's public listing is expected to occur later this year.

site_title: Mass evacuations as rains cause record flooding in Australia
summary: Mass evacuations were ordered in Australia's east coast due to record flooding caused by torrential rains. Hundreds of people sought shelter in evacuation centers north of Sydney, with the Hastings River surpassing record 2013 flood levels. The Bureau of Meteorology warned of life-threatening flash flooding, with over 500 calls for help and 180 rescues reported. The floods, which have seen over 300 millimeters of rain since Friday, are expected to continue through Saturday, affecting towns from Port Macquarie to south of Sydney.

site_title: EU's plodding stirs ECB concerns as US delivers stimulus
summary: The European Union's path to joint fiscal stimulus is uncertain, casting doubt on its ability to address the output gap. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde expressed concern over the slow rollout of the 750 billion-euro pandemic recovery fund. EU officials fear that without similar fiscal efforts, the output gap will persist, further complicating the bloc's economic recovery. This raises pressure on EU leadership to implement its flagship tool effectively, amidst a faltering crisis response.

site_title: Sing Holdings adopts back to basics strategy
summary: Sing Holdings, a Singapore-based property developer, is adopting a "back to basics" strategy by focusing on mass-market private condos and executive condos (ECs). The company's CEO, Lee Sze Hao, attributes this shift to the uncertain property market caused by the pandemic and the low interest rate environment. The group is targeting the upgrader housing market, with pricing for new EC projects at around S$1,100-1,200 per square foot, lower than new mass-market private condos. Sing Holdings is developing a new EC project in Yishun, which will feature 12 blocks of 14 storeys with over 600 units, and is expected to be completed by the end of this year.

site_title: Rotimatic kneads more focus on economic viability, says new owner
summary: Rotimatic, an Indian flatbread-maker, has seen a turnaround since its new owner, Madhujeet Chimni, took over last October. The company is focusing on refining logistics, customer support, and marketing, while also improving its kitchen appliance. This comes after the company doubled down on these efforts following a change in ownership.

site_title: Polybee wins two DBS awards worth S$75,000 for bee-imitating technology
summary: Polybee, a Singaporean startup, won two DBS awards worth S$75,000 for its bee-imitating technology that uses autonomous drones for indoor pollination. The awards include the DBS Tech for Impact award and the People's Choice Award in the DBS Foundation Social Impact Prize competition. The recognition will provide Polybee with access to the DBS Innovation ecosystem and marketing support.

site_title: Turkey pulls out of landmark treaty protecting women from violence
summary: Turkey has withdrawn from the 2011 Istanbul Convention, the world's first binding treaty to prevent and combat violence against women, in a move seen as a victory for conservatives in President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's ruling party. The treaty, signed by 45 countries and the European Union, aimed to prosecute domestic violence and similar abuse, but was criticized by conservatives as damaging family unity and promoting divorce. Rights groups and opposition parties have condemned the move, with calls for protests in Istanbul and warnings that women will remain "second-class citizens."

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco seeking greener pastures following political unrest
summary: Singapore-listed firm Myanmar Investco (SMI) is seeking opportunities outside of Myanmar amid escalating risks in the country following the February military coup. The company's business remains wounded by the pandemic, with its primary source of revenue, travel and fashion retail operations, severely impacted by the closure of Yangon International Airport and lockdowns. SMI's executive director, Mark Bedingham, stated that the company has reduced costs and is exploring consumer-oriented opportunities in the broader region, with a focus on Singapore.

site_title: Apple told to pay US$308.5m for infringing patent
summary: A US federal jury ordered Apple to pay $308.5 million for allegedly infringing a patent related to digital rights management. The patent, held by Personalized Media Communications, was used in Apple's FairPlay technology for the distribution of encrypted content. A running royalty will be paid based on Apple's sales or usage, with one expert estimating $240 million in royalties. Apple plans to appeal the ruling, stating that the case "stifle[s] innovation and ultimately harm[s] consumers."

site_title: Apple told to pay US$308.5m for patent infringement
summary: A US federal jury ordered Apple to pay $308.5 million to Personalized Media Communications for patent infringement related to digital rights management. The jury found Apple infringed on a patent used in its iTunes, App Store, and Apple Music applications. Apple plans to appeal the decision, stating it would "stifle innovation and harm consumers." This ruling comes after a five-day trial and a previous US appeals court decision revived the case.

images.alt_text: Apple must pay US$308.5 million to closely held Personalized Media Communications after a federal jury in Marshall, Texas, decided on Friday that the tech giant infringed a patent related to digital rights management.

site_title: China steps up Covid-19 vaccination; considers differentiated visa policies
summary: China has administered 10 million Covid-19 vaccine doses in a week, reaching 74.96 million doses, with a goal to vaccinate 40% of its 1.4 billion people by mid-year. Beijing is considering differentiated visa policies based on vaccination and virus conditions in different countries. China aims to increase vaccine production to meet domestic needs and may adjust virus curbing measures after domestic immunization reaches a high level. The country is prioritizing elderly populations for vaccination and may adopt "vaccine passports" to ease travel restrictions.

site_title: Greater focus on innovation crucial for Singapore's future, says DPM
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of innovation for Singapore's future, citing the city-state's need to grow and develop its economy without natural resources. At the Lee Kuan Yew Global Business Plan Competition, Singapore drew a record 850 entries from 60 countries, with MIT and the University of Melbourne winning top prizes in their respective categories. The competition aims to discover and engage global young talent, with the goal of driving innovation and entrepreneurship in sustainable urban solutions.

site_title: Human-centred
summary: Accenture Singapore Chairperson Teo Lay Lim emphasizes the importance of understanding individual uniqueness and fostering a human-centered approach in business. She attributes her curiosity to a childhood fascination with historical figures and the idea of viewing events through their lens. Lim notes that Accenture's traditional rigid methodology is giving way to a more agile approach, focusing on co-creation and innovation with clients. As Chairperson, Lim prioritizes building people and promoting responsible business practices, including sustainability and employee well-being. She relinquished her roles to focus on mentorship, expanding her mind, and contributing to society through external appointments.

site_title: Gold up, heads for second weekly rise as US dollar eases off session high
summary: Gold rose 0.3% to $1,742.14 per ounce, on track for a second weekly gain, as US Treasury yields dipped and the US dollar eased off session highs. Analysts attributed the rise to stabilization of interest rates and fears of inflation, making gold a hedge against inflation. Spot gold was up 0.9% this week, while palladium fell 1.9% but rose 11% for the week, its largest gain since early November.

site_title: Musk says Tesla would be shut down if its cars spied in China, elsewhere
summary: Elon Musk stated that Tesla would be shut down if its cars were used to spy in China or elsewhere, amid reports that China's military has banned Teslas from its facilities due to security concerns over cameras. Musk emphasized the importance of confidentiality and urged greater mutual trust between the US and China. The ban affects Tesla's sales in China, the world's biggest car market, where the company sold 147,445 vehicles last year.

images.alt_text: Tesla chief executive Elon Musk said on Saturday his company would be shut down if its cars were used to spy, his first comments on news that China's military has banned Teslas from its facilities.

site_title: Singapore bonds' real yields seen drawing buyers after sell-off
summary: Singapore offers the highest real yields among top-rated countries, with its 10-year inflation-adjusted yield now offering a 62 basis points upside. The nation's bond investors will benefit from the added supply, which will be used to fund infrastructure projects, as the government aims to develop a yield curve and add diversity to the bond market. Despite concerns about supply, analysts see long-term benefits of the infrastructure funding plan, which will outweigh the supply concerns, and expect decent demand for the new bonds.

site_title: Finland is world's happiest country despite Covid-19 pandemic: report
summary: Finland remains the world's happiest country, ranking first for the fourth consecutive year, according to the World Happiness Report. The report, which assesses happiness based on GDP, social support, and personal freedom, found that European countries dominated the top spots, with Denmark and Switzerland also in the top five. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic, Finland's high quality of life, security, and public services contributed to its top ranking, with a significant decrease in rates of inequality and poverty.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower on lockdown worries, still posts third week of gains
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 fell 0.8% on Friday amid concerns over France's new lockdown and vaccination campaigns. France's CAC 40 dropped 1.1% after the nation imposed a four-week lockdown in 16 regions. Bank stocks led sectoral declines. The new lockdown is expected to worsen France's economic outlook for the first part of 2021.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to divest YewTee Point for S$220m
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust will divest YewTee Point for S$220 million, with the transaction expected to be completed on May 28. The sale proceeds will be used to repay debts and lower the trust's gearing level.

site_title: Gold's hopes from the Fed are hijacked by soaring Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices surged mid-week after the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting, where the Fed pledged to maintain near-zero interest rates until 2023. This dovish stance boosted gold prices to a two-week high, driven by expectations of a continued accommodative monetary policy. The Fed's statement also suggested it would not be overly concerned with inflation, further supporting gold. Despite a rise in US Treasury yields, the US dollar slipped, and gold prices rose over one percent.

site_title: Canadian dollar steadies as oil rebounds in volatile trading
summary: The Canadian dollar steadied against the US dollar on Friday after a sharp decline the previous day, as oil prices rebounded in volatile trading. Oil rose 2.4% to $61.42 a barrel, helping to keep the loonie in check. Canadian retail sales fell 1.1% in January, less than expected, and the loonie was trading nearly unchanged at 1.2491 to the greenback. The decline in oil prices had erased about 7% from prices earlier in the week, driven by concerns over a resurgence of coronavirus cases in Europe.

site_title: Biden deplores rising anti-Asian violence, asks Americans to stand together against hate
summary: US President Joe Biden condemned rising anti-Asian violence in the country, particularly after a deadly shooting rampage in Georgia that killed eight people, six of whom were Asian women. He called for lawmakers to pass a Covid-19 hate crimes bill and urged Americans to stand together against hate. The meeting with Asian-American leaders came as a surge of attacks on the community is linked to the pandemic and has been fueled by language used by former President Donald Trump. Biden promised to speak out against violence and discrimination, while Vice-President Kamala Harris tied the violence to the long history of racism in the US.

site_title: Oil prices rise 2%, but set for weekly loss on demand fears
summary: Oil prices rose 2% in volatile trading on Friday, driven by a sell-off earlier in the week that erased 7% from prices, amid concerns over European lockdowns and vaccine distribution issues. Despite a surge in US shale production, oil prices are expected to end the week in a loss due to ongoing demand fears. Brent crude rose to $64.63 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate rose to $61.45 a barrel. Goldman Sachs predicts a significant increase in global oil demand in the coming months, but warns of a 750,000-barrel-per-day supply shortfall in the second quarter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lian Beng Group secured a S$131 million contract for a residential project with communal facilities in Canberra Drive, expected to positively impact the group's financials. Sen Yue Holdings plans to oppose interim judicial management applications from DBS, while Yunnan Energy International reported a preliminary net loss of HK$38.8 million, 200% higher than the previous year, due to revenue hit by the pandemic.

site_title: US dollar rises after Fed lifts bank leverage exemption
summary: The US dollar rose to a one-week high against major currencies after the Federal Reserve allowed a pandemic-driven break on capital requirements to lapse, pushing US Treasury yields up. The US dollar index gained 0.6% for the week, and the benchmark US 10-year note climbed 80 basis points. The Fed's decision to let expire a temporary rule directing larger banks to hold more capital against assets was seen as a sign of its loose policy stance. This has led to higher US Treasury yields, supporting the dollar's value.

site_title: Malaysia PM backs Indonesia's call for emergency Asean summit on Myanmar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin supports Indonesia's call for an emergency Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) summit to address the situation in Myanmar, where lethal violence against civilians persists. Indonesia's President Joko Widodo urged the Asean leaders to hold a meeting to discuss the crisis and restore democracy in Myanmar. The Brunei Sultan, currently Asean chair, will be contacted to facilitate the meeting. The situation in Myanmar remains a pressing concern, with Malaysia and Indonesia emphasizing the need for peaceful solutions.

site_title: International pressure on Myanmar generals grows as two more killed in gunfire
summary: International pressure on Myanmar's military junta intensified as two more people were killed in gunfire in the northern ruby mining town of Mogok, bringing the death toll since the February 1 coup to 237. The UN Secretary-General condemned the violence, while Western countries and Asian neighbors condemned the military's actions as "immoral and indefensible." The US House of Representatives approved legislation condemning the coup, and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) urged an end to the violence, with Indonesian President Joko Widodo calling for an urgent meeting.

site_title: New York mall owner tries to hang on with debt storm swirling
summary: Pyramid Management Group, a US$4 billion mall owner, is struggling with debt as the pandemic hit its operations hard. Eight of its malls were revalued at 59% lower, leaving them worth less than their debt. Despite this, CEO Stephen J Congel remains optimistic, saying his company can withstand the crisis that has pushed other mall owners to file for bankruptcy. The company's debt storm is a significant challenge, but Congel's optimism suggests a potential path forward.

site_title: Fairfax Asia making cash offer of S$0.3535 a share for Singapore Reinsurance with a view of delisting
summary: Fairfax Asia is making a cash offer of S$0.3535 per share for 71.82% of Singapore Reinsurance's stakes, conditional on a 50% stake ownership. The offer price is a 20.6% premium over the 1-month volume-weighted average price. The acquisition presents shareholders with an opportunity to exit their investment at a premium, and Fairfax Asia aims to delist after obtaining 90% of stakes. The deal is seen as a chance for Fairfax Asia to stabilize the reinsurance business and explore business synergies with related companies across Asia.

site_title: In first talks, duelling accusations set testy tone for US-China diplomacy
summary: US and Chinese diplomats engaged in a tense, confrontational meeting in Anchorage, Alaska, marking the first face-to-face talks between the two nations under the Biden administration. The talks began with dueling accusations, with US officials claiming China violated the meeting format and China accusing the US of a condescending approach. The discussion centered on human rights, democracy, and economic sanctions, with both sides criticizing each other's policies. Despite the tension, the talks yielded a substantive conversation, and US officials acknowledged a cooling of the discussion after journalists left the room.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower after Fed tightens banking regulations
summary: US stocks ended lower on Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 closing 0.7% and 0.1% lower respectively, amid concerns over the Federal Reserve's decision to tighten banking regulations. The Fed's temporary rule allowing banks to exclude central bank deposits and Treasury bonds from capital requirements will expire at the end of the month, raising fears of a bond market sell-off and higher interest rates. Tech stocks, however, gained, with the Nasdaq Composite Index closing 0.8% higher, as investors sought cheaper tech stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow and S&P 500 closed lower on Friday while tech stocks gained, as markets weighed bond risks and a Federal Reserve decision to tighten capital requirements for banks.

site_title: Should we invest in cryptocurrency?
summary: Cryptocurrency, particularly Bitcoin, has gained significant attention in recent months due to its price surge and adoption by companies like Tesla. However, investing in cryptocurrency carries high risks, including lack of acceptability and regulatory uncertainty. Experts advise considering the six characteristics of a good form of money: durability, portability, divisibility, fungibility, acceptability, and scarcity and stability. Cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin lack acceptability, and investors should weigh the potential returns against the risks and consider building a core portfolio before investing in cryptocurrency. A cautious approach can help achieve financial goals while maintaining peace of mind.

images.alt_text: The name Bitcoin is actually misleading because we don't actually own a digital coin per se. What we own is actually a computer file that acts like a private ledger recording every transaction.

site_title: The problem with data science education
summary: Data science education has proliferated, but it may be producing generalists rather than practical experts. The field's complexity and diversity pose an academic challenge, as it's difficult to balance multiple areas without sacrificing depth. Existing degree programs often leave students needing a ramp-up period before they can impact their first employers. To produce well-rounded data scientists, academia should focus on professional application and specific roles, such as data science developer, engineer, solution architect, and storyteller. Employers should also recognize that newly minted data scientists require on-the-ground training to contextualize their skills.

site_title: Debt-hit Lim family's Universal Terminal now with Jurong Port
summary: Singapore port operator Jurong Port has acquired a 41% stake in Universal Terminal, a commercial oil storage facility on Jurong Island, for between S$400m and S$500m. The deal, completed earlier this month, makes Jurong Port the largest independent oil storage operator in Singapore. The acquisition follows a winding-up order granted by a Singapore court on Hin Leong Trading, the flagship firm of the Lim family, which collapsed due to massive debts. The sale of Universal Terminal is seen as a step in resolving the family's financial woes, but concerns remain over how the proceeds will be used and if creditors will be able to recoup some monies owed to them.

site_title: Jurong Port completes takeover of 41% stake in Universal Terminal
summary: Jurong Port has completed its acquisition of a 41% stake in Universal Terminal, a commercial storage facility on Jurong Island, making it the largest independent oil storage operator in Singapore. The deal boosts Jurong Port's position in the oil storage business, following a tie-up with German firm Oiltanking two years ago. The acquisition's price tag remains undisclosed.

site_title: Making a big push for Singapore tennis
summary: Singapore successfully hosted the ATP 250 tennis tournament, the Singapore Tennis Open, in February, with Australian Alexei Popyrin winning the event. The tournament was held with strict COVID-19 protocols in place, including daily testing and isolation for players. Despite initial plans for limited spectators, organizers eventually allowed 250 ticket-holders per day for the semi-finals and final. The event's success has sparked hope for more live sports events in Singapore, with plans to develop a new Kallang Tennis Centre and explore hosting more tennis tournaments.

site_title: US Fed to let leverage exemption expire on March 31, will review rule
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced it will not extend a temporary waiver exempting US Treasuries and central bank deposits from a key bank leverage rule, allowing these assets to be subject to the "supplementary leverage ratio" starting March 31. The move aims to prevent strains on the economy and financial stability, as bank deposits at the Fed have surged since the pandemic. The Fed will review the rule to ensure it continues to function as intended, and changes will be made to prevent any impact on bank capital requirements.

site_title: US: Stocks fall after Fed tightens banking rules
summary: US stocks fell on Friday after the Federal Reserve announced it would let an emergency rule lapse, temporarily relaxing capital reserve requirements for banks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.8%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.5%. The move was seen as unwelcome news for tech and growth stocks, which have suffered in recent weeks due to rising bond yields and inflation concerns. Bank stocks were hit hardest, with significant losses for major banks like Citigroup and Goldman Sachs.

site_title: What does it mean to support a local brand?
summary: A Singapore-based online media publisher, Sass and the City, has explained the concept of supporting local brands, highlighting the flaws of entitled "Made in Singapore" labels. The article uses a hypothetical cookie-baking side-hustle as a case study, emphasizing the importance of critically evaluating local products and services. The publisher encourages readers to look beyond surface-level labels and consider the actual value and impact of supporting local businesses.

site_title: Bigger is the enemy of better investing
summary: A study on investment sizing found that investors who bet too much on a series of favorable gambles are more likely to lose money than those who bet optimally. Research showed that betting 10-20% of one's bankroll on a risky investment generates a 95% chance of reaching a $250 cap, but only 20% of participants achieved this payout. The authors argue that concentrated holdings and over-leveraging are sub-optimal and can lead to extraordinary losses, despite ultimately being sound investments. They advocate for diversification and caution against taking too much risk.

site_title: Defensive and high yielding S-Reits
summary: Singapore's top-performing S-Reits, ARA Logos Logistics Trust, Sasseur Reit, and EC World Reit, have delivered strong returns despite the COVID-19 pandemic. These high-yielding Reits, which distribute at least 90% of taxable income, offer a unique blend of long-term capital appreciation and regular income streams. Their average distribution yield stands at 7.4%, with ARA Logos Logistics Trust and Sasseur Reit boasting an average yield of 7.4% and 7.4% respectively. These Reits have demonstrated resilience, with ARA Logos Logistics Trust and Sasseur Reit reporting positive total returns in 2020, while EC World Reit has seen a rebound in occupancy rates.

site_title: Electric cars shift into the fast lane
summary: Global electric vehicle (EV) sales are expected to rise 28% annually over the next decade, driven by decreasing battery costs, tightening emissions standards, and government incentives. EVs are becoming cost-competitive with traditional cars, with the potential to dominate the roads in the coming years. Companies that adapt quickly to structural change will be winners, while those that lag behind may struggle. The transformation of the global auto industry will have broader economic implications, including reduced peak oil consumption, increased demand for raw materials, and changes in industries such as insurance and media.

site_title: Didi accelerates IPO plans, targeting valuation above US$62b
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology Co. is accelerating plans for an initial public offering (IPO) targeting a valuation above $62 billion, as the company capitalizes on a post-pandemic turnaround. The IPO could raise around $9 billion, with the company hoping to tap into the enthusiasm for China's tech debuts. Didi's plans come after its core business began making small profits, with daily rides and revenue surpassing pre-pandemic levels. The company aims to expand into online commerce, Europe, and adjacent areas like autonomous driving and electric vehicles.

site_title: Japan's malls and restaurants brace for an Olympics without overseas spectators
summary: Tokyo is set to host the Olympics without overseas spectators, dealing a significant blow to Japan's service sector. The expected decision, following Tokyo 2020's plan to block foreigners, will impact shopping malls and restaurants that were built to serve foreign visitors. The COVID-19 pandemic has already caused losses, and the Olympics' cancellation of overseas spectators will likely exacerbate these losses, with developers facing financial struggles and some businesses, like a vegan restaurant in Shibuya, relying on foreign tourists to survive.

images.alt_text: Yuta Namekawa, manager of vegan izakaya restaurant Masaka, in the kitchen of the empty restaurant during dinner hour in Tokyo on March 2.

site_title: Understanding heart attacks
summary: A recent update to the Fourth Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction (heart attack) broadens the understanding of what causes heart attacks. Heart attacks can now be categorized into five types, including Type 1, where blood clot occlusion occurs, and Type 2, where an imbalance between oxygen supply and demand occurs due to causes other than severe narrowing of heart arteries. This means heart attacks can occur in the absence of risk factors for heart disease, such as smoking or high blood pressure. Understanding these new categories can help doctors diagnose and prevent heart attacks more effectively.

site_title: Hong Kong rattles bankers with strict Covid-19 quarantine
summary: Hong Kong's strict coronavirus quarantine measures are causing anxiety within the city's financial sector, with several firms shutting offices and employees and their children being stuck in Spartan government quarantine facilities. The quarantine rules, which include up to two-week stays in centralized facilities for close contacts, are being scrutinized by the banking community, with some executives warning that they may consider shifting traders to other financial hubs if the rules persist. Industry groups are calling for a clear roadmap for Covid-19 policies and improved communication from the government.

site_title: North Korea to sever ties with Malaysia over extradition of citizen to US
summary: North Korea has announced it will sever diplomatic ties with Malaysia after the country extradited a North Korean citizen, Mun Chol Myong, to the US to face money-laundering charges. Malaysia denied the move was unwarranted, stating it was carried out according to law. North Korea warned the US that it will "pay a price" for the extradition, while Malaysia has closed its embassy in Pyongyang and ordered its diplomats to leave Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Which lockdown habits could last a lifetime?
summary: Investors must navigate the lasting impacts of the pandemic on consumer behavior, as lifestyle changes are permanent and new trends will emerge. The COVID-19 vaccine's announcement sparked a market rally, but there will be no clean break from the pandemic, with ongoing variants and logistical issues. Consumer spending patterns will be erratic, with pent-up demand for experiences when restrictions ease, and high savings rates may crowd out spending in other areas. Identifying companies with lasting positive impacts on profitability and returns is crucial, such as those in e-commerce and digitalization. A clear vision of post-pandemic consumption patterns is necessary to build positive growth gaps.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with big losses
summary: Hong Kong shares ended the week with a 1.41% loss, shedding 414.78 points to 28,990.94. Global markets retreated due to worries about inflation caused by a strong economic recovery. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index lost 1.69% and the Shenzhen Composite Index sank 1.90%.

site_title: US home-selling platform Offerpad to go public in US$3b SPAC deal
summary: US home-selling platform Offerpad is going public through a US$3 billion SPAC deal with Supernova Partners Acquisition Company. The deal values Offerpad at US$3 billion, with US$650 million in proceeds for the company. Offerpad, which expects revenue of US$1.4 billion in 2021, plans to use the capital to expand its presence and flip homes in a higher price range. The company will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker "OPAD" after the deal closes, with a top-end price range of US$400,000 to US$1 million.

site_title: Taiwan says China bolstering ability to attack, blockade island
summary: China is bolstering its military capabilities to attack and blockade Taiwan, according to the island's defense ministry. China has deployed long-range missiles, building copies of Taiwanese facilities, and conducting landing drills to simulate an invasion. The ministry warned that China's "grey zone" warfare tactics aim to wear Taiwan down, undermine its military, and spread "fake news" to erode faith in its government. Taiwan's military modernization efforts are dwarfed by China's, but President Tsai Ing-wen vows to defend democracy and sovereignty.

site_title: Blackstone closes inaugural growth equity fund at US$4.5b
summary: Blackstone closed its inaugural growth equity fund, Blackstone Growth (BXG), at $4.5 billion, exceeding its target. The fund received capital commitments from various investors, including family offices, entrepreneurs, and institutional investors. BXG's investments include Bumble and Oatly, backed by prominent figures such as Oprah Winfrey and Jay-Z. The successful fundraising marks a significant milestone for Blackstone, solidifying its position as the world's largest manager of alternative assets.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Jurong Port completed a takeover of a 41% stake in Universal Terminal, significantly bolstering its presence in the oil storage business. This acquisition creates strategic depth and critical mass for the company in oil handling. The deal marks a notable move for Jurong Port, elevating its position in the oil storage industry.

site_title: Metakovan, owner of world's dearest NFT, sells tokens of a token out of Singapore
summary: Tan Teck Long, former DBS veteran, is named OCBC's incoming CEO. In unrelated news, a Singaporean investor, Metakovan, sells B.20 tokens, which represent fractions of high-value art pieces and virtual real estate, to 5,300 individuals. This sale is part of a larger trend in the sale of non-fungible tokens (NFTs). The sale is not directly related to the news about Tan Teck Long's appointment or the economic trends mentioned in the other articles.

site_title: Record defaults hit weak Chinese firms as liquidity tightens
summary: Record defaults in China's corporate sector are rising, with developers accounting for a fifth of the US$10 billion worth of delinquencies. The country's liquidity is tightening, affecting property firms, local government financing vehicles, and energy producers. A state-owned coal company's default in the north-east has led to refinancing struggles for coal companies. This raises pressure on Chinese policymakers as the country's GDP growth is set to slow. The situation highlights the vulnerability of weak Chinese firms to credit-market stress.

images.alt_text: It's becoming clearer which parts of China's corporate sector are most at risk of credit-market stress as Beijing pulls back liquidity: property firms, local government financing vehicles and energy producers.

site_title: DBS Private Bank to expand share of sustainable investments in client portfolios
summary: DBS Private Bank aims to increase sustainable investments in client portfolios to over 50% by 2023, driven by expanding its sustainable product suite, portfolio-weighted ESG rating methodology, and client education efforts. The bank has a current share of 41% and will widen access to its social enterprise ecosystem. DBS defines sustainable investments as those rated BBB and above, and has integrated MSCI ESG ratings into its product suite, making it a leader in ESG advocacy in Asia.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways eyes Q3 listing with market cap of US$2.73b
summary: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans to list its shares on a local stock exchange in Q3, aiming to raise $2.73 billion and increase domestic market share to 30% by year-end. The airline, owned by FLC Group, aims to expand its fleet to 40 aircraft by year-end and resume international flights once the government lifts the coronavirus suspension. Bamboo Airways has asked the government to arrange a loan of $5 trillion dong with low or zero interest rates to compete with regional rivals. The listing is expected to raise its market capitalization and support its growth plans.

images.alt_text: Bamboo Airways also expects to receive supportive policies from the government to help it compete with regional rivals.

site_title: PSA International posts 6.2% lower net profit for 2020
summary: PSA International reported a 6.2% decline in year-on-year net profit to S$1.168 billion in 2020, despite a 2.5% increase in revenue to S$4.179 billion. The decline was attributed to lower other income and higher operating expenses. The company handled 86.6 million TEUs, with throughput at Singapore terminals down 0.9% and those outside Singapore up 3.7%. PSA's balance sheet remains strong, with a gross debt equity ratio of 0.58 times at the end of 2020.

site_title: Greek archaeologists unearth bronze bull idol in ancient Olympia
summary: Greek archaeologists have unearthed a 2,500-year-old bronze bull idol at the ancient Olympia site, near the temple of Zeus, the birthplace of the Olympic Games. The idol, intact and partially buried due to heavy rainfall, is believed to be one of thousands of gifts offered to Zeus between 1050-700 BC. Bulls and horses played significant roles in ancient Greek culture, and the discovery sheds light on the importance of these animals in ancient Greek worship. The statuette has been transferred to a laboratory for conservation.

site_title: Didi accelerates IPO plans as business rebounds
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing Technology is accelerating its initial public offering (IPO) plans to as early as next quarter, targeting a valuation above $62 billion. The company's business has rebounded post-pandemic, with daily rides and revenue surpassing pre-pandemic levels and reaching record highs. Didi plans to raise around $9 billion in its IPO, which would be one of the largest tech debuts globally in 2021. The company is looking to expand into online commerce and Europe, where it will compete with Uber Technologies.

site_title: Native flavours
summary: Native, a Singaporean bar, has been a pioneer in sustainable cocktail-making since its inception in 2016. The bar forages for ingredients, has its own garden, and partners with local farms to create unique cocktails. Its menu features drinks like Chasing the Dragon, which incorporates local Thai basil, calamansi, and dragonfruit kombucha. The bar also showcases its pandan and ginger flowers from Green Circle Eco-Farm in its Garden City cocktail, created for the Singapore Cocktail Festival. Native's focus on local and sustainable ingredients reflects its commitment to community and environmental values.

site_title: Malaysian prince eyes stake in Manchester United
summary: Malaysian Prince Tunku Ismail Sultan Ibrahim has expressed interest in investing in English Premier League club Manchester United, stating he is "open to any shares" and would consider a 3-5% stake. This follows speculation of a potential takeover bid for Spanish club Valencia, which he also expressed interest in. The 36-year-old prince, who already owns Malaysia's Johor Darul Ta'zim football club, believes Manchester United's commercial value will increase over time and sees the club as a sustainable investment opportunity.

site_title: Myanmar security forces kill nine as Indonesia calls for end to violence
summary: Myanmar security forces killed nine people on Friday in a confrontation with protesters in the central town of Aungban, as Indonesia urged an end to the violence and the restoration of democracy. The total number of killed protesters has risen to at least 233, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners activist group. Indonesian President Joko Widodo called for democracy to be restored and for the violence to stop, while Western countries and Asian neighbours have condemned the coup and called for an end to the violence and the release of detained leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower on inflation fears
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Friday due to fears of high inflation, which could hinder economic recovery from the pandemic. London's FTSE 100 index fell 1.2% to 6,698.58 points, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices lost 0.6% and 0.7% respectively. This follows sharp losses in Asia and overnight on Wall Street.

site_title: Sen Yue to oppose the judicial management applications by DBS
summary: Sen Yue will contest judicial management applications by creditor DBS at hearings in April and May. The waste-management firm opposes the applications, which were filed by DBS due to SMC Industrial's outstanding debt of around S$5.9 million and US$9 million. Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corp is participating as a creditor, but its stance is unclear. The company's shares traded at 2.2 Singapore cents in April last year, after requesting a trading halt.

site_title: Lian Beng Group unit bags S$131m contract to build flats in Sembawang
summary: Lian Beng Group, a subsidiary of United Tec Construction, secured an S$131 million contract to develop a 448-unit residential project in Sembawang. The project, featuring communal facilities, is expected to positively impact the group's financials, particularly its net tangible assets and earnings per share. This deal adds to the company's S$1.6 billion order book, providing a sustainable flow of activity through FY2025.

site_title: US appeals WTO decision in South Korea trade dispute
summary: The US has appealed a World Trade Organization (WTO) decision to revise duties imposed on South Korea under President Barack Obama. The WTO panel found the US Department of Commerce failed to consider all information when calculating dumping or subsidies. The tariffs on steel and power transformers were deemed inconsistent with WTO rules. The appeal, along with 18 other cases, has pushed the case into legal limbo due to the WTO's lack of a functioning appellate body. The US decision may indicate President Joe Biden's approach to the WTO's dispute settlement system.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 15 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported, bringing the total to 60,167. All cases were individuals who had been placed on stay-home notices or isolated upon arrival. There were no community cases or cases from migrant workers' dormitories.

site_title: Foxconn in talks with Vietnam's Vinfast on electric car partnership: sources
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn is in talks with Vietnam's VinFast about a potential partnership in electric vehicles. Foxconn has proposed acquiring VinFast's EV production lines, but VinFast prefers a partnership to maintain its eco-friendly brand and retain its EV business. This partnership would follow deals with Fiat Chrysler and EV startups, and would help Foxconn become a major provider of parts and services in the global EV market.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's Foxconn is in early stage talks with Vietnamese carmaker VinFast about partnering in electric vehicles (EVs), two sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mapletree Logistics Trust, GL, Jardine Strategic, Yanlord, Matex
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust completed the acquisition of five South Korean logistics properties for S$334.8 million. GL Limited, a hotel operator, will exercise its right of compulsory acquisition after crossing the 90% acceptance mark. The offer remains open until April 1.

site_title: Investors pour record money into equities even as bond yields rise: BofA
summary: Investors poured a record $68.3 billion into US equity funds in the week to March 17, despite rising bond yields and a decline in the Nasdaq index. This surge in risk appetite is attributed to ultra-easy monetary policy. However, Bank of America (BofA) warned of tightening global financial conditions, citing eight interest rate hikes versus five cuts so far this year.

site_title: Asian markets tumble amid rising yields; STI down 0.1 %
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, mirroring US losses, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.1% to 3,134.54. The decline was driven by rising treasury yields, which affected the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite and the S&P 500, which fell 1.5% and 3% respectively. The STI fared better than major regional indices, indicating a mixed performance in the Asian market.

site_title: UK borrows lower-than-expected £19.1b in Feb
summary: The UK government borrowed £19.1 billion in February, lower than the forecast £21 billion, and took the budget deficit to almost £279 billion for the first 11 months of the financial year. This puts the government on track to borrow slightly below the expected £350 billion for the year, which would be the highest borrowing relative to the economy since World War II. The lower-than-expected borrowing suggests a potential easing of economic pressure.

site_title: Thailand to reduce quarantine for visitors to revive tourism
summary: Thailand is set to shorten the mandatory quarantine period for foreign travelers from two weeks to 10 days starting April 1, in an effort to revive its tourism industry. The move aims to make the country more attractive to millions of foreign tourists, but the decision has been delayed on recognizing vaccine certificates for global mobility. The government also plans to consider a seven-day quarantine for vaccinated tourists, with a potential full reopening of the tourism industry from October 1.

site_title: Greater focus on innovation crucial for Singapore's future: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of innovation for Singapore's future, citing the city-state's lack of natural resources. The 10th edition of the Lee Kuan Yew Global Business Plan Competition focused on sustainable urban innovations and solutions. The competition drew a record 850 entries from 650 universities worldwide, with finalists raising over US$40 million to build their startups. Heng noted that universities and research institutions are crucial for innovation, and Singapore will put an even greater focus on innovation and partnership in its next phase of development.

site_title: UBS, Credit Suisse have improved emergency planning: Swiss bank watchdog
summary: Swiss financial markets watchdog FINMA has stated that UBS and Credit Suisse have strengthened their emergency plans to stabilize themselves in a financial crisis. Although UBS's plan is still subject to certain conditions, FINMA considers all domestic systemically important banks in Switzerland to have credible resolution strategies. This marks the first time all domestic banks have met this standard, with Post Finance, Raiffeisen, and Zuercher Kantonalbank now also having effective plans.

site_title: Seoul: Shares finish lower on rising US yields
summary: South Korean shares ended lower on Friday, posting their first weekly loss in three weeks, due to a spike in US bond yields and Sino-US tensions. The Kospi closed down 26.48 points, or 0.86%, at 3,039.53, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading the decline. Battery maker LG Chem also fell 3.60%. The benchmark index posted a weekly decline of 0.49%, reversing a 0.93% gain the previous week.

site_title: British Airways considers selling its headquarters after homeworking switch
summary: British Airways is considering selling its £200 million headquarters building due to the shift to homeworking during the pandemic, which may reduce the airline's need for office space. The airline has already cut costs, including shedding 10,000 employees, and is exploring ways to raise cash. The potential sale could boost British Airways' finances, which have been impacted by the pandemic. The airline's future policy will likely involve a flexible mix of home and office working. The decision comes as other major companies, such as Lloyds and HSBC, are also reevaluating their office footprints.

site_title: Bank of Japan holds negative rates, tweaks easing policy
summary: The Bank of Japan maintained its negative interest rate and tweaked its monetary easing policy to boost inflation and support the pandemic-hit economy. The adjustments include expanding the fluctuation in 10-year bond rates and increasing flexibility in stock purchases. The bank also dropped its target for intervention in the Tokyo stock market, which has recovered strongly since the pandemic. The tweaks are seen as a potential forerunner to further policy changes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.80 points to 1,626.19. Losers outnumbered gainers 787 to 347, and volume reached 9.041 billion lots worth RM5.795 billion.

site_title: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways sees US$2.7b market cap at listing
summary: Vietnam's Bamboo Airways plans to list 105 million shares on either Ho Chi Minh City or Hanoi Stock Exchange, aiming for a market capitalization of $2.7 billion. The airline expects a June or July easing of the government's pandemic halt on international flights and plans to list shares at 60,000 dong ($3.48) per share. Bamboo Airways aims to expand its fleet to 40 aircraft and increase its market share to 30% this year, driven by a "boom" in the aviation industry expected due to global vaccines.

site_title: Asia: Stocks spooked by spike in yields, oil sell-off
summary: Asian stocks eased on Friday as a spike in global bond yields and a sell-off in oil prices soured sentiment towards tech stocks. Brent crude futures fell 38 cents to $62.90 a barrel, wiping out four weeks of gains. The retreat may mark the end of a five-month bull run and sent Asian-Pacific shares down 0.5% and US stocks mixed, with Nasdaq futures up 0.1% and S&P 500 futures up 0.2%. The Bank of Japan is expected to loosen its control of bond yields, potentially boosting markets.

site_title: Thai central bank to regulate stablecoins
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, plans to issue regulations on asset-backed stablecoins by the end of this year. The bank will regulate foreign currency-backed, asset-backed, and algorithmic stablecoins that are not illegal. This move comes after a warning against the use of a new baht-denominated stablecoin created abroad. The Bank of Thailand is receiving opinions from market regulators and participants before announcing the regulations.

images.alt_text: Thailand's central bank expects to issue regulations on asset-backed stablecoins this year, an assistant governor said on Friday, after warning against use of a new baht-denominated stablecoin that was created abroad.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei dips on BOJ's ETF purchase plan
summary: Japan's benchmark Nikkei index fell 1.41% to 29,792.05, while the Topix hit a 30-year high at 2,012.21. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) announced it will only buy Topix-linked ETFs, with a maximum purchase of 12 trillion yen (S$148.12 billion). The BOJ also widened its trading band for the 10-year bond yield target. The Nikkei's decline accelerated after the announcement, while the Topix rose 0.18%.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH raises SATS target price as airline market recovers
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price for SATS to S$4.27 from S$4.07, citing a recovery in the airline market due to border reopenings and swift market pricing in. Analyst K Ajith notes SATS is trading 5% below pre-Covid-19 levels, implying a swift recovery. Despite lowering FY2022 earnings estimates, Ajith raised FY2023 net profit estimates by 19% due to slower wage growth and stronger associate earnings.

site_title: Robinhood's Vlad Tenev talks crypto growth in 'fireside chat'
summary: Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev discussed the company's plans for crypto growth and recovery from the GameStop trading frenzy in a "fireside chat" video. Tenev stated that Robinhood is working to expand its crypto trading platform, including the introduction of a wallet feature, and hiring a large team for its crypto operation. The company aims to scale its service and improve its cost-effectiveness, which he believes is a key selling point over competitors like Coinbase. Tenev also acknowledged that the company may still take a few more months to recover from the reputational damage caused by the recent events.

site_title: With Clubhouse banned, China investors are hunting for copycats
summary: China's venture capital firms are backing untested Clubhouse-like apps amid the ban on the original app. Tencent, Alibaba, and Xiaomi are testing audio-only chats on their platforms, seeking the next big hit. Big-name investors are pouring in millions, with some apps attracting over 10,000 daily active users. However, the Chinese startup industry faces harsh realities, with investors favoring proven business models from Silicon Valley over untested innovations. To succeed, wannabes must adapt and innovate, and navigate the risk of Beijing's scrutiny and potential crackdowns.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on firmer bond yields, set to post weekly loss
summary: South Korean stocks fell on Friday, on track for their first weekly loss in three, due to a spike in global bond yields and Sino-US tensions. The Kospi index dropped 0.9% to 3,038.93, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.1% and 2.5%, respectively. The benchmark US 10-year yield rose to 1.754%, while the won weakened against the US dollar. Foreigners were net sellers of 259 billion won worth of shares, and the US and China exchanged sharp rebukes during their first high-level talks.

site_title: Asean tech stocks down but not out: DBS
summary: Asean technology stocks have underperformed this year, with the FTSE ST Technology Index up only 0.1%, compared to the FTSE ST Health Care Index's 28.6% gain. Despite this, DBS Group Research believes technology stocks have "ample room" to run, driven by structural trends such as 5G adoption, telecommuting, and electric vehicles. The analysts point to a low-interest-rate environment and the early stages of economic recovery as favorable factors, with target prices set for several tech stocks, including Venture Corp and Nanofilm Technologies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday due to profit-taking, influenced by falls on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.9% to 29,935.89, while the Topix index fell 0.7% to 1,994.67. The focus shifted to the Bank of Japan's policy decision later in the day.

site_title: Walmart opens marketplace to non-US vendors in strategy shift
summary: Walmart has opened its US marketplace to non-US vendors, allowing foreign sellers to list products on its website without needing a US address or business tax identification. The move aims to close the e-commerce gap with Amazon and tap into China's vast network of manufacturers.
