The UK economy contracted by 10% last year, but is now rolling out vaccines faster than other European countries, with the government aiming to fully lift social-distancing restrictions by late June.

site_title: Olam cooks up a storm with major reboot
summary: Olam International, a Singapore-based agri-food giant, is undergoing a major restructuring by spinning off two of its largest businesses into separate entities, Olam Food Ingredients (OFI) and Olam Global Agri (OGA). The move, led by CEO Sunny Verghese, aims to create world-class businesses that will be true market leaders, with significant growth potential and sustained long-term value creation. OFI will focus on developed markets, while OGA will concentrate on high-growth emerging markets. The spin-off is expected to raise growth capital and unlock value for investors, with a potential IPO planned for early next year.

site_title: Federal Reserve standing firm on inflation fears
summary: The US Federal Reserve is standing firm on keeping interest rates low, despite concerns about inflation, which has been rising due to the economic recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has signaled that the Fed will accept higher inflation to achieve full employment, and analysts expect the Fed to maintain its dovish stance during its policy meeting. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has also downplayed inflation fears, stating that the risk is small and the Fed has tools to address it.

site_title: Dollar rises with Treasury yields as economic prospects improve
summary: The US dollar rose on Friday due to a surge in Treasury yields as investors grew concerned about potential inflation from emerging economies. As lockdowns end and vaccination campaigns progress, market participants are worried about a jump in inflation. This concern led to a rise in the dollar.

site_title: UN envoy calls for united action after deadly day in Myanmar
summary: The United Nations envoy for Myanmar strongly condemned the bloodshed after at least 18 protesters were killed, marking one of the deadliest days since the February 1 coup. The envoy, Christine Schraner Burgener, called for united international action to support the people of Myanmar and their democratic aspirations. The military, defying international calls for restraint, has imposed martial law in two Yangon townships, leading to widespread violence and killings. Over 80 people have been killed in mass protests since the coup, with the toll expected to rise dramatically.

site_title: Bloom boom: Malaysians get passionate about potted plants
summary: In Malaysia, a surge in houseplant collecting has become a popular pastime during the COVID-19 pandemic, with collectors seeking out rare and intricately patterned plants like elephant ears and flamingo flowers. Prices for these plants have skyrocketed, with some selling for up to RM6,000 each, as people use them as a distraction from lockdowns. The trend is expected to continue even as authorities lift restrictions, with nurseries reporting a significant increase in demand for these plants.

site_title: Myanmar junta imposes martial law in part of Yangon amid clashes
summary: Myanmar's junta imposed full martial law in parts of Yangon amid clashes between soldiers and protesters. The declaration follows clashes between soldiers and protesters, with at least 88 deaths reported since the coup on Feb 1. The martial law order applies to the Hlaing Thar Yar and Shwe Pyi Thar townships, where Chinese-owned factories were burnt during clashes. The Chinese embassy urged authorities to protect its investments and citizens, while international experts warn of a major military crackdown and call for immediate international intervention.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange reported a rollercoaster week in the Capesize 5TC market, with prices opening at $14,794 and reaching $17,889 before declining to $16,741 by the weekend. This week's activity was high on the west Australia and Brazil to China routes.

site_title: BTS lose at Grammys, as Beyonce, Megan Thee Stallion among early winners
summary: BTS lost the Grammy award for Best Pop Duo/Group Performance to Lady Gaga and Ariana Grande for their single "Rain on Me." The K-Pop band was hoping to be the first K-Pop act to win a Grammy, but ultimately fell short. Other notable winners include Megan Thee Stallion, who won for her rap performance of "Savage," and Billie Eilish, who won for her theme song to the James Bond film "No Time to Die."

site_title: Australia: Shares fall as losses in mining, tech stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.36% to 6,742.2, hurt by losses in mining and technology stocks. Mining stocks declined 1.3% due to steep falls in iron ore prices, while tech stocks fell 1.6% as Afterpay and Bravura Solutions dropped 4.4% and 4.1% respectively. Gold stocks rose 1% after Evolution Mining's acquisition of Battle North Gold Corp. Energy stocks gained, while the NZ benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.9%.

images.alt_text: Australian shares fell in early trade on Monday, hurt by losses among mining and technology stocks, while investors looked to the release of minutes from the central bank's monetary policy meeting later this week.

site_title: Post-Brexit Britain's global ambitions start with investment at home, says PM
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has stated that the country's global ambitions must start with strengthening the union between its home nations, England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The government will publish a comprehensive review of foreign policy, defense, security, and aid spending, aiming to drive investment back into communities and create a robust economy. The review will prioritize the creation of an open international order with free trade, and Johnson's office has announced plans to move operations to Scotland, strengthening Britain's core industrial base and creating jobs.

site_title: Merkel's party suffers heavy losses in German state polls
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservative party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU), suffered heavy losses in two regional elections, losing ground to the left-leaning Green party. The CDU's worst-ever score was reported in the southwestern states of Baden-Wuerttemberg and Rhineland-Palatinate, with the Greens emerging as the largest party in both regions. The results are seen as a snapshot of the national mood ahead of a general election on September 26, and could impact Merkel's legacy and the party's chances of staying in government.

site_title: Investors need to stay alert to what SPACs can offer
summary: A new wave of blank-cheque companies, known as SPACs, has raised over US$70 billion in the US this year, prompting investors to ask why invest and who stands to gain. SPACs involve a shell company listed at US$10, with sponsors finding a business to merge with within two years. Early investors receive warrants that can be exercised at a certain price, but there's significant risk due to time pressure and share dilution. Investors must also consider alignment with the investment, potential for fraud, and protection from redemption clauses.

site_title: Top Global's Sukmawati raises her stake
summary: Top Global executive director and controlling shareholder Sukmawati Widjaja increased her stake in the company by acquiring 26,023,193 shares for S$10,149,045, bringing her total interest to 85.50% from 77.40%. This comes after Top Global reported its FY20 operating performance, which was broadly in line with guidance, but resulted in a net loss of S$16.0 million due to lower gross profit margins.

site_title: AstraZeneca finds no evidence of increased blood clot risk from vaccine
summary: AstraZeneca has released a review of safety data from its Covid-19 vaccine, finding no evidence of an increased risk of blood clots. The review covered over 17 million people vaccinated in the UK and EU, after some countries suspended the vaccine due to clotting issues. The European Medicines Agency and World Health Organisation have stated that there is no indication that the events were caused by the vaccination. The company has reported 15 cases of deep vein thrombosis and 22 cases of pulmonary embolism, but additional testing has shown no cause for concern.

site_title: US drillers line up to unlock Colombian copper riches
summary: Colombia plans to develop its copper deposits ahead of a forecast surge in demand for metals used in rechargeable batteries. Authorities will award five copper exploration blocks by the end of June, with US and Canadian juniors leading the interest. The country aims to reduce its dependence on oil and coal, with a focus on renewable energy and electric vehicles. Colombia is part of a global transition towards cleaner energy, with a 7,000-megawatt pipeline of solar, wind, and bioenergy projects, and plans to sell around 10,000 hybrid and electric vehicles this year.

site_title: It's not possible for many nations, including Singapore, to pick between US and China: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country cannot choose between the US and China due to extensive ties with both superpowers. He emphasized that competition and tension between the two are inevitable in the Asia-Pacific region, but coexistence is necessary. Lee noted that both the US and China have significant vitality and creativity, making a military conflict unlikely. He urged the US and China to work together, particularly in multilateralism and international trade, and for China to be a country where its prosperity is welcomed by other nations.

site_title: Singapore banks likely to ease rather than lift dividend caps fully
summary: Singapore banks are unlikely to fully lift their 60% dividend cap, despite earnings recovery, due to tail risks from regional loan moratoriums, border closures, and vaccine delivery logistics. Analysts expect a partial relaxation of the cap, rather than a full lift, as these risks persist.

site_title: Museums, coins to mark Greek revolution bicentenary
summary: Athens is hosting a virtual display of rare items from the 1821 Greek revolution, including Lord Byron's belongings and a letter from Marquis de Lafayette. A new museum dedicated to Philhellenic foreign volunteers will open in April, featuring contemporary paintings and personal items. Limited-edition coins and commemorative two-euro coins are also being released to mark the bicentenary. Due to the pandemic, events have been scaled back, and French President Emmanuel Macron, Prince Charles, and Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin's attendance is uncertain.

site_title: NZD-USD likely to continue rebound
summary: The NZDUSD currency pair is likely to continue its upward trend, following a bullish reversal in March 2020. An ascending wedge pattern has formed, with the pair rebounding from the lower band and coinciding with a dynamic support line. The stochastic oscillator is expected to cross above the oversold region, validating the upward trend. Confirmation of the trend will come if the MACD indicator crosses above the signal line and both are sustained above zero. The first resistance line is expected to be reached at 0.7464, with further price targets at the dynamic resistance line at the top band of the rising wedge.

site_title: VW bets on US$30b tech reboot to catch Tesla
summary: Volkswagen is investing over $30 billion in its technology reboot to catch up with Tesla, a goal that requires a significant shift in its culture and business model. The company aims to boost its in-house software development to 60% from 10%, with a new coding school and partnerships with Amazon and Microsoft. However, internal rivalries and teething problems have hindered progress, and traditional rivals Toyota and Mercedes-Benz are also adapting to the digital age. VW's efforts are critical to its survival, but replicating the takeover of the mobile-phone industry won't be easy, and the company faces significant challenges in catching up with tech giants like Tesla.

site_title: ECB's revved-up QE perplexes traders as volatility strikes back
summary: The European Central Bank's (ECB) QE program has sparked uncertainty among traders as volatility struck back in the bond markets. Despite announcing a faster pace of bond-buying to curb rising yields, the ECB made no changes to the overall program size and duration. Many policymakers privately expressed doubts about expanding the program, fueling concerns about the bank's resolve to stem rising borrowing costs. The move has left traders questioning the ECB's ability to control long-term interest rates.

images.alt_text: The answer to the question of how fast the ECB is stepping up won't show up on data due on Monday, though traders will get a sense of the scale of the response in the next set of reports.

site_title: Energy firms seize on carbon tech to build new businesses
summary: Major energy companies are turning their carbon sequestration technologies into business ventures, aiming to reduce greenhouse gas emissions intensity and move closer to Paris Agreement climate change targets. Companies like Kinder Morgan, Baker Hughes, Exxon Mobil, Occidental Petroleum, and Total SE are forming new units, acquiring assets, and investing in low-carbon projects, including carbon capture, hydrogen production, and renewable gas. These efforts could help big emitters balance customer demands for oil and gas while fitting into a lower-carbon energy world, necessary to limit planetary warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius.

site_title: EM outflows could be disruptive for markets: IIF
summary: The Institute of International Finance warns that large capital outflows from emerging markets (EMs) could be disruptive unless the US Federal Reserve acts to support the US bond market. This follows a surge in US bond yields, which have led to outflows of $52.5 billion in January and $31.2 billion in February. The US dollar's strength, fueled by rising interest rates, poses a risk to EM currencies, and foreign investors have cut positions in the Chinese yuan. The IIF fears that EM debt, totaling $77.7 trillion, could be negatively impacted by these outflows.

site_title: The specs of SPACs
summary: A special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) is a shell company formed to raise funds for a private company. Typically, the SPAC raises funds through an initial public offering (IPO) and then merges with a private company, taking that company public. The process can be used for companies looking to go public but don't meet traditional IPO requirements. SPACs have gained popularity in recent years, with notable examples including Grab's US$40 billion SPAC talks. This financing method can provide companies with access to public capital and help them compete with traditional IPOs.

site_title: Apollo bets a new Roaring '20s will revive Vegas after vaccines
summary: Apollo Global Management Inc. has invested $6.25 billion to purchase the Venetian Las Vegas, Palazzo, and Sands Expo Convention Center from Las Vegas Sands Corp. despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on the Las Vegas resort industry. The purchase aims to revive the city's economy and potentially capitalize on a new wave of visitors in the 2020s, following the end of the pandemic. The deal is seen as a surprise by industry observers, who expect the Las Vegas resort industry to take time to recover.

site_title: Jardine Matheson's offer for Jardine Strategic has room to be improved
summary: Jardine Matheson's proposed acquisition of Jardine Strategic has raised concerns among minority investors and observers due to the lowball offer price of US$33 per share, representing a 43% discount to the company's net asset value. The deal has been criticized for lack of independent directors and the potential for a "walkover" that could save the acquirer US$2 billion. Minority investors have been left dissatisfied, with some considering legal action to seek a fairer price.

site_title: British Airways calling for unrestricted travel for those vaccinated
summary: British Airways CEO Sean Doyle is calling for the UK government to allow vaccinated individuals to travel without restriction and non-vaccinated individuals with a negative COVID-19 test to travel freely. Doyle wants the government to support health apps that verify vaccination status and negative test results to facilitate travel. He expects the government to announce plans for non-essential travel on April 12, with holidays potentially resuming on May 17. Doyle is optimistic about BA's recovery this summer, but notes that the recovery depends on government decisions.

site_title: Caution to reign amid Singapore-Australia air travel bubble talks: analysts
summary: Singapore and Australia are discussing an air travel bubble, with analysts warning both countries to proceed with caution. The move comes after Singapore's highly anticipated travel bubble with Hong Kong was suspended last year due to a spike in Covid-19 cases. The Singapore Ministry of Foreign Affairs has confirmed discussions with Australia, but no further details have been released. Analysts expect a cautious approach to avoid similar setbacks as with the Hong Kong travel bubble.

site_title: Masters of equities universe unfazed by spike in bond yields
summary: Investors in the equities universe are unfazed by the recent spike in bond yields, with most respondents from a Bloomberg News survey saying equities can continue to rally despite the rise in government bond yields. Fund managers are focusing on economic and profit recovery, and believe central banks' accommodative policies will keep yields from rising too high. The US stock market has seen a dip, but investors are optimistic about other international equities, such as Europe and emerging markets, which may benefit from the shift.

site_title: AMC theatres to start reopening in Los Angeles on Monday
summary: AMC Entertainment Holdings, the world's largest cinema operator, will start reopening its Los Angeles locations on Monday, with two theatres in Burbank and Century City initially opening at 25% capacity. This follows local authorities' clearance to resume operations after a year-long closure due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company plans to expand to the rest of its Los Angeles area and California theatres starting on March 19.

site_title: Johor to vaccinate Malaysians who work in Singapore
summary: Malaysia plans to vaccinate at least 100,000 Malaysians working in Singapore as part of phase two of the National Covid-19 Immunisation Programme. The goal is to reopen Malaysia's border with Singapore by May or June. The state government, led by Johor Menteri Besar Hasni Mohammad, will work with the Science, Technology and Innovation Ministry to register workers and create a system for vaccinations. This move aims to facilitate cross-border travel, including daily commuting, under the Daily Commuting Arrangement (DCA) and the Reciprocal Green Lane (RGL).

site_title: Why CDL shareholders should be heartened by Sincere's recent complaints
summary: CDL's China-based investment arm Sincere Property Group has made public complaints against the Singaporean developer, accusing it of hindering decision-making and affecting its ability to raise funds. However, CDL maintains it has a joint controlling stake in Sincere and has clarified that it only has four seats on the eight-member board. The exchange highlights CDL's control over Sincere, which may be frustrating for the China-based company. Despite this, CDL appears to have insulated itself from further financial trouble at Sincere, and investors may see the situation as a sign of transparency and good governance.

site_title: Bitcoin hits record high of US$60,000
summary: Bitcoin reached a record high of US$60,000, surpassing its previous record of US$58,000. The cryptocurrency's value has risen sharply this year, driven by increased acceptance as a form of payment and companies' use of it to raise funding. Tesla's US$1.5 billion Bitcoin bet and Goldman Sachs' restart of its cryptocurrency trading desk have contributed to the surge. As the market continues to grow, Goldman Sachs is exploring ways to serve cryptocurrency clients while adhering to regulations.

site_title: Hospitality Reits waiting to take off
summary: Singapore-listed hospitality trusts, including Ascott Residence Trust, CDL Hospitality Trusts, and Frasers Hospitality Trust, are poised for a gradual recovery in the tourism industry. The International Air Transport Association predicts personal and leisure travel to return from the second half of 2021, driven by border reopenings. These trusts have an average price-to-book ratio of 0.8 time and an average distribution yield of 4.6%, indicating potential investment opportunities.

site_title: Britain's toniest shopping malls left reeling
summary: Britain's toniest shopping malls are reeling from the pandemic, with Hammerson Plc slashing the value of its properties by nearly £2 billion (S$3.7 billion) last year due to a 41% collapse in rent. The company, once a pillar of the UK's real estate sector, reported its worst loss in history, a £1.7 billion loss. The pandemic has accelerated the decline of an already crisis-ridden industry, with UK retailers facing a high risk of closure. Investors are not betting on a near-term recovery, with Hammerson's shares trading at a 60% discount to book value.

site_title: Thai resort island plans to open to vaccinated tourists in Oct
summary: Thai resort island Koh Samui plans to fully reopen to foreign vaccinated tourists starting October 1, allowing them to skip quarantine. The move aims to boost the island's economy, which has struggled without foreign visitors over the past year. Koh Samui will also allow quarantine-free travel to neighboring islands of Koh Tao and Koh Phangan. The move is part of Thailand's efforts to revive its tourism industry, which accounts for about a fifth of the country's GDP.

site_title: Breaking glass ceilings start from different sectors of society
summary: Singaporean business leaders and companies are championing gender equality in the workplace, aiming for 50% women in leadership by 2025. SAP Southeast Asia's Verena Siow and P&G's Magesvaran Suranjan emphasize the critical role companies play in driving progress. Despite initiatives, six in 10 women in Singapore experience gender bias in the workplace. Experts, including UN Women's Anita Bhatia and LinkedIn's Feon Ang, stress the need for intersectional policies, gender parity, and civil society involvement to achieve a gender-inclusive society.

images.alt_text: Verena Siow: it is important for females to always challenge the status quo and speak up for themselves.

site_title: UK pension fund nest to invest £250m in renewable power
summary: Nest Corp, the UK's largest pension fund, will invest £250 million in renewable energy through a partnership with Octopus Renewables. The investment aims to diversify the fund's holdings and support the transition to clean energy. About two-thirds of the investment will go towards operational assets, while 25% could be directed towards earlier-stage developments. This initial investment could potentially increase to £1.4 billion over the decade, depending on the success of the partnership. The move is part of a growing trend of institutional investors investing in renewable energy assets.

site_title: Five Chinese companies pose threat to US national security: FCC
summary: The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has designated five Chinese companies as posing a threat to US national security. The companies include Huawei Technologies, ZTE Corp, Hytera Communications Corp, Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology Co, and Zhejiang Dahua Technology Co. The designation is under a 2019 law aimed at protecting US communications networks from equipment and services deemed to pose an unacceptable risk. This move follows a growing concern over China's influence in the global telecommunications industry.

site_title: NGO exits Sime Darby Plantation rights panel over company's lawsuit
summary: NGO Shift has left Sime Darby Plantation's human rights commission after the company sued an activist, potentially undermining the panel's effectiveness. The commission was formed to address forced labor accusations in the palm oil industry. Sime Darby's lawsuit against an activist who filed complaints with Malaysia's Securities Commission has raised concerns about the impact on whistleblowers and the commission's ability to conduct its work objectively. The US had previously banned Sime Darby's palm imports due to labor abuse allegations, prompting some buyers to drop the company from their supply chains.

site_title: Premier League chief hopes fans can return by end of season
summary: The Premier League plans to welcome up to 10,000 fans to stadiums for the final two rounds of matches this season, according to chief executive Richard Masters. This comes after the British government set out a four-stage easing of England's Covid-19 lockdown restrictions, with very large outdoor stadiums allowed to have up to 10,000 people or 25% capacity, whichever is lower. Masters hopes the final two fixtures will have 10,000 supporters, aiming to end the season with a "fantastic finale."

site_title: Tesla investor sues Musk, claims tweets violate SEC settlement
summary: A Tesla shareholder, Chase Gharrity, has sued CEO Elon Musk, accusing him of violating his 2018 SEC settlement over Twitter use. Gharrity claims Musk's "erratic" tweets and the company's directors' failure to enforce the settlement have caused billions of dollars in losses for shareholders. The lawsuit centers on a May 1 tweet where Musk said Tesla's stock price was "too high," resulting in a $13 billion market drop. Musk's actions and the directors' inaction are alleged to have caused "substantial financial harm" to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Tesla chief executive Elon Musk has been sued by a shareholder who accused him of violating his 2018 settlement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission over his Twitter use.

site_title: Bernie Sanders asks Amazon's Jeff Bezos to testify on union drive
summary: Senator Bernie Sanders has asked Amazon founder Jeff Bezos to testify at a hearing on a "union-busting" campaign at an Amazon facility in Alabama, where workers are voting on whether to form a union. Bezos is accused of spending millions to deny workers' economic dignity, while increasing his own wealth to $78 billion during the pandemic. The hearing comes amid a contentious union drive that could result in the first US collective bargaining unit at Amazon, employing 800,000 people.

site_title: Reinsurer Miller finds new owner in GIC, and a refreshed strategy
summary: Singapore's GIC and international private equity firm Cinven have acquired insurance and reinsurance broker Miller, targeting growth through expanding into private wealth and acquisitions. The new owners expect 9% year-on-year revenue growth for the next four or five years. Miller plans to rebuild its treaty reinsurance business, open a new office in Bermuda, and invest in technology to improve client experiences. The acquisition, a 50:50 investment, will allow Miller to hit its targets and increase employees' stakes in the business.

images.alt_text: Mr Cross said that growth across all business functions can also come from acquisitions - a strategy that it has been less acquainted with until now.

site_title: WHO insists AstraZeneca vaccine safe as jab faces new setbacks
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has assured that the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine is safe, despite several countries suspending its rollout due to blood clot fears. The WHO's vaccines advisory committee is examining the safety data, and no causal link has been established between the vaccine and clotting. The US has administered over 100 million vaccine doses, and the European Union has approved the Johnson & Johnson vaccine. Meanwhile, Italy has announced new lockdown restrictions, and several countries have paused or banned the use of AstraZeneca's vaccine due to concerns over blood clots.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization said Friday there was no reason to stop using AstraZeneca's Covid-19 jab after several countries suspended rollout over blood clot fears, while the hard-hit US exceeded 100 million doses of vaccine administered to its people.

site_title: Bond market's 'game of chicken' with Fed is set for a reckoning
summary: The US bond market is facing a potential reckoning as it takes a hard stance against the Federal Reserve's anticipated rate hikes. Five-year Treasury yields have surged amid speculation of earlier rate hikes, threatening a classic reflation trade. This shift has created a widening gap between five- and 30-year yields, contrary to the narrative of a stimulus-fueled recovery, which has only gained momentum. The bond market's "game of chicken" with the Fed is set to intensify, potentially reevaluating the reflation wager.

site_title: UK economy shrank less than expected in January lockdown
summary: The UK economy shrank 2.9% in January, less than expected, driven by a surprise gain in construction and stronger activity in the health sector. Despite a 3.5% drop in services, the construction industry posted a 0.9% gain. The economy is now 9% smaller than pre-pandemic levels, with the Bank of England considering additional stimulus. A rapid vaccination campaign is expected to allow most restrictions to be lifted by mid-2021, according to Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

site_title: Proxy adviser ISS recommends LG shareholders reject spinoff plan
summary: Proxy advisers ISS and Glass Lewis recommend that LG shareholders vote against the company's plan to spin off five affiliates, citing a lack of compelling business justification and inadequate rationale. The proposed transaction, aimed at resolving family succession issues, has been met with opposition from US hedge fund Whitebox Advisors, which owns 1% of LG. Analysts expect the new holding firm to eventually be separated from LG Corp, with family dynamics fueling suspicions about the true purpose of the spinoff.

images.alt_text: Proxy adviser Institutional Shareholder Services said LG Corp. shareholders should vote against the South Korean company's plan to spin off five affiliates, arguing there is no "compelling" reason for the proposed transaction.

site_title: Ford to launch recall of 2.9m vehicles for air bag inflators
summary: Ford will begin notifying owners of its 2.9 million North American vehicles on April 1 due to potentially defective driver-side Takata air bags. The recall, costing $610 million, comes after US regulators demanded the fix in January. The defect can lead to air bag inflators rupturing and sending metal fragments, prompting the largest automotive recall in US history of over 67 million inflators.

site_title: US household net worth surges in closing months of 2020
summary: US household net worth surged to a record $130.2 trillion in the fourth quarter of 2020, driven by rising stock prices and residential real estate values. Household debt increased at a 6.5% annual rate, the fastest in 13 years, while net savings for 2020 reached a record $2.85 trillion. This trend is attributed to government financial aid during the pandemic and record-low mortgage rates.

site_title: Court ruling suspends US ban on investment in Xiaomi
summary: A US federal judge has temporarily blocked the Department of Defense's order requiring American investors to divest holdings in Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp due to alleged ties to China's military. Xiaomi filed a complaint in a Washington court, claiming its inclusion on the list was "unlawful and unconstitutional." The court ruled that the national security interests at stake do not justify the restrictions, suspending the ban. The ruling applies until a full hearing can be held.

images.alt_text: A US federal judge on Friday temporarily blocked the Department of Defense from forcing American investors to divest holdings in Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp on the grounds the company has ties to China's military.

site_title: Alibaba-backed AI startup Megvii files for IPO in Shanghai
summary: Megvii Technology, backed by Alibaba Group Holding, has filed for a Chinese Depositary Receipt offering on Shanghai's Star board, aiming to become the first major Chinese AI startup to go public. The startup plans to issue up to 253 million Class B shares, potentially raising at least six billion yuan, to fund research and development in robotics and visual Internet of Things. Megvii specializes in facial recognition and registered a loss of 1.03 billion yuan in the first nine months of 2020. The company joins Lenovo Group in utilizing the CDR program to lure promising startups to mainland bourses.

site_title: Temasek-backed Openspace Ventures closes third S-E Asia fund at US$200m
summary: Openspace Ventures, backed by Temasek Holdings, has closed its third South-east Asia fund at US$200 million, boosting its total committed capital to US$425 million. The fund, which includes investors such as DEG, Norfund, and Mizuho Financial Group, aims to replicate the firm's successes in startups across the region. Openspace was an early investor in Gojek and Biofourmis, and its first fund has returned 35.3%. The venture capital firm, co-founded by Shane Chesson and Hian Goh, has seen the Singapore VC industry grow from US$100 million in 2010 to US$8.9 billion in 2019.

site_title: Oil giants prepare to put carbon back in the ground
summary: BP and other oil giants are shifting their focus from extracting and transporting oil to combating climate change. Companies like BP are exploring new ventures, such as carbon capture and storage, to reduce pollution. This change is driven by growing climate concerns. The shift in strategy aims to help the industry play a more positive role in the fight against global warming.

site_title: A Bitcoin bubble deja vu
summary: A Bitcoin bubble deja vu has emerged as the cryptocurrency's price has more than doubled in just three months, sparking concerns about its sustainability as a store of value. Despite its price gains, Bitcoin's long-term returns are expected to resemble those of gold, averaging annual gains equal to the rate of inflation. The author, a Bitcoin skeptic, has reevaluated its potential after conducting research and speaking with experts, but remains uncertain about its future. Key issues include the immense electricity needed to maintain the network, the risk of government regulation, and the divisibility, transferability, and durability of Bitcoin compared to traditional currencies.

site_title: Google slams Microsoft over stance in media payments
summary: Google has accused Microsoft of "distraction" for its stance on media payments, urging the tech giant to focus on addressing a potential attack on Exchange email servers. Google argues that Microsoft's collaboration with governments seeking mandatory payments for news content is a self-serving move. Microsoft president Brad Smith claims Google's business model is devouring ad revenue, while Google senior vice president Kent Walker says Microsoft is willing to break the open web to undercut a rival. The debate over media payments has sparked a heated battle between Google, Facebook, and Microsoft.

site_title: WHO approves J&J's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency listing
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) approved Johnson & Johnson's Covid-19 vaccine for emergency listing, allowing its use in all countries, particularly in those with weaker regulatory agencies. This is the third Covid-19 vaccine to receive WHO backing, following Pfizer/BioNTech and AstraZeneca's two-shot regimens. The single-shot vaccine, not requiring an ultra cold chain, is expected to facilitate vaccination logistics, especially in countries worst-hit by the pandemic. The WHO aims to roll out the vaccine through the COVAX program, with hopes of having access to doses by July.

site_title: US: Tech stocks lose tug-of-war amid inflation worries
summary: US tech stocks declined as inflation worries outweighed optimism about a stronger economy. The 10-year Treasury yield rose above 1.6% and US stocks closed mostly higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average setting a record. The Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6% and tech shares like Apple and Amazon lost 0.8%. Investors are concerned about potential interest rate hikes to contain inflation, despite the Federal Reserve's assurances.

site_title: Sequoia-backed India's Stanza Living in final stages of raising up to US$120m: sources
summary: Stanza Living, a managed accommodation provider in India, is in the final stages of raising up to US$120 million in a Series D round led by an Abu Dhabi-based investor. The deal values the company at about US$600 million, up from US$300 million in the prior Series C round. Stanza's business model focuses on small guesthouses, or PGs, offering affordable food and accommodation to students and workers in India's megacities. The company aims to add 100,000 beds by the end of 2021 and has already raised US$70 million from venture capital firms including Sequoia Capital.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat on rising bond yields; logs best week since November
summary: European stocks retreated 0.3% on Friday, despite a 3.5% weekly gain, due to rising bond yields. The Stoxx 600 index reached pre-pandemic highs earlier in the week. The US stimulus package, signed by President Biden, boosted risk appetite, but concerns about inflation and its potential impact on monetary policy weighed on markets. Tech stocks fell 2.1%, while automakers and miners also declined, while luxury groups like Burberry and Brunello Cucinelli rose on positive sales forecasts.

site_title: Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan mansion sold for US$51m after judge lifts asset freeze
summary: Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan mansion has been sold for $51 million after a US judge lifted an asset freeze, allowing the funds to be transferred to a restitution fund for his victims. The sale was completed after the estate's lawyer successfully resisted an attempt to freeze further assets. The mansion, once valued at $600 million, has distributed $55 million to dozens of Epstein's accusers. Several other major transactions, including the sales of his private islands and homes, are pending, with the islands currently under a lien due to a civil lawsuit.

site_title: Electric vehicles less pollutive, but public transport still most sustainable way to get around: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung emphasized the importance of public transport as the most sustainable way to get around the island, despite promoting electric vehicles (EVs). While EVs are less pollutive, Ong warned that their large batteries and disposal of metals can pollute the environment. The government is investing S$60 billion to expand rail networks and has set a target of 60,000 EV charging points by 2030. New incentives and regulations will be introduced to encourage the adoption of EVs, with a focus on increasing charging points and developing industry standards.

site_title: Aztech Global ends first day of trading 1 cent above IPO price
summary: Aztech Global, a tech products manufacturer, ended its first day of trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$1.29, 1 cent above its IPO price of S$1.28. The company received oversubscriptions for its public tranche, with 4,143 valid applications for 64.4 million shares. Analysts attribute the price drop to investors rushing for exit after the share price failed to keep rising, with some viewing it as a speculative move to make quick profits.

site_title: Gold prices are beholden to bond yields
summary: Gold prices rebounded from a nine-month low below $1,680 after rising above the $1,700 mark due to concerns over drone and missile attacks on Saudi oil installations. The metal's safe-haven status was partially regained as US Treasury and German Bund yields retreated. Solid demand for US Treasury auctions also contributed to gold's 2% gain. Despite this, gold is expected to finish the week on a sober note. The article suggests that dollar asset diversification will drive growth in Asia, with retail investors expected to drive massive ETF growth in the region.

site_title: Singaporean collectors continue to invest in luxury goods despite Covid-19
summary: Singaporean ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs) have continued to invest in luxury goods despite the pandemic, with 36% increasing spending on passion investments in 2020, according to Knight Frank's The Attitude Survey. The survey of over 600 private bankers and wealth advisers found that Singaporean UHNWIs managed approximately US$3.3 trillion globally.

site_title: Sembcorp unit awarded 60 MWp solar rooftop project by HDB and EDB
summary: Sembcorp Industries has been awarded a 60 MWp solar rooftop project by the Housing & Development Board (HDB) and the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB). The project, worth 60 MWp, will power about 16,000 four-room HDB flats annually, offsetting 32 kilotonnes of carbon emissions. The award comes as part of the SolarNova programme to accelerate solar deployment in Singapore, with a 540 MWp target by 2030, and is expected to create over 400 jobs.

site_title: Bitcoin snaps five-day rally after flirting with record high
summary: Bitcoin declined 1.1% to US$56,965, snapping its five-day rally, after flirting with a record high of US$58,350. The cryptocurrency's decline follows a broader easing of risk-on sentiment in financial markets. Industry participants argue that institutional adoption will prevent Bitcoin from plummeting from its highs, while concerns over US rules on cryptocurrency trading have emerged. The largest cryptocurrency exchange, Binance Holdings, is under scrutiny from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin declined for the first time in six trading sessions alongside a broader easing of risk-on sentiment in financial markets.

site_title: A glimpse of the Workers' Party
summary: A former Non-Constitutional Member of Parliament, Yee Jenn Jong, has written a book, "Journey In Blue," offering insights into the Workers' Party (WP), Singapore's opposition party. The book provides a personal account of Yee's involvement in the WP and its inner workings. Although the book offers a glimpse into the party, it lacks sensational revelations, instead focusing on clarifying rumors and providing a nuanced view of the WP's leadership under Low Thia Khiang. The book highlights the party's growth and maturity, with Yee acknowledging the PAP's efforts to improve relations with the opposition. The book retails at $29.96 (soft cover) and $58 (hard cover).

site_title: High-yield junk bonds and their ETFs attracting huge fund inflows
summary: High-yield junk bonds and their exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are attracting huge fund inflows as investors anticipate a brighter economic outlook and higher interest rates. The iShares iBoxx High Yield Corporate Bond ETF (HYG) saw its second-largest single-day inflow of $1.3 billion, while the SPDR Bloomberg Barclays High Yield Bond ETF (JNK) absorbed $560 million. The reflation trade is driving the demand for high-yield ETFs, which have lower durations and are less sensitive to interest-rate changes. Analysts expect the trend to continue as US growth becomes more broad-based and supports the rest of the world.

site_title: Aspial to privatise World Class Global unit via scheme of arrangement
summary: Aspial Corp plans to privatise its subsidiary World Class Global through a scheme of arrangement, simplifying the group's structure. The move will transfer all World Class Global shares held by non-Aspial shareholders to Aspial, with a consideration of S$36.3 million. Aspial will issue up to 191 million new shares in exchange, representing a premium of 107.9% over the one-month volume weighted average prices of World Class Global shares. The scheme is conditional on shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Bilateral travel corridors could open for vaccinated passengers in the second half of 2021: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung suggests that bilateral travel corridors for vaccinated passengers from countries with low to moderate infection rates may open in the second half of 2021, helping to revive air travel. The move aims to balance vaccinations, testing, and movement restrictions to identify countries with controlled virus spread.

site_title: Till debt do us part: When corporate debt work-outs don't work out, and why
summary: Singapore's High Court approved the winding up of collapsed oil trader Hin Leong Trading, which had US$4.9 billion of debt. The case highlights difficulties in rehabilitating overly leveraged businesses that have fallen during a deep downturn. While judicial management has been used to help firms in distress, questions remain about its effectiveness. Corporate defaults worldwide have outpaced levels seen during the global financial crisis, with Singapore's corporate bond defaults peaking in 2016 and 2017. A court-sanctioned scheme has been more successful in paving the way for debt refinancing or restructuring, but the years following 2019 have seen firms recommencing debt revamps after implementing sanctioned schemes.

site_title: Oil settles near US$70 a barrel on hopes of recovering demand
summary: Oil prices settled near US$70 a barrel on Friday, supported by production cuts and optimism about demand recovery in the second half of the year. Benchmark Brent settled at US$69.22 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at US$65.61 a barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) forecast a stronger oil demand recovery, while US drillers cut the number of oil and natural gas rigs operating for the first time since November. This suggests sustained higher prices could encourage US producers to increase output, potentially weighing on prices.

images.alt_text: Oil settled near US$70 a barrel on Friday, supported by production cuts by major oil producers and optimism about a demand recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: An NFT sells for US$69m, blasting crypto art records
summary: A digital artwork, "Everydays: the First 5,000 Days," created by artist Mike Winkelmann, sold for a record-breaking US$69.3 million at Christie's in New York, shattering previous NFT market records. The sale, which took place online, saw a dramatic price surge, with the final price exceeding US$60 million. The buyer, whose identity remains anonymous, paid in cryptocurrency, marking a significant shift in the art market. This sale cements Beeple as the third-most expensive living artist to sell at auction, with the artist set to receive the full US$60 million hammer price.

site_title: Japan needs ambitious dose of fiscal medicine, lawmaker says
summary: Japan needs to double its existing budget of nearly $700 billion to ensure a recovery from the pandemic, according to influential lawmaker Kozo Yamamoto. The country's economy is forecast to grow at only half the pace of the US this year, and Yamamoto believes the Bank of Japan (BOJ) cannot do enough on its own. He recommends a new, ambitious fiscal package to support the economy and inflation, echoing the US aid bill. Yamamoto also calls for Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga to reaffirm support for monetary policy and inflation targets, citing concerns that current measures are too granular.

site_title: With Covid-19 on the loose, sick leave is nothing to sneeze at
summary: Sick workers in Singapore continue to report to their desks despite COVID-19 symptoms, sparking concerns over the responsibility and flexibility of employers. The unions and ministry are urging workers and bosses to be fair and considerate of employees' health. This trend is particularly alarming as it may compromise workplace safety and the spread of the virus. The government and unions are calling for a more responsible approach to sick leave, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing employee health and well-being.

site_title: KORE to go public via US$1.01b deal with Cerberus SPAC
summary: KORE Wireless Group has agreed to go public through a merger with Cerberus Telecom Acquisition Corp, a blank-check firm backed by private equity company Cerberus Capital Management, in a deal valued at US$1.01 billion. The combined entity will receive US$484 million in gross cash proceeds, with US$225 million coming from private investment led by Koch Strategic Platforms and other investors. The merged company, listed on the New York Stock Exchange, will trade under the ticker symbol "KORE".

site_title: Grab's US$40b SPAC talks signal race against Gojek-Tokopedia
summary: Grab is reportedly in talks to merge with a SPAC affiliated with Altimeter Capital Management, valuing the Singapore-headquartered company at US$35-40 billion. This comes as Gojek is also in advanced merger talks with Indonesian e-commerce platform Tokopedia, also targeting a US$35-40 billion valuation. The move may be a bid for a first-mover advantage in the public markets, with global investors potentially reacting more exuberantly to the firm that goes public first.

site_title: Investor demand for distressed US hotels on the rise
summary: Investor demand for distressed US hotels is on the rise, driven by pent-up vacation demand and optimism about a travel rebound. Dreamscape, a firm with over $1 billion to buy hotels, is exploring opportunities to acquire lodging properties catering to business clients, despite corporate America's hesitance to return to the road. The firm is partnering with Aimbridge Hospitality to operate hotels, with the first acquisition being the Warwick Hotel in Philadelphia. Despite a slow burn, lenders are raising cash to make rescue loans, and net asset values for hotels owned by real estate investment trusts have ticked up 4% since January.

site_title: Myanmar's first satellite held by Japan on space station after coup
summary: Myanmar's first satellite, built by Japan's Hokkaido University in a joint project with Myanmar's government-funded Myanmar Aerospace Engineering University, is being held on the International Space Station following the country's coup. The $15 million satellite, equipped with cameras to monitor agriculture and fisheries, has raised concerns about potential military use, prompting discussions with Japan's space agency, Jaxa, on what to do next. The project's future is uncertain, with some officials calling for it to be suspended due to human rights risks.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-based company, announced that talks with potential partners for new restaurant outlets and studies on other food-related opportunities will not be affected by the resignation of its executive chairman and CEO, and an independent director. The company's new executive chairman and CEO, Lam Siew Kee, has over 18 years of corporate finance experience and is familiar with Singapore's listing rules. EC World Reit Asset Management waived S$11 million in late rental payment penalties, while AMTD International established a joint venture with 36Kr and Airstar Digital to provide services to "new economy companies and entrepreneurs".

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Friday, down 13.72 points to 1,615.69. The market saw 9.632 billion lots worth RM5.510 billion, with 630 gainers outnumbering losers 529.

site_title: Apple could reach a US$3t market valuation, analysts say
summary: Analysts predict Apple's market valuation could reach US$3 trillion, a 50% increase from its current US$2.05 trillion. The development of the Apple Car and high expectations for the next iPhone drive this forecast. Citigroup analyst Jim Suva expects the Apple Car to boost sales by 10-15% after 2024, while Wedbush analyst Daniel Ives sees a US$175 price target and a "game-changer" iPhone 13.

site_title: IT engineer at Deutsche Bank is sole Covid-19 community case
summary: A sole Covid-19 community case was announced in Singapore, involving an IT engineer at Deutsche Bank who developed symptoms on March 1 and tested positive on March 12 after initially declining to be tested. The engineer had previously served a stay-home notice and had a negative test result on January 29. Nine imported cases were also confirmed, bringing the total to 60,080. The number of new community cases has remained stable at three per week, and 59,935 patients have fully recovered from the disease.

site_title: Ant Group publishes financial self-discipline rules amid tougher Chinese scrutiny
summary: Ant Group, a Chinese fintech giant, released financial self-discipline rules amid intensified scrutiny by Chinese authorities. The rules follow the suspension of its US$37 billion listing plan in Shanghai and Hong Kong four months ago. Chinese regulators have tightened control over fintech companies, citing concerns over systemic financial risks linked to Alibaba Group.

site_title: Chinese debt becomes unlikely safe haven amid bond turmoil
summary: Chinese government bonds have defied market turmoil, maintaining a tight eight basis-point range over the past month. This has led some investors to view them as a viable alternative to US Treasuries, with JPMorgan and Brandywine Global Investment Management among those now seeing them as a shock absorber in the global reflation storm. Chinese debt funds saw $420 million in inflows in the week through March 10, despite investors lowering emerging-market holdings. However, risks such as liquidity issues, currency risk, and geopolitical rivalry with the US remain, casting a shadow over the market's potential as a safe haven.

site_title: UK exports to EU slump in first month of new Brexit trade ties
summary: The UK's exports to the EU plummeted 40.7% and imports fell by 28.8% in January, the first month of the country's new trade relationship with the bloc, according to the Office for National Statistics. The decline was attributed to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, which complicated the data. The UK government had warned that the pandemic would make it difficult to separate Brexit's impact from its effects. The data suggests a challenging start for the UK's post-Brexit trade ties with the EU.

site_title: Alpine A110S review: At the speed of light
summary: The Alpine A110S is a highly praised driver's car that offers exceptional balance and handling, making it a joy to drive. With its 1.8-liter turbo engine producing 292 horsepower, the A110S accelerates quickly and has a responsive exhaust sound. The car's lightweight design and rear-drive layout contribute to its agility. While it comes with a hefty price tag of S$268,800, the Alpine A110S is a unique offering in the market, with no direct competitors. Its revival in 2017 has revitalized the brand, but its sales have been struggling, making it essential for Alpine to continue producing this exceptional vehicle.

site_title: 200 Myanmar police, family members now in India
summary: Scores of Myanmar police officers and their families have fled to India, with 264 people crossing the border into the northeastern state of Mizoram since the February 1 coup. The officers, including 198 police officers and family members, are escaping military crackdowns and beatings. One officer stated that the authorities are "beating and torturing" protestors, while others believe joining the protests can lead to winning the fight against the military junta. India authorities have pushed back eight of those who crossed the border, with dozens waiting to enter.

site_title: Australia's former finance minister named OECD chief
summary: Australia's former finance minister Mathias Cormann was elected as the new head of the OECD, chosen by a slim majority of ambassadors from the 37-nation Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. Cormann, a powerbroker in the ruling centre-right Liberal party, served as Australia's finance minister for over 10 years before quitting parliament to seek the top job. His appointment marks a significant shift in the OECD's leadership, following his experience in finance and his role in shaping Australia's economic policies.

site_title: Popularity of Harry and Meghan plummets in UK after Oprah interview
summary: Prince Harry and Meghan's popularity in the UK has plummeted after their explosive Oprah interview, with 48% of respondents having a negative attitude towards Harry and 58% towards Meghan, according to a YouGov poll. The couple's comments about being ignored and having a family member ask about Archie's skin color have sparked widespread criticism. The only other member of the royal family to see a decline in popularity is Prince Charles, with 42% of respondents now having a negative view. The monarchy's overall support remains largely unchanged, with 63% backing the institution.

site_title: Singapore stocks sink into the red; STI down 0.35%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.35% on Friday, closing at 3,095.22, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 10.79 points. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding led gains, up 2.56%, while Mapletree Industrial Trust followed with a 1.17% increase. Thai Beverage, however, dropped 3.95% to S$0.73, marking a reversal from Thursday's gains. The decline comes after a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Oceanus refutes rumours of 'pump-and-dump' scheme, financial investigation and move to Catalist
summary: Oceanus Group has refuted rumors of a "pump-and-dump" scheme, a financial investigation, and a move to the Catalist board, calling them "untrue and misleading information". The company will investigate the circulating rumors and pursue legal avenues, including civil suits and police reports. Oceanus' financial accounts are accurate, and its independent auditors have not raised material concerns. The company's shares rebounded 24.14% after hitting a new low for the year.

site_title: New project to unleash football's roar again will raise the sport's standards
summary: The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) has unveiled a new project, "Unleash The Roar," aimed at raising the sport's standards. The initiative, which includes better youth development programs, foreign stints for players, and coaching upgrades, must involve a whole stakeholder group, including sponsors, players, and the public. Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong has expressed support for the project, which aims to create a culture of excellence in Singaporean football. The project's success depends on a sustained effort and collaboration with stakeholders to overcome the challenges faced by Singaporean football.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end week on a negative note
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a negative note, with the Hang Seng Index falling 2.20% to 28,739.72 after Tencent tumbled following an anti-monopoly fine by China. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.47%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.17%. The decline comes amid concerns about regulatory scrutiny of tech giants.

site_title: The Bitcoin lottery
summary: A former Goldman Sachs executive and UK treasury minister expresses skepticism about the value of cryptocurrencies, particularly Bitcoin, calling it a "speculative punt" rather than a bet on the future of the monetary system. He notes the volatility of Bitcoin's price and its inability to meet the conventional criteria for a currency, including serving as a means of exchange, store of value, and unit of account. He cautions that cryptocurrency investors, including those who made early profits, should not let their windfall go to their heads, as speculative bets can be unpredictable and may not lead to long-term success.

images.alt_text: I can see why there is so much excitement behind Bitcoin . . . and its many competitors. Particularly in developing and "emerging" economies . . . the opportunity to stow one's savings in a digital currency is obviously an inviting one.

site_title: Post-Brexit UK is fourth most favoured investment destination, overtaking India: PwC survey
summary: Post-Brexit UK has become the fourth most favored investment destination, surpassing India, according to a PwC survey of over 5,000 CEOs. The top three destinations remain the US, China, and Germany. The shift is attributed to changes in Britain's post-Brexit status and favorable views from US and German companies. A new trade deal between Britain and the EU was agreed on December 24, 2020, amidst record-high CEO optimism for global economic growth in 2021, despite concerns over inflation and market risks.

site_title: Blackstone to expand head office in Park Avenue
summary: Blackstone Group has signed a lease to expand its headquarters in Manhattan, taking an additional 80,000 sq ft at 345 Park Avenue, bringing its total to about 720,000 sq ft. The expansion will add 12 full floors and five partial floors to the building, where Blackstone has been based for over 30 years. The deal comes as the firm recommits to staying in New York and is part of a larger trend of companies returning to office space in the city. The lease now runs through 2028.

site_title: US producer prices increase solidly in February
summary: US producer prices rose 0.5% in February, the largest annual gain in nearly 2-1/2 years, driven by a 2.8% surge in the 12-month period. This follows a 1.3% jump in January, the largest advance since December 2009. Economists had forecast a 0.5% increase in February, but the actual gain was higher than expected. Despite the increase, labor market slack may limit businesses' ability to pass on costs to consumers.

site_title: Microsoft warns of new threat against unpatched networks
summary: Microsoft has detected and blocked a new family of ransomware targeting unpatched networks, particularly those that haven't installed patches for vulnerabilities in Microsoft's Exchange business email software. The company has released temporary updates to defend against the attacks, which are being carried out by suspected Chinese state-sponsored hackers. Governments have urged businesses to install the patches, with Microsoft warning that those who haven't taken action risk significant damage, as backups may not be enough to recover data.

site_title: Hoteliers to get more help with job redesign
summary: Singapore's hotel industry is receiving enhanced government support through a revamped job redesign scheme, aiming to qualify hotels for wage support and aid their recovery. The scheme, which began in 2019, helps hoteliers transform jobs into digital roles, such as guest experience ambassadors, and provides up to 90% wage support and 90% funding for course fees. Since its inception, 64 employees have been reskilled or upskilled, with the goal of reducing turnover and boosting morale. The initiative is part of the government's efforts to support the industry's transition to digitalization and emerge stronger from the crisis.

site_title: Deutsche Bank investment banking bonuses soar 46% after boom year
summary: Deutsche Bank's investment banking bonus pool surged 46% to 1.9 billion euros, driven by a boom year in the markets. This marks a significant increase compared to smaller gains or cuts at major European banks. The move comes after the lender posted its first profit in five years, driven by booming income in its trading unit. CEO Christian Sewing's pay rose 46% to 7.4 million euros, while the bank initially planned to raise bonuses by more than a third before scaling back amid European Central Bank objections.

site_title: Malaysia defends coronavirus fake news law amid outcry
summary: Malaysia's government defended its new law aimed at tackling coronavirus-related fake news, which critics warned could be used to silence dissent and curtail free speech. The emergency ordinance, which took effect on Friday, prescribes hefty fines and jail terms of up to six years for publishing or reproducing "wholly or partly false" content. The law was defended by Communications Minister Saifuddin Abdullah as necessary to expedite enforcement, but opposition lawmakers and civil society groups said it was too sweeping and could be used to instill fear among the public.

site_title: Europe: Shares retreat as rising bond yields weigh
summary: European stocks declined 0.4% on Friday as rising bond yields weighed on the market, despite strong weekly gains expected due to stimulus and vaccination efforts. The Stoxx 600 fell to a four-session low, with tech stocks down 1.4% and Dutch company Prosus dropping 4.8% after a Chinese regulator fined companies including Tencent. However, British luxury group Burberry rose 7.2% after reporting a strong sales rebound.

site_title: Shell doubled oil-trading profit to US$2.6b last year
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a nearly doubling of its oil-trading profit to US$2.6 billion last year, thanks to taking advantage of wild price swings and storing oil to sell later for a profit. This surpasses the highest ever net income at Vitol Group, the world's largest independent trading house, which made US$2.3 billion in 2019. Shell's trading division played a crucial role in the company's earnings, particularly in a year marked by weak demand and prices.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell disclosed the profitability of its sprawling and secretive oil-trading unit for the first time, saying it almost doubled to US$2.6 billion last year.

site_title: Why I stopped running during the pandemic, and how I started again
summary: A writer, a senior editor and runner, reflects on how the pandemic affected her running habits and mental health. She initially stopped running due to the overwhelming global situation, feeling a "pandemic wall" of fatigue and despair. After finding motivation through the science of behavioral activation, she restarted running, beginning with short sprints and gradually increasing her endurance. The process has been humbling and uncomfortable, but she feels a sense of reconnecting with her former self. The writer argues that breaking the pandemic wall requires taking action, rather than relying on self-care or wellness hacks, and encourages readers to reconnect with their lives and engage in activities that bring them joy and fulfillment.

site_title: Ant Group CEO Simon Hu resigns amid regulatory-driven revamp
summary: Ant Group CEO Simon Hu resigns amid regulatory-driven revamp. Hu, who took over as CEO in December 2019, will be replaced by company veteran Eric Jing. The move comes after Ant's failed US$37 billion IPO and China's regulatory crackdown on fintech firms. The overhaul, which includes turning Ant into a financial holding company, could slash the company's valuation by 60%. This decision follows Chinese Premier Li Keqiang's pledge to expand oversight of financial technology and curb the "reckless" expansion of capital by tech firms into finance.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Two licensed property agents and four individuals were charged in court under Singapore's Stamp Duties Act for attempting to evade higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD). Additionally, 10,300 employers hired or redesigned jobs through government programs, with 1,500 SMEs ramping up career conversion programs. Select Group plans to invest S$10m in cloud kitchens, while Aztech Global debuted on the SGX mainboard at 7% above its IPO price. Singapore stocks declined 0.35% in the STI, closing at 3,095.22 points.

images.alt_text: The buyers, Halim and Lee, were said to have executed the backdated OTP for a fourth-storey unit at the Sandy Palm condominium.

site_title: EU battery ambitions to get US$1.1b research boost
summary: The European Union's Battery Alliance project is set to receive a $1.1 billion research boost, bolstering innovation and competitiveness in the sector. The EU aims to become the world's second-largest battery producer by 2025, with a market value of 250 billion euros. This investment will help close the gap with Asian competitors and support the bloc's goal of "open strategic autonomy." The EU's battery ambitions are seen as a key step in its efforts to reduce dependence on Asian suppliers and increase its presence in the global electric vehicle market.

site_title: Temasek-backed Openspace Ventures closes third S-E Asia fund at US$200m
summary: Openspace Ventures, backed by Temasek Holdings, has closed its third South-east Asia fund at US$200 million, boosting its total committed capital to US$425 million. The fund's investors include DEG, Norfund AS, and Mizuho Financial Group. Openspace has a successful track record, with its first fund returning 35.3% and backing companies like Gojek, Halodoc, and TaniHub. The venture capital firm's co-founders, Shane Chesson and Hian Goh, plan to replicate their successes with the new fund, which will focus on mid-stage tech startups in the region.

site_title: Sewing's 2020 pay up as bank turns profit
summary: Deutsche Bank's CEO Christian Sewing received a 46% increase in pay to 7.4 million euros in 2020, as the bank reported a net profit of 113 million euros, marking an important milestone after years of losses. The bank's revenue is expected to be "marginally lower" this year. The surge in investment banking earnings offset weaker performances in other businesses, with bonuses reaching 1.9 billion euros, comparable to 2018 levels.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 10 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 60,080. One case was in the community, identified as a 37-year-old Indonesian foreign domestic worker who was asymptomatic. The other nine cases were imported and had been placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. Epidemiological investigations suggest the cases were likely separately infected and not linked. With 28 cases discharged, 59,924 patients have recovered, and 21 remain hospitalized, including one in critical condition.

site_title: Hot stock: FJB up 32.5% after clinching exclusive rights to distribute Airfree purifiers in Indonesia
summary: FJB shares surged 32.5% to a three-year high after securing exclusive rights to distribute Airfree purifiers in Indonesia, with over 132.2 million shares changing hands. The counter reached 5.3 Singapore cents. This marks a similar trading level to March 2018. No new deals were recorded for the day.

site_title: Eligible foreign listings to join MSCI Singapore indices in four steps
summary: Foreign listings, including Sea, will be included in the MSCI Singapore Indices in four phases starting with a 5% free float adjusted market capitalization in May. The phased approach aims to minimize market disruption and allows for a smoother integration of foreign listings into the index. The initial inclusion of Sea is expected to have a minimal impact on trading activity, but its full weight in the index could lead to reduced liquidity and trading opportunities, particularly for index arbitrage traders.

site_title: Gold eases on firmer US yields, but set for best week in seven
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.2% to $1,718.10 per ounce, weighed down by firmer US bond yields and a strong dollar, but are on track for a 1% weekly gain. US gold futures fell 0.4% to $1,715.10. Elevated yields and a strong dollar increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, with investors awaiting the US Federal Reserve meeting next week for direction on monetary policy.

site_title: Select Group to invest S$10m to open 20 cloud kitchens in Singapore
summary: Select Group, a Singapore-based food and catering company, plans to invest S$10 million to open 20 cloud kitchens in the next five years, focusing on densely populated heartland areas. The cloud kitchens will be leased out, with some Select brands occupying units. The company expects demand for food delivery to remain strong after the Covid-19 pandemic, driven by a 200% surge in delivery orders in 2020. Select aims to differentiate itself with low rents and strategic locations, including Jalan Mas Puteh in Clementi and Tampines Mart.

site_title: Ex-director gets S$30,000 fine, eight-week jail term for rigging Gaylin shares
summary: A Singapore court sentenced Wong Leon Keat, a former director, to an eight-week jail term and a S$30,000 fine for rigging the market for Gaylin Holdings in 2016. He had bought shares 17 times between 2015 and 2016 to save his reputation after the company's share price declined. Wong pleaded guilty to seven charges of market manipulation and one count of misusing an investor's securities account.

site_title: SGX queries LifeBrandz on business development, board changes
summary: LifeBrandz, a Singapore-based company with various businesses in fintech, travel, and food and beverage, has responded to queries from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) regarding the resignations of its executive chairman and chief executive, and an independent director. Despite the changes, the company said talks with potential partners and studies on new business opportunities will not be "materially affected". New executive chairman and chief executive Lam Siew Kee, with over 18 years of corporate finance experience, has been appointed to oversee the company's strategic direction and plans.

site_title: UK economy shrank by less than expected 2.9% in January
summary: The UK economy contracted by 2.9% in January, less severe than expected, due to a coronavirus lockdown. This is a smaller contraction than forecast by economists, who predicted a 4.9% decline. Despite the lockdown, health services saw an increase due to the vaccine rollout and increased testing, partially offsetting the decline. The economy is expected to shrink by 4% in the first quarter of 2021, mainly due to the lockdown and post-Brexit trade disruptions.

site_title: JD.com in talks to purchase stake in brokerage worth US$1.5b: sources
summary: JD.com is in talks to purchase a stake in Sinolink Securities, a Chinese brokerage firm, worth at least $1.5 billion. The deal would be JD.com's largest acquisition in China's financial market and would bolster the company's financial services operations. Sinolink's largest shareholder, Yongjin Group, is considering a sale to JD.com to divest its financial services business amid new regulations. The potential deal comes as Chinese tech giants expand into financial services despite regulatory crackdowns.

site_title: Brent crude eases, but stays near US$70 as demand optimism lends support
summary: Brent crude prices eased to $69.52 a barrel, down 11 cents, as production cuts by major oil producers constrained supply. Demand optimism, driven by a recovery in global demand and a wider rollout of Covid-19 vaccines, lent support. Opec+ maintained production cuts in April, and analysts expect a surge in petrol demand this summer, supporting oil prices. US crude oil production is forecast to average 11.78 million barrels per day in December 2021, up from 11.32 million in 2020.

site_title: Travel corridors for vaccinated passengers could open in second half of 2021: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung suggests that travel corridors for vaccinated passengers from countries with low to moderate COVID-19 infection rates could open in the second half of 2021. This move would require a combination of vaccination, testing, movement restrictions, and identifying "safe" countries. Ong notes that Singapore's air travel bubble with Hong Kong remains on ice due to the city's recent surge in cases, and that the aviation sector is unlikely to recover with a "V-shaped" recovery, but rather a gradual one.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post best weekly jump in five weeks on US stimulus
summary: South Korean shares closed at a 1.35% gain, their largest weekly jump in five weeks, driven by the passage of the US$1.9 trillion stimulus bill and easing concerns about inflation and rising bond yields. The benchmark KospI rose 40.69 points to 3,054.39. This follows a 1.88% gain on Thursday. The positive sentiment is attributed to US President Biden's pledge to speed up vaccinations and move the country closer to normality by July 4.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes up more than 1.7%
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index rose 1.73% to 29,717.83, its fourth consecutive gain, driven by a new US economic package and the ECB's stimulus bond-buying. The broader Topix index also advanced 1.36% to 1,951.06. This move comes as investors remain optimistic despite tariff uncertainty and split views on the Fed's future actions.

site_title: Thai PM delays AstraZeneca shot over probe into blood clots
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha has delayed receiving the AstraZeneca COVID-19 vaccine amid a probe into potential blood clots, joining European nations in suspending its use. European regulators have backed the vaccine, stating no link to the clots. The decision follows concerns about potential side effects and the vaccine's effectiveness for people over 65. Thailand's health authorities continue to monitor the situation, while the Philippine health authorities have concurred with European regulators, allowing the rollout of the vaccine to proceed.

site_title: 10,300 employers hire or redesign jobs through MOM, WSG programmes in 2020
summary: In 2020, 10,300 employers in Singapore hired or redesigned jobs through government-led programmes, a 45% increase from the previous year. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and Workforce Singapore (WSG) facilitated these placements. Career conversion programmes for new hires saw a 10% increase, with 1,500 employers, mostly SMEs, participating.

images.alt_text: Some 10,300 employers hired new staff or redesigned their jobs through the help of government-led programmes last year, a 45 per cent increase from the year before.

site_title: China market regulator fines 12 companies for illegal monopolistic behaviour
summary: China's market regulator fined 12 companies, including Baidu, Tencent Holdings, and Didi Chuxing, for violating anti-monopoly rules in 10 deals. The companies were each fined 500,000 yuan (S$103,400) for causing market concentration without excluding all competition. The State Administration for Market Regulation (SAMR) said the behavior led to market concentration, but not complete exclusion of competition. The fines are part of efforts to promote fair competition in China's market.

site_title: India's SpiceJet offering 299 rupee Covid tests to get people flying
summary: SpiceJet, India's second-largest carrier, is offering COVID-19 tests to passengers for 299 rupees (S$5.50), about one-third the current market rate. The airline aims to make extra money while encouraging people to fly amid the pandemic. SpiceJet posted a net loss of 569.6 million rupees for the quarter ended Dec 31, highlighting the need for new revenue streams. This move follows similar initiatives by other airlines, such as Qantas Airways and AirAsia Group, as the industry faces significant financial challenges due to the pandemic.

site_title: Philippines secures US$900m in loans from World Bank, ADB for Covid-19 vaccines
summary: The Philippines secured US$900 million in loan commitments from the World Bank and Asian Development Bank (ADB) to purchase Covid-19 vaccines and aid its pandemic-hit economy.
