The loans include US$500 million from the World Bank for vaccine procurement and US$400 million from the ADB for vaccine access support. The country aims to inoculate 70 million of its over 108 million population and is in talks with vaccine manufacturers to buy 161 million doses. The loans will help the Philippines strengthen its health systems and provide relief to those who lost jobs during lockdowns.

site_title: Coupang shares soar 41% in trading debut after biggest US IPO since Uber
summary: Coupang, a South Korean e-commerce giant, made its trading debut with a 41% surge, becoming the biggest US IPO since Uber. The company's shares opened at $63.50 and briefly reached a market value of over $100 billion. Coupang's IPO raised $4.6 billion, surpassing the total raised by other companies this year, and valued the company at around $84 billion. Founder and CEO Bom Kim attributed the success to the company's strong investor base and long-term vision.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH raises Elite Commercial Reit target post UK acquisition
summary: UOB Kay Hian has raised its target price for Elite Commercial Reit to £0.95 from £0.88 following the UK acquisition, expanding its assets by 67%. Analyst Jonathan Koh sees the trust as a "recession-resistant" yield play, benefiting from the UK government's Jobcentre Plus scheme and reduced likelihood of tenants exercising break clauses. He has also raised the FY2021 distribution per unit estimate by 9% to 5.2 pence.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up with Asia amid US stimulus afterglow; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% to 3,113.88, following a strong lead from US markets, which closed at fresh records after the passage of the US$1.9 trillion economic relief package. Asian markets, including Tokyo and Europe, also gained, with focus on manufacturing reports and the European Central Bank's stimulus efforts. Gainers outnumbered losers 90 to 34 on the Singapore bourse, with Soilbuild Business Space Reit and Mapletree Logistics Trust leading gains.

site_title: US imposes new 5G licence limits on some Huawei suppliers
summary: The US has imposed new 5G licence limits on some Huawei suppliers, prohibiting items for use in or with 5G devices. The ban, effective as of this week, creates a more uniform prohibition on the export of components like semiconductors, antennas, and batteries to Huawei. This move reflects the Biden administration's plan to implement tighter export controls and follows through on pledges to be tough on China. The decision affects Chinese-listed telecom equipment stocks, with Fiberhome Telecommunication Technologies and Shennan Circuits falling over 1% in Hong Kong.

site_title: Japan says PM Suga plans to meet Biden in US next month
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga plans to meet US President Joe Biden in the US next month, becoming the first foreign leader to hold a face-to-face meeting with him. The meeting, expected to take place in the first half of April, will focus on an open and free Indo-Pacific region, coronavirus measures, and climate change. Suga will be the first foreign leader to meet Biden in person, and officials say the visit is crucial at a time of rising concern about China. The final schedule for the trip is still being worked out, with all members of the delegation to be vaccinated beforehand.

site_title: Asia: Most markets track Wall Street record as Biden signs stimulus
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday following US President Joe Biden's signing of a $1.9 trillion stimulus package, tracking Wall Street's record highs. The package includes cash handouts, unemployment benefits, and aid programs, boosting domestic and global growth. Equity markets, which had been rattled by inflation concerns, surged as the US government eases lockdowns and vaccine drives. The European Central Bank's decision to ramp up bond-buying also calmed investor fears of interest rate hikes, with Frankfurt's DAX index hitting a third consecutive record.

site_title: Fire at Tesla's Fremont factory under control, no injuries reported
summary: A fire broke out at Tesla's Fremont factory in California, but was brought under control without causing injuries. The fire occurred in a construction area, involving a vehicle manufacturing stamping machine, and was caused by hydraulic fluid coming into contact with molten aluminum. The fire department and Tesla's response team worked together to contain the fire, with no reports of production disruption. Two fire engines remained at the scene to monitor the situation.

site_title: Japan Post Holdings, Rakuten to form capital alliance
summary: Japan Post Holdings and Rakuten will form a capital alliance, sharpening competition with Amazon in Japan's e-commerce market. The tie-up was first reported by NHK and saw shares of both companies rise in Tokyo. Details of the alliance, including its size, were not immediately clear. Japan Post Holdings, a $41 billion market value company, and Rakuten, a mobile phone and online shopping mall operator, will collaborate to strengthen their presence in Japan's high streets. The partnership is expected to impact competition in the Japanese e-commerce market.

images.alt_text: Japanese e-commerce firm Rakuten will form a capital alliance with postal and banking giant Japan Post Holdings, two sources with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

site_title: Blackstone inks deal to expand headquarters on Park Avenue
summary: Blackstone Group has signed a lease to expand its headquarters in Manhattan, taking an additional 80,000 square feet at 345 Park Avenue. The expansion brings the firm's total space to approximately 720,000 sq ft, with leases running until 2028. The move comes as the office market in New York recovers from the pandemic, with subleases flooding the market and driving down rent. Blackstone's commitment to staying in New York signals an important part of the city's recovery, according to CEO Bill Rudin.

site_title: Temasek-backed payments processor Flywire files paperwork to go public
summary: Flywire Corp, a payments processor backed by Temasek Holdings, has submitted a draft registration statement with the US Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed initial public offering (IPO) of its common stock. The IPO, which could value the firm at around $3 billion, is expected to take place later this year. Flywire focuses on facilitating payments in the education, healthcare, and travel sectors. The company has partnered with Goldman Sachs Group and JPMorgan Chase & Co for the IPO. The number of shares and price range for the offering have not been determined yet.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on ECB, US stimulus
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, driven by the US economic relief package and the ECB's stimulus bond buying. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.28% to 29,292.17, while the Topix index advanced 0.08% to 1,926.43. The positive sentiment followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which await GDP data.

site_title: Property agents, condo buyers charged with intent to evade higher ABSD
summary: Four individuals, including two licensed property agents, have been charged in court for allegedly exercising a backdated option to purchase (OTP) to avoid paying higher additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) on their third private residential property. The alleged offence occurred in July 2018, after the government announced cooling measures for the housing market. The individuals, Mu Shen, Loy Thye Wei, Daniel Halim, and Lee Liu Ying, may face fines up to S$10,000 and/or imprisonment for up to three years if found guilty.

site_title: Evergrande taps new tycoons for EV startup worth more than Ford
summary: Chinese billionaire Hui Ka Yan has raised billions for his electric-vehicle startup, China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group, tapping new tycoons including Chen Hua, Wong Kwong Miu, and Liu Ming Hui. The US$3.4 billion share offering, now worth over US$61 billion, has helped the company expand its network of rich acquaintances despite government restrictions on property firms. The new investors have agreed to a 12-month lock-up period, showing their confidence in the electric-vehicle business.

site_title: Aztech Global debuts on SGX mainboard at 7% above IPO price
summary: Aztech Global began trading on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard at S$1.37, 7% above its IPO price of S$1.28. The company's public tranche was subscribed 18.4 times, and placement shares were subscribed 16.4 times. Aztech's market capitalization stands at about S$990.4 million, with net proceeds of S$188.6 million to be used for expansion and growth. The company aims to strengthen its market position through mergers and acquisitions and expand into new areas.

site_title: Renault to sell stake in Daimler
summary: Renault has announced the sale of its 1.54% stake in Daimler for 1.2 billion euros, with the proceeds to be used for financial deleveraging. The sale does not impact Renault's industrial partnership with Daimler. Renault booked a record loss of 8.05 billion euros in 2020 due to the pandemic, with 3.6 billion euros in automotive losses. The sale will allow Renault to accelerate its financial recovery.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Grab in talks to go public in nearly US$40b SPAC deal: sources
summary: Grab Holdings Inc, backed by SoftBank, is in talks for a nearly US$40 billion merger with a special purpose acquisition company, Altimeter Capital Management LP. The deal would value Grab at nearly US$40 billion, making it the largest ever blank-cheque deal. Grab is expected to raise US$3-4 billion from private investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.10 points, or 0.01%, to 1,629.31. Volume was 356.10 million lots worth RM140.30 million. Gainers beat losers 444 to 104.

site_title: Sembcorp awarded 60 MWp solar project by HDB and EDB
summary: Sembcorp Industries has been awarded a 60 MWp solar project by the HDB and EDB, aiming to generate enough energy to power 16,000 four-room HDB flats for a year. The project, part of the SolarNova programme, is expected to offset 32 kilotonnes of carbon emissions annually. This is Sembcorp's 82nd MWp of new solar energy projects this year, estimated to add over 400 jobs. The project is not expected to impact Sembcorp's earnings per share and net asset per share for the financial year ending Dec 31.

site_title: Citi cuts Revlon lenders off from new debt, credit lines over S$500m error
summary: Citigroup has frozen out several lenders that were mistakenly paid $500 million by the bank, excluding them from new debt, credit lines, and trading activities. The lenders, which were critical to the bank's collateralized loan obligations, will also lose warehouse financing. This move affects not only new debt but also other lucrative businesses, including trading activities. The decision denies the lenders access to these critical services, effectively blocking them from leveraged-loan new-issue allocations.

site_title: UAE announces US$10b Israel investment fund
summary: The UAE has announced a US$10 billion investment fund to be invested in strategic sectors in Israel, including energy, manufacturing, water, space, healthcare, and agri-tech. The fund is part of the historic Abraham Accords, which normalized ties between Israel and the UAE, following a US-brokered agreement. The investment aims to bolster economic ties between the two countries, unlocking investments and partnership opportunities to drive socio-economic progress. The fund will be allocated from government and private sector institutions, building on the agreements reached by Bahrain, Morocco, and Sudan.

site_title: Europe: Shares at fresh one-year peak after dovish ECB signal
summary: European stocks reached a fresh one-year peak on Thursday, driven by the European Central Bank's dovish stance on inflation and plans to accelerate money-printing. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5% and euro zone blue chip stocks gained 0.7%, their highest levels in over 13 years. The ECB warned against premature policy tightening and signaled its commitment to containing rising bond yields. The technology, mining, and travel sectors were top gainers, while banks fell the most.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Friday, following a record performance on Wall Street and in Europe. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.56% to 29,550.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.30% and 0.40%, respectively. The gains came after US President Joe Biden signed off on a massive economic stimulus package, boosting investor sentiment.

site_title: 'I've aged 30 years': long Covid patients battle acute symptoms
summary: Long Covid patients in Montreal are experiencing severe and debilitating symptoms, with some reporting a significant decline in their quality of life. Violaine Cousineau, a 47-year-old mother of two, has been bedridden for three days after contracting Covid-19 in October and now struggles with difficulty breathing, concentrating, and walking. A new clinic has been set up to study the long-term health impacts of Covid-19, with some patients showing symptoms up to a year after infection. Experts estimate that 10-30% of patients may experience long-term complications, with fatigue, shortness of breath, and muscle pain being common symptoms.

images.alt_text: Difficulty breathing, concentrating and even walking: five months after being diagnosed with Covid-19, Violaine Cousineau continues to suffer severe symptoms that prevent her from resuming normal life.

site_title: Australia PM says Quad meet to discuss Indo-Pacific, Covid-19, climate change
summary: Australia Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced the first meeting of the Quad countries, consisting of US President Joe Biden, Australian, Indian, and Japanese leaders, will discuss security challenges in the Indo-Pacific, climate change, and containing Covid-19. The virtual meeting aims to create a new anchor for peace and stability in the region and lay groundwork for an in-person meeting later this year. The talks will also focus on achieving net zero emission targets and financing agreements for coronavirus vaccine manufacturing capacity in India.

images.alt_text: Australia Prime Minister Scott Morrison said the first meeting of the leaders of "Quad" countries would discuss security challenges across the Indo-Pacific, climate change and efforts to contain the spread of Covid-19 in the region.

site_title: Homeless man roams air base housing Biden's plane for five hours
summary: A homeless man spent five hours roaming the Joint Base Andrews, where US President Biden's plane is kept, after easily passing through multiple layers of security. The man drove onto the base, visited a food court, and boarded a C-40 transport plane, but did not get close to Air Force One or other protected planes. He was arrested after his suspicious behavior drew attention. The incident highlighted security failures, including a distracted guard and a malfunctioning automatic gate, but authorities found no intent to harm. The man's motivations remain unclear.

site_title: US says China stifling democracy with Hong Kong election plan
summary: The US has denounced China's approval of changes to Hong Kong's electoral system, saying Beijing is stifling democracy in the financial capital. Secretary of State Antony Blinken called the move a "direct attack on autonomy" and urged Hong Kong to proceed with September elections. The changes limit political participation, reduce democratic representation, and stifle debate, Blinken stated. He also urged the authorities to drop charges against activists under a new security law. The US calls for a transparent and credible election process and the inclusion of all candidates.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Dairy Farm, CDL, JMH, JSH, Sembcorp, Aztech Global
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies reported significant financial updates, including Dairy Farm International's flat closing price despite a 16% fall in net profit, City Developments Limited's shares rising after a statement denying misrepresentation claims, and Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic Holdings incurring full-year net losses. Sembcorp Industries secured a 60 MWp solar energy project, while Aztech Global's IPO received strong interest. Koufu Group Limited is set to receive S$11.8 million from a proposed property sale, and MTQ Corporation Limited expects to be profitable despite recognizing a goodwill impairment charge.

site_title: Swiss bank Rahn+Bodmer admits to tax evasion in US probe
summary: Swiss private bank Rahn+Bodmer has admitted to helping US clients evade taxes between 2004 and 2012, concealing assets and filing false returns. The bank agreed to pay US$22 million in penalties, including US$4.9 million in unpaid taxes, US$9.7 million in unreported fees, and a US$7.4 million fine. In exchange, the charges will be dropped if the bank complies with certain rules for three years and cooperates with authorities. Approximately 340 clients were affected, with their assets hidden in Swiss bank accounts.

site_title: Tokyo area Covid-19 numbers showing signs of rising, health ministry says: Kyodo News
summary: Tokyo's coronavirus cases are showing signs of rising, with the seven-day average of new cases stuck in the mid- to high-200s since late February. The Japanese government extended the emergency declaration for Tokyo and three neighboring prefectures by 14 days, citing concerns over new, more infectious variants and slow vaccination efforts. The country has recorded about 441,000 coronavirus cases and 8,400 deaths. The decision on lifting the state of emergency will be made after expert input, with the Summer Olympics set to begin on July 23, highlighting the need for control and vaccination efforts.

site_title: Coin and stamp could reach US$15m each at US auction
summary: A 1933 Double Eagle gold coin and a British Guiana One-Cent Magenta stamp are set to be sold at auction in June for up to $15 million each. The 1933 Double Eagle is the only example legally sanctioned for private ownership, while the One-Cent Magenta is the sole-surviving item of its type. The coins and stamp come from the collection of fashion designer Stuart Weitzman, with proceeds going to charity. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity, according to Sotheby's expert Richard Austin, and could break new records for these rare treasures.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Epicentre Holdings, under judicial management, has terminated an agreement to transfer its Catalist listing to an entity linked to South Korean steelmaker Kossen, due to lack of progress on pre-clearance from the Singapore Exchange. MTQ Corporation Limited expects to recognize a goodwill impairment charge and certain provisions, resulting in an accounting loss for FY2021, but remains in a net cash position. LifeBrandz has appointed Lam Siew Kee as executive chairman and CEO, while Koufu Group Limited is set to receive S$11.8 million from a proposed property sale.

site_title: Oil advances with signs emerging of fuel consumption rebound
summary: Oil prices rose 2.2% on Thursday as signs of a fuel consumption rebound emerged, with vehicle miles driven in the US increasing 10% and UK road use climbing. The rally is driven by a surge in refined products, particularly gasoline, and a rapid vaccine rollout. However, OPEC downgraded its oil-market outlook, citing ongoing pandemic effects. The US crude market may need to trade at a bigger discount to the global Brent benchmark to boost exports, according to Energy Aspects.

site_title: Gold 'failing' as equity hedge, faces headwinds: BlackRock
summary: BlackRock warns that gold is "failing as an equity hedge" and its ability to hedge against inflation has been "somewhat exaggerated." The company's portfolio manager, Russ Koesterich, notes that gold's positive relationship with stocks and inflation is stronger when compared to tech stocks. With the US recovery gaining pace and Treasury yields surging, gold faces headwinds, particularly if interest rates rise. Koesterich advises investors to consider cash as a hedge, saying "gold should probably still be thought of as a dollar hedge."

site_title: UN fears 'crimes against humanity' in Myanmar
summary: The UN's top expert on rights in Myanmar, Thomas Andrews, has warned that the country's military is likely committing "crimes against humanity" amid a crackdown on protests since the February coup. At least 70 people have been killed, with widespread reports of acts of murder, enforced disappearance, and persecution. The military has accused ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi of corruption, but human rights groups have catalogued the use of "battlefield weapons" against unarmed protesters. The UN and diplomatic pressure are calling for de-escalation and dialogue, but the situation remains volatile.

site_title: EU threatens China with 'additional steps' over Hong Kong vote
summary: The European Union has warned China it could take "additional steps" over Beijing's decision to make sweeping changes to Hong Kong's electoral system, which the EU calls "significant" and "under increasing pressure" on democratic freedoms. The EU regrets the move, which includes powers to veto candidates, and calls on China to restore confidence in Hong Kong's democratic process. Brussels has previously limited surveillance equipment exports and discussed broader sanctions, with EU foreign ministers agreeing to increase support to civil society in Hong Kong. The EU will consider further action.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as US jobs data, stimulus spur global recovery bets
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% to 6,752, driven by hopes of a global economic recovery after US jobless claims fell and President Joe Biden signed a $1.9 trillion stimulus package. Technology stocks led gains, with Afterpay and Appen rising 3.1% and 2.4%, respectively. Mining stocks also increased, with OZ Minerals and Pilbara Minerals advancing 3.6% and 3.5%. The S&P/ASX 200 index posted its second consecutive weekly gain.

site_title: European countries suspend use of AstraZeneca shots over blood clot worries
summary: European health authorities have suspended use of AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine in several countries due to concerns over blood clot risks. Denmark, Norway, Iceland, Italy, and Romania paused shots after reports of severe blood clots, but regulators say there's no evidence of a causal link. The European Medicines Agency stated the vaccine's benefits outweigh risks, and AstraZeneca's data show no increased risk of blood clots. The suspensions are a setback for the vaccine, which has already faced production issues and lower efficacy rates in clinical trials.

images.alt_text: Health authorities in three European countries on Thursday suspended use of AstraZeneca's vaccine because of concerns that it might increase the risk of blood clots, but emphasised that they were taking action as a precaution and that there is no evidence of any causal link.

site_title: US: Dow, S&P 500 end at records, extending rally
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Thursday, driven by the passage of the $1.9 trillion economic relief package, which boosted confidence in the country's economic rebound. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 gained 1.0%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 2.5%. Investors are optimistic about the package's stimulus funds for households, small businesses, and low-income families. However, some economists fear it may catalyze inflation, prompting a shift in Federal Reserve policy.

site_title: Europe clears J&J's single-shot Covid-19 vaccine as roll-out falters
summary: The European Union has approved Johnson & Johnson's single-shot Covid-19 vaccine, allowing it to be delivered in Europe as the region seeks to speed up its inoculation campaign. The vaccine, which is recommended for those over 18 years old, was found to be 66% effective in preventing moderate-to-severe Covid-19 four weeks after inoculation. The approval comes as Europe struggles to control a spike in cases driven by a more contagious variant of the coronavirus, with countries imposing fresh lockdowns. The first shipments of the vaccine are expected to start in the second half of April.

site_title: Biden's US$1.9t stimulus bill a major catalyst for Singapore's recovery
summary: US President Joe Biden's US$1.9 trillion stimulus bill, set to be signed on Friday, could boost Singapore's exports and cyclical stocks, benefiting its economy. With an externally oriented economy, Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on the package. However, rising inflation expectations pose a risk. The stimulus could lift cyclical stocks such as banks and property developers, but market watchers caution against potential risks.

site_title: Jardine Matheson posts FY net loss of US$394m
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a full-year net loss of US$394 million, reversing a net profit of US$2.84 billion a year ago, due to weaker performances by Astra and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, as well as decreases in property valuations. The group's gearing has decreased to 6% from 7% at the end of 2019, but will increase to 16% after acquiring Jardine Strategic Holdings shares.

site_title: Boardroom sees opportunity in unicorns' stock option plans
summary: Boardroom Limited, a corporate services provider, sees increased demand for employee stock ownership plans (ESOPs) among Asian companies, driven by the Covid-19 pandemic. CEO Kim Teo hopes to serve more unicorns and provide ESOPs for a wider range of companies. ESOPs are a "core differentiator" for Boardroom, allowing companies to incentivize employees and manage cash flow better. The company expects growth across all segments and is open to overseas expansion, including acquisitions and digital entry into new markets.

site_title: ECB ramps up debt buying to contain rising bond yields
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has pledged to increase its government debt buying in the coming months to combat rising bond yields that threaten the region's economic recovery. The ECB will conduct purchases at a significantly higher pace than initially planned, with the overall size of the 1.85 trillion-euro program remaining unchanged. The move aims to contain inflation expectations and prevent a premature tightening of financing conditions for the economy. ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that the enhanced spending commitment is necessary to address rising bond yields and maintain financial stability.

site_title: Platinum Equity weighing sale of Singapore electronics maker PCI
summary: Platinum Equity, a private equity firm, is considering selling its investment in Singapore-based electronics manufacturing services provider PCI, potentially valuing the company at $400 million. The firm is working with financial advisers to gauge interest from potential buyers, and deliberations are at an early stage. PCI, which serves various industries, won a contract from the Singaporean government to manufacture wearable contact tracing devices in June. The company was taken private by Platinum Equity in 2019 after buying it from Chuan Hup Holdings.

site_title: America is returning to the world
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration is shifting towards a systemic, not transactional, approach to diplomacy, prioritizing strategic continuity and coherence. The administration has reengaged with international institutions, such as the Paris climate agreement, and is seeking to reform multilateral institutions. Biden's "galvanising mission" is to help democracy succeed, and he will work closely with democratic allies to achieve desired outcomes. However, the administration will not support regime change and will instead lead by example, highlighting the successes of democracies. The US will also negotiate hard with China on technological and economic matters, while avoiding clear ideological differences that could lead to conflict.

site_title: Rolls-Royce losses double to £3.2b in 2020 pandemic
summary: Rolls-Royce reports a net loss of £3.2 billion (US$4.4 billion) for 2020, more than doubling from £1.3 billion in 2019, due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the aviation sector. Revenues dropped 29% to £11.8 billion. The company saved £1.0 billion in costs by laying off 7,000 jobs and reducing costs. CEO Warren East stated that the pandemic had a severe impact on the group's performance and near-term outlook, prompting decisive actions to enhance finances and improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Canada's housing market is in a 'huge bubble', says economist
summary: Canada's housing market is in a "huge bubble" due to months of runaway price gains, according to economist David Rosenberg. Homes in the Toronto region sold for over C$1 million on average, while detached homes in Vancouver's west side sold for a median price of C$3.3 million. The price gains are out of proportion to the damaged labour market, with home prices up 18% year-over-year despite stagnant wage growth. This has caught the attention of policymakers, including the Bank of Canada, which held its key short-term rate at 0.25% due to low inflation.

site_title: History told through jewellery
summary: Simone Jewels, the Singapore-based jewellery brand founded by Simone Ng, is showcasing a 15-year retrospective exhibition featuring creations rooted in famous chapters of history. Ng, a self-proclaimed history junkie, draws inspiration from periods and figures such as the Hanging Gardens of Babylon, the Georgian era, and actress Hedy Lamarr. Her collections, including "From Russia With Love" and "One Thousand And One Nights," feature intricate pieces that tell the stories of these historical events and figures.

site_title: Debt restructuring: From trial to tribulation
summary: A debt restructuring process has begun for Hin Leong, an oil trader facing allegations of fraud, amidst the economic chaos caused by the pandemic. Many companies are seeking judicial management or scheme of arrangement to escape debt. However, experts warn that such workouts often do not succeed. Meanwhile, other business and financial news includes AIA's new CEO, the resurgence of the bitcoin market, and a review of the book "Journey In Blue".

site_title: Spanish ayes for Kulto
summary: Kulto, a newly opened paella and tapas eatery in Singapore, has received a satisfying start with its authentic Spanish cuisine. Chef-owner Jose Alonso, a native of Rioja, has created a comfortable middle ground between Spanish authenticity and Singaporean pragmatism. The restaurant offers a two-course set lunch for S$30++ and a la carte menu priced at an average of S$28 to S$38 per course. Highlights include the chilli crab croquettes, Iberico chorizo, and seafood paella, all showcasing Alonso's expertise in capturing the essence of Spanish street food. The restaurant has earned a rating of 7, praising its good to very good dining experience.

site_title: Shares of Chinese chip firms up on 'working with US'
summary: China's semiconductor industry group, the China Semiconductor Industry Association (CSIA), has agreed to work with the US Semiconductor Industry Association on chip-related issues, a rare example of bilateral cooperation. The two groups will meet twice a year to discuss policies on export curbs, supply chain safety, and encryption technology. Shares of Chinese chip firms rose after the announcement, with Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp (SMIC) rising 12% in Hong Kong trading. The move is seen as a positive step towards reducing tensions between the US and China in the semiconductor industry.

site_title: Credit Suisse tax whistle-blowers urge US to punish bank
summary: Former Credit Suisse bankers who exposed the bank's tax evasion scheme are urging US authorities to punish the bank beyond the $2.6 billion paid as part of a guilty plea in 2014. The bankers claim the conspiracy continued "well after the plea agreement and sentencing." They are seeking more severe punishment for the bank's actions, which involved helping wealthy Americans dodge taxes.

site_title: Government moves help mitigate Covid impact on US firms in Singapore
summary: US firms in Singapore are more resilient to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact compared to their peers in the region. The annual Asean Business Outlook Survey found that 80% of businesses in Singapore reported a negative impact, but only 13% were severely impacted. In contrast, 24% of Singapore-based American businesses expect the pandemic to continue weighing on revenue this year. Despite this, 54% of respondents expect continued revenue reductions, with 58% anticipating a 1-10% reduction.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Coupang prices US IPO above target
summary: South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang has priced its US IPO at $35 per share, raising $4.6 billion and making it one of the largest listings by an Asian company on a US exchange. The IPO surpasses Uber's 2019 listing and Coupang's market value would be around $60 billion. SoftBank-backed Coupang has aggressively expanded its delivery and logistics operations, with Japanese conglomerate SoftBank reaping a gain of over $16 billion from the IPO.

site_title: Manhattan renters trading up drive big gain in new leasing
summary: Manhattan renters drove a 112% surge in leasing last month, the largest monthly gain since April 2011, according to appraiser Miller Samuel and brokerage Douglas Elliman Real Estate. The increase was fueled by record concessions and falling prices, with higher-end units seeing a 114% jump in signings. Doorman buildings attracted new renters at a rate more than twice that of non-doorman buildings, and luxury units offered some of the biggest move-in concessions on record, with incentives averaging 2.1 months of free rent.

site_title: For digital creators, everything is for sale
summary: Digital creators are developing new revenue streams to monetize their lives, from polls on platforms like NewNew, which allows fans to vote on daily decisions, to nonfungible tokens (NFTs) that enable creators to sell digital art and media as rare collectibles. Platforms like PearPop and Stir facilitate creator collaborations and monetization, while Rally.io and $BOO Coin allow creators to build independent economies with their fans. As the creator economy grows, startups are creating new tools to help creators extract value from everyday interactions, providing an alternative to traditional social media platforms and brand deals.

site_title: Lego may ditch plastic bags in toy sets earlier than planned
summary: Lego, the European toymaker, may stop using plastic bags in its boxes earlier than planned, aiming to ditch fossil fuels for sustainable materials in its iconic building blocks by 2030. The company has set aside $400 million for a green transition and has made progress in producing 100 building blocks from sustainable materials. Lego aims to reduce its carbon emissions by 37% by 2032 and has developed a team of 100 people dedicated to creating environmentally friendly products.

site_title: House prices in central London slump even as rest of UK enjoys boom
summary: House prices in central London have slumped, with the City of London experiencing a 10.8% drop and Tower Hamlets seeing a 9.5% decrease in the year through January, according to e.surv. This contrasts with the rest of the UK, which has seen a housing boom during the pandemic. The drop is attributed to sliding rents and the shift of residents to greener areas with more space due to lockdowns. Despite government support measures, the decline may indicate that the movement from central London to suburbs has largely run its course.

site_title: Humour has an ROI. Here's how to laugh at work
summary: A Stanford business school professor and comedian argue that humor in the workplace can boost morale and the bottom line. They debunk common myths about humor, including the notion that it undermines seriousness and that people are born funny. Instead, they emphasize the importance of levity, a mindset that brings people together and creates a sense of lightness. To incorporate humor into work, leaders should focus on being generous with laughter, naming truths, and using humor to build trust and empathy. The pair also offer tips for maintaining levity on remote teams, including creating space for humor and being mindful of cultural differences.

site_title: What's hot in the property market for investors
summary: Investors are betting on real estate returns outpacing equities and bonds as the world recovers post-Covid. A historic Italian office building, Palazzo delle Poste, was sold to a group of private investors for 246.7 million euros, 27 million euros above the original asking price. Meanwhile, US mortgage rates have risen after five weeks of declines, and Manhattan rents have hit a record. The Q3 condo launch wave in Singapore may test demand for prime projects above the S$3,000 psf benchmark. UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high.

site_title: Sleuthing at Raffles Hotel
summary: The Raffles Hotel in Singapore is hosting a detective game, "The Curious Case Of The Missing Peranakan Treasure," a whodunit inspired by Agatha Christie's works. Guests can solve the mystery virtually at home or in-person at the hotel, with clues hidden in 360-degree views of the hotel's rooms and on-site treasure hunts. The game runs from April 1 to June 30, with prizes for successful solvers, including a stay in a Palm Court Suite. The hotel is offering "daycation" and "staycation" packages starting at S$450 and S$950 per night.

site_title: Li Keqiang says 2021 GDP growth target is 'not low'
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang defended the government's 6% GDP growth target for 2021, stating it is "not low" and will not be dramatically loosened. He emphasized the focus on consolidating China's economic recovery and avoiding a "sharp turn" in policy making. Li also vowed to secure people's livelihoods and create over 11 million urban jobs, with a push to open up to outside investment and services. The government will guide financial institutions to stabilize leverage ratios and support small and medium-sized enterprises, while continuing to boost domestic demand.

site_title: Soft US consumer prices calm inflation fears
summary: The US dollar index fell to its lowest in a week after the release of US consumer price index (CPI) data, calming inflation fears. Softer consumer prices eased concerns about a possible spike in inflation as economies reopen from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: CDL, Sincere in public blame game over China group's liquidity crunch
summary: CDL and Sincere Property Group are engaging in a public blame game over a liquidity crunch in a China developer. CDL claims Sincere Property has misrepresented the circumstances of their investment and the relationship between the two parties. Sincere Property accused CDL of holding up key decisions since taking control. The dispute raises questions about the handling of the investment and potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Businesses, workers well positioned to ride digital wave: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat stated that businesses and workers in Singapore are well-positioned to ride the digital wave, thanks to the progress made in the country's Smart Nation Initiative. The tech sector remains a "bright spot," and the government is utilizing industry transformation maps to support digitalization efforts.

site_title: Junta accuses Suu Kyi of accepting illegal payments; 8 more protesters killed
summary: Myanmar's military government accused deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi of accepting $600,000 in illegal payments, as well as gold, while in office. Eight protesters were killed in clashes with security forces, bringing the total death toll since the February 1 coup to over 60. The military maintains that a disputed election was marred by fraud, and has justified its takeover. The international community has rejected this claim, with Amnesty International accusing the military of adopting battle tactics against demonstrators.

site_title: Japanese suppliers step in to meet chip demand
summary: Japanese suppliers, including Towa Corp, Lasertec Corp, and Advantest Corp, are stepping in to meet the growing demand for semiconductors amidst the global chip shortage. The shortage, fueled by increased purchases of electronics during the pandemic, is affecting industries such as autos and household appliances, with potential losses of $60 billion in global sales in 2021. These suppliers, which specialize in chip manufacturing and testing, are expected to see increased orders in the second half of 2021, with Towa and Lasertec poised to benefit from the auto sector's shift to high-performance chips.

site_title: With green energy, Japanese governor wants to take Fukushima out of nuclear shadow
summary: Japanese Governor Taro Aso aims to transform Fukushima into a symbol for green energy, 10 years after the devastating 2011 nuclear meltdown. The prefecture seeks to shift its focus away from nuclear power, which has been marred by public opposition and concerns. Aso's plan includes investing in renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar power, and promoting sustainable development. While some residents remain skeptical, the governor hopes to create a new narrative for Fukushima and showcase its potential for green energy.

site_title: The next evolution of executive education
summary: The next evolution of executive education is underway, driven by the profound changes brought about by the COVID-19 pandemic. New technologies have forced firms to acquire new capabilities at lightning speed, defying long-standing assumptions about what can be done in the virtual world and its impact on the physical world. This shift marks the beginning of a new era, where disruption and innovation will continue to shape business. As a result, executive education must evolve to keep pace with these changes, prioritizing leadership development and complex problem-solving.

site_title: Surge in mortgage rates threatens to slow US housing rally
summary: US mortgage rates have surged, rising above 3% for the first time since July, threatening to slow the housing rally. The increase in borrowing costs is eroding purchasing power, making it harder for buyers to afford homes. Despite this, home prices are still expected to rise due to underlying demand and tight supply. Experts warn that buyers, particularly first-time homebuyers, will face challenges in navigating the market, and some may be forced to look at lower price points or reconsider their budgets.

images.alt_text: The bidding frenzy has been one of the big surprises of the pandemic. When lockdowns lifted, buyers - armed with low mortgage rates - emerged with a newfound urgency to acquire properties with enough room for home offices and Zoom school.

site_title: Handcrafted with passion
summary: A group of young woodcrafters in Singapore are reviving the tradition of handmade furniture, with a focus on locally sourced materials and sustainable practices. Alvan Koh, founder of Mokko Wood Studio, and Ahmad Habshee, founder of Urban Salvation, are two of the artisans who have gained popularity for their unique and handcrafted pieces. Their work emphasizes the importance of attention to detail, quality materials, and the preservation of traditional craftsmanship. Meanwhile, Darryl Loh, founder of The Table Guy, has also seen a growing interest in handcrafted furniture among homeowners, particularly those in their 20s and 30s. As the industry continues to grow, these woodcrafters hope to inspire a new generation of consumers to appreciate the value of handmade furniture.

site_title: More than 1,500 tech-related jobs at virtual career fair starting March 13
summary: More than 1,500 tech-related jobs are available at a virtual career fair starting March 13 in Singapore, with 100 organizations participating, including Shopee and Standard Chartered Bank. Positions range from tech-savvy roles like software developers to "tech lite" jobs that require minimal tech expertise. The virtual fair is part of the Smart Nation and U event, which aims to upskill workers and businesses in the digital economy. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for digital literacy and basic coding skills for future workforce.

site_title: US: Tech shares rally as ECB speeds bond purchases
summary: US tech shares rallied as the European Central Bank announced accelerated bond purchases to counter rising interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained 0.9% and 1.6%, respectively. Apple, Facebook, and Netflix shares surged. New jobless aid applications dropped to a pre-pandemic level, a positive sign ahead of the US stimulus package. The ECB's move aimed to prevent financing conditions from tightening, supporting the fragile eurozone economy.

site_title: Dairy Farm full-year net profit falls 16% to US$271m
summary: Dairy Farm International reported a full-year net profit of US$271 million, a 16% decline from the previous year, despite a 2% increase in total sales to US$28.2 billion. The group's operating profit for its grocery retail segment and Ikea grew, but was offset by lower profits in health and beauty and convenience businesses. The company attributed the decline to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly in Hong Kong, and introduced price investment campaigns to mitigate the effects. Dairy Farm recommended a final dividend of 11.5 US cents per share, 21% lower than the previous year.

site_title: Saxonia specials
summary: A Lange & Sohne celebrates two key anniversaries by releasing two new watch models: the Saxonia Outsize Date and the Saxonia Thin. The Saxonia Outsize Date features a pink and white gold case with a complex outsized date mechanism, while the Saxonia Thin boasts a shimmering black gold dial in a limited 50-watch edition. Both watches showcase the brand's commitment to mechanical innovation and classic design, with prices starting at S$39,700 for the Saxonia Outsize Date and S$22,800 for the Saxonia Thin.

site_title: Baidu looks to raise US$3.03b in Hong Kong listing
summary: Chinese search engine company Baidu plans to raise up to US$3.03 billion in its Hong Kong listing by selling 95 million shares, priced at HK$295 (S$51) per share for retail investors. The shares represent 3.4% of the company's total shares. Institutional investors may pay more for the shares, but specifics were not disclosed.

site_title: Indonesian foreign domestic worker is sole Covid-19 community case
summary: An Indonesian foreign domestic worker in Singapore has been identified as the sole community case of COVID-19, with a positive serological test result indicating a likely past infection. She was tested after being a participant in the same settling in programme as another infected individual. Epidemiological investigations suggest she was separately infected and not a close contact. The woman is asymptomatic and has been classified as an unlinked community case, with 28 cases discharged and 59,924 patients recovered.

site_title: ECB ramps up bond-buying speed to contain rising bond yields
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has pledged to increase its government debt purchases in the coming months to contain rising bond yields, which could threaten the region's economic recovery. The ECB will buy US$2.2 trillion in debt at a significantly higher pace than initially planned, with policy makers expecting a faster-than-expected economic rebound. The move aims to prevent premature tightening of financing conditions and maintain favorable financial conditions during the pandemic period.

site_title: As the aviation industry stabilises, long-term sustainable growth strategies are vital
summary: The aviation industry is recovering from the Covid-19 pandemic, but long-term sustainable growth strategies are crucial. Airlines must adopt change and innovation to regain passenger confidence. A worldwide survey found that 69% of industry professionals do not expect Covid-19 to impact passenger experience investments. Digital technologies, such as real-time data analytics, biometrics, and artificial intelligence, will drive recovery and future profitability growth. Airlines can use digital solutions to minimize touchpoints, enhance safety measures, and offer connected inflight experiences. The industry is also exploring new revenue streams, including sponsored access, streaming services, and targeted advertising.

site_title: Australia unveils A$1.2b Covid-19 stimulus package for tourism industry
summary: The Australian government has unveiled a A$1.2 billion stimulus package for the tourism industry, aiming to boost local travel and keep the sector afloat until foreign tourists return. The package includes airline ticket subsidies, cheap loans for small tour companies, and financial aid for major airlines. The move is designed to support the sector, which was severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, generating A$60.8 billion in GDP in 2018/19. The package includes A$200 million for Qantas and Virgin Australia to maintain mothballed aircraft and wages for international flying staff.

site_title: Feb new home sales plunge 60% on lack of new launches
summary: Singapore new home sales plummeted 60% in February, with 639 units sold, compared to 1,609 in January, largely due to the lack of new project launches and Chinese New Year holidays. Despite this, some high-end buyers are showing a preference for city fringe locations like Katong, with 11 homes sold in the S$5 million to S$10 million bracket, up from four in January. Experts attribute the slower sales to supply-led demand, with new projects stimulating sales during the month of launch, and expect numbers to pick up in March with upcoming launches.

site_title: Picture brightens for commercial EVs on rising demand from delivery customers
summary: Commercial electric vehicles (EVs) are experiencing a surge in demand due to soaring e-commerce and changing emissions regulations. Companies like Arrival and Volta Trucks are fielding multiple times the number of queries from potential customers as a result, with interest boosted by Britain's ban on new fossil-fuel vehicles by 2030 and the US government's stated interest in electrification. Despite higher upfront costs, experts predict that commercial EVs will become more competitive in terms of total cost of ownership, with battery prices expected to fall to parity with fossil-fuel vehicles by 2025.

site_title: China moves to overhaul Hong Kong politics
summary: China's parliament approved a draft decision to overhaul Hong Kong's electoral system, reducing democratic representation and introducing a mechanism to vet politicians' loyalty to Beijing. This move is part of Beijing's efforts to consolidate its authoritarian grip on Hong Kong, following the imposition of a national security law in June. The changes aim to further limit democratic freedoms in the global financial hub.

site_title: Glencore chairman to step down by 2022 after one more term
summary: Glencore's chairman Tony Hayward will step down by 2022 after a one-year extension of his term, allowing him to navigate the company through a change in leadership and ongoing legal probes. CEO Ivan Glasenberg is stepping down this year, replaced by Gary Nagle. A search for Hayward's successor is underway, amid the company's multiple probes, including a US Department of Justice investigation.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing emphasizes the country's potential to set regional standards for waste management. He believes this can attract a new generation of engineers to the industry, which is often overlooked for opportunities.

images.alt_text: 800 Super landed a S$46 million contract in Phnom Penh with the support of economic agencies, and plans to expand its operations across Cambodia and South-east Asia.

site_title: Malaysia imposes emergency law to clamp down on Covid fake news
summary: Malaysia has imposed an emergency law to combat Covid-19 fake news, taking effect on Friday. The ordinance carries hefty fines and up to six years in jail for publishing or reproducing false content related to the pandemic or emergency declaration. Critics view the move as a bid to shore up Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's position. The law does not require parliamentary approval, a departure from the country's constitution.

site_title: Singapore aiming to cement business hub status
summary: Singapore aims to solidify its position as a global business hub despite the post-pandemic new normal, where hubs will be fewer but of higher quality. Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing stated that Singapore will focus on building niche capabilities, enhancing enterprise capabilities, and developing intellectual capital. The country will reject export controls and partner with long-term investors to create a reputation as a reliable partner. Singapore policymakers acknowledge that the economy will change qualitatively, and they will focus on emerging areas like precision engineering, biotechnology, and urban solutions.

site_title: Shell CEO takes pay cut in 2020 for second straight year
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's CEO Ben van Beurden's pay package nearly halved in 2020, his second consecutive year of pay cuts, due to low oil prices and the Covid-19 pandemic. The company's profit tumbled to a two-decade low, and van Beurden's total remuneration for 2020 was 5.8 million euros, down from 10 million euros in 2019. Former BHP CEO Andrew Mackenzie will become Shell's next chairman, replacing Charles Holliday.

site_title: Restaurant wine directors worry about the future
summary: Restaurant wine directors worry about the future as the pandemic has posed daunting challenges, forcing many to furloughed and rehired, and some to auction off valuable wine collections. The role of wine in restaurants has evolved from an afterthought to a central component, but with the industry's future uncertain, some are concerned that good wine lists may be the first thing to go as restaurants try to cut costs. Many are adapting by converting to retail operations, downsizing wine lists, and exploring more humane restaurant models.

site_title: Aztech Global's IPO public offer 18.4 times subscribed
summary: Aztech Global's initial public offering (IPO) public offer received 18.4 times subscriptions, exceeding the available 3.5 million shares. The company received 4,143 valid applications for 64.42 million shares, with application monies totaling S$82.5 million. The IPO was 16.5 times subscribed, with cornerstone investors subscribing for 163.88 million shares. The estimated net proceeds to the company will be S$188.6 million.

site_title: CDL: Sincere Property 'misrepresented' circumstances of investment, relationship
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based property developer, has accused Sincere Property Group of "misrepresenting" the circumstances of their investment and relationship. Sincere Property claimed CDL held up key decisions, but CDL denies this, stating that it only acted to uphold its corporate governance standards. CDL also highlighted two material inaccuracies in Sincere Property's claims, including the lack of majority control over board decisions. The dispute comes after Sincere Property missed a bond repayment deadline, citing CDL's delays in supporting its management recommendations.

site_title: HSBC bosses try to quell investment bankers' ire over bonus cuts
summary: HSBC's CEO Noel Quinn and top executives defended bonus cuts to investment bankers and traders, citing a year marked by volatile markets and a pandemic-eroded overall performance. Despite a 3% revenue growth in the global banking and markets division, adjusted profit declined 7%, leading to reduced bonuses. The cuts affected top performers, with some bankers facing reduced or no bonuses, while junior staff were less affected. This move follows similar reductions at European lenders, including Deutsche Bank and UniCredit SpA, amid economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings' chief executive officer Noel Quinn and his top lieutenants were forced to defend bonus cuts to unhappy investment bankers and traders after a year marked by hectic dealmaking and volatile markets.

site_title: Jardine Matheson slides into full-year net loss of US$394m
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported a full-year net loss of US$394 million, reversing from a US$2.84 billion profit in 2020. Weaker performances by Astra and Jardine Cycle & Carriage, as well as decreased property valuations, contributed to the loss. Without property valuation decreases, the group would have recorded a US$1.09 billion net profit, 32% lower than the previous year. Astra's net profit was 26% lower than the previous year, at S$1.47 billion.

site_title: Firms restart London office moves after Covid pause
summary: Companies in the UK are reviving plans to move offices to London city centers, with AllianceBernstein Holding LP close to signing a lease on new space. The New York-based asset manager is set to rent over 50,000 square feet at 60 London Wall, following a pause in office moves last year. This trend suggests that some executives believe in a return to city centers after the coronavirus pandemic. The move is a sign of confidence in London's office market, which has been recovering since the pandemic pause.

images.alt_text: The vacancy rate in the City of London has reached a nine-year high, thanks mainly to an increase in surplus space that's being marketed for sublet.

site_title: Digital-only artwork fetches nearly US$70m at Christie's
summary: Digital artist Mike Winkelmann, aka Beeple, sold his digital artwork "Everydays - The First 5000 Days" for nearly US$70 million at Christie's, becoming one of the top three most valuable living artists. The work, a collage of 5,000 individual images, was sold as a Non-Fungible Token (NFT) and is authenticated by blockchain. The sale marked a significant milestone for NFTs, which have seen a surge in popularity in recent months, with Beeple expecting them to be digitized in the physical art market within the next five years.

site_title: BlackRock says gold 'failing' as equity hedge, faces risks
summary: BlackRock's portfolio manager Russ Koesterich warned that gold is "failing as an equity hedge" and its ability to hedge against inflation has been "somewhat exaggerated." The firm's blog post stated that gold's positive relationship with risky assets is weaker compared to tech stocks, making it less reliable for short-term investment horizons. Koesterich also noted that gold's value as a store of value over the long-term is more relevant.

site_title: Insurers, reinsurers prepare for battle over UK Covid-19 business payments
summary: UK insurance companies ordered to pay millions in claims for Covid-19 disruption to small businesses are facing a battle with reinsurers over who should foot the bill. Senior insurance executives say reinsurers are expected to take their share, but some are pushing back. Disputes may be settled in private arbitration hearings, with investors concerned about potential tail risks. Insurers have started making payments or settlement offers, but some businesses are expecting tens of thousands in payouts after a 10-month wait. The UK case affects 60 insurers and has implications for investors worldwide.

site_title: Firms with eco-friendly proposals awarded tenders to run two farms
summary: Singapore has awarded tenders to two companies, Nextgen Farms and Livfresh, to run eco-friendly farms in Sungei Tengah and Lim Chu Kang, respectively. The 20-year leases will focus on sustainable agriculture practices, including solar panels, smart lighting, and integrated waste management systems. The farms will utilize technology like hydroponic systems to increase productivity and reduce manpower. The move aims to promote food security and support the country's shift towards sustainable agriculture.

site_title: Chinese premier rejects idea that 2021 GDP growth target too 'low'
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang defended the government's target for 6% economic growth this year, saying it's "not low" and policies won't be dramatically loosened to chase higher growth. He emphasized the focus on consolidating China's economic recovery and warned against any "sharp turn" in policy making. Li also expressed confidence in meeting the 2021 target to create over 11 million urban jobs, with a focus on letting the market play a critical role in job generation. China will continue to open up to outside investment and boost domestic demand.

site_title: 'Superior digital experience' the key to unlocking greater growth: study
summary: A survey by VMware found that nearly eight in 10 South-east Asian consumers consider themselves "digitally curious" and value superior digital experiences. 69% of respondents in the region reported an enjoyable digital experience, contrasting with 40% globally. Financial services and retail are driving digital transformation in South-east Asia, with 63% and 60% of respondents saying they are happy to engage with such organisations. To unlock greater growth, companies must deliver "superior digital experiences" that provide high data protection, ease of access, and fast service speeds.

site_title: Passing of US stimulus bill lifts Asian markets; STI up 0.85%
summary: US President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus bill passed in Congress lifted Asian markets, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 0.85% and closing at 3,106.01. The Nikkei 225 Index in Tokyo rose 0.60%, while the Hang Seng Index in China increased 1.65%. Investor sentiment improved due to the stimulus package and benign US inflation data, with market strategist Geoff Howie attributing the gains to a stabilizing tone in US Treasury yields.

site_title: Europe: Stocks ahead at open
summary: European stock markets rose in opening deals on Thursday, tracking Asian gains as inflation concerns eased. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.3%, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris' CAC 40 rose 0.1% and 0.4%, respectively. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare stocks. US markets also reached fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Myanmar junta says Suu Kyi accepted illegal payments of US$600,000, plus gold
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi accepted illegal payments worth US$600,000 plus gold, according to a junta spokesman. President Win Myint and several Cabinet ministers also allegedly engaged in corruption. The military council reiterated they will hold an election and hand power to the winning party after a certain period. The allegations are the strongest yet by the military since the coup on February 1. Suu Kyi and other leaders remain under house arrest.

site_title: Digitalisation the only way forward for businesses to thrive: panellists
summary: Singapore Business Federation chairman Lim Ming Yan emphasizes that businesses must judiciously select technological solutions to thrive in a digitalized world. Micro businesses require pre-selected solutions for backend functions, while larger companies must rethink their business models for automation. Digitalization, accelerated by the pandemic, is a necessary step for companies, with some 47 participating companies seeing a 30% improvement in productivity. Panellists stress the importance of buy-in from management and worker willingness to reskill for digitalization to succeed, and highlight the need for companies to rethink their business models to stay competitive.

site_title: Two land parcels awarded to innovative, eco-friendly tenderers
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) has awarded two land parcels for innovative and eco-friendly farming projects. Nextgen Farms Pte Ltd and Livfresh Pte Ltd won the tender for a vegetable farming plot in Sungei Tengah for S$174,000, while Hay Dairies Pte Ltd secured a general agriculture plot in Lim Chu Kang for S$500,000. The successful proposals incorporated productive farming systems, eco-friendly features, and innovative technologies, such as solar panels and hydroponic systems, to enhance farm productivity and reduce manpower.

site_title: Soilbuild Reit unitholders vote in favour of privatisation, Australia assets disposal
summary: Soilbuild Business Space Reit's unitholders voted 91.94% in favour of the proposed privatisation offer from Blackstone Real Estate and Lim Chap Huat, with 8.06% opposing. The offer, valued at S$0.55 per unit, represents a 34.5% premium over the 12-month average price. In conjunction, unitholders approved the disposal of Australian assets, with 83.67% voting in favour and 16.33% opposing. Trading in the units was halted before the market opened on Thursday.

site_title: Shell fuel sales fall drives 16% drop in its 2020 carbon emissions
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 16% drop in its 2020 carbon emissions, primarily due to a sharp decline in oil and gas sales during the coronavirus pandemic. The company's total emissions fell to 1.38 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide, a 4% reduction from 2019. Shell attributes this reduction to lower energy demand and has begun an overhaul to shift away from oil and gas towards low-carbon energy, aiming to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions to net zero by mid-century.

site_title: Epicentre terminates agreement to transfer listing to South Korean steelmaker
summary: Epicentre Holdings has terminated an agreement to transfer its Catalist listing to an entity linked to South Korean steelmaker Kossen. The agreement, signed last year, was valued at S$3 million, but Kossen and its advisory firm Tardis Capital failed to obtain pre-clearance from the Singapore Exchange since October. This decision comes after Epicentre's judicial managers expressed concerns over the lack of progress in the transaction. The termination marks a setback for Epicentre's restructuring efforts under judicial management.

site_title: Credit Suisse tax whistle-blowers urge US to punish bank
summary: Former Credit Suisse Group bankers who blew the whistle on their employer's tax evasion scheme are urging the US to punish the bank beyond the $2.6 billion it paid in 2014. The whistleblowers claim the bank's conspiracy continued after the initial plea agreement, with a lawyer stating that Credit Suisse's misrepresentations and material omissions about a wealthy American client, Dan Horsky, may have led to the bank violating its plea agreement. If found in violation, Credit Suisse could face additional penalties and potentially have its US license revoked.

site_title: Credit Suisse freezes US$1b of funds as scandal widens
summary: Credit Suisse has frozen US$1 billion of funds from its US$10 billion supply chain finance strategy, following the collapse of Lex Greensill's empire. The Swiss lender froze redemptions and suspended fund valuations after doubts emerged about asset valuations. This move comes after Credit Suisse previously froze US$10 billion of funds last week. The scandal has widened, with the bank's exposure to Greensill's failed empire now totaling US$1 billion. The bank's actions aim to mitigate potential losses and protect investors.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group froze four more funds that invested in the bank's US$10 billion supply chain finance strategy, adding to the widening scandal surrounding the bank's exposure to Lex Greensill's failed empire.

site_title: In the can: Armed Hong Kong toilet roll heist gang jailed
summary: Three men in Hong Kong were jailed for 40 months each for armed robbery during the early stages of the coronavirus pandemic. In February 2020, they stole 600 toilet rolls worth HK$1,700 from a supermarket in Mongkok. The men used a knife to threaten a delivery driver, but later admitted to the crime and paid for the toilet rolls. The trial judge described the crime as pre-meditated and deserving of a custodial sentence, highlighting the desperation and chaos caused by the pandemic's impact on the city's supermarket supplies.

site_title: Pfizer to consider new production sites only after 'pandemic supply phase'
summary: Pfizer will consider expanding its COVID-19 vaccine production outside the US and Europe only after the "pandemic supply phase" ends. The company has not been in discussions with India for local production, despite previous reports, and has pulled its application for emergency approval in the country due to a regulatory decline. Pfizer remains committed to equitable and affordable access to its vaccine globally, including in India, and will evaluate opportunities for local manufacturing once the pandemic supply phase is over.

site_title: Philippines' first billion dollar IPO seeks to tap into meat alternative boom
summary: Monde Nissin, a four-decade-old food conglomerate in the Philippines, is set to list its shares in the first half of this year, aiming to raise up to $1.73 billion in its first billion-dollar IPO. The company's meat alternative business, acquired in 2015, contributed 22% to its net sales of $1.4 billion last year. Monde Nissin's strong market position and core profit margins of 25% make it an attractive investment opportunity, particularly for sustainability funds and global investors.

site_title: China's Parliament moves to overhaul Hong Kong's electoral system
summary: China's parliament approved a draft decision to overhaul Hong Kong's electoral system, further reducing democratic representation and introducing a mechanism to vet politicians' loyalty to Beijing. The changes aim to consolidate Beijing's authoritarian grip on the global financial hub, following the imposition of a national security law in June. The measures virtually eliminate opposition influence in elections, potentially leading to politicians competing over loyalty rather than governance ideas. The changes alter the size and composition of Hong Kong's legislature and electoral committee in favor of pro-Beijing figures.

site_title: H&M says one fifth of stores still shuttered by pandemic
summary: H&M reports that around 1,050 of its 5,000 stores remain temporarily closed due to the Covid-19 pandemic and government measures. The Swedish fashion retailer is expected to report a 28% drop in net sales for its fiscal first quarter, which ends on March 31. This follows a 70% fall in profit for Inditex, the owner of Zara, which predicted a return to healthy sales once lockdowns are lifted.

images.alt_text: Around 1,050 of H&M's around 5,000 stores remain temporarily closed due to the Covid-19 pandemic and government measures to stop it.

site_title: Lego may ditch plastic bags in toy sets earlier than planned
summary: Lego, Europe's largest toymaker, is moving towards a greener future by potentially ditching plastic bags in its toy sets earlier than planned. The company aims to stop using plastic bags before its 2025 deadline. According to CEO Niels Christiansen, the transition is progressing well, with adjustments to machines in its factories underway. Lego is making significant strides in reducing its reliance on fossil fuels, marking a significant shift towards a more sustainable future.

site_title: Seven killed in Myanmar protests; army accused of using battle tactics
summary: Seven people were killed in Myanmar protests against the military coup, with six killed in the central town of Myaing and one in the North Dagon district of Yangon. Rights groups, including Amnesty International, accused the army of using lethal force against protesters, labeling the killings as extrajudicial executions. The incident brings the total number of protester deaths to over 60 since the February coup.

site_title: Eight new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 8 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 60,070. One case was in the community, while the remaining 7 were imported cases who were placed on stay-home notice. The number of community cases has decreased to 2 in the past week. 59,896 patients have fully recovered, and 25 remain in hospital, including 1 in critical condition. Globally, the virus has infected over 117 million people and claimed over 2.6 million lives.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post biggest jump in two weeks as inflation worries ease
summary: South Korean shares posted their biggest single-day jump in two weeks, closing up 1.88% to 3,013.70, as inflation worries eased following subdued US consumer price data. The data showed underlying inflation remained tepid, boosting Asian shares. Preliminary exports data also jumped 25.2% from a year earlier, further boosting sentiment. Heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose, while the won strengthened and bond yields fell. Foreigners were net buyers of 1.70 trillion won worth of shares, and the won ended 0.60% higher than its previous close.

site_title: Manhattan renters trading up drive big gain in new leasing
summary: Manhattan renters drove a surge in leasing last month, with new lease signings jumping 112% in February from the same period last year, according to a report by Miller Samuel and Douglas Elliman Real Estate. Higher-end units saw the biggest gains, with doorman buildings attracting new renters at more than twice the rate than those without the amenity. Despite a decline in luxury unit prices, landlords offered record concessions, including 2.1 months of free rent on new leases, as the city's listing inventory rose 154% to 11,750 units.

site_title: US, China envoys to hold first in-person meeting in Alaska
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan will meet with Chinese counterparts Yang Jiechi and Wang Yi in Alaska on March 18-19, marking the highest-level in-person exchange since President Joe Biden took office. The meeting aims to address US concerns over China's human rights record, industrial policies, and South China Sea disputes, while also exploring potential cooperation on climate change. The meeting follows a phone call between Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping in February and comes amid a deterioration in US-China ties under former President Donald Trump.

site_title: Malaysia property stocks flash bullish sign as rally mounts
summary: Malaysia's property stocks are experiencing a rally, with developers such as Gromutual and Eco World Development seeing significant gains. The Bursa Malaysia Property Index has climbed for a fifth day, its longest streak of gains this year. A vaccine rollout and easing infection rates are contributing to the improved outlook for the battered industry. Technical indicators suggest a "new uptrend" is unfolding, with the property gauge surpassing its 50-week exponential moving average line for the first time since 2017.

site_title: Boost digital adoption for businesses and workers to stay ahead: DPM Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the importance of digital adoption for businesses and workers to stay ahead in the digitalisation journey. Singapore remains focused on its Smart Nation initiative, with the digital economy as a key research and development focus for the next five years. The country aims to seize the best opportunities by working with both businesses and workers to get ahead in their digital transformation.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, driven by hopes for a global economic recovery, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.60% to 29,211.64. The Topix index also increased 0.27% to 1,924.92. Investors are shifting focus to major central bank meetings and a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose sharply, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.65% to 29,385.61, following benign US inflation data that eased concerns about a global price surge. Asian markets tracked a record US close, with the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also advancing. The gains were attributed to a positive global economic outlook and easing interest rate concerns.

site_title: Australia: Shares give up gains as Afterpay, big banks drop
summary: Australian shares closed flat on Thursday, despite early gains, as a tourism support package countered losses in big banks and Afterpay. The S&P/ASX 200 index settled at 6,713.90, repeating a trend of early momentum fizzling by midday. Analyst Steven Daghlian attributed the market's caution to the stabilizing bond yields, which have been a concern after recent strong runs.

site_title: Rolls-Royce plunges to worse than expected £4b loss
summary: Rolls-Royce, a British engine-maker, reported a £4 billion loss in 2020, worse than expected, due to the pandemic's impact on air travel. The company's income dried up as airlines stopped flying, forcing it to raise £5 billion from shareholders and loans. However, Rolls-Royce expects its cash outflow to improve in 2021, with a target of £2 billion, assuming airlines fly 55% of 2019 levels. The company's cash outflow is expected to turn positive in the second half of 2021 as travel restrictions ease and vaccine programs progress.

site_title: Warren Buffett net worth surpasses US$100b: Forbes
summary: Warren Buffett's net worth has surpassed $100 billion, joining an elite group of executives including Jeff Bezos, Elon Musk, Bernard Arnault, and Bill Gates. His Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate owns over 60 companies and has a record share price, pushing his fortune to $100.3 billion. Buffett, 90, is a generous donor, having given over $41 billion to charitable organizations. He is one of the most successful and respected executives, but his fortune has never before reached such a peak.

site_title: More than half of US firms in Asean expect Covid-19 to continue hitting revenue in 2021
summary: US firms in Asean expect Covid-19 to continue negatively impacting revenue in 2021, with 54% anticipating reduced revenue. The majority (58%) foresee a 1-10% reduction. Only 27% expect a positive impact, and 19% are neutral. The survey, conducted by Blackbox Research, highlights ongoing economic challenges for businesses in the region.

site_title: Condo, HDB rents rise again on lower volumes in February: SRX
summary: Singapore condo and HDB rents rose in February, with condos increasing 1% month-on-month and HDBs up 0.5%. Condo rents are now 1.2% higher than last year, while HDB rents have risen 5.2% from June 2020. The decrease in available listings due to high occupancy rates is contributing to the rent increases. Experts predict the leasing market may return to pre-Covid normalcy as border restrictions ease and the employment market expands.

images.alt_text: Rents continued to rise last month for both private apartments and Housing Board flats, while the number of leasings for both fell with the double-whammy of the Chinese New Year lull and Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Copper wobbles mask ongoing demand strength, says top supplier
