summary: Copper prices have retreated 6% from their record high last month, but the underlying trend of rising demand remains intact, according to Chile's Energy and Mining Minister Juan Jobet. Despite daily market fluctuations, Jobet attributes the price drop to the rise of the US dollar and bond yields, rather than cooling Chinese demand. He emphasizes that the ongoing global recovery, driven by vaccinations and stimulus, is the key driver of copper demand.

images.alt_text: The official overseeing the world's biggest copper industry isn't losing any sleep over the recent pullback in prices, saying the underlying trend of rising demand remains intact despite hard-to-read daily market gyrations.

site_title: Covid outbreak hits Hong Kong banks, gyms, international schools
summary: A coronavirus outbreak at a Hong Kong gym has spread to international schools and fitness centers, infecting hundreds of close contacts who are being sent to mandatory quarantine. The outbreak is linked to a 27-year-old trainer at Ursus Fitness, where five staff members and a client tested positive for Covid-19. At least three schools have been closed, and employees at some banks were advised to work from home, as the city emerges from a prolonged round of social restrictions. The outbreak is another blow to Hong Kong's efforts to contain the virus.

site_title: BHP says acquisitions unlikely near-term given high commodity prices
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest listed miner, is unlikely to make major acquisitions in the near term due to high commodity prices, according to CEO Mike Henry. Instead, the company will focus on exploration, innovation, and increasing value from existing assets. BHP is targeting "future-facing commodities" like copper and nickel for electric vehicles, and is exploring hydrogen to curb emissions in industrial processes. The company plans to boost its permanent workforce to 60-80% of total staff to increase safety and productivity.

site_title: Platinum Equity weighing sale of Singapore electronics maker PCI
summary: Platinum Equity, a US-based private equity firm, is considering selling its investment in Singapore electronics manufacturing services provider PCI. The firm is working with financial advisers to gauge interest from potential buyers, with a possible deal valuation at around $400 million. PCI, which serves various industries, won a contract from the Singaporean government to manufacture wearable contact tracing devices in June 2021. The decision to sell is at an early stage, and Platinum Equity could decide not to proceed.

site_title: Personal travel will return from second half of 2021: Iata chief
summary: International Air Transport Association (IATA) chief Alexandre de Juniac predicts personal and leisure travel will return from the second half of 2021, with business travel recovering slower. The recovery will be driven by vaccination and testing protocols, such as IATA's Travel Pass app, which will speed up border reopening and international flights. Despite gradual reopenings, air passenger traffic volume is expected to remain low compared to pre-Covid-19 2019. IATA and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (Icao) will accelerate protocols for safe air travel, but consolidation in the industry is unlikely due to cash shortages and government bailouts.

site_title: Facebook halts project for undersea data cable to Hong Kong
summary: Facebook has halted its project for a trans-Pacific undersea cable connecting California and Hong Kong due to US government concerns about potential national security risks related to China's tightening control over Hong Kong. The project, which was initially filed in 2018, was intended to facilitate high-speed data communications between the US, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and the Philippines. The US Department of Justice recommended bypassing Hong Kong, citing the potential for Beijing to collect US communications traffic. Facebook plans to reconfigure the system to meet US government concerns.

site_title: At least 10 hacking groups using Microsoft software flaw: researchers
summary: At least 10 hacking groups are using recently discovered flaws in Microsoft's mail server software to break into targets worldwide, according to cybersecurity company ESET. The vulnerabilities leave open the door to industrial-scale cyber espionage, allowing malicious actors to steal emails and move elsewhere in the network. Tens of thousands of organizations have already been compromised, and new victims are being reported daily. Microsoft has issued fixes, but the pace of updates has been slow, leaving some systems open to hackers.

images.alt_text: At least 10 different hacking groups are using recently discovered flaws in Microsoft's mail server software to break in to targets around the world, cybersecurity company ESET said in a blog post on Wednesday.

site_title: One-third of Singaporeans made first online purchase amid Covid-19 measures: poll
summary: Singaporeans made an online purchase for the first time during the Covid-19 pandemic, with 31% of consumers shopping online more frequently, and 52% shopping less in physical stores. A Visa study found that 41% of online shoppers use social media channels, 25% use home delivery, and 20% expect to continue shopping from large online marketplaces after the pandemic. Experts believe that these new shopping habits will outlast the pandemic, with 59% of Singaporeans planning to travel internationally once border restrictions are lifted.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall at Thursday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 4.37 points or 0.27% to 1,635.46 at the open on Thursday, with 357.34 billion lots traded worth RM150.55 million.

site_title: Tokopedia denies report on sales agreement with Gojek
summary: Indonesian e-commerce platform Tokopedia has denied a report that it signed a sales agreement with Gojek as part of their planned merger. The report, published by D-Insights, claimed Tokopedia and Gojek had agreed on a conditional sales and purchase agreement, with Gojek owning 60% of the merged entity. Tokopedia's vice-president stated the news is inaccurate and speculative, while Gojek declined to comment on the matter. The two companies are reportedly finalizing merger terms, with the goal of pursuing an initial public offering in Indonesia and the US.

site_title: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantations says securities panel probes green disclosures
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission is investigating Sime Darby Plantations, the world's largest producer of sustainably-made palm oil, following a complaint by anti-trafficking group Liberty Shared over alleged wrongful disclosures in the company's 2019 Sustainability Report. The US had previously issued a "withhold release order" on the company due to accusations of forced labor. Sime Darby has begun legal action against Liberty Shared's managing director and will cooperate fully with the Securities Commission investigation. This marks the first time the company has taken legal action against an NGO in its 200-year history.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Securities Commission has begun an investigation into palm giant Sime Darby Plantations (SDP), the company said on Thursday, following a complaint by a non-government body in the wake of a US ban on imports over accusations of forced labour.

site_title: Gold scales one-week peak as dollar, US yields ease
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-week peak, reaching US$1,732.05 per ounce, after weaker-than-expected US inflation data halted Treasury yield advances and eased dollar strength. The US CPI data did not change expectations of inflation exceeding the Federal Reserve's 2% target, a positive factor for gold. Benchmark US Treasury yields remained subdued, and investors await the European Central Bank policy meeting for potential action.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at start of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened flat on Thursday, following two days of gains, as investors reacted to welcome news about Joe Biden's stimulus and lingering inflation worries. The Hang Seng Index rose 2.46 points to 28,909.98, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased.

site_title: Bank of Korea flags chances of faster-than-expected inflation pace
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, has warned that consumer inflation could increase faster than expected due to the ongoing recovery from the pandemic. The bank raised this year's inflation outlook to 1.3% from 1% earlier and kept the policy interest rate unchanged at 0.5%. This comes as South Korea's consumer inflation accelerated to a 13-month high in February due to improving domestic demand and rising global oil prices. The Bank of Korea will closely monitor local bond yields and take measures if volatility worsens.

site_title: Indonesia bus plunge kills two dozen pilgrims
summary: A bus carrying 66 pilgrims, including junior high school students, plunged down a 20-metre ravine in West Java's Sumedang district, killing at least 27 people, including the driver and teenage passengers. Rescuers worked through the night to pluck survivors from the wreckage, with 39 injured people rescued. Authorities are probing the accident's cause, which is believed to be related to a poorly maintained road and flouted traffic rules.

site_title: HSBC toughens stance on fossil fuel funding after shareholder heat
summary: HSBC has set new targets to phase out support for the coal industry by 2030 in developed countries and 2040 in developing countries, aligning with the Paris agreement on climate change. The bank's move comes after investors managing $2.4 trillion in assets withdrew a resolution to bind the bank to stronger commitments, instead opting for a compromise. HSBC will report on its progress annually and has explicitly stated the expansion of coal-fired power is incompatible with the Paris agreement goals. The bank's new stance reflects mounting public and political pressure to reduce fossil fuel financing.

site_title: Samsung to drive growth in South-east Asia through Galaxy, consumer products
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to drive growth in South-east Asia and Oceania through its Galaxy and consumer products, with a focus on the region's young population and digital natives. The company's newly appointed CEO for the region, Sangho Jo, believes the region has strong potential for growth and will be integral to Samsung's long-term plans. The company will focus on its mobile communications and consumer electronics segments, with a emphasis on affordable and mid-tier products, as well as supporting digital ambitions of nations and communities.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Snyk raises US$300m in Series E round; Temasek joins as new investor
summary: Cybersecurity firm Snyk has raised $300 million in its Series E funding, valuing the company at $4.7 billion. Temasek Holdings joined as a new investor, along with several other firms, in the round led by Accel and Tiger Global. The company plans to use the funding to accelerate growth, expand its product offerings, and enter new markets, particularly in Asia-Pacific and Japan. Snyk's CEO Peter McKay stated that the investment will enable the company to double down on its product-led growth strategy and expand its customer roster.

site_title: US may label Taiwan currency manipulator, says central bank governor
summary: Taiwan's central bank governor Yang Chin-long said the US may label the island a currency manipulator, citing three criteria. However, he believes this would have no immediate disadvantage for Taiwan. The US criteria include a large trade surplus, a high trade deficit, and the inability to increase foreign exchange reserves. Yang's comments come after Taiwan reached these criteria, but he downplays the potential impact, stating it would not be too serious for the island.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher ahead of ECB
summary: Tokyo stocks opened 0.05% higher, supported by US key indexes, ahead of the ECB monetary decision. The Nikkei 225 index rose 13.77 points to 29,050.33, while the Topix index gained 0.22 points to 1,919.96. Investors remained cautious despite the rally, awaiting the ECB's decision.

site_title: Singapore can set the region's standards for waste management: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore can set the region's standards for waste management, attracting a new generation of engineers to join the industry, said Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing. The country's waste management industry employs over 80,000 workers and has helped Singapore firms secure contracts in Cambodia and other markets. Chan highlighted the industry's potential for growth and innovation, citing 800 Super Holdings' successful bid to collect and transport solid waste in Phnom Penh, valued at S$46 million.

site_title: What's in the US$1.9t stimulus Bill Joe Biden is about to sign
summary: US President Joe Biden is set to sign the US$1.9 trillion stimulus bill, which includes a wave of new spending, an extension of jobless benefits, and direct household payments. The legislation includes funding for vaccinations and virus-testing programs, state and local aid, and a massive expansion of the child tax credit program. The bill also includes provisions for rental assistance, nutrition assistance, and small businesses, and aims to curb child poverty. The package rivals the US$2 trillion Cares Act in size and scope, and follows a US$900 billion December relief package.

site_title: Singapore shares advance after US stimulus Bill; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore shares rose 0.3% after the US Congress approved a $1.9 trillion economic relief package, lifting the Dow to a record high. The positive sentiment was attributed to the Biden stimulus package, expected to be signed by the president tomorrow. This cyclical rotation on Wall Street overnight and optimism over the stimulus drove Singapore stocks to a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: A strawberry with a US$10 price tag helps one tsunami-hit town to recover
summary: A Japanese town, Yamamoto, is recovering from the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami with the help of premium strawberries priced at US$10 each. GRA Inc, a startup founded by the grandson of a local farmer, has boosted productivity by consolidating farmland and using technology to increase strawberry production. The town now produces more strawberries than before the disaster, with production levels higher than in 2011. GRA's high-end strawberries have gained national acclaim and are sold in upscale department stores, with plans to attract new farmers and boost sales overseas.

site_title: Five things to know about the US$1.9t Covid-19 relief bill
summary: The US House of Representatives passed the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, President Joe Biden's first major victory in office. The bill includes a $1,400 stimulus payment for individuals earning under $75,000 and $150,000 for married couples, $160 billion for vaccine and testing programs, $350 billion in aid for states and local governments, and aims to boost the global economy, with the OECD forecasting a 5.6% global growth rate. The bill is expected to return the US to "full employment" next year, according to US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen.

images.alt_text: The US$1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief bill hands President Joe Biden his first major victory in office.

site_title: UN rebukes Myanmar's military over violent protest clampdown
summary: The UN Security Council has condemned Myanmar's military for its violent crackdown on peaceful anti-coup protesters, with over 60 deaths and 2,000 arrests reported since the military ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi. The US has also sanctioned members of the junta leader's family, and thousands of government workers are participating in a civil disobedience movement to paralyze the economy. The international community continues to demand the release of political prisoners and the generals' relinquishment of power.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set to firm after Dow hits record
summary: Asian stocks are set to open higher after the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a record close, driven by a calming report on US consumer prices. The Dow rose 1.45% to a record high, while the S&P 500 gained 0.60%. Asian markets, including Japan's Nikkei 225, Hong Kong's Hang Seng, and Australia's S&P/ASX 200, are expected to open higher, with futures adding 0.02-0.24%. Analysts expect a reflation trade to support markets, with the US dollar moving lower.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street record as inflation fears ease
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, tracking Wall Street's record close, as inflation concerns eased. The Dow's new record was fueled by news of Joe Biden's stimulus package clearing Congress, injecting nearly $2 trillion into the economy. Investors shifted focus from inflation fears to the global recovery and pandemic progress. Despite tariff uncertainty, the Singapore Stock Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai and Taipei all rose more than one per cent while Seoul jumped two per cent. Tokyo, Singapore, Wellington also rose while Sydney was flat, though Manila dipped.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Coupang prices US IPO above target
summary: South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang has priced its US$4.6 billion initial public offering (IPO) above its target, with 130 million shares sold at $35 each. The IPO is the largest on a US exchange since Uber's 2019 listing and the biggest by an Asian company since Alibaba's 2014 listing. Japanese conglomerate SoftBank, Coupang's largest shareholder, has reaped a gain of over $16 billion from the IPO, bolstering its reputation in backing successful startups.

site_title: Top US, China diplomats to hold first in-person talks of Biden presidency
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken will meet with top Chinese officials on March 18 in Alaska, marking the first high-level in-person contact between the two countries under the Biden administration. The meeting aims to address US concerns, including human rights in China's Xinjiang region, and will be followed by a visit to Japan and South Korea. National security adviser Jake Sullivan and State Councillor Wang Yi will join the meeting, which is seen as a diplomatic push to solidify US alliances in Asia and Europe to counter China's growing military and economic power.

site_title: Sydney housing boom lifts prices to a record high
summary: Sydney housing prices have reached a record high, with a 5.7% gain since October last year, surpassing the 2017 peak. The city's property values are now higher than ever before. However, this boom poses challenges for non-homeowners, who face rising prices and incomes that are not keeping pace. Experts attribute the rapid gains to low borrowing rates, an improving economy, and government incentives, which also drive price increases in other cities like Singapore and Canada. The surge in prices threatens to swell household debt and make it harder for young people to buy their first property.

site_title: Sincere accuses CDL of holding up decision making
summary: Chinese real estate company Chongqing Sincere Yuanchuang Industrial accuses its parent company, City Developments Limited (CDL), of delaying decision making following a missed debt payment. This has stunted opportunities to raise funds and improve cash flow, highlighting the challenges faced by foreign companies acquiring companies in Singapore. The rift between Sincere's local management team and CDL's headquarters has been exposed after Singapore's richest property family acquired the company last year. The missed bond repayment deadline has underscored the challenges of foreign companies in Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Sincere Property Group said CDL delayed decision-making, stalling opportunities to raise funds and improve cash flow.

site_title: L Catterton prices SPAC IPO at US$10 per unit, to make Nasdaq debut on March 11
summary: L Catterton Asia Acquisition, backed by luxury French fashion house LVMH, priced its SPAC IPO at US$10 per unit, with 25 million units to be listed on the Nasdaq under "LCAAU" on March 11. Each unit consists of one share of Class A common stock and a redeemable warrant. The offering is expected to close on March 15, with the underwriter having a 45-day option to purchase up to an additional 3.75 million units. L Catterton has not yet selected a business combination target, focusing on high-growth consumer technology sectors in Asia.

site_title: Los Angeles cleared to reopen indoor dining, theatres from this weekend
summary: Los Angeles and southern California can partially reopen indoor dining and movie theatres starting this weekend, following key health criteria. The region has seen a decline in infection rates due to a vaccination rollout, and the state aims to deliver two million doses to vulnerable communities by Friday. Indoor dining and theatres will operate at reduced capacities, while theme parks, including Disneyland, will reopen at limited capacity from April 1. However, local counties can enforce stricter restrictions than state mandates.

site_title: Singapore seeks to cement business hub status in post-Covid new normal: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore aims to maintain its status as a global business hub in the post-pandemic new normal, Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing said. The country has never restricted exports of products from mask manufacturer 3M, even during the Covid-19 pandemic, to build a reputation as a partner for long-term investment. Chan anticipates that business hubs will be fewer but of higher quality in the future, reflecting Singapore's commitment to fostering a favorable business environment.

site_title: Roblox, after winning over kids, becomes a hit on Wall Street
summary: Roblox, a popular gaming platform among children, made a significant debut on Wall Street, with its shares surging 54% to US$69.50. The company's direct listing on the New York Stock Exchange valued it at around US$40 billion. This success comes after the platform's popularity soared during the pandemic, making it a pandemic hit.

site_title: Do internal estimates of property values have a place in calculating RNAV?
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) reported two RNAV per share figures, S$14.26 and S$16.88, calculated using internal estimates of asset values, including hotel revaluation surpluses. The S$16.88 figure was based on internal estimates and external valuations, but specifics were not provided. CDL's accounting policy considers hotels as operating assets, recorded at cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Analysts believe the RNAV numbers are meaningful, despite the lack of disclosure, and can serve as a guidance for investors. CDL is reviewing the hotel portfolio with plans to unlock its "deep value".

site_title: Biden administration extends US tariff exclusion on Chinese medical goods
summary: The US Trade Representative's office has extended tariff exclusions on about 99 categories of Chinese medical products until September 30, 2021, to aid in the fight against Covid-19. The exclusions, set to lapse on March 31, cover items such as masks, gloves, blood pressure cuff sleeves, and X-ray tables. The decision was made in light of ongoing efforts to combat the pandemic, and the exclusions were initially imposed by the Trump administration in 2019 as part of a trade agreement with China.

site_title: Greenback regains footing; riskier currencies retreat
summary: The US dollar regained ground on Wednesday, recovering from overnight losses as US bond yields stabilized. Riskier currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars, retreated after significant gains on March 9. Bitcoin also declined after reaching a record high of over $55,000.

site_title: European Parliament backs carbon border tax plan
summary: The European Parliament has endorsed a non-binding plan to create a carbon border tax, aimed at shielding EU companies from cheaper imports from countries with weaker climate policies. The tax would require non-European products to buy pollution permits from the EU's emissions trading system, level the playing field for heavy industry, and achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The plan faces a challenging ratification process, with opinions widely diverged among EU member states. The target date for the start of the mechanism is 2023.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sabana Reit, FSL Trust, Del Monte Pacific, Union Gas, MC Payment
summary: Sabana Reit's new mall at New Tech Park is set to open in the second quarter, with 80.2% of units taken up. FSL Trust has been ordered to seek unitholders' approval for a sale of two product tanker newbuildings by April 30. Del Monte Pacific reported a net profit of US$30.16 million for its third quarter, with shares closing up 4% on the news. Union Gas signed a non-binding letter of intent for a joint venture in Cambodia. MC Payment received subscriptions for 10 million new shares, totaling S$4 million.

site_title: Texas reopens '100%' as US vaccination drive gains pace
summary: Texas has lifted its mask mandate and capacity restrictions, becoming the fifth US state to do so, despite experts warning of the potential for increased spread of coronavirus variants. The decision comes as the US vaccination campaign gains momentum, with 62 million people receiving one or more doses. President Joe Biden announced plans to acquire 100 million more vaccines, targeting the adult population by May, and has committed $4 billion to global vaccine distribution. The move has sparked mixed reactions, with some supporting the decision and others expressing concerns about the potential risks.

site_title: US to unveil Paris climate pact commitments in April
summary: US climate envoy John Kerry announced new financing commitments for the Paris Agreement ahead of the pact's fifth anniversary on April 22. The US will lay out its nationally determined contributions to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Kerry also discussed joint efforts with France to enlist private financing for the fight against global warming and explored a carbon border tax for the European Union. The US aims to keep global temperature increase under 2°C and ideally closer to 1.5°C by 2050.

site_title: Tech sell-off in HK, China present buying opportunities: analysts
summary: Analysts say the recent tech sell-off in Hong Kong and China presents buying opportunities, particularly in e-commerce and tech-related stocks. Favored stocks include Kingsoft, Weimob, Tencent, Alibaba, JD.com, and Meituan. Despite recent declines, analysts believe there is still significant upside potential in these companies. This comes after the markets reacted to the spike in US Treasury yields and fears of global reflation.

site_title: Royal family contests Harry and Meghan's racism claims
summary: The British royal family has responded to Prince Harry and Meghan's racism claims, with Queen Elizabeth II releasing a statement that acknowledged the concerns but also noted that "some recollections may vary." Buckingham Palace has vowed to investigate the claim that a royal asked about the skin tone of their unborn son Archie. The palace statement was seen as conciliatory but also defensive, with senior ministers denying any wider ramifications for the queen. The row has sparked a national debate about racism and the monarchy's colonial past, with some calling for Australia to hold another referendum on abolishing the monarchy.

site_title: Europe: Defensive sectors, Adidas lift stocks; cyclicals fall
summary: Europe's main index rose 0.4% on Wednesday, near pre-pandemic highs, driven by gains in telecoms and healthcare stocks, with Adidas adding 2.8% after an upbeat sales forecast. The tech rally on Tuesday pushed the benchmark to its highest level since February 2020. Most sectors, including cyclicals, tech, and defensives, have had time in the spotlight this week, with overseas investors seeking a mix of sectors, viewing Europe as cheaper.

site_title: NYC's US$45b luxury-condo glut set to start easing soon
summary: New York City's luxury-condo market, which has been nearly a decade in the making, is expected to start easing soon. Developers are dropping unit prices to attract buyers, and professional investors are amassing funds to purchase unsold apartments in bulk. This glut, which began with the 2013 launch of the 111 West 57th Street tower, is likely to lead to increased competition and lower prices for luxury condos. The market's decline may provide relief for buyers and developers, although the exact timing and extent of the easing are still uncertain.

site_title: Churchill artwork sold for record £8.3m at auction
summary: A painting by Winston Churchill, "Tower of the Koutoubia Mosque" (1943), sold at Christie's auction for a record £8.3m (S$15.5m), surpassing previous Churchill artwork sales. The piece, initially owned by President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was sold by actress Angelina Jolie. The sale marks a new price league for Churchill's artwork, highlighting his talent as an amateur painter.

images.alt_text: Churchill's Tower of the Koutoubia. He gave his Impressionist-style painting of a sunlit Marrakech with the Atlas Mountains in the background to Roosevelt in 1943, as a birthday gift, after a pivotal World War II meeting in Casablanca to discuss long-term strategy.

site_title: Verkada surveillance cameras at Tesla, hundreds more businesses breached
summary: Hackers gained administrative access to Verkada surveillance cameras, viewing live and archived footage from hundreds of businesses, including Tesla, an Alabama jail, and a community gym. The hackers, led by Swiss developer Tillie Kottmann, sought to draw attention to pervasive monitoring of people after finding Verkada's login information publicly online. Verkada acknowledged the breach and disabled internal administrator accounts, while companies like Cloudflare and Okta reported no customer data were affected. The incident highlights concerns about the security of surveillance camera systems.

site_title: Adidas profit plummets 78% in pandemic-hit year
summary: Adidas reported a 78% drop in profits to 432 million euros in 2020 due to the pandemic, with sales falling 16% to 19.8 billion euros. However, the company forecast a sharp rebound, with sales expected to grow 15-20% in 2021. Online sales surged 53% to 4 billion euros, and 95% of stores are now open globally. Adidas also announced plans to sell its struggling US subsidiary Reebok, citing a formal process to divest the brand.

site_title: Myanmar fuel imports plunge as protests disrupt trade
summary: Myanmar's fuel imports plummeted to a three-year low in February due to disruptions in trade caused by protests against the military coup. Suppliers are demanding payment in full upfront, and importers are switching to telegraphic transfers instead of letters of credit. Fuel prices have risen nearly 40% due to global oil prices and a weakened kyat currency. The country's imports of gasoline and diesel fell 63% and 40% respectively in February, while domestic prices have increased by 36-37%.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts record loss, warns of long recovery
summary: Cathay Pacific reported a record loss of $2.8 billion in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with losses exceeding estimates. The airline expects passenger traffic to remain below half of pre-pandemic levels in 2021. Chairman Patrick Healy warned of a long recovery, citing the effectiveness of global vaccination programs. Cathay has reduced costs, cut executive pay, and implemented unpaid leave, but faces challenges due to strict quarantine measures in Hong Kong, where it has no domestic market.

site_title: Covid-induced digital push will transform Singapore's SME sector for the better
summary: Singapore's SME sector has rapidly digitalised over the past year, accelerating progress by 3-5 years globally. The government's initiatives, including a S$1 billion digital transformation scheme, have supported this growth. As a result, digitally-mature SMEs are expected to contribute up to US$24 billion to the country's GDP by 2024, with those embracing digitalisation enjoying twice the benefits of revenue and productivity compared to non-digital SMEs. This digital push is seen as a vital step in ensuring the sector's resilience and contributing to the country's economic rebound.

site_title: Malaysian court overturns ban on use of 'Allah' by non-Muslim publications
summary: A Malaysian court overturned a 1986 government policy banning non-Muslim publications from using the word "Allah" to refer to God, in a landmark ruling. The decision was made in a case brought by a Malaysian Christian, Jill Ireland, who sought a declaration that her constitutional rights had been violated. The ruling allows Malay-speaking Christians to use the word, which they claim has been used for centuries in the country. The decision has been confirmed by a lawyer in the case and reported by media.

site_title: Idle containers leave global supply chains fractured
summary: Global shipping is experiencing a severe supply chain crisis due to the COVID-19 pandemic, resulting in a mismatch between container availability and demand. Major US ports are overwhelmed with shipping containers from Asia, while container availability in China, the world's factory, is at a record low. This has led to delays, congestion, and increased freight costs, with some 85% of ships unable to go straight to berth. Industry experts expect the container shortages to last until mid-2021, affecting global trade and manufacturing.

site_title: PayPal brings its 'buy-now-pay-later' offer to crowded Australia
summary: PayPal is set to launch its "buy now, pay later" (BNPL) option in Australia this June, entering a crowded market dominated by Afterpay and Zip Co Ltd. The service, which allows interest-free transactions in four installments, has been successful in the US and Britain, with over $750 million in transactions handled by the end of 2020. PayPal's arrival is expected to present a new competitor in the market, potentially affecting Afterpay and Zip Co Ltd. The company plans to capitalize on its relationships with Australian merchants, but will not seek exclusive arrangements.

site_title: US: Dow ends at record after US Congress approves stimulus package
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a record high of 32,297.02 after the US Congress approved a $1.9 trillion economic relief package. The package, signed by President Joe Biden, provides billions of dollars to US households and unemployed workers. Despite rising energy prices driving US consumer inflation up 0.4% in February, investors remained optimistic about improving conditions, with 72% of executives surveyed by the Business Roundtable expecting recovery by the end of 2021.

images.alt_text: The Dow rocketed to a fresh record on Wednesday after Congress approved a US$1.9 trillion economic relief package, the last hurdle before President Joe Biden signs it into law.

site_title: Fed warns banks over slow Libor shifts
summary: The US Federal Reserve has warned major banks that they risk facing consequences if they don't quickly transition away from the Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate) due to safety and soundness risks. The Fed will examine banks' transition plans and may issue supervisory findings or actions if they're not ready to stop issuing Libor-based contracts by December 31, 2021. The deadline for new Libor-based contracts is approaching, with most major banks expected to spend over $100 million this year preparing for the transition.

site_title: Young artisans offering bespoke woodwork
summary: A group of young artisans in Singapore are reviving the art of handmade woodcraft, creating bespoke furniture that combines traditional techniques with modern designs. This emerging industry is gaining traction as consumers increasingly appreciate artisanal craftsmanship. Meanwhile, local designer Simone Ng showcases her stunning jewelry pieces inspired by history at Harrods in London, while Raffles Singapore has been transformed into a detective game destination for staycationers.

site_title: Oil ticks up on global economic outlook, plummeting US fuel inventories
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday due to an upbeat forecast for global economic recovery and plummeting US fuel inventories. Brent crude settled at $67.90 a barrel, gaining 38 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 43 cents to $64.44 a barrel. US petrol stocks dropped 11.9 million barrels and distillates fell 5.5 million barrels, while crude oil stocks jumped 13.8 million barrels. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) forecast 5.6% growth this year and 4% next year, boosting market sentiment.

site_title: Individually rational, collectively insane
summary: A financial economist reflects on the recent Bitcoin craze, negative 10-year US Treasury repo rates, and the GameStop saga as symptoms of the global economic system's underlying illness. The economist attributes these phenomena to the distortion created by macroeconomic and financial policies post the 2008 global financial crisis, exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The economist argues that markets have become "rationally insane" due to excessive liquidity and the power of social media, where cooler heads are overpowered by the frenzy justified by continually rising prices. The economist warns of more asset bubbles and bizarre happenings until fiscal and monetary balances are reined in.

site_title: Demise of UK financier Greensill sparks global jobs panic
summary: The UK-based finance firm Greensill Capital has collapsed, sparking a global jobs panic and threatening 50,000 jobs, particularly at Indian-British billionaire Sanjeev Gupta's steel empire. Greensill's complex business model, which involved short-term corporate loans, led to its insolvency. The company's demise has created uncertainty for clients, who may default on payments, and investors face potential losses. Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance empire, which employs 35,000 staff worldwide, is among the hardest hit, with the UK-based Liberty Steel division employing 5,000 people.

site_title: Pandemic property investors bet on Hong Kong's old factories
summary: Hong Kong's property investors are shifting focus to industrial buildings, particularly those that once served as factories, due to the surge in e-commerce and demand for logistics and storage space during the pandemic. Transactions reached HK$2.7 billion in the first two months of 2021, with industrial properties offering higher rental yields of 3.5% compared to office or retail properties. The city's lack of new industrial supply and dwindling existing stock are driving demand, with investors willing to bid above asking prices for logistics real estate, according to a CBRE survey.

site_title: Indonesia eager to roll out red carpet for foreign investors
summary: Indonesia aims to attract foreign investors despite the COVID-19 pandemic, with President Joko Widodo's government pushing a job creation and investment bill to simplify regulations and open up more sectors to foreign investors. The bill surpassed the country's combined domestic and foreign direct investment target of US$56.6 billion in 2020. However, recent comments by Widodo, urging Indonesian consumers to "hate" foreign products, have raised concerns among investors, with some questioning the country's commitment to openness for business. Analysts believe Indonesia could still attract significant foreign investment, particularly in the electric transportation industry.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil inventories fall more than expected in February
summary: Malaysia's palm oil inventories fell 1.8% in February to a three-month low of 1.3 million tonnes, as production declined 1.85% to 1.11 million tonnes, its lowest in five years. Imports plummeted 47% and exports dropped 5.5% to 895,556 tonnes, their lowest since 2007. Despite this, a weakening ringgit is expected to boost demand in the second half of March. Malaysia is also in talks with Saudi Arabia to increase imports of palm oil to 500,000 tonnes.

site_title: I fled Myanmar in the 1988 crackdown. Now it needs Biden's help
summary: The US, under President Joe Biden, has condemned the Myanmar military's actions following the February coup, which overthrew the democratically elected government. The US has imposed sanctions on Myanmar military leaders and individuals, but critics argue that more can be done to support the people of Myanmar, including an arms embargo, economic pressure, and support for civil disobedience organizations. The writer, a former student leader in the 1988 democracy movement, calls for the US to use its relationship with Singapore to prompt change and ensure that US companies are not doing business with Singaporean companies with interests in Myanmar.

site_title: Can Oceanus's digital farming ambitions lift investor confidence?
summary: Oceanus Group, a Singapore-based digital farming company, aims to "tech up" its business model and diversify its products and operations. Following a profitable FY2020, CEO Peter Koh plans to invest in new farming technologies to increase efficiency and returns for shareholders. With a clean balance sheet and steady revenue, Oceanus Group is poised to continue investing in new technologies, bolstering investor confidence.

site_title: SGX needs to take a long hard look at SPACs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) should carefully consider the listing of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) to ensure investors have confidence in the vehicles' quality and align their interests. While SPACs offer a path to public listing and have been successful in some cases, studies have shown that many do not outperform other investments, particularly in rising markets. To mitigate risks, SGX can capture the attractiveness of SPACs by introducing investor-friendly policies and setting rules for longer-term success. Investors must also take responsibility for critically evaluating SPACs and considering the sponsors' credentials and the structure's alignment with their interests.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: MC Payment has received subscriptions for 10 million new shares worth S$4 million from investors, including high-net-worth clients from OCBC and Levin Lee. The funds will be used to redeem outstanding convertible bonds and pay expenses related to a proposed reverse takeover.

site_title: Container ships flood Singapore as global scheduling left in tatters
summary: Container ships are experiencing longer wait times at Singapore's port due to a surge in vessel calls and container volumes, with daily average vessels staying over two days increasing by 60% year-over-year. Turnaround times are estimated to be 5-7 days, a significant increase from the maximum of 2 days earlier. The congestion is attributed to factors such as increased cargo demand, volatile supply chain disruptions, and unreliable vessel sailing schedules. Despite this, Singapore appears to be coping better than other ports, and the congestion is expected to impact spot container freight prices, with exports from Singapore to North America attracting higher pricing.

site_title: Accelerating shift to EVs key to hitting EU's climate goals
summary: The European Union must set a date to phase out new petrol and diesel car sales by 2030 to meet its climate-neutral goal by 2050, according to nine member states. The move aims to reduce transport emissions, which account for a quarter of the bloc's greenhouse gas emissions. The EU's regulatory arm, "Fit for 55", will propose new regulations, including strengthened CO2 standards for cars and vans, and phase-out provisions for fossil-fuel vehicles. This push follows the bloc's leaders endorsing a 55% emissions-reduction target and comes as Europe is leading the world in EV adoption, with over 1.4 million EVs on the road.

site_title: Inditex's full-year net profit falls 70% to 1.1b euros
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, reported a 70% drop in full-year net profit to 1.1 billion euros in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic and global lockdowns. Total sales fell 28% to 20.4 billion euros, with online sales increasing 77% to offset the decline. The company expects most stores to be open by April 12, despite 30% being closed at the end of January. Inditex mitigated supply chain uncertainty through efficient inventory management and returned to its dividend policy.

site_title: China factory prices rise as industries recover from pandemic
summary: China's factory prices rose 1.7% in February, the fastest pace in over two years, as the country's industrial sector recovered from the pandemic. This exceeded analyst expectations. The producer price index (PPI) had risen for the first time in a year in January. Analysts expect global commodity prices to lift inflation further in the coming months, with rising international metal commodity prices and electronics components contributing to the increase. Consumer prices fell 0.2% in February, but are expected to rise in the coming months.

site_title: Technology will drive the reboot of the mall in Singapore
summary: The Singapore government plans to impose Goods and Services Tax (GST) on imported low-value goods bought online in 2023, aiming to level the playing field for local businesses. This move comes as brick-and-mortar stores struggle due to technology disruption and the pandemic. Despite the shuttering of Robinsons, many shoppers showed enthusiasm for in-store shopping, with research data suggesting consumers in Singapore are eager to return to stores for pleasure, but also desire changes. The government's plan may help revitalize the local retail landscape.

site_title: Asian firms ready debt deals under new benchmark rate rules
summary: Asian financial companies are gearing up to issue debt using the new global benchmark interest rate, the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR), which will replace the contentious Libor. The US dollar Libor will be halted by the end of this year, with lenders fined billions of dollars for trying to rig the reference rate in 2012. Asia's first SOFR-backed debt deal was issued by Korea Development Bank last week, with $300 million raised in a three-year floating rate note. The switch is expected to expedite debt transactions in the region, with bankers and advisers urging issuers to make steps towards transitioning.

site_title: Office rents may stay lower for longer
summary: Office rents in Singapore may remain lower for longer due to a flight to quality amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Companies are reviewing their office space needs, and firms in the finance and insurance sectors are taking a hard look at their business models. This shift is expected to lead to rents at older buildings remaining under pressure, while newer buildings may experience increased demand. The recovery in office rents is likely to be slower than in the 2008 global financial crisis, with the information and communications sector expected to have a greater impact on office demand.

site_title: Investors managing combined US$33t devising net-zero investing standard
summary: A group of investors managing US$33 trillion has developed a global standard for net-zero investing, known as the "Net-Zero Investment Framework". This framework aims to decarbonize investor portfolios and the economy to meet the Paris climate accord's 1.5 degrees Celsius target. 35 investors, including DWS Group and Fidelity International, are already using the framework, and 21 asset owners have committed to achieving net-zero alignment by 2050. The framework encourages investors to develop net-zero strategies for asset allocation, policy advocacy, and engaging with portfolio companies.

site_title: Salesforce's Bret Taylor emerges as CEO candidate, say sources
summary: Salesforce is reportedly grooming COO Bret Taylor to succeed co-founder Marc Benioff as CEO, following Keith Block's departure last year. The promotion is not imminent but could happen in the coming months. This move comes as Salesforce competes with Microsoft and Oracle in the booming business software market.

site_title: When Europe's theatres reopen, will fans return?
summary: European theatres are set to reopen, but the impact of the pandemic on theatre attendance remains uncertain. Fans have adapted to digital performances, with some venues expanding their audiences through online streams. However, critics argue that virtual experiences lack the intimacy and social aspect of in-person performances. Some fans, like Jessi Parrott, miss the physicality of live theatre, while others, like Ronan Ynard, prefer the educational and social aspects of live shows. The shift towards online performances has raised questions about the future of European theatre, with some fearing it may become the new norm.

site_title: Swallowing bitter pill of GST hike for the collective good
summary: Singapore's Goods and Services Tax (GST) rate will increase to 9% from 7% due to escalating government spending and operating deficits. The hike, initially planned for 2021-2025, has been deferred to 2022-2025 to avoid timing issues amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The government will provide a S$6 billion Assurance Package to cushion the impact, with offsets for households and subsidies for healthcare and education. The GST increase is seen as a necessary step for the collective good, despite its regressive nature, and will be closely monitored to ensure its effectiveness in funding government spending.

images.alt_text: It has been 14 years since Singapore last raised its GST rate from 5 to 7 per cent. Arguably, any hike in taxes will be a bitter pill to swallow for those affected.

site_title: Women employment rate remained steady during pandemic: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's female employment rate remained steady at around 73% during the pandemic, despite concerns about women being disproportionately affected globally. Manpower Minister Josephine Teo noted that women need to upskill to remain relevant in the workforce, especially with rising retirement and re-employment ages. The government aims to increase women's representation on company boards, with a target of 50% by 2030, and is prepared to introduce anti-discrimination legislation if necessary.

site_title: Reclusive Chinese water tycoon is now Asia's richest person
summary: Reclusive Chinese billionaire Zhong Shanshan has become Asia's richest person after his company's stock listings in 2021, primarily due to the massive demand for Covid-19 test kits. His Nongfu Spring mineral water and pharma company Wantai Biological Pharmacy Enterprise have fueled his wealth, surpassing other Asian billionaires. Zhong's reclusive nature and gruff reputation were previously unknown to many, but his business acumen has earned him the top spot in Asia's rich list.

site_title: New Indonesia sovereign wealth fund eyes assets worth US$2.6b
summary: Indonesia's new sovereign wealth fund, the Indonesia Investment Authority (INA), is exploring investments in dozens of projects worth $2.6 billion, including toll road concessions. The fund aims to manage $20 billion of assets, with $5 billion from the state to aid pandemic recovery. INA will review investments in seaports and airports and plans to close deals this year. The fund will be an active, long-term investor, aiming to exit projects in seven years or when most suitable, to recycle assets and finance Indonesia's targeted infrastructure of $460 billion between 2020 and 2024.

site_title: Vaccine 'revolution' could see shots for next pandemic in 100 days
summary: An international coalition, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI), is calling for a $3.5 billion, five-year strategy to develop vaccines for future pandemics in 100 days. CEPI's CEO Richard Hatchett says the next emerging disease could be worse than COVID-19, and the coalition aims to expedite a "revolution in vaccinology" that enabled rapid COVID-19 vaccine development. The goal is to streamline vaccine development, manufacturing, and approval processes to prepare for the next pandemic.

site_title: South Korea's Coupang ups price range in US$4b US IPO
summary: South Korea's e-commerce giant Coupang is seeking to raise up to $4.08 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO) after boosting its price target to $32 to $34 per share. The company is offering 120 million shares, up from an earlier marketing price of $27 to $30 per share. This move aims to capitalize on the company's growing presence in the US market, solidifying its position as a leading e-commerce player in South Korea.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's PIF signs US$15b loan
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has signed a $15 billion multi-currency revolving credit facility with 17 banks, providing access to extra capital for deployment as needed. The one-year facility can be renewed four times and will be used for general corporate purposes. This marks the fund's latest move to boost firepower, following a $40 billion transfer from central bank reserves last year. The new loan is part of Crown Prince Mohammed Salman's economic transformation plans to reduce Saudi Arabia's reliance on oil, with plans to invest at least $40 billion locally by 2025.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 15.05 points to 1,639.83. The index saw 11.007 billion lots traded worth RM7.197 billion, with 850 gainers outnumbering 358 losers.

site_title: US core CPI rises less than expected, temporarily easing inflation concerns
summary: US core consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.1% in February, less than expected, easing inflation concerns. The core CPI, excluding food and energy costs, increased 1.3% from the prior year. Despite this, experts remain divided on the inflation outlook. The overall CPI rose 0.4% from the prior month, with costs of used vehicles, clothing, and transportation services declining from a month earlier. The data suggests broader inflationary pressures remain tame, but the overall inflation outlook remains uncertain.

site_title: GE aircraft leasing unit agrees to US$30b Irish tie-up
summary: General Electric has agreed to a US$30 billion tie-up with Irish peer AerCap, creating an industry-leading aviation lessor. GE will have a 46% stake in the new company and US$24 billion in cash following AerCap's 100% takeover of Gecas aircraft leasing. The deal aims to reduce GE's debt by US$30 billion and focus on its industrial core. The combined company will own over 2,000 aircraft and have approximately 300 customers worldwide, with AerCap's CEO stating the combination will enhance the group's ability to provide innovative solutions for customers.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Securities downgrades Yoma to 'neutral' amid Myanmar crisis
summary: Phillip Securities has downgraded its call on Yoma Strategic Holdings to "neutral" from "buy" with a lower target price of 15.6 Singapore cents, citing Myanmar's political regression and ongoing violence as a major threat to the company's growth prospects. Analysts expect revenue disruptions and reduced consumer spending, particularly in the Q2 of FY2021. Yoma's real estate arm may also face delays in recognizing revenue from ongoing property development projects. The brokerage now values the stock at 0.45 times price-to-book, slightly above its 2007-2010 low.

site_title: Jetstar back to 90% of pre-pandemic domestic capacity
summary: Jetstar, Qantas Airways' budget arm, has reached 90% of its pre-pandemic domestic schedule in March, driven by a rebound in demand as state borders reopened in Australia. Jetstar's CEO Gareth Evans expressed positivity, citing the airline's lower-cost offering as a key factor in its success. Qantas expects its total domestic capacity to reach 80% of normal by the end of June. Jetstar plans to delay the delivery of its Airbus A321neoLRs to 2022 or 2023, and will resume using Boeing 787s in the international market once borders reopen.

site_title: Why Japan is centre stage in anti-China alliance
summary: US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken and Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin will visit Japan on Monday for two-plus-two talks with Japanese officials, amid growing US concerns about China's assertive foreign policy in the Asia-Pacific region. Japan is seen as a critical bulwark against China's rise, with the US seeking to strengthen ties with its key regional allies. The visit comes as the Biden administration reviews its policy towards North Korea and China, with the Quad security dialogue set to convene virtually. The US and Japan are also working together to distribute Covid-19 vaccines in Asia-Pacific, with Japan's economic and strategic importance being highlighted as a potential anchor of the US-led anti-China alliance.

images.alt_text: Next week, US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken and Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin will visit Tokyo to meet Japanese Foreign Minister Toshimitsu Motegi (above) and Defence Minister Nobuo Kishi for so-called two-plus-two talks.

site_title: US consumer prices increase solidly in February
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in February, the largest annual gain since February 2020, with a 1.7% year-on-year increase. This is the biggest annual gain in a year, despite underlying inflation remaining tepid. Demand for services, including airline travel, is gradually picking up amid an improving public health picture. The increase was in line with economists' forecasts.

site_title: China approves US$1.5b currency swap with Sri Lanka
summary: China has approved a US$1.54 billion currency swap with Sri Lanka, aiming to help the island nation weather financial difficulties. Sri Lanka's dwindling foreign reserves, tumbling currency, and rising debt levels have raised concerns of a default. The deal is seen as a move to stabilize the country's economy, despite previous downgrades by credit rating agencies and negative comments from investment banks. The agreement is part of Sri Lanka's efforts to secure financing options, following talks with foreign governments and multilateral partners.

site_title: Malaysian court overturns ban on use of 'Allah' by non-Muslim publications
summary: A Malaysian court overturned a decades-old ban on non-Muslim publications using the word "Allah" to refer to God, ruling that it violates a Christian woman's constitutional rights. The decision was made in a case brought by Jill Ireland, who sought a declaration that her rights had been violated after authorities seized her publications in 2008. The court declared the 1986 directive banning Malay-language Christian publications from using the word "Allah" as unlawful and unconstitutional, granting Ireland equality before the law and the right to import her publications for education and religious practice.

site_title: Australia to aid ailing tourism with 800,000 half-price flights
summary: Australia's government will provide a A$1.2 billion package to support the nation's ailing tourism industry, including 800,000 half-price air fares from April 1 to July 31. The discounted fares aim to help tourism-dependent regions and support airlines, hotels, and hospitality venues. This move comes as the country's domestic and international aviation industry has been severely damaged by the pandemic, with Qantas Airways losing A$11 billion in revenue last year. The package is also expected to support small and medium-sized businesses.

site_title: US: Stocks resume climb as Biden relief plan nears passage
summary: US stocks resumed their climb on Wednesday as investors awaited the passage of President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus plan, which is expected to boost the US economy's recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.0%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.1%. A government report showed no sign of an inflationary spike in February, alleviating concerns. The stimulus plan includes billions of dollars for Covid-19 vaccinations and supporting the unemployed, as well as paying for stimulus checks.

site_title: Condo resale prices in Singapore rise for seventh straight month; up 1% in Feb: SRX
summary: Condo resale prices in Singapore rose 1% in February, marking the seventh consecutive month of growth, according to SRX Property. This year-over-year increase of 4.4% is attributed to the higher prices of new residential launches driving demand in the secondary market. Property analysts attribute the price growth to the relatively higher prices of new launches.

site_title: IOC president Bach wins unopposed second term to 2025
summary: International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach won an unopposed second term, securing 93 of 94 votes until 2025. Bach, who took office in 2013, has introduced reforms to reduce Olympics costs and navigated the 2014 Sochi Olympics doping scandal and the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Games' financial and corruption issues. His eight-year term has seen unanimous support from IOC members, who currently number over 100. Bach expressed gratitude for the vote of confidence, stating he aims to achieve ambitious goals in the post-coronavirus world.

site_title: Google to review adverts for Myanmar military-backed telecoms firm
summary: Google is reviewing advertisements by a Myanmar military-backed telecoms firm following the country's coup. The move comes amid protests and dozens of deaths. Google has disabled some army-linked accounts on its services and removed YouTube channels and videos related to the military. The decision is in response to calls from activists for the US tech giant to restrict access to its services.

site_title: Foreign businesses in Myanmar could struggle to remain neutral in crisis: Report
summary: Foreign businesses operating in Myanmar may struggle to remain neutral amid the ongoing crisis, according to a report by Control Risks. The report warns that engaging with either the military government or the pro-democracy movement could lead to perceptions of legitimacy, triggering boycott campaigns or anti-coup demonstrations. Corporate decision-makers are advised to avoid assuming momentum towards either endgame, instead focusing on neutral and cautious strategies to mitigate potential risks.

site_title: Indonesia VC firm East Ventures assumes leadership of EV Growth Fund
summary: East Ventures has assumed leadership of the EV Growth Fund, a joint venture between East Ventures, SMDV, and ZVC, following a restructuring of the co-general partnership structure. The fund, which reached its hard cap of $250 million, focuses on Indonesia- and South-east Asia-based startups, including Shopback and Grab. The move aims to strengthen East Ventures' presence in the region and accelerate investments. Roderick Purwana from SMDV will become managing partner, while Shiniciro Hori from ZVC will remain on the investment committee.

site_title: Queen's response to racism claim the 'bare minimum': UK media
summary: Queen Elizabeth II issued a statement in response to racism claims made by Prince Harry and Meghan Markle, saying the family is "saddened" and that "the issues raised, particularly that of race, are concerning." The 61-word statement, which included the phrase "recollections may vary," was deemed the "bare minimum" by some, with critics arguing it did not adequately address the allegations. The Queen's response dominated British media, with varying interpretations of its meaning.

site_title: STI reverses two-day gain to end 0.93% lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.93% to 3,079.72 on Wednesday, snapping a two-day winning streak. The decline was attributed to a pull-back in Treasury yields, which lifted technology stocks on Wall Street. Despite this, a strategist noted that the immense macro forces at play suggest the rally may not be a trend. On the broader market, decliners outnumbered advancers 241 to 234, with 2.91 billion securities changing hands.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close marginally higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed marginally higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.03% to 29,036.56 and the Topix index advancing 0.11% to 1,919.74, despite a lack of fresh trade clues.

site_title: Myanmar fuel imports plunge in Feb as protests disrupt trade
summary: Myanmar's fuel imports plummeted in February, reaching their lowest level in over 3 years due to protests against the military coup, which disrupted trade. Fuel importers switched to telegraphic transfers to pay suppliers, as letters of credit were no longer accepted. This led to a 63% drop in diesel imports and a 40% drop in gasoline imports. The country's economic instability, currency depreciation, and rising oil prices have further exacerbated the shortage, with domestic gasoline and diesel prices rising by 36% to 37% since January.

site_title: SGX RegCo orders FSL Trust to seek unitholders' approval for vessel sale
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has ordered First Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) to seek unitholders' approval for the sale of two product tanker newbuildings, citing it as "short-term trading" that deviates from the trust's main objective of generating a stable income stream. The sale was completed for a total of US$103.8 million, despite the trust's initial public offering prospectus stating its intention to renew its ageing fleet. FSL Trust will comply with SGX RegCo's directives and submit a written undertaking to seek unitholders' ratification by April 30.

site_title: England's US$32b Covid-19 test and trace not making a difference, lawmakers say
summary: England's £23 billion (approximately $32 billion) test and trace system has been deemed ineffective by the British Parliament's Public Accounts Committee, with limited impact on preventing lockdowns. The committee criticized the system's high costs and called for it to be run by the state-run health service. Despite spending billions, Test and Trace has not achieved its key goal of avoiding a cycle of national lockdowns. The committee's findings have drawn criticism from opposition politicians, who are now pushing for the system to be restructured.

site_title: US lawmakers to introduce antitrust bills to protect news media
summary: US lawmakers, led by Senator Amy Klobuchar and Representative David Cicilline, will introduce bipartisan legislation to make it easier for news organizations to negotiate collectively with platforms like Google and Facebook. The bill would allow news organizations to work together to win better deals for four years, exempt from antitrust laws, and boost revenues. The move comes after Facebook's $1 billion investment in the news industry and follows a pitched battle with Australia over news page revenue.

site_title: Seoul: Shares decline for fifth session on China market volatility worries
summary: South Korean shares declined for a fifth consecutive session due to concerns over volatile Chinese markets. The Kospi index fell 0.60% to 2,958.12, with tech giants Samsung and SK Hynix losing ground. Foreigners sold 11.3 billion won worth of shares, and the Korean won weakened against the dollar. Despite a rebound in the Nasdaq index overnight, doubts remain about the stability of the Chinese market, with inflation and producer prices exceeding expectations.

site_title: Grab weighs US listing through SPAC merger
summary: Grab Holdings, a South-east Asian ride-hailing and delivery giant, is exploring a US listing through a merger with a blank-cheque company, according to people familiar with the matter. JPMorgan Chase & Co and Morgan Stanley are advising Grab on its initial public offering plans. The move comes after talks to combine with Indonesian rival Gojek collapsed. Grab's listing could accelerate if it merges with a SPAC, similar to Sea Ltd's 2017 US listing. The company's market value is estimated to be over $10 billion, making it one of the most valuable startups in the region.

site_title: Cathay Pacific posts record HK$21.65b annual loss because of pandemic
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways reported a record annual loss of HK$21.65 billion in 2020 due to the pandemic, surpassing analysts' forecast of a net loss of HK$19.9 billion. The airline's passenger numbers fell 98.7% compared to 2019, while cargo carriage declined 32.3%. Nearly 60% of Cathay's 2020 revenue came from cargo operations. The airline's chairman attributed the loss to "challenging and dynamic market conditions" and vowed to continue cash preservation measures.

site_title: Gold falls back as US yields, dollar advance
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $1,712.60 per ounce on Wednesday, reversing a 2% gain from the previous day, as US Treasury yields recovered and the dollar strengthened. The decline is attributed to a rise in bond yields, making gold less attractive as investors seek steady income. The US $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief bill is expected to be passed, further fueling inflation concerns and tightening monetary policy.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: European stock markets opened mixed on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.5% to 6,694.11 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 rose 0.1% to 14,447.57. Paris was marginally higher at 5,928.13. The mixed performance was attributed to mining and healthcare sectors. Meanwhile, in the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed in positive territory, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.47% to 28,907.52. The gains followed a healthy lead from Wall Street. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight increases. Investors remain cautious about the potential for inflation and interest rate hikes, which could impact the global economic recovery.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB initiates coverage on Q&M with 'add', S$0.92 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB has initiated coverage on Q&M Dental Group with an "add" rating, citing its "almost recession-proof" dentistry franchise and earnings growth from its new Covid-19 diagnostic testing segment. The brokerage has set a target price of S$0.92 and estimates the group's core net profit compound annual growth rate of 74% over two years. Q&M's shares closed up 2.3% on the day, driven by the positive analyst assessment, which also highlights the company's strong market position in Singapore's private dental space and its potential for future expansion.

images.alt_text: CATALIST-listed Aoxin Q&M Dental Group announced it has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire 49 per cent of Acumen Diagnostics for S$29.4 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Analysts have raised their forecast for Singapore's 2021 GDP growth to 5.8%, a 0.3 point increase from the previous estimate, within the government's official outlook range of 4-6%. Private home prices may continue to rise, while some expect a weaker Singapore dollar. The Singapore Savings Bond yield crossed 1% in its April issue, while an Indonesian VC firm took over the leadership of the EV Growth Fund. Industry players are exploring the use of green ammonia as a marine fuel, and Second Minister Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of trust and professionalism in the real estate sector.

site_title: China Feb factory prices roar back, consumer deflation ebbs
summary: China's factory gate prices rose 1.7% in February, the fastest pace since November 2018, driven by a low base and export orders. The producer price index (PPI) surpassed the median forecast of 1.5%. This robust price growth raises expectations for China's economy in 2021, potentially offsetting concerns about global inflation.

site_title: Sabana Reit's mall at New Tech Park to open in Q2
summary: Sabana Reit's new mall, NTP+, has received a temporary occupation permit and is set to open in the second quarter of this year at New Tech Park. The 43,000 sqft mall will feature 25 retail and F&B units on the ground floor and a food court on the second floor, with about 80.2% of units leased as of March 10. Tenants include brands like Collins, Wine Connection, and Ace Signature.

site_title: Del Monte Q3 net profit surges from US$6.7m to US$30.2m
summary: Del Monte Pacific Limited reported a net profit of US$30.16 million for the third quarter, nearly five times that of the same period last year. Revenue rose 13.1% year-on-year to US$628.35 million, driven by higher sales in the Philippines and overseas. The company also reduced its net debt to US$1.3 billion and gearing to 2.2x. For the nine months, Del Monte Pacific recorded a net profit of US$48.76 million, reversing a US$68.95 million net loss last year.

site_title: Myanmar security forces target striking railway workers
summary: Myanmar security forces have targeted striking railway workers, deploying hundreds of soldiers and police to a railway station in Yangon to arrest workers protesting against the military coup. The workers, part of a civil disobedience movement, have been arrested and the death toll has risen to over 60. The crackdown has also led to hospital disruptions, bank closures, and empty ministry offices. International condemnation has grown, with France calling for the release of all political prisoners jailed since the coup.

site_title: 10 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 10 new Covid-19 cases on March 10, 2021, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. The total number of cases reached 60,062. There were no community cases and no cases from migrant workers' dormitories. Five patients were discharged, bringing the total number of recovered cases to 59,890. The number of unlinked community cases increased to three, and 21 patients remained in hospital, including one in critical condition.

site_title: Pair of shophouses in Tanjong Pagar up for sale with S$15m guide price
summary: A pair of shophouses at 16 and 18 Tanjong Pagar Road in Singapore has been put up for sale via an EOI exercise with a guide price of S$15 million. The 4,090 sq ft shophouse pair spans 1,976 sq ft of land and is fully leased to a contemporary Italian-Japanese restaurant. The property is zoned full commercial and eligible for foreign purchase without additional buyer's stamp duty. The sale is seen as an attractive investment play by PropNex, with the property's 99-year tenure being younger than most Tanjong Pagar shophouses.

site_title: Property market froth and monetary easing hopes spill over into economist forecasts
summary: Singapore's private home prices are expected to continue rising, with 75% of analysts predicting a growth in 2021 and 62.5% expecting an increase in 2022. Despite this, some analysts are warning of the risk of an asset bubble and the potential for cooling measures, such as higher taxes and stricter loan requirements. The economy is forecast to grow by 5.8% in 2021, driven by the manufacturing sector and finance services. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to maintain a neutral stance on monetary policy, with only a minority expecting a weaker Singapore dollar nominal effective exchange rate.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bond yield crosses 1% in April issue
summary: The 10-year Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) yield has crossed 1% for the April issue, marking the first time since June 2020. The first-year interest rate is 0.35%, while the average return over a decade is 1.15% per annum. The maximum amount offered for the April issue is S$100 million, with interest payment dates every six months until maturity. This marks a significant increase from the previous low of S$10.1 million in July 2020, and the highest applications since July 2018.

site_title: Asian companies ready debt deals under new benchmark rate rules
summary: Asian companies are gearing up to issue debt using the new global benchmark interest rate, the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR), which will replace the contentious Libor. The move comes after Britain's regulators halted Libor rates at the end of this year, and lenders have been fined billions for trying to rig the reference rate. The first wave of deals using SOFR is expected to be initiated by banks and financial institutions, with Korea Development Bank already issuing a $300 million note in March. This is part of Asia's efforts to catch up with the rest of the world in adopting the new benchmark rate.

site_title: Asia: Markets up but inflation fears keep traders in check
summary: Asian markets rose, but inflation fears kept traders cautious. The US stimulus package, set to be passed, fueled concerns about soaring inflation and potential interest rate hikes. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields climbed to one-year highs, prompting fears of a Fed rate hike. Despite this, US markets, including the Nasdaq, rose, with European markets also gaining. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development increased its growth outlook, citing improved global economic prospects.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as miners, financials weigh
summary: Australia's shares ended 0.8% lower on Wednesday, reversing earlier gains, due to declines in mining and financial stocks. Iron ore miners like Fortescue Metals and Rio Tinto fell 8.3% and 5.5%, respectively, after Chinese iron ore futures plummeted. The central bank dismissed rate hike expectations, saying it will take until 2024 to reach full employment. Energy stocks also declined, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos falling 2.7% and 3.8%, respectively.

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus plunges 24.2% to year-to-date low
summary: Oceanus Group's shares plummeted 24.2% to a year-to-date low of 2.5 Singapore cents, their lowest point since 2012. The seafood supplier's downward spiral began earlier this month, with a record peak of 7.8 cents reached on Feb 22, 2021. The company is seeking an extension to exit the Singapore Exchange's watch list and has announced its full-year consolidated accounts will be released on or before April 15.

site_title: Adidas profit plummets 78% in pandemic-hit 2020
summary: Adidas reported a 78% profit decline in 2020 due to the pandemic, with net profits falling to 432 million euros and sales dropping 16% to 19.8 billion euros. However, the company forecasts a sharp rebound in 2021, with sales expected to grow 15-20% and net profits of 1.25-1.45 billion euros. Adidas also plans to sell its struggling US subsidiary Reebok, citing the brand's inability to shine under its German ownership. Despite store closures, online sales surged 53% to 4 billion euros.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Wednesday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.55 points or 0.8% to 1,637.33 at 9:07am on Wednesday, with 1.31 billion lots traded worth RM810 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 535 to 226.

site_title: Budget airline Jetstar back to 90% of pre-pandemic domestic capacity
summary: Jetstar, Qantas Airways' budget arm, has reached 90% of its pre-pandemic domestic capacity in March, up from 70% in December.
