The airline's CEO, Gareth Evans, attributed the rebound to state border reopenings in Australia. Qantas expects its total domestic capacity to reach 80% in the fourth quarter. Jetstar is focusing on leisure travel and undercutting competitor Regional Express on the Sydney-Melbourne route with fares as low as A$29. The airline has delayed delivery of its Airbus A321neoLRs to 2022 or 2023 due to the pandemic.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB maintains 'add' on Top Glove but expects ASPs to fall in Q3
summary: CGS-CIMB maintains its "add" call on Top Glove with an unchanged target price of RM7.80, citing strong Q2 results boosted by higher average selling prices (ASPs) that are expected to fall in Q3. Analyst Walter Aw notes that Top Glove's ASPs are at a 25-35% premium to its peers, but the decline will be gradual due to high consumption patterns. However, earnings per share (EPS) are expected to fall 49% in Q3 2022 due to labor abuse allegations and a US customs ban, diluting EPS by 11.2-15.1% between FY2021 and FY2023.

site_title: Bitcoin breaks through US$55,000 as risk appetite revives
summary: Bitcoin broke through the $55,000 mark, rising 2.8% on Wednesday, amid increased investor sentiment following the US stock surge on Tuesday. Speculation is growing about the largest cryptocurrency testing its record set last month, with institutional interest and US stimulus checks potentially fueling the rally. The digital token has risen 600% in the past year, sparking debate over whether it's a precarious bubble or a bigger bull run. Mainstream finance is inching closer, with JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs reporting increased interest from institutions in cryptocurrency trading.

site_title: South Korea's Coupang ups price range in US$4b US IPO
summary: Coupang, a South Korean e-commerce giant, is raising up to $4.08 billion in its US initial public offering (IPO) after boosting its price target to $32-$34 per share. The company, valued at $58 billion at the new price, is offering 100 million new shares and 20 million shares by existing investors. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, with the main goal of providing liquidity. The shares are expected to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange on Thursday under the symbol CPNG.

site_title: Taiwan says economy may grow 5% this year as exports boom
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow 5% this year, its fastest pace in seven years, driven by booming exports. The country's exports reached a record high of $345.28 billion last year, driven by demand for gadgets during the pandemic. The growth forecast is higher than the previous estimate of 4.64% made in February. The strong rebound in exports and chip demand is helping the island recover from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: BTxM+S podcast Ep 1: Pros and cons of investing in mixed-use property
summary: BTxM+S podcast Ep 1 discusses the pros and cons of investing in mixed-use property in Singapore's downtown area. Host Chris Lim talks to Ong Choon Fah, CEO of Edmund Tie & Company, about the advantages of mixed-use developments, including resilience in the Covid-19 era and sustainability. They also explore the benefits of living in the Marina Bay financial district, including a 20-minute town concept and a tenant pool of financial workers. The podcast highlights the appeal of mixed-use property developments to millennials and seniors, and notes that any investment decisions should be made after consulting a financial adviser.

site_title: Private analysts raise GDP hopes to 5.8% for 2021, up by 0.3 point on earlier forecast
summary: Private analysts have raised their forecast for Singapore's GDP growth in 2021 to 5.8%, up 0.3 points from earlier predictions, with a cooling to 3.8% in 2022. This is within the government's official outlook range of 4-6%. The revised estimate is higher than the 5.5% predicted in 2020, reflecting a more optimistic view of the economy's recovery.

images.alt_text: Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) may grow by 5.8 per cent in 2021, before cooling to 3.8 per cent in 2022, according to the results of the latest quarterly survey from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS).

site_title: Branson-backed SPAC to raise US$500m through US IPO
summary: Virgin Group-backed SPAC, Virgin Group Acquisition Corp III, plans to raise up to US$500 million through a US IPO, selling 50 million units at US$10 per unit. The firm will focus on acquiring companies in travel and leisure, financial services, and renewable energy. This is the third SPAC venture by billionaire Richard Branson, following a successful merger with 23andMe in February.

images.alt_text: A blank-cheque firm, backed by Virgin Group's billionaire founder Richard Branson, is looking to raise as much as US$500 million through an initial public offering (IPO), a regulatory filing showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with rally
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 1.68% higher on Wednesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index jumped to 29,255.37, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. Investors were reassured by the US government's stimulus package and declining inflation fears. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened more than 1 per cent higher Wednesday morning following a strong lead from Wall Street as Joe Biden's huge stimulus edged closer to being passed and inflation fears subsided.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end higher on support from oil, utilities
summary: European stocks rose 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by gains in oil and utility companies, which countered losses in miners. The Stoxx 600 index, which includes utilities, rose 1.5% and Danish jewelry maker Pandora jumped 7.2% after reporting a 12% rise in organic sales. Investors are watching a European Central Bank meeting later this week for potential policy changes to calm markets.

site_title: Apple loses bid to move consumer privacy suit to arbitration
summary: US District Judge Lorna G. Schofield ruled that Apple must continue fighting a consumer privacy lawsuit in open court, rejecting the company's request to move the case to arbitration. The lawsuit claims an iPhone operating system flaw and recycled phone numbers gave third parties unauthorized access to users' communications. The judge denied Apple's argument that a T-Mobile terms and conditions provision required arbitration, stating that Apple is not a party to the agreement and cannot enforce it. The ruling is seen as a victory for consumers, with their lawyers hailing it as recognition of the significant merit of their claims.

site_title: Pandemic property investors bet on Hong Kong's old factories
summary: Hong Kong property investors are shifting focus to dated factory buildings for better returns, driven by the pandemic's surge in e-commerce and demand for logistics and storage space. Industrial property transactions reached HK$2.7 billion in the first two months of 2021, with rental yields typically 3.5% compared to 2.5% for office and retail properties. The city's lack of new industrial supply and growing demand make these properties attractive investments, with prices expected to rise by 5% in 2021.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.3% or 97.13 points at 29,125.07, following a rally on Wall Street.

site_title: Keppel O&M, Maersk and other industry players to explore ammonia as marine fuel
summary: Maersk, Keppel O&M, and other industry players are exploring ammonia as a marine fuel alternative, aiming to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2050. A joint feasibility study will be conducted to establish the world's first green ammonia ship-to-ship bunkering in Singapore. The study will cover supply chain development, bunkering vessel design, and related infrastructure. Green ammonia, produced from renewable energy, is seen as a future fuel for decarbonizing global shipping, with Maersk and Keppel O&M working together to address supply, safety, and infrastructure challenges.

site_title: Singapore stocks pull back at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the opening on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping to 3,099.52. Despite US Treasury yields stabilizing, investors traded cautiously. Banking stocks declined, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC falling 1.3%, 0.2%, and 0.2% respectively. Tech stocks in the US bounced back after a period of weakness, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 3.7%.

site_title: UN Security Council wrestles with threat of action over Myanmar coup
summary: The UN Security Council failed to agree on a statement condemning the Myanmar coup, with China, Russia, India, and Vietnam suggesting amendments to remove the reference to a coup and threaten further action. The statement, which would have called for restraint by the military and the release of detained officials, was opposed by Russia and China. Over 60 people have been killed and 1,800 detained in protests against the coup, with dozens of journalists arrested. Diplomats say sanctions are unlikely due to opposition from China and Russia, and the council will likely continue discussing the issue.

images.alt_text: The United Nations (UN) Security Council failed to agree on Tuesday on a statement that would have condemned the coup in Myanmar, called for restraint by the military and threatened to consider "further measures", though diplomats said talks would likely continue.

site_title: China's US$1.3 trillion stock rout tests limit of intervention
summary: China's benchmark CSI 300 Index plummeted 14% in 14 trading days, wiping out over $1.3 trillion in value, the largest global stock rout since 2008. The market's collapse shocked investors and evaded state efforts to slow losses. State-backed funds intervened briefly on Tuesday, but losses resumed. The government has traditionally acted to ensure market stability, particularly around key events like the National People's Congress, now in session. The authorities may take further measures to prevent a panic in a year marking the Communist Party's 100th anniversary.

site_title: In message to China, Biden to meet Australia, India, Japan PMs
summary: US President Joe Biden will hold virtual talks with Australian, Indian, and Japanese prime ministers on Friday, marking the first summit of the "Quad" alliance aimed at countering China's growing assertiveness in the Indo-Pacific region. The meeting will focus on climate change, the Covid-19 pandemic, and maritime security, while also addressing regional and global issues. The talks follow a February meeting of Quad foreign ministers, which pressed for democracy in Myanmar. The summit is seen as a key way for the US to exert pressure on China, with the Biden administration pledging to continue its hawkish line on Beijing while seeking cooperation on issues like climate change.

site_title: Indranee encourages real estate agencies to build trust and professionalism
summary: Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of trust and professionalism in the real estate agency industry, encouraging agencies to raise their standards. She urged property agencies to provide sound advice that meets clients' needs, citing the significance of consumer confidence in property transactions. The government will continue to support the industry through various grants and programs, including the Productivity Solutions Grant and SMEs Go Digital. Indranee also congratulated the Real Estate Women Association on its launch, aiming to cultivate women as industry leaders.

site_title: GameStop stock climbs again as US Congress watches
summary: GameStop's stock price surged 22.9% to $238, a 75% increase for the week, after the retailer announced a digital transition committee led by activist shareholder Ryan Cohen. This comes as the US Congress holds a hearing on making Wall Street fairer for retail investors. The stock's recent climb has drawn attention, particularly after its involvement in a speculative fever on Reddit that impacted Wall Street last month. The company's recent announcement has sparked renewed interest in the stock.

site_title: Crypto-artists court controversy while cashing in on NFTs
summary: Crypto-artists are cashing in on non-fungible tokens (NFTs), with some creators, such as Ben Mauro, becoming multimillionaires. NFTs, unique digital assets, have gained popularity among digital artists as certificates of authenticity, allowing them to claim ownership and value. However, the phenomenon has also raised concerns over the environmental impact of mining cryptocurrencies, such as Ethereum, and potential scams. Critics argue that NFTs deepen wealth disparities among artists and are prone to copyright violations. Despite these concerns, artists like Mauro see NFTs as a new opportunity for digital art, with some platforms, like Flow, offering more eco-friendly alternatives.

site_title: UK TV host Piers Morgan steps down amid Meghan controversies
summary: British TV host Piers Morgan has stepped down from his role presenting ITV's Good Morning Britain after sparking 41,000 complaints over a row with Meghan Markle. Morgan left the show following discussions with ITV, with the network accepting his decision. This comes after Morgan stormed off the set in a row over the Duchess of Sussex.

site_title: US dollar gives up gains as Treasury yields stabilise
summary: The US dollar fell back from 3½-month highs as US Treasury yields stabilized, allowing other currencies such as the pound, Australian dollar, and Kiwi dollar to gain. The dollar index was 0.4% lower, while US 10-year Treasury yields fell to 1.5230%, down from last week's high. The Norwegian crown, an oil-linked currency, gained 0.7% due to rising oil prices, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars also rose. The US Federal Reserve's two-day meeting next week is expected to be closely watched, but no major policy changes are anticipated.

site_title: Top US commander fears Chinese invasion of Taiwan by 2027
summary: US top military commander Admiral Philip Davidson warns that China may invade Taiwan by 2027, accelerating its ambitions to supplant US power in Asia-Pacific. China views Taiwan as part of its territory and has vowed to take it back. Davidson's concerns come as Beijing intensifies its military presence in the region. The US and Taiwan have long been allies, with the US providing military aid to the self-ruled island. China's growing military power and economic influence have raised concerns about its intentions in the region.

site_title: Booking agents tackle friction in tourism voucher checkout
summary: Singapore's SingapoRediscovers Vouchers (SRV) system has improved with the integration of payment portals and time-slot reminders, addressing teething problems. Five appointed booking platforms, including GlobalTix and Klook, have integrated their platforms with merchants, allowing customers to redeem SRV credits directly on attraction and hotel websites. This move aims to enhance the customer experience, streamline the booking process, and drive direct traffic to merchants' channels.

site_title: Death of 60/40 portfolio makes returns tougher for wealth funds
summary: Sovereign wealth funds, including Singapore's GIC and Australia's Future Fund, warn that the typical 60/40 stock and bond portfolio no longer generates sufficient returns due to rising bond yields. Investors can expect annual returns of 1-2% after inflation, down from 6-8% over the past 30-40 years. To adapt, funds must diversify and manage increased regulatory intervention, inflation risks, and geopolitical challenges. Experts caution that the current environment is not conducive to hiding from market volatility, and investors must work harder to achieve returns.

site_title: Oil slips below US$68 as rally fizzles before US supply report
summary: Oil prices slipped below $68 a barrel on Tuesday as concerns about a supply disruption in Saudi Arabia eased, following a drone attack on oil sites the previous day. Brent crude fell 1.06% to $67.52 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) declined 1.6% to $64.01 a barrel. Crude inventories rose sharply in the latest week, according to industry data, with analysts citing refineries remaining shut down due to winter storms. The market is expected to soften further ahead of US supply report on Wednesday.

site_title: Women could give US$20 trillion boost to economic growth by 2050: study
summary: A new study by Bloomberg economists suggests that if women are educated at the same levels as men and hold the same number of jobs, global economic growth could receive a $20 trillion boost by 2050. The study, analyzing 36 developed and emerging economies, found that closing labor market gender gaps is crucial for economic recovery, particularly in the US where women are falling behind in the workforce. Closing the gap could add 30% to India's GDP by 2050 and more than $20 trillion to global growth.

site_title: These 10 key tech trends are reshaping many industries
summary: Bain & Company has identified 10 key tech trends shaping industries, driven by the Covid-19 crisis. These trends include edge AI, 5G factory revolution, usage-based auto insurance, automated and explainable AI, enhanced cybersecurity, workforce technologies, health data, cognitive science and gamification in HR, sharing and leasing models, and technology to reduce food waste. To remain competitive, companies must stay on top of these trends, which have the potential to accelerate digital transformation, improve efficiency, and create new business opportunities.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends 3.7% higher as tech stocks rebound
summary: US stocks rebounded on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 3.7% to 13,073.82, its highest level since March 2020. The tech-rich index has underperformed the Dow and S&P 500 in recent sessions, but Tuesday's gains suggest investors are stepping in when there are pullbacks. Tesla surged nearly 20%, while Apple, Facebook, and Amazon all jumped around four percent or more. The rebound is seen as a positive sign that the Nasdaq has found a bottom, and investors remain optimistic about the economy, which is expected to grow 5.6% in 2021, according to the OECD.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Top Glove, ComfortDelGro
summary: Top Glove Corporation's second-quarter net profit surged to RM2.87 billion, quadrupling from the previous year, and its shares closed up 1.8% on the Singapore bourse. ComfortDelGro's shares also surged 3.7% on Tuesday after the government announced plans to review the financing framework for the Downtown Line.

site_title: Swat Mobility considering IPO in Japan
summary: Swat Mobility, a Singapore-based on-demand bus service provider, is considering an initial public offering in Japan to fund its expansion. The startup, which uses high-precision route-optimizing technology, has partnered with Toyota Motor and other major Japanese companies. An IPO in Japan is preferred, but the firm has also explored listing in the US through a merger with a special purpose acquisition company. Swat Mobility currently operates in several countries, including Japan, the Philippines, and Australia, and has secured investments from prominent venture-capital firms.

site_title: Biden eyes Big Tech critic for regulatory post: media
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to nominate Lina Khan, a Columbia University law professor and advocate for breaking up Big Tech firms, to the Federal Trade Commission. Khan, who has written extensively on the topic, has suggested that antitrust laws could be used to split up tech giants. Her appointment, along with that of Tim Wu to an economic advisory post in the White House, signals an aggressive antitrust stance by the Biden administration. The move is seen as a response to growing backlash against tech behemoths, which have dominated key economic sectors during the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Vaccines, US stimulus boost global GDP forecast: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has sharply raised its 2021 global growth forecast to 5.6%, a 1.4 percentage point increase from its December forecast, citing the deployment of effective vaccines and a US stimulus program as key factors. This improvement in economic prospects is expected to have a positive impact on global GDP. The revised forecast reflects the growing optimism in the global economy, which is expected to continue improving in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The OECD sharply raised its 2021 global growth forecast on Tuesday as the deployment of vaccines and a huge US stimulus programme have greatly improved economic prospects.

site_title: EU plans for 'bumpy' vaccine production
summary: The European Union has acknowledged the challenges in Covid-19 vaccine production and is working to ramp up deliveries in the coming months. The EU's industry commissioner, Thierry Breton, plans to add Johnson & Johnson's single-shot vaccine to its strategy, expected to bring the number of vaccines in use to four. The bloc aims to receive 100 million doses in each of the next three months, despite a disappointing rollout in January due to shortfalls by vaccine makers. Breton has integrated contingency actions into the planning and is in regular contact with the US to ensure supply chains operate with minimum friction.

site_title: Fiscal follies in the Covid recovery
summary: The Covid-19 recovery has led to massive fiscal and monetary policy interventions, including massive government support and low interest rates, which have resulted in a surge in public assets and stock markets. However, as lockdowns lift, policymakers must consider whether to gradually withdraw support or provide more stimulus. The experience of the past year suggests that large-scale transfers will be saved, implying low multiplier effects on aggregate demand. The US$1.9 trillion fiscal package may not be necessary, as most new transfers will be saved, and the additional stimulus is unlikely to fuel inflationary pressure.

site_title: China and Russia to launch lunar space station
summary: Russia and China plan to launch a joint lunar space station, with the project expected to be the largest international space cooperation project for China. The joint venture aims to recapture Russia's former glory in space exploration and to counter China's growing extraterrestrial ambitions. The project follows China's successful launch of its Tianwen-1 probe to Mars last year and its recent mission to bring back rock and soil samples from the Moon. The joint lunar space station is set to be developed on the surface and/or in orbit of the Moon, with the project open to all interested countries and international partners.

images.alt_text: Russia and China unveiled plans on Tuesday for a joint lunar space station, as Moscow seeks to recapture the glory of its space pioneering days of Soviet times, and Beijing gears up its own extraterrestrial ambitions.

site_title: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala partners Apple to produce dramas, comedies, documentaries
summary: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala Yousafzai has partnered with Apple to produce dramas, comedies, documentaries, and children's series for its streaming service, Apple TV+. This expansion builds on their existing partnership, which includes a 2015 documentary and a 2018 promotion of secondary education for girls. Malala aims to bring new voices to the platform and inspire young people and girls worldwide through storytelling. Her production company, Extracurricular, will join Apple TV+'s roster of content creators, including Oprah Winfrey and Steven Spielberg.

site_title: Digital Reboot programme to help SMEs deepen digital capabilities
summary: A collective effort by NTUC, UOB, Ngee Ann Polytechnic, and LearningHub was launched to help 500 SMEs in Singapore transform their businesses through digitalization by the end of next year. The SME Digital Reboot programme, which includes digitalization plans, workflow automation, digital marketing, and training, aims to support companies of all sizes but focuses on SMEs, which employ two-thirds of Singapore's workforce and contribute half of its GDP. The programme has shown promising results in its pilot phase, with 40 companies benefiting from training.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Megachem's associated company, Megachem (Thailand) Public Company, has entered a 49-51% joint venture with Fuji Graphite Works to expand into manufacturing expandable graphite.

site_title: Rising Treasury yields, inflation expectations fuel safe haven pull-out
summary: US Treasury yields surged, reaching 1.59%, amid rising inflation expectations and a $1.9 trillion stimulus package, fueling a sell-off in safe-haven assets like the Japanese yen, Swiss franc, and gold. This has created opportunities for carry trades, with the strengthening US dollar against the yen and franc. Most strategists expect 10-year Treasury yields to rise further, potentially to 1.75-2% this year, with some predicting a US dollar surge to 113 or more and gold falling to $1,600. The US Federal Reserve may also be forced to raise interest rates rapidly, sparking concerns about a systematic meltdown.

site_title: Japan GDP grows 11.7% in Q4, less than preliminary figure
summary: Japan's economy expanded 11.7% in the fourth quarter of 2020, slower than the preliminary 12.7% annualized growth. Weaker capital expenditure and public spending, despite solid exports, contributed to the slower growth. Household spending fell 6.1% in January, indicating consumers remain cautious due to the pandemic. The Bank of Japan will review its policy tools to address concerns of a prolonged economic slowdown, with some analysts warning of a potential delay in Japan's economic recovery.

site_title: Living long and preparing financially for the next black swan
summary: Singapore residents, with one of the longest life expectancies in the world, face challenges in financial planning for a longer life. A steady income stream from work can help fund a long life, but relying on passive income can be scary, especially during uncertain times like the Covid-19 pandemic. The closest product to a defined benefit pension in Singapore is the Central Provident Fund (CPF) Lifelong Income for the Elderly, which provides monthly payouts for life. To age well, saving and learning to invest are crucial, but managing investments becomes challenging with age, requiring strategy, character, and fortitude to cope with volatility and uncertainty.

site_title: The art of de-biasing investment decisions
summary: Investors must acknowledge uncertainties and reduce reliance on mental shortcuts to make informed investment decisions. The US dollar's past performance can be misleading, as market reactions often anticipate interest rate hikes, rather than being driven by them. Historical relationships, or "outside views," such as the US 12-month forward price-earnings ratio and US equity risk premia, can provide a statistical perspective of asset class returns. However, these views are not guarantees, and investors should diversify their portfolios to mitigate risk.

site_title: Is it time to raise taxes on the rich?
summary: A proposed tax hike on the rich in Singapore could raise S$1 billion in revenue, benefiting the government's reserves and redistributive policies. The top 20% of households already pay 56% of taxes but receive 11% of benefits, while the lowest 20% pay 9% of taxes but receive 27% of benefits. Research shows that increasing taxes on the rich by a few percentage points does not affect their consumption, but rather redistributes wealth to lower-income groups. This measure could help narrow the income gap and boost GDP.

site_title: US firms can help Asia-Pacific face challenges: Heng
summary: Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore Heng Swee Keat said US firms can play a constructive role in helping the Asia-Pacific region face challenges such as the pandemic, US-China relations, and rising global debt. He shares the IMF's view that the region will rebound faster than the rest of the world over the next two years. Heng emphasized the importance of securing vaccines for all countries, engaging in strategic competition with China, and promoting free trade agreements to continue globalisation momentum. US corporations can help navigate these challenges and contribute to the region's growth by investing in emerging opportunities, particularly in infrastructure, the digital economy, and sustainability.

site_title: Vodafone to raise 2.58b euros from German tower unit IPO
summary: Vodafone is planning to raise up to 2.58 billion euros (S$4.1 billion) from an initial public offering (IPO) of its European mobile-phone towers unit, Vantage, valued at up to 14.7 billion euros. The IPO, set to run through March 17, will see 88.9 million shares sold at 22.50-29 euros apiece, with two investment funds agreeing to buy 500 million and 450 million euros of stock. Proceeds will be used to pay down Vodafone's debt pile, and the company plans to pay out 60% of recurring free cash flow annually in dividends.

site_title: The new challenge facing SMEs is how to be deeply digital
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have made significant progress in digitalization since the COVID-19 pandemic, with over 35,000 enterprises adopting digital solutions and 40,000 signing up in 2020. However, to achieve sustained impact on their bottom lines, SMEs must deepen their digital capabilities, particularly in handling the new currency of digitalization - data. The government has announced initiatives to help SMEs achieve this, including the Chief Technology Officer-as-a-Service scheme and the Better Data Driven Business programme. According to a bank, SMEs that are "highly digital" (conducting more than 50% of their banking activities digitally) outperform less digitalized peers by 2.5 times in revenue.

site_title: Can new collaboration models help us build back better together?
summary: Singapore is exploring new collaboration models to effectively solve complex social problems. The government has named this year's Budget "Emerging Stronger Together," emphasizing the need for deeper civic participation. Social impact investing models, such as Pay For Success and Social Impact Guarantee, have been adapted to Asia and show promise in mobilizing new segments of society to solve problems in a fiscally prudent way. These models aim to complement the state's role in solving social issues and tap into the vast assets under management in Singapore, potentially adding $38 billion to the local social ecosystem.

site_title: Property scandal roils S Korea as house prices soar
summary: Police in South Korea raided the headquarters of Korea Land and Housing Corp, amid allegations of insider information being used to profit from soaring property prices. The move piles pressure on the ruling party ahead of key elections. The corporation's employees are accused of engaging in illegal property speculation, fueling the issue and draining support from the ruling party. The police are gathering evidence to determine the extent of the alleged wrongdoing.

site_title: The Louvre turns to merch
summary: The Louvre museum in Paris has begun selling merchandise, such as face masks and T-shirts, to help offset losses from the pandemic. The museum, which typically attracts 9.6 million visitors annually, suffered a 90 million euro loss in revenue due to the coronavirus closures. Since March 2021, the Louvre has remained shut, with the goal of keeping the museum's name alive while its doors stay closed. Selling merchandise is seen as a way to generate revenue and maintain the museum's brand presence.

site_title: Covid-19 dents financial confidence of Singapore's high-net-worth women
summary: A survey of 250 high-net-worth women in Singapore found nearly half feel financially insecure despite having a personal net wealth of at least S$2 million. Concerns include inadequate knowledge of wealth management, fear of investments failing, and rising medical expenses. The Covid-19 pandemic has reduced risk tolerance and confidence in investments. Only 24% focus on wealth preservation, and 30% believe they are on track to reach retirement goals. The survey highlights the need for financial education and planning among high-net-worth women.

site_title: Chinese EV trio eyes HK listings this year to raise combined US$5b
summary: Chinese electric vehicle makers Li Auto, Nio, and Xpeng plan to list in Hong Kong this year, aiming to raise around $5 billion by selling at least 5% of their enlarged share capital. The listings would tap into growing demand from Asian investors and allow the companies to expand their sales networks and fund technology development. The move comes as the industry expects Chinese sales of new-energy vehicles to jump 40% this year, and the companies seek to compete with US peer Tesla in the world's biggest EV market.

site_title: S-Reits on journey to raise sustainability standards
summary: S-REITs in Singapore are shifting focus towards sustainability, with many producing annual sustainability reports and incorporating green finance into their strategies. The Singapore Exchange and Monetary Authority of Singapore have encouraged companies to prioritize sustainability, with initiatives such as the Green Finance Action Plan and guidelines for environmental risk management. As investors increasingly prioritize ESG considerations, S-REITs aim to increase the proportion of "green" properties in their portfolios and achieve relevant green building certifications. The industry is well-positioned to remain globally competitive, with REITAS working to raise sustainability standards and enjoy a "sustainability premium".

site_title: Loan growth, easing provisions, low valuations among factors that will lift China bank shares
summary: China's Big Four banks are expected to see earnings support in 2021 due to loan growth and easing provisions. Loan growth is forecasted to be double-digit, driven by the country's GDP, while loan loss provisions are expected to return to normal levels. The banks' valuations remain cheap, and a potential re-rating of their shares is expected as China opens up its financial market. Additionally, the banks offer attractive dividend yields of over 6%.

site_title: Google Pay shaping up to be serious contender in South-east Asia
summary: Google Pay is expanding its presence in South-east Asia, particularly in Singapore, with viral marketing campaigns and cashback promises. The platform has already made a significant impact in India, posing a threat to local players. Google Pay's aggressive marketing strategy has captured consumers' attention, as seen in its campaign during Chinese New Year. Observers believe Google Pay could become a serious contender in the region, following its successful entry into the Indian market.

images.alt_text: Patrick Teo, site lead and engineering director for payments at Google Singapore, says Google Pay aims to help consumers access a range of services through a single app.

site_title: US and China must avoid exaggerated fears that could create conflict
summary: The US-China relationship is entering a period of competition, with some analysts predicting a potential conflict between an established hegemon and an increasingly powerful challenger. However, the author argues that economic and ecological interdependence reduces the probability of a real cold war, and that both countries have an incentive to cooperate. Despite China's growing economic power, the US retains long-term power advantages in geography, energy, demographics, and key technologies. Both sides must avoid exaggerated fears and miscalculations, as a new cold or hot war could be catastrophic. A constructive relationship is possible if American leaders acknowledge China's rise and take a nuanced approach.

site_title: US: Nasdaq jumps at open as tech stocks gain ground
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite rising 313.9 points, or 2.4%, to 12,923.071, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 89.9 points, or 0.28%, and the S&P 500 rose 30.6 points, or 0.80%. Investors bought into beaten-down technology stocks amid retreating US bond yields.

site_title: US Treasury yields stabilise, but investors still wary
summary: US Treasury yields have stabilised, but traders remain cautious, awaiting February consumer prices data and Treasury auctions. Higher nominal yields may be required if inflation expectations rise, driven by improving US economic expectations. Market-based inflation expectations are near 2014 levels, and a 10-year yield above 2% is possible, posing risks of a stock-market sell-off. Traders are setting short bets in futures, and volatility may curb appetite to cover, leading to messy auctions and bloated dealer balance sheets.

site_title: Patchy earnings recovery in FY20 hints at 'worst being over'
summary: Analysts say the worst corporate earnings downturn is over, citing a recent bounce-back in financial results. Banks surpassed expectations, with lower credit costs and easing net interest margin pressure. Plantation and healthcare companies also saw earnings recover, while some real estate investment trusts (Reits) outperformed due to capital distribution. Despite a patchy recovery, the trend suggests a positive shift in corporate earnings, with analysts upgrading forecasts for banks and Reits.

site_title: Thai PM sprays reporters with hand sanitiser to duck tricky questions
summary: Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha interrupted a news conference, spraying reporters with hand sanitizer to avoid answering questions about vacant Cabinet posts following the jailing of three ministers. He became frustrated when asked about the list, saying he didn't know and shouldn't be informed first. The unusual move was seen as comical and not out of character for Prayuth, who has a history of lashing out at reporters. The incident left journalists stunned and amused, but Prayuth continued to speak with them, looking increasingly vexed.

site_title: Capturing the wind and carbon
summary: The European Union is considering promoting the use of green hydrogen and ammonia as part of its upcoming maritime fuel law, with major shipping companies and environmentalists backing the move. This comes as the industry faces pressure to reduce emissions, with some companies opting for liquefied natural gas (LNG) and others investing in wind power and carbon capture technology. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) is also exploring a $5 billion programme to accelerate the introduction of zero-emission technologies.

site_title: Twitter files lawsuit against Texas AG over probe after Trump ban
summary: Twitter sued Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton to halt an investigation into its moderation practices after the social media giant banned former President Donald Trump. Twitter claims the investigation is an attempt to intimidate and target the company over its exercise of free speech rights. The company asked a court to block the request for confidential documents, but Paxton's office refused. Paxton also opened investigations into YouTube, Facebook, Apple, and Google, accusing them of anti-conservative bias. Twitter maintains its right to remove content under the First Amendment.

site_title: Financier Greensill files for UK insolvency after valuation fears
summary: Greensill Capital, a supply chain finance company, filed for UK insolvency after key backers, including Credit Suisse, walked away over concerns about asset valuations. The company had sought a US$7 billion valuation in fundraising talks last year but is now expected to sell its business for around US$60 million. Greensill's loans to non-investment grade borrowers, including Sanjeev Gupta's companies, were at the center of the trouble. The company's collapse was swift, with regulators in Germany shutting down its local bank and regulators in the UK reviewing its administration filing.

site_title: India considers national plan for cybersecurity
summary: India is considering a national cybersecurity plan to strengthen its defenses against potential threats, including alleged Chinese intrusions that may have affected critical infrastructure such as the stock exchange and electricity supply in Mumbai. The plan will coordinate responses across government ministries and set up audit procedures to secure critical infrastructure like water, health, and education systems. The Cabinet committee on security, headed by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, is expected to approve the plan, which aims to prevent and respond to cyber threats and protect India's digital systems.

site_title: Establish proper protocol for future closure of Johor-Singapore border
summary: Malaysia's closure of the Johor-Singapore border during the COVID-19 pandemic has had significant economic and social impacts on the region. The unilateral decision, made without prior consultation with Singapore, has disrupted cross-border trade and travel, affecting thousands of workers who commute daily to Singapore. The closure has also damaged the notion of seamless connectivity between the two countries, impacting Johor's economy and property values. To mitigate future disruptions, there is an urgent need for Malaysia and Singapore to establish a permanent cross-border health protocol, considering their close physical and economic ties.

site_title: The Covid crucible: A play in three acts
summary: CFA Singapore Insights: A professor at New York University analyzed the Covid-19 crisis and found it followed a three-stage pattern: a meltdown, a melt-up, and a recalibration. The initial meltdown occurred in February 2020, with global markets plummeting by 30% or more. However, the Federal Reserve intervened and the markets stabilized by March 2020. The market then experienced a significant recovery, with stocks reaching new highs by September 2020. The crisis reshaped the markets, with the worst-performing regions being the United Kingdom, Russia, Eastern Europe, Africa, and Latin America.

site_title: China's electric vehicles in fresh fight using million-dollar showrooms in malls
summary: China's electric vehicle makers are investing heavily in luxury malls to gain an edge in the market, with over half of Shanghai's malls featuring EV showrooms. Rents for these showrooms can reach $1 million annually, as brands like Nio and Xpeng seek to differentiate themselves from established automakers and target the middle class. The trend is driven by growing demand for EVs in China, forecast to soar 50% in 2021, and mall owners seeking new tenants to replace declining sales of traditional shopping center drawcards.

site_title: US stimulus set to boost global economy as Europe lags behind: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) forecasts a faster-than-expected global economic upswing, driven by the US stimulus package, which will boost global output to above pre-pandemic levels by mid-2021. The US growth forecast is raised to 6.5% from 4.2%, while Europe is expected to lag behind, with the euro area contracting 0.7% in Q4 2020. The OECD warns of "sizable risks" to the outlook, but emphasizes the need for governments and central banks to act cautiously to avoid tightening policies too quickly and risking a prolonged recovery.

site_title: A composer's notes echo after his death
summary: Finnish composer Einojuhani Rautavaara's death in 2016 left behind a legacy of his serenades, which were completed by his protégé Mikko Franck and performed by violinist Hilary Hahn and the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France. The two serenades, Serenade to My Love and Serenade to Life, were written as a gift for Hahn, with Rautavaara drawing from his own music and a set of serenades from the 1970s. The premiere recording, released on a new album, showcases the beautiful and emotive music, with Hahn describing it as a "living legacy" that completes Rautavaara's catalogue.

site_title: ION Group, GIC in 1.86b euro bid for Italian credit group
summary: ION Group and Singapore's GIC are launching a 1.86 billion euro bid for Italian credit group Cerved, valuing it at 9.50 euros per share. This represents a 34.9% premium on the March 5 closing share price. The bid, made through Castor, is conditional on securing at least 90% of the company's shares and will support Cerved's current business plan. This follows recent acquisitions by Ion Group, including a 1.5 billion euro deal for Italian banking software provider Cedacri and a 2.52 billion dollar deal for financial news company Acuris in 2019.

site_title: Gojek invests in Indonesian e-wallet LinkAja, joins Grab as investor
summary: Gojek has invested in Indonesian e-wallet LinkAja, joining Grab as an investor. The partnership will allow LinkAja users to pay for selected Gojek services and vice versa. The investment, valued at over $100 million, aims to improve cashless payments in Indonesia. This move strengthens the digital footprint of both companies and marks a significant development in the Indonesian fintech market.

site_title: Wristbands to track visitor movements at hybrid business event
summary: Singapore is set to revive its Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions (MICE) sector with new measures at the Geo Connect Asia 2021 event. Almost 1,000 business visitors and delegates will try out wristbands to track movements and partitioned meeting pods with microphones at the Marina Bay Sands on March 24-25. This is the first large-scale hybrid MICE event since the Covid-19 pandemic, and aims to promote safe and efficient event management.

site_title: Top Glove Q2 net profit surges to RM2.87b on record sales
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, reported a surge in Q2 net profit to RM2.87 billion, quadrupling from RM115.7 million in the same period last year. The company achieved its highest-ever quarterly sales revenue of RM5.37 billion and a 19% year-over-year increase in sales volume. The board declared a Q2 dividend of 25.2 sen per share, totaling a 70% dividend payout, with earnings per share reaching 35.77 sen. The company attributed its strong sales to continued global demand for gloves and higher average selling prices.

site_title: Will local investors take to foreign-listed tech stocks like Sea after inclusion in key indices?
summary: Singapore's inclusion of Nasdaq-listed Sea Ltd in the MSCI Singapore Indices could boost local investment sentiment, but investors may treat Sea as an anomaly due to its foreign listing and unfamiliar businesses. The company's inclusion could provide a growth-oriented dimension to the local market, but its valuation may be viewed differently from staid stalwarts like DBS, OCBC, and Singtel. The MSCI Singapore Index has historically been dominated by these banks and Singtel, with a 58% weighting towards them. Sea's American Depositary Receipts have climbed 480% since 2019, and its market capitalization tops US$117 billion, more than twice DBS's current market value.

site_title: Shell strikes US$926m deal to sell oil assets in Egyptian desert
summary: Royal Dutch Shell has agreed to sell its oil assets in Egypt's Western Desert to Cairn Energy and Cheiron Petroleum for up to $926 million. The deal includes 13 onshore concessions and will allow Shell to focus on offshore production and natural gas in Egypt. The transaction, valued at $646 million, is contingent on exploration results and oil prices. The sale will help Egypt maximize its onshore assets through new investment.

site_title: Japan to keep foreign spectators away from Tokyo Olympics
summary: Japan has decided to stage this summer's Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics without overseas spectators due to public concern about Covid-19. The decision was made following a survey showing 77% of respondents opposed to allowing foreign fans to attend, citing fears of a resurgence of infections. The Olympics are scheduled for July 23 to August 8, and the Paralympics from August 24 to September 5, with only participants and invitees allowed to attend the opening ceremony in Fukushima.

images.alt_text: Japan has decided to stage this summer's Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics without overseas spectators due to concern among the Japanese public about Covid-19.

site_title: US cites new threat to carriers from Chinese anti-ship missile
summary: The US military has warned that China's recent test launch of its DF-21D anti-ship ballistic missile in the South China Sea poses a significant threat to US aircraft carriers. Admiral Phil Davidson stated that the missile's range and capabilities make it a credible threat, and China's military exercises in the region demonstrate its focus on countering potential third-party intervention. China's military actions in the South China Sea are seen as a challenge to regional peace and stability, and the US is concerned about the impact on its allies and partners' autonomy.

site_title: UK shop sales soar as end of lockdown nears: report
summary: UK retail sales growth accelerated in February, with a 1% increase compared to the same period last year, driven by purchases of back-to-school items ahead of the end of the coronavirus lockdown. This is in contrast to a 0.1% gain in the same period a year ago and an average 0.6% growth over the past three months, according to the British Retail Consortium and KPMG.

images.alt_text: Retail businesses have invested heavily to make their premises Covid- secure to encourage customers to return to shops.

site_title: Women could give US$20t boost to economic growth by 2050
summary: A new study by Bloomberg economists suggests that if women are educated at the same levels as men and hold the same number of jobs, global economic growth could receive a US$20 trillion boost by 2050. Currently, women make up 58.4% of the workforce, compared to 92.1% of men, with the US experiencing a decline in female workforce participation. Closing the labor-market gender gap is crucial for the economy's recovery and could add 30% to India's GDP by 2050, according to the report.

site_title: Myanmar party official dies after arrest
summary: A Myanmar official, Zaw Myat Linn, from the National League for Democracy (NLD), died in custody after being arrested in Yangon on Tuesday. This is the second NLD official to die in detention in two days, following Khin Maung Latt's arrest on Saturday night. Hundreds of protesters were trapped in Yangon's Sanchaung district on Monday night, but thousands rallied in support, with many escaping detention. The military's crackdown on protests continues, with over 60 protesters killed and 1,800 detained since the February 1 coup.

site_title: Puma Energy to launch US$1.1b rights issue
summary: Puma Energy, a Singapore-based fuel retailer and storage firm, is launching a $1.1 billion rights issue to repay a 2018 term loan facility. The funds will be used to support the company's five-year strategic plan. Trafigura Group, which owns 55.6% of Puma's shares, has indicated support for the rights issue and will take up the offered shares. The rights issue is expected to close in mid-April, following a period of restructuring and asset sales due to annual losses of $753 million in 2019 and $250 million in the third quarter of 2020.

site_title: Trader buys US$36m of copper and gets painted rocks instead
summary: A commodities trader, Mercuria Energy Group, lost $36 million after buying 6,000 tons of copper from a Turkish supplier, only to find containers full of painted rocks instead. The incident, dubbed cargo fraud, highlights traders' vulnerability to such scams despite security measures. This is not the first time Mercuria has faced losses due to similar incidents, with provisions taken in 2014 and 2015 after metal seizures in a Chinese port. The case underscores the need for improved security and inspection controls to prevent such fraud.

site_title: Healthtech startup Mesh Bio raises US$1.8m in seed funding
summary: Singapore-based Mesh Bio, a digital health startup, raised US$1.8 million in seed funding led by Elev8.vc and SEEDS Capital. The funds will be used to accelerate the rollout of its predictive analytics platform, DARA, in South-east Asia, and support clinical partnerships and collaborations. Mesh Bio aims to use its platform to manage chronic diseases using predictive analytics. The investment marks a significant boost for the startup, which will help it expand its presence in the region and drive innovation in the digital health space.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 12.97 points to 1,624.78 on Tuesday, closing higher. Volume was 8.124 billion lots worth RM5.908 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 634 to 551.

site_title: Connect@Changi receives first batch of guests
summary: The first batch of guests has arrived at Connect@Changi, a dedicated business meeting facility at Singapore Expo, with 15 travellers from countries including Germany, France, Indonesia, Japan, and the UAE. The facility, launched on February 18, offers specially-designed meeting rooms with air-tight glass panels, allowing for safe in-person meetings. The first guest, French CEO Olivier Leroux, will stay for five days, meeting his Singapore-based counterparts four to five times. The facility aims to resume international business meetings safely under pandemic conditions, with plans to host up to 1,300 travellers at a time when fully operational later this year.

site_title: 'Shoot me instead', Myanmar nun pleads with junta forces
summary: A Catholic nun, Sister Ann Rose Nu Tawng, pleaded with Myanmar junta forces to spare "the children" during a protest in the city of Myitkyina, where she was shot and tear gas was used, killing two protesters. The incident, which has gone viral, is part of the chaotic aftermath of the military's February 1 ouster of civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi. The junta has escalated its use of force, and more than 60 people have been killed in anti-coup demonstrations around the country.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets little changed at open
summary: European stock markets opened little changed on Tuesday, as investors weighed inflation and interest rate concerns against a strong recovery from the coronavirus crisis. Despite EU leaders' pledge to double vaccine deliveries, European markets were flat, with the FTSE 100, DAX 30, and CAC 40 indices unchanged or slightly down.

site_title: Meghan's father suggests she exaggerated royal racism
summary: Meghan Markle's father, Thomas Markle, has suggested that his daughter exaggerated racism in the British royal family during her interview with Oprah Winfrey, calling the couple's claims "way over the top." He downplayed a comment about a royal family member asking about the baby's skin color, saying it was likely a "dumb question." Markle also expressed regret over not being there for Meghan when she felt suicidal, but claimed she had "pretty much ghosted" him and his family.

site_title: Rotation into cyclicals puts Singapore shares at advantage as STI rises 1.22%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.22% to 3,108.53 points, driven by a rotation out of technology stocks into cyclical counters. The STI, dominated by banks and property, benefited from the shift, with Jardine Matheson's acquisition bid and unaudited results boosting the diversified conglomerate. Meanwhile, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust shed 1.46% due to rising inflation fears. Key regional markets were mixed, with Japan and Australia's indices rising, while South Korea's Kospi Index fell.

site_title: Six new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported six new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 60,052. All cases were placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. There were no community cases and no cases from migrant workers' dormitories. The Ministry of Health confirmed the new cases at noon on March 9, 2021.

site_title: Vodafone seeks US$2.4b from Vantage Towers IPO
summary: Vodafone Group plans to raise US$2.4 billion from an initial public offering (IPO) of its European mobile-phone towers unit, Vantage Towers. The UK telecommunications giant will sell shares at 22.50-29 euros apiece, with a target of 2.8 billion euros in proceeds. Two investment funds have agreed to buy 950 million euros of stock, covering the full deal size. The IPO values Vantage at up to 14.7 billion euros, with Vodafone using the proceeds to pay down debt. The offering will run through March 17, with trading starting on March 18.

site_title: Singapore SMEs on road to recovery, but challenges remain: report
summary: Nearly three-quarters of Singapore SMEs expect to recover from the pandemic by April, with 23% investing in preparations and 56% expanding their online presence. Despite optimistic sentiments, challenges remain, including labour, sales, and financing difficulties. A third of SMEs plan to adopt non-cash payment options, driven by the accelerated adoption of digital payment services. SMEs have shown resilience through innovation and adaptation, with the commercial landscape becoming more digital and fast-paced.

site_title: US stimulus set to boost global economy as Europe lags behind
summary: The OECD forecasts a faster-than-expected global economic upswing, with US output expected to rise 6.5% in 2021, driven by President Biden's stimulus package. The global growth forecast is raised to 5.6% from 4.2%, with Canada and Mexico expected to benefit from positive spillovers. However, Europe is expected to lag behind, with the euro area contracting 0.7% in the final quarter of 2020, and some economies not making up lost GDP by 2022. The OECD warns of "sizable risks" to the outlook due to the pandemic, and calls for cautious fiscal policies to ensure a smooth recovery.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek partnered with global impact investor Leapfrog in a US$500m deal. GIC invested US$1.2b in a US retail real estate platform. Bond yields rose, but experts say they're still below a potential Minsky moment. 1982 Ventures partnered with South Korean investors, and condominium developments were put on the market. A Mastercard report found nearly three quarters of Singapore SMEs expect to recover from the pandemic by April. The Straits Times Index rose 1.22% due to rotation into cyclicals.

site_title: Myanmar protesters able to leave Yangon district after being trapped
summary: Hundreds of Myanmar protesters trapped in a Yangon district by security forces have been allowed to leave after international pressure and calls for restraint. The protests, which began over a month ago, demand the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and respect for the election won by her National League for Democracy party. Despite security forces killing over 60 protesters and detaining over 1,800, thousands of people defied a curfew to support the youths in Sanchaung district. The UN, US, and Britain have condemned the junta's actions, with the European Union preparing to widen sanctions.

site_title: Severe obesity raises risk of Covid-19 hospitalisation and death, study finds
summary: A large US study of nearly 150,000 adults found that severe obesity significantly increases the risk of Covid-19 hospitalization and death. Patients with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 45 or higher were 33% more likely to be hospitalized and 61% more likely to die than those at a healthy weight. The study also revealed that underweight patients were more likely to be hospitalized than those at a healthy weight. The findings suggest the need for early vaccination recommendations for those with high BMI.

images.alt_text: Over the past year, many scientific teams around the world have reported that obese people who contract the coronavirus are especially likely to become dangerously ill.

site_title: Argentine wheat planting facing pressure from rival barley, politics
summary: Argentina's wheat planting is likely to fall this year due to increased demand for South American feed barley from China, which has sidelined Australia as its usual supplier. Chinese imports of barley are expected to drive some farmers to switch from wheat to barley, a move that can reduce regulatory risks. The Argentine government's recent intervention in the corn market has left farmers wary of future market disruptions, leading some to opt for barley instead. Wheat planting has shrunk in recent years due to government intervention, and this year's sowing is likely to be lower.

site_title: Eagle Hospitality Trust entities' sale of properties gets opening bid
summary: Eagle Hospitality Trust entities have entered into a stalking-horse agreement with Madison Phoenix LLC, an affiliate of Monarch Alternative Capital LP, to sell 15 out of 18 properties as part of their Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings. The stalking-horse agreement sets an opening price of $470 million, but it's unlikely to generate any residual value for stapled security holders. A second bid round and auction will follow to solicit higher bids, with proceeds first used to cover costs and pay pre-petition creditors.

site_title: Asia needs ESG to boost longer-term GDP growth: report
summary: A Deutsche Bank CIO report suggests that focusing on green investments in Asia can stimulate longer-term economic growth, citing a statistically significant relationship between environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) performance and a country's living standards. Improving ESG practices in Indonesia, for example, could lead to a 15% increase in GDP per capita. The report notes that Asia is already embracing ESG, with countries like Singapore launching green plans and regional integration agreements creating opportunities for enhanced regulation and fair competition. However, standardizing ESG standards and improving data quality remain challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on financials
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by strong financials, as technology stocks fell 1.7% to a five-month low. The S&P/ASX 200 index added to Monday's 0.4% gain. Financial stocks supported the index with a 1% gain, while tech stocks were weighed down by rising US Treasury yields and concerns over lofty valuations. Afterpay and software companies Megaport and Xero fell 3.6%, 4.4%, and 3.8%, respectively.

site_title: Astrea VI private equity bonds launched; subscription starts March 10
summary: Azalea Asset Management has launched the retail tranche of Astrea VI private equity bonds with a fixed interest rate of 3% per annum. The S$250 million worth of Class A-1 bonds will be open for subscription starting March 10, with a minimum subscription of S$2000. The bonds have a scheduled call date in five years and final maturity in 10 years. The latest issue aims to democratize access to private equity for retail investors, with the lowest interest rates yet, and follows the successful placement of previous Astrea issuances.

site_title: Bond yields up, but 'still some way off' from Minsky moment, says GIC's top exec
summary: GIC's CEO Lim Chow Kiat notes that while bond yields have spiked due to vaccine optimism and stimulus, the situation is not yet at the "Minsky moment" - a sudden collapse of asset values. He warns of potential overheating concerns, including inflation and excessive credit growth, but believes the current level of yields is not high enough to cause significant valuation issues. Lim also highlights the importance of ESG investing and green finance, stating that GIC will focus on transitioning to sustainability, with technology playing a key role.

site_title: WH Smith trims monthly cash burn estimate as online sales surge
summary: Retailer WH Smith has trimmed its monthly cash burn estimate due to a surge in online sales during Britain's latest lockdown. The company now estimates 12-17 million pounds in monthly cash burn between January and March, down from a previous range of 15-20 million pounds. High street revenue was at 74% of 2019 levels for January and 84% for February, with record sales for Valentine's Day in its online greeting cards business. The company also extended its term loans and canceled a liquidity loan, allowing it to reduce its cash burn.

site_title: UK shop sales accelerate as end of lockdown nears, BRC says
summary: UK retail sales growth accelerated to 1% in February, driven by purchases of back-to-school items ahead of the government's roadmap to end the coronavirus lockdown. This marked a significant increase from 0.1% a year ago and 0.6% for the past three months. E-commerce sales surged 115% and food and drink sales grew 63%. Despite the uptick, retailers remain concerned about the months ahead, with demand expected to be slow to return. Online sales, in particular, have become a popular mainstay of life in lockdown.

site_title: Coffee company JDE Peet's 2020 sales fall, sees 2021 growth
summary: JDE Peet's, a coffee company, reported a 4.2% decline in annual sales to 6.65 billion euros (S$10.6 billion) for 2020, mainly due to lost sales in cafes caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. However, adjusted operating profit rose 1.2% to 1.28 billion euros. The company expects to see growth in 2021 as home-use products continue to boom.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei snaps losing streak
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed nearly 1% higher on Tuesday, snapping a three-day losing streak, as bargain-hunting drove gains. The Nikkei 225 rose 0.99% to 29,027.94, while the broader Topix index gained 1.27% to 1,917.68.

site_title: Get BT's Personal Edition now with Grab Ride vouchers
summary: The Business Times (BT) is offering a limited-time promotion for its Personal Edition package in celebration of International Women's Day. New subscribers can receive S$30 worth of Grab Ride vouchers for a one-year contract and S$80 for a two-year subscription. The Personal Edition package costs S$9.90 per month and provides unlimited access to premium articles, a daily e-paper, and two-week e-paper archives. Interested readers can visit btsub.sg/IWD2021 for more information and to subscribe.

site_title: Singapore-Indonesia Bilateral Investment Treaty enters into force
summary: The Singapore-Indonesia Bilateral Investment Treaty (BIT) entered into force on March 9, 2021, providing additional protection for investments from both countries. The treaty offers recourse to international arbitration and aims to promote greater investment flows, trade, and business ties between the two nations. Singapore's investments in Indonesia totaled US$9.8 billion in 2020, while Indonesia remained Singapore's top 10 trading partner, with bilateral trade reaching S$48.8 billion. The treaty is expected to strengthen the regulatory framework and boost confidence among business communities.

site_title: Bitcoin mania triggers fundraising rush by Chinese players
summary: Chinese companies are raising funds to expand into the cryptocurrency sector, fueled by Bitcoin's surge in value. Ebang International Holdings and newcomer Code Chain New Continent have conducted fundraising rounds, with Ebang raising $170 million and Code Chain raising $25 million. Despite China's complicated official attitudes towards cryptocurrencies, investors see opportunities in blockchain technology, which underpins Bitcoin and is also key to new innovations. The market boom has attracted venture capitalists, and Coinbase's upcoming Nasdaq listing is expected to lift the mood further.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end on positive note
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Tuesday, rebounding from a sharp sell-off the previous day, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.81% to 28,773.23. Investors remain cautious about a global economic recovery and potential inflation. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.82% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 2.84%.

site_title: Australia health minister in hospital after Covid-19 vaccination
summary: Australian Health Minister Greg Hunt, 55, was admitted to hospital with a suspected Covid-19 infection two days after receiving the AstraZeneca vaccine. He is receiving antibiotics and fluid for observation and is expected to make a full recovery, his office stated. This marks the third time a federal Cabinet member has received treatment for health issues, following Attorney-General Christian Porter and Defence Minister Linda Reynolds. The health minister's condition is not related to the vaccine.

site_title: Zwift names Twitter's Pichette, Lululemon's Burgoyne to board
summary: Zwift, an online fitness platform, has named Patrick Pichette and Celeste Burgoyne to its board. Pichette, Twitter's chairman and a partner at Inovia Capital, and Burgoyne, Lululemon's first president, bring experience in tech and customer-facing aspects. Zwift plans to develop hardware to complement its software platform, aiming for a fully integrated at-home fitness experience. The company, valued above $1 billion, has seen a boom in at-home workouts due to the pandemic, hosting virtual events like the Tour de France.

site_title: Norway suspends Rolls-Royce asset sale on security grounds
summary: Norway has suspended a planned asset sale by Rolls-Royce engine maker Bergen Engines due to security concerns. The 150 million euro sale to a company controlled by Russia's TMH Group was set to be completed as part of Rolls-Royce's disposal plan to aid the company's survival during the pandemic. Norway's NSM security agency is assessing the implications of the sale on the country's navy, prompting the suspension.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end lower on rising bond yields, tech sell-off
summary: South Korean shares closed lower on Tuesday, down 0.67% at 2,976.12, following a fourth straight session of declines. The decline was driven by higher bond yields and weaker technology shares, with the Kospi reaching a 2.23% intraday low. The benchmark index had previously fallen by over 2% earlier in the session, but retreated from its lowest level since January 5.

site_title: Carlyle-backed China biotech firm plans Hong Kong IPO
summary: Abbisko Therapeutics Co, a Shanghai-based Chinese biotech company backed by Carlyle Group and Warburg Pincus, plans a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) to raise approximately $250 million. The company, which focuses on oncology treatments, aims to list in Hong Kong this year. This follows a record year for healthcare and biotech firms listing in the city, with seven debut companies raising $2.1 billion so far this year. Abbisko has previously raised $263 million in funding, including a $123 million series D round led by Carlyle and Warburg in January.

site_title: Malaysia court allows rights groups to challenge Myanmar deportations: lawyer
summary: A Malaysian court has allowed international human rights groups to challenge the country's deportation of over 1,000 Myanmar nationals to their homeland. Despite a law preventing court challenges to immigration authorities' decisions, the court granted the groups the right to review the deportation plan. The groups' lawyer said the ruling recognizes the role of non-governmental organizations in holding authorities accountable. The deportation plan was made despite concerns that it could include asylum-seekers or refugees fleeing persecution in Myanmar.

site_title: 7 in 10 plan to invest more into Asia-Pacific hotels: poll
summary: A poll by JLL found that 7 in 10 investors plan to increase their investment in the Asia-Pacific hotel sector in 2021, with expected transactions reaching US$7 billion, a 20% increase from last year. Despite the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, investors see a recovery on the horizon and are willing to invest in renovations, repurposing, and repositioning to adapt to changing consumer preferences. Investors are also anticipating a narrowing of the price-expectation gap between buyers and sellers, with discounts expected to decrease as sellers adjust to operating cash flow.

site_title: Chinese EV trio eye Hong Kong listings this year to raise combined US$5b: sources
summary: US-listed Chinese electric vehicle makers Li Auto, Nio, and Xpeng plan to list in Hong Kong this year, raising at least US$5 billion in combined capital. The trio aims to sell at least 5% of their enlarged share capital, seeking to tap a growing investor base closer to home. The listings come as the companies increase capital raising efforts to fund technology development and expand sales networks in the world's biggest EV market. Analysts see the move as a strategic step for the companies to access domestic capital markets and enhance their global presence.

site_title: Facebook tests feature in India to share Instagram reels on its news feed
summary: Facebook is testing a feature in India that allows some Instagram creators to share their 30-second "Reels" on their Facebook accounts. This feature, currently in testing, aims to expand content creators' reach and provide users with more entertaining content. The move follows the success of TikTok, which was banned in India last year, and comes as other social media companies, such as Snapchat, roll out similar short-video services.

site_title: Office space provider IWG says recovery taking longer
summary: IWG, a leading office space provider, announced that the market recovery from the coronavirus pandemic is taking longer than anticipated, prompting the shutdown of underperforming centers. Despite this, the company has seen increased demand for hybrid workspaces and suburban locations. IWG posted an adjusted operating loss of 173.8 million pounds for the year ended Dec. 31, 2020, compared to a profit a year earlier. The company is adapting to the shift to remote working, offering flexible access to its over 3,300 offices.

images.alt_text: Office space provider IWG on Tuesday signalled that it will shut more underperforming centres as the market recovery from the coronavirus pandemic was taking longer than anticipated, but said it was seeing increased demand for hybrid work.

site_title: Gold recovers from nine-month low as US yields retreat
summary: Gold prices rose 0.7% to $1,692.21 per ounce, rebounding from a nine-month low of $1,676.10, after US Treasury yields retreated. The US 10-year Treasury yield eased, making gold more attractive as a safe-haven asset. Analysts say demand for gold is likely to struggle in an environment of rising US yields and growing economic optimism. Silver, palladium, and platinum also rose, while gold holdings of the SPDR Gold Trust fell to their lowest since April 2020.

images.alt_text: Gold prices rose on Tuesday, as a pullback in US Treasury yields added some lustre to the metal after it hit a nine-month low in the previous session.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, rising 0.44% to 28,665.26, following a steep loss the previous day. Investors remain cautious over higher interest rates as the global economy recovers.

site_title: SME Digital Reboot programme to help SMEs in Singapore deepen digital capabilities
summary: Singapore's SME Digital Reboot programme aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) deepen their digital capabilities by 2022. The programme, led by NTUC LearningHub, will offer digital resources and tools, training in five key tracks, and on-ground implementation support. It targets 500 companies, focusing on SMEs, which often perceive digital transformation as costly and lack support and expertise. The programme has already benefited 38 SMEs and two multinational corporations, and partnerships have been formed with NTUC U SME, The FinLab, and Ngee Ann Polytechnic to boost outreach and provide training and resources.

site_title: Hot stock: ComfortDelGro rallies 4.3% on DTL financing framework review
summary: ComfortDelGro shares surged 4.3% on Tuesday after the government announced its intention to review the financing framework for the Downtown Line (DTL). The review of the New Rail Financing Framework (NRFF) version three, which reduces commercial volatility, is seen as a positive development for ComfortDelGro, which owns a 74% stake in DTL operator SBS Transit. Analysts, including Maybank Kim Eng, view NRFF version three as the most ideal scenario for ComfortDelGro, potentially adding 49% to its FY2021 earnings per share.

site_title: GIC makes further foray in US retail segment, invests in US$1.2b retail real estate platform
summary: GIC has partnered with RPT Realty, Zimmer Partners, and Monarch Alternative Capital to form a net lease retail real estate platform, RGMZ, targeting over $1.2 billion in strategic assets. The platform will be seeded with 42 single-tenant retail assets, valued at $151 million, and will have a secured credit facility of $175 million. GIC and its partners have committed to funding $470 million over the next three years, with RPT owning 6% of the platform. The partnership aims to create a scalable and stable-growth investment platform in the US retail sector.

site_title: Egyptian Billy Elliot sets new bar for Middle Eastern ballet
summary: Luca Abdel-Nour, a 17-year-old Egyptian ballet dancer, has achieved the rare feat of becoming the first Middle Eastern prizewinner at the prestigious Prix de Lausanne in Switzerland. Born to a French mother, Abdel-Nour initially resisted ballet due to societal expectations, but his determination and hard work ultimately led to three prizes, including second overall and the audience award. His success aims to inspire more boys from the Middle East to pursue dance, despite prejudice.

site_title: Swiss retailer Dufry H2 cash burn close to worst-scenario forcast
summary: Swiss duty-free retailer Dufry reported a 2020 turnover of 2.56 billion Swiss francs, a 71.1% decline from the previous year due to coronavirus-led international travel curbs. Its average monthly cash burn was 45.7 million Swiss francs in the second half, close to its worst-case scenario forecast of 60 million Swiss francs. The company operates over 2,400 shops in 65 countries.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as rate hike fears offset reflation trade
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Tuesday as traders weighed growing optimism about global recovery against concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes. Despite a surge in equities over the past year, recent weeks have seen a decline in global stocks. European indexes rose after EU leaders pledged to double vaccine deliveries, while US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, with investors remaining positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Japan's Terumo says makes syringe to draw seven doses from Pfizer vaccine vials
summary: Japan's Terumo Corp has developed a syringe capable of drawing seven doses from each Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine vial, exceeding the standard six doses. The health ministry approved the design, and production is set to begin in March. Terumo aims to manufacture 20 million units this year to address the shortage of specialty syringes, which may result in some vaccine doses going to waste.
