site_title: Singapore-based 1982 Ventures strikes partnership with South Korean investors
summary: Singapore-based venture capital firm 1982 Ventures has partnered with South Korean investors Infobank, C&Venture Partners, and BTC Investment. The partnership aims to provide local support for the Korean investors' expansion into Southeast Asia and offer 1982 Ventures' expertise in fintech. Managing partners Herston Powers and Lee Moonkyu expressed excitement about the collaboration, citing the growing market opportunity in Southeast Asia for Korean investors and startups. The partnership is expected to deepen ties between the two ecosystems.

site_title: Condominium and serviced apartment tower on Devonshire Rd put on market
summary: A condominium and serviced apartment tower on Devonshire Rd in Singapore have been put up for sale by CBRE. The condominium, The Bayron, has a guide price of S$376 million and 96 units, while the serviced apartment tower, Devonshire Apartment, has a guide price of S$66 million. Both properties are freehold and have been zoned for residential use under the Master Plan 2019. The sale is seen as a rare opportunity for developers to acquire quality freehold sites at a strategic location, with CBRE's head of capital markets predicting strong interest from local and foreign investors.

site_title: China launches virus passport
summary: China has launched a health certificate programme for domestic travellers, providing a digital certificate showing vaccination status and virus test results. The programme, available via WeChat, aims to promote world economic recovery and facilitate cross-border travel. While the certificate is not yet mandatory and only available for Chinese citizens, it is seen as a precursor to "virus passports" considered by other countries, including the US and Britain. China's move has raised concerns about government surveillance, but its goal is to enable smoother international travel and economic recovery.

site_title: Global mining trade group picks sustainability expert as new CEO
summary: The International Council on Mining and Metals (ICMM) has appointed Rohitesh Dhawan, a sustainability expert, as its new CEO, effective April 6. Dhawan, currently a managing director at Eurasia Group, will focus on environmental, social, and governance issues, amid increased pressure on the mining industry. The appointment reflects the industry's need to adapt to a "net zero emissions economy." Current CEO Tom Butler will step down, and the ICMM's 27 member companies, representing 30% of the global metals market, will be expected to prioritize sustainability.

site_title: Japan government nominates Nomura Asset CEO Junko Nakagawa for BOJ board: document
summary: The Japanese government has nominated Nomura Asset Management CEO Junko Nakagawa for a seat on the Bank of Japan's nine-member board. The nomination, which needs parliamentary approval, aims to replace Takako Masai, who has consistently voted with the majority but also calls for more debate on prolonged monetary easing. Nakagawa would assume the post after Masai's five-year term ends on June 29.

site_title: Ten years after Fukushima, Japan remembers 'man-made' nuclear disaster
summary: Japan is commemorating the 10th anniversary of the Fukushima nuclear disaster, which was described as "profoundly man-made" by a government investigation. The disaster, triggered by a 9.0-magnitude earthquake and tsunami, killed nearly 20,000 people and led to widespread evacuations. Despite a $300 billion reconstruction effort, the plant remains off-limits due to radiation concerns, and decommissioning is expected to take decades. As Japan aims to achieve net carbon neutrality by 2050, the role of nuclear power remains contentious, with public opinion sharply divided against restarting reactors.

site_title: Philippines' unemployment rate steady at 8.7% in Jan
summary: The Philippines' unemployment rate remained steady at 8.7% in January, unchanged from October, with 4 million jobless people. The labour force expanded to 45.2 million, indicating a recovery from the pandemic. The government believes a gradual relaxation of COVID-19 measures will boost consumer spending and job opportunities, suggesting a return to pre-pandemic employment levels. The rate has decreased from a record 17.7% in April.

site_title: Showrooms in malls new battleground for China EVs
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) makers are investing heavily in luxury malls to gain an edge in the competitive market. Over half of Shanghai's malls now have EV showrooms, with rents reaching around $1 million per year for a 200-300 square meter space. Upstart brands like Nio and Xpeng are staking out ground to differentiate themselves from established automakers and appeal to the middle class. The move is part of a broader strategy to burnish their premium image and gain a foothold in the world's largest EV market.

images.alt_text: China's electric-car makers are paying top-dollar rents to open showrooms in luxury malls, as they seek to gain an edge in the hyper-competitive market.

site_title: Bitcoin hits highest level in two weeks as big-money bets flow
summary: Bitcoin surged to a two-week high of around $53,900, driven by institutional interest and big-money bets. The digital token rose 4.3% as the Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index extended its two-day rally by 13%. Analyst Edward Moya attributed the surge to "big-money bets keep flowing into cryptocurrencies" and "institutional interest still seems strong."

site_title: US daily virus toll below 1,000 for first time in months
summary: The US recorded fewer than 1,000 deaths from Covid-19 for the first time in nearly three and a half months, with 749 fatalities on Monday, according to Johns Hopkins University. This marks a significant drop from the peak of 4,473 deaths on January 12. The last time the daily death toll was below 1,000 was on November 29, 2021, when 822 people died. This decrease suggests a decline in the pandemic's severity in the US.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on hopes of swift passage for US stimulus; tech stocks slide
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,791.3, driven by hopes of a swift US stimulus package, while tech stocks slid 3.1% to a five-month low. Financial stocks, including the "Big Four" banks, gained 1.6% to 2.1%. The benchmark index rose despite tech stocks falling and gold stocks plummeting 1.9%. Investors await a quick passage of President Biden's coronavirus stimulus bill, which would boost liquidity into the markets.

site_title: Colombia targets 30% reduction in deforestation
summary: Colombia has set a target to reduce deforestation by 30% during President Ivan Duque's term, which ends in August 2022. This goal aims to stem tree-felling in the Amazon and other areas. The move is part of efforts to protect old-growth tropical rainforests, which absorb vast amounts of carbon dioxide and are crucial in curbing climate change. The target is less ambitious than previously floated by Duque, but still reflects the country's commitment to preserving the Amazon and its role in mitigating climate change.

site_title: Gap is said to weigh sale of China business as sales lag behind
summary: Gap Inc is considering selling its China business due to lagging sales, which account for about 5% of the company's total revenue. The US clothing retailer is working with an adviser to explore options and has reached out to potential buyers. Gap's China business has faced challenges since the pandemic, and the company may decide to keep the operation or close some stores in Europe, including in the UK, France, and Italy, as part of a strategic review. The company's fourth-quarter sales missed estimates, further highlighting the need for a business overhaul.

images.alt_text: Gap Inc is weighing options including a potential sale for its China business, according to people with knowledge of the matter, as the US clothing retailer looks to revamp the operation in the world's second-largest economy.

site_title: US barbecue enthusiasm to lift earnings for beef giant Marfrig this year
summary: US barbecue enthusiasm is expected to boost beef giant Marfrig's earnings this year. As the US economy rebounds and government stimulus money increases spending on food, Marfrig's North America unit is set to benefit from a sweet spot in the commodity cycle. The company aims to vaccinate at least 70% of its 7,000 workers and expects margins in the US to be at least as high as in 2020, despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on operations. Marfrig reported record earnings in 2020 and is optimistic about the year ahead.

site_title: Temasek in US$500m partnership with global impact investor Leapfrog
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, has partnered with global impact investor LeapFrog Investments for a US$500 million strategic partnership. Temasek will take a minority stake in LeapFrog, providing growth capital to support the expansion of the LeapFrog team and investment capabilities across Asia and Africa. LeapFrog's investment process will remain managed by its team, with Temasek holding one non-executive seat on the management board. This partnership aims to anchor LeapFrog's future funds and support the group's growth in the impact investing space.

images.alt_text: Temasek announced on Tuesday that it has entered into a US$500 million strategic partnership with global impact investment group LeapFrog Investments.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, Singapore Airlines, Jardine Strategic, Jardine Matheson, FLCT
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include UOB launching staff promotions and lifting hiring freezes, Singapore Airlines potentially using the International Air Transport Association's Travel Pass software for travel without stay-home notices, and Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine Matheson Holdings reaching 52-week highs due to a significant discount in the offer price for Jardine Strategic.

site_title: UK consumer spending hit again as lockdown goes on: Barclaycard
summary: UK consumer spending fell 13.8% in February compared to the previous year, with essential items seeing a 5.3% increase and online grocery shopping surging. Non-essential spending plummeted 22.1%. Despite this, consumers' confidence in the economy rose to a 12-month high of 28%, with many planning to spend their savings on big holidays or treats. The Bank of England is monitoring household savings to gauge the economy's bounce-back strength.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 7.76 points or 0.48% to 1,619.57. The market saw 359.28 million lots traded worth RM225.86 million, with losers beating gainers 266 to 259.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens lower on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened 0.28% lower on Tuesday, despite a mixed close on Wall Street. The benchmark index fell 81.75 points to 28,661.50, while the broader Topix index gained 0.16% to 1,896.52. The move follows a global rally, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: US firms can help Asia-Pacific tackle challenges of Covid-19, geopolitics, debt: Heng
summary: US firms can contribute to Asia-Pacific's recovery from the challenges of Covid-19, US-China relations, and rising global debt. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat emphasized the need for cooperation on global issues like vaccination and economic recovery. He urged US corporations to champion globalization, invest in emerging opportunities, and engage in free trade agreements to boost confidence in the region's growth potential.

site_title: DBS joins JPMorgan, Barclays to endorse benefits of office work
summary: DBS Group Holdings CEO Piyush Gupta emphasized the importance of office work in building a company's identity, stating that employees need to work from the office to develop a firm's culture. This aligns with remarks from JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon and Barclays CEO Jes Staley, who also highlighted the benefits of in-office work. Despite allowing employees to work remotely up to 40% of the time, DBS found that over four-fifth of its staff could work seamlessly from home, but Gupta believes companies are stronger when staff are also office-based, citing the need for alignment of purpose and culture.

site_title: In inclusivity push, Unilever to exclude word 'normal' from beauty products
summary: Unilever, a leading beauty and personal care company, plans to remove the word "normal" from its products and advertising, replacing it with more inclusive terms such as "grey hair" or "moisture replenish". The move follows a global poll showing that using the word "normal" made people feel excluded, and comes after previous backlash over advertising campaigns. Unilever will also stop digitally altering models' body shapes and skin tones in its advertisements. The changes aim to promote a more inclusive definition of beauty.

site_title: Covid-19 economies to recover quicker than in previous crises: Bank of England
summary: The Bank of England's governor, Andrew Bailey, stated that the economic crisis caused by Covid-19 will leave fewer long-term scars than previous recessions. Despite Britain's worst recession among developed countries, the country expects to return to its pre-crisis level by mid-2022, six months earlier than forecast. A rapid vaccination campaign is seen as a key factor in this recovery. The BoE is considering adopting negative rates and tightening monetary policy to combat inflation, which has led to investors abandoning bonds and pushing up rates.

site_title: Australia business confidence at decade highs as activity rebounds
summary: Australia's business confidence surged to decade highs in February, reaching +16 points, its highest level since 2010, as sales, profits, and employment rebounded sharply. The National Australia Bank's index showed conditions rebounded 6 points to +15, almost entirely recouping a January pullback. The economy is expected to have recovered pre-virus GDP levels in Q1 2021, with capacity utilization and investment firmed above pre-virus and long-run averages.

site_title: Canada home prices are boiling over, but policymakers downplay need for action
summary: Canada's housing market has reached a boiling point, with prices rising and investors driving sales. Despite calls for cooling measures, policymakers are hesitant to intervene, fearing it may harm the country's fragile economic recovery from the pandemic. Desperate buyers are over-extending themselves, paying tens of thousands more than budgeted, as investors and flipping activity increase. Authorities seem unwilling to act, prioritizing economic stability over addressing the housing market's rapid growth.

site_title: New Zealand manufacturing sales rise in fourth quarter
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing sales volumes rose 0.5% in the fourth quarter, according to Statistics New Zealand. Dairy and meat product sales, the country's largest export earners, fell 0.1% after adjusting for price effects. The increase in overall sales volumes suggests a positive trend in the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Europe: Banks boost stocks as recovery hopes grow
summary: Europe's stock market rose 2.22% on Monday, its best one-day performance since early November, driven by gains in banks and automakers as investors hopeful for a solid economic rebound from the coronavirus downturn. The banking sector surged 3.73%, with shares of HSBC, Banco Santander, and ING Groep rising over 2%. The European Union and US agreed to suspend tariffs on aircraft subsidies, boosting shares of Rolls-Royce and other companies.

site_title: Brokers' take: FLCT could replace Jardine Strategic in STI, says CGS-CIMB
summary: CGS-CIMB predicts FRASERS Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) could replace Jardine Strategic Holdings in the FTSE Straits Times Index (STI) due to its market capitalization and exposure to the logistics warehouse sector. FLCT's free-float market capitalization was S$3.2 billion, with an estimated weight of 1.1% in the STI. The research team has an "add" call on FLCT, setting a target price of S$1.57.

site_title: Zoom founder Eric Yuan donates US$6b worth of shares
summary: Zoom founder Eric Yuan donated nearly 18 million shares worth around $6 billion, consistent with his estate planning practices. The donation, made through a Grantor Retained Annuity Trust (GRAT), is part of Yuan's $15.1 billion net worth, which has increased by $9.2 billion since last March. Yuan's share transfer follows other mega-rich individuals, such as Jeff Bezos, who have been donating shares to combat climate change. The donation does not affect Yuan's wealth, which remains one of the world's highest, at $15.1 billion.

site_title: From checks to child poverty, US economy awaits Biden stimulus
summary: US President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion stimulus package is set to be approved by Congress, injecting $1.2 trillion into the economy through direct payments, unemployment benefits, and COVID-19 vaccine funding. The package aims to cut child poverty in half, with tax credits for low-income families, and economists forecast a 7% expansion in GDP. Despite initial concerns, the bill has survived largely intact, with firms expecting the US economy to expand even faster this year.

site_title: UK finance firm Greensill collapses into insolvency
summary: UK finance firm Greensill has collapsed into administration after encountering serious financial difficulties, sparking fears over thousands of jobs worldwide. The company, which specializes in short-term supply chain financing, faces funding problems and mounting questions over opaque accounting methods. Administration caps a crisis-hit March for Greensill, which risks over 50,000 jobs globally, including 7,000 in Australia. US private equity firm Apollo is reportedly seeking to buy parts of the group, but a rescue deal is uncertain.

site_title: Conversation on hiring of women should not happen only in March
summary: Preet Grewal, head of inclusion and diversity at JAPAC at Twitter, emphasizes that conversations about hiring women in tech should not be limited to March. She believes that ensuring gender diversity is crucial for real gender equality and sets a foundation to address ingrained biases. Grewal stresses that it's not just leaders who need to drive change, but also the entire organization, and that constant attention to improving gender equality is necessary, not just during specific months.

site_title: Trump back in New York for first time since leaving office
summary: Former US President Donald Trump returned to New York for the first time since leaving office, arriving at his luxury residence atop Trump Tower in Manhattan. A small group of Trump supporters gathered outside, carrying signs and flags, and some even claimed they were challenging Trump to run for president in 2024. The Secret Service did not provide information on Trump's visit, amid ongoing investigations into possible bank fraud, tax evasion, and insurance fraud by the Manhattan district attorney and New York state attorney general.

site_title: Year on, WHO says Covid early alarm fell on some deaf ears
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is expressing frustration that some countries failed to act quickly enough in response to its early warnings about the COVID-19 pandemic. Despite declaring a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC) on January 30, 2020, it wasn't until March 11, 2020, that the term "pandemic" was used, prompting widespread action. The WHO attributes the delay to countries' assumption that the problem would pass them by, with some countries taking too long to react and ultimately facing devastating consequences.

site_title: Brazil judge clears ex-leader Lula to run again in 2022
summary: Brazil's Supreme Court judge cleared former president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva to run in the 2022 presidential election, overturning graft convictions stemming from a massive corruption scheme involving state oil company Petrobras. The decision, made by Justice Edson Fachin, sent the cases to a federal court in Brasilia, allowing Lula to regain his right to run unless the convictions are reinstated. Lula's lawyers hailed the decision as vindication of their arguments, while the prosecutor general's office said it would appeal.

site_title: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala partners Apple to produce dramas, comedies, docus
summary: Nobel Peace Prize winner Malala Yousafzai has partnered with Apple to produce dramas, comedies, documentaries, and children's series for Apple TV+. The partnership expands on their previous collaboration, which began in 2020. Malala aims to bring new voices to the platform and inspire young people, particularly girls, to watch and be engaged. This move marks Malala's first foray into scripted content production, joining a growing roster of content creators on Apple TV+. The partnership was announced on International Women's Day.

site_title: San Francisco home to Dropbox sold for US$1.08b
summary: A San Francisco building leased by Dropbox as its headquarters is being sold for $1.08 billion, a new high in the commercial real estate market. The 60,000 sqm office property was leased by Dropbox in 2017, but the company has shifted to remote work due to the pandemic. Mayor London Breed called the sale a sign of excitement for San Francisco's future. The sale price per sqm is also a record high, and Dropbox plans to sublease some office space while keeping some for team collaboration.

site_title: Covid-19 raises retirement uncertainty: poll
summary: A survey by Syfe found that 71% of Singaporeans are uncertain about retiring comfortably due to the financial impact of Covid-19, up from 69% in 2019. Despite saving more, most respondents across all income groups do not expect to maintain their current lifestyles in retirement. The survey also revealed that Singaporeans believe they need approximately $1.39 million to retire comfortably.

images.alt_text: In the wake of Covid-19, more Singaporeans are concerned that they will retire less comfortably, a survey by digital wealth manager Syfe has shown.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.8% to 3,097.01 on Tuesday, driven by gains from local banks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, which advanced 1.6%, 0.9%, and 0.9% respectively. Shen Yao fell 25% after a strong trading day, while Singapore Airlines gained 1.2% following its International Air Transport Association's Travel Pass software trials. The market's rally is seen as a sign of investors' optimism for a strong economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares opened higher on Tuesday as investors continue to place their bets on a strong economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Europe seeks semiconductor boost, first quantum computer
summary: The European Union aims to produce 20% of the world's cutting-edge semiconductors by 2030 and develop its first quantum computer by 2025, in an effort to reduce dependence on non-European technologies. The 2030 Digital Compass plan also targets 10,000 climate-neutral facilities, doubling unicorns, and expanding Gigabit networks by 2030. The plan, presented by European Commission Vice President Margrethe Vestager and EU industry chief Thierry Breton, must be approved by EU countries and the European Parliament before implementation.

site_title: Citi sees more civil trading floors amid bid to boost female participation
summary: Citi's Deirdre Dunn, global co-head of rates trading, notes a significant shift in Wall Street's trading culture, where aggressive behavior and yelling at computers are no longer common. This change is attributed to banks' efforts to boost female participation, with Citigroup aiming to increase the share of women in roles from assistant vice-president to managing director. The shift has led to increased flexibility and a more lenient approach to managing work, with executives embracing remote work arrangements to accommodate family responsibilities.

site_title: Home sales soar in Manhattan and the New York region
summary: The New York region's housing market is experiencing a surge in home sales, with Manhattan and suburbs seeing a second wave of activity after a surge last summer. Historically low mortgage rates, pandemic-fatigued city dwellers seeking more space, and remote work's impact on commuting patterns have fueled the frenzy. Bidding wars and all-cash deals are common, with brokers reporting long lines at open houses and multiple offers within days of listings going live. Manhattan's housing market has also picked up, with signed contracts jumping 73.1% from a year ago, while suburban areas like Westchester, New Jersey, and Long Island face cutthroat competition and rising prices due to low inventory and high demand.

site_title: Oil settles lower, shrugs off Saudi attack after climbing above US$70/barrel
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Monday after Saudi Arabian attacks on oil facilities lifted prices above US$70 a barrel for the first time since the Covid-19 pandemic. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude prices retreated from session highs of US$71.38 and US$67.98, respectively, settling at US$68.24 and US$65.05. The attacks, carried out by Yemen's Houthi forces, did not result in significant damage or casualties, and US officials expressed alarm at the "genuine security threats" to Saudi Arabia.

site_title: UOB lifts wage, hiring freeze; pay hike, promotion for selected staff
summary: UOB, Singapore's third-largest bank, is lifting a hiring freeze and offering pay increments to most of its 26,000-strong workforce, with 98% eligible for a review. High-performing employees can expect above-market-average salary increases of up to 15%, while about 5% will be promoted. The bank had previously put a freeze on promotions and wage increments in 2020 due to the pandemic. UOB's head of human resources, Dean Tong, said the bank is "beginning to see the signs of recovery" and is reinstating salary increases and promotions to support employees impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: US: Mixed day for stocks as investors flee tech shares
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed day on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1.0% to 31,802.44, while the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 2.4% to 12,609.16. Investors shifted from tech shares to economically sensitive cyclicals, driven by progress on President Biden's stimulus package and vaccine momentum. However, rising inflation and potential Federal Reserve policy shifts weighed on the market. Dow leaders included Disney, Goldman Sachs, and Home Depot, while GameStop surged 41.2% on e-commerce plans.

site_title: S$20 million arts top-up includes new grant for freelancers
summary: Singapore's government has allocated an additional S$20 million to support arts and culture organizations through the Arts and Culture Resilience Package (ACRP). The package includes new grants for freelancers, businesses, and collaborations, aiming to help the sector recover from the pandemic. The grants include the Business Transformation Fund, which will provide up to S$30,000 per project, and the Self-Employed Person Grant, which will award up to S$50,000 per project. The government also plans to extend existing support measures, including venue-hire subsidies and operating grants, until June.

site_title: Concrete policies critical to close gender gap in tech
summary: The tech industry continues to grapple with a significant gender imbalance, with women making up only 30% of info-communications jobs in Singapore, despite increased enrollment in computer science and IT-related courses. Industry players and observers stress the need for concrete policies to address the talent pipeline leak and promote diversity. Technology companies are taking steps to acknowledge the gap, with over 50 companies committing to support women in tech. Simple measures such as flexible work environments and biased language elimination in recruiting processes can help eliminate gender barriers, and creating diversity programs can retain female tech talent.

site_title: Istana to be restored, Malay Heritage Centre revamped
summary: Singapore's Istana and former Istana Kampong Glam are set to undergo restoration, with works beginning in 2023 and next year respectively. The Malay Heritage Centre will also be closed for redevelopment. The government aims to preserve national monuments, including the Singapore Philatelic Museum, Peranakan Museum, and Changi Chapel and Museum, with several exhibitions and events planned to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Preservation of Monuments Act and the 25th anniversary of the Museum Roundtable.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: OCBC appointed Andrew Khoo Cheng Hoe, 57, as a non-executive and independent director. Khoo is currently an adjunct professor at the National University of Singapore's business school.

site_title: Asian American lives matter too
summary: A wave of racially motivated attacks against Asian Americans, including physical violence and verbal harassment, has been on the rise in the US, with over 3,000 incidents reported since mid-March 2020. The attacks have disproportionately targeted Asian American elders, including an 84-year-old man who died after being shoved to the ground in San Francisco. The incidents have been fueled by anti-Chinese xenophobia, with former President Donald Trump blaming China for the COVID-19 pandemic. The Asian American community is speaking out against the attacks, with a younger generation demanding recognition of the issue and pushing for policy action from the Biden administration.

site_title: Movie theatres reopen in New York City
summary: New York City's movie theaters reopened for the first time in almost a year, allowing moviegoers to enjoy films on the big screen with limited capacity and social distancing measures. The reopening comes after Governor Andrew M Cuomo cleared the way for cinemas in the city to open with restrictions in place. Despite concerns about safety, many patrons reported feeling a sense of normalcy and joy, with some even comparing the experience to a "miniature milestone" in the city's recovery. The reopening marks a significant step forward for the movie industry, which has been severely impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: US wholesale inventories up
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1.3% in January, exceeding expectations, and stocks rebounded 1.2% as businesses replenished inventories after the pandemic. This increase suggests potential economic growth in the first quarter. Sales at wholesalers surged 4.9% in January, taking 1.24 months to clear shelves, down from 1.29 in December.

site_title: Thailand closer to vaccine passport ahead of wider reopening
summary: Thailand has moved closer to issuing vaccine passports, a key step towards reopening its borders to foreign tourists. The Health Ministry plans to issue documents to vaccinated residents, allowing them to travel abroad with a reduced mandatory quarantine period of seven days from 14 days. The proposal is expected to be approved by a national committee later this month, with a potential complete waiver from quarantine on arrival from October. This move could spur other tourism-reliant nations to follow suit, supporting Thailand's economy.

site_title: US dollar at 3½-month high on firmer US yields
summary: The US dollar reached a 3½-month high due to rising US Treasury yields, boosting its safe-haven appeal and strengthening by nearly 2.5% year to date. Investors expect the higher yields to weigh on stretched equity valuations and boost demand for the US currency. Recent economic data showed non-farm payrolls surged by 379,000 jobs and President Biden's $1.9 trillion recovery package was approved by the Senate. The US dollar index reached 92.30, its highest level since late November, while the euro fell to a near-four month low below US$1.19.

site_title: Women shouldn't have to behave like men to 'make it' at work
summary: A former consulting firm partner shares her experience of being promoted to one of the first female partners in her country despite facing cultural biases and stereotypes. She notes that organizations expect typical male behaviors from women, such as self-confidence and fluid networking, and that addressing this issue requires a conscious push to accept and support diverse leadership styles. The author argues that women don't have to behave like men to succeed, and that companies can create a more inclusive culture by fostering awareness and adapting to diverse leadership styles.

site_title: Frasers Property: S$1.28b rights issue to build resilience
summary: Frasers Property is raising up to S$1.28 billion through a S$1.18-per-share rights issue to boost business resilience, build financial agility, and strengthen its balance sheet. The equity fundraising aims to capitalize on growth opportunities in industrial, logistics, and business park assets, with S$700 million allocated for acquisitions and investments. The rights issue is renounceable, and existing shareholders have an "equal chance" to participate, with the issue price being 47.5% below the adjusted net asset value.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore stocks see a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned H2 revenue may be below target, while London's Heathrow eyes higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. MAS and PBOC announced deeper cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Jardine Matheson: From tea and opium to diversified conglomerate
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings, a Singapore-based conglomerate, has a nearly two-century history dating back to the 19th century tea and opium trade in China. Founded in 1832, the company has evolved into a diversified business with interests in hotels, automobiles, supermarkets, and more. Over the years, it has undergone significant restructurings, including the formation of holding companies and cross-shareholdings to deter hostile takeovers. Today, Jardine Matheson continues to expand its portfolio through strategic investments and acquisitions, solidifying its position as one of the largest conglomerates in the region.

site_title: Avimac, Asia Enterprises, Phoon Huat score digitalisation success
summary: The Singapore Business Federation's eight-week IHCI Enabler Programme has helped 47 companies, including precision engineering company Avimac, steel distributor Asia Enterprises, and baking supply company Phoon Huat, to transition into Industry 4.0. The programme, developed and funded by Workforce Singapore, provides masterclasses, a shop-floor pilot programme, and professional assessments to identify areas for digitalisation and improve business performance. Participating companies have seen improvements in productivity, with Avimac experiencing a 9-12% increase in productivity and Phoon Huat seeing a 12% increase in overall production. The programme aims to reach 300 companies by 2022.

site_title: How SMEs can own their digitalisation journeys
summary: The Singapore Budget 2021 allocates S$1 billion to support mature enterprises' adoption of digital solutions, prioritizing the digital transformation of local SMEs. A survey found that 84% of business respondents accelerated digital transformation efforts during the pandemic, with an average delay of two years. This support aims to improve productivity, create new opportunities, and drive growth for SMEs.

site_title: Key entities in the Jardine empire
summary: The Jardine Matheson conglomerate has evolved from its origins in tea and opium trading to become a diversified business, with interests spanning various sectors. The company is now 30% off its net asset value, which could impact the Singapore Stock Exchange Index. Jardine Matheson has undergone significant transformations, expanding its portfolio to include industries such as real estate, finance, and technology. The company's history and current market implications are highlighted, showcasing its growth and diversification over the years.

site_title: Jardine Strategic offer is 30% off net asset value; deal could affect ST Index
summary: Jardine Matheson's US$5.5 billion offer to buy out the remaining stake in Jardine Strategic Holdings is set to be completed by the end of April. The offer price of US$33 is a 30% discount to Jardine Strategic's estimated net asset value of US$46.67 per share. Analysts predict the deal will simplify Jardine Matheson's structure and allow it to capture value from minority shareholders. Jardine Matheson's controlling stake in Jardine Strategic will increase to 43%, while the trust's listing on the Straits Times Index (STI) is likely to be replaced by Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust.

site_title: Supply chain financing: The good, the bad and the ugly
summary: A global supply chain financing crisis has been sparked by the potential insolvency of London-based fintech company Greensill, which froze $10 billion worth of investment funds for its supply chain business. Supply chain financing, or SCF, allows suppliers to receive immediate payment from buyers, but the benefits are often skewed towards large corporate buyers. The lack of transparency in financial accounting and inadequate regulation can lead to a "financial tsunami" for corporate buyers, while SCF programmes are increasingly being packaged as investments, similar to mortgage products that triggered the 2008 financial crisis.

site_title: GE nears deal to create behemoth aircraft lessor with AerCap
summary: General Electric Co is nearing a deal to combine its jet-leasing business, GE Capital Aviation Services, with Ireland's AerCap Holdings NV, creating a behemoth aircraft lessor. The potential deal, valued over $30 billion, would join the world's two biggest aircraft financiers and speed GE's push to streamline the US industrial icon. The combination could be announced as soon as Monday and would be a "win-win situation" for both companies and the airline industry, as they rebuild after the pandemic.

site_title: How it all went south for Hin Leong
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singaporean oil trader, collapsed due to a liquidity crunch in March 2020 following the historic oil crash and price war. Founder OK Lim hid $800m in futures losses and filed for a six-month debt moratorium, which was rejected by creditors. The company was placed under judicial management, and its assets were seized. OK Lim and his family faced multiple charges, including abetment of forgery, and a $3.5 billion lawsuit from judicial managers. The court eventually granted an order to wind up the company in March 2021, bringing an end to the firm.

site_title: Businesses should consider social factors
summary: In a post-pandemic Singapore, businesses must prioritize crisis planning and stakeholder management to thrive. A recent study by the Centre for Governance and Sustainability found that current ESG frameworks have limitations in addressing social risks, particularly in remote working and crisis management. The study proposed 15 enhanced standards across four areas: remote working, crisis management, stakeholder management, and employee management. The study also found that companies in the real estate, communication services, and consumer staples sectors demonstrated robust social sustainability practices. To address the pandemic's social impacts, regulators and businesses must reconsider the social elements of ESG sustainability frameworks.

site_title: Can the 3 big listed property groups overturn their underperformance?
summary: Singapore's three largest listed property groups, CapitaLand, City Developments, and UOL Group, have underperformed compared to the country's three largest listed banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, over the past five years. The banks have seen their share prices roughly double, while the property groups have gained just 8%. The banks' superior return on equity (ROE) of 11.1% compared to the property groups' 6.7% may explain the differing performances. However, the property groups may benefit from the growth of new economy asset classes and the potential for real estate investment trusts (Reits). Despite the challenges posed by digitalization and the ongoing pandemic, the property groups may still outperform the banks, especially if they adopt more aggressive strategies and business models.

site_title: Educate, mentor and make women role models in tech sector
summary: Patricia Liu, chief of staff at gaming firm Razer, shares her 25-year journey in the tech sector, overcoming initial doubts and challenges to become a board member. She emphasizes the importance of addressing gender gaps in tech, citing Razer's goal of tapping into the fullest talents of its workforce. The company is launching initiatives to boost female representation, including school outreach programs and anti-bias training. Liu hopes to see a shift towards equal gender representation in tech through combined efforts from companies, public policy, and female leaders.

site_title: What are the new inflation hawks thinking?
summary: Inflation hawks, including Lawrence Summers, warned in 1992 that lowering the US Federal Reserve's inflation target from 4% to 2% could cause problems, as it increased the risk of interest-rate policy hitting the zero lower bound. The Fed's decision to lower the target was made despite Summers' objections. Summers suggests that if the Fed could adjust asset markets to make a 5% federal funds rate consistent with full employment, many economic problems could be alleviated.

site_title: Investing in recycling and circular economy to fight climate change
summary: Investors are shifting focus to the waste management and recycling sector as a climate-resilient opportunity. The sector has been hindered by the COVID-19 pandemic and the surge in single-use and virgin plastics in South and South-east Asia. As the world moves towards mass vaccination, these crises present opportunities for economic recovery and growth. Companies are exploring ways to invest in recycling and circular economy, with Temasek's SIA burden and the MAS evolving climate investing approach being highlighted. This trend is expected to have a significant impact on the global economy and environmental sustainability.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Hin Leong Trading, a Singaporean oil trading firm, faces an end-of-road as a court grants a winding-up order. Joint liquidators PricewaterhouseCoopers' Goh Thien Phong and Chan Kheng Tek are appointed. Additionally, Jardine Strategic's offer price is announced at a 30% discount to its estimated net asset value, while DBS chief Piyush Gupta's 2020 pay drops 24% due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Singaporean stocks close the week in the black, with the STI gaining 1.9%.

site_title: Saudis raise oil prices to Asia as Opec+ extends output cuts
summary: Saudi Arabia raised oil prices for Asia and the US by 40 cents a barrel to a record high, indicating demand growth continues despite the Opec+ decision to keep oil supply largely unchanged. The price increase suggests Saudi Arabia sees continued demand in the physical market, particularly in China. The move also suggests Saudi Arabia is cautious about increasing production, following the recent attack on its Ras Tanura crude export terminal by Iran-backed Houthi rebels.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 vaccination drive brought forward for seniors, extended to teachers, postmen, migrant workers
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 vaccination drive has been accelerated for seniors and extended to high-risk groups and essential workers, including teachers, postmen, and migrant workers. The Health Ministry announced that more than 596,000 vaccine doses have been administered, with over 379,000 individuals receiving at least one dose. Vaccination will be made available to educators, staff working in pre-schools, and those in the food delivery industry, as well as migrant workers living in dormitories. The program aims to protect vulnerable populations and prevent transmission of the virus.

site_title: McAfee to sell enterprise business for US$4b
summary: McAfee Corp plans to sell its enterprise business to a consortium led by Symphony Technology Group for US$4 billion in cash, subject to regulatory approvals. The deal is expected to close by the end of 2021. McAfee's enterprise business generated US$1.3 billion in net revenue in 2020. The sale comes after the company strengthened its retail cybersecurity software business through price increases and retention efforts.

site_title: Myanmar junta leader says Australian adviser's detention revealed financial secrets
summary: Myanmar junta leader Min Aung Hlaing stated that the detention of Australian financial adviser Sean Turnell revealed secret financial information, according to state-run MRTV television. Turnell was detained five days after the coup that led to the arrest of Aung San Suu Kyi. The junta leader also announced that five media companies in Myanmar, known for covering protests against the military coup, have had their licenses revoked. Australia has called for Turnell's release, and the situation highlights the junta's efforts to suppress dissent and opposition.

site_title: SIA trials app for Covid-19 test booking and check-in
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is launching a trial app that allows passengers to view Covid-19 test results and check-in at Changi Airport. Developed by IATA, the app integrates testing with boarding credentials, potentially paving the way for travel without stay-home notices and quarantine. The trial, starting March 15-28, will involve 7 Singapore clinics and may be rolled out globally if successful. Passengers will have control over their data, and a physical health certificate will still be required due to regulatory requirements.

site_title: Nordea says it's not axing polluters from ESG investment banking
summary: Nordea Bank has stated it does not plan to exclude polluters from its sustainable finance services. Head of sustainable finance advisory Jacob Michaelsen said setting strict definitions for ESG investment banking is "basically infeasible" due to the new area's complexity. This decision contradicts efforts to hold polluters accountable for their environmental and social impact.

images.alt_text: At Nordea, the transaction volume in sustainability-linked loans increased more than threefold to 21.6 billion euros last year.

site_title: Lacklustre debut for Disney's Raya and the Last Dragon
summary: Disney's Raya and the Last Dragon opened to lower-than-expected box office sales of $8.6 million in North America, failing to draw audiences back to theaters. The film, featuring Kelly Marie Tran and Awkwafina, was also launched on Disney+ for an extra $30, with an estimated $26.2 million internationally, mainly in China. This follows Disney CEO Bob Chapek's statement that theaters need to adapt to movies being released in different ways due to customer preferences.

site_title: Judicial management for Hiap Seng and unit extended
summary: The High Court has extended the judicial management period for Hiap Seng Engineering and its subsidiary until September 14. Both companies' applications to extend the order were granted. The subsidiary had entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement last October for 300 million Thai baht. The extension allows the companies more time to restructure and dispose of assets.

site_title: Swiss voters back Indonesia free trade deal
summary: Switzerland's voters have narrowly approved a free trade deal with Indonesia, opening a vast market for Swiss businesses. The agreement was made despite controversy over the importation of Indonesian palm oil, a key concern for Swiss voters. The outcome of the public vote will likely have significant implications for Switzerland's economy.

site_title: Progress is when women in tech are no longer a minority
summary: Singaporean tech industry expert Wynthia Goh emphasizes the need for progress in increasing women's representation in tech. At 23, she became a team leader of all-male engineers, breaking barriers in the male-dominated industry. Today, she advocates for organizational policies to prevent underutilization of human potential due to lack of diversity. Goh aims to change the norm by promoting female leaders in tech, believing they can thrive alongside men in the industry. With initiatives like her podcast series, she encourages women to consider tech careers and combat the misconception that tech is only for men.

site_title: Singapore startup Stamped to be acquired for up to US$110m by Canada-listed WeCommerce
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce marketing platform Stamped is being acquired by Canada-listed WeCommerce Holdings for up to US$110 million. The acquisition includes US$75 million in cash and 496,697 Class A common shares. Stamped had US$11 million in annualised recurring subscription revenue as of December 2020, with an estimated growth rate of over 100% compared to 2019. The deal is expected to accelerate growth, with WeCommerce's management team bringing over a decade of experience in developing similar businesses. The acquisition is subject to a minimum revenue target of US$10 million in 2021.

site_title: PayPal to acquire Curv to further its push into cryptocurrencies
summary: PayPal is acquiring cryptocurrency firm Curv to bolster its talent pool for handling digital currencies. The acquisition, expected to be completed by mid-year, aims to further PayPal's push into cryptocurrencies. Curv, with about 40 employees, will join PayPal's blockchain, crypto, and digital currencies team, led by Jose Fernandez da Ponte. The deal is part of PayPal's effort to invest in talent and technology to achieve its vision for a more inclusive financial system.

site_title: Yellen says stimulus unlikely to cause inflation problem
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has dismissed concerns that the $1.9 trillion pandemic-relief package will cause inflation problems, stating she doesn't think it will happen. Yellen, a former Federal Reserve head, reiterated that policy makers can address any challenge with price gains, if needed. The package aims to return the US to "full employment" next year, with payrolls still down by over 9 million due to Covid-19. Once passed, the agenda will focus on addressing underlying economic problems contributing to inequality. Yellen expects the relief plan to provide hundreds of millions of Americans with the help they need.

site_title: Online funerals, Zen apps keep Japan's Buddhist temples afloat
summary: Buddhist temples in Japan are adapting to the pandemic by offering online funerals, Zen meditation apps, and matchmaking services. The temples, which number around 77,000, are trying to survive amidst the pandemic. These innovative efforts aim to maintain the temples' relevance and continue to serve their communities.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund PIF to support corporate credit growth, S&P says
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) plans to inject at least $40 billion annually in the local economy until 2025, aiming to increase its assets to 4 trillion riyals ($1.4 trillion) by 2025. This move is expected to support credit growth among companies in the kingdom, according to S&P Global Ratings. As part of economic reforms to transform the oil-dependent economy, PIF's investments will help diversify the economy and reduce reliance on oil. The fund's efforts aim to promote sustainable growth and development in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly higher on progress of stimulus package
summary: US stocks rose early Monday, driven by optimism over a massive fiscal package, despite concerns about inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6% to 31,699.33, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.2% to 3,850.57. The package, which includes $1,400 stimulus checks, has raised hopes for a strong economic recovery but also sparked inflation concerns. US President Joe Biden applauded the Senate's passage of the $1.9 trillion spending package, which is now in the House of Representatives.

site_title: Parliament must choose between what is popular and what is right as spending needs grow
summary: Singapore's Parliament approved the government's S$107 billion spending plans for the financial year, following nine days of debate on key issues like sustainability, industry transformation, and job security. Leader of the House Indranee Rajah warned that Singapore may face difficult choices ahead as spending needs grow despite a tight fiscal situation. The decision comes as global economic concerns, including US tariffs and China's slowing GDP growth, put pressure on policymakers worldwide.

site_title: America is Back! - but not if nation remains weak and divided
summary: US President Joe Biden has declared "America is Back!" after reversing former President Donald Trump's isolationist policies, including withdrawing from the Paris Climate Accord and revoking the Iran nuclear deal. Biden has signaled a return to multilateralism, seeking to salvage international agreements and working with allies to address common challenges. However, the new administration faces challenges, including opposition from Republicans and some Democrats, and must address domestic issues such as the COVID-19 pandemic and economic recovery before pursuing an ambitious foreign policy agenda.

site_title: Deliveroo cuts annual loss before London float
summary: Deliveroo reported an underlying loss of £223.7 million in 2020, down from £317 million the previous year, as demand surged during the pandemic. The company's total transaction value increased 64% to £4.1 billion. Deliveroo confirmed plans for a London stock market listing, targeting institutional investors, with a planned listing in April. The IPO will also include a community offer for UK-based consumers with a Deliveroo account. The company has expanded across Europe, Asia, Australia, and the Middle East since its 2013 London launch.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets up at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on Monday, driven by soaring oil prices and concerns over inflation. The FTSE 100 index climbed 0.6%, rebounding from losses on Friday, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. The European Central Bank's upcoming meeting is expected to focus on price pressures amid recovering economies.

site_title: Panasonic to buy US software firm Blue Yonder for US$6.5b
summary: Panasonic is set to acquire US software firm Blue Yonder for $6.45 billion, its largest acquisition since 2011. The Japanese electronics firm initially purchased a 20% stake in 2020 and is now acquiring the remaining shares from shareholders including Blackstone Group. The deal aims to expand Panasonic's hardware that combines software, sensors, and devices to improve operational efficiencies. The acquisition is part of Panasonic's strategy to integrate technology and improve its offerings.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down for third straight session
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei index closed down for a third consecutive session, losing 0.42% to 28,743.25. The decline followed early gains after US job data showed a better-than-expected increase in February. Interest rate fears in the US weighed on the market, with tech and gaming giants among the losers. Tokyo Electron fell 1.13% and Sony dropped 1.73%.

site_title: No more extension of premium-deferment scheme, but insurance industry will still help
summary: The Deferred Premium Payment (DPP) scheme for insurance policyholders in Singapore, which allowed for up to six months of premium deferment, will close on March 31 as previously announced. Despite the deadline, life insurers will continue to provide company-specific assistance to policyholders. The scheme was launched in April 2020 to support policyholders affected by the pandemic.

site_title: Thailand backs vaccine passport ahead of wider reopening
summary: Thailand moves closer to fully reopening its borders to foreign visitors, with a panel of officials backing the proposal for a vaccine passport that would allow vaccinated residents to travel abroad and vaccinated foreign visitors to reduce their mandatory quarantine period from 14 to 7 days. The Health Ministry plans to issue documents to residents who have completed their Covid-19 vaccinations, with the goal of reviving the tourism industry, which accounted for about a fifth of Thailand's pre-pandemic GDP. A successful reopening could spur other tourism-reliant nations to follow suit.

site_title: Syria president and first lady test positive for Covid
summary: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his wife Asma have tested positive for Covid-19 after experiencing mild symptoms. They will quarantine for up to three weeks. The couple's positive test results come as Syria starts vaccinating frontline health workers, with the World Health Organisation aiming to provide jabs to at least 3% of the population by the end of the year. This is the latest development in a country ravaged by a 10-year conflict that has killed over 387,000 people and severely impacted its healthcare sector.

site_title: Myanmar protesters begin national strike, vow to defeat army
summary: Myanmar protesters began a nationwide strike, marching in cities like Yangon and Mandalay, to pressure the military to relinquish power after the February 1 coup. The strike, backed by 18 labour organizations, aims to restore democracy, following the military's failure to recognize Aung San Suu Kyi's party's election win. At least 64 deaths have been reported since the coup, with protesters calling for a civil disobedience movement to achieve their goal. The international community continues to pressure the military, with the UN envoy urging action to halt the violent crackdown.

site_title: Deals of the week: Stamped to be acquired; SiCepat goes the extra mile
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several South-east Asian tech deals made headlines last week. Stamped, a Singapore-based e-commerce marketing platform, was acquired by WeCommerce Holdings for up to $110 million. SiCepat, a last-mile delivery specialist, raised $170 million in its largest Series B round, valuing the business at $744 million. Insurtech startup Symbo raised $9.4 million and acquired health platform Vivant. Agrifoodtech startup Nutrition Technologies received $5 million and opened an insect protein factory, while supply chain solutions startup Advotics secured $2.75 million. These deals highlight the region's growing tech funding and innovation landscape.

site_title: Withers appoints Joel Shen as partner for tech practice
summary: Withers has appointed Joel Shen as a partner for its tech practice in Singapore, focusing on fintech and venture capital in South-east Asia. Shen specializes in advising the technology sector in the region and will help the firm tap into the growth of the venture capital and technology space. The region's venture capital market has grown exponentially, with US$13 billion invested in 2020, and Shen is expected to contribute to this regional growth story.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares closed 1.92% down on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index ending at 28,540.83. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dropped 2.3% and the Shenzhen Composite Index plummeted 3.2%. Traders are concerned about inflation and interest rate hikes due to the expected economic recovery from the pandemic.

site_title: OCBC appoints Andrew Khoo as non-executive, independent director
summary: OCBC appointed 57-year-old Andrew Khoo Cheng Hoe as a non-executive and independent director, effective last July and set to end in June this year. Before joining the bank, Khoo was an adjunct professor at the National University of Singapore and a deputy managing director at the Monetary Authority of Singapore. His appointment aims to refresh the board's competency and skills. As a director at the National Environment Agency and Stroke Support Station Limited, Khoo also holds 7,167 shares in OCBC, contributing to a 1.13% increase in the bank's stock price.

site_title: Deliveroo kicks off London IPO, bolstering busy UK market
summary: Deliveroo, a food-delivery company backed by Amazon, has kicked off an initial public offering in London, aiming to raise billions of pounds and potentially surpass the UK market's best-ever first quarter. The startup, valued at over $7 billion, will list with a dual-class share structure, allowing CEO Will Shu to maintain control. This move is seen as a trend among UK-based tech startups, following THG's successful use of dual-class shares in its recent IPO. The offering could add billions to the UK IPO market's total this year, potentially setting a record.

site_title: Singapore stocks end Monday in the black, STI up 1.9%
summary: Singapore stocks closed Monday with a 1.9% gain, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,071.16 points. Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine Matheson Holdings were top performers, with gains of 19.49% and 15.48%, respectively. Analysts noted the offer price for JSH is a significant discount to its net asset value. On the other hand, Mapletree Industrial Trust, Keppel DC Reit, and Ascendas Reit were among the worst performers, with declines of 2.29%, 2.25%, and 2.05%, respectively.

site_title: Investment firm for ultra-rich opens office in Hong Kong
summary: Cambridge Associates, a Boston-based investment firm serving ultra-rich clients, is opening a Hong Kong office to expand its focus on Asia amid a surge in wealth in the region. The company, which already has offices in Singapore and Beijing, has hired Edwina Ho as senior director of business development for Asia and relocated Mary Pang, head of global private client practice, to Singapore. This move aims to capitalize on the growing wealth in Asia and diversify the firm's client base.

site_title: Online funerals, Zen apps keep Japan's Buddhist temples afloat
summary: Buddhist temples in Japan are adapting to the COVID-19 pandemic by innovating online services, such as meditation apps and virtual memorial services, to stay afloat. With a shrinking population and declining interest in religion among the young, temples are exploring new ways to generate income, including match-making services and environmental investing. Despite a 51% drop in temple income since 2015, some temples are finding success with online operations, such as Ryosokuin's meditation app and Tsukiji Hongwanji's online memorial services, which have helped them stay financially viable.

site_title: Lockdown shopping surge in US and Europe causes Asia-Pacific shipping container shortage
summary: A surge in lockdown shopping in the US and Europe has led to a shortage of shipping containers in the Asia-Pacific region, according to a report by IHS Markit. The demand for consumer goods has increased significantly, driven by stay-at-home imports, resulting in a 16.9% year-over-year growth in US imports from Asia. The industry's pricing power has also increased, with freight rates expected to rise by 40-50% this year due to equipment shortages and tight supply. However, the report suggests that the supply chain bottlenecks are likely to be temporary and resolve themselves in the second half of the year.

site_title: Offer price for Jardine Strategic at significant discount to NAV
summary: Analysts note that Jardine Strategic Holdings' offer price of US$33 for a done deal is a 30% discount to its estimated net asset value of US$46.67 per share. This deal will untangle the cross-holding between Jardine Matheson Holdings and Jardine Strategic, with the latter buying out the remaining stake. The offer price is a 20.2% premium to the close of US$27.45 last Friday, despite Jardine Strategic trading near its lower end of the range over the last six years.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 11.69 points to 1,611.81 on Monday, driven by higher volume of 9.803 billion lots worth RM 6.279 billion. Losers narrowly outnumbered gainers 647 to 621.

site_title: LTA awards S$356m contract for Cross Island Line tunnel works
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$356m contract to Taisei Corporation of Japan and the Singapore branch of China State Construction Engineering Corporation for the construction of a 3.2-kilometre tunnel for the Cross Island Line MRT. This project will use a large-diameter tunnel boring machine, marking the first time for this technology in Singapore. The tunnel will be built between Aviation Park station and Loyang station, with operations slated for 2030.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on firm commodity prices, passage of US stimulus plan
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 6,739.60, driven by gains in resource stocks due to firm commodity prices. The US Senate passed a $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief plan, boosting risk appetite globally. China's iron ore imports rose 2.8% in the first two months of 2021, supporting prices and shares of major miners. BHP Group and Rio Tinto rose 2.4% and 3% respectively, while gold miners also rallied.

site_title: World's most gender-diverse corporation says secret to success is childcare
summary: DNB ASA, Norway's largest bank, has been named the world's most gender-diverse corporation by the Equileap Gender Equality Global Report & Ranking of 2021. CEO Kjerstin Braathen attributes the bank's success to providing adequate paid parental leave, allowing women to balance careers and family. The goal is to have 40% of top management positions held by women, with Braathen stating that quotas are a useful tool but should be phased out. Meanwhile, Norway's Prime Minister Erna Solberg highlights the country's struggle to achieve parity between men and women, with real gender equality not yet achieved despite equal access to education.

site_title: Thai prosecutor indicts 18 over anti-government protests
summary: A Thai prosecutor has indicted 18 activists for their roles in anti-government protests last year, charging them with sedition and breaching a ban on public assembly. The youth-led movement sought to reform the powerful Thai monarchy, breaking a longstanding taboo under the country's lese majeste law. Three prominent leaders face trial for sedition and lese majeste, while the remaining 15 protesters also face trial for sedition. The indictment is seen as a challenge to the royal palace and military-dominated establishment, with the protesters demanding reform of the monarchy and the resignation of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha.

site_title: Australia to spend US$920m to expand wage subsidy scheme for apprentices
summary: Australia will spend US$920 million to expand its wage subsidy scheme for apprentices, with the government paying half the wages of apprentices up to US$7,000 each quarter for 12 months. The expanded scheme will cover 70,000 new apprentices and run until September 2022. The move aims to support businesses and apprentices as the economy weans off the US$70-billion JobKeeper scheme, which is set to end in March. The expansion is part of a plan to provide targeted stimulus and boost skills for apprentices.

images.alt_text: Australia will spend US$920 million to expand its wage subsidy scheme for apprentices, Prime Minister Scott Morrison will say on Tuesday, the first step in a plan to wean the economy off a wider wage subsidy scheme.

site_title: New Zealand to buy enough Pfizer Covid-19 vaccines for entire population
summary: New Zealand has signed an agreement to purchase 8.5 million Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine doses, enough to vaccinate over 4 million people, bringing its total order to 10 million doses. The government aims to fully vaccinate its population by the end of the year, with the vaccine being 95% effective against symptomatic infection. This decision follows the country's successful containment of the pandemic, with just over 2,000 confirmed cases and 26 deaths.

site_title: Indonesia's SiCepat valued at US$744 million after latest Series B round
summary: Indonesian logistics startup SiCepat has raised US$170 million in its largest Series B round, valuing the company at approximately US$744 million. The funding round was backed by prominent investors, including Temasek's Pavilion Capital and MDI Ventures. SiCepat provides last-mile delivery services for social commerce merchants in Indonesia and plans to further invest in its logistics services and infrastructure to strengthen its presence in the market. The company is already profitable and has fulfilled over 1.4 million packages per day in 2020.

images.alt_text: SiCepat provides last-mile deliveries for social commerce merchants in Indonesia.

site_title: Porsche lifts stake in electric supercar maker linked to Bugatti
summary: Porsche AG has agreed to invest 70 million euros in Rimac Automobili, a Croatian electric supercar maker, to raise its stake to 24% from 15%. This move could pave the way for parent Volkswagen AG to sell its ultra-luxury Bugatti brand to Rimac. Porsche sees Rimac as a strategic partner for its electrification drive, while Rimac aims to maintain its independence to develop and supply high-tech parts for electric vehicles. The investment will help Rimac expand its engineering operations and supplies to automakers worldwide.

site_title: China to crack down harder on fake African swine fever vaccines: ministry
summary: China's Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs has announced tougher measures to crack down on the production and sale of counterfeit African swine fever vaccines, which are believed to have caused a new, chronic form of the disease. The move comes as China's hog herd continues to recover from a devastating outbreak, with a resurgence of the disease over the winter slowing progress. The ministry urges strengthened identification and testing, and reports any suspicious samples to provincial veterinary authorities.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end 1% lower on rising bond yields
summary: South Korean stocks ended 1% lower on Monday due to rising bond yields, following a 0.97% rise in early trade. The US Senate passed a $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief plan, boosting bond yields and driving stocks down. Global economic data also showed the US economy created more jobs than expected in February. The Kospi closed at 2,996.11 points.

site_title: Two protesters killed in Myanmar, shops and factories closed
summary: Two protesters were killed in Myanmar's main city Yangon on Monday, with witnesses claiming police fired stun grenades and tear gas before gunfire from nearby buildings injured three others. Shops, factories, and banks were closed as part of the uprising against the country's military rulers. The killings bring the total number of deaths to over 50 since the February 1 coup, according to the United Nations. Protesters, including women, have been using traditional women's sarongs as flags to mark International Women's Day and denounce the junta, while unions have called for a nationwide strike to reverse the coup and restore the elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: The 'ugliest' Rolls-Royce in history may be worth a second look
summary: The Rolls-Royce Camargue, often considered the "ugliest" Rolls-Royce, is gaining value due to its rarity and increasing demand. Despite its unconventional design, the Camargue presents a unique opportunity to own a rare Rolls-Royce at a lower price point, with daily driving condition models available for around $30,000. Its production run of 531 units, including a limited number of convertibles, has contributed to its increasing value, with prices reaching $64,350 in 2020 and $85,800 in 2022. The car's unique features, such as dual-zone air conditioning and a slanted grille, make it a sought-after collector's item.

site_title: Toyota VC invests in AI startups, firms that refine everyday processes
summary: Toyota's Silicon Valley-based venture capital fund, Toyota AI Ventures, has invested in 36 startups, including Nauto, Drishti, and Joby Aviation, to refine everyday processes with AI. The fund aims to maximize efficiencies by sharing lessons learned across factories worldwide. With $200 million under management, the fund seeks to bring AI to the factory floor, improving supply-chain management and robotics. This investment is part of Toyota's strategy to gain an edge in AI, particularly in self-driving cars.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lam says China's planned electoral changes could prompt vote delay
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam said China's planned electoral changes could delay a vote for the city's legislature, citing a need for an election for the electoral committee, currently scheduled for December. The changes, approved by China's National People's Congress, reduce democratic representation and vet candidates for "patriotism." Lam is uncertain on the timing of the vote, initially scheduled for September 2021, and may not be able to adhere to the original date. The changes are seen as a blow to the pro-democracy opposition, which had slim hopes of winning a majority in the city's mini-parliament.

site_title: 13 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 13 new Covid-19 cases, all of which were imported, bringing the total to 60,046. The new cases were from countries including India, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Myanmar. No new community cases or cases in worker's dormitories were reported, with the number of unlinked cases in the community increasing to three. Six cases were discharged, leaving 21 patients in hospital, including one in critical condition. Globally, the virus has infected over 115.6 million people and over 2.6 million have died.

site_title: Two adjoining GCBs on Ewart Park and Holland Rd for sale at S$35m and S$31m respectively
summary: Two adjoining Good Class Bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore have been put up for sale with prices of S$35 million and S$31 million, respectively. The properties, located on Ewart Park and Holland Road, feature a double-storey bungalow with four en-suite bedrooms and a swimming pool. The sale is an opportunity for multi-generational families to acquire adjoining GCBs, which are rare due to limited supply, with only 2,500 available in 39 gazetted areas. The sale will close on April 14 via an expression of interest exercise.

site_title: Japan Covid-19 inoculations off to snail pace start due to vaccine, syringe shortages
summary: Japan's COVID-19 inoculation campaign is off to a slow start due to vaccine and syringe shortages. As of March 8, just under 46,500 doses had been administered to frontline medical workers, with the current rate indicating it would take 126 years to vaccinate the entire population of 126 million. The country's requirement for clinical trials with Japanese patients has slowed down the approval process, with only the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine currently approved. Supplies are expected to increase in the coming months, but the government faces a challenge in vaccinating its elderly population of 36 million with limited supplies of specialty syringes.

site_title: Kai Fook Mansion in Tiong Bahru launched for collective sale at S$123m
summary: Kai Fook Mansion, a 9,999-year leasehold site in Singapore, is up for collective sale via public tender with an asking price of S$123 million. The site can be developed into a six-storey building with 41 residential apartments and 12,500 sq ft of commercial space. Located near Tiong Bahru MRT station and Tiong Bahru Plaza mall, the site is zoned for residential with commercial use at the first storey. The sale closes on May 19, with experts noting the site offers an excellent redevelopment opportunity for developers.

site_title: DBS chief Piyush Gupta's 2020 pay falls 24% as Covid-19 bites
summary: DBS Group's CEO Piyush Gupta's 2020 pay dropped 24% to S$9.18 million due to the Covid-19 pandemic affecting bank earnings. His compensation in 2019 was S$12.13 million, a difference of about S$2.94 million. The drop was attributed to a difficult operating environment, general cutbacks, and a 26% reduction in profits. Gupta's 11th year with the bank was marked by a quadrupling of provisions due to asset quality risks arising from the pandemic.

site_title: Investment firm for ultra-rich opens office in Hong Kong
summary: Wealth management firm Cambridge Associates is opening a Hong Kong office, expanding its focus on Asia amid a surge in wealth in the region. The Boston-based company, serving clients such as endowments, family offices, and pension funds, already has offices in Singapore and Beijing. With over $38 billion under management, Cambridge Associates aims to provide strong investment performance and excellent service to clients across the region, capitalizing on the region's rapid wealth growth. The move follows similar expansions by other financial firms in the region.

site_title: Marks & Spencer to expand online reach in latest overseas foray
summary: Marks & Spencer plans to launch websites in 46 new overseas markets, extending its online reach to over 100 countries. The move aims to revive its international business, which has struggled in recent years despite turnaround efforts. Online sales abroad have soared 75% since the pandemic, driven by a preference for home shopping. The new websites will offer clothing and home products, with orders fulfilled through M&S' existing distribution network, allowing for a cost-effective expansion without significant upfront investment.

site_title: How Cambodia is rebuilding its economy for the post-pandemic future
summary: Cambodia is rebuilding its economy after the COVID-19 pandemic, with a projected 2% contraction in 2020. The country's key sectors, such as tourism, manufacturing, and construction, were heavily affected. However, the government's fiscal support measures, new trade agreements, and growing foreign direct investment (FDI) are expected to boost the economy in 2021. The World Bank predicts a slow tourism recovery, but stronger growth in the second half of the year as vaccines become more widely available. Cambodia's openness to trade and FTA agreements with China and South Korea are also expected to spur recovery.

site_title: China should speed nuclear development to meet carbon goals: industry legislators
summary: China should accelerate nuclear power development to meet its carbon goals, with a target of 180 gigawatts by 2035. The country's current capacity of 51 GW falls short of its 58 GW target. Industry delegates and experts propose stepped-up construction of the Hualong One reactor design, with at least six new units commissioned annually to benefit from economies of scale. However, concerns over quality management and public safety remain, with calls for improved communications and promotion of nuclear power in residential heating.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
