summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Monday, rising 11.14 points to 1,611.26, with a 0.70% gain. Volume reached 418.23 million lots worth RM163.54 million. Gainers outpaced losers 490 to 76.

site_title: Peak aluminium looms for China as Xi pushes new green mission
summary: China is poised to halt the growth of its massive aluminium industry as policymakers aim to meet President Xi Jinping's goal for carbon neutrality by 2060. A recent halt on new projects in Inner Mongolia, a coal-rich province, may trigger a wider crackdown on the industry, potentially leading to peak production sooner than the 2025 target. Goldman Sachs predicts a global supply deficit from 2021, with larger gaps in 2022 and 2023, and prices may rise due to restricted supplies. This could shake up the global aluminium market, which has been plagued by supply gluts in the past.

site_title: South Africa's Massmart annual net loss widens on Covid-19 hit
summary: South African retailer Massmart reported a net loss of 1.753 billion rand (S$153.48 million) for the 2020 full year, widening by 35.3% from the previous year due to COVID-19 restrictions. The company lost 6.1 billion rand in sales and saw group sales fall 7.7% to 86.5 billion rand. Sales in South African stores fell 7.9%, while those in the rest of Africa decreased by 5.4% in rand terms and 6.9% in constant currencies. Massmart is reviewing its stores outside the Southern African Development Community region as part of a turnaround plan.

images.alt_text: The Game and Makro department chain owner estimated that it lost out on sales worth 6.1 billion rand in 2020 due to the restrictions.

site_title: End of road for Singapore's Hin Leong as court grants winding up order
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted a winding-up order for Hin Leong Trading, an oil trader brought to its knees by last year's oil slump amid fraud allegations. The court-appointed managers, Goh Thien Phong and Chan Kheng Tek, were granted their wish to be appointed as joint liquidators, and the JM order was discharged. Hin Leong had assets valued at US$273.28 million and total debt of US$4.59 billion at the end of October 2020. The court's decision underscores the difficulty in restructuring a giant entity during an oil downturn and amid a scandal involving the firm's founder, Lim Oon Kuin.

images.alt_text: It's the end of passage for collapsed oil trader Hin Leong Trading (HLT) after the Singapore High Court on Monday granted an order to wind up the debt-roiled firm that was brought to its knees by last year's oil slump amid the spectre of fraud allegations.

site_title: England's children go back to school after virus lockdown
summary: England's children returned to school on Monday after a virus lockdown, marking the first time since January. The government, which has vaccinated around 23 million people, is easing restrictions as case numbers decrease. The staggered return will see primary school students aged 5-11 back in class first, followed by secondary school students over the next week. Regular testing and mask-wearing will be enforced to curb the spread of infection.

site_title: Brokers' take: JPMorgan says industrial Reits 'most vulnerable' amid S-Reit headwinds
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict a correction in Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), citing a "period of volatility" due to the steepening yield curve. Industrial Reits, which outperformed the S-Reit index last year, are deemed the most vulnerable, with analysts downgrading several industrial Reits to "underweight" and recommending a focus on retail/hospitality Reits. JPMorgan also upgraded Mapletree Commercial Trust to "overweight" and identified CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust as a top pick.

site_title: Markets look to ECB for reassurance on cheap money
summary: The European Central Bank is set to stress its commitment to keeping borrowing costs low amidst inflation concerns and a slow vaccination drive in the eurozone economy. Investors fear faster price growth could lead to higher interest rates, slowing the recovery from the pandemic. The ECB's meeting is likely to be dominated by rising global bond yields triggered by inflation signs.

site_title: China's focus on annual GDP targets gives greater policy flexibility: official
summary: China's 2021-2025 economic plan omitted setting an average annual growth target, citing uncertainties and giving policymakers room to respond flexibly. The plan sets an annual GDP target of above 6% for 2021, with a focus on maintaining a "reasonable" growth range. China will set annual growth goals contingent on circumstances, prioritizing quality over numerical growth. Economists expect China's economy to grow more than 8% in 2021, with a long-term target of maintaining average annual growth of at least 4.7% to bring GDP per capita in line with moderately developed countries.

site_title: UK aviation industry calls on Johnson for more financial aid
summary: The UK aviation industry is urging Prime Minister Boris Johnson to provide more financial aid due to the COVID-19 pandemic's impact, with demand at just 2% of its usual level. Heathrow airport, unionized workers, and ground-handling staff are calling for full business rates relief, extended furlough schemes, government loans, and a 12-month holiday for airport passenger duty. The industry faces 124,000 job losses on top of existing losses, with opposition Labour Party criticizing the government's lack of sector-specific support.

site_title: Singaporean-led Arrow Capital co-sponsors US$240m SPAC with US venture firm
summary: ARROW Capital, a Singaporean-led advisory firm, co-sponsored a US$240 million special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) with US-based venture firm Tribe Capital. The SPAC, Tribe Capital Growth Corp I, debuted on the Nasdaq and is seeking mergers and acquisitions opportunities with technology companies in "inflection points of growth." Rohit Nanani, founder and leader of Arrow Capital, will join the SPAC's board, while Tribe partner Arjun Sethi will be its chairman and CEO. The partnership aims to tap into emerging markets like the Middle East and South-east Asia.

site_title: Meghan accuses British royals of racism, says they pushed her to brink of suicide
summary: Meghan Markle, the wife of Prince Harry, has accused the British royal family of racism, lying, and pushing her to the brink of suicide in an explosive televised interview. The 39-year-old said she experienced suicidal thoughts and considered self-harm after marrying into the family in 2018. She also claimed her son Archie was denied the title of prince due to concerns about his dark skin. The interview has raised concerns about the monarchy's treatment of Meghan, potentially shaking the institution to its core.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up on US jobs news but inflation fears linger
summary: Asian markets rose Monday, driven by a US jobs report and the Senate's approval of Joe Biden's stimulus package, which set up the package for potential signing by the end of the week. Brent crude broke past US$70 for the first time in almost two years. Despite the positive news, inflation fears lingered. The approval of the US stimulus package and the US jobs report pushed most Asian equities higher, while Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jardine Matheson, Lian Beng, Yangzijiang, IHH Healthcare, Yongnam
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include Jardine Matheson's US$5.5 billion acquisition of 15% of Jardine Strategic Holdings, simplifying its structure. Lian Beng Group exercised a call option to acquire the BreadTalk IHQ Building, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding secured US$1.74 billion in shipbuilding contracts. IHH Healthcare is exploring the sale of its medical education arm, and Yongnam Holdings won five contracts worth S$32.8 million. These announcements may impact trading of the respective companies' securities.

site_title: Billionaire MacKenzie Scott marries Seattle science teacher
summary: MacKenzie Scott, ex-wife of Amazon's Jeff Bezos, has married Dan Jewett, a Seattle science teacher. Jewett plans to help give away most of their wealth to charity, as stated on the Giving Pledge website. Jewett described Scott as "one of the most generous and kind people I know" and expressed his commitment to passing on their wealth to serve others.

images.alt_text: MacKenzie Scott, the ex-wife of Amazon's Jeff Bezos and one of the world's richest women, has married a Seattle science teacher, who promptly declared he plans to help give away most of their wealth to charity.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by rallies on Wall Street after better-than-expected US jobs data. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.03% to 29,162.99, while the Topix index edged up 0.97% to 1,914.50.

site_title: Swiss voters narrowly approve a ban on face coverings
summary: Switzerland has become the latest European country to ban face coverings in public places, with 51.2% of voters supporting the ban. The proposal, backed by the Swiss People's Party, prohibits full facial coverings but allows for exceptions at religious sites and for security or health purposes. Critics argue the ban is racist and Islamophobic, citing a study showing only 30 women in Switzerland wear the veil, mostly born in the country and converted to Islam. The federal government had urged voters to reject the ban, citing concerns it would damage tourism.

images.alt_text: Switzerland on Sunday became the latest European country to ban the wearing of face coverings in public places, prohibiting the veils worn by Muslim women.

site_title: Atari setting up crypto casino to tap into nostalgia and NFTs
summary: Atari, a gaming company, is launching a crypto casino in partnership with Decentral Games on the Ethereum blockchain. The casino will feature Atari-themed games and NFTs, allowing players to earn digital currency. The companies expect $150 million in bets in 2021 and $400 million over two years. This move aims to revitalize Atari, which has struggled to compete with stronger rivals since its arcade and home titles were popular in the 1970s and 1980s. The collaboration leverages blockchain technology and NFTs to create a new gaming experience.

site_title: Potential wealth tax raises concern over Singapore's competitiveness as wealth hub
summary: Singapore's competitiveness as a wealth management hub may be impacted by potential wealth taxes, including reinstatement of estate duty and introduction of capital gains tax. Consultants and banks believe the impact will be felt more among high net worth individuals (HNW) rather than ultra wealthy and family offices. The country's tax competitiveness is currently among the highest globally, but introducing wealth taxes could deter HNW individuals from setting up family offices in Singapore, potentially affecting the country's position as a wealth management hub.

site_title: Cambodia's dwindling fish stocks put spotlight on changing rivers
summary: Cambodia's fish stocks are dwindling due to hydropower projects, sand mining, deforestation, and climate change, which have disrupted fishing and threatened food supplies for millions. The Tonle Sap River and Mekong rivers have experienced dramatic drops in water levels, causing reduced fish catches and reversing the typical flow into the Tonle Sap Lake. Experts blame these factors for the decline, with some fishermen feeling trapped in a declining livelihood with little future. The issue has become a geopolitical concern, with the US urging Lower Mekong nations to demand answers from China about its dams.

images.alt_text: Cambodian fisherman Tin Yusos tucks into a meal of the previous day's catch with his wife and granddaughter aboard a boat which doubles as their home moored by the banks of the Tonle Sap River.

site_title: Australia: Stocks rise on US stimulus, economic recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 1.8% on Monday, their best day in two months, after the US Senate passed a $1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief plan and upbeat US jobs data. The S&P/ASX 200 index advanced to 6,830.7, driven by gains in mining, technology, and financial stocks. Energy stocks also rose, tracking a jump in oil prices. The move follows positive sentiment from last week's US jobs data and the start of AstraZeneca's coronavirus vaccine rollout in Australia.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose sharply on Monday and were set for their best day in two months after the US Senate passed a US$1.9 trillion Covid-19 relief plan, while last week's upbeat US jobs data also supported sentiment.

site_title: Brent cracks US$70 for first time since pandemic began after Saudi facilities attacked
summary: Brent crude futures reached a 2-year high of US$70.76 a barrel, surpassing the US$70 mark for the first time since the pandemic began, following attacks on Saudi Arabian oil facilities by Iran-backed Houthi rebels. US crude also surged, touching its highest in over two years. The attacks, which targeted key oil facilities and military bases, are believed to have disrupted global energy security. Oil prices have spiked for the fourth consecutive session, despite Saudi Arabia's oil minister expressing doubts on demand recovery.

site_title: Women in finance
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, as part of its efforts to reduce carbon emissions. Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments reached S$46 billion in FY2025, with the company evolving its climate investing approach. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also deepening cooperation with the People's Bank of China in green and transition finance. Meanwhile, BYD and other electric vehicle battery makers face pressure to reduce emissions. Singapore is also considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines.

site_title: The Mann for the job
summary: M1 CEO Manjot Singh Mann aims to transform the Singaporean telco into a more customer-centric and future-relevant entity. Two years into his tenure, Mann hopes he is on the right track. The company faces intense competition from other postpaid mobile players in Singapore. To stay ahead, Mann must ensure M1 remains competitive and innovative in the rapidly evolving telecommunications landscape.

site_title: Japan minister apologises for bureaucrat's dinners with NTT executives
summary: Japan's internal affairs minister removed Vice-Minister Yasuhiko Taniwaki for attending meals with Nippon Telegraph and Telephone (NTT) executives, potentially breaching the National Civil Service Ethics Law. The move comes after a ministerial apology and follows a resignation of a key government spokeswoman who attended similar events. The incident has raised concerns about the administration's handling of public affairs. Despite this, a recent poll showed support for Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's administration at 48%, its highest level since December.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's administration has faced public criticism after the Shukan Bunshun magazine said internal affairs officials wined and dined with NTT, as well as Suga's son, an executive at a company that produces television programmes for satellite broadcasters.

site_title: Australia halts defence ties with Myanmar, redirects aid
summary: Australia has suspended its defense cooperation program with Myanmar amid an intensified crackdown on protests following the country's military coup. The decision prioritizes humanitarian aid for Rohingya and ethnic minorities, redirecting assistance away from government entities. Foreign Affairs Minister Marise Payne stated that Australia will engage with non-government organizations to address pressing humanitarian needs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin Monday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Monday's session with gains, following a strong lead from Wall Street in reaction to a bumper US jobs report and the edge of passing Joe Biden's stimulus package. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.91% to 29,362.59, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.66% to 3,524.98. This move comes amidst positive sentiment from US markets, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened sharply higher on Monday morning following a strong lead from Wall Street in reaction to a bumper US jobs report and as lawmakers in Washington edge closer to passing Joe Biden's huge stimulus package.

site_title: Brokers' take: DTL financing framework review to benefit SBS Transit, says CGS-CIMB
summary: CGS-CIMB has maintained its "add" rating on SBS Transit and ComfortDelGro, citing potential benefits from the government's review of the Downtown Line (DTL) financing framework. The review could lead to a 13-16% upside for SBS Transit's FY2021-23 net profit forecasts and a 3.6-4.3% upside for ComfortDelGro's forward earnings. The brokerage expects a recovery in ridership figures and a shift to a risk-sharing model for the DTL, which it believes will help SBS Transit overcome its long-standing loss-making status.

site_title: Jardine Matheson to incorporate Jardine Strategic via US$5.5b cash acquisition
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings will acquire the remaining 15% of Jardine Strategic Holdings for approximately US$5.5 billion, simplifying its parent company structure. Upon completion, Jardine Matheson will be the single holding company for all its Jardine subsidiaries, aiming to increase operational efficiency and financial flexibility. The acquisition price represents a 20.2% premium to Jardine Strategic's last closing price.

site_title: Singapore stocks advance at open, tracking Wall Street rally; STI up 1.9%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) jumped 1.9% to 3,070.74, tracking a Wall Street rally, with industrial and cyclical sectors leading gains. The rally follows strong US non-farm payroll figures, the passage of the US$1.9 trillion fiscal stimulus bill, and rising crude oil prices. The most heavily traded counters were Oceanus, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC, with Jardine Strategic Holdings and Jardine Matheson Holdings also surging.

site_title: Hot stock: Jardine Strategic up 36.5% on proposed Jardine Matheson acquisition
summary: Shares of Jardine Strategic Holdings surged 36.5% to a one-year-high of US$37.50 after Jardine Matheson Holdings announced a proposed acquisition of the remaining 15% stake in Jardine Strategic, valued at US$5.5 billion. The deal is expected to become effective by April 2021, simplifying Jardine Matheson's parent company structure and increasing operational efficiency. Jardine Matheson shares also rose 15.5% to US$62.0, while Jardine Strategic's shares closed up 19.49% at US$32.80.

site_title: Chinese beauty app becomes first major company to buy Ether
summary: Chinese beauty app Meitu has become the first major company to invest in Ether, buying 15,000 units for $22.1 million and 379.1 Bitcoins for $17.9 million. The investment, part of a $100 million plan, aims to diversify its portfolio and capitalize on Ether's price appreciation. Meitu's chairman, Cai Wensheng, is a crypto enthusiast who began exploring blockchain technology in recent years. The investment follows Tesla's $1.5 billion Bitcoin purchase and signals growing interest in cryptocurrencies among institutions. Meitu's stock surged 14% on the news, with Ether also rising 5.3%.

site_title: Drone hits eastern Saudi port, missile targets Aramco facilities: energy ministry
summary: A drone struck a Saudi oil port and a ballistic missile targeted Aramco facilities in eastern Saudi Arabia on Sunday, according to the energy ministry. The attacks did not result in casualties or damage. Yemen's Huthi rebels claimed responsibility for the drone and missile strikes, which marked a new escalation in Yemen's six-year conflict. The developments came despite a renewed US push to end hostilities.

images.alt_text: A drone struck a Saudi oil port and a ballistic missile targeted facilities of energy giant Aramco in the country's east on Sunday, the energy ministry said.

site_title: Hackers breach thousands of Microsoft customers around the world
summary: Hackers, believed to be a Chinese government-backed group, have breached thousands of Microsoft customers worldwide, claiming over 60,000 victims globally. The attack, which started with a vulnerability in Microsoft's Exchange e-mail software, has spread rapidly and has infected victims across various industries, including banks, electricity providers, and small businesses. The hackers have automated the process, targeting servers worldwide, and researchers warn that this may mark a new era in cybersecurity threats.

site_title: Gender diversity: Giving women the equal opportunities they deserve
summary: The article highlights the persistence of sexism and gender inequality despite societal progress. Research by LinkedIn found that in the Asia-Pacific region, women were disproportionately affected by COVID-19 and less optimistic about their future. The issue of gender diversity and equal opportunities for women remains a pressing concern, with the need for continued efforts to address these disparities and promote greater inclusivity.

site_title: STI Reserve List S-Reits active with M&A deals
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) Reserve List of Reits and business trusts, comprising Keppel Reit, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Suntec Reit, and NetLink NBN Trust, showed improved performance with average total returns of 0.9% compared to the STI's 4.5% decline. Keppel Reit, the top-performing stock, generated a total return of 6.1%, following its acquisition of Pinnacle Office Park in December 2020. The STI Reserve List will be used in case of index deletions, and its members have outperformed the STI's S-Reits in the 2021 year-to-date till March 4.

site_title: Swiss approve Indonesia free trade deal
summary: Switzerland has narrowly approved a free trade deal with Indonesia, with 51.7% of voters supporting the agreement after a public vote. The deal aims to boost ties between the two countries, with tariffs to be gradually removed from Swiss exports to Indonesia and abolished on Indonesian industrial products. However, environmentalists had raised concerns over Indonesia's palm oil industry, which has been linked to deforestation. The deal includes exceptions for certain agricultural products and requires Indonesian palm oil to meet certain environmental and social standards.

images.alt_text: Controversy surrounding the importation of Indonesian palm oil and its sustainability fuelled enough concern in Switzerland to trigger a public vote on the agreement.

site_title: Manchester United shatters Manchester City's winning streak; Liverpool crisis mounts
summary: Manchester United defeated Manchester City 2-0, ending City's 28-game unbeaten run in all competitions and shattering their record winning streak. Bruno Fernandes scored the opening penalty and Luke Shaw sealed the win with a second-half strike. The victory moved Manchester United above Leicester into second place, but they remain 11 points behind City with 10 games left. Meanwhile, Liverpool suffered a 1-0 loss to relegation-threatened Fulham, extending their home league losing streak to six consecutive games.

site_title: Dollar jumps as US jobs growth surges
summary: The US dollar surged after jobs growth beat expectations in February, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 379,000 jobs. This data supported the Federal Reserve's view of a justified rise in US government bond yields, driven by an improving economic outlook. The dollar index jumped to a one-year high, while the euro fell to its lowest since November. Benchmark 10-year Treasury yields reached a one-year high, and other currencies such as the Swiss franc and Japanese yen weakened against the US dollar.

site_title: Ryde targets S$200m Catalist IPO in 2022; to add 100 staff
summary: Singapore-based ride-hailing platform Ryde plans to list on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board in 2022 with a targeted valuation of S$200 million. The firm aims to recruit 100 more staff and invest IPO proceeds in technology, product development, and operations. Ryde claims to have broken even in Q4 last year and has seen a 30% year-on-year growth in users, with over 10,000 monthly active drivers on its platform. The company aims to capture 30% of the Singapore ride-hailing market by 2023.

site_title: New York's Cuomo rejects new calls to resign over harassment claims
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has refused to resign despite criticism from fellow Democrats over sexual harassment allegations. Cuomo, who initially praised his state's pandemic response, has faced calls to step down from influential Democrats, including New York State Senate leader Andrea Stewart-Cousins and Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie. Cuomo has denied the allegations, saying he never touched anyone inappropriately and apologizes for making his accusers feel "uncomfortable." State Attorney General Letitia James is leading an inquiry into the allegations.

site_title: Coupang's US$3.6b IPO shows US is king for tech IPOs
summary: South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang is set to become the largest Korean company to list on the US market in a decade with its $3.6 billion IPO. The company chose New York over Seoul due to a valuation premium, a deeper and more liquid market, and unequal voting rights that benefit founder Bom Kim. This follows other major tech IPOs, including Airbnb and DoorDash, which listed in New York in 2020. Coupang's IPO could value the company at over $50 billion, making it the largest float by a Korean company since Samsung Group in 2010.

site_title: Queen praises 'dedication to duty' before Harry and Meghan interview
summary: Queen Elizabeth II praised "dedication to duty" in a Commonwealth Day Service address, hours before the screening of Oprah Winfrey's interview with Prince Harry and Meghan, which has sparked a rift between the couple and Buckingham Palace. The pre-recorded message from London's Westminster Abbey highlighted the importance of putting others first during the pandemic. The queen's speech comes ahead of the tell-all interview, which has been highly anticipated and has significant implications for the royal family's relationships.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II on Sunday spoke of the importance of "dedication to duty" in a television address hours before the screening of US chat show host Oprah Winfrey's eagerly-anticipated interview with Prince Harry and his American wife Meghan.

site_title: Gender parity: More than workplace flexibility required
summary: The rise of hybrid and work-from-home (WFH) work norms may not necessarily lead to improved gender equality in the workplace. Global research suggests women face significant challenges in balancing paid employment with caregiving responsibilities at home. Despite flexibility and cost savings, women are often overworked and burnt out. To achieve true gender parity, more than just flexible work arrangements are required, and a comprehensive approach to addressing unequal responsibilities and support systems is needed.

site_title: Good Class Bungalow market continues to sizzle
summary: The Singapore Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market continues to thrive, with nearly 40% of the total transactions in the first two months of this year exceeding the entire 2020 tally. Since the start of the year, 16 deals have been recorded, with the latest transaction taking place on February 23. Experts attribute the strong sales momentum to a combination of pent-up demand, low interest rates, and a narrowing price gap, with some predicting a further 5-10% price rise this year.

site_title: French billionaire MP Olivier Dassault dies in helicopter crash
summary: French billionaire Olivier Dassault, 69, a politician and scion of the Dassault aircraft-making family, was killed in a helicopter crash near the coastal resort of Deauville in north-west France on Sunday. French President Emmanuel Macron called his death a "great loss" and sent condolences to the Dassault family. An involuntary manslaughter investigation was opened by prosecutors, and the pilot of the helicopter was also killed. Dassault was a leading figure in French politics and industry, with interests spanning aeronautics, defence, and media.

site_title: How women can take charge of their financial well-being
summary: OCBC Bank's survey of 2,000 working adults in Singapore found that women tend to be less invested in their finances, but those who do take the plunge outperform men in terms of investment returns. Despite this, 60% of women have investments, compared to 75% of men, and just 28% of women are confident or knowledgeable about investing. OCBC's head of wealth management, Tan Siew Lee, advises women to take responsibility for their financial planning, starting with getting interested and clear on their desired lifestyle. She suggests tracking expenses, investing excess savings, and starting with a regular investment plan to beat inflation and achieve financial independence.

site_title: Manhattan's real estate agents take up TikTok to find renters
summary: Manhattan real estate agents are using TikTok to find renters in a market with near-record vacancies. Agents like Madison Sutton and Alexander Zakharin have gained large followings and are using the platform to showcase apartments, conduct virtual tours, and reach potential clients. With many city-dwellers fleeing the area and newcomers hesitant to settle down, alternative marketing strategies like TikTok have become essential. The platform's algorithm allows agents to target specific audiences, increasing their chances of finding tenants. As a result, TikTok has become a crucial tool for agents in the competitive Manhattan rental market.

site_title: Jakarta MRT eyes working with private investors for urban renewal
summary: Jakarta's MRT Jakarta, the operator of the city's mass rapid transit system, is exploring working with private investors to fund its urban renewal projects. The company aims to expand its network, with the second line expected to be completed by 2028 and a third phase planned for 2025. MRT Jakarta president director William Sabandar is seeking investors to partner with for phase 3 and 4, which will include property development projects surrounding the stations. The goal is to create liveable spaces where citizens can work, live, and socialize in a safe and clean environment, improving mobility and reducing reliance on private vehicles.

site_title: Why is Top Glove raising fresh equity after repurchasing shares at a much higher price?
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysia-based rubber glove maker, is raising fresh equity after repurchasing shares at a higher price. The company issued 1.495 billion new shares to raise up to HK$14.95 billion, seeking a listing in Hong Kong. However, this move has raised concerns among shareholders, as the company repurchased shares at an average price of RM7 per share, then issued new shares at an implied price of RM5.20. The company's shares have dipped, and its earnings growth is expected to slow due to a surge in unit prices during the pandemic, followed by a subsequent decline in revenue.

site_title: China's February exports post record surge from Covid-depressed 2020 levels
summary: China's February exports surged by 154.9% from a year earlier, driven by fiscal stimulus measures and a rebound in foreign demand. Imports rose 17.3% in February, the most since October 2018. The strong exports helped fuel the country's recovery from the pandemic-induced paralysis. A rebound in manufacturing industries in the European Union and the US, and increased imports of Chinese products, contributed to the surge. China posted a trade surplus of $103.25 billion for the first two months, exceeding forecasts.

site_title: Deliveroo to offer £50 million of stock to customers
summary: Deliveroo plans to offer £50 million of shares to customers in its upcoming London flotation, making it the largest market debut in Britain for three years. The offer, branded "Great food with a side of shares," aims to give customers a chance to become shareholders alongside restaurant partners and riders. Loyal customers will be prioritized if the offer is oversubscribed, with each able to apply for up to £1,000 of shares. The company's founder, Will Shu, aims to reward customers for their support during the pandemic.

site_title: Innopac's bid for judicial management dismissed due to unsuccessful application to adjourn court hearing
summary: INNOPAC Holdings' application for judicial management has been dismissed due to an unsuccessful attempt to adjourn a court hearing. The company, which has faced financial struggles and claims from Saxo Bank, can resubmit a fresh application if necessary. Innopac had previously failed to meet the requirements to remove itself from the Singapore Exchange's watch-list in 2019, resulting in a delisting notice. The company has recorded significant losses in recent years, including a net loss of S$3.8 million in FY2019.

site_title: New York City's Financial District faces office glut as tenant exits loom
summary: New York City's Financial District is facing an office glut as the pandemic keeps workers at home, with JPMorgan Chase being the latest high-profile tenant to look for an exit. The area has seen an 80% surge in sublease space, with S&P Global and Fitch Ratings Inc also marketing large blocks of offices. The glut is driving down average asking rents to $61.59 a square foot, the lowest since 2016, and putting pressure on landlords, with some buildings seeing up to 90% vacancy.

site_title: Swedish funds managing US$250b get slammed for poor ESG record
summary: Sweden's state-backed pension funds, managing $250 billion in assets, have been criticized for failing to live up to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) goals. The Swedish Society for Nature Conservation found that the funds still hold $1.8 billion in investments in 66 of the world's largest polluters, despite cutting ties with some fossil-fuel companies last year. The organization argues that the funds' approach is too little, too late, and that investors should abandon such holdings to make a meaningful impact.

site_title: UAE's first independent digital banking platform launched
summary: UAE's first independent digital banking platform, YAP, launched in Dubai, offering spending and budgeting analytics, peer-to-peer payments, and remittances services. YAP partners with RAK Bank for international account numbers and secure funding. The platform aims to become a leader in the Middle East, Africa, and South Asia, with plans to partner with banks in other countries. Founded by Marwan Hachem, YAP has secured seed funding and over 20,000 pre-registered customers, with accounts expected to go live in coming weeks.

site_title: US hotel property not expected to recover till 2024
summary: US hotel property values are forecast to take until 2024 to recover from the pandemic's impact, with distressed asset values expected to recover at least 50% of their losses by 2023. The sector's performance will vary depending on hotel type, location, and chain, with economy and midscale hotels likely to weather the downturn better than luxury and full-service hotels. Industrial and warehouse properties are expected to fare the best, with retail properties also showing some resilience, despite significant valuation declines.

site_title: Software icon McAfee charged in cryptocurrency scam
summary: John McAfee, creator of McAfee computer security software, faces charges of conspiracy, fraud, and money laundering in connection with a "pump-and-dump" scheme promoting cryptocurrencies on Twitter. McAfee and co-defendant Jimmy Watson are accused of making millions by duping investors and exploiting social media to drive up cryptocurrency values. The US Department of Justice says they used lies and deception to rake in millions. McAfee is in custody in Spain pending extradition to the US, where he is wanted for tax evasion.

site_title: Protests erupt across Myanmar; Suu Kyi party official dies in custody
summary: Protests in Myanmar have escalated with at least six cities participating, following the death of Khin Maung Latt, a campaign manager for the party of deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi, in police custody. The cause of his death is unknown, but his body was found with a bloodstained cloth around the head. The protests, which began after the coup last month, demonstrate widespread opposition to the military regime. Suu Kyi's party has been dissolved, and the situation remains volatile in the country.

site_title: Bond traders going all-in on US Treasury market's big short bet
summary: US Treasury market sees a surge in yields, with the benchmark 10-year yield reaching 1.62% last Friday, the highest since February 2020. Stronger-than-expected job creation and the Federal Reserve's lack of concern about long-term borrowing costs have emboldened traders, leading to a big short bet. Demand to borrow 10-year notes in the repurchase-agreement market is so great that rates have gone negative, likely part of the move to short the maturity. This shift in market sentiment has crucial implications across asset classes, prompting analysts to recalibrate expectations for 10-year rates.

site_title: Breast Cancer Foundation raises over $250,000 through charity golf event
summary: The Breast Cancer Foundation (BCF) raised over $250,000 through its seventh Tee for Pink Charity Golf event in Singapore, exceeding expectations despite COVID-19 challenges. The event, held at Tanah Merah Country Club, aimed to raise awareness about breast cancer and encouraged male participation. The donations were matched dollar-for-dollar by Tote Board, with BCF president Staphnie Tang emphasizing the importance of male involvement in promoting breast cancer awareness and early detection. The event follows the World Health Organization's announcement that breast cancer is now the most occurring cancer globally.

site_title: Technology shifts that enhance board governance in the hybrid era
summary: Key technology shifts are enhancing board governance in the hybrid era, including unified collaboration platforms for healthier dynamics, data lakes and AI for real-time insights, and blockchain technology for secure remote voting. These advancements boost connectivity, communications, and engagement, while also increasing access to information and improving decision-making. As companies adopt these technologies, boards may need to refresh skills and experiences, and veteran directors may need to adapt to new digitalization and cybersecurity challenges.

site_title: Gridlock at sea and chaos ashore as pandemic snarls trade network
summary: A pandemic-induced shipping gridlock is causing chaos at sea and ashore, disrupting global trade networks. Over two dozen container ships have been idling off the coast of Los Angeles for up to two weeks, while farmers struggle to ship soybeans to Asia. In China, furniture destined for North America is piling up on factory floors. The disruption has driven up shipping costs, adding to the challenges faced by the global economy in its recovery.

site_title: Swedish real estate hotter than ever
summary: Swedish house prices have reached a record high, with a 15% increase in February compared to the previous year. Apartments also saw a 6% rise, as central bank stimulus fuels demand for bigger homes. Experts attribute the surge to "hysteria" connected to quantitative easing, and warn that the market may get even hotter due to the Riksbank's stimulus efforts. Funding costs are falling, and property bonds are heavily exposed to the real estate sector, contributing to the market's growth.

site_title: Oil prices are bubbling in a stream of optimism
summary: Oil prices surged to 12-month highs after Opec's surprise decision to constrain supplies, boosting Brent and West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices to record levels. Despite predictions of $70-80 a barrel this year, Goldman Sachs and UBS raised their forecasts to $75-80 a barrel, citing a "supercycle" and increased demand in China and Japan. However, some analysts warn that prices may overshoot and fall to $60 a barrel by the end of the year, while India's economic recovery is threatened by high prices.

site_title: China hopes US will remove 'unreasonable' curbs on cooperation
summary: China urged the US to remove "unreasonable" curbs on cooperation, including on climate change and human rights issues, as the two nations continue to face tensions over Taiwan, Xinjiang, and the South China Sea. State Councillor Wang Yi said the US should realize its interference in other countries' affairs based on democracy and human rights, and instead work together on issues like climate change. China also plans to reform Hong Kong's electoral system, which Wang described as a "brighter future" for the city.

images.alt_text: Mr Wang strikes a tough line even as he outlines where the world's two biggest economies could work together.

site_title: Biggest short-selling players getting a pass
summary: The largest short-selling players, including BlackRock and State Street Corp, are not being held accountable for their role in the GameStop short squeeze, despite being the primary lenders of securities used for short-selling. These asset managers generate significant income from lending fees, which can increase when short interest is high. However, some investors, like Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund, are reevaluating their lending practices due to concerns about fiduciary responsibilities. The GameStop saga may lead to a decrease in short-selling, threatening the revenue of dealers and lenders who supply securities.

site_title: Women in leadership, women on boards - it's time for a change
summary: Investors in Singapore are calling for more women on corporate boards, citing research that shows diversity in leadership is essential for business sustainability. The country has a 51% female university graduate rate and 31% female leadership presence, presenting opportunities for women to excel. Global investors are increasingly vocal about the need for board gender diversity, following the Covid-19 crisis that has brought societal issues to the forefront. Companies are expected to take action to increase female representation on boards, aligning with the growing recognition of the benefits of diversity in leadership.

site_title: China investors turning to bank stocks as market darlings plunge
summary: China investors are shifting to bank stocks as market darlings decline, with the CSI 300 Banks Index rising 12% this year. This trend is driven by investors seeking cheaper assets to escape lofty valuations in growth shares. Fund managers are also recasting expectations for the year, citing rising US sovereign bond yields and expectations that banks may not need more support from Beijing. As a result, banks and other undervalued shares are expected to rally, with some fund managers buying back into consumer and technology stocks that have fallen.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 5, 2021, highlights the surge in tanker and dry bulk market prices. Capesize rates surged $920, with the West Australia to China C5 gaining $0.609 to $8.959, and the trans-Atlantic C8 route at $15,215. The Brazil market was highly active, with the Brazil market lifting strongly despite a solid ballaster fleet. The Panamax market trend was eventful, with rates fluctuating in the Atlantic and EC South America. Ultramax/Supramax rates increased in many areas, with period cover active in various routes. The VLCC market saw pressure due to Opec production quotas, while Suezmax and Aframax rates fell. Handysize rates remained relatively quiet in the Atlantic, but surged in the Pacific.

site_title: Director of firms under probe also owns several F&B outlets
summary: Singapore director Ng Yu Zhi, who owns several F&B outlets, is also being probed for alleged fraud related to nickel trading. Ng, director of firms under investigation, manages Envy Hospitality Holdings, which operates high-end restaurants like Nishikane and Cicada. He is also a minority shareholder in the upcoming Joël Robuchon restaurants. Ng was arrested last month for suspected cheating in connection with an investment scheme involving the two firms, and his restaurant businesses claim to be "not implicated in any investigations."

site_title: Twitter's Dorsey auctions first ever tweet as digital memorabilia
summary: Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey is auctioning off his first-ever tweet as digital memorabilia, valued at up to $100,000. The 15-year-old tweet, sent in March 2006, is one of the most famous tweets on the platform and can be bought as a unique digital signature in the form of a non-fungible token (NFT). The tweet will continue to be available on Twitter, and the buyer will receive an autographed digital certificate signed using cryptography. The auction is taking place on the website Valuables, which compares buying tweets to buying an autographed baseball card.

site_title: AUDUSD recovers on commodities boom
summary: The Australian dollar (AUDUSD) has recovered to new highs, breaking above US$0.8000 for the first time since February 2, 2018, due to a commodities boom triggered by the rollout of COVID-19 vaccines and a predicted increase in global consumption. The surge in commodities, including iron ore, copper, and soybeans, has led to a positive market narrative, with traders and investors becoming more risk-appetitive. However, market sentiment can change rapidly, and the AUDUSD price may experience volatile swings and trend reversals.

site_title: US agency probes Facebook for 'systemic' racial bias in hiring, promotions
summary: The US Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) has launched a "systemic" probe into Facebook for alleged racial bias in hiring and promotions. Three job applicants and a manager claim the company discriminates against black candidates and employees by relying on subjective evaluations and promoting racial stereotypes. The EEOC investigation, which may last months, aims to determine if company policies contribute to widespread discrimination, potentially leading to a broader lawsuit representing entire classes of workers.

site_title: Over $1.2m raised in UOB Chinese New Year charity event
summary: UOB raised over S$1.2 million in its annual Chinese New Year charity event, supporting four organizations including The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund. The funds were raised through bamboo art workshops and an e-hongbao donation drive. A bamboo art piece auctioned off for S$100,888 will support SPD, a charity helping adults, youth, and children with disabilities, to further its programs for children with developmental needs. Despite the pandemic, customers showed strong support and generosity, according to UOB deputy chairman Wee Ee Cheong.

site_title: Airbus books slew of lost orders while deliveries lag output
summary: Airbus lost 92 orders in February, mostly due to Norwegian Air Shuttle's cancellation of narrow-body jet purchases. This marks a significant increase from the 115 lost orders in 2020. The company's deliveries in February were also lower than expected, with only 32 handed over. Airbus's production rate is currently around 50 planes per month, leading to concerns about undelivered jets. The trend could jeopardize the planned ramp-up in A320neo production and impact the company's ability to meet customer demand.

site_title: Yellen says higher Treasury yields signal recovery, not inflation
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that higher long-term Treasury debt yields signal market expectations of a stronger economic recovery, not increased inflation concerns. She believes the US can reach full employment by next year with President Biden's stimulus plan in place. Yellen also mentioned the need for faster job growth, but does not see inflation rising above the 2% average inflation rate objective set by the Fed.

site_title: Deliveroo riders to get cash bonus if potential IPO goes through
summary: Deliveroo is offering cash bonuses to its riders in Singapore if the company's planned IPO in London goes through. About 10 riders are eligible for the top payment of S$18,500, with payments ranging from S$370 to the top amount based on the number of orders completed. The Thank You Fund will reward riders who have delivered the most orders, with an estimated total payout of £16 million (S$29.7 million) for over 36,000 riders globally. Deliveroo's CEO, Will Shu, aims to reward riders for their efforts in helping the company grow and offer the best food delivery experience.

site_title: Biden's USDA chief is exploring making a carbon bank for farmers
summary: US Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack is exploring a carbon bank to encourage US farmers to reduce emissions, with a potential price guarantee for credits. The Biden administration is also examining changes to existing conservation programs and crop insurance premiums. Vilsack aims to devote significant resources to climate initiatives, initially on a small scale, and is considering tapping the Commodity Credit Corp's borrowing authority to fund climate projects. However, the entity's Congressionally-authorised credit ceiling may limit funding without disrupting farm subsidy programs.

site_title: Better targeted subsidies to those in greater need as healthcare spending likely to continue rising over time: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's healthcare spending is expected to continue rising due to an ageing population and increasing healthcare consumption. The government aims to strengthen primary care by building 12 new polyclinics by 2030 and targeting subsidies to those in greater need. The healthcare system will also be made more efficient and cost-effective through risk pooling and improved cost management. The government is also developing a national research and development program to prepare for future public health crises, including a national infectious disease repository and database.

site_title: Pompeo calls for US to boycott Beijing Olympics
summary: Former US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has called for a US boycott of the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, citing China's "nasty" activities as reasons. Pompeo, a vocal critic of Beijing, said the Olympics would be an "inappropriate" host due to China's human rights record, including the mass incarceration of Uighur Muslims. Pompeo's comments echo those of Republican lawmakers, including former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley, who have also called for a boycott. The US government has yet to officially state its position on boycotting the Olympics.

site_title: Bostic says Fed will support US economy as long as necessary
summary: Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic stated that the US economy is still under "considerable distress" and the Federal Reserve will continue to provide support until the labor market strengthens and inflation meets the central bank's long-term target. The US economy is expected to grow between 5% and 6% this year, but some jobs lost during the pandemic may not return due to structural changes. Bostic emphasized the need to minimize long-term damage and ensure a broad-based and inclusive recovery.

site_title: China abandons 24-year experiment with open Hong Kong elections
summary: China has abandoned its 24-year experiment with open Hong Kong elections, introducing sweeping plans to prevent pro-democracy movements. The proposed changes require candidates to be "patriots" and remove district councilors from the next leadership vote. The move signals a dramatic rejection of democratic institutions in Hong Kong, which had allowed opposition parties to win a majority of seats in local elections. The changes are seen as a response to the 2019 protests and the growing pro-democracy movement, which has been met with increasing repression by Beijing.

site_title: Retail sales down 6.1% in Jan but economists see recovery ahead
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 6.1% year-on-year in January, with online sales accounting for 10.3% of total sales. Despite this, economists see signs of improving domestic demand, particularly in industries such as furniture and household equipment. The decline is attributed to factors such as the Chinese New Year festival and low visitor arrivals. Economists expect retail sales to stay subdued in the first half of the year but may recover in the second half, with some predicting a full-year rebound of 1-13% depending on the easing of Covid-19 restrictions and vaccination efforts.

site_title: Chaswood Resources unit enters franchise agreements
summary: Chaswood Resources Holdings' subsidiary Bistro Italiana has entered into development agreements with five companies to develop and operate Chaswood's Italiannies brand of restaurants in Malaysia and overseas. The agreements include plans for five outlets in Johor and Singapore, five in China, three in Beijing, seven in Malaysia, and three in Penang and Ipoh. The cumulative development fee income from the agreements has a positive impact on the company's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share.

site_title: Downtown Line financing framework to be reviewed
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing the financing framework for the Downtown Line, a public transport line that has been operating under a fixed-fee model since its opening in 2015. The review aims to ensure the line is run reliably and sustainably. The government may consider adopting a risk-sharing model, similar to one used for other lines, where the operator bears significant commercial risk. Analysts suggest this could be necessary due to the line's history of losses, with some predicting it may need to transition to a more stringent model if ridership and costs remain unstable.

site_title: Microsoft server flaws raise alarms at the White House, DHS
summary: The US government has raised concerns over newly discovered flaws in Microsoft's email software, which have been exploited by suspected Chinese attackers to steal email from victims. At least 30,000 organizations, including small businesses and local governments, have been hacked. The White House and Department of Homeland Security are urging users to apply patches immediately. The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency has issued an emergency directive, and the Pentagon is assessing its systems. The vulnerabilities were disclosed in early January, but attacks may have begun as early as January 6.

site_title: American Air 737 MAX declared emergency after engine shutdown, lands safely
summary: A US-bound American Airlines 737 MAX aircraft, Flight 2555, declared an emergency after the captain shut down one engine due to a possible mechanical issue related to oil pressure or volume indicator. The plane landed safely at Newark Liberty International Airport without incident. The incident occurred after the aircraft resumed flights following the FAA's approval of safety updates by Boeing, the manufacturer. The FAA will investigate the incident, which was the first reported issue with the 737 MAX since its 20-month grounding following two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019.

site_title: Hong Kong turns empty hotels into apartments for residents
summary: Hong Kong is repurposing empty hotels into apartments to address the city's housing shortage. As the tourism industry remains weak due to the pandemic, property developers and the government are working together to transform hotels into residential developments. This move aims to satisfy the demand for apartments, which is currently in short supply. The initiative is seen as a solution to the city's housing crisis, which has been exacerbated by the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: California theme parks get go-ahead for limited reopening from April 1
summary: California health officials have given Walt Disney Co's Disneyland and other theme parks the go-ahead to reopen at limited capacity from April 1, after a nearly year-long closure due to the coronavirus pandemic. Capacity will be limited to 15-35% and masks and safety measures will be required. The parks will initially be open only to state residents, with outdoor stadiums and ball parks also allowed to reopen at reduced capacity. The decision is seen as a positive step for the local economy and thousands of workers who will return to their jobs.

site_title: Europe: Stocks pressured by yields, but mark weekly gains on firm cyclicals
summary: European stocks closed lower on Friday due to rising bond yields, but still marked a weekly gain as investors optimistic about an economic recovery. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.8% but rose 0.9% for the week. Automobile stocks led gains, while technology and utilities lagged. Analysts expect euro zone growth to be tamer this year, with rising bond yields seen as a sign of reflation. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that higher yields don't warrant intervention, supporting bond yields.

site_title: AT&T sued by SEC over information disclosed to analysts
summary: The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has sued AT&T and three of its executives, alleging that the company selectively disclosed non-public information about its finances to Wall Street analysts in early 2016. The SEC claims that AT&T's chief financial officer and other executives made private calls to analysts, sharing internal sales data and impact on revenue, which led analysts to reduce their revenue forecasts. AT&T has denied the allegations, calling them "meritless," and claims that the SEC's own enforcement policy is inconsistent with the testimony of those involved in the calls.

site_title: Washington Prime Group prepares potential bankruptcy filing; shares sink 44%
summary: Washington Prime Group, a US mall owner, is preparing a potential bankruptcy filing after missing an interest payment on its debt. The real estate investment trust (Reit) owns about 100 malls and has been negotiating with lenders to cut borrowings. Despite a 30-day grace period, talks are faltering, and shares have sunk 44% to $3.50. The company cited the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its operations and debt covenants, and a bankruptcy filing could change if negotiations evolve or the company's grace period is extended.

site_title: China's plan for digital yuan imperils bitcoin's biggest markets
summary: China's planned digital yuan could disrupt global cryptocurrency markets, particularly those in China, as the country tightens regulations. A digital yuan could lead to "panic selling" if it siphons liquidity from trading platforms for digital coins, according to Phillip Gillespie, CEO of B2C2 Japan. Tether, a digital coin pegged to the US dollar, is seen as a key risk as Chinese citizens may use it to dodge yuan conversion rules. The People's Bank of China's draft law prohibiting token creation and sales could also lead to a ban on Tether, further disrupting the market.

site_title: Covid rescue plan hurdle cleared, as US economy shows gains
summary: US Democrats reached a compromise on President Joe Biden's massive Covid-19 relief package, clearing a hurdle in the Senate and setting the bill on a path towards a final vote. The $1.9 trillion stimulus bill includes relief checks, funding for the vaccine rollout, and extended unemployment benefits. Despite concerns about the economy's recovery, the US unemployment rate dropped to 6.2% in February, with 379,000 jobs added. The compromise allows for tax breaks for low-income families, but a national minimum wage hike was dropped. The bill is expected to pass the Senate with a final vote expected this weekend.

site_title: Acquiring power to do good
summary: A former finance executive argues that women, despite making progress, still fear being perceived as power-hungry due to traditional feminine traits being undervalued. To gain access to more opportunities, women should focus on building their unique advantage through competency, presence, reputation, and networking. These personal powers can be cultivated and are not limited by gender, and a good reputation can open up more opportunities and inspire respect. The author believes that everyone can learn to acquire power to shape a better future.

site_title: Democrats reach deal on unemployment benefits
summary: Democrats reached a deal on unemployment benefits, clearing the way for the Senate to continue debating the pandemic-relief bill. The US$1.9 trillion stimulus package is expected to pass over the weekend, despite stalled negotiations on supplemental jobless benefits. President Joe Biden made public appeals for passage, highlighting continuing damage in the labor market. The deal comes after President Biden met with potential recipients of direct payments, emphasizing the need for the stimulus package to address ongoing economic challenges.

site_title: China sets modest GDP growth target as economy improves
summary: China has set a modest annual economic growth target of above 6% for 2021, following a year of disruption from the COVID-19 pandemic. This target is below analysts' expectations of around 8% growth. The government also aims to create more jobs in cities and boost lending to small businesses by over 30%. China's GDP expanded 2.3% last year, and the country targets a 2021 budget deficit of around 3.2% of GDP. The government will also focus on promoting the sharing of credit information and strengthening oversight over financial holding companies.

site_title: Gold bulls lose steam for now as yields trump inflation bet
summary: Gold prices have declined more than 10% in 2021, marking its worst first quarter in almost four decades, as investors shift from the traditional haven asset due to rising yields and optimism in global recovery. The Federal Reserve's lack of action on long-term borrowing costs has fueled the surge in US Treasury yields. Investor disillusionment with gold is partly driven by the emergence of Bitcoin as a competitor, with hedge funds and banks slashing their forecasts for the precious metal. Despite signs of a physical market recovery, gold prices are expected to remain low in the short-term.

site_title: Surge in director acquisitions and net institutional inflows
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) gained 1.4% over five trading sessions from February 26 to March 4, bringing its 2021 total return to 6.2%. OCBC, UOB, DBS, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding Holdings, and ST Engineering received the highest net institutional inflows. Meanwhile, Singapore Press Holdings, Thomson Medical Group, Raffles Medical Group, Q & M Dental Group, and Suntec Reit saw the highest net institutional inflows outside the STI. Wilmar International led share buybacks with a total consideration of S$32.59 million, accounting for 84% of the weekly tally. Notable director and substantial shareholder transactions included Edy Wiranto's acquisition of 2.6 million shares in United Global, Calvin Ho Han Leong's 496,900-share buy in First Sponsor Group, and Guo Jingyu's 655,800-share purchase in GHY Culture & Media.

site_title: Oil surges after Opec+ holds cuts, strong US jobs growth
summary: Oil prices surged 3% on Friday, reaching their highest levels in over a year, after Opec+ extended oil output cuts into April, despite a stronger-than-expected US jobs report. Brent futures rose $2.62 to $69.36 a barrel, while WTI crude rose $2.26 to $66.09 a barrel. The decision was seen as a cautious approach, with Saudi Arabia maintaining its 1 million barrel-per-day cut through April. Analysts expect oil prices to remain high, with Goldman Sachs raising its Brent crude forecast to $75 a barrel in the second quarter.

site_title: Shares of tanker owners hit by Opec+ supply shock
summary: OPEC+ has surprised oil traders by keeping oil production for April almost unchanged, hitting tanker owners with a supply shock. Shares of supertanker owners, including Frontline and DHT Holdings, fell as the move will lead to fewer cargoes and worsen the oversupply of ships. Global oil stockpiles could fall by 4.1 million barrels a day in the first quarter, potentially leading to more demand and a recovery in the tanker market.

site_title: Dr Seuss books are pulled, and a 'cancel culture' controversy erupts
summary: The Dr. Seuss estate has pulled six of the beloved author's books, including "And to Think That I Saw It on Mulberry Street", due to outdated and hurtful racial stereotypes. The decision has sparked a "cancel culture" controversy, with some questioning whether an author's work should be posthumously curated to reflect evolving social attitudes. Scholars argue that the move is necessary to update and protect Dr. Seuss's brand while acknowledging and rejecting his problematic views. The decision has raised questions about the cultural record and the importance of preserving children's classics with sensitivity.

site_title: MAS makes senior management changes
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced new senior management appointments, effective April 1, 2021. Ong Chong Tee, head of financial supervision, is leaving and will be replaced by Ho Hern Shin, currently assistant managing director (banking and insurance). Lim Tuang Lee, assistant managing director (organisation & people development), will be redesignated as assistant managing director (capital markets). The changes aim to renew MAS' leadership bench, following dedicated service of 35 years from Ong Chong Tee and Lee Boon Ngiap.

site_title: What does a normal or abnormal treadmill test mean?
summary: A normal treadmill test result does not guarantee the absence of underlying heart artery disease, especially in women, who are more likely to have baseline ECG changes and abnormal test results. Women are also more likely to have false positive results, especially in pre-menopausal women. An abnormal test result may indicate significant heart artery disease in men with risk factors, but it does not necessarily mean the same in women. Alternative diagnostic methods, such as CT coronary angiogram and stress echocardiography, are now available and may be more accurate, reducing the need for invasive coronary angiograms.

site_title: Queen's husband Philip moved back to private hospital to recover
summary: Prince Philip, 99, has been transferred from St Bartholomew's Hospital to King Edward VII's Hospital in London for continuing treatment after a heart procedure. The Duke of Edinburgh will remain in hospital for several days. This move follows his previous stay at the state-run hospital, and Buckingham Palace has confirmed his expected recovery period.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II's 99-year-old husband, Prince Philip, has been moved back to a private hospital to recuperate from a heart procedure at a specialist cardiac unit, Buckingham Palace said on Friday.

site_title: Australia housing to rise 10% in 2021, but there are risks ahead: Goldman
summary: Australia's housing market is expected to rise 10% in 2021, driven by low interest rates and improved sentiment, according to Goldman Sachs. However, there are risks ahead, including a potentially more hawkish Reserve Bank of Australia, which could hike interest rates earlier than expected. Goldman also forecasts 5% house price growth in 2022 and 3% in 2023, with positive wealth effects contributing to the housing industry's impact on annual GDP. Prolonged border restrictions or earlier-than-expected monetary policy tightening pose downside risks to the market.

site_title: US trade deficit widens as goods imports hit record high
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $68.2 billion in January, driven by a record high in goods imports of $221.1 billion. Consumer spending surged, boosted by government Covid-19 relief, while exports rose 1.6% to $135.7 billion. The trade gap has subtracted from GDP growth for two straight quarters, highlighting the ongoing impact of trade on the US economy.

site_title: Unstoppable Manchester City on the road to greatness
summary: Manchester City, under Pep Guardiola's leadership, has embarked on a historic winning streak, now standing at 21 consecutive victories. The team, initially struggling mid-table in the English Premier League, has claimed impressive wins over top opponents, including Arsenal, Manchester United, and Chelsea. City's impressive defense has not trailed in 19 Premier League games, and they have booked their place in the Carabao Cup final and Champions League quarter-finals. With 14-point leads in the EPL standings, Manchester City is on track to win the league and potentially achieve an unprecedented quadruple haul of trophies.

site_title: TikTok leases New London office following UK-China tech spat
summary: TikTok has leased a 88,500 square foot office building in London's Farringdon area through a 15-year deal. The move comes after the UK's decision to limit Huawei's 5G products and a review of TikTok's activities, prompting the company to reconsider its global headquarters plans for Britain. The lease was signed despite a UK government review likely to impose restrictions on TikTok's activities. The company is still searching for a larger office in Dublin.

site_title: Predicting the future of prediction markets
summary: Prediction markets, which allow people to "bet" on real-world events, have the potential to be a useful means of hedging risk and discovering information about future events. However, despite being supported by economists, they have struggled to gain mainstream acceptance since the 19th century. A new startup, Kalshi, aims to create prediction markets in various assets, including future weather and climate change risks, and has already won approval from the Commodities Futures Trading Commission. For prediction markets to succeed, they must meet certain criteria, including being general enough to attract widespread interest, important enough to matter, and unusual enough not to be replicable by trading in existing assets.

site_title: US: Fuelled by tech, Wall Street rebounds at end of volatile week
summary: US stocks rebounded sharply at the end of a volatile week, with the Nasdaq bouncing back from a 10% decline from its record high. Investors were boosted by gains in tech giants like Microsoft, Alphabet, Apple, and Oracle, which lifted the S&P 500. The rebound was driven by optimism about an economic rebound despite rising interest rates. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 reached fresh records, defying tariff uncertainty and split views on the Federal Reserve's future actions.

site_title: HK police arrest 12 over 'ramp and dump' stock scam
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 12 people, including 7 men and 5 women, for allegedly running a "ramp and dump" stock scam. The joint investigation with the Securities and Futures Commission froze HK$900 million (S$155.5 million) in assets. The suspects, who posed as investment gurus, used popular messaging apps to run the scam, where they hyped up certain stocks and sold them before leaving other investors to shoulder losses. Authorities are calling for victims to come forward, estimating a large number of victims but many may feel embarrassed about being duped.

site_title: The gender investment divide: Thinking beyond stereotypes
summary: A third of the world's wealth is under women's control, making them a significant economic force. Conventional wisdom suggests men are risk-takers and women are more risk-averse, but research suggests this may be rooted in confirmation bias. Studies indicate that women's risk tolerance is not as low as assumed, especially when their decisions have social impact. The pay gap, career breaks, and caregiver roles limit women's career progression and salary growth, exacerbating the investment gap. Greater representation of women in the financial services industry can be a win-win, valuing sustainability and harnessing individual strengths.

site_title: TPG Capital weighing potential IPO for its Asian pathology business
summary: TPG Capital Asia is considering an initial public offering (IPO) for its pathology business, Pathology Asia Holdings, which was initially acquired in 2018 for A$279 million. The business, worth about US$2 billion, is being weighed for a potential listing in Singapore or another venue. TPG is still deliberating on the listing and has asked banks to submit proposals. There is no certainty that the listing will proceed, and a TPG representative declined to comment.

site_title: The German city where cars are not welcome
summary: Heidelberg, Germany, is pioneering environmentally conscious urban planning, aiming to be emission-free by 2030. The city is cutting power usage, building bicycle "superhighways," and designing neighborhoods to discourage cars. Residents who give up their cars get free public transportation for a year. Despite promises from automakers to swear off fossil fuels, the city's mayor, Eckart Würzner, remains skeptical, citing high costs and limited accessibility of electric vehicles. Heidelberg's innovative projects, such as the Bahnstadt neighborhood, offer a glimpse of an automobile-light city of the future, but some critics argue it may be too little, too late.

site_title: IHH Healthcare explores sale of education arm
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest hospital group, is exploring the sale of its medical education arm International Medical University (IMU) for approximately US$300 million. The Malaysian company is working with Rippledot Capital Advisers on the potential deal, which is private and ongoing. This sale is part of IHH's business strategy shift under CEO Kelvin Loh Chi-Keon, focusing on extracting value from existing assets and divestments. The IMU unit generated RM75.7 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation in 2020.

site_title: EU-Singapore trade pact served as anchor for both economies amid Covid-19: President Halimah
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob emphasized the EU-Singapore free trade agreement (FTA) as a crucial anchor for both economies during the Covid-19 pandemic. The landmark deal has fostered strong economic ties and signals a commitment to free, fair global trade. Halimah also called for a digital economy agreement to strengthen connectivity and tap into the growing Internet user base in South-east Asia, following the pandemic.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Lian Beng Group's 75%-owned subsidiary has acquired the BreadTalk IHQ Building in a S$118 million deal. The 10-storey building, housing BreadTalk's international headquarters, will be rented by the company for 10 years. After the initial lease, BreadTalk can either extend the lease or buy the building at a mutually agreed price. Meanwhile, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding has secured shipbuilding contracts worth US$1.74 billion for 31 vessels, scheduled for deliveries in 2022-2023.

site_title: China pledges to tackle housing problem in biggest cities
summary: China has pledged to tackle its housing problem in large cities through a new 5-year plan, 2021-2025. Premier Li Keqiang announced measures to increase subsidized rental properties, shared-ownership housing, and lower rental apartment tax burdens. The government will also press ahead with the legislation of a property tax, aimed at cooling speculation. This comes as home prices in cities like Shanghai and Shenzhen reached record highs, with some areas seeing prices 9-43 times higher than residents' disposable income.

images.alt_text: Home prices in the secondary market, which faces less government intervention, gained the most in 18 months in January, the latest Chinese official data show.

site_title: Virgin Galactic chairman sells holding worth US$213 million
summary: Virgin Galactic chairman Chamath Palihapitiya sold 6.2 million shares worth US$213 million, disposing of his personal holding in the space-tourism company. The sale comes after he previously sold shares worth almost US$100 million in December. Palihapitiya still owns 15.8 million shares through his investment firm Social Capital Hedosophia, representing a 6.5% stake in the company.

site_title: FTSE Russell to drop Xiaomi, Luokung from indexes on Trump administration order
summary: FTSE Russell will remove Xiaomi and Luokung from global and Chinese indexes due to a US executive order by former President Donald Trump, which placed the companies on a blacklist for alleged ties to the Chinese military. The move follows a January ban on US investors holding shares in these companies. This decision affects the companies' inclusion in FTSE Russell indexes, which are used as benchmarks for investment portfolios. The changes are in line with the Trump administration's actions.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi is to be deleted from the Global All Cap and FTSE Global China A Inclusion indexes from March 12.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo from Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target and similar operating loss in H2. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing the current head. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and PBOC to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Give domestic workers a break
summary: A campaign, launched nearly 19 years ago, advocates for decent treatment and respect for domestic workers. The initiative, Transient Workers Count Too (TWC2), aims to address abuse through providing days off for foreign domestic workers. The organization found that existing resources, such as embassies, Ministries of Manpower, and voluntary organizations, already offer assistance. The campaign's focus has shifted from limited goals to promoting the rights and well-being of all migrant workers. Implementing days off could help stop abuse, and TWC2 continues to advocate for better treatment of domestic workers.

site_title: Myanmar police kill one protester, ahead of UN Security Council meeting
summary: Myanmar police opened fire on protesters, killing one man, ahead of a UN Security Council meeting to discuss the crisis. The violence occurred as the military lost control of its UN mission in New York and the US announced new sanctions targeting military conglomerates. Demonstrations continued in several towns and cities, with thousands marching peacefully, chanting "The stone age is over, we're not scared because you threaten us." The UN human rights chief called for an end to the "vicious crackdown" on peaceful protesters, who have seen at least 55 killed since the February 1 coup.

site_title: SoftBank strategy chief makes exit after just three years
summary: SoftBank's chief strategy officer Katsunori Sago is leaving the company after less than three years, effective March 31.
