Sago, a Goldman Sachs veteran, will be replaced by other executives at the Tokyo-based investment conglomerate. The departure comes as SoftBank continues to shift its focus to other areas. No reasons for Sago's exit have been disclosed, but his departure marks a significant change in leadership at the company.

site_title: Indonesia president's aide named head of opposition party, but turmoil ensues
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo's chief of staff, Moeldoko, was named chairman of the Democratic Party, a move seen as an attempt to broaden the president's coalition and tighten his grip on parliament. However, the legitimacy of the move was challenged by Agus Harimurti Yudhoyono, who claims to be the party's chairman. The government is expected to confirm which party leader will be recognized by the state, but analysts say Moeldoko's appointment could strengthen the government's position and influence in policy-making. The move has sparked turmoil within the party and raises questions about the party's leadership.

site_title: Hong Kong police arrest 12 over 'ramp and dump' stock scam
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 12 individuals for allegedly running a "ramp and dump" stock scam, freezing HK$900 million in assets. The joint investigation, with the Securities and Futures Commission, targeted those using popular messaging apps to manipulate market prices and sell stocks to unsuspecting investors. The accused, seven men and five women, face charges of market manipulation, money laundering, and fraud. Authorities urge victims to come forward, noting many may feel embarrassed about being scammed.

site_title: 'I'm ready to talk', says Meghan ahead of Oprah interview
summary: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, has given an in-depth interview to Oprah Winfrey, set to air on Sunday, after stepping away from royal duties with husband Prince Harry. The couple's decision to give the interview comes after a bitter war of words with Buckingham Palace, amid claims of lies, bullying, and smears. Meghan stated she's "ready to talk" and feels liberated to speak for herself, citing the need for independence and freedom to make choices. The interview has been criticized as hypocrisy, but Meghan emphasized her desire to be able to "say yes" and speak for herself.

images.alt_text: Meghan, Britain's Duchess of Sussex, said she had given an in-depth interview to US chat show host Oprah Winfrey to be aired on Sunday because she was now free speak for herself after she and husband Prince Harry quit their royal duties.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 case count passes 60,000
summary: Singapore has surpassed 60,000 Covid-19 cases, with 60,007 confirmed cases reported as of March 5. All the new cases were imported, and 59,842 have recovered, with 24 patients still in hospital. The sole community case is an 81-year-old woman who tested positive despite having previously developed symptoms after receiving a Covid-19 vaccine. The Ministry of Health attributes her case to a current infection, not the vaccine. Eighteen new imported cases were also confirmed on Thursday.

site_title: SoftBank strategy chief Sago to step down
summary: SoftBank Group's chief strategy officer, Katsunori Sago, will resign at the end of March. Sago, a former chief investment officer of Japan Post Bank Co, joined SoftBank in 2018. His departure comes as SoftBank consolidates power around Vision Fund chief Rajeev Misra and COO Marcelo Claure, and invests in public companies under Akshay Naheta. CEO Masayoshi Son praised Sago's role in expanding SoftBank's potential as an investment company, but did not provide a reason for his departure.

site_title: Virgin Galactic chairman sells US$213m stake
summary: Chamath Palihapitiya, chairman of Virgin Galactic, sold 6.2 million shares worth $213 million, raising his stake to 6.5% in the space-tourism company. The sale comes after he previously sold shares worth almost $100 million in December. Virgin Galactic's shares have increased 150% since merging with Social Capital's SPAC in 2019. Palihapitiya has made a fortune through his investments in blank-cheque companies, including Opendoor Technologies and Clover Health Investments Corp.

site_title: Volkswagen core brand to accelerate electric vehicle shift
summary: Volkswagen's core brand plans to more than double the share of fully electric vehicles in total European sales by 2030, aiming for 70% market share, up from a previous target of 35%. The company aims to become the world's leader in electric vehicle production, surpassing rivals like Tesla. In China and the US, electric vehicles are expected to account for 50% of total sales by 2030. Volkswagen's "Accelerate" strategy accelerates the carmaker's shift towards battery-powered cars, driven by the company's commitment to digital transformation.

site_title: New R&D programme to deal with future public health crises unveiled; Dorscon framework to be beefed up
summary: Singapore unveils a new R&D programme called the Programme for Research in Epidemic Preparedness And Response (Prepare) to enhance its capabilities in preventing, preparing, and responding to future public health crises. The programme aims to strengthen infectious disease collaboration networks, accelerate the development of diagnostics, therapeutics, and vaccines, and establish a national infectious disease repository and database. This move is part of the country's efforts to boost its R&D capabilities.

site_title: Pope in Baghdad for 'emblematic' visit
summary: Pope Francis arrived in Baghdad on Friday for an "emblematic" visit, marking his first foreign trip since November 2019. The 84-year-old pope has been met with thousands of additional security personnel due to rocket and suicide bomb attacks in the area. During his four-city whirlwind tour, Francis will visit churches, meet with Iraq's top Shi'ite Muslim cleric, and travel to areas inaccessible to most foreign dignitaries, including the former Islamic State stronghold of Mosul. The visit aims to promote a fresh view of Iraq and foster greater understanding between the country's Christian and Muslim populations.

site_title: The Covid catapult is upending the status quo for women
summary:
The COVID-19 pandemic has led to significant progress for women in various areas, including corporate diversity, gender lens investing, women in tech, and women investors. Key trends include:

- Corporate diversity mandates: Goldman Sachs and Nasdaq have implemented policies requiring companies to have diverse boards, leading to an increase in women on boards.
- Gender lens funds: The number of funds investing through a gender lens has increased by 59% since 2019, with a growing focus on regions outside of North America.
- Women in tech: The pandemic has led to increased flexibility and reduced harassment, with women making up over 41% of applicants to tech jobs and 37% of new hires.
- Women investors: Online investing platforms have seen a surge in women signing up, with some platforms reporting a 366% increase in female investors since 2020.

These trends suggest that the pandemic has accelerated progress for women in various areas, leading to improved representation, increased investment, and reduced barriers to entry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.86 points to 1,600.12, closing higher on Friday. The index saw a trading volume of 7.978 billion lots worth RM5.149 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 617 to 561.

site_title: Pay increase of 3-14% for nurses and healthcare workers in public sector
summary: Singapore is offering a 3-14% pay increase to nurses and healthcare workers in the public sector, starting from July. This move aims to maintain salary competitiveness and attract and retain staff. Nurses will receive a 5-14% increase, while allied health professionals, pharmacists, and administrative staff will get a 3-7% increase. The government is also introducing changes to subsidy frameworks for inpatient care, specialist outpatient clinics, and community hospitals to make healthcare services more targeted and efficient.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower after volatile week
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a volatile week with a loss, falling 0.47% to 29,098.29. Optimism over vaccine rollouts and economic recovery was offset by concerns about inflation and interest rate hikes. The Shanghai Composite Index also fell marginally, while the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up. The decline was part of a broader market trend, with other Asian markets also experiencing volatility.

site_title: Powell statement causes markets to tank, STI drop 0.03%
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's statement on inflation sparked an overnight sell-off in US equities and bonds, causing the Straits Times Index to drop 0.03% to 3,013.85 points. Most regional markets declined, except Malaysia, while the US stock market also dropped. The sell-off was attributed to Powell's hint at a potential rise in inflation, which led to a decrease in investor confidence.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at the start of trading
summary: European stock markets fell at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.6% to 6,609.50 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices shedding 0.7% and 0.6% respectively. The losses followed overnight declines on Wall Street and Asian markets, amid concerns over inflation pressures fueled by surging oil prices. The decline in European markets came ahead of key US jobs data later Friday.

site_title: Women's clothes help protesters skirt Myanmar's junta
summary: Protesters in Myanmar have employed unconventional tactics to evade security forces, utilizing women's undergarments and long skirts, known as "longyis," to create makeshift barriers. According to traditional superstitions, these garments are believed to sap power from men, deterring soldiers from crossing them. This defensive strategy has been effective in halting security forces' progress, allowing protesters to continue their demonstrations. Over 50 civilians have been killed since the military coup on February 1, with the junta denying responsibility for the loss of life.

site_title: Singapore's healthcare spending is likely to continue rising; targeted support needed: Gan
summary: Singapore's healthcare spending is expected to continue rising due to an ageing population and increased healthcare consumption. Health Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for targeted support for those in greater need, with the government aiming to allocate resources more efficiently. The government plans to strengthen primary care, improve cost effectiveness, and leverage risk pooling to stretch Singaporeans' health dollar. The country is also making progress in its vaccination programme, with over 350,000 residents having received their first dose.

site_title: More than 6 in 10 in Singapore have high trust in banks here: ABS study
summary: More than 63% of Singapore residents have high trust in banks, according to a survey commissioned by the Association of Banks in Singapore. The survey found that banks' ability to offer various products, use innovative technologies, and handle customer data with integrity contributed to the high trust. However, areas for improvement include acknowledging mistakes and prioritizing customers' interests. The survey aims to monitor public sentiment and identify areas for improvement, with Monetary Authority of Singapore and banks expressing commitment to sustaining trust and raising standards of culture and conduct.

site_title: Australian broadcaster suspends China's CGTN citing human rights complaint
summary: Australia's public broadcaster SBS has suspended broadcasts of news bulletins from China's state-run television news services CGTN and CCTV following a human rights complaint from an organization. The suspension comes after Britain's media regulator revoked CGTN's license due to non-compliance with human rights standards. The complaint alleges CGTN broadcast the forced confessions of 56 prisoners between 2013 and 2020, and SBS will review the complaint while suspending the broadcasts. China's foreign ministry has urged relevant parties to "cast aside ideological prejudice" and protect Chinese media rights.

images.alt_text: Australian broadcaster SBS said on Friday it would suspend its broadcasts of news bulletins from Chinese state television news services CGTN and CCTV after receiving a human rights complaint.

site_title: Retail sales down 6.1% in January, but economists see domestic demand improving
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 6.1% year-on-year in January, a steeper decline than December's 3.3% fall. The decline was partly due to high sales in January 2020, when Chinese New Year was celebrated. Economists see signs of improving domestic demand, despite the low base effect from last year. The decline is in line with expectations, and year-on-year figures in upcoming months should be viewed in this context.

site_title: Bollywood, streaming giants on edge as Amazon gets flak for hurting religious beliefs
summary: Amazon's streaming service Prime Video is under scrutiny in India after its show "Tandav" sparked outrage over its depiction of Hindu gods and goddesses in a derogatory manner. The controversy led to police questioning Amazon India's head of original content, Aparna Purohit, who is now facing an anticipatory bail plea. In response, Amazon has delayed the release of a new season of "The Family Man" and is vetting content for potential offense. Bollywood directors and producers are also re-examining scripts to avoid hurting religious sentiments in the key growth market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on price concerns
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, extending a rout on Wall Street, where investors were disappointed by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's response to inflation fears. The Nikkei 225 index slid 0.23% and the Topix index fell 0.61%. This follows a decline in US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Pope Francis departs Rome for risky, historic Iraq tour
summary: Pope Francis departed Rome on a four-day trip to Iraq, marking his most risky foreign trip since 2012. Thousands of security personnel will accompany him to protect him from rocket and suicide bomb attacks. The pontiff will visit four cities, including Baghdad, Najaf, Mosul, and Ur, and meet with Iraq's top Shi'ite Muslim cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani. Despite opposition from some Shi'ite militant groups, many Iraqis hope the visit can foster a fresh view of the country, promoting peace and understanding.

images.alt_text: Pope Francis left Rome on Friday to start a four-day trip to Iraq, his most risky foreign trip since his election in 2012 and the first visit by a pontiff to the country.

summary: Singapore's Downtown Line's operator SBS Transit will review its financing framework. The city-state is set to reopen its borders safely using a four-pronged approach, including testing and vaccination measures. Healthcare spending is expected to continue rising, prompting calls for targeted support. Nurses and healthcare workers in the public sector will receive a 3-14% pay increase starting July. site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as bond yields rise on Powell's remarks
summary: Australian shares closed 0.7% lower on Friday, weighed down by mining and tech stocks, amid rising US bond yields. US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's comments failed to calm investors, who remain concerned about bond market volatility. Despite a weekly gain of 0.6%, the S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 6,710.8 points. Global miners BHP and Rio Tinto dropped 2.2% and 3.3%, respectively, as investors await reassurance from the Australian central bank on its bond-buying program.

site_title: US dollar ascendant as Powell stays dovish course; risk currencies slide
summary: The US dollar surged to three-month highs after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stuck to a dovish stance, despite recent bond market volatility. Powell's comments on the sell-off in Treasuries were seen as not disorderly, and he reiterated a commitment to maintaining ultra-easy monetary policy until the economy recovers. This led to a decline in riskier currencies, including the Australian and New Zealand dollars, and a rise in the US dollar index to 91.66.

images.alt_text: The US dollar held firmly near three-month highs on Friday after surging overnight as Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stuck with dovish rhetoric despite a recent spike in bond market volatility.

site_title: IHH Healthcare explores sale of education arm
summary: IHH Healthcare, Asia's largest hospital group, is exploring the sale of its medical education arm International Medical University (IMU) with the help of Rippledot Capital Advisers. A potential deal could fetch around $300 million. IMU, founded in 1992, offers various health programs and generated RM75.7 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization in 2020. The sale is part of IHH's strategy shift under CEO Kelvin Loh Chi-Keon, who focuses on extracting value from existing assets and divestments, following a series of acquisitions. A decision on the sale remains uncertain.

site_title: Yongnam wins five contracts in Singapore, Hong Kong totalling S$32.8m
summary: Yongnam Holdings has secured five contracts worth S$32.8 million in Singapore and Hong Kong, with four specialist civil engineering contracts. The contracts will contribute positively to the company's financial performance for the year ending Dec 31, 2021. In Singapore, Yongnam will supply structural steelwork for a new integrated services centre and retrofitting works to the Immigration & Checkpoints Authority Building, both set to be completed by 2022.

site_title: China's Parliament to delay Hong Kong legislative vote, overhaul electoral system
summary: China's Parliament is set to delay Hong Kong's legislative vote and overhaul the electoral system, a move that will likely reduce democratic representation in the city. The changes, which include increasing the size of a committee to select the leader and legislature, will be implemented in September 2022, aligning with Beijing's effort to ensure "patriots" are in charge of public institutions. The move is a significant blow to remaining democratic hopes in Hong Kong, where most high-profile pro-democracy politicians and activists are either in jail or in exile.

site_title: EMA seeks proposals for trial to import electricity from Malaysia
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) of Singapore is seeking proposals to import up to 100 megawatts of electricity from Malaysia via an existing undersea cable for a two-year trial. The trial aims to test technical and regulatory frameworks for importing electricity from the region, with a focus on low-carbon sources. Proposals must demonstrate supply reliability, credibility, and plans to manage carbon emissions. The trial is expected to begin as early as end-2021, following a joint venture announcement between Sunseap Group and Tenaga Nasional Berhad.

site_title: Japanese investors dump record amount of foreign bonds after surprise market rout
summary: Japanese investors sold a record 3.6 trillion yen ($44.49 billion) of foreign bonds in February, largely due to rising US bond yields. The sales, which cancelled out constant net buying since the start of the year, were prompted by inflation fears and a surprise market rout. US bond yields rose to a one-year high of 1.614% last month, prompting a sell-off, especially among short-term bonds. However, analysts expect buying to resume when the new financial year starts next month.

site_title: UBS pays new CEO US$4.5m in first four months
summary: UBS Group's new CEO Ralph Hamers earned a total of US$4.5 million in his first four months, exceeding his previous annual salary of about US$2.16 million at ING Group. This includes a fixed pay of 1.21 million francs (S$1.74 million) and variable compensation of 3 million francs. The news comes as UBS weathered the pandemic better than peers, with a 24% increase in the total bonus pool for employees to US$3.3 billion for 2020.

site_title: Widespread electricity cuts in Myanmar after system failure
summary: Widespread electricity cuts occurred in Myanmar on Friday due to a system failure, affecting cities such as Yangon and Naypyitaw. The power outage came after weeks of protests over the military coup on February 1, which has led to a civil disobedience campaign by state workers. The utility official attributed the outage to a system breakdown, stating it would be restored in the evening.

site_title: Green Li-ion raises US$3.45m in seed funding; aims to reach US$1b in sales
summary: Green Li-ion, a battery processor startup, has secured US$3.45 million in seed funding led by LiNiCo Corporation. This is the company's second funding round, following a pre-seed funding of US$400,000 in August 2020. The funds will be used for hardware developments, such as engineering and manufacturing support, with the goal of reaching US$1 billion in sales.

site_title: Singapore retail sales decline steepens to 6.1% in January, due partly to CNY timing
summary: Singapore's retail sales declined 6.1% year-on-year in January, with a 1.8% month-on-month drop, due in part to Chinese New Year celebrations in 2020 affecting sales in January 2021. Online sales accounted for 10.3% of total sales. Key industries saw varying growth rates, with furniture and household equipment seeing a 25.9% increase and recreational goods rising 7.3%. Conversely, food and alcohol sales plummeted 43.6% and department stores fell 36.1%.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares tumble at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.95% in the morning session, mirroring a drop on Wall Street and across Asia due to concerns over an expected global economic recovery fueling inflation. The Hang Seng Index sank to 28,667.14, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined by 1.15% and 1.50%, respectively. The decline was attributed to worries about inflation and global economic growth.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end at one-week low on rising US yields
summary: South Korean shares ended at a one-week low on Friday due to rising US Treasury yields and a decline in Wall Street. The Kospi index dropped 0.57% to 3,026.26, with tech giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix experiencing significant losses. The Korean won also weakened, and foreigners sold 368.7 billion won worth of shares. The benchmark 10-year US Treasury yield rose to 1.986%, contributing to the decline. Despite a weekly gain of 0.44%, the market remains cautious amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Australian court upholds landmark suit against Johnson & Johnson
summary: An Australian court upheld a landmark class-action lawsuit against Johnson & Johnson, finding the company guilty of "negligent" marketing of pelvic mesh implants, which caused serious side effects in thousands of women. The ruling allows thousands of women to seek compensation, with lawyers estimating claims could amount to hundreds of millions of dollars. The decision is part of a global trend, following similar rulings in the US, where Johnson & Johnson has paid millions in settlements for false marketing of pelvic mesh products.

site_title: Australia asks European Commission to review Italy's vaccine block
summary: Australia has asked the European Commission to review Italy's decision to block a shipment of 250,000 AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine doses. The decision comes as Italy, supported by the European Commission, cited AstraZeneca's failure to meet EU contract commitments. Australia, which has received 300,000 doses, has assured that the missing doses won't affect its inoculation program. The country's Prime Minister Scott Morrison understands Italy's concerns, citing the country's high death rate.

site_title: 'She is a hero': In Myanmar's protests, women are on the frontlines
summary: In Myanmar's protests against the military coup, women have taken the forefront, defying patriarchal norms and risking their lives. At least 30 people were killed, including 18-year-old Ma Kyal Sin, who was shot in the head while wearing a black T-shirt with the message "Everything will be OK." Women have been instrumental in organizing daily marches and flouting gender stereotypes, with some even hanging women's sarongs to protect protest zones. The military's brutal tactics have outraged human rights advocates worldwide, with the UN calling for an end to the violence.

site_title: Maritime R&D fund to raise co-funding to up to 70% after S$15m MPA top-up
summary: Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) will increase its co-funding support for maritime research and development (R&D) projects to up to 70% after adding S$15 million to the Maritime Innovation and Technology Fund. The fund now has S$100 million, supporting over 350 projects since its creation in 2003. The MPA aims to create a maritime tech hub, with a target of S$20 billion in business spending commitments and more than tripling the number of maritime tech startups supported by 2025. The fund will also support projects at Tuas Port, which will be fully operational in the early 2040s.

site_title: Singapore to reopen borders safely using four-pronged approach: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore plans to reopen its borders safely using a four-pronged approach, including testing travellers, bubble-wrapping, and reopening borders to controlled virus zones. The government expects some recovery in the aviation sector this year, with vaccinations being rolled out. The approach aims to adapt to a new normal and build confidence in Changi Airport as an international air hub. The city-state has already reopened borders to Australia, Brunei, China, and Hong Kong, and expects Air Travel Bubbles to play a key role in safe reopening.

site_title: China sets growth target of 'above 6%' for 2021
summary: China sets an economic growth target of "above 6%" for 2021, according to Premier Li Keqiang's speech at the country's annual legislative session. This marks a return to setting targets after officials avoided a specific target in 2020 due to the COVID-19 outbreak. Analysts predict China's economy will grow around 8-9% this year, with the government aiming to create over 11 million new urban jobs and keep a surveyed urban unemployment rate of around 5.5%. The budget deficit ratio is set at around 3.2%.

site_title: En bloc deals: Surrey Point sold for S$47.8m; Mt Emily Rd site fetches S$18m
summary: Two en bloc deals were announced in Singapore, marking the year's first collective sale. Amara Holdings acquired Surrey Point for S$47.8 million, with a land rate of S$1,434 psf ppr, while a trio of freehold residential properties at 2, 4, and 6 Mount Emily Road sold for S$18 million. Both deals reflect a strong interest in acquiring properties with value-added potential in prime locations. The en bloc market is expected to garner more interest in the first half of 2021, with over half of developers keen to replenish their land bank.

images.alt_text: Surrey Point (left) was sold to an Amara joint venture for S$47.8 million, while 2, 4 and 6 Mount Emily Road (right) changed hands for S$18 million in this year's first en bloc deal.

site_title: Australia: Shares skid as concerns over bond yields persist
summary: Australian shares fell 1.1% to 6,687.1, following a slump on Wall Street, as investors remained concerned about rising US bond yields. US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments did not address concerns about the Fed's asset purchases, despite expectations of increased purchases. Energy stocks outperformed, rising 3.1%, while technology stocks fell 3.5%. Despite this, the Australian benchmark was still on track to record modest gains for the week.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB downgrades EC World Reit to 'neutral' on lack of near-term catalysts
summary: RHB downgraded EC World Reit to "neutral" from "buy" due to a lack of near-term catalysts and limited upside to its target price of S$0.76. The Reit's occupancy rate and income have remained stable despite the pandemic, but rental growth has plateaued. Acquisitions are expected to be key drivers for the Reit, with a modest gearing of 38.1% providing S$175 million in debt headroom for acquisitions. RHB cut its FY2021-22 distribution per unit forecast by 7-8% due to lower payout ratio assumptions.

site_title: WHO scraps plan for interim report on Covid-19 probe
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has scrapped plans to issue an interim report on its investigation into the origins of the coronavirus pandemic, citing the need for a more detailed and comprehensive final report. The WHO team, led by scientist Peter Ben Embarek, visited Wuhan, China, but found no clear findings on the virus's genesis. The US has expressed "deep concerns" and pressed China for more information, with the US State Department calling for transparency from the Chinese government to better protect against future pandemic threats.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.03 points, or 0.2%, to 1,584.29 at 9:13 am on Friday. The index saw 769.4 million lots traded worth RM349.3 million. Losers outpaced gainers 391 to 216.

site_title: China military budget to grow 6.8% in 2021
summary: China's military budget is set to increase by 6.8% in 2021 to 1.36 trillion yuan (S$280.9 billion), with a focus on modernization and technological advancements. The growth rate is the highest since 2020, reflecting China's rising economic power and determination to underpin its strategic ambitions. Beijing aims to transform the People's Liberation Army into a world-class force by 2050, with costs expected to "skyrocket" due to the push for technologically advanced equipment.

site_title: China ramps up tech commitment in five-year plan, eyes 7% boost in R&D spend
summary: China has increased its annual research and development spending by over 7% every year for the next five years, with a focus on advancing in the tech sector. The country aims to boost spending on seven key areas, including next-generation artificial intelligence, quantum information, and biotechnology. China also plans to establish more national laboratories, improve domestic companies' access to public markets, and support foreign-funded companies setting up R&D centers in China. The government aims to achieve 56% 5G penetration in the next five years, with a focus on advancing its tech sector and competing with the US and other countries.

site_title: Hang Seng overhaul will bring flow of funds to these stocks
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index is set to overhaul, expanding to 80 stocks by mid-2022, with consumer and healthcare firms expected to see significant improvements in sector representation. Goldman Sachs and CGS-CIMB Securities International predict at least double market cap coverage for these sectors. Smoore International Holdings, Kuaishou Technology, and JD Health International are among the companies poised for inclusion in the coming quarterly reviews. This change is expected to bring a flow of funds to these stocks, potentially benefiting investors.

site_title: Japan to extend Tokyo area state of emergency to March 21
summary: The Japanese government plans to extend the state of emergency in Tokyo and its surrounding prefectures until March 21, two weeks beyond the original scheduled end date of March 7. The extension aims to combat rising COVID-19 cases in the region, where new cases have not decreased enough to meet targets. The current curbs, including restaurant closures and restrictions on gatherings, will be maintained, and foreign athletes barred from entering Japan to train for the Tokyo Olympics may face an extension of the ban.

images.alt_text: The Japanese government plans to extend a state of emergency to combat Covid-19 for Tokyo and three neighbouring prefectures until March 21, two weeks longer than originally scheduled, Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura said on Friday.

site_title: GIC-backed Bank Jago races to upend mobile banking in Indonesia
summary: Bank Jago, backed by Singapore's GIC, is racing to become a leading digital bank in Indonesia by offering mobile banking services and partnering with ride-hailing giant Gojek. The lender plans to expand its services to include loans and embed its services on Gojek's platform this year. With Gojek's 70 million users, Bank Jago aims to become the first technology-based lender catering to the masses in Indonesia, one of the most underbanked markets in Asia. The bank's market value has soared to $8.4 billion, driven by its recent investment and high growth expectations.

site_title: Ascendas India Trust to buy industrial facility in Chennai for 2.11b rupees
summary: Ascendas India Trust (a-iTrust) announced the proposed acquisition of an industrial facility in Chennai for 2.11 billion rupees (S$38.3 million). The estimated completion is by mid-year, adding 0.04 cents to FY2020 distribution per unit. The facility, 0.42 million sq ft, is fully pre-leased to Pegatron Technology India. This acquisition will diversify a-iTrust's portfolio, bringing its total portfolio size to approximately 23.2 million sq ft, a 1.9% increase.

site_title: Hot stock: HGH down 14.3%, gets SGX query
summary: HGH Holdings' shares plummet 14.3% to 1.2 Singapore cents, prompting an SGX query on "unusual volume movements". The trading activity, worth S$1.5 million, occurred despite no announced information or rumors. The company's shares had risen since Wednesday, reaching a one-year high of 1.4 cents on Thursday before the decline. HGH is a manufacturer of concrete, cement, and plaster, and listed on the Catalist board in 2005.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Ascendas India Trust, GL, KIT
summary: Singapore Airlines shares closed 1.2% lower after a cyber attack compromised frequent flyer programme information. Ascendas India Trust proposed the acquisition of an industrial facility for about S$38.3 million, potentially adding to its FY2020 distribution per unit. Guoco Leisure Holdings extended the closing date for its voluntary offer to take GL private until March 18. Keppel Infrastructure Trust appointed an independent non-executive director, while Penguin International's mandatory offer turned unconditional with 50.29% shares accepted. MC Payment called for a trading halt pending an announcement.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending a global market downturn. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.7% and the Topix index slipped 0.4%. The decline follows disappointing comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell on inflation fears. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, extending a rout on Wall Street, where investors were disappointed by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's response to inflation fears.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop as treasury yields rise on Powell's response
summary: Asian stocks fell as US treasury yields rose after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell refrained from intervening in the bond market. The S&P 500 erased nearly all its 2021 gains, with the Nasdaq 100 extending losses to almost 10% from February's high. Oil prices jumped after Opec+ announced no output change, while the US dollar strengthened, pushing the yen to an eight-month low. The US Senate voted to take up a $1.9 trillion relief bill, and China's National People's Congress began its annual review.

site_title: Gold crumbles under rising yields, US dollar; hits nine-month low
summary: Gold prices fell to a near nine-month low, dropping 0.9% to $1,695.26 per ounce, amid rising US Treasury yields and the US dollar. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments on no immediate action to address bond yields pressured the market. Analysts predict gold prices may continue to decline, with the ETF liquidation and increased opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion contributing to the decline.

site_title: TPG Capital considering IPO plan for Asian pathology business
summary: TPG Capital Asia is considering an initial public offering for its pathology business, Pathology Asia Holdings, valued at approximately US$2 billion. The company has asked banks to submit proposals for a potential listing in Singapore, among other options. TPG acquired the business in 2018 for A$279 million and has since expanded its operations. The IPO plan is still in the early stages, with the company weighing a listing venue.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks hit one-month low as Powell comments push yields higher
summary: South Korean stocks hit a one-month low on Friday, falling 1.4% to 3,001.59, amid rising US Treasury yields and a disappointing Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments. The won weakened while the benchmark bond yield rose to 2.012%. Heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix declined 0.9% and 2.5%, respectively. Foreigners were net sellers of 371.2 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi index is poised for a weekly gain of 0.2%.

site_title: Australia house prices to rise 10% in 2021, risks ahead, Goldman says
summary: Australian house prices are expected to rise 10% in 2021 due to low interest rates and improved sentiment, according to Goldman Sachs Group. The forecast assumes normalizing immigration and the Reserve Bank not hiking interest rates until 2024. However, prolonged border restrictions or earlier-than-expected rate hikes pose downside risks. Goldman predicts house prices will rise 5% in 2022 and 3% in 2023. The housing industry's contribution to annual GDP is expected to be around 1 percentage point over the next few years.

site_title: Apple faces EU charges over Spotify complaint: sources
summary: Apple may face EU antitrust charges over a complaint by Spotify, with the European Commission set to issue a statement of objections before summer. The case stems from Spotify's claim that Apple unfairly restricts rivals to its own music streaming service and charges 30% fees on app developers. This is part of a larger investigation by the EU into Apple's App Stores rules and terms for competing apps, e-books, and audio books. The European Commission declined to comment, but the UK competition watchdog has opened an investigation into Apple's practices.

site_title: Singapore court grants oil trader GP Global Apac debt moratorium
summary: The Singapore High Court has granted GP Global Apac, a unit of oil trader GP Global, a six-month debt moratorium worth over US$1 billion, allowing its parent company to restructure its debt. The moratorium will prevent creditors from pursuing independent legal actions, enabling GP Apac to sell its assets and resume restructuring efforts. The Singapore unit owes over US$464 million to its top 20 unsecured creditors, while its parent has total liabilities of over US$1.2 billion. The court order also prevents the seizure of GP's Singapore office to recoup claims.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as miners and tech are pressured by firmer yields
summary: European stocks closed 0.4% lower on Thursday, led by miners and technology stocks, as firmer US bond yields and inflation concerns pressured risk appetite. Heavyweight miners Rio Tinto and BHP Group fell 7.7% and 5.8%, respectively. Technology stocks dropped 3.3% due to a global semiconductor shortage. The Stoxx 600 has yet to reach pre-pandemic highs, and market participants are awaiting comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes lower, battered by price concerns
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 2.1% and the S&P 500 dropping 1.3%, amid concerns over inflation. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech failed to alleviate investor worries, with the yield on 10-year US Treasury notes spiking to 1.55%, a record high. The Nasdaq is now nearly 10% below its peak, and markets are concerned about rising borrowing costs and potential interest rate hikes.

site_title: Oil scales one-year peak as Opec+ rolls over output for April
summary: Oil prices reached a one-year peak after Opec+ announced it would keep production unchanged in April, citing fragile demand recovery from the coronavirus pandemic. Brent crude rose 4.2% to $66.74 a barrel, while US crude futures increased 4.2% to $63.83 a barrel. The decision was seen as a surprise, with some analysts predicting an increase in output. Russia is set to boost output by 150,000 barrels per day, while the US is expected to increase production due to high prices. The decision is expected to reduce inventory overhang.

site_title: Australia's AstraZeneca vaccines blocked by Italy under new rule
summary: Italy has blocked a shipment of AstraZeneca's coronavirus vaccine to Australia under a new EU regulation requiring export transparency. The 250,700 doses were blocked due to vaccine scarcity in Europe and supply delays. This move is seen as a symbolic gesture by Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi to be tougher on pharmaceuticals that don't respect delivery commitments. The decision may trigger a global backlash and raise concerns about EU protectionism, particularly as countries rush to immunize their populations amid growing concerns over fast-spreading coronavirus variants.

site_title: Technology shifts that enhance board governance in the hybrid era
summary: In the hybrid era of corporate governance, technological advancements will significantly enhance board governance. Key shifts include unified collaboration platforms for healthier board dynamics, data lakes and artificial intelligence for real-time insights and informed decision-making. Hybrid AGMs will combine in-person and virtual meetings, allowing for robust engagement with retail shareholders. Blockchain technology may overcome data security concerns, enabling more transparent and real-time decision-making. These technologies will strengthen connectivity, improve meeting efficiency, and increase engagement with stakeholders, ultimately leading to improved board governance and better decision-making.

site_title: Nintendo plans Switch model with bigger Samsung OLED display
summary: Nintendo plans to release a Switch model with a bigger Samsung OLED display, aiming to boost holiday demand. The new console will feature a 7-inch, 720p-resolution display, with Samsung starting mass production in June with an initial target of 700,000 units. This move is seen as a response to declining Switch sales.

site_title: Obesity a driving factor in Covid-19 deaths, global report finds
summary: A global study found that 90% of Covid-19 deaths, or 2.2 million, occurred in countries with high obesity rates, with fatality rates 10 times higher in nations with at least 50% of adults overweight. Countries with low obesity rates, such as Japan and South Korea, had low Covid-19 death rates. Experts recommend recognizing obesity as a key Covid-19 health risk and prioritizing vaccination for those with obesity. The US and UK have high Covid-19 death rates and obesity levels, with the UK having the world's third-highest death rate and the US having the fourth-highest.

site_title: Fed chairman Powell sends dovish message that leaves bond market disappointed
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell sent a dovish message to the bond market, warning of potential disorderly conditions and persistent tightening, but stopped short of reining in long-term interest rates. Despite this, bond yields rose, and the stock market fell, with some traders disappointed that Powell didn't provide specifics on how the Fed could address the issue. Powell emphasized that the Fed's current policy stance is appropriate and that it will be patient in achieving its economic goals, with an increase in interest rates unlikely in the near term.

site_title: Hong Kong turns empty hotels into apartments as tourists vanish
summary: Hong Kong hotels are being repurposed into residential developments as the city's tourism industry struggles to recover from the pandemic. Property developers, including CK Asset Holdings, and the government are converting hotels into apartments to address the shortage of housing. The government has allocated HK$95 million to subsidize 800 hotel rooms for local families, while developers are planning to convert hotels into over 5,000 homes. The trend aims to provide transitional housing for eligible residents awaiting public housing apartments, addressing the demand for affordable housing in the city.

images.alt_text: Hotels in Hong Kong are being transformed into residential developments to satisfy housing demand as the pandemic-hit tourism industry shows no signs of recovery.

site_title: US adds Myanmar ministries, military businesses to trade blacklist
summary: The US has added Myanmar's ministries of defence and home affairs, as well as its top military conglomerates, to a trade blacklist. The move aims to punish the military for its February coup, which overthrew the country's elected government. At least 54 people have been killed and over 1,700 arrested in the crackdown. The US has also imposed 'military end use' export control restrictions, requiring US suppliers to seek licences to ship certain items to Myanmar. The actions are in response to the escalating violence and protests against the military takeover.

site_title: Malls may bank on resilient retail categories
summary: Malls are expected to focus on resilient retail categories that have outperformed during the pandemic, according to data from NUS' IREUS. These categories, such as grocery stores, pharmacies, and dining establishments, have shown strong sales despite the economic downturn. In contrast, non-essential retail categories like clothing and electronics have struggled. By adapting their retail mix, shopping malls can increase their chances of success in the post-pandemic market.

site_title: Apex court criticises Nicky Tan, lawyers from Rajah & Tann and Tan Kok Quan
summary: Singapore's apex court criticizes liquidator Nicky Tan and lawyers from Rajah & Tann and Tan Kok Quan for misleading judges and wasting court time. They were appointed as court-appointed liquidators of Sembawang Engineers and Constructors and proceeded with an appeal despite reaching a settlement, failing to disclose this information. The court's written grounds of decision criticized the actions, stating they were "totally wasted" and "misleading".

site_title: Maxus e-Deliver 3 review: No more fueling around
summary: The Maxus e-Deliver 3, an all-electric van from Chinese brand Maxus, offers significant savings on fuel costs, with a potential annual savings of $2,647 compared to a diesel van and $7,388 compared to a petrol van. The new Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme (CVES) in Singapore provides a rebate of up to $30,000, spread over three years, making the van even more affordable. With a range of 240km and fast charging capabilities, the Maxus is well-suited for commercial use, offering a unique blend of performance, cargo space, and sustainability.

site_title: Sias reminds unitholders of Soilbuild Reit to take action
summary: Sias reminds unitholders of Soilbuild Reit to vote on a proposed privatisation offer from Blackstone Real Estate and Lim Chap Huat, the executive chairman of Soilbuild Group, by March 11. The offer, via a trust scheme of arrangement, aims to address the Reit's high yield hindering growth through yield-accretive acquisitions. Unitholders will receive S$0.53806 per unit, a 49.9% premium to the 6-month volume weighted average price, and a 0.99-time the Reit's net asset value.

site_title: US dollar holds gains ahead of Fed chief's speech
summary: The US dollar maintained its gains against a basket of peers ahead of Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech, which may influence global bond markets and currencies. The dollar reached a five-month high against the Swiss franc and a seven-month high against the Japanese yen, while holding gains against most currencies. A renewed calm in the Treasury market supported the dollar's rise.

site_title: Asia's ultra-rich are piling investments into blank-cheque firms
summary: Asia's ultra-rich are investing heavily in blank-cheque firms, known as SPACs, amid low interest rates. Family offices and wealthy individuals are seeking alternative investment channels, with some reporting a spike in interest from private wealth. SPACs raise funds, then look to acquire businesses within two years, with investors potentially redeeming their investment at the IPO price if they fail to find a target. The trend is expected to continue, with Hong Kong and Singapore exploring SPAC listings, and the US dominating the market.

site_title: The complicated web of electric cars
summary: Singapore takes decisive steps towards a future of electric cars with full government support and policy moves. However, there's a need for caution due to the environmental impact of electric vehicles, which is yet to be fully understood. Experts emphasize the importance of sustainable change and innovation in addressing the challenges of renewable energy and the role of women in driving business opportunities.

site_title: Xero to buy workforce management platform Planday in largest acquisition yet
summary: Xero is acquiring Planday, a workforce management platform, for 183.5 million euros (S$294.7 million), its largest acquisition to date. The deal is expected to be completed in the first quarter of Xero's financial year ending March 31, 2022. Planday's platform simplifies employee scheduling, allowing businesses to forecast and manage labor costs. The acquisition aims to expand Xero's offerings in the cloud-based accounting and workforce management space.

site_title: Storming her way ahead
summary: Debbie Lee, CEO and founder of TechStorm, is a tech-entrepreneur who turned down two high-paying jobs to pursue her startup idea, despite being a minority in the industry. She is one of four women featured on International Women's Day, showcasing their trailblazing efforts.

site_title: Mandatory offer for Penguin turns unconditional; closing date extended
summary: A mandatory offer for Penguin International has turned unconditional, with valid acceptances and total shares owned reaching 50.29% as of March 4. The offer, previously set to close on March 10, will now remain open until March 24 or a later date. The offeror, a consortium led by Penguin's executive chairman Jeffrey Hing, is offering S$0.65 per share. The extension ensures compliance with a 14-day rule after the original closing date.

site_title: Timing the market
summary: Sherrie Han, a 29-year-old lawyer and watchmaker, founded The Eliana Timekeeper, a boutique women's watch company that offers affordable mechanical watches. Han, one of few women watchmakers, aims to introduce young women to the beauty and complexity of mechanical watches. Her company's first collection, The Twilight Glint, features three 28mm automatic watches with a Miyota movement and retails between $588 and $590. Despite initial plans to target women, most customers are men purchasing elegant watches for their partners, with Han's watches selling out quickly.

site_title: McKinsey is becoming an MBA case study in crisis
summary: McKinsey & Co's global managing partner, Kevin Sneader, will not serve a second term after failing to secure sufficient support during the firm's ongoing referendum on leadership. This move comes amid ongoing scrutiny over McKinsey's past work with Purdue Pharma, which advised on how to increase sales of highly addictive painkillers, and the firm's role in the opioid crisis. The change in leadership may mark a show of accountability and offer a chance to reset the firm's culture, following a $600 million settlement to end litigation brought by US states.

site_title: Sands' Sin City sale might fund pivot to Australia
summary: LAS Vegas Sands is considering selling its Las Vegas assets, potentially funding a pivot to Australia, after securing a $6.3 billion sale. The company's Asian empire, including Crown Resorts, could benefit from the sale, which would be valued at 13 times Ebitda for 2019. This is more attractive than other opportunities, including James Packer's Crown Resorts, which is valued around 8 times Ebitda. Sands' focus on non-gaming operations and high standards in regulatory environments makes it a more appealing option for Australian watchdogs.

site_title: Asia hedge funds pare bets on green energy after 2020 surge
summary: Asia's hedge funds are reducing bets on green energy after last year's surge, citing lofty valuations. Despite long-term optimism, valuations for electric vehicle (EV) makers and suppliers have become stretched, with Tesla's stock price tumbling 22% and Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) losing 14% since January. Funds are shifting focus to parts suppliers with large global market share and alternative green investments, such as uranium, to mitigate concerns about overvaluation.

site_title: Coastal-protection measures to be carried out in phases
summary: Singapore's Sustainability and Environment Minister Grace Fu announced the government's plan to implement coastal-protection measures in phases, focusing on the most vulnerable parts of the country's coastlines to combat rising sea levels and inland flood risks.

site_title: Ferrari Roma review: Roman conquest
summary: Ferrari's Roma, priced at S$888,000, is the brand's cheapest coupe, offering a balance of elegance and explosive driving dynamics. The 3.8L twin-turbo V8 engine produces 620 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100km/h in 3.4 seconds. The Roma features a more classic design, plush interior, and advanced digital features, while maintaining Ferrari's "eyes on the road, hands on the wheel" philosophy. The Roma is positioned to compete with rivals like Mercedes-AMG and Porsche, with a price that keeps it in the six-figure range.

site_title: Empty buildings squeeze city budgets as property values fall
summary: US cities face a fiscal time bomb due to the decline in commercial property values, with empty buildings and malls foreshadowing a 10% revenue loss in 2021. The pandemic has led to a sharp decline in office and retail values, with the US$16 trillion commercial property sector being stressed. Municipal budgets, which rely heavily on property taxes, are expected to face significant losses, with cities like New York and Texas warning of cuts to services and jobs. Lawmakers are negotiating a stimulus package that could provide up to $350 billion to states and cities, but Republicans are objecting to significant aid, citing states' financial stability.

site_title: Adopt US SPAC rules - but with tweaks for Singapore, say observers
summary: Singapore is considering adopting rules for special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) similar to those in the US, with the goal of attracting more foreign listings. Industry players say the US model has proven effective, but with small adjustments to improve it. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) aims to admit SPACs for listing this year, despite concerns about the risks and speculative nature of the vehicles. Regulators must strike a balance between protecting investors and allowing deals to happen, with some experts suggesting transparency on SPAC sponsors and specific sector focus could be key to success.

site_title: Accepting the challenge of gender equality
summary: Citi marks International Women's Day with the appointment of its first female CEO, Jane Fraser, as part of its commitment to gender equality. The bank has made progress in increasing female representation and pay equity, with median pay for women now at 74% of median pay for men. However, Citi recognizes that more work is needed to achieve full gender equality, particularly in light of the current global crisis that may threaten to reverse progress. The bank emphasizes the importance of transparency, accountability, and support for employees, particularly women, to push forward towards a more gender-equal world.

site_title: Investors look to Fed for next steps amid Twist speculation
summary: Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's next move amid a recent bond sell-off, with many considering it a high bar for the US central bank to take action. Despite a rise in bond yields, the Fed is unlikely to intervene unless necessary, as real yields remain low and financial conditions remain unchanged. The "Twist" maneuver, used to lower long-term rates, is seen as an optimal solution but may not be necessary at this time. Powell's comments at a Wall Street Journal conference on Thursday are closely watched for any hints of concern about the market.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund puts Japan's Kirin on watch list
summary: The Norwegian sovereign wealth fund has put Japan's Kirin Holdings on a watch list for possible exclusion due to its business ties to Myanmar's military. Kirin announced it will end its partnership with a company run by the army after a military coup. The fund will monitor Kirin's plan to terminate the ties, which effectively scrap a joint venture valued at up to $1.7 billion. Kirin aims to continue selling beer in Myanmar while ending its partnership with the Myanmar military.

site_title: Records of a disruptive era
summary: Artist Heman Chong's solo show at STPI captures the complexities of the modern era through his "Circuit Breaker Paintings" and other works, which respond to the COVID-19 pandemic and contemporary issues. Chong destroyed 56 paintings during the 2020 circuit breaker period, reworking them into new images. His works, such as "Safe Entry" and "Foreign Affairs," use QR codes, empty spaces, and other symbols to critique systems of power and control. The show runs until April 18, offering a poignant record of our "strange times."

site_title: Lufthansa counting on vaccine rollout after US$8.1b loss
summary: Lufthansa, Europe's largest airline group, reported a record annual loss of 6.7 billion euros ($10.7 billion) due to the ongoing coronavirus crisis. The airline expects to deploy 40-50% of its 2019 capacity levels this year, down from a previous target of 40-60%. CEO Carsten Spohr believes a successful vaccine rollout will be crucial to reviving air travel, with international curbs easing as vaccination rates increase. Lufthansa may operate only 90% of its pre-pandemic capacity by mid-decade, a significant decline from its previous estimate of full recovery by 2024.

site_title: Sake and izakaya at Sakemaru
summary: Sakemaru Artisan Sake Hideout, a Japanese restaurant in Singapore, offers a casual dining experience with a focus on artisanal sake. The izakaya-style restaurant, started as an online sake subscription service, features a no-frills atmosphere with bright blue wall tiles and mismatched crockery. Chef Daisuke Yomogi's omakase menu showcases a variety of dishes, including seasonal firefly squid and grilled tuna collar, with a focus on detail and effort despite some delays due to understaffing. The restaurant has a promising start, with a good intentions and variety to keep interest, earning a rating of 6.5.

site_title: GIC cashes in on Taiwan stock boom: sources
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC sold Taiwan stocks last week, cashing in on the island's booming bourse. Taiwan's benchmark stock index has risen 8% this year, driven by its surging economy and strong demand for technology goods during the pandemic. GIC's move comes as foreign investors sold NT$222.7 billion in Taiwan stocks, while purchasing NT$128.3 billion, resulting in a net difference of NT$94.4 billion. The fund cited regular rebalancing activities, but sources suggest sovereign wealth funds view Taiwan stocks as a "safe haven" during the pandemic.

site_title: Take on more risk or taper? BOJ faces tough choice with Reit buying
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) faces a challenge in sustaining its massive stimulus program due to its Reit buying rules. The central bank may reconsider its current limit of 10% ownership in individual Reits, as nearly a third of its holdings approach this threshold. A review of policy tools at the BOJ's March 18-19 meeting could lead to a potential relaxation of the rules to maintain its current buying pace. This decision could impact the BOJ's ability to support the Japanese economy.

site_title: From singing to retail
summary: Singer-songwriter Sarah Cheng-De Winne, founder of Taizjo, a homegrown brand of phone slings, is a trailblazer entrepreneur. Since 2019, she has successfully launched her retail business alongside her husband, despite personal challenges, including the miscarriage of their third child. Cheng-De Winne's experience has taught her the importance of adaptability, perseverance, and staying connected to different industries. She is now expanding Taizjo to include design-led accessories that empower work, home, and play, and is set to release a new single inspired by her entrepreneurial journey.

site_title: Pandemics and the paradox of human progress
summary: A 1962 prediction by Australian virologist Sir Frank Macfarlane Burnet that infectious diseases had been virtually eliminated proved incorrect. Covid-19 is likely the third coronavirus to jump from bats to humans since 2002, following Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome and Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. The emergence of new infectious diseases has increased, with 335 new diseases emerging between 1940 and 2004, 72% of which came from wildlife. The paradox of progress, where human advances increase the risk of pandemics, is a concern. The author suggests that halting the destruction of nature, regulating markets, investing in early warning systems, and producing vaccines are necessary to mitigate this risk.

site_title: Sunak's UK Budget strategy: first boost growth, then raise taxes
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak's budget strategy involves boosting economic growth first, followed by a sharp hike in corporate tax during the recovery phase. This plan has been criticized by conservatives, who oppose the tax increase. Sunak's immediate priorities include supporting those hardest hit by the pandemic, such as extending furlough and offering business grants. The UK economy has already shrunk for the second month, adding to the pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Former Ferrari dealer charges into a surprising new business
summary: A Singaporean father-son duo, Alfred and Edward Tan, have launched Hong Seh Evolution (HSEV) to focus on electric vehicles, particularly the BYD T3 electric van. The T3 offers a range of 300km and can save commercial operators up to S$40,000 over 10 years compared to diesel or petrol vans. The new incentive scheme, the Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme, will lower the cost of buying the T3 by S$30,000. Despite their background in luxury car sales, the Tans are optimistic about the prospects of electric vans, citing their smooth acceleration, silent operation, and lower operating costs.

site_title: 7.2 magnitude earthquake shakes New Zealand, tsunami warning issued
summary: A 7.2 magnitude earthquake struck off New Zealand's North Island, prompting a tsunami warning. The quake's epicentre is 300 km from the coast, with waves possible within that area. Authorities advised people in coastal areas to move to high ground immediately. No immediate damage reports were provided. The quake was felt by over 60,000 people, with some describing the shaking as severe or extreme.

site_title: Dependant's Pass moves could hurt startups, limit talent
summary: Singapore's plans to require Dependant's Pass (DP) holders to obtain work passes by May 1 may disproportionately affect startups, as they often hire dependants on Letter of Consent (LOCs) who form a small percentage of work pass holders. Experts worry that this change could limit talent, hurt startups, and dampen openness to foreign talent, potentially leading to job losses in the long term. The policy change may also discourage professionals from relocating to Singapore, further exacerbating workforce shortages.

site_title: Singapore-listed tech manufacturers may benefit from global chip shortage
summary: Singapore-listed tech manufacturers may benefit from the global chip shortage due to rapid adoption of technology. However, tighter supply capacity could hinder potential gains. Shares of chip makers in Asia have surged as they scramble to meet orders from the electronics and automotive industries, driven by pandemic-driven trends such as remote working. Analysts expect these companies to benefit from the shortage, despite potential supply constraints.

site_title: Singapore to stop registration of diesel cars and taxis from 2025
summary: Singapore will stop new registrations of diesel cars and taxis from 2025, with all new car and taxi registrations to be of cleaner-energy models from 2030. This move aims to reduce the country's carbon footprint. The decision, made by Minister for Transport Ong Ye Kung, comes five years earlier than the previously targeted 2030 deadline. Fleet operators seem unsurprised by the announcement, indicating a growing acceptance of cleaner-energy vehicles in the industry.

site_title: Pandemic to shape Singapore's land use plans amid ongoing review: Indranee Rajah
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing the country's long-term land-use plans, influenced by the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The review aims to incorporate changing trends and emerging insights, including the shift towards e-commerce and telecommuting. The government will factor in these changes through incentives such as the CBD Incentive scheme and Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) scheme, which encourage mixed-use developments and community co-working spaces. The review will engage the public, private, and people sectors to gather feedback and ensure sustainable development for future generations.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust appointed Susan Chong, founder of Greenpac, as an independent non-executive director. Boustead Projects launched its first scalable private business trust, Boustead Industrial Fund (BIF), acquiring 14 properties valued at S$511.3 million. The trust raised S$328.4 million, with funds used to discharge loans, subscribe units, and fund expansion plans. This move allowed Boustead Projects to recycle capital and reduce its borrowings.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust manager appoints Greenpac founder to its board
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's trustee-manager has appointed Susan Chong, founder of Greenpac, as an independent non-executive director. Chong brings decades of experience in entrepreneurship and sustainable practices to the board. Her appointment takes effect from March 5 and is seen as a move to broaden and strengthen the board's competencies. Chong currently sits on several boards, including the National Environment Agency and Singapore Institute of Management, and has received awards for her entrepreneurial achievements.

site_title: So ancient, yet so new: gorgeous red wines from Greece
summary: Greece's red wines have gained global recognition in the past 20 years, with many emerging from lesser-known regions. The article highlights 12 gorgeous Greek red wines, including xinomavro, agiorgitiko, and mavrodaphne, which offer unique flavor profiles and aging potential. From affordable options like Gaia Peloponnese Monograph Agiorgitiko ($14) to premium bottles like Domaine Vaimaki Mater Natura 4 Xinomavro ($40), these wines showcase Greece's diverse wine-making capabilities. With their rich flavors and affordable prices, Greek red wines are now easily accessible to global consumers, offering a new perspective on the country's ancient wine tradition.

site_title: Last hurrah for Triple Three
summary: Mandarin Orchard Singapore's restaurant, Triple Three, is set to close due to a new dining concept. The restaurant, known for its Japanese-inspired international buffet, will offer dinner specials before its closure. The daily dinner delights feature exclusive highlights on the buffet spread, including fresh sashimi and sushi, seafood on ice, and live cooking stations. The closure marks the end of an era for the stalwart restaurant, which has delighted diners for years.

site_title: Push for greener buildings under refreshed masterplan
summary: Singapore has set new sustainability targets for its green buildings, aiming for 80% of new buildings to be Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings by 2030. The government plans to raise energy performance standards, with minimum energy efficiency levels set to increase to 50% and 40% for new and existing buildings, respectively. Additionally, the government will enhance support for industry alliances to drive transformation in the built environment sector through technologies like Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DfMA) and Integrated Digital Delivery.

site_title: A ballet on the wrist
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels' latest Poetic Complications collection features the Lady Arpels Ballerine Musicale, a three-piece set of watches paying homage to ballet. Inspired by the 1960s ballet "Jewels" choreographed by George Balanchine, the timepieces incorporate a carillon and music box to reproduce melodies from the ballet. Each watch has a unique color scheme and design, with a retrograde indicator and a star displaying the passage of time. The watches also feature on-demand animation of ballerinas dancing to the music, and come with a price tag of S$660,000.

images.alt_text: Balanchine's Jewels - Lady Arpels Ballerine Musicale Emeraude with its green tones, Rubis in red and Diamant in a combination of white, blue and golden hues. Each timepiece is conceived as a three-dimensional tableaux of an actual theatre stage.

site_title: The serial entrepreneur
summary: Cassandra Riene Tan, a 32-year-old serial entrepreneur, has built three businesses, including The Ritual Café Bar, Botany, and Bitsy. Born into a family of entrepreneurs, Tan's exposure to the business landscape has shaped her into a resilient and adaptable individual. She initially worked in advertising before starting Bitsy, a tech startup that connects business owners to short-term spaces. Tan's F&B ventures, Dazzling Cafe and Botany, have been successful, and she recently launched The Ritual, a community cafe and bar focusing on holistic wellness. Tan attributes her success to identifying gaps in the market, building a strong team, and fostering good relationships.

site_title: Thailand speeds up plans to reopen borders after taming coronavirus wave
summary: Thailand accelerates its plan to reopen its borders as the country continues to manage the COVID-19 pandemic. The government has rolled out a national inoculation program and is exploring coronavirus vaccine passports and quarantine waivers. The tourism industry, which accounts for about 20% of Thailand's GDP, is pushing for the lifting of mandatory quarantines for vaccinated visitors as early as July 1. A successful reopening could spur other tourism-dependent nations to follow suit, but the World Health Organization warns of the risks of easing restrictions too quickly.

site_title: Novartis deal bolsters CureVac's vaccine contractor line-up
summary: German biotech firm CureVac has partnered with Swiss pharma giant Novartis to manufacture its experimental Covid-19 vaccine, boosting its contract manufacturer network ahead of trial results. Novartis will produce mRNA molecules and bulk drug product for up to 250 million doses by 2022. The deal adds Novartis to a list of CureVac contractors, including Bayer and GlaxoSmithKline, and is expected to start delivering doses in summer 2021. CureVac aims to produce up to 300 million doses in 2021 and 600-1 billion doses in 2022.

site_title: US: Stocks fall, eyeing inflation, Opec
summary: US stocks fell in early trading, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 down 0.3% and 0.8% respectively, amid concerns over inflation and interest rate increases. Investors are watching the Opec oil producers' meeting to cut output and Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's appearance, which is expected to reassure on no interest rate hikes. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index fell 1.6% after a sharp decline in the prior session.

site_title: Billionaire Premji makes his biggest purchase with Capco
summary: Billionaire Premji's company Wipro agreed to acquire London-based Capco for $1.45 billion, its largest purchase to boost growth. Capco, employing 5,000 consultants, will help Wipro gain banking, insurance, and financial services clients. The deal is expected to close by June 30 and will add 30 new clients. The purchase is expected to dilute Wipro's margins by 2% in the first year, but is expected to improve due to revenue and cost synergies.

site_title: ByteDance developing Clubhouse-like app for China amid copycat rush
summary: ByteDance, owner of TikTok, is developing a Clubhouse-like app for China amid a surge of copycats in the country. Plans are still in early stages, but at least a dozen similar apps have been launched in the past month, including Xiaomi's Mi Talk. The apps will cater to Chinese users, incorporating censorship and government oversight. ByteDance's CEO Zhang Yiming has expressed interest in the genre, prompting the development of the new app, which is expected to offer features such as real name registration and AI-powered content moderation.

images.alt_text: Discussions about TikTok and ByteDance on Clubhouse have prompted interest in the genre from ByteDance executives including CEO Zhang Yiming, according to one of the sources.

site_title: China's Parliament to discuss Hong Kong electoral reform
summary: China's National People's Congress will discuss electoral reform in Hong Kong, amid speculation that Beijing will tighten control over the financial hub. The draft decision aims to "improve the electoral system" and may involve removing seats from local-level district councils. The move is seen as an attempt to limit the influence of "staunch patriots" and opposition candidates, who have been critical of Beijing's tightening grip on the territory. The changes could further erode Hong Kong's democratic institutions, following the introduction of a security law last year.

site_title: Hippo to go public in US$5b merger with Mark Pincus
summary: Hippo Enterprises, a Palo Alto-based insurance technology startup, will go public through a US$5 billion merger with special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) Reinvent Technology Partners Z. Backed by Silicon Valley heavyweights Reid Hoffman and Mark Pincus, the deal includes a private investment of about US$450 million. Hippo will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol "RTPZ" after the merger. This is the latest in a string of insurance tech firms taking the SPAC merger route to go public.

site_title: Singapore advises citizens to leave Myanmar while they can
summary: Singapore advises its citizens in Myanmar to leave the country due to escalating violence against anti-coup protesters, with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs warning of rapidly increasing civilian casualties. Citizens should consider leaving by commercial means while possible, and those remaining should remain indoors and avoid travel to protest areas. The advice comes amid clashes between protesters and Myanmar security forces.

site_title: Minimum energy performance requirements to be raised for new, some existing buildings
summary: Singapore is raising its minimum energy performance requirements for new buildings and existing ones undergoing major retrofitting to 50% and 40% more energy efficient, respectively, to match the existing Green Mark Platinum standards. The revised scheme will also emphasize health, well-being, and maintainability. The new standards will be trialed from Q2, and Singapore aims to "green" 80% of its buildings by 2030. The move is part of the government's efforts to speed up the adoption of technologies such as Design for Manufacturing and Assembly (DfMA) and achieve its target of 70% DfMA adoption by 2025.

site_title: Jewellery as supple as fabric
summary: Chanel's high jewellery collection pays homage to the iconic material, tweed, which was first adopted by the fashion house in the 1920s. Coco Chanel fell in love with tweed after borrowing her boyfriend's sportswear, and it became a symbol of women's power, popularized by icons like Jackie Kennedy. The tweed two-piece has endured in fashion for nearly a century, remaining a timeless and versatile piece.

images.alt_text: (Left) Tweed d'Or Necklace. (Right) Tweed Graphique Ring.
(Left) Tweed d'Ete Necklace (Right) Tweed Couture Bracelet.

site_title: No change to Straits Times Index components following March review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) components remain unchanged following its March 2021 quarterly review. The reserve list, comprising Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Suntec Reit, Keppel Reit, and NetLink NBN Trust, will replace ineligible constituents through corporate actions before the next review. No changes were made to the STI's constituents, ensuring continuity in the index's composition.

site_title: UN tells Myanmar military to 'stop murdering' protesters
summary: The UN rights chief, Michelle Bachelet, has urged Myanmar's military to "stop murdering" protesters, citing at least 54 killed and 1,700 detained since the February 1 coup. The deadliest day of protests saw 38 dead, with security forces firing into crowds. Bachelet also expressed alarm at attacks on medical staff and ambulances, and called for the immediate release of arbitrarily detained individuals, including journalists and parliamentarians.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.19 points to 1,581.26. The market saw a loser-to-gainer ratio of 701 to 445. Volume was 9.632 billion lots worth RM5.372 billion.

site_title: KrisFlyer member data affected by data breach at information tech firm SITA
summary: A data breach at IT firm SITA has affected the frequent flyer programme information of approximately 580,000 KrisFlyer and Singapore Airlines (SIA) members, compromising membership numbers, tier statuses, and some names. The breach occurred on February 24, 2021, and SITA took immediate action to contact affected customers. SIA, a Star Alliance member, was affected due to SITA's access to restricted frequent flyer data. The airline assures that none of its IT systems were compromised, and it is reviewing procedures to improve data security.

site_title: Seven companies that SPACs could target
summary: Blank-cheque companies are heavily oversubscribing for special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) targeting South-east Asia, with investors seeking high-growth, consumer-focused tech companies. Potential targets include those valued at $1 billion or more, with a high-growth potential, sizeable revenue stream, and profitability. Companies such as Bukalapak, Gojek, and Tokopedia are reportedly eyeing SPAC listings in the US, while Singapore-based companies like JustCo and Ninja Van are also being considered.
