site_title: US and UK agree to suspend tariffs and seek aircraft row resolution
summary: The US and UK have agreed to suspend tariffs imposed on goods like Scotch whisky for four months, allowing them to resolve the long-running aircraft subsidy dispute. The US had imposed tariffs on EU food, wine, and spirits, including Scotch whisky, which the UK industry claims are threatening its future. The suspension aims to ease industry burden and facilitate a joint resolution to the dispute.

site_title: Pandemic will change Singapore's land-use plans and designs: Indranee
summary: Singapore's land-use plans and designs will be revised due to the coronavirus pandemic, with a focus on reducing office and retail space as people shift to e-commerce and telecommuting. The review, led by the Ministry of National Development and Urban Redevelopment Authority, aims to refresh long-term plans to accommodate changing needs and emerging trends. The review is not a new exercise, having last been conducted in 2011, and will consider re-development strategies as Singapore's land becomes increasingly built-up.

site_title: US factory orders surge, but business spending on equipment slowing
summary: US factory orders surged 2.6% in January, exceeding expectations, but business spending on equipment slowed, with non-defence capital goods orders increasing 0.4% and shipments of core capital goods rising 1.8%. The manufacturing sector, accounting for 11.9% of the US economy, is expected to continue recovering, despite a potential shift back to services in the summer due to vaccination efforts. A global semiconductor chip shortage and slowdown in machinery orders may also impact momentum. The outlook for manufacturing remains solid, with the Institute for Supply Management's index reaching a three-year high in February.

site_title: New Growth and Transformation Scheme to support alliances of firms across the built environment sector
summary: The Singapore government will launch the Growth and Transformation Scheme (GTS) in the second half of this year to support alliances of firms across the built environment sector, focusing on improving capabilities and productivity. The scheme will also support sustainability targets and workforce development. Minister of National Development Desmond Lee also announced plans to introduce a new housing model for public housing, aiming to keep flats affordable for young families, and to make the HDB flat-buying process more convenient and seamless.

site_title: Aviva dangles possibility of shareholder cash as it exits Italy
summary: British insurer Aviva plans to sell its remaining Italian business as part of a strategy shift to focus on key markets of Britain, Canada, and Ireland. The move is part of CEO Amanda Blanc's efforts to address concerns over the group's unwieldy structure. Following the sale, Aviva may give cash back to shareholders, with its shares rising 3.5% on the news. This strategic change aims to simplify the company's operations and improve its performance in core markets.

images.alt_text: British insurer Aviva said it may give cash back to shareholders after selling its remaining business in Italy as part of plans to focus on key markets of Britain, Canada and Ireland.

site_title: Lufthansa sees delayed recovery after US$8.1b record loss
summary: Deutsche Lufthansa posted a record $8.1 billion annual loss due to the coronavirus crisis, with the airline group expecting to struggle to make money on flights until the end of the year. Lufthansa will operate at 40-50% of its 2019 capacity levels this year, down from a previous target of 40-60%. CEO Carsten Spohr warned that the airline may only operate 90% of its pre-pandemic capacity by mid-decade, indicating a delayed recovery.

site_title: Apex court criticises Nicky Tan, lawyers from Rajah & Tann and Tan Kok Quan
summary: The Singaporean apex court has criticized Nicky Tan, a liquidator, and lawyers from Rajah & Tann and Tan Kok Quan for misleading the court by proceeding with an appeal despite a settlement between the parties. The court deemed the appeal "totally wasted" after the parties reached a settlement, and the liquidators were accused of breaching their duties to the court. The liquidators were also criticized for attempting to stage a "walkover" in the appeal and for not acknowledging their failure to fulfill their duties.

site_title: 19 Myanmar police seek refuge in India, more expected
summary: At least 19 low-ranking Myanmar police officers have sought refuge in India, crossing into the northeastern state of Mizoram, to escape the military junta's suppression of protests following last month's coup. More are expected to arrive, according to an Indian police official citing intelligence reports. The officers, who are unarmed, have taken refuge in Champhai and Serchhip districts. The Indian government has not commented on the situation, but the official's statement indicates that the country is willing to provide assistance to those fleeing persecution.

site_title: Nissan Note e-Power: Another hybrid to note
summary: Nissan unveiled the Note e-Power, a compact five-door hatchback hybrid car in Singapore. The car starts at S$99,800 and uses a petrol-electric system, where it runs on electricity but generates power from a petrol engine. The e-Power system helps drivers experience instant acceleration and whisper quietness, while also recapturing energy to minimize the need for braking. This is part of Nissan's efforts to popularize hybrids, following the success of the Note e-Power in Japan, where it became the country's best-selling car in 2016.

site_title: Myanmar soldiers use TikTok to threaten protesters
summary: Armed Myanmar soldiers and police are using TikTok to deliver death threats to protesters against last month's coup, according to researchers. Over 800 pro-military videos have been found on the app, featuring uniformed soldiers and police menacing protesters. In response, TikTok has announced it will remove content that incites violence. The move comes as the US tech giant Facebook has banned all pages linked to Myanmar's army and has itself been banned. The increase in menacing content on TikTok has raised concerns about the military's growing online presence.

site_title: Khazanah's holding in Malaysia Airlines diluted by debt restructuring
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional reported a "minor dilution" of its equity in Malaysia Airlines due to debt-to-equity conversions as part of the airline's debt restructuring plan. The dilution was minor and Khazanah remains the largest shareholder. The fund injected RM3.6 billion into the airline to fund its operations through 2025, aiming to provide certainty to creditors and facilitate debt-to-equity conversions. Industry experts expect consolidation due to oversupply in the aviation market, with Khazanah's managing director stating that discussions on new investors will likely wait until 2023 or 2022.

site_title: Singapore shares close up 0.48%, buck regional markets slide on rising yields
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.48% to 3,014.78 points on Thursday, bucking regional market declines driven by rising bond yields. Senior market analyst Jeffrey Halley predicts a material global equity market correction. This marks a 5-day rally for Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Singapore court grants oil trader GP Global APAC debt moratorium
summary: Singapore's High Court granted oil trader GP Global APAC a six-month debt moratorium, allowing its parent company to restructure over US$1 billion in debt. GP APAC, which owes more than US$464 million to creditors, will be able to resume restructuring efforts, including selling off oil refining and storage assets. The moratorium prevents creditors from pursuing independent legal actions, paving the way for a restructuring scheme. The company had applied for the moratorium after a court ruling allowed a creditor to seize its office to recoup claims.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims increase less than expected
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose to 745,000 for the week ended Feb 27, exceeding economists' forecast of 750,000. The increase is likely due to brutal winter storms in the South, but the labour market outlook is improving as Covid-19 cases decline. Weekly jobless claims have dropped from a record 6.867 million in March 2020, but remain above the 200,000 to 250,000 range typically seen in a well-functioning labour market. Economists expect the labour market to accelerate in the spring and summer, driven by President Biden's recovery plan and increasing vaccinations.

site_title: Measures to preserve Singapore's coastline to start this year
summary: Singapore's National Water Agency and JTC will conduct site-specific studies on coastal protection measures for vulnerable areas, starting this year. Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu announced plans to implement measures such as sea walls, polders, and nature-based solutions like mangrove planting. The government will also develop a Coastal-Inland Flood Model to assess flood risk and invest S$1.36 billion in drainage works over the next five years.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares finished sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong shares plummeted 2.15% on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 643.63 points to 29,236.79, as economic recovery optimism gave way to concerns about rising interest rates. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index dropping 2.05% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shedding 2.90%. The losses were attributed to worries about a surge in prices leading to higher interest rates.

site_title: Higher co-funding quantum and expanded scope in new S$60 million agri-food fund
summary: Singapore has launched a new S$60 million Agri-Food Cluster Transformation (ACT) Fund to support the agri-food sector over the next five years. The fund, established by the Singapore Food Agency, aims to increase productivity and achieve the "30 by 30" goal of producing 30% of the nation's nutritional needs through local farms by 2030. The new fund offers higher co-funding of up to S$4.5 million and expanded scope to support farms adopting advanced farming systems, technology, and innovation.

site_title: YCH and Cambodia sign framework pact to develop Phnom Penh Logistics Complex
summary: Singapore's YCH Group and Cambodia's Ministry of Public Works and Transport have signed a framework agreement to develop the Phnom Penh Logistics Complex, a key project under the Asean Smart Logistics Network. YCH will design, develop, and operate the complex, expected to enhance Cambodia's connectivity with regional trade flows and contribute to the country's long-term economic growth. The project is part of the Smart Growth Connect Initiative, aimed at strengthening intra-regional trade among Mekong countries and south-western China.

images.alt_text: Clockwise direction, starting from top right corner: Hem Vanndy (Secretary of State, Ministry of Economy and Finance, Cambodia); Teo Lay Cheng (Singapore Ambassador to Cambodia); Robert Yap (executive chairman, YCH Group); Seth Tan (executive director, Infrastructure Asia, Singapore); Indranee Rajah (Second Minister for Finance and National Development, Singapore); and Sun Chanthol (Senior Minister and Minister of Public Works and Transport, Cambodia)

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall over 1% as US yields rise
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.22% to 3,045.31, following a 1% decline in US tech shares and weak jobs data, with investors awaiting US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's speech. The won weakened, while bond yields rose, with foreigners selling 927.8 billion won worth of shares. Chip giants Samsung and SK Hynix led declines, while internet giant Naver and battery maker LG Chem slipped.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open lower
summary: European stock markets opened lower on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 down 0.6% to 6,636.05 points, Frankfurt's DAX 30 down 0.3% to 14,036.43 points, and Paris's CAC 40 down 0.2% to 5,819.57 points. The losses follow sharp declines in Asia. Despite this, mining and healthcare shares have provided some support. US stocks also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq rising.

site_title: Imran Khan to seek Pakistan parliament vote after shock loss
summary: Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan will seek a confidence vote in the National Assembly after his finance minister lost an election for a seat in the upper house, the Senate. Khan's government is facing its biggest test yet, with the opposition alliance planning to march on Islamabad on March 26 to topple his government. Khan's Tehreek-e-Insaf party holds 26 Senate seats, but his ruling coalition is likely to fall short of a majority needed to push through legislation. The vote will determine Khan's ability to maintain his government, with failure leading to dissolution and fresh elections.

site_title: Honda to sell limited batch of level three self-driving cars
summary: Honda Motor plans to sell a limited batch of its Legend sedan with level three autonomous driving technology, known as "Traffic Jam Pilot," in Japan. The 100 vehicles will feature advanced technology that enables navigation on congested highways, allowing drivers to watch movies or use navigation while the system controls acceleration, braking, and steering. The move represents a significant step towards Honda's goal of mass-producing a car with level three technology. The vehicles will be sold at a retail price of 11 million yen (S$136,649) and have no plans for increased production or sales at this time.

site_title: GreenGov.SG: Public sector aims to peak carbon emissions by 2025
summary: Singapore's public sector aims to peak carbon emissions by 2025, five years ahead of the national target of 2030, as part of the "GreenGov.SG" initiative. The initiative, part of the Singapore Green Plan 2030, will incorporate environmental sustainability requirements into procurement frameworks and embed sustainability practices in core business areas. The public sector will also build an organisational culture of sustainability, with targets for electricity and water consumption, as well as green buildings.

site_title: GIC cashes in on Taiwan stock boom: sources
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC sold Taiwan stocks last week, taking advantage of the island's booming bourse, which has risen 8% so far this year. The index has outperformed Japan and China, rising 23% last year. GIC's move comes as Taiwan's economy benefits from global demand for technology goods during the pandemic. The decision highlights the fund's strategy to cash in on the Taiwan stock market's growth.

site_title: No new diesel cars, taxis in Singapore; road taxes for EVs updated: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore will stop registering new diesel cars and taxis from 2025 and all new car and taxi registrations will be for cleaner-energy models from 2030. The government also lowered the registration fee floor for electric cars from $5,000 to zero and revised road tax structures to make EVs comparable to ICE models. To support EV adoption, the government plans to install 60,000 charging points by 2030 and offer an EV Common Charger Grant to non-landed private residences. The newly formed National Electric Vehicle Centre will review EV regulations and standards.

site_title: Malaysia's Khazanah 2020 profit down 60% as divestment gains fall
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional reported a 60% decline in operating profit to RM2.9 billion in 2020 due to falling divestment gains amid the coronavirus pandemic. Profits slumped from RM7.4 billion in 2019, with impairment charges of RM6 billion largely attributed to aviation and hospitality assets. Despite this, dividend income rose 36.8% to RM5.2 billion, and debt decreased 6% to RM43.1 billion. Khazanah is in talks with the government to invest in new sectors, aiming to spur growth and recovery.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional reported on Thursday its operating profit fell about 60 per cent last year to RM2.9 billion (S$952.9 million) as divestment gains fell sharply amid the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong removed from economic freedom ranking it once dominated
summary: Hong Kong has been removed from the Heritage Foundation's annual Index of Economic Freedom due to its direct control by Beijing. This move comes as Beijing ramps up efforts to quash dissent following pro-democracy demonstrations in 2019. The removal is a reputational blow to Hong Kong, which previously dominated the ranking. The decision reflects the significant erosion of economic freedom in the city, which is now subject to increased regulatory oversight and censorship.

site_title: Exxon and Macquarie in US$11.7m US lawsuit over gas contract
summary: ExxonMobil is suing Macquarie Energy in a Texas court over a US$11.7 million gas contract, citing the winter freeze as a natural disaster that prevented it from fulfilling its supply commitment. Exxon claims the massive storm, which caused widespread power outages, was a natural disaster that allowed it to break its contract without penalty. Macquarie, the second largest US gas marketer, had rejected Exxon's declaration and instead issued its own force majeure declaration, but the Australian company is seeking damages for missed deliveries.

site_title: Singapore dollar's fortunes darken as buy momentum set to wane
summary: The Singapore dollar's strength appears to be waning as the US dollar is poised to rally against it, potentially breaking its 200-day moving average. The currency pair formed a potential bullish double bottom pattern in February, but momentum may be waning as the moving average convergence-divergence indicator signaled bearish momentum. A close above the 100-day moving average could lead to further gains towards the 200-day moving average. This reversal could impact the Singapore dollar's fortunes, potentially darkening its outlook.

site_title: Australia: Ex-dividend trading, global selling trip shares
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Thursday, weighed down by miners Rio Tinto and BHP Group as they traded ex-dividend. Tech stocks dropped 1.5% and healthcare stocks fell 3.5%, with CSL dropping 5.8%. Financials, however, rose 1% to their highest in over a year, driven by data on faster-than-expected economic growth and the central bank's accommodative stance. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 1%, with dairy firm Synlait Milk diving 10% after withdrawing its 2021 earnings forecast.

site_title: Monde Nissin seeks 63b pesos in Philippines' biggest IPO
summary: Monde Nissin, a Philippine food maker, filed for an initial public offering (IPO) to raise up to 63 billion pesos (S$1.73 billion), the country's largest-ever first-time share sale. The company plans to sell 3.6 billion shares at up to 17.5 pesos each, with an overallotment option for up to 540 million additional shares. Monde Nissin produces instant noodles, crackers, and other food products, and the IPO proceeds will be used for loan repayment and general corporate purposes. The deal is being led by UBS Group and Citigroup, among others.

site_title: SPACs look to India for next wave of targets, Nomura says
summary: Blank-cheque companies are targeting India for potential acquisition targets, with Nomura Holdings predicting up to 10 Indian companies could go public through SPAC deals by the end of the year. Following recent deals involving ReNew Power and Grofers, Nomura expects equal revenue contributions from equity capital markets, mergers and acquisitions, and financing in India. The Japanese bank also anticipates more initial public offerings (IPOs) in India, with sentiment boosted by the strong post-debut performance of recently listed companies.

site_title: BOJ shares hit upper limit for fourth session, nearly doubling this week
summary: Bank of Japan shares hit their upper limit for a fourth consecutive session, nearly doubling this week, amid a surge in market demand for cash. The stock's gain is comparable to the rise in cryptocurrency bitcoin. Despite the BOJ's rally, the Nikkei 225 index slumped over 2% and the overall index ended with a small loss for the week. Analysts attribute the BOJ's surge to excess cash in the market seeking a home, with some comparing it to the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: Asia: Markets resume losses as inflation fears take hold again
summary: Asian markets plummeted as inflation fears took hold, with Tokyo and Hong Kong down around 2% and Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul losing over 1%. The US Treasury bond yields hit one-year highs, sparking concerns of higher borrowing costs. Investors are also worried about the potential surge in spending and stimulus packages, which could force central banks to tighten monetary policies. Despite some optimism, markets strategist Louis Navellier believes the current consolidation is a "pause that refreshes" before the next leg higher.

site_title: Guoco Group extends closing date for offer to take GL private
summary: Guoco Group has extended the closing date for its voluntary conditional cash offer to take GL Ltd private to March 18, from March 4. The offer, valued at S$0.70 per share, aims to acquire at least 90% of GL's shares to meet delisting requirements. As of March 3, GuocoLeisure Holdings held 83.18% of GL's shares, and its independent directors have recommended minority shareholders accept the offer despite the independent financial adviser deeming it "not fair but reasonable".

site_title: Wife of retiree who tested positive for Covid-19 is new community case
summary: An 81-year-old Singaporean woman, wife of an 82-year-old retiree, tested positive for Covid-19 on February 27, becoming the sole new community case announced on March 4. She initially developed symptoms, including fever and chills, but recovered on the same day. Her symptoms may have been due to the first dose of the Covid-19 vaccine, administered on February 26.

site_title: Brokers' take: Singapore Reits poised for full recovery, says CGS-CIMB
summary: Singapore Reits are poised for a full recovery, according to CGS-CIMB, driven by improved footfall and tenant sales. The brokerage has placed an "add" call on three Reits: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, and SPH Reit, with target prices of S$3.01, 85.8 cents, and S$1.06 respectively. Despite challenging leasing environments, CGS-CIMB expects rental reversion to range from -3 to -20% in FY2021, with valuations remaining stable.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank leaves key rate steady, sees vaccine boost to economy
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its benchmark interest rate steady at 1.75% as forecast, citing a recently launched Covid-19 vaccination programme that will boost consumer and business sentiment, supporting economic recovery. The bank expects a pick-up in growth from the second quarter, driven by global demand, private and public spending, and continued policy support, despite coronavirus curbs in the first quarter.

site_title: Shell to pilot faster-charging, solar-powered stations for EVs in Singapore
summary: Shell will pilot three solar-powered, fast-charging stations for electric vehicles (EVs) in Singapore by early 2022, offering up to three times faster charging times than existing stations. The new stations, powered by solar photovoltaic panels and energy storage systems, will be part of Shell's growing EV charging network. The project is part of a multi-year partnership between Shell and the Energy Market Authority (EMA), with the goal of expanding EV charging options in Singapore by 2030, with 40% of Shell's network offering fast-charging options.

site_title: UN says 38 dead in Myanmar's 'bloodiest' day since coup
summary: At least 38 people died in Myanmar's "bloodiest" day since the military coup, according to the UN, amid escalating violence against protesters. The junta has defied international condemnation, with the US calling it "appalled and revulsed." Over 50 people have died since the coup, with many more wounded. The US is considering further action, while China has been urged to use its influence to promote peaceful resolution. International pressure continues to mount, with Western powers hitting the generals with sanctions and Britain calling for a UN Security Council meeting.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS maintains 'overweight' on Malaysia's healthcare, gaming sectors
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "overweight" call on Malaysia's healthcare, gaming sectors, citing a projected 31% earnings rise in 2021 before a 1% contraction in 2022. The research team favors companies like Westports, Gamuda, Telekom Malaysia, and Sentral Reit, citing the country's economic recovery and improving trade activities. DBS also expects exporters to deliver good financial results due to strong external demand, and believes the central bank may cut interest rates to stimulate the economy if it remains lacklustre. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index (KLCI) target is set at 1,770.

site_title: Overseas fans likely to be barred from Tokyo Games: local media
summary: Tokyo Olympics officials are leaning towards holding the event with a domestic-only audience due to concerns about public safety amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Japanese media reported that public safety would be the top priority, with officials fearing an influx of international visitors would endanger the Japanese public. The decision is expected to be made by the end of the month, with around 900,000 tickets already sold outside Japan.

site_title: Push for greener buildings under refreshed Singapore Green Building Masterplan: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore aims to green 80% of new buildings, with 80% of new developments to be Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings by 2030, under the refreshed Singapore Green Building Masterplan. The country also targets an 80% improvement in energy efficiency levels for best-in-class green buildings by 2030. To achieve this, the government will lead in SLE buildings and build industry capabilities, while ramping up research and innovation efforts for cost-effective green technologies.

site_title: South Korea's inflation picks up amid higher food, oil prices
summary: South Korea's inflation rose to 1.1% in February, the highest since last year, driven by increased food prices during the Lunar New Holiday and elevated oil prices. The Bank of Korea reported the economy grew 1.2% last quarter, exceeding initial estimates, despite a 1% annual contraction. The central bank raised its inflation forecast to 1.3% for this year, citing a gradual economic recovery and higher oil prices. The economy is showing signs of an accelerating recovery, with manufacturing activity expanding at the fastest pace in over a decade.

site_title: Indonesia fintech PAYFAZZ invests US$30m in Singapore's Xfers; to form new entity
summary: Indonesia-based fintech PAYFAZZ has invested US$30 million in Singapore's Xfers, forming a new entity, Fazz Financial Group (FFG), to provide financial services across South-east Asia. FFG plans to launch two products: a zero-integration payment solution for Singapore-based merchants and a single-integration solution for brands entering the region. PAYFAZZ co-founder Hendra Kwik will be CEO of FFG, while Xfers' co-founder Liu Tianwei will be deputy CEO. The new entity aims to strengthen infrastructure and product offerings to accelerate financial inclusion in South-east Asia.

site_title: Sands' Sin City sale might fund pivot to Australia
summary: Las Vegas Sands is selling its Las Vegas assets for $6.3 billion, potentially funding a pivot to Australia. The sale comes after Crown Resorts, a beleaguered Australian business, was acquired by Sands. Crown's assets are valued around 8 times Ebitda for 2019, compared to Sands' 13 times valuation. Sands' CEO plans to focus on Asia, particularly Macau and Singapore, and its business model is seen as less risky and more appealing to Australian regulators.

site_title: Sembmarine obtains S$500m Sora-based sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: Sembmarine has secured a S$500 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS, believed to be the first in the maritime industry referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). The loan features a compounded daily Sora rate and interest rate discounts linked to ESG targets, and is aimed at promoting environmental sustainability.

site_title: Insurtech Symbo raises US$9.4m, acquires health platform Vivant
summary: Singapore-based insurtech startup Symbo has raised US$9.4 million in a Series A round led by CreditEase Fintech Investment Fund. The company also acquired health platform Vivant in an all-stock transaction. Symbo's insurtech platform supports insurance distribution across India and South-east Asia, with plans to expand in India and bolster its technology and leadership teams. The startup aims to acquire complete ownership of its Indian affiliate, subject to regulatory approvals.

site_title: Gold recovers from nine-month low, but higher yields weigh
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,714.27 per ounce, recovering from a near nine-month low. Higher US Treasury yields, near 1.5%, continued to weigh on the metal's appeal. Benchmark US Treasury yields increased the opportunity cost of holding bullion, which pays no returns. Despite this, gold prices edged higher after Trump announced fresh tariffs on Canada and threatened others.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 6.78 points lower, 0.43% down, at 1,581.67 on Thursday. Volume was 257.65 million lots worth RM130 million. Gainers beat losers 210-207.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open, tracking Wall Street sell-off; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% at the opening on Thursday, tracking a weak lead from Wall Street, where tech shares dropped after disappointing US economic data. Analysts predict the tech-heavy Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, and China markets to suffer, while more cyclical Asean markets like Singapore are expected to escape the worst of the tech sell-off. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,988.40, with decliners outnumbering advancers 100 to 44.

site_title: Most countries in APAC looking at 2022, 2023 before herd immunity can be achieved: report
summary: Most countries in the Asia-Pacific region will likely reach herd immunity in 2022 or 2023, according to Moody's Analytics. Exceptions include Singapore, which has already achieved a 6.2% vaccination rate by February 18. Many Asian countries, including China, Sri Lanka, Nepal, and Indonesia, have vaccination rates below 3%. The need for vaccination is critical for reopening international borders and supporting business travelers. Countries where containment of Covid-19 has been less successful, such as Indonesia and Malaysia, require rapid roll-outs to protect public health and revive their economies.

site_title: China's market rates unlikely to rise rapidly in short term: state media
summary: China's market interest rates are unlikely to rise rapidly in the short term, according to the state-run China Securities Journal. The recent sharp uptick in US bond yields has not significantly impacted Chinese bond rates, which have already priced in the impact of macroeconomic policy changes. Two key policy rates remain stable with no signs of a short-term increase, limiting further rises in market rates. This suggests that China's monetary policy is expected to remain relatively unchanged in the near future.

site_title: Amazon to open cashierless store in London, first outside US
summary: Amazon is opening its first cashierless store outside the US in London, a 2,500-square foot Amazon Fresh-branded store that uses Just Walk Out technology to track shoppers and charges a credit card on file. The store marks the retail giant's biggest effort to reshape physical retailing and is the first of 26 cashierless stores Amazon has opened in the US. The company also introduced a new private label food brand, "by Amazon", to be sold in the store, and plans to license the Just Walk Out technology to other companies.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start Thursday's session with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began Thursday's session with losses, falling 1.19% to 29,525.48 on the Hang Seng Index, amid global market fluctuations between vaccine optimism and inflation concerns. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.85% and the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.86%.

site_title: Aztech Global to raise S$297m in IPO; sees theoretical market cap of S$990.4m
summary: Aztech Global, the technology unit of Aztech Group, is set to raise S$297 million in its initial public offering (IPO) with a theoretical market cap of S$990.4 million. The company plans to use the funds for expansion, research and development, and mergers and acquisitions. Aztech has seen revenue grow 14% to S$428.8 million in FY2019 and its net profit quadrupled to S$47.2 million. The IPO is seen as a natural decision for the company, given its strong brand presence in Singapore and its position as a hub for the capital market.

images.alt_text: (Left) Jeremy Mun, executive director and chief operating officer of Aztech Global, together with Michael Mun, executive chairman and chief executive of the company.

site_title: SpaceX rocket explodes on ground after seemingly successful flight
summary: A SpaceX Starship rocket prototype, SN10, exploded on the ground after a successful-looking flight and landing in Boca Chica, Texas. This is the third consecutive failure for the prototype, following two previous crashes. The rocket appeared to land properly but experienced flames and explosions shortly after landing. No explanation has been provided for the incident. The test was part of SpaceX's development of a next-generation rocket for Mars missions, with potential uses for closer trips to the Moon.

site_title: Singapore-based Neuron Mobility to launch e-scooter rental services in Korea
summary: Neuron Mobility, a Singapore-based startup, is launching e-scooter rental services in Seoul, Korea, following the government's introduction of stricter rules on e-scooter usage. The company will initially deploy 2,000 e-scooters and recruit over 100 people in Korea. This move is part of Neuron's international expansion, which includes contracts in Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The company has secured US$30.5 million in funding and aims to scale significantly later in the year.

site_title: Myanmar police fire without warning, killing 18 protesters
summary: Myanmar security forces opened fire on protesters without warning, killing at least 18 people, according to a human rights group. The violence came a day after Asean members urged restraint, but failed to unite behind a call for democracy. The death toll since the coup has risen to 40, with many more wounded. The military-appointed foreign minister attended a virtual Asean meeting, but made no mention of the focus on Myanmar's problems.

site_title: Disney to close 60 North American stores in 2021
summary: Disney to close at least 60 North American stores in 2021 to focus on online sales, significantly reducing its brick-and-mortar footprint. The closures are part of a plan to develop its "shopDisney" sales platform and expand its integration with mobile apps and social media. The company aims to create new products, such as adult clothing and collectible items, to offset the loss of physical stores. The closures are a response to changing consumer behavior and the global pandemic, with Disney hoping to maintain its e-commerce presence.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday due to profit-taking, tracking losses on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.25% to 29,188.24, while the Topix index declined 0.92% to 1,887.01. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record-breaking session on US stock exchanges, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged past fresh records despite US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street lower on weak US jobs data
summary: Australian shares fell 1.5% to 6,716.1 on Thursday, tracking a decline in US stocks due to weak US jobs data. The S&P/ASX 200 index was on track to end a three-day winning streak, reversing a 0.8% gain from the previous day. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq fell 0.39%, 1.31%, and 2.70%, respectively, after data showed fewer US private employer hires in February.

site_title: Xero to buy workforce management platform Planday in largest acquisition yet
summary: Xero is acquiring Planday, a workforce management platform, for 183.5 million euros (S$294.7 million), its largest acquisition to date. The deal includes an upfront payment of 155.7 million euros and a potential earnout payment based on product development and revenue milestones. Planday, with over 350,000 users, will continue to offer services to existing customers and partners. The acquisition is expected to contribute 3% of additional operating revenue growth for Xero in FY22 and aligns with its purpose to make life better for small business owners.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Oceanus, Prudential, Union Gas, Sarine Tech, FJ Benjamin
summary: Stocks to watch: Oceanus Group plummeted 45.3% after a 2.9 Singapore cent drop, while Union Gas Holdings fell 9.2% following an announcement about redeveloping a fuel station. Prudential reported a 4% operating profit growth for 2020, and Sarine Technologies plans a dual listing on Israel's Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. FJ Benjamin rose 130% after a partnership with Lazada Singapore and removal from the watch list. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) closed 0.4% higher despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Transportation woes expected to send coffee prices up
summary: US coffee processors and roasters expect to raise retail prices due to significant transportation cost increases. The rising costs are attributed to the pandemic's impact on shipping, safety guidelines, and supply chain constraints. Mid-sized and smaller roasters, particularly specialty coffee companies, are hit hardest, with some reporting 15% price increases. The US coffee market faces similar challenges, with freight costs adding nearly $10 billion to corporate costs in the fourth quarter of 2020.

site_title: Europe: Stocks muted as rise in yields, inflation bets curb initial gains
summary: European stocks ended flat on Wednesday, with gains in economy-sensitive sectors offset by rising bond yields and inflation expectations. Consumer-oriented stocks led gains, while utilities lost due to higher yields. British stocks rose after finance minister Rishi Sunak extended emergency programs to support the economy. German stocks rose 0.3% on anticipation of easing coronavirus curbs, while automobile supplier Continental jumped 5.4% after a rating upgrade.

site_title: PSA, Fiat Chrysler in black despite weaker sales
summary: Fiat Chrysler and PSA, merged in the Stellantis group, posted a 2020 profit of 24 million euros despite weaker sales due to the coronavirus pandemic. The two automakers reported a 20% decline in sales and 22% decline in vehicle volume. However, they managed to maintain profit margins of 4.3% and 6.1%, respectively. Stellantis aims to achieve an operating profit margin of 5.5-7.5% this year, with a focus on electric vehicle expansion and cost savings.

images.alt_text: US-Italian automaker Fiat Chrysler and France's PSA, now merged in the Stellantis group, managed to post a 2020 profit despite weaker sales during the coronavirus pandemic, company results showed Wednesday.

site_title: Sustainability: the rise of green agendas
summary: Singapore has unveiled the Singapore Green Plan 2030, a new initiative aimed at tackling environmental issues through green finance. The plan, spearheaded by Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu, seeks to leverage "greener" technologies across various sectors. The goal is to address pressing problems in capital markets, such as inefficient trade settlement and high transaction costs. Blockchain technology is seen as a solution, enabling effective ESG financing, smart contracts, and real-time tracking. The plan is part of a growing trend of international recognition of green finance, with institutions worldwide recognizing the need for sustainable practices in finance.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund puts Japan's Kirin on watch list over Myanmar link
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund has put Japan's Kirin Holdings on a watch list due to its ties to a business owned by Myanmar's military. The decision comes after Kirin announced plans to end its business cooperation with the joint venture, but later stated it still wanted to sell beer in Myanmar. The fund holds a 1.29% stake in Kirin, valued at $277.1 million. This move is part of the fund's efforts to exclude companies with ties to human rights abuses or other negative ESG practices.

site_title: Ding Zhou to buy 41-year lease in ex-Mazda, Volkswagen showroom site in MacPherson
summary: A 67,000 sq ft freehold site in MacPherson, Singapore, currently occupied by a two-storey front office and showroom, and a three-storey rear workshop and car park, has been sold to Woodlands Smartisan Pte Ltd for S$41 million. The 41-year leasehold interest will be held by the buyer, part of Ding Zhou Group, which has a presence in Singapore, Cambodia, and Australia. The site has significant redevelopment potential, zoned for Business 1 use with a 2.5 allowable plot ratio, allowing for up to 167,295 sq ft gross floor area.

site_title: Critics shrug at latest ExxonMobil climate pitch
summary: ExxonMobil unveiled a "lower-carbon" plan, emphasizing carbon capture and storage (CCS) to reduce emissions, but critics argue the plan falls short of European rivals' net-zero targets and renewable energy investments. The company plans $3 billion in new CCS investments over five years and has a 2021 capital budget of $16-19 billion for oil and gas projects. Despite the shift in tone, activists say ExxonMobil's plan "risks continued long-term value destruction" and more significant technological advancements are needed to make CCS projects affordable.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Medtecs International has entered a joint venture with ACO International to build a fully integrated product development, manufacturing, sales, and distribution platform. This move aims to expand Medtecs' manufacturing capabilities and product offerings, ultimately increasing revenue streams. The partnership is expected to enhance the group's competitiveness in the healthcare industry.

site_title: EU commission seeks to tackle gender pay gap
summary: The European Commission is set to propose measures to tackle the 14.1% average pay gap between men and women in the EU. The proposals include requiring large firms to publish reports on salary gaps and imposing fines, with employers bearing the burden of proof. The EU executive branch also plans to establish specific sanctions and require full compensation for missing wages and bonuses in cases of gender-based discrimination. The aim is to increase pay transparency and empower workers to demand fair treatment.

site_title: Bank of England remit updated to include climate change
summary: The Bank of England's monetary policy committee remit has been updated to include climate change, reflecting the UK government's economic strategy for achieving sustainable growth. The updated remit will allow the central bank to consider the "climate impact" of bond issuers when purchasing corporate bonds. The Bank of England will also adapt its bond-buying scheme to account for climate change, with more information to be released in the coming months. The move comes ahead of COP26, where Britain aims to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Rare 15th century Chinese bowl found at US yard sale
summary: A rare 15th-century Chinese porcelain bowl, possibly worth $500,000, was discovered at a US yard sale for $35. The bowl, featuring delicate floral motifs, was appraised by Sotheby's experts, who confirmed it was painted for the court of Emperor Yongle during the Ming dynasty. Only six similar bowls are known to exist, and the seventh will be auctioned off on March 17, expected to sell between $300,000 and $500,000. The bowl's origins remain a mystery, but its discovery is expected to generate significant interest from collectors and institutions.

site_title: US inflation expectations hit decade high as yields resurge
summary: US Treasury yields surged, hitting a decade high, as inflation expectations rose to 2.5% for the next half-decade, surpassing 2008 levels. The surge was driven by UK bond sales, climbing oil prices, and the US government's plan to distribute vaccine doses to every adult by May. Federal Reserve officials, including Chair Jerome Powell, are watching the trend, which may lead to a rate hike. Analysts warn that the market may experience further selloffs in the coming weeks.

site_title: Potential listing of Sea on MSCI Singapore will bring tech exposure and visibility to Republic
summary: Singapore's potential listing of Sea on the MSCI Singapore will bring tech exposure and visibility to the country, aligning with global indices that factor in new economy sectors. The inclusion of Sea, a US-listed tech giant, is expected to add dynamism and relevance to the index, with analysts predicting a potential increase in volatility. The move could also reduce the index's correlation with the Straits Times Index and attract more interest from investors, driving passive inflows and boosting the country's visibility.

site_title: Blinken calls China biggest 'test', vows US strength
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that the US is ready to confront China wherever necessary, calling the relationship with China the "biggest geopolitical test" of the century. Blinken vowed to prioritize diplomacy over military action, focusing on areas like climate change, global health, and nonproliferation. He also emphasized the US's commitment to defending its allies, including Taiwan, and will engage China from a position of strength, while working with allies and finding common ground in narrow cases.

images.alt_text: Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday that the United States was ready to confront China wherever necessary, calling Washington's ties with the Asian power the "biggest geopolitical test" of the century.

site_title: US: Tech shares tumble amid revived fears of inflation
summary: US tech shares plummeted amid concerns of rising inflation and potential interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve. Disappointing services sector data and private job growth also weighed on the market. The US Treasury yields resumed their upward climb, sparking fears of inflation. Investors are now closely watching the Fed's next move, which could impact interest rates and the overall economy.

site_title: ExxonMobil latest casualty in Big Oil layoffs as industry awaits recovery
summary: ExxonMobil has announced the layoffs of approximately 300 jobs, about 7% of its Singapore workforce, due to restructuring efforts amid the industry's shift towards sustainability. The move comes as oil majors face pressure to adapt to changing market conditions. Despite the job cuts, some industry observers believe the worst is over, citing improving global demand and the competitive nature of the Singaporean market.

site_title: Fortune Park near Kovan MRT station up for collective sale
summary: A freehold 10-storey residential block in Singapore, Fortune Park, near Kovan MRT station, is up for collective sale with an indicative price tag of S$115m to S$118m. The 68-apartment property has a land area of 44,878 sq ft and a proposed redevelopment into an 88-unit property. The sale will close on April 22, and the site's 7% bonus gross floor area scheme incentive will not require a development charge.

site_title: Oil gains as US fuels stocks drop, Opec+ considers deal rollover
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, driven by a record drop in US fuel inventories and expectations that Opec+ producers won't increase output. US gasoline stocks fell to 243.5 million barrels and distillate stockpiles plummeted to 143 million barrels. Crude inventories rose to 484.6 million barrels, the most on record. Opec+ is considering rolling over production cuts, not increasing output, amid optimism over vaccinations. US President Joe Biden also expressed optimism over the US vaccine rollout, contributing to the price surge.

site_title: Foreign Employees Dormitories Act to be reviewed to cover all dorms: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's Foreign Employees Dormitories Act will be reviewed to cover all dormitories, regardless of size, to introduce housing standards and safe-living requirements. The review aims to address gaps in primary health care for foreign workers during the pandemic. Second Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng plans to bring all dormitories under a single Act, enabling the Ministry of Manpower to regulate all dormitories uniformly.

images.alt_text: Expanding the scope of FEDA would empower MOM to directly and quickly impose safe- living and infection-control requirements, says Minister Tan See Leng.

site_title: US farmers see veggie burgers carving up meat's dominance
summary: US farmers are concerned as plant-based imitations gain market share, potentially carving into the dominance of meat. Over half of US growers surveyed expect meatless meats to capture 10% of the total protein market in five years, up from 1.5% currently. The rise of alt-meat benefits companies like Beyond Meat and Impossible Foods, but farmers worry about the impact on farm income and environmental regulations under President Biden's administration.

site_title: Biden's SEC chair nominee Gary Gensler signals more regulation for cryptocurrencies
summary: US President Joe Biden's nominee for SEC chair, Gary Gensler, has signaled that the agency will provide guidance and clarity on cryptocurrencies, promising to balance regulation with innovation. Gensler stated that Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies raise new issues of investor protection, which the SEC needs to address. He also indicated that digital currencies created by companies may have violated securities laws. The move could lead to the development of the first SEC guidelines for cryptocurrencies, providing much-needed clarity in the rapidly evolving market.

site_title: At 160 years old, Dentons Rodyk aims to raise $160,000 for charity
summary: Dentons Rodyk, Singapore's oldest law firm, is celebrating its 160th anniversary with a month-long virtual run in March to raise at least S$160,000 for the Singapore Association of Women Lawyers (SAWL) Scholarship Fund. The event aims to support women in the legal profession and promote financial literacy.

site_title: Deloitte to pay Malaysia RM324m in 1MDB-related settlement
summary: Deloitte agreed to a RM324-million settlement with the Malaysian government to resolve claims related to its audit of 1MDB and SRC International between 2011 and 2014. The payout is the largest 1MDB-related settlement by an audit firm in South-east Asia. The settlement will speed up payment of outstanding obligations, but the Malaysian government will continue to pursue individuals involved in the scandal, including fugitive businessman Low Taek Jho. The Finance Minister said the settlement marks another success in the government's recovery efforts against parties involved in the 1MDB scandal.

site_title: Federal Reserve says firms optimistic but jobs gaining only slowly
summary: The US Federal Reserve reported that the American economy expanded "modestly" in recent weeks, with firms becoming more optimistic about their prospects as Covid-19 vaccines are rolled out nationwide. However, employment gains are slow, and companies continue to struggle with finding and retaining workers. Despite this, manufacturing remains a bright spot, and low mortgage rates have spurred "robust demand" for homes. The Fed's policy-setting committee is expected to keep benchmark interest rates low until inflation reaches 2.0% mark, and the pandemic-imposed closure of schools and daycare facilities remains a challenge for employers.

images.alt_text: Activity in the American economy expanded only "modestly" in recent weeks but firms are becoming more upbeat about their prospects as Covid-19 vaccines are rolled out nationwide, the Federal Reserve said on Wednesday.

site_title: US police warn of new militant plot to 'breach' Capitol
summary: US police have bolstered security in Washington ahead of a possible plot to "breach the Capitol" on Thursday, when some Trump supporters predict the former president's inauguration for another term. The threat comes nearly two months after Trump supporters stormed the Capitol, leaving five dead. Some QAnon followers believe Trump was cheated out of a second term and will return to power to confront a secret global cabal. The move is a response to the January 6 attack, which shook American democracy.

images.alt_text: US police said they have bolstered security in Washington after intelligence uncovered a possible plot to "breach the Capitol" on Thursday, when some conspiracy-believing supporters of Donald Trump predict he will be inaugurated for another presidential term.

site_title: Dependant's Pass holders need work passes from May
summary: Singapore's Manpower Minister Josephine Teo announced that from May 1, 2021, Dependant's Pass (DP) holders must apply for a relevant work pass, instead of relying on a letter of consent (LOC). This change aims to harmonize work arrangements with recent tightening of work pass policies. DP holders who wish to work in Singapore must now apply for an Employment Pass, S Pass, or Work Permit, unless they are business owners meeting specific criteria. The move is expected to impact about 11,000 DP holders, mostly in part-time and temporary jobs, and may send a negative message to those contributing to society.

images.alt_text: Currently, DP-holding dependants of work pass holders apply for a letter of consent to work, and do not need a separate work pass.

site_title: China revs up grand chip ambitions to counter US blacklistings
summary: China is launching a five-year plan to become a semiconductor powerhouse, aiming to replace US suppliers and counter blacklistings. The strategy involves using aging semiconductors for electric cars and military applications, while investing in emerging third-generation chip-making and creating indigenous giants in design software and chip-making gear. China's efforts come as the Biden administration escalates a battle against "techno-autocracies," including China, and amid a global chip shortage. The country plans to bankroll research and investment, with a focus on up-and-comer companies like Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corp and Tsinghua Unigroup, to eventually match foreign counterparts in manufacturing and design expertise.

site_title: Pandemic shakes up Singapore conglomerates
summary: Singapore conglomerates are re-evaluating their strategies to boost growth and shareholder value amid the pandemic slump. Companies like Keppel and Sembcorp Industries are shedding underperforming units and refocusing on core competencies. Others, such as Olam International, are demerging subsidiaries to capitalize on booming consumer trends like protein-based diets and sustainable food. The move aims to unlock more value and combat the "conglomerate discount," where investors undervalue diversified groups of businesses.

site_title: Snarl-ups to startups: Cairo's jams inspire homegrown tech solutions
summary: Cairo's notorious traffic jams are driving the growth of homegrown tech startups in Egypt. The city's overcrowded and polluted public transport system, with only three metro lines and run-down buses, is a major challenge. Startups are developing innovative solutions, such as autonomous vehicles and smart traffic management systems, to alleviate congestion and improve air quality. As the megacity's population exceeds 20 million, these startups aim to provide efficient and sustainable transportation options, transforming the city's infrastructure and quality of life.

site_title: Singapore SPAC to merge with the 'Spotify of the Middle-East'
summary: A Singapore-based blank-cheque company, Vistas Media Acquisition Company (VMAC), has agreed to merge with music-streaming service Anghami in a deal that could value the Middle Eastern startup at over US$200 million. The merger will make Anghami one of the first Middle Eastern technology companies to list on the Nasdaq. Anghami has over 70 million users and operates in 16 countries across the Middle East and North Africa. The deal includes a combined PIPE financing of US$40 million and is expected to fuel the company's expansion in existing markets.

site_title: Microsoft steps up push to bring virtual reality to the masses
summary: Microsoft unveiled software tools called Mesh to make virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) content more accessible and affordable. The cloud-based platform allows users to interact with holograms on devices of various price points, from high-end goggles to mobile phones and computers. Mesh enables multiple people to see the same holograms from different locations, facilitating events like concerts and meetings. The software giant aims to bring VR and AR to a wider audience, following a similar approach that led to the success of Xbox Live, Microsoft's online gaming service.

site_title: US dollar slips as bond yields drop; markets calm
summary: The US dollar fell on Wednesday as investor sentiment improved and government bond yields dropped, calming markets. The dollar's appeal was sapped by lower yields, with the yen and Swiss franc recovering from multi-month lows. Global stocks dropped earlier but rebounded this week, and analysts expect Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell to reiterate gradual rate hikes, dampening volatility. Sterling rose 0.1%, the Aussie held flat, and commodity-linked currencies like the Norwegian crown and Canadian dollar also rose.

site_title: Goldman plans to swell to record size in Singapore with 100 tech hires
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to hire approximately 100 tech staff in Singapore, increasing its workforce in the city to over 1,000 employees, according to EG Morse, head of regional operations. The new hires will support the bank's cash management operations and investment banking activities, as Goldman faces its "strongest deal pipeline for many years." The move comes after the bank's reputation was tarnished by a corruption scandal involving Malaysia's 1MDB sovereign wealth fund, but Morse stated that the controversy has not impacted hiring plans in Asia.

site_title: Oil up as Opec+ considers rollover rather than hiking output
summary: Oil prices rose 1.3% to $63.50 a barrel for Brent and 1.2% to $60.48 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, driven by expectations that Opec+ producers will not increase output. The group is considering rolling over production cuts into April instead of raising output. Analysts predict oil prices will push above $70 by mid-year due to growing demand and optimism about the COVID-19 vaccine rollout. The US is also seeing an increase in crude stocks, with 7.4 million barrels added in the week to February 26.

site_title: Can fashion be a form of self-care?
summary: Italian designers are embracing tactile pleasure in their collections, creating clothes that provide a sense of comfort and physical interaction. Collections from Marni, Valentino, and Armani feature soft fabrics, layering, and intricate details that invite the wearer to touch and feel. This "self-care" approach to fashion is a response to the pandemic's isolation and a desire for physical connection. Designers are using their runway shows as a way to express intimacy and human connection, blurring the lines between fashion and art. The result is a season of "swaddling clothes" that prioritize comfort and sensation over traditional notions of style and elegance.

site_title: UK economy to regain pre-pandemic size earlier than forecast
summary: The UK economy is expected to regain its pre-pandemic size by mid-2022, six months earlier than forecast, according to finance minister Rishi Sunak. The economy will remain 3% smaller than it would have been without the coronavirus crisis. To mitigate the impact, the government will extend emergency aid until the country lifts its coronavirus restrictions.

site_title: Global cargo traffic jam could last into 2022, freight CEO warns
summary: A global cargo traffic jam could last into 2022, according to C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. CEO Bob Biesterfeld, citing dislocations in the domestic freight markets and constraints in air-freight and ocean markets. This has led to increased shipping costs, with air-freight prices doubling from a year ago and maritime rates surging nearly quadrupled. Retailers and manufacturers will face higher costs, while truckers, air-freight companies, and maritime shipping lines will benefit.

site_title: Turning homes into 'mini solar power stations'
summary: India's Kerala state is launching a new solar rooftop program, "Soura," aimed at installing solar panels on 75,000 homes to reduce carbon emissions and cut reliance on imported power. The program, which aims to cover 10% of the state's electricity needs, offers subsidies to encourage residents to sign up, making solar panels more affordable for ordinary people. The project is part of Kerala's plan to generate 1,000 MW of electricity from the sun by 2022, and could help the state reduce its reliance on imported power and lower its carbon emissions.

site_title: Dubai developer Emaar to take over mall unit amid slump
summary: Dubai developer Emaar Properties PJSC plans to take over its malls unit, Emaar Malls, amid a property downturn in the Middle East. Emaar Properties proposed a 0.51 share offer, valuing Emaar Malls at $8.7 billion. The offer, a 10% premium, is seen as low by some investors. Shares of both companies rose, with Emaar Malls jumping 8.3% and Emaar Properties climbing 5%. The takeover is driven by the coronavirus pandemic and a property glut in Dubai, which has driven prices down by over a third since the market peaked.

site_title: France to widen use of AstraZeneca's Covid vaccine to elderly
summary: France has expanded its guidelines for AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine, allowing it to be used to immunize the elderly after previously limiting shots to younger people. Health Minister Olivier Veran stated that all three vaccines currently in use show "remarkable efficacy."

site_title: Committees to look into Progressive Wage Model for food services and retail sectors: Zaqy
summary: Singapore has formed two tripartite cluster committees to explore implementing the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for the food services and retail sectors over the next two to three years. The committees will assess the skills workers must attain to qualify for higher wages in these sectors, which could benefit up to 218,000 workers. The government aims to eventually cover all low-wage workers with progressive wages, while balancing the need for meaningful wage increases with the viability of small and medium enterprises.

site_title: Skills funding to be tweaked as economy shifts post-pandemic
summary: Singapore's government has tweaked skills funding to support post-pandemic economic recovery, with Minister of State for Education Gan Siow Huang announcing a shift towards shorter training courses. The SGUnited Skills Programme and SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme will be extended until March 31, 2022, with a focus on courses lasting six months or less. This change aims to help trainees transition to employment quickly and address the growing demand from firms planning to expand. Funding support will be limited to courses with strong employment outcomes, and the government plans to phase out certain schemes and cap company claims.

images.alt_text: Goverment support for skills training schemes has been beefed up under the latest national Budget.

site_title: A US$21t Treasuries mystery bedevils global markets
summary: US Treasury yields experienced a sudden and jarring move last week, prompting concerns about the liquidity of the $21 trillion bond market. The episode, which saw the gap between bid and offer prices for 30-year bonds hit its widest since March 2020, has raised questions about the market's vulnerability to turbulence. Analysts point to heightened bank regulations, improved economic readings, and ultra-loose Fed policy as potential culprits, but regulators are also exploring changes to bolster the market's structure. The episode has sparked calls for change, with some arguing that the market's functioning has broken down and that redesign is needed.

site_title: SGX-listed Sarine Tech to seek dual listing on Tel Aviv Stock Exchange
summary: Sarine Technologies, a Singapore-listed diamond technology firm, plans to seek a dual listing on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE) in the second quarter of this year. The move comes as the company has "progressively generated growing interest" in its business and equities in the Israeli investment market. The dual listing will expose the company to a broader investing public, including the US, with a time difference of only seven hours. Sarine's shares closed unchanged at S$0.495 before the announcement.

site_title: Britain to ease listing rules to buttress London after Brexit
summary: The UK government plans to modernize its listing rules to make London more competitive after Brexit, following a review led by former European Commissioner Jonathan Hill. The proposed changes include allowing dual shares and lower free float requirements to attract high-growth companies, and liberalizing listing rules for special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs). The Financial Conduct Authority will consult on the proposed changes, which aim to close a gap with other global financial centers. The government faces pressure to act after Brexit led to euro stock and swaps trading leaving London for Amsterdam and New York.

site_title: Pacific International Lines' debt restructuring plan receives court sanction
summary: Pacific International Lines (PIL) has received court sanction for its debt restructuring plan, allowing the company to proceed with a US$600 million investment by Heliconia Capital Management to rescue the company. The plan, approved by creditors last month, will dilute the stakes held by PIL's executive chairman's family to under 15%. The scheme aims to restructure PIL's debt, with the majority shareholder being Heliconia Capital Management, a unit of Temasek Holdings. The company's creditors, including secured lenders and unsecured claimants, will benefit from the investment.

site_title: S'pore's post-pandemic future rests on empowering women entrepreneurs
summary: Singapore's post-pandemic future relies on empowering women entrepreneurs, despite the city-state's ranking slipping to 24th in the Mastercard Index of Women Entrepreneurs in 2020. Many successful women, such as Grab co-founder Tan Hooi Ling and Love Bonito's Rachel Lim, have paved their own paths to success. However, countless women still struggle economically, with difficulties exacerbated by the pandemic. To address this, the government must prioritize initiatives that support and uplift women in the business community, fostering a more inclusive and equitable economic environment.

site_title: US proptech start-up in US$3b SPAC deal for IPO
summary: US real estate technology company Doma has agreed to go public through a merger with blank-cheque acquisition firm Capitol Investment Corp V, valuing the start-up at around $3 billion. The deal includes debt and is supported by the US housing market boom, driven by cheaper mortgages and the shift to remote work. Doma's system aims to make real estate transactions more efficient, and the company expects up to $645 million in cash from the deal. The merger is part of a growing trend of proptech start-ups going public through SPAC deals.

site_title: Raising of retirement, re-employment ages will go ahead as planned in 2022
summary: Singapore's plan to raise the statutory retirement age to 63 and re-employment age to 68 will proceed as scheduled on July 1, 2022, according to Manpower Minister Josephine Teo. The public service will also advance the retirement age to 65 and re-employment age to 70 by the end of the decade. Additionally, Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution rates for senior workers will increase on January 1, 2022, pending unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Deloitte to pay Malaysia US$80m to settle claims linked to 1MDB
summary: Deloitte agrees to pay Malaysia $80 million to settle claims related to its auditing of 1MDB accounts from 2011 to 2014. The audit firm has been under scrutiny for its role in the scandal linked to at least $4.5 billion stolen from the state fund between 2009 and 2014. The settlement will expedite payment of outstanding obligations and avoid potentially costly court battles. This is the largest 1MDB-related settlement involving an audit firm in Southeast Asia, following similar deals with Goldman Sachs and AmBank.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands shuts door on US gambling hub with US$6.25b asset sale
summary: Las Vegas Sands, founded by Sheldon Adelson, is selling its US properties for $6.25 billion, exiting the US gaming market after 30 years to focus on Asia, particularly Macau. The sale includes the Venetian Resort Las Vegas and the Sands Expo and Convention Center. The move comes after the company reported a loss of $1.69 billion in 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The sale will help fund future growth in other domestic and global markets, with analysts viewing it as a net positive for the company.

site_title: HSI's facelift sparks calls to revamp STI to include key growth sectors
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) is under pressure to revamp its composition to better reflect the country's growing economy, following the Hang Seng Index's (HSI) facelift. The STI currently favors real estate and banking stocks, with a 63% market cap representation. Experts suggest adding sectors like technology, healthcare, and e-commerce to improve representation. However, finding a middle tier of companies with sufficient investor interest and liquidity is a challenge. The Singapore Exchange and index administrators are considering revamps, with some arguing that it's essential for the STI to better reflect the country's economic growth.

site_title: China's new policy direction will affect road maps of global economies
summary: China's upcoming National People's Congress (NPC) will approve a long-term plan potentially reshaping the global economy, with President Xi Jinping's "dual circulation" concept aiming to spur domestic consumption and self-reliance. The plan includes boosting per-capita income, new industrialization, and technology strength, while also focusing on eco-friendliness and job creation. China's growth target is expected to be around 8% this year, and the nation is likely to increase its defence spending amid rising tensions in Hong Kong and Taiwan. The plan's impact on global economies and investments will be significant, requiring businesses and investors to adapt their thinking on long-term road maps.

site_title: Women who are powering their own businesses
summary: Four women entrepreneurs, including watchmaker Sherrie Han, singer-songwriter Sarah Cheng De-Winne, tech founder Debbie Lee, and serial F&B entrepreneur Cassandra Riene Tan, share their stories of overcoming industry challenges and pursuing their passions without being held back by gender. They are featured alongside luxury watch brands, art exhibitions, and dining reviews, highlighting the diversity and achievements of women in various fields.

site_title: Intel to pay US$2.18b after losing patent trial
summary: A federal jury in Texas ruled that Intel must pay VLSI Technology $2.18 billion after losing a patent-infringement trial over chip-making technology. The jury found Intel infringed on two patents, one worth $1.5 billion and the other $675 million. Intel plans to appeal the verdict, which is one of the largest patent-damages awards in US history, and could impact the company's dominance in the $400 billion chip industry.

site_title: Realising the 'Great Realisation': lessons from a pandemic
summary: A recent article discusses the potential silver lining of the COVID-19 pandemic, highlighting lessons that can lead to more constructive policy solutions. The US is seeing widespread support for extending financial support to those hurt by the pandemic, with 76% of voters supporting a $1.9 trillion package. Additionally, there is growing support for reopening schools safely, with a focus on vaccination, testing, and mitigation measures. Furthermore, there is bipartisan support for investing in public research and development to strengthen the education system and develop new technologies. The article concludes that by realising the lessons of COVID-19, the US can be better prepared to face future challenges.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ExxonMobil announced plans to cut 7% of its workforce in Singapore, impacting approximately 300 positions by the end of 2021. The oil major cited 'unprecedented market conditions' as the reason for the restructuring.

site_title: Survey shows weaker than expected US private hiring in February
summary: US private employers added 117,000 jobs in February, less than expected, indicating the economy's continued struggle to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. The service sector saw all hiring gains, while the goods-producing sector declined by 14,000. Analysts forecast stronger payroll growth, but the ADP report suggests the Labor Department's monthly employment data may show weaker hiring. The unemployment rate remains at 6.3%.

site_title: Hiring of local workers would have been slower without Jobs Growth Incentive: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) has helped to facilitate the hiring of local workers, with over 110,000 new hires supported from September to October 2020. Minister Josephine Teo stated that the JGI "lubricated the process" of workers moving into growing firms and industries, and that it may also be addressing unemployment and underemployment. However, Teo emphasized that the JGI is an "extraordinary measure" and that employers should not delay local hiring in hopes of extending the program indefinitely.

site_title: US: Bond uptick spooks stocks at open
summary: US Treasury bond rates rose slightly, leading to a mixed opening on Wall Street. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 31,499.65, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5% to 13,295.63, and the S&P 500 fell 0.1% to 3,866.71. The mixed opening was attributed to traders' uncertainty, with the focus shifting to Friday's government employment report, which could indicate the US economy's recovery from Covid-19.

site_title: A coming-out party for KAWS
summary: American artist Brian Donnelly, aka KAWS, has unveiled his first major museum survey, "KAWS: WHAT PARTY," at the Brooklyn Museum, showcasing his 25-year career. The exhibition, curated by Eugenie Tsai, features 167 objects, including early street work, collaborations with brands, and cartoon characters like The Simpsons and Smurfs. Donnelly's work is characterized by its use of appropriation and pop culture references, blurring the lines between high and low art. The exhibition highlights his commercial success and explores themes of mass culture, identity, and the art market.

site_title: Singapore, regional markets surge on receding US inflation fears
summary: Singapore and regional markets surged on Wednesday, driven by receding US inflation fears, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 26.5 points or 0.89% to 3,000.37. DBS and OCBC hit 52-week highs, while UOB ended just two cents below its record high. The Hang Seng Index, Shanghai Composite Index, and other regional markets also rose, with Japan's Nikkei 225 Index and South Korea's Kospi index increasing by 0.51% and 1.29% respectively.

site_title: UK economy to regain pre-pandemic size earlier than forecast
summary: The UK economy is expected to regain its pre-pandemic size in the middle of 2022, six months earlier than forecast, according to finance minister Rishi Sunak. The economy will remain 3% smaller in five years compared to the pre-pandemic size, prompting the government to extend emergency aid measures. Sunak announced a five-month extension of the jobs rescue plan, increased support for the self-employed, and continued emergency welfare payments. The Office for Budgetary Responsibility forecasts 4% growth in 2021 and 7.3% growth in 2022.

site_title: Boeing cites risks in design of newest Airbus jet
summary: Boeing has expressed concerns over Airbus' A321XLR design, citing risks associated with a novel fuel tank that could pose fire hazards. The US giant submitted its concerns to the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) amid a pivotal moment for Airbus, which faces tougher regulatory scrutiny following the 20-month grounding of its 737 MAX. The A321XLR's fuel tank, which is molded into the fuselage, could expose passengers to increased risk if a fire occurs, Boeing warned. The issue may delay the A321XLR's service entry from late 2023 to 2024 or beyond.

site_title: Former Hong Kong chief does not rule out return to post
summary: Former Hong Kong Chief Executive CY Leung, a vocal supporter of Beijing's control, left open the possibility of returning to his post, citing his desire to serve Hong Kong and China. Leung, 66, has been a high-profile figure since his surprise announcement in 2016 not to stand for a second term. His eligibility to run for chief executive, whose term expires in March 2022, remains uncertain due to the requirement of being a Chinese citizen at least 40 years old with over 20 years of residency in Hong Kong.

site_title: DBS applies for Sen Yue and subsidiary to be placed under judicial management
summary: DBS has applied to the High Court for Sen Yue Holdings and its subsidiary SMC Industrial to be placed under judicial management due to outstanding debts of around S$5.9 million and US$9 million. The move comes after the subsidiary received a letter of demand from DBS in January and failed to pay the sums. A pre-trial conference is scheduled for March 18. Sen Yue is reviewing the applications and seeking legal advice. The company is facing other financial woes and is currently under investigation by the Commercial Affairs Department.

site_title: Thai Airways revamp plan gets support from top shareholder
summary: Thai Airways International has received support from its top shareholder, the Thai finance ministry, for a restructuring plan. The plan includes raising US$1.65 billion in fresh capital, cutting its workforce by half, and deferring bond repayments for six years. The airline aims to return to profit by 2024 and has posted a record loss of US$4.7 billion last year.
