The finance ministry will study the proposals before deciding on its vote, and the creditors are expected to vote on the plan on May 12.

site_title: Myanmar security forces kill 18 anti-coup protesters despite calls for restraint
summary: Myanmar security forces killed at least 18 anti-coup protesters on Wednesday, despite calls for restraint from neighboring countries. The killings occurred in several towns and cities, including Yangon, Mandalay, and Monywa, as the junta attempted to suppress protests against the February 1 coup that ousted the elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi. The violence brings the total death toll to at least 40 since the coup, with many more injured. International leaders, including Pope Francis, have condemned the violence and urged the authorities to engage in dialogue instead of repression.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose 0.8-0.7% at the start of trading, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. London's FTSE 100 index led the gains, followed by Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40. The strong performance comes ahead of Britain's annual budget announcement and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: ExxonMobil pitches investors on dividend growth, debt reduction
summary: ExxonMobil presented its investor day plans, focusing on dividend growth, debt reduction, and cost-cutting measures amid investor pressure for better financial returns and climate action. The company reaffirmed its spending plans, expecting flat oil and gas production through mid-decade, and announced plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15-20% from 2016 levels. ExxonMobil also showcased its Low Carbon Solutions Business and commercialized carbon emissions-cutting technology, aiming to "lean in" on cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 18.58 points to 1,588.45, with a trading volume of 10.780 billion lots worth RM6.180 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 631 to 559.

site_title: STI up 0.89%; DBS and OCBC at 52-week highs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 26.5 points or 0.89% to 3,000.37, driven by gains from DBS and OCBC, which hit 52-week highs at S$27.48 and S$11.25 respectively. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index led regional gains, up 2.7%. The Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index also rose, while Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi index followed suit.

site_title: Asia Partners closes debut fund at US$384m in commitments
summary: Asia Partners, a Singapore-based growth equity investor, has closed its debut fund at US$384 million in commitments. The fund's limited partners include the US International Development Finance Corporation and the Deutsche Investitions-und Entwicklungsgesellschaft from Germany. Asia Partners' co-founders and advisory board, chaired by Hsieh Fu Hua, hold over 7% of the fund's capital. This achievement highlights the growing presence of Asian investors in the venture capital market.

site_title: Skills training funds extended - but with plans for shorter courses, eventual tapering
summary: Singapore's government has extended support for skills-training schemes, but with plans to reduce course lengths and eventually taper off funding. The Enhanced Training Support Package will run until December 2021, while the SGUnited Skills Programme and SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme will be extended to March 2022. The government aims to focus on training that delivers strong employment outcomes, with a focus on industries with "good hiring opportunities" and "career transition programmes".

site_title: Union Gas studying potential of redeveloping fuel station into multi-fuels and energy facility
summary: Union Gas Holdings is studying the potential to redevelop its fuel station in Singapore into a multi-fuels and energy facility, in collaboration with Surbana Jurong. The proposed facility could include sustainable energy delivery, storage, and electric vehicle charging stations. The study aims to explore options such as renewable energy solutions, battery storage, and natural gas-based power generation. The project is expected to be completed within the next six months, with the goal of creating a sustainable energy hub in Singapore. This move is part of Union Gas' strategic plan to diversify and enhance its business.

site_title: Foreign Employees Dormitories Act to be reviewed, and to cover all dorms
summary: Singapore's Foreign Employees Dormitories Act (FEDA) will be reviewed to cover all dormitories, regardless of size, to establish common housing standards and safe-living requirements. The review aims to prevent disease outbreaks and enable the Ministry of Manpower to directly impose requirements. The government plans to engage stakeholders and complete the review by the second half of this year, with potential adjustments to dormitory standards that may result in higher costs for employers and dorm operators.

site_title: Thai activist arrested for burning king's portrait
summary: Thai activist Chaiamorn "Ammy" Kaewwiboonpan, 32, was arrested for burning a portrait of King Maha Vajiralongkorn, a gesture of defiance and frustration over fellow activists' detention. He faces charges under Thailand's strict lese majeste law, which carries a penalty of up to 15 years in prison, as well as arson and computer crimes. This incident is the latest in a series of arrests for royal insult in recent months, sparking concerns about freedom of expression in Thailand.

site_title: Singapore SPAC to merge with the 'Spotify of the Middle-East'
summary: Singapore-based Vistas Media Acquisition Company (VMAC) is in talks to merge with music streaming service Anghami, valuing the Middle Eastern startup at over $200 million. VMAC, backed by Vistas Media, raised $100 million in a public listing in 2020. If successful, the deal could mark Anghami as one of the first Middle Eastern tech companies to list on the Nasdaq stock exchange in New York. The merger is expected to be announced soon and finalise financing.

site_title: SMIC buys US$1.2b manufacturing tools from ASML
summary: China's largest chipmaker, Semiconductor Manufacturing International (SMIC), has agreed to buy $1.2 billion in manufacturing tools from ASML Holding, a move that follows US sanctions on the company. The tools include extreme ultraviolet lithography machines needed for advanced chip production. The deal comes after the US Commerce Department blacklisted SMIC due to concerns over China's military activities and ties with Chinese military industrial companies. This sale is seen as a setback for US efforts to restrict China's access to advanced chipmaking technology.

site_title: Perennial-led group to develop project in Hangzhou's 'Silicon Valley'
summary: Perennial Holdings has won a tender to develop a 2.9 billion yuan (S$591.3 million) project in Hangzhou's 'Silicon Valley'. The site, adjacent to the south square of the upcoming Hangzhou West High Speed Railway Station, will feature an integrated Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) with retail, apartment, office, and hotel components. The project is part of a 13-square-kilometer TOD district, which is expected to attract science and technology firms, including the Alibaba headquarters nearby. The entire precinct is set to be transformed into Hangzhou's "Silicon Valley".

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 2.70% on Wednesday, driven by positive news on vaccines. The Hang Seng Index rose to 29,880.42, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.95%. Despite a year-long advance, traders remain cautious about a possible correction. The gains follow previous day's steep losses, with investors focusing on vaccine developments and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Committees formed to look into Progressive Wage Model for food services and retail
summary: Singapore has formed two tripartite cluster committees to explore the implementation of the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for food services and retail sectors over the next two to three years. The committees will provide recommendations on an implementation timeline, taking into account stakeholders' concerns. The PWM, which sets out skills workers must attain for higher wages, aims to uplift wages for cleaners and security officers. The government will carefully calibrate the approach, balancing worker benefits with business viability, and will support the transition alongside employers and consumers.

site_title: S$10m for jobs transformation maps to study impact of tech on jobs: Josephine Teo
summary: The Singapore government is allocating S$10 million over two years to create jobs transformation maps (JTM) to aid companies in workforce planning. Three sectors - human resources, logistics, and financial services - have completed their JTMs, with plans for another 12 sectors, including wholesale trade, retail, and food manufacturing. The initiative aims to help companies adapt to technological changes and prepare for the future job market.

site_title: Hyflux has at least seven non-binding offers as cash runs out
summary: Hyflux, a Singaporean water-treatment company, has received at least seven non-binding offers from potential investors as its cash dwindles. The company had $18.4 million in cash as of January 31, enough to last five months. The judicial manager is seeking binding offers by March 31 and aims to finalize term sheets with shortlisted investors by April 15. The company's restructuring process, which began in 2018, continues, with the outcome uncertain. The offers have varying complexity, and the judicial manager is assessing whether the company will be restructured or its assets sold piecemeal.

site_title: Asia growth drives 4% rise in Prudential 2020 operating profit
summary: Prudential's operating profit rose 4% in 2020, driven by a 13% increase in Asia-adjusted operating profit to $3.7 billion. The life insurer will split off its US business, Jackson, through a demerger and may raise $2.5-3 billion in new equity. The proposed demerger marks Prudential's shift to a growth business focusing on Asia and Africa, with CEO Mike Wells stating the move will complete the company's structural transformation. Prudential shares rose 0.9% to £14.98.

site_title: Microsoft says China-linked group targets exchange email
summary: Microsoft has warned customers to download software patches after Chinese state-sponsored hackers broke into Microsoft Exchange Server, exploiting previously undiscovered vulnerabilities. The hackers, operating out of China, targeted on-premises versions of the software, allowing them to access email accounts and install malware. Microsoft released patches and urged customers to patch their systems immediately. The hackers have been linked to targeting entities in the US across various industries. Chinese authorities have called for caution, emphasizing the need for complete evidence before making conclusions.

site_title: Samsung considers four sites in US for US$17b chip plant: documents
summary: Samsung Electronics is considering four sites in the US for a $17 billion chip plant, including two in Arizona and one in New York, in addition to its existing site in Austin, Texas. The new plant would produce advanced logic devices and create 1,800 jobs. Samsung is seeking combined tax abatements of $1.48 billion over 20 years from Travis County in Texas and the city of Austin. The company is also exploring infrastructure improvements with the Arizona and New York sites.

site_title: Hot stock: FJ Benjamin soars after announcing partnership with Lazada
summary: FJ Benjamin's shares soared 130% to S$0.046 after announcing a partnership with Lazada Singapore, removing it from the Singapore Exchange's watchlist. The partnership aims to expand and incubate new FJB brands and boost e-commerce performance in Singapore and Southeast Asian markets. This follows a successful restructuring that brought the company's earnings back to black, with net profit improving to S$177,000 in FY2019.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb as strong GDP growth cements recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% on Wednesday, driven by a stronger-than-expected economic growth of 3.1% in the final quarter of 2020, higher than forecasted 2.5%. The recovery hopes are fueled by low Covid-19 transmission and timely fiscal and monetary stimulus.

images.alt_text: Australian shares climbed on Wednesday after a much faster-than-expected economic growth in the final quarter of 2020 cemented hopes of a stronger recovery this year.

site_title: Putting AI into sailing
summary: An AI bot has learned to sail like an Olympic sailor as part of a bid to win the America's Cup, showcasing the technological edge in the competition. The America's Cup, a sailing trophy, has a long history of technological innovation, with recent advancements in hydrofoils and winged keels. The AI bot's success highlights the growing importance of artificial intelligence in various industries.

site_title: Four dead in Myanmar as police fire to break up protests
summary: Myanmar security forces opened fire, killing four people during protests against the military coup, with at least 24 deaths reported since the coup on February 1. Protests continue nationwide, with hundreds detained, including protest leaders. A regional diplomatic push to end the crisis made little headway, with only four Asean members calling for the release of ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi and other detainees. The military has justified the coup, citing voter fraud, and has pledged to hold new elections but given no time frame.

site_title: Singaporean retiree among 2 new community cases
summary: An 82-year-old Singaporean man has been identified as one of two new community cases of COVID-19. He initially tested negative but developed symptoms on February 14 and was later confirmed positive after a second test. The second case is a 38-year-old asymptomatic permanent resident who tested positive after a pre-departure test. The total number of cases in Singapore has risen to 59,979, with 21 imported cases and 18 patients still in hospital.

site_title: SGX invests US$1.5m to take up stake in HeveaConnect
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has invested US$1.5 million in rubber trading platform HeveaConnect (HC) through its subsidiary, acquiring a 9.09% stake. As part of the deal, future prices of Sicom rubber contracts will be made available on HeveaConnect's platform. Following the investment, Halcyon Agri's total equity interest in HC will decrease from 71.1% to 49.9%, and the company will no longer be a subsidiary but an associated company.

site_title: Dependant's Pass holders must apply for work passes from May 1
summary: Dependant's Pass holders in Singapore will need to apply for a relevant work pass starting May 1, 2021, instead of using a letter of consent to seek employment. Currently, about 1% of work pass holders use this method, and most DP holders do not work during their stay. Existing DP holders working on an LOC will be allowed to continue until the letter expires, and their employers will need to apply for a work pass if they wish to keep employing them. Business owners who meet specified criteria can continue running their business with an LOC.

site_title: Gold prices under pressure on firm US Treasury yields
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.2% to $1,734.26 per ounce, falling for a sixth session in seven, due to expectations of higher US Treasury yields on further economic stimulus. Analysts say the Federal Reserve's reluctance to control yields and the prospect of an earlier-than-planned rate hike will continue to pressure gold prices. Benchmark US Treasury yields held near 1.4% levels, and investors await the Senate's debate on the $1.9 trillion US stimulus bill. Higher yields increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, which pays no interest, making it a less attractive hedge against inflation.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end higher as US yields retreat, China policy anxiety eases
summary: South Korean shares ended higher on Wednesday as US Treasury yields retreated and concerns about China's policy tightening eased. The Kospi index rose 1.29% to 3,082.99, with heavyweights Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix gaining 0.48% and 1.73%, respectively. Internet giant Naver and biopharmaceutical firm Celltrion also saw significant gains. The won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell, contributing to the market's rebound.

site_title: Nutrition Technologies raises US$5m, opens insect protein factory in Malaysia
summary: Nutrition Technologies, a Singapore-based agrifoodtech startup, has raised US$5 million in funding, bringing its total to US$14 million, to support research and development and expand into new markets in South-east Asia. The company has opened its first industrial-scale insect protein factory in Malaysia, which spans 2.5 hectares and produces 16,000 tonnes of insect products per year, diverting 80,000 tonnes of waste from landfills and saving fishmeal. The company aims to establish a large network of insect farms across the region and raise US$30 million in Series B funds.

site_title: Australia's Attorney-General denies rape allegation
summary: Australia's Attorney-General Christian Porter has denied raping a 16-year-old girl in 1988, calling the allegations "false" and "untrue". Porter, 50, made the denial after speculation about his involvement in the decades-old incident sparked a crisis in the conservative government. The alleged rape occurred during a debating competition at the University of Sydney. Porter, a former state prosecutor, has denied wrongdoing, stating "what is being alleged did not happen".

site_title: Lasalle, Nafa to set up new private arts university with government backing
summary: Singapore plans to establish a new private arts university by 2025, in partnership with Lasalle College of the Arts and Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (Nafa), backed by the government. The university will have degree-granting powers and be supported by the Ministry of Education and Ministry of Culture. It aims to nurture talent in specialized fields, foster collaboration, and contribute to Singapore's cultural life. The MOE has appointed a pro-tem committee to develop the university's structure and operating model, with a focus on retaining the institutions' distinctive identities.

site_title: Singapore's unemployment rates continue to decline in January: MOM
summary: Singapore's unemployment rates declined in January, with the overall unemployment rate edging down to 3.2% and the resident unemployment rate falling to 4.3%. The citizen unemployment rate remained steady at 4.5%. Additionally, 93% of firms offered some form of flexible work arrangement, and 97% of employees had access to it.

site_title: COEs end mostly lower at latest tender
summary: COE prices ended mostly lower in the latest tender, with the COE for cars up to 1,600cc and 130bhp finishing at S$41,996, a slight increase from the previous price. The commercial vehicle COE dropped by more than S$3,000, while the motorcycle premium rose to S$7,752. The open COE, which is mostly used for bigger cars, ended at S$47,001, down slightly from the previous price. The new emission scheme taking effect in April is believed to have contributed to the drop in commercial vehicle COE prices.

site_title: Johor prince puts Valencia in his sights
summary: Malaysia's crown prince, Tunku Ismail Sultan Ibrahim, has sparked speculation of a takeover bid for Spanish football club Valencia after expressing his ambition to "create history" with the team. He believes Valencia needs someone "hungry for success". The prince's comments come after billionaire businessman Peter Lim, Valencia's owner, has been under pressure to sell the club.

site_title: US coffee roasters weigh price increases, cite shipping inflation
summary: US coffee roasters are expected to raise retail prices due to significant cost increases in operations, mainly related to transportation. Mid-sized and smaller roasters, especially specialty coffee companies, have been hit hardest. Larger companies like Peet's and JM Smucker are also coping with higher costs. Shipping inflation, reported by S&P Global Platts, may have added nearly $10 billion to corporate costs in the fourth quarter of 2020, with potential growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, advancing 0.51% or 150.93 points to 29,559.10, driven by gains on Asian shares. The broader Topix index also rose 0.51% or 9.69 points to 1,904.54. The market was influenced by US jobs data expected later this week, with traders keeping a close eye on the release.

site_title: Fortune Park near Kovan MRT station up for collective sale at S$115-118m
summary: A 10-storey freehold residential block, Fortune Park, near Kovan MRT station is up for collective sale with an indicative price tag of S$115-118 million. The property, comprising 68 apartments, has a land area of 44,878 sq ft and a gross plot ratio of 2:1. Developers can redevelop the site into an 88-unit apartment, with a proposed gross floor area of nearly 94,245 sq ft. The sale will close on April 22 via public tender.

site_title: Pandemic-era investment rules pose hurdles for sovereign funds: report
summary: Sovereign wealth funds face increased regulatory scrutiny in areas like pharmaceuticals, infrastructure, technology, and logistics due to the pandemic. Governments of over 50 countries imposed rules on pandemic-related exports, and regulators are reviewing foreign investments with enhanced scrutiny. Investments in these sectors have grown, with pharmaceuticals, software, and biotech attracting the largest investments. The trend is expected to accelerate post-pandemic, with increased time and costs associated with regulatory reviews.

site_title: Five things to know about ExxonMobil's Singapore layoffs
summary: ExxonMobil will cut 300 positions at its Singapore affiliate, approximately 7% of its 4,000-strong workforce, due to "unprecedented market conditions." The layoffs will affect employees, who will be informed starting March 8. This move comes amid a challenging oil market, with the US oil giant seeking to adapt to changing market conditions. The company's Singapore operations will continue to operate with the remaining workforce. The layoffs are part of ExxonMobil's efforts to adjust to the current market environment.

site_title: Asia: Equities advance but inflation, correction worries persist
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, but investors remain cautious due to concerns about asset bubbles and inflation. The expected passage of Joe Biden's stimulus package and a surge in vaccine distribution are contributing to a narrative of a global economic burst in the second half of the year. However, reflation expectations and rising interest rates are causing anxiety, which may lead to a correction in the market. Despite this, many experts believe the market is still in a bull trend, with some predicting a natural pullback if interest rates rise.

site_title: Maezawa wants you: Japan billionaire seeks 'crew' for moon trip
summary: Japanese billionaire Yusaku Maezawa is searching for eight crew members to join him on a week-long trip around the moon in 2023 on SpaceX's Starship. Originally planning to invite artists, Maezawa has broadened the selection process to include anyone who sees themselves as an artist. Applicants must pass medical checks and an interview with Maezawa before being chosen. The trip, costing over $110 million, will be the first private journey beyond Earth's orbit, with Maezawa watching his alcohol intake and exercising to prepare mentally.

site_title: Digital wallets to overtake credit cards by 2024 amid e-commerce boom: report
summary: Digital wallets are expected to surpass credit cards as the most popular online payment method in Singapore by 2024, driven by the e-commerce boom fueled by the pandemic. According to a report by Worldpay from FIS, digital wallets accounted for 20% of online payments in 2020 and are projected to reach 27% by 2024, while credit cards remain the preferred in-store payment method. The e-commerce market in Singapore is expected to grow 40% over the next four years, reaching US$10 billion, with digital wallets capturing a significant share.

site_title: Volocopter raises 200m euros for air taxi certification push
summary: German aviation startup Volocopter raised 200 million euros from investors including BlackRock to seek certification for its battery-powered flying taxi. The funding round brings the total amount raised to 322 million euros. Volocopter aims to bring its VoloCity air taxi into commercial service within the next two years, while also deploying heavy-lift cargo drones with logistics group DB Schenker.

site_title: Goldman to swell to record size in Singapore with 100 tech hires
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to add approximately 100 staff in Singapore, taking its headcount in the city to a record 1,000. The new hires will mainly be in technology, following a tumultuous period in the region. The move aims to grow the bank's franchise across all products, particularly in wealth management and commodities trading. Goldman Sachs joins global rivals expanding in Singapore, which has become a rapidly growing wealth management centre and alternative to Hong Kong. The bank's hiring plans were not impacted by the 1MDB scandal, which hurt its reputation globally.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Wednesday; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 13.25 points or 0.5% to 2,987.12. Gainers outnumbered losers 83 to 48, driven by local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC, which rose 1.4%, 0.4%, and 0.8% respectively. US investors retreated due to a bond yield jump, while European equities ended higher amid optimism about an economic recovery.

site_title: US to impose anti-dumping tax on 18 countries
summary: The US Department of Commerce is set to impose anti-dumping and countervailing duties on aluminum sheet exporters from 18 countries, including Germany, Bahrain, and India, after finding they had benefited from subsidies and dumping. The decision follows an investigation launched under the Trump administration, which found that imports from these countries were priced below the cost of production or local market prices. The US International Trade Commission must approve the final decision by April 15, with the aim of providing relief to American companies and industries impacted by unfair trade.

site_title: ExxonMobil to cut 7% of Singapore workforce, cites 'unprecedented market conditions'
summary: ExxonMobil plans to cut about 7% of its workforce in Singapore, impacting around 300 positions by the end of 2021. The move is attributed to "unprecedented market conditions" due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite this, the city state remains a strategic location for the company, housing its largest refinery and integrated petrochemical complex. ExxonMobil cited the need to improve competitiveness and strengthen its business foundation for future success.

site_title: Time for a renewed focus on ESG in Asean
summary: Asean governments recognize the importance of rebuilding better using Environmental, Social, and Corporate Governance (ESG) principles, following the COVID-19 pandemic. The region aims to develop resilience and sustainability, with a focus on transitioning to a low-carbon economy, digital transformation, and green infrastructure. Financial services play a crucial role in promoting ESG, with investors seeking sustainable debt options, and companies that adopt ESG principles are expected to reap benefits, while those that don't risk facing increased costs. By embracing ESG, Asean can navigate a fast-evolving global landscape and support the region's growth and sustainability.

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus tumbles 45.3% amid heavy trading, prompts SGX query
summary: Oceanus Group's shares plummeted 45.3% to 3.5 cents amid heavy trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), prompting a query from the exchange. The company's board attributed the unusual price movements to efforts to grow its business, stating it was unaware of any undisclosed information. This follows a net profit of S$8.6 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2020, reversing a net loss of S$7.4 million for the previous year. The company is also seeking an extension to exit the SGX's watch-list.

site_title: Prickly problem: Taiwan says won't be beaten by China pineapple ban
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen vowed to rally farmers and find new markets after China banned imports of Taiwanese pineapples, citing "harmful creatures." The ban is seen as a political move by China to pressure Taiwan. The Taiwanese government denies the charge, calling it a "clear case of economic coercion." Tsai stated that Taiwan will not be intimidated and will work to increase domestic sales and explore new export opportunities. The move is a defiant response to China's actions, which Taiwan sees as an attempt to exert control over the island.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.7 points, or 0.3%, to 1,574.6, with 1.39 billion lots traded worth RM583.6 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 322 to 314. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Toyota US employees to keep masks on in Texas even as state lifts mandate
summary: Toyota US employees will continue to wear face masks despite Texas lifting its mask mandate. The company has no plans to change its policy, with a spokesman stating "the early read is - no change for us." Toyota's US headquarters and factory in Texas will remain compliant with the mask requirement, which was rolled back by Governor Greg Abbott.

site_title: US gaming platform Roblox sees revenue doubling in first quarter
summary: Roblox, a popular gaming platform, expects its revenue to double in the first quarter of 2021 to $320-$335 million, a 98-107% growth from the same period last year. The company also forecasts daily active users of 37.6-39.6 million, up 59-68% from a year earlier. This growth is attributed to the surge in demand for video games during the COVID-19 pandemic. Roblox is going public through a direct listing, which will determine its share price. The company expects full-year revenue between $1.44 billion and $1.52 billion.

site_title: Australia's economy expands at brisk pace in Q4
summary: Australia's economy expanded 3.1% in Q4 2021, exceeding forecast, driven by monetary and fiscal stimulus. This marks the best back-to-back quarters of growth on record. Despite annual output still shrinking 1.1%, the expansion suggests a strong start to 2021. The A$2 trillion economy still requires policy support due to the pandemic's impact.

site_title: South Korea probing two deaths after AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine
summary: South Korean authorities are investigating the deaths of two individuals after receiving AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine. A 63-year-old nursing home patient with cerebrovascular disease died after showing symptoms of blood poisoning and pneumonia, while another person in their 50s with a cardiac disorder and diabetes died after multiple heart attacks. The Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency is investigating the cause of the deaths, but no further details have been confirmed. South Korea has vaccinated over 87,000 people with the AstraZeneca vaccine, with 444 new Covid-19 cases reported.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.3% and the Topix index up 0.1%. The gains came despite falls on Wall Street. The broader market trends are influenced by US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty, with investors staying positive despite split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hiring of locals would have been slower without Jobs Growth Incentive: Josephine Teo
summary: Singapore's Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) helped facilitate the movement of workers into growing firms and industries, Minister Josephine Teo said in Parliament. Without the incentive, hiring would have been slower. Teo signaled that unemployment may not decrease and could even rise, with long-term consequences. An extension of the JGI for seven more months is considered helpful, and the government will assess its effectiveness after September.

site_title: Emerging Towns & Cities suspends trading; to conduct review of Myanmar contract
summary: Emerging Towns & Cities Singapore (ETC) has suspended trading to review its dealings in Myanmar, following allegations that it had contributed millions to the Myanmar army. The company has maintained that its dealings with the military are in accordance with local laws, which involve the military. ETC will engage an independent professional to review its dealings, including its 70% equity interest in a commercial and residential project in Myanmar. The review will also examine the company's fund-raising efforts to provide stakeholders with assurance.

site_title: GuocoLand's Midtown Modern to draw more families, retirees into city area
summary: GuocoLand's Midtown Modern, a 99-year leasehold condominium in Singapore's central area, aims to attract a wider range of buyers, including families and retirees, with its diverse unit sizes. The project features one- to four-bedroom units, including penthouses, and offers amenities such as a 50-metre pool, tennis court, and green spaces. Prices start from S$1.1 million, with the largest penthouse costing nearly S$15 million. The condominium is part of the larger Guoco Midtown integrated development, which also includes office and retail spaces. The project is expected to be completed in 2024.

images.alt_text: Slated for completion in 2024, Midtown Modern is a full-facilities condominium in the CBD with over one hectare of gardens and landscaped areas.
Midtown Modern residents will have direct access to Bugis MRT interchange. The luxury residential project, part of Guoco Midtown, is expected to be completed in 2024.
One of the thematic gardens in Midtown Modern, featuring a tea pavilion and lily pond. The luxury residential project is expected to be completed in 2024.

site_title: US oil industry lobby weighs support of carbon pricing: source
summary: The American Petroleum Institute (API), the main US oil industry lobby group, is considering endorsing a price on carbon emissions as part of its efforts to reduce emissions and meet the Paris Agreement's ambitions. The decision comes after a shift in industry strategy and the new US presidency, amid resistance from European member Total and other major industry groups. A draft statement suggests the group does not endorse a specific carbon pricing tool, but its January report was supportive of market-based carbon pricing. API's efforts focus on supporting a new US contribution to the Paris Agreement.

site_title: Australia: Shares climb as upbeat GDP data cements economic recovery hopes
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Wednesday, driven by upbeat GDP data showing a 3.1% growth in the December quarter, beating economists' forecasts. The mining sector led gains, with domestic gold stocks surging 2.9% and mining giants BHP and Rio Tinto advancing 4.5% and 2.4%, respectively. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept interest rates unchanged, supporting the economic recovery hopes.

site_title: Perennial-led group to develop project in precinct of Hangzhou's Silicon Valley
summary: Perennial Holdings has won a tender to develop a 96,931 sq m plot of land adjacent to Hangzhou's upcoming Hangzhou West High Speed Railway (HSR) Station. The project, valued at 2,873.28 million yuan (S$591.3 million), will feature an integrated Transit-Oriented Development (TOD) with retail, apartment, office, and hotel components. The site is part of a new government-designated TOD District, expected to transform into Hangzhou's Silicon Valley-equivalent, with science and technology firms anticipated to set up offices. The project marks Perennial's fifth TOD project in China.

images.alt_text: Together with its partners, Perennial Holdings will develop a plot of land adjacent to the south square of the upcoming Hangzhou West High Speed Railway Station.

site_title: US military wages war on extremism in its own ranks
summary: The US military has begun addressing extremism within its ranks, two months after the US Capitol attack. New Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin ordered units to discuss right-wing and white supremacist extremism. Austin expressed concern that military personnel would hold such beliefs, saying it's "disturbing" for someone in uniform to espouse extremist views. The discussion aims to tackle the difficult issue, which Austin acknowledged would require a sustained effort to overcome.

site_title: US will have enough vaccine supply for all adults by end May: Biden
summary: US President Joe Biden announced that the country will have sufficient vaccine supply by the end of May to inoculate all adult Americans, reversing his previous forecast of July. However, Biden emphasized that having enough vaccine supply is not enough, as the country needs millions of vaccinators to administer the shots. This development comes as the US continues to navigate the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tina Turner meets 'new generation' with moving new documentary
summary: Music legend Tina Turner confronts her demons in a new documentary, "Tina," which premiered at the Berlin film festival. The 81-year-old singer recounts her six-decade career, overcoming abuse and discrimination, including her violent marriage to Ike Turner. Friends, including Oprah Winfrey, weigh in on her journey, praising Turner as a trailblazer for speaking out about her trauma. Turner reflects on her perseverance and power, saying she "slayed her dragons" and continues to slay them, even at 81. The documentary is billed as her farewell to fans while introducing her to a new generation.

site_title: US concludes Russia poisoned Navalny, joins EU in sanctions
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials, including the director of the FSB security service, in response to the poisoning of Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny. US intelligence concluded with "high confidence" that Moscow orchestrated the poisoning, which occurred on August 20, 2020, using the nerve agent Novichok. The sanctions, imposed in coordination with the European Union, target seven senior Russians, including Alexander Kalashnikov, the administrator of Russia's prisons. The move comes as the Biden administration seeks to take a harder line on Russia, while also working to maintain stability and predictability in relations.

images.alt_text: The United States on Tuesday imposed sanctions on senior Russian officials in a coordinated action with the European Union as US intelligence concluded that Moscow orchestrated the near fatal poisoning of jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.5% to 29,249.43 on Wednesday, following a previous day's drop, amid warnings of a financial market bubble and potential inflation. The Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.2%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.4%. Investors remain cautious despite recent rallies in other markets, including Singapore and the US.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher Wednesday morning following the previous day's drop, but investors remain on edge over warnings of a bubble in financial markets and the possibility of surging inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong considering allowing SPAC listings
summary: Hong Kong is exploring allowing Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to list in the Asian financial hub, a move that could make the city a global competitor to the US. A forum of top financial leaders briefed on the development, which follows several Hong Kong tycoons setting up or working on SPACs. The government aims to enhance Hong Kong's competitiveness while safeguarding public interests. This could bring in significant investment, as SPACs raised US$60 billion in the first two months of 2021, exceeding 70% of 2020's annual deal value.

site_title: US halts trials of plasma transfusions for Covid patients
summary: US health experts have halted clinical trials of convalescent plasma transfusions for Covid patients with mild to moderate symptoms, citing preliminary results showing no benefit. The trial, involving over 500 participants, found the treatment unlikely to benefit patients and caused no harm. The US Food and Drug Administration previously granted emergency authorization for the treatment in August, but restrictions have since been imposed to limit its use. The decision follows a similar study in India that found limited effectiveness.

site_title: Japan's service sector shrinks for 13th month as emergency weighs: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector contracted for 13th consecutive month in February due to the coronavirus pandemic, with the au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers'Index (PMI) at 46.3. Demand remained fragile, and export business continued to contract. However, short-term uncertainty appears to be easing with vaccine rollouts. Firms expanded employment levels for the first time since last February, showing optimism for future demand. The composite PMI also remained in contraction for 13th month at 48.2.

site_title: Microsoft sets stage for mixed-reality future
summary: Microsoft launched the Mesh platform, a mixed-reality tool, at its Ignite conference, aiming to enable remote collaboration as if in the same room. The platform combines augmented reality glasses, cloud computing power, and artificial intelligence, allowing users to transcend physical boundaries. Mesh can be synced with various devices, including HoloLens, Oculus, and smartphones, and will initially be used as avatars before projecting lifelike holograms. The tech giant expects developers and partners to build applications and integrate it into services like Teams.

images.alt_text: Microsoft on Tuesday set the stage for a future in which long-distance coworkers can collaborate as though in the same room, using augmented reality glasses and cloud computing power.

site_title: Medtecs in joint venture with US healthcare market player
summary: Medtecs International has entered a joint venture with ACO International, a US healthcare market player, to build a vertically integrated product development, manufacturing, and distribution platform. ACO will assist in site selection for a personal protective equipment (PPE) production facility, and both parties will jointly develop the site. Medtecs and ACO will hold an equal stake in the JV company Resilient Medical. This partnership aims to strengthen Medtecs' presence in the US healthcare market.

site_title: Asia rebuffs US sanctions on Myanmar, giving generals lifeline
summary: Asia's reluctance to join US-led sanctions on Myanmar's military regime has given the generals a diplomatic lifeline. Despite the US imposing targeted sanctions and 18 protesters being killed, countries such as Indonesia and Singapore have not taken concrete action. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has sought to balance calls for the release of Aung San Suu Kyi while avoiding interference in Myanmar's internal affairs. Asian economies, particularly China and Singapore, have significant trade and business ties with Myanmar, making sanctions ineffective.

site_title: Rio Tinto chairman resigns over Aboriginal site destruction
summary: Rio Tinto's chairman, Keith Anderson, has resigned following the destruction of a 46,000-year-old Aboriginal site in Western Australia to expand an iron ore mine. The site, Juukan Gorge, was one of the earliest known locations inhabited by Australia's Indigenous people. The public backlash and investor revolt led to the resignation of the CEO and two top executives in September. Anderson's resignation comes after a period of intense scrutiny over the company's environmental and cultural practices.

site_title: Movie-going has likely changed forever, says Disney CEO
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek believes fundamental changes in people's attitudes toward movie-going will continue even after the pandemic passes, citing consumers' increasing impatience and preference for home viewing. The company will experiment with offering films online for purchase or moving them to streaming services more quickly, rather than maintaining traditional theatrical releases. Chapek emphasized the need for flexibility in distribution channels to meet consumer demand.

site_title: Oil sinks towards US$60 before Opec+ meets to decide on supplies
summary: Oil prices sank below $60 a barrel as the Opec+ alliance is set to agree on a production increase, potentially lifting the market. The group is expected to restore 1.5 million barrels a day of crude output, despite concerns over the market's ability to absorb the increase. Despite this, oil prices have rallied over 20% since the start of the year, supported by Saudi Arabia's output cuts and investor demand. The decision could ease concerns over global oil inventories, which are expected to decline this year, but risks remain for the short-term outlook.

site_title: Britain to ease listing rules to buttress London after Brexit
summary: Britain plans to modernize its listing rules to attract high-growth companies and SPACs to London, following Brexit. Finance Minister Rishi Sunak commissioned a review of listings rules, led by former European Commissioner Jonathan Hill, which will publish recommendations on Wednesday. The changes aim to move London in line with New York and other financial centers, allowing founders to retain control and liberalizing listing rules for SPACs. The government faces pressure to act after euro stock and swaps trading left London for Amsterdam and New York after Brexit.

site_title: Boeing cites risks in design of newest Airbus jet
summary: Boeing has raised concerns over the design of Airbus' newest narrow-body jet, the A321XLR, citing risks associated with a novel fuel tank that could pose fire hazards. The fuel tank, molded into the fuselage to increase range, could expose passengers to inadequate evacuation time in the event of an external fire. Boeing's intervention comes as Airbus faces a crucial test of its certification process following the 20-month grounding of its 737 MAX. The A321XLR's service entry could be delayed, potentially pushing its introduction to 2024 or beyond.

site_title: US lagging in critical artificial intelligence: panel
summary: The US is lagging behind in critical artificial intelligence, according to a National Security Commission report. The country needs to invest $40 billion to compete with China, which is rapidly advancing in AI. Experts warn that AI could be used as a tool for power and as a threat in future conflicts. The commission calls for the creation of a US academy to develop tech talent, increased science and technology education, and a focus on reviving domestic computer chip production. The report concludes that the US must address its AI gap to ensure national security and competitiveness.

site_title: US: Stocks edge down as investors hit pause, watch bond yields
summary: US stocks edged down on Tuesday, following a flat close in Europe and slipping shares in Asia, as investors paused to gauge the impact of a recent bond yield jump. The Dow Jones fell 0.5%, the S&P 500 lost 0.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.7%. Investors took profits from Monday's surge and awaited a US Congress stimulus package, with materials stocks climbing. Bond yields stabilized, and gold prices rose as investors retreated from the dollar and Treasury yields.

site_title: Dublin is top relocation spot for finance firms after Brexit: EY
summary: Dublin has emerged as the top relocation spot for finance firms in the European Union after Brexit, according to a study by EY. Three dozen firms are considering or have already moved UK operations to the Irish capital, with 20 businesses relocating to Paris. The total 7,600 jobs and £1.3 trillion (S$2.4 trillion) in assets are shifting from the UK to the EU bloc. This trend is seen as a response to uncertainty over London's access to EU markets, with EY partner Omar Ali stating that ongoing uncertainty poses the risk of fragmented markets and potential damage to global competitiveness.

site_title: Futu sets up SE-Asia HQ in Singapore as springboard into the region
summary: Futu Holdings, a Tencent Holdings-backed online broker, has set up its Southeast Asia headquarters in Singapore, aiming to launch services and expand into the region. The firm, which operates a popular trading app called moomoo, is also in the process of applying for a virtual banking license in Hong Kong. With a focus on user-friendly platforms and low commissions, Futu seeks to disrupt the online stock brokerage industry in the region, targeting countries such as Vietnam, Thailand, and the Philippines.

site_title: It's evolution, not revolution, in economics
summary: A growing acceptance of aggressive fiscal policy marks a shift in the global economic landscape, with many economists and institutions, including the International Monetary Fund, now advocating for more stimulus to combat the crisis. This perceived "silent revolution in macroeconomics" challenges conventional macroeconomists and raises questions about the future of the field. The shift is seen as a response to the failures of neoliberal ideology, with some hailing it as a post-revolutionary regime.

site_title: New programmes give more access to talent, advice for SMEs, startups
summary: The Singapore Budget 2021 aims to enhance support for startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). New initiatives include the Innovation and Enterprise Fellowship, expanding the Innovation Advisors Programme to more sectors, and introducing specialist advice from SME Centres. The government also plans to develop a competency framework for trade associations and chambers, and enhance support for internationalisation costs, including expanding the Double Tax Deduction for Internationalisation scheme to include virtual trade fairs.

site_title: Intel hit with US$2.2b verdict in US patent trial
summary: A federal jury in Texas has ruled that Intel must pay US$2.2 billion to VLSI Technology in a patent infringement case. The jury found Intel guilty of violating patents related to memory cache and voltage regulation in its chips. Intel plans to appeal the decision, stating it is confident it will prevail. The case, filed in 2019, alleged Intel was "willfully blind" to the patents and forbade employees from reading about them. VLSI obtained the rights to the chips from Dutch tech firm NXP.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance a second day as investors return to risk
summary: European stocks advanced for a second day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index rising 0.2% as investors focused on vaccination efforts and economic recovery. The insurance, construction, mining, and media sectors led gains, while technology shares declined. Despite caution, analysts like Ipek Ozkardeskaya favor cyclical and value sectors for a rapid economic bounce. Investors will monitor economic data, including the US employment report, for clues on policy moves and potential yield spikes.

site_title: Lower-income group still bears brunt of wage deterioration: DBS
summary: Singapore's lower-income group continues to bear the brunt of wage deterioration, with those earning S$2,999 or less accounting for about half of customers experiencing income decline. Overall financial wellness has improved, but 19.4% of customers saw incomes shaved over 10%, with 49% of this sub-group earning less than S$2,999. The report also notes that middle-aged workers are experiencing higher unemployment rates, and younger workers may face further wage cuts if they fail to secure permanent positions.

site_title: Dr Seuss pulls six books over racist imagery
summary: Dr. Seuss Enterprises is pulling six of its children's books from circulation due to racist imagery, including "If I Ran the Zoo" and "The Cat's Quizzer", following a review by experts. The decision comes as criticism grows over the portrayal of minority communities in Dr. Seuss's books. The company stated that the books "portray people in ways that are hurtful and wrong" and aims to ensure its catalog represents and supports all communities and families.

site_title: Flipkart expands grocery sales to more Indian cities
summary: Flipkart, a Walmart-owned e-commerce company, is expanding its online grocery sales to more Indian cities, aiming to reach over 70 locations in six months. The company has already expanded to over 50 cities and has seen exponential growth in its grocery service since the COVID-19 pandemic. This move aims to compete with Amazon and Reliance's JioMart in India's rapidly growing e-grocery market.

site_title: End of the party looms for market high on stimulus
summary: Global markets are expected to turn from a recovery to a boom, potentially ending the stimulus-fueled party. The rapid printing of money in 2020, combined with Americans saving at the highest rate since World War II, led to a surge in online brokerage accounts and trading by middle-class Americans. This year's economic growth could be mirrored to 2020, with markets potentially going flat amid soaring growth. The rapid influx of money and increased time on their hands due to lockdowns contributed to the surge in market participation, but an overheating economy could signal the end of the market rally.

site_title: KKR-backed PropertyGuru weighs US listing via SPAC
summary: KKR-backed PropertyGuru is exploring a US listing via a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC), valuing the combined firm at approximately $1 billion. The Singaporean online real-estate firm, which scrapped IPO plans in Australia in 2019, is in early-stage talks with a financial adviser. PropertyGuru, backed by KKR & Co and TPG Capital, has operations in multiple countries and recently secured $300 million in new funding. The company aims to strike a deal as early as this year, although deliberations are still in their early stages.

site_title: Out of office: Lloyds, Metro Bank join retreat from workplaces
summary: Banks Lloyds and Metro Bank are reducing their office space due to the pandemic, with Lloyds planning to cut its office footprint by 20% by 2023 and Metro Bank booking a £41 million charge to vacate an office in London. HSBC Holdings expects to shrink its property footprint by 40%, and office rents in London's financial districts are expected to fall by 15% this year. The shift to remote work is a long-term trend, with financial firms and technology companies driving demand for flexible office space.

site_title: As businesses change, so should investors
summary: Investors must adapt to a changing corporate landscape where old industry stalwarts fall and new companies emerge. The article highlights the need for investors to adjust to shifting business dynamics, citing General Electric's removal from the Dow Jones Industrial Average in 2018. It also touches on emerging trends such as dollar asset diversification, the growth of ETFs, and the potential for de-dollarisation. The article concludes that productivity gains will be key to unlocking wealth creation in the market.

site_title: Schitt's Creek mansion returns to market at a lower price
summary: A Toronto mansion featured in the popular TV series Schitt's Creek has returned to the market at a lower price. The 24,000-square-foot estate, with 25 film and TV credits, was built by Van Lapoyan and features luxurious amenities such as frescoed ceilings and a marble staircase. The mansion, which was the Rose family's home in the show, is now listed for C$19.9 million (S$20.9 million).

site_title: World will not be rid of Covid-19 by end of this year: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that the world will not be rid of Covid-19 by the end of 2021, despite efforts to reduce hospitalizations and deaths. Global new case numbers increased last week after six consecutive weeks of decline, and the virus remains in control. Vaccinating front-line healthcare workers and vulnerable populations can "take the fear out of the pandemic," but basic public health measures remain crucial. The WHO aims to have Covid-19 vaccination underway in every country within the first 100 days of 2021.

site_title: Sias exploring possibility of unitholders represented in EHT bankruptcy case
summary: Sias, a Singapore investor watchdog, is exploring the possibility of having unitholders represented in the bankruptcy case of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) by an official committee. Interested unitholders can form an informal steering committee by March 8, with a US lawyer submitting a request to the Office for the US Trustee. Meanwhile, Bank of America has filed a motion to dismiss EHT's Chapter 11 cases, which could affect access to a $100 million debtor-in-possession loan facility.

site_title: Challenging maritime protectionism
summary: A new study by the International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) challenges maritime protectionism, highlighting its negative impact on national economies. The study, titled "Protectionism in Maritime Economies," assesses protectionist/restrictive trade policies worldwide and suggests that reducing or removing these measures could benefit economies. The study includes a Prime Index and explores four alternative scenarios for potential reform, revealing that all countries would be better off without reform. The ICS argues that domestic reform and multilateral trade negotiations should be complementary options, rather than mutually exclusive alternatives.

site_title: New income strategies for a low yielding world
summary: A multi-asset income strategy incorporating call writing is recommended for investors seeking higher returns in a low-yielding world. US bond yields have trended upward, driven by market expectations of strong fiscal stimulus and "reflation trades." However, this trend is reminiscent of previous periods, which have seen significant corrections. Historically, global bond yields have trended downward since the early 1980s. Investors should consider diversifying into dollar assets to capitalize on growth in Asia.

images.alt_text: Analysis shows that the buy-write index encapsulates higher Sharpe ratio (or returns over risk ratio) than the S&P 500 Index over the longer term, and tends to outperform during bearish and moderately bullish markets.

site_title: Take a holistic view of Budget support to stay competitive: business leaders
summary: Singaporean business leaders emphasize the need for firms to adopt a holistic approach to utilizing government support schemes to stay competitive during the pandemic. This involves setting clear business objectives, redesigning jobs, and training staff to work with digital solutions. New schemes like the CTO-as-a-Service initiative and Digital Leaders Programme aim to provide businesses with access to IT consultants and digital transformation support. Experts also stress the importance of documenting internal processes and hiring skilled workers, particularly in data analytics and social media management.

site_title: Broadway is dark. London is quiet. But in Australia, it's showtime
summary: Australia's theatre industry has successfully reopened with strict safety protocols, averaging fewer than one daily case per 100,000 people, compared to Britain's 15 and the US's 21. Producers on Broadway and the West End are watching with envy, hoping to learn from Australia's model. The country's strong ticket sales and government incentives have contributed to the industry's recovery. Australia's nationwide coronavirus safety plan has also persuaded officials that theatres can operate safely, paving the way for the global theatre industry's potential rebound.

site_title: Uber spins off robot delivery unit of Postmates
summary: Uber is spinning off its robot delivery unit from Postmates, creating a new company called Serve Robotics. The new company has received seed funding from venture capital firm Neo and other investors. Serve Robotics aims to develop autonomous robots to deliver goods in urban environments, marking a new form of mobility. The spinoff follows Uber's acquisition of Postmates last year.

site_title: Dubai real estate market may bottom out next year, S&P says
summary: Dubai's real estate market is expected to "bottom out" in 2022, according to S&P Global Ratings. Prices have declined by more than a third since 2014 due to a property glut and faltering demand. The market has been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with Dubai suffering the steepest population shrinkage in the Gulf and a 11% contraction in its gross domestic product. Analysts predict two more years of price declines, with the market expected to recover in 2023.

site_title: Singapore PMI eases in Feb, but sentiment remains positive
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) eased to 50.5 in February, down 0.2 points from the previous month, but remains in positive territory. This marks the eighth consecutive month of expansion for the manufacturing sector. The slight decrease is attributed to the Chinese New Year holidays. Despite the slight slowdown, optimism prevails among Singapore manufacturers, indicating a positive sentiment in the economy.

images.alt_text: February's PMI came in at 50.5, down 0.2 point from the previous month, according to the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore's ranks of the ultra-wealthy grew last year despite pandemic: report
summary: Singapore's number of ultra-wealthy individuals increased by 10.2% in 2020, reaching 3,732, making it the Asian country with the second-highest rate of growth. This growth occurred despite the COVID-19 pandemic. Knight Frank's report ranks Singapore as the world's fourth most desirable place for rich Asian home buyers.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: HRnetGroup posted a net profit of S$46.9 million for its full-year 2020, down 9.2% from the previous year, but achieved a record high revenue of S$433 million.

site_title: US dollar stays up as bond market calms
summary: The US dollar rose for a fourth consecutive day, driven by a calming bond market and improving market sentiment, despite recent concerns over inflation. The dollar index reached a one-month high at 91.13, while the Swiss franc hit its lowest since November 2020. Riskier currencies, such as the Australian and New Zealand dollars, also recovered losses. Market experts attribute the dollar's strength to the short end of the yield curve and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Protecting our future is not a zero-sum game
summary: Singapore's Budget 2021 aims to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, but reducing the "green premium" of sources of productivity is crucial. The green premium is the difference in cost between emitting and non-emitting products, and lowering it is key to avoiding a climate disaster. Collective action is necessary to reduce the green premium, including sustainable financing, equitable innovation, and data-driven accountability. Institutional investors are increasingly adopting sustainability-labelled bonds, but the market still lags behind expectations, with only 3% of bonds issued in Singapore being labelled green.

site_title: Why post-Brexit EU needs to assert itself internationally
summary: European leaders met to discuss the EU's role in the world post-Brexit, with a focus on increasing the EU's autonomy and promoting its interests globally. The UK's exit has created a new non-EU power in Western Europe, changing the EU's relationship with other non-EU countries, including Switzerland and Russia. EU leaders also discussed defence and resilience, particularly against cyberattacks and hybrid threats, amid a multipolar world with growing influence from the US, China, and Russia. The EU must assert itself internationally to address these challenges and frame its future relationship with the UK.

site_title: Singapore PMI eases in February but manufacturing sentiment remains positive
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a slight easing in February's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) to 50.5, down 0.2 point from the previous month, indicating growth but at a slower pace. Despite this, optimism remains, with economists attributing the moderation to seasonal factors such as the Chinese New Year holidays. The electronics sector PMI also dipped, but the overall reading suggests further growth in industrial production, with economists expecting 3.5% year-on-year growth for Singapore's 2021 industrial production.

site_title: China charging ahead with national digital currency
summary: China has launched a national digital currency, eCNY, with the goal of remaking the country's monetary system. The digital currency was tested in four cities last year and recently expanded to bigger cities like Beijing and Shanghai. Recipients, like Bejing-based business strategist Annabelle Huang, can use the digital currency to make payments similar to other Chinese payment apps. The eCNY is designed to enable direct handouts of money and track financial transactions, giving the government more control. Over 60 countries have experimented with national digital currencies, with China aiming to be the first to introduce the eCNY nationwide.

site_title: AirAsia rolls out its food-delivery service in Singapore
summary: AirAsia Group has launched its food-delivery service, airasia food, in Singapore, aiming to be cheaper for consumers and merchants. The service, available on the airasia food platform, offers a lower commission rate of 15% compared to market rates of 25-30%. AirAsia plans to expand the service to the rest of Asean, with the goal of reaching a turnover of US$250 million this year. The company is leveraging its logistics arm and budget airline experience to keep costs low and is focusing on a smaller group of merchants to give them a sense of identity and belonging.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Compass makes IPO filing public
summary: Compass, a real estate brokerage firm backed by SoftBank, filed for an initial public offering (IPO) after revealing a 56% surge in revenue to $3.72 billion in 2020, driven by the strong housing market. The company's net loss narrowed to $270.2 million, a significant improvement from $388 million the previous year. Compass, founded in 2012, has raised $1.5 billion from investors and was valued at $6.4 billion after a 2019 funding round. The IPO is led by Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Barclays, following a confidential filing in January.

site_title: How to navigate changes in valuation and fee calculation methods
summary: A CFA Institute report found that lack of communication or responsiveness is a major reason retail investors in Singapore drop a financial advisor. The report also highlights the importance of clear communication in investment processes, including changes in valuation and fee calculation methods. CFA Institute advises managers to disclose changes in their investment processes, risks, and limitations, and to use reasonable judgment when selecting factors for investment analyses. Effective communication can help clients make informed decisions and trust financial services.

site_title: Sea posts net loss of US$523.6m in Q4 FY20
summary: Sea Ltd reported a net loss of US$523.6 million in Q4 FY20, exceeding the net loss of US$283.8 million in the same period last year. Total revenue increased 101.6% year-over-year to S$1.6 billion. The company established Sea Capital to manage its investment efforts, allocating US$1 billion initially. Despite the loss, Sea expects bookings for digital entertainment to be between US$4.3 billion and US$4.5 billion for FY21, and e-commerce revenue to be between US$4.5 billion and US$4.7 billion.

site_title: Higher revenue threshold for sole-proprietorship 2-line income reports
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has updated its tax filing requirements for sole-proprietors, with those earning below S$200,000 now required to use a two-line statement for income reporting. This change aims to simplify tax filing, benefiting approximately 21,000 sole-proprietors. The initiative is part of Iras' efforts to improve tax filing, including the introduction of a Direct Notice of Assessment and the expansion of the No-Filing Service (NFS) to more taxpayers.

site_title: 'Wrong signals' on openness could hurt Singapore
summary: Singapore's Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing warned that the country must avoid sending "wrong signals" on openness to prevent jeopardizing its reputation for openness and attracting global companies. The minister emphasized the importance of consistent policies on business, taxation, and talent, and of maintaining a safe harbour for capital, talent, and ideas. Singapore aims to strengthen its position as a global hub, entrench itself in critical niches in global value chains, and nurture local companies to become future global champions.

site_title: Myanmar situation 'enormous, tragic step back': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong calls the Myanmar military coup an "enormous, tragic step back" for the country, condemning the use of lethal force against civilians. He urges the regime to release detained state counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi and negotiate with her party, and to work towards a peaceful solution. Lee believes sanctions imposed by outsiders have limited influence and may harm the Myanmar population, rather than the military. He hopes wisdom will prevail and the armed forces will work with the civilian government, leading to a democratic outcome.

site_title: Merck to make J&J vaccine to boost supply: US official
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to announce an agreement with Merck to produce Johnson & Johnson's single-dose Covid-19 vaccine, aiming to boost supply and combat the coronavirus outbreak. Merck will dedicate US facilities to manufacturing and packaging the vaccine, with the goal of delivering 20 million doses by March and 100 million by June. The agreement comes as the Biden administration seeks to increase vaccine distribution, following the FDA's greenlighting of the J&J vaccine.

site_title: Facial recognition tech at Delhi schools sparks fears for children's privacy
summary: Facial recognition technology has been installed in at least a dozen government-funded schools in Delhi, India, sparking concerns over children's privacy. The technology is being used without laws regulating data collection and use, and its accuracy rate is low, increasing the risk of misidentification. Digital rights advocates claim it's an "overreach" and an invasion of children's privacy, and some countries and states are banning its use on minors. A personal data protection law is being drafted, but critics argue that safeguards are lacking.

site_title: Australia is running out of cows
summary: Australia's cattle herd is near its lowest levels since the early 1990s, threatening the country's position as the world's second-largest beef exporter. With global demand picking up after the pandemic, Australia's beef producers face a nationwide herd rebuild challenge. The current ratio of female cattle to total slaughter is 48.2%, below the 47% threshold needed for a technical rebuild. If not addressed, this could lead to Australia losing its export position to Brazil, with prices for Australian beef reaching record highs due to drought conditions and climate change.

site_title: Lessons to learn from Japan disaster, 10 years on
summary: The 10th anniversary of the Great East Japan earthquake and tsunami highlights the need for improved disaster response and preparedness in urban areas. The 2011 disaster, which killed 15,900 people, was exacerbated by the rapid growth of Japan's population, with 80 million people concentrated on the Pacific shore of Honshu island. The disaster has raised questions about the feasibility of evacuation as a response to extreme natural hazards, and the need for integrated shelter design in urban and rural areas. As the world's population is projected to increase to 68% urban by 2050, disaster planners must rethink key assumptions and prioritize community preparedness and shelter design.

site_title: Doctor copper, I've got a bad case of loving you
summary: Copper prices have surged 117% from their February 2020 low to around $4.30 a pound, driven by rapid demand growth. This rapid rise, reminiscent of the 2008-2010 period, has raised concerns about a potential correction. However, chart analysis suggests that the trend is driven by sustainable economic recovery and optimism among investors, as evidenced by the Hang Seng Index's strong recovery and record trading volumes. The market's behavior may be likened to "lust rather than enduring love," but it could ultimately support a sustained economic revival.

site_title: Notes toward reinventing America's orchestras
summary: US orchestras are considering reinventing themselves to recover from pandemic closures. Flexible programming, broader racial representation, and welcoming spaces are key to revitalizing the industry. Orchestras must think big and take chances, incorporating contemporary music and commissioning works from diverse composers. The subscription-series schedule, which locks orchestras into standard programs, is a major impediment to creative programming. New flexibility, such as broadcasting rehearsals and hosting events in non-traditional spaces, can help orchestras adapt to changing times. Renovating concert halls to be more intimate and acoustically vibrant can also enhance the overall experience.

site_title: China's Parliament to address long-term pitfalls as economy rebounds
summary: China's National People's Congress will address long-term economic pitfalls as the country's economy rebounds, amid strategic rivalry with the US. The 2021 work report, to be delivered by Premier Li Keqiang, will unveil a five-year plan to counter stagnation through consumption and homegrown technology. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers. The report will also chart a course for economic recovery, following disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: MCO lifted in Selangor, KL, Johor and Penang
summary: Malaysia's Movement Control Order (MCO) has been lifted in Selangor, Kuala Lumpur, Johor, and Penang, while Negri Sembilan, Kelantan, Perak, Kedah, and Sarawak remain under Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO). The Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) will be implemented in other affected states. Inter-district travel is allowed starting March 5, except for Sabah, and inter-state travel remains restricted. The new measures will begin on March 5 and end on March 18.

site_title: mm2 Asia's bet on cinemas may be a long shot
summary: mm2 Asia, a Mainboard-listed company, is considering spinning off its cinema business to pare down debt. The cinema operations have been a significant burden, with a pre-tax loss of S$16.5 million in the six months to September last year. Revenue from cinemas shrunk to S$3.6 million, down from S$49.5 million the previous year. The company faces a grim post-pandemic reality, with cinemas competing with streaming services for consumer attention. To succeed, mm2 will need a strong backer and fresh ideas to convince investors of growth potential in the cinema business.

site_title: Volvo to go all-electric by 2030; bets on death of petrol cars
summary: Volvo plans to transition its entire car lineup to fully electric vehicles by 2030, with 50% of global sales expected to be electric by 2025. The company aims to launch a new family of electric cars in the next few years and will include wireless upgrades and fixes for its models. Volvo's decision follows similar plans from other carmakers, including Ford, Jaguar Land Rover, and Bentley, as they face CO2 emissions targets and bans on fossil fuel vehicles. The shift to electric vehicles is expected to affect engine plants and auto suppliers, but Volvo believes it will not significantly impact overall employment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 2.73 points to 1,569.87. The market saw 12.890 billion lots worth RM6.423 billion, but 677 losers outnumbered gainers 485.

site_title: Supply chain solutions startup Advotics bags US$2.75m led by East Ventures
summary: Indonesia-based supply chain solutions startup Advotics has secured US$2.75 million in a Series A round led by East Ventures. The company will use the funding to expand its footprint into the small and medium enterprises market and increase its sales team. Advotics provides integrated platforms for managing supply chains in Indonesia's retail market, helping brands track inventory and sales force activities. The startup aims to tap into the growing US$3 billion enterprise software market in Indonesia, driven by the digital transformation of local companies.

site_title: London gets its first Europe IPO this year with Trustpilot
summary: Trustpilot, a Denmark-based online review platform, plans an initial public offering (IPO) in London, boosting the city's image as a European IPO hotspot. The company expects to raise around $50 million to fund growth and repay debt, seeking a valuation of around $1 billion. Trustpilot will be the first large EU company to list on the London stock market this year, following Brexit. The IPO is part of a surge in UK listings, with several firms, including Dr. Martens and Deliveroo, also planning listings.

site_title: Big economies agree to boost IMF funding, Georgieva says
summary: Major economies agree to boost International Monetary Fund (IMF) reserves by issuing $500 billion in special drawing rights (SDRs), a move backed by many G20 members to provide liquidity to poor countries hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. IMF head Kristalina Georgieva said the allocation will be made immediately, with each member receiving a share, contributing to the fund's reserves. The move aims to provide debt relief to the poorest nations without increasing their debt levels, with G20 leaders expected to agree to extend the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI) in April.

site_title: Mary Chia Holdings proposes debt conversion at S$0.15 per conversion share
summary: Mary Chia Holdings proposes a debt conversion agreement, issuing 25.5 million new ordinary shares at S$0.15 per share to aggregate debt of S$3.83 million. The debt, primarily owed by executive chairman and CEO Ho Yow Ping, remains unpaid. The company aims to capitalize on the agreement to restructure its debt.

site_title: Microsoft-backed Bukalapak weighs US listing via SPAC
summary: Indonesian e-commerce company Bukalapak, backed by Microsoft, is considering a US listing via a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), with potential valuation ranging from $4 billion to $5 billion.
