The company is in preliminary talks with several blank-check companies and may list a small part of its business in Jakarta before a US SPAC deal. Bukalapak, founded in 2010, hosts 13.5 million online sellers and 100 million users, and is valued at $3.5 billion. A final decision has not been made, and a representative for Bukalapak declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: No breakthrough on Myanmar crisis at Asean meeting
summary: A summit of Southeast Asian states failed to find a breakthrough to resolve the crisis in Myanmar after the military takeover. Foreign ministers from Asean urged the junta to allow the bloc to resolve escalating tensions, but did not forge a common position. Asean expressed concern and called for restraint, with Singapore's foreign minister warning of the group's lack of unity and credibility. The group also called for the release of political detainees, including Aung San Suu Kyi, but the position was not endorsed by all.

site_title: Women in tech can get gender equality back on track
summary: COVID-19 has exacerbated the global gender gap in the workforce, with women disproportionately affected by job losses and transitioning to new jobs due to automation. Despite Singapore having a relatively high percentage of women in the workforce, women still make up only 19% of executive teams. The pandemic has shown that women's jobs are nearly twice as vulnerable as men's, with 54% of job losses attributed to women. To bridge this gap, getting more women into skilled tech jobs is crucial, but obstacles remain, including underrepresentation in the tech sector and a huge skills gap.

site_title: Higher palm oil prices lift revenues of locally listed planters and refiners
summary: SINGAPORE-listed palm oil companies have seen improved financial results due to higher crude palm oil (CPO) prices, with smaller, pure-play stocks like Bumitama Agri and Mewah International outperforming larger ones. The price surge, driven by supply crunch and strong demand from countries like India and China, has lifted revenues of CPO planters and refiners. However, some companies, such as First Resources, were hurt by poor weather conditions and export levies, leading to production declines and lower profit margins. Analysts expect CPO prices to stay buoyant in the first quarter but moderate later in the year.

site_title: US: Stocks pull back after Monday rally
summary: US stocks declined early Tuesday, retreating from Monday's surge as investors weigh inflation concerns against economic growth expectations. The Dow Jones fell 0.2%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.6% after the US Treasury bond yields surged. The economic aid package, awaiting Senate approval, also contributed to the market pullback.

site_title: Seoul: Shares jump on Wall Street rally, upbeat trade data
summary: South Korean shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the Kospi benchmark rising 1.03% to 3,043.87. The rally was driven by a new stimulus plan, upbeat export data, and a Wall Street rally overnight. US stocks surged, with the S&P 500 posting its best day in nearly nine months, as investors took lower US bond yields in stride. Foreigners were net buyers of 212.6 billion won worth of shares, and the won inched lower.

site_title: Online demand fuels Abercrombie & Fitch profit, rosy sales outlook
summary: Abercrombie & Fitch reported a better-than-expected quarterly profit due to increased online sales and tightened costs. The company's net sales rose above estimates, driven by demand for loungewear and activewear, and projected a 3-40% increase in net sales in the first quarter. Despite a 5% decline in net sales, the company reported a profit of $1.50 per share, beating analysts' estimates. Abercrombie & Fitch plans to resume share buybacks and has partnered with TikTok influencers to boost its online presence.

site_title: 'Cliff effect' from loan moratoriums rollback not a concern: DBS
summary: Singapore's largest bank DBS has found that the "cliff effect" from rolling back loan moratoriums is not a significant concern, with only 8% of residential mortgages that were deferred having their deferments extended into January 2021. However, the bank's analysis shows diverging fortunes between higher- and lower-income segments, with vulnerable customers making up 31% of mortgage applicants and strategic ones making up 17%. The bank suggests a more stringent set of criteria for granting deferments in future crises to prevent abuse by customers with substantial emergency funds.

site_title: Singapore urges Asean's external partners not to impose broad-based sanctions on Myanmar
summary: Singapore's foreign minister, Vivian Balakrishnan, urged Asean's external partners not to impose broad-based economic sanctions on Myanmar, citing concerns that such measures could harm the ordinary people. He called on the Myanmar military authorities to exercise restraint and ensure no further violence. This comes amid growing re-evaluation of investments in Myanmar's economy, with foreign investors including those in Singapore.

site_title: HRnetGroup posts net profit of S$46.9m for FY20
summary: HRnetGroup reported a net profit of S$46.9 million for FY20, down 9.2% from the previous year. Revenue increased 2.4% to S$433 million, a record high for the group. The healthcare sector saw a 28% revenue growth, while the government sector grew 68.2%. The company added 14,347 contractor employees in December, a 13.7% increase, and helped 42,998 people secure employment in contract roles. A final cash dividend of 2.5 Singapore cents is proposed for FY2020.

site_title: Spurring switch away from door delivery key for 1,000 parcel stations to be effective
summary: Singapore plans to roll out 1,000 parcel-locker stations by the end of this year to spur a switch away from door delivery, aiming for more efficient e-commerce logistics. Industry players are divided on the success of this approach, with some concerned consumers may stick with doorstep delivery and others believing locker adoption will increase, easing initial costs. The move is seen as a response to consumer preference for doorstep delivery, which may hinder the adoption of locker systems.

site_title: Moelis seeks US$1.2b from three new SPACs
summary: Ken Moelis, a prominent dealmaker, is seeking $1.2 billion from three new special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs): Atlas Crest Investment Corp III, Atlas Crest Investment Corp IV, and Atlas Crest Investment Corp V. The SPACs plan to raise $600 million, $400 million, and $200 million, respectively, with listings on the New York Stock Exchange. Moelis will be chairman of the firms, and Michael Spellacy will serve as CEO. This is part of a trend of serial dealmakers tapping the market to raise funds for dealmaking, with the first SPAC in Moelis's Atlas Crest series reaching a deal last month.

site_title: Thai PM orders study on 'vaccine passports' to boost tourism
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha has commissioned a study to explore the possibility of issuing COVID-19 vaccination certificates for international travelers, aiming to revive the country's tourism industry. The study will assess the effectiveness of vaccines in preventing the spread of COVID-19 before making any decisions. This move comes as tourism operators have expressed concerns about lost revenue due to coronavirus curbs. No target date has been set for the implementation of "vaccine passports" in Thailand.

site_title: STI up 0.03% to 2,973.87 while several others in Asia dip
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.03% to 2,973.87 points, with three Jardine companies leading the gainers. However, the mainboard-listed company Oceanus fell 11.1% due to heavy trading. Markets in Asia, including Hong Kong, Japan, and Australia, declined, while South Korea and Malaysia saw gains. Analysts attribute the decline to cautious comments from the People's Bank of China and anticipation of less accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Malaysia approves Sinovac, AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines for use
summary: Malaysia has approved the use of Sinovac and AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines, with conditional approval required for additional data on effectiveness and safety. The country began its nationwide vaccination program using Pfizer-BioNTech on February 24, and aims to vaccinate 80% of its 32 million population by February 2022. Malaysia has secured 66.7 million vaccine doses, enough to cover its population. Health authorities are also evaluating a Russian vaccine and Sinovac's local bottling facility.

site_title: Myanmar situation an 'enormous, tragic step back': PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described the Myanmar military coup as a "tragic step back" for the country, calling for the release of detained state counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi and negotiations with her National League for Democracy party. The situation has sparked nationwide protests, with at least 21 killed and over 1,000 arrested, and has sparked global condemnation. Lee expressed skepticism about the effectiveness of sanctions, citing the lack of influence in the past and the potential harm to the Myanmar population. He hopes that wisdom will prevail, leading to a peaceful resolution.

site_title: Jack Ma no longer China's richest man after coming under Beijing's scrutiny
summary: Jack Ma, co-founder of Alibaba, has lost the title of China's richest man after coming under Beijing's scrutiny. He now trails in fourth place with a net worth of 360 billion yuan, behind Zhong Shanshan of Nongfu Spring, Pony Ma of Tencent, and Collin Huang of Pinduoduo. Ma's empire was put under heavy scrutiny after criticizing China's regulatory system, leading to the suspension of Ant Group's IPO and tighter anti-trust probes on the tech sector.

site_title: Sunseap, Tenaga Nasional in JV to trial import of clean energy from Malaysia
summary: Sunseap Group and Tenaga Nasional Berhad (TNB) announced a joint venture to trial importing 100 MegaWatt of electricity from Malaysia's renewable energy sources into Singapore. The trial, initiated by the Energy Market Authority in 2020, aims to diversify Singapore's energy supply. If successful, the JV will invest in multiple solar farms across Malaysia and other clean energy sources, accounting for 1.5% of peak electricity demand in Singapore. The partnership is expected to begin in late 2021 via the existing electricity interconnector between Singapore and Malaysia.

site_title: Malaysia's export gains to China most notable, but challenges remain: UOB
summary: Malaysia's exports to China have seen significant growth, increasing by 9.3% compounded annually from 2016 to 2020, with gains also seen in exports to the US and Singapore. Key products such as electrical and electronics, mineral fuels, and machinery have seen increased demand. However, challenges remain to strengthen Malaysia's investments and trade linkages, with policymakers advised to align with shifting global trends and implement a holistic investment plan to improve the investment climate.

site_title: 'Nongsa D-Town' launched in Singapore-Indonesia tech park
summary: Singapore and Indonesia's economic ministers launched Nongsa D-Town, a 62-hectare "digital downtown" in Batam, Indonesia, aiming to bridge tech companies and talents between the two countries. The development, designed by Surbana Jurong, will house 8,000 tech talents and builds on the existing Nongsa Digital Park, designated as a Special Economic Zone for digital economy and tourism.

site_title: Europe: Equities slip at open
summary: European stock markets declined in opening deals on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index dropping 0.2% to 6,573.10 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also falling 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. Investors paused after a surge the previous day, with no major economic events announced. The decline was attributed to no specific cause, with US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty remaining a focus.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined by 1.21% on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng Index falling 356.71 points to 29,095.86, following a warning from a top Chinese central bank official about forming bubbles in global financial markets. The Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 1.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.70%. The warning led investors to anticipate a correction in the market.

site_title: Through the mailbox slot: Japanese theatre offers new viewing experience
summary: A Japanese dance company, Moonlight Mobile Theater, has introduced a novel viewing experience, where audience members watch performers through letter-box slots or peephole-like openings in cubicles, maintaining social distancing. The unique setup has been a success, with all 12 performances selling out since its December launch. The company aims to propose this model to bring audiences back to theatres, despite facing financial difficulties. By limiting audience size to 30 people per show, the company hopes to sustain its operations and ensure artists continue to perform.

site_title: New schemes to help SMEs speed up digitalisation and create new revenue streams
summary: Singapore is introducing three initiatives to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in digitalising their businesses and creating new revenue streams. The Chief Technology Officer-as-a-Service (CTO-as-a-Service) initiative will help SMEs devise a digitalisation plan, while the Digital Leaders Programme will provide funding for companies to develop new digital capabilities. The Better Data Driven Business (BDDB) programme will offer free tools and resources to help businesses use data more effectively and responsibly.

site_title: Sea posts net loss of US$523.6m in Q4 FY20
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based gaming and e-commerce giant, reported a net loss of US$523.6 million in Q4 FY20, down from a net loss of US$283.8 million in the previous year. The company also announced the establishment of Sea Capital, a platform to manage its overall investment efforts, with an initial allocation of US$1 billion. David Ma, founder of Composite Capital Management, will serve as chief investment officer of Sea Capital, reporting directly to Forrest Li, group chief executive and chairman.

site_title: Eight new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 8 new Covid-19 cases, all imported, bringing the total to 59,956. All 8 cases were individuals placed on stay-home notices upon arrival, with no community cases or migrant worker dormitory cases. The number of unlinked community cases increased to 2, while 59,815 patients have fully recovered. 20 patients remain hospitalized, including 1 in critical condition. Globally, over 114 million people have been infected and over 2.5 million have died from the virus.

site_title: After historic fall, carbon emissions are now coming back fast
summary: Carbon emissions have rebounded after historic pandemic-driven declines, with global emissions 2% higher in December 2020 compared to the same month in 2019. Energy-use emissions fell by 5.8% in 2020, with the US and EU seeing the largest reductions, while China saw a 0.8% increase. The biggest drop was in transportation, mainly due to reduced oil use. The International Energy Agency warns of a potential "CO2 gusher" as energy demand returns, and scientists estimate that emissions must decrease by 10% for the year to detect a reduction in atmospheric CO2 concentration.

site_title: No significant increase in fraud, cyber-risk incidents from remote working in 2020: MAS-ABS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) released a joint white paper stating that there was no significant increase in operational, fraud, and cyber-risk incidents from remote working in 2020 compared to the previous year. However, the paper warned of potential emerging risks that may only become apparent over time. The MAS and ABS encourage financial institutions to review and enhance their risk-management practices to address evolving risks, particularly in areas such as technology, information security, and staff misconduct.

site_title: Malaysia lifts Movement Control Order for Selangor, KL, Johor and Penang
summary: The Malaysian government has lifted the Movement Control Order (MCO) for Selangor, Kuala Lumpur, Johor, and Penang, replacing it with a Conditional Movement Control Order (CMCO) starting March 5. Negri Sembilan, Kelantan, Perak, Kedah, and Sarawak will remain under CMCO. Inter-district travel is permitted, except for Sabah, while inter-state travel remains restricted. The MCO had been in place for various states from January to February, with the CMCO and Recovery Movement Control Order (RMCO) phases set to run from March 5 to 18.

site_title: Dubai real estate market may bottom out next year, S&P says
summary: Dubai's real estate market is expected to "bottom out" in 2022, according to S&P Global Ratings, following a tough 2020. Prices of residential and office spaces have declined by more than a third since 2014, driven by a property glut and faltering demand. The market is expected to continue a high supply momentum, leading to two more years of price declines. The city's gross domestic product contracted around 11% last year, and its population shrunk by the steepest amount in the Gulf.

site_title: SK Group to invest US$16b by 2025 in hydrogen energy
summary: SK Group plans to invest US$16.5 billion by 2025 to establish a domestic hydrogen energy industry in South Korea. The company will build the world's largest clean hydrogen production base, producing 250,000 tonnes of eco-friendly hydrogen annually from LNG. This is part of South Korea's efforts to recover from the coronavirus pandemic and cut its reliance on fossil fuels, with a goal of producing 6.2 million hydrogen-powered vehicles by 2040 and 1,200 hydrogen fueling stations. The investment is also in line with South Korea's "Green New Deal" and its goal to set net zero carbon emissions by the middle of the century.

site_title: AirAsia not just delivering food here, but wants to deliver fresh food as well
summary: AirAsia has launched its food delivery service in Singapore, offering a 15% commission rate for merchants and 5% lower delivery fees for customers. The company aims to leverage its low-cost airline experience to keep costs low. AirAsia has partnered with 80 merchants and plans to expand to 300 more, with a projected turnover of $250 million this year. The airline also plans to enter the fresh food delivery market within two to three months, targeting a lower commission structure and flat fees for merchants.

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus sinks 11.1% amid active trading
summary: Oceanus Group, a seafood supplier, saw its shares plummet 11.1% on Tuesday, with 452.9 million shares changing hands, amid active trading. The stock hit an intra-day low of 6.4 cents, reversing from a weekly gain of 13.6% since the start of the year. Despite a net profit of S$8.6 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2020, the group has accumulated losses of about S$418.6 million. Oceanus is seeking an extension to exit the Singapore Exchange's watch-list.

site_title: Dublin is top Brexit relocation spot for finance firms
summary: Dublin is the top destination for finance firms relocating to the EU after Brexit, with 3 dozen firms considering or already moving UK operations to the Irish capital. Luxembourg and Frankfurt are second and third, respectively. Approximately 7,600 jobs and 1.3 trillion pounds of assets have moved from the UK to the bloc since October. This trend reflects London's decreasing dominance in European finance, with Amsterdam now leading in stock trading and interest-rate swaps.

site_title: Specialised financial, digitalisation advice to be available at SME Centres in Singapore
summary: Singapore's SME Centres will offer specialist financial and digitalisation advice to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) starting with financial advisory and digitalisation. Financing specialist advisers will help SMEs assess their financial health and recommend financing options. The service will be available through the SME Centre's website. Additionally, a new TAC competency framework and two new features will be introduced to the GoBusiness portal to improve capabilities and support SMEs. These initiatives aim to strengthen the financial health of SMEs and improve their access to resources.

site_title: TeamViewer acquires US augmented reality software firm Upskill
summary: TeamViewer, a German remote connectivity software company, acquired US-based augmented reality software firm Upskill, expanding its presence in the US market. The deal, undisclosed in terms, marks the third takeover by TeamViewer CEO Oliver Steil since the company's initial public offering in 2019. The acquisition aims to strengthen TeamViewer's product range and widen its market reach.

site_title: Germany's HelloFresh reports quarterly sales above expectations
summary: Germany's HelloFresh reported quarterly sales above expectations, more than doubling to beat forecasts, driven by the trend of cooking at home during the COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects consumers to continue relying on e-commerce solutions, citing its superior value proposition. CEO Dominik Richter stated that as the pandemic winds down, HelloFresh will continue to ride the e-commerce wave, offering price, variety, and convenience.

site_title: UK to extend virus support, may raise tax in budget
summary: The UK is expected to extend emergency financial support to its virus-battered economy when unveiling its annual budget, but may also raise taxes to combat surging debt. The country's economic recovery hopes have been boosted by its vaccination efforts, with over 10 million adults vaccinated. Britain is exiting its third Covid lockdown, and the government aims to balance supporting the economy with transparency.

site_title: Microsoft-backed Bukalapak considers US listing via SPAC
summary: Bukalapak.com, an Indonesian e-commerce company backed by Microsoft, is considering a US listing via a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). The company is in preliminary talks with several blank-check companies and could be valued at $4 billion to $5 billion. This move comes as the coronavirus pandemic has boosted demand for e-commerce in Indonesia, where Bukalapak competes with rivals such as Tokopedia and Lazada. A decision has not been made, and a representative for Bukalapak declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall in muted response to central bank stance
summary: Australian shares fell 0.4% to 6,762.3, as the Reserve Bank of Australia re-committed to keeping interest rates at historic lows, with no change expected. Weak commodity prices also pressured miners and energy stocks. The benchmark closed 1.7% higher on Monday. The central bank's decision to stand pat on interest rates was met with a muted market response.

site_title: Singapore must not send 'wrong signals' to world about openness: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing warned that the country must not send "wrong signals" to the world about its openness, risking its hard-won reputation and ecosystem. This virtuous cycle, which attracts global and local companies, must be protected from damage. Chan emphasized the importance of preserving Singapore's openness and reputation, which has been built over time.

site_title: Licence fee waiver for hotels, travel agents, tourist guides extended through end-2021
summary: Singapore has extended the waiver of licence fees for hotels, travel agents, and tourist guides through December 2021 as part of continued aid for the hard-hit tourism sector. This is the second extension, following a six-month waiver through the end of 2020. The move aims to support the sector during the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.86% to 29,408.17, and the Topix index dipping 0.40% to 1,894.85. The decline was attributed to profit-taking ahead of a speech by the Federal Reserve chairman scheduled for this week.

site_title: Which unicorn listings could GIC and Temasek stand to gain from?
summary: Singapore's state investors, GIC and Temasek, could gain from several tech unicorn listings, including Gojek, Traveloka, and Didi Chuxing, which are reportedly eyeing public markets. As global tech stocks rally, these investors, ranked as top tech investors globally in a 2020 survey, could benefit from the potential returns. Both GIC and Temasek have backing from these tech unicorns, indicating a strong potential for investment growth. Their involvement could further solidify their positions as leading tech investors worldwide.

site_title: Farming in Australia faces slowdown following bumper year
summary: Australian farming faces a slowdown following a bumper year, with the overall value of farm production forecast to contract 4% to A$63.3 billion in 2021-22 due to lower prices and reduced volumes. Despite this, exports are expected to climb 6% in 2021-22, driven by increased demand for cotton, wool, and dairy products. The sector is also impacted by trade curbs and a highly variable climate, with wine, beef, and barley exports among those hit by rising tensions with China.

site_title: China considers ways to manage financial risks stemming from capital inflows
summary: China's top banking and insurance regulator, Guo Shuqing, expressed concerns about the risk of foreign market bubbles bursting, which could affect the domestic market. China is studying measures to manage capital inflows and prevent turbulence. Guo noted that financial markets in Europe and the US are trading at high levels, contradicting the real economy. This comes as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Twitter to boot users who persist with Covid-19 lies
summary: Twitter will label and potentially boot users who persistently spread Covid-19 misinformation, including vaccine lies. The platform's "strike system" will label misleading tweets and escalate penalties for repeated offenses, culminating in a permanent ban after five strikes. Twitter has already removed over 8,400 tweets and notified 11.5 million accounts about Covid-19 information rule violations since late 2020. The move aims to reduce the spread of potentially harmful misinformation and align with its policies on election-related misinformation.

site_title: Australia's central bank commits to keep three-year yields low
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) reaffirmed its pledge to keep interest rates at historic lows, affirming its "highly supportive monetary conditions" until employment and inflation goals are met. The central bank maintained its 0.1% three-year yield target, despite global bond markets selling off due to speculation of ending monetary stimulus. The RBA also committed to purchasing more bonds as needed to support the target, with Governor Philip Lowe noting that the Aussie dollar is in the upper end of its recent range.

site_title: More access to innovation experts for startups, SMEs: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore is expanding access to innovation experts for startups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to aid in innovation and commercialization. The Innovation and Enterprise Fellowship programme connects researchers with accelerators, startups, or investors, while the Innovation Advisors Programme provides mentorship and advice to SMEs in various sectors. The government also aims to support firms in transforming and going global through initiatives such as the Industry Transformation Maps and the Global Innovation Alliance network, with expanded support for internationalization costs and new modes of internationalization.

site_title: China's billionaires club swells as market rally offsets virus pain
summary: China has seen over 200 billionaires created in 2021, with the country's exclusive club nearly doubling in the past five years. The Hurun Global Rich List shows China has 1,058 billionaires, surpassing the US, which added 70 new billionaires, taking its total to 696. Leading the Chinese pack is Zhong Shanshan, who entered the list with an $85 billion fortune, while Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos, and Colin Huang added over $50 billion each in a single year. China continues to lead the world in wealth creation, with 490 new billionaires added in the past five years.

site_title: Almost 9,000 notifications for contractual relief submitted: Edwin Tong
summary: The Ministry of Law reported 8,655 online notifications for contractual relief submitted as of Feb 23, with 66% related to hire-purchase agreements for commercial equipment or vehicles, and leases or licences of non-residential property. This figure excludes notifications served via other modes of service, and relates to businesses and individuals impacted by Covid-19. The Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act, introduced last April, provides six months of legal reprieve from contracts for affected parties, which was later extended.

site_title: Euro 2020 shrouded in uncertainty 100 days before kick-off
summary: Euro 2020 is 100 days away, but uncertainty surrounds the tournament's format and host cities due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Uefa has stuck to its original plan of 12 host cities, but has given cities until April to determine if they can accommodate spectators. England is being considered as a potential host, with reports suggesting the whole tournament could be moved there if it means selling more tickets. The travel logistics and economic consequences of playing behind closed doors have led to tough decisions about the tournament's format.

site_title: South-east Asian ministers aim to encourage Myanmar talks as crisis intensifies
summary: Southeast Asian foreign ministers are holding talks with Myanmar's ruling military to address deadly violence and quell the country's escalating crisis. The talks come two days after the bloodiest day of unrest since the military removed Aung San Suu Kyi's elected government, with at least 21 protesters killed. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) aims to encourage dialogue between Suu Kyi and the junta, with Singapore's Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan saying Asean will be frank and appalled by the violence. The US has warned the military that it will take further action if security forces kill unarmed people and attack journalists and activists.

site_title: Volvo's car lineup to go all electric by 2030
summary: Volvo plans to transition its entire car lineup to fully electric vehicles by 2030, with 50% of global sales expected to be electric by 2025. The company aims to launch a new family of electric cars online, featuring wireless upgrades and fixes. Volvo joins other carmakers, such as Ford, Jaguar Land Rover, and Bentley, in phasing out fossil-fuel engines by the end of this decade. Industry-wide electrification is expected to impact engine plants and suppliers, but Volvo plans to "radically reduce" complexity and provide transparent pricing.

site_title: China's Nio signals slowing EV deliveries as volumes rise
summary: China's Nio Inc forecasts slower electric vehicle deliveries in the first quarter, citing higher volumes, despite a 15% sequential increase from the fourth quarter. The company expects 20,000-20,500 deliveries, down from 17,353 in the fourth quarter. This slowdown follows a 42% rise in deliveries in the fourth quarter. Nio's shares fell 7% in extended trading after the announcement. The company's revenue jumped 133% to 6.64 billion Chinese yuan in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: China's Nio Inc on Monday forecast slowing growth for its electric vehicle deliveries in its current quarter, as the automaker ships higher volumes, sending its shares down 7 per cent in extended trading.

site_title: Firm US dollar, elevated yields push gold prices to 8-1/2-month low
summary: Gold prices dropped to an 8-1/2-month low on Tuesday, falling 0.7% to $1,711.13 per ounce, amid a stronger US dollar and elevated US Treasury yields. The potential for higher yields erodes investor appetite for gold, while a stronger dollar also contributes to its fall. Benchmark US Treasury yields remain elevated, and European Central Bank policymakers hint at potential yield cuts to prevent premature borrowing cost increases.

site_title: Trading stamp duty won't harm Hong Kong's competitiveness, says finance chief
summary: Hong Kong's finance chief, Paul Chan, stated that the city's decision to raise stamp duty on stock trading won't harm its competitiveness. The 30% increase, implemented to boost spending and relieve economic distress, was met with a 9% decline in the stock market. The city's economy is expected to grow 3.5-5.5% in 2021, after a record 6.1% contraction in 2020. The government has unveiled HK$120 billion in fiscal support, including a HK$5,000 consumption voucher and loans to the unemployed, to ease joblessness and stimulate consumption.

site_title: Philippines reports first cases of Covid-19 South African variant
summary: The Philippines has reported six cases of the South African coronavirus variant, raising concerns about the effectiveness of its current vaccines. The cases, including three detected locally and two returning from overseas, may have higher transmissibility and impact on vaccine efficacy. The country has documented 87 cases with the more transmissible variant, complicating its recovery effort from the pandemic. The discovery comes as the Philippines starts its vaccination campaign, with President Rodrigo Duterte aiming to lift restrictions once 20-40 million doses of vaccines are secured.

site_title: Sorry steak lovers, Australia's running out of cows
summary: Australia's cattle herd is near its lowest since the early 1990s, threatening the nation's position as the world's second-largest beef exporter. With a female cattle-to-slaughter ratio of 48.2%, producers are at risk of losing their export position to Brazil. The situation worsens if farmers continue to slaughter females instead of keeping them to expand herds, as demand increases post-Covid-19.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise target prices on China Aviation Oil on air traffic recovery hopes
summary: Analysts from CGS-CIMB and RHB have raised their target prices on China Aviation Oil (CAO) due to hopes for air traffic recovery. CGS-CIMB maintained a "hold" call with a target price of S$1.17, while RHB raised its target price to S$1.30. Analysts expect domestic aviation traffic in China to remain strong in 2021 and international aviation traffic to recover gradually. CAO's cash balance and earnings-accretive merger and acquisition plans are seen as positive factors.

site_title: Hong Kong considering allowing SPAC listings
summary: Hong Kong is considering allowing Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) to list in the Asian financial hub, marking a potential shift towards global expansion. The move follows a largely US phenomenon, with SPACs raising US$60 billion in the first two months of 2021. Hong Kong's markets regulator and exchange operator have briefed top financial leaders on the development, which could enhance the city's competitiveness as an international financial center. Several Hong Kong tycoons have already set up or are working on SPACs, and the government is seriously exploring the possibility of allowing them to list in Hong Kong.

site_title: Amazon accused of race-gender bias in workplace
summary: A US federal court lawsuit has accused Amazon of perpetuating systemic racism and sexism in the workplace, targeting Black and female employees. Charlotte Newman, a Black and female Amazon employee, alleges she was harassed, sexually assaulted, and passed over for promotions despite her qualifications. The lawsuit claims Amazon's practices, such as assigning Black employees to lower-paying jobs and making them wait longer for promotions, amount to discriminatory behavior. Amazon denies the allegations, stating it does not tolerate discrimination and thoroughly investigates claims.

site_title: South Korea's factory activity expands at fastest pace in almost 11 years
summary: South Korea's factory activity expanded at its fastest pace in nearly 11 years in February, according to a private survey. The IHS Markit purchasing managers' index (PMI) rose to 55.3, driven by strong growth in production and new orders. This marked the strongest level since April 2010. Manufacturers attributed the improvement to higher domestic demand and new business, which also helped stabilize employment levels. Businesses were optimistic, with confidence surging to its highest in eight years, and industrial production is expected to grow 1.4% in 2021.

site_title: Singapore's lower-income group still bears brunt of wage, savings deterioration: DBS report
summary: Singapore's lower-income group continues to face financial struggles, with those earning S$2,999 or less accounting for half of customers experiencing income deterioration, according to a DBS report. The report found that 49% of this group, or 113,900 customers, experienced significant income loss, and 42% had less than a month of emergency funds. The uptick in unemployment among middle-aged workers may be due to biases or a preference for permanent positions. The report highlights the need for continued support for vulnerable individuals, particularly those who have permanently lost their jobs.

site_title: PropertyGuru weighs US listing via SPAC
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singaporean online real estate firm backed by KKR & Co and TPG Capital, is considering a US listing via a merger with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). The company aims to strike a deal this year, valuing the combined firm at approximately $1 billion. PropertyGuru's management is holding preliminary talks with several SPACs. This move could provide the company with access to the US market and additional funding.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Tuesday, rising 5.97 points or 0.38% to 1,573.11. Volume reached 552.04 million lots worth RM216.62 million. Gainers outpaced losers 375 to 137.

site_title: Boeing, Australian air force say pilotless, fighter-like jet completed first test flight
summary: Boeing and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) successfully completed the first test flight of the "Loyal Wingman", a pilotless fighter-like jet designed to operate with crewed aircraft. The Australian government invested A$40 million in its development, which has also attracted interest from the US and UK as potential customers. The jet, manufactured in Australia for the first time in over 50 years, flew under Boeing's supervision from a ground control station in South Australia.

images.alt_text: Boeing and the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) said on Tuesday they had completed the first flight test on a pilotless fighter-like jet designed to operate in conjunction with crewed aircraft.

site_title: WHO panel issues strong advice against hydroxychloroquine for Covid-19
summary: A World Health Organization expert panel advises against using hydroxychloroquine to prevent Covid-19 and notes it has no meaningful effect on patients already infected. The recommendation is based on high-certainty evidence from six randomized controlled trials involving over 6,000 participants. The panel considers hydroxychloroquine "not worthwhile" exploring further, citing its lack of efficacy and safety concerns. The guideline is a "living guideline" that can be updated as new evidence emerges.

site_title: Danone's Faber to give up CEO role after investor pressure
summary: Danone SA, the world's largest yoghurt maker, has voted to separate its chairman and CEO roles, with Emmanuel Faber to remain in the dual position until a new CEO is found and then become non-executive chairman. The move comes after investor pressure and calls to shake up governance, with several shareholders urging the firm to find a new CEO and boost returns. The board has also announced plans to cut 2,000 jobs and sell some assets, including the business in Argentina.

site_title: Australian government spending adds 0.3 percentage points to GDP in Q4
summary: The Australian government's spending in the December quarter contributed 0.3 percentage points to the country's gross domestic product (GDP). Total public sector demand increased 1.1% and investment in fixed assets rose 2.5%. This growth is expected to rebound the GDP by around 2.5% in the fourth quarter, following a 3.3% jump in the previous quarter. Public spending accounts for approximately 24% of GDP, and analysts forecast a strong economic performance in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Japan steel giant shifts to recycled metal in green race
summary: Japan's top steel producer, Nippon Steel, is shifting its focus to recycling metal as part of its mid-term business plan, aiming to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. The company is working on larger electric-arc furnaces to mass-produce recycled steel, following global pressure to reduce pollution. Nippon Steel's shares fell 1.5% after announcing the plan, which also includes streamlining operations and expanding outside Japan. The move comes as the world's third-largest steel producer faces a "crisis of survival" if it fails to develop cleaner steel.

site_title: Serial dealmaker Bill Foley looks for carveouts with new SPAC
summary: Bill Foley, a prominent serial dealmaker, is seeking carveouts from publicly traded consumer companies through his new special purpose acquisition company (SPAC). Foley's SPAC, which raised $2.07 billion, will focus on acquiring divisions from large consumer companies like Revlon Inc. This approach deviates from Foley's typical focus on technology or fintech businesses. Foley expressed interest in exploring corporate spinouts as a potential hunting ground for deals. This move comes as blank-check companies raise record amounts of capital, allowing them to invest in various sectors.

images.alt_text: Bill Foley, one of the highest-profile names in blank-check dealmaking, is on the lookout for public company assets that it could take public as a separate business.

site_title: Freezer firm to launch probe after Japan vaccines spoiled
summary: A Japanese freezer malfunction has rendered 172 vials of Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine useless, wasting up to 1,032 doses. An investigation will be launched by the firm that installed the freezer to determine the cause. Japan has installed around 100 vaccine freezers nationwide and has administered first doses to nearly 32,000 healthcare workers. The country is planning to initially vaccinate 40,000 healthcare workers and 3.7 million more in March, with vaccines for 36 million people aged 65 or older set to start from April.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin on front foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 0.9% to 29,708.39, following a global market recovery after last week's losses. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains, extending the rally. The gains come as investors become more optimistic, despite ongoing concerns over rising bond yields.

site_title: Philippines fires diplomat whose maid attacks were caught on film
summary: The Philippines has fired its former ambassador to Brazil, Marichu Mauro, after security footage showed her attacking a domestic worker at her official residence in Brasilia. The footage, broadcast by Brazil's GloboNews channel, captured Mauro repeatedly assaulting the household staff member over eight months. President Rodrigo Duterte dismissed Mauro from the foreign service, citing her actions as unacceptable. Mauro's dismissal comes after she was recalled to Manila late last year due to the controversy.

site_title: Nike executive leaves following report about son's business
summary: Nike executive Ann Hebert left the company after a Bloomberg Businessweek report revealed her son's business, a sneaker reselling operation, used a credit card in her name. Hebert, a 25-year veteran of the company, had been vice president and general manager of North America. Despite disclosing the business to Nike in 2018, she departed Monday, effective immediately, following the report. The company will announce a new leader for North America shortly.

site_title: Vietnam electric-car startup plans US factory, 2022 roll-out
summary: Vietnam's electric-car startup, VinFast, plans to establish a US factory and begin sales in the US and Canada in 2022, with the goal of becoming a global smart electric car company. The company, founded by billionaire Pham Nhat Vuong, has already set up a 50-member research office in San Francisco and has received a license to test autonomous vehicles in California. VinFast plans to offer two luxury SUVs in the US, Europe, and Canada, and aims to be profitable after five years of operation.

site_title: Hearing for Hong Kong democracy activists resumes after marathon session
summary: A marathon hearing for 47 Hong Kong democracy activists charged with conspiracy to commit subversion resumed on Tuesday after a defendant fainted during the previous session. Lawyers are challenging a prosecution bid to deny bail and keep them in custody for up to three months. The defendants, charged under the Chinese-ruled city's national security law, are accused of organizing an unofficial primary poll. International condemnation has been raised, with the US State Department calling for their release and the drop of charges. The hearing is part of a crackdown on dissent in Hong Kong since Beijing imposed the security law in June.

site_title: Minerals exploration in Australia jumps as supercycle looms
summary: Australia's minerals exploration spending reached A$718.4 million in the December quarter, the highest in over seven years. This surge is driven by the looming supercycle in the commodities complex, with miners seeking new deposits to meet global demand for clean energy transition minerals. Australia's copper resources are the second-largest in the world, and the country holds a quarter of the world's nickel. The country's biggest export, lithium, is key to battery technology driving the electric vehicle switch. Base metals saw the strongest rise in spending, up 13% on the prior quarter.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) advancing 21.97 points or 0.7% to 2,994.97. Gainers outnumbered losers 132 to 25, driven by gains in banking stocks and a rally on Wall Street, where equities rose on stimulus and vaccine hopes. The focus is on global economic recovery, with key economic data and Fed speakers set for the week.

site_title: Ant's staff expect a windfall; they got unsellable shares
summary: Ant Group employees who were set to receive a multi-billion-dollar windfall after the company's IPO are now facing uncertainty due to the company's inability to determine a fair price for their shares. The company has shelved its share buyback program, citing regulatory uncertainty, and is exploring possibilities to revive its IPO. Employee morale is under threat, with some departing employees quitting rather than holding out for a revival of the listing. The company's valuation has been slashed to less than $108 billion, down 60% from the IPO price, and employees are likely to receive substantially reduced payouts when they cash in.

site_title: Bank of America files motion to dismiss Chapter 11 cases of EH-Reit, certain entities
summary: Bank of America has filed a motion to dismiss the Chapter 11 bankruptcy cases of Eagle Hospitality Real Estate Investment Trust (EH-Reit) and certain entities of Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) Singapore. The motion comes after the US bankruptcy court approved a $100 million debtor-in-possession (DIP) term loan facility for the entities. If successful, EH-Reit and the Singapore entities will not be able to access the DIP financing facility, which would impact their ability to restructure and potentially sell their assets. The hearing for Bank of America's motion is scheduled for April 7.

site_title: Oil falls with Opec+ meeting hovering over tightening market
summary: Oil prices plummeted as the Opec+ meeting approaches, falling to the lowest in over a week. The alliance is expected to loosen supply restrictions, potentially returning 500,000 barrels a day to the market. However, uncertainty remains, with the Saudi Arabian energy minister calling for cautious action. Despite bullish calls, risks persist, including weaker sales in China and record pump prices in India, which point to a limit on recent oil market firmness.

site_title: One in four people will have hearing problems by 2050: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization warns that by 2050, one in four people worldwide will suffer from hearing problems, with the number potentially increasing to 2.5 billion. Currently, one in five people have hearing issues. The report identifies preventable causes, such as infections and lifestyle choices, and proposes measures to prevent and treat hearing loss, including public health initiatives and systematic screening. The estimated annual cost of unaddressed hearing loss is nearly $1 trillion, with the potential financial burden being even higher due to the impact on communication, education, and employment.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.8% or 229.94 points to 29,893.44, and the Topix index advancing 0.5% or 8.6 points to 1,911.03. The gains followed Wall Street's rally on optimism over coronavirus vaccines and US fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Bitcoin rises as Citi, Goldman find crypto allure hard to resist
summary: Bitcoin surged to a record US$58,350 on February 21, then dropped 21% last week, but rebounded to US$49,080 in Hong Kong trading on March 2, rising 2.8% amid a broad resurgence in risk assets. Citigroup and Goldman Sachs Group have warmed up to Bitcoin, with Citigroup's Global Perspectives & Solutions report suggesting the cryptocurrency could become "the currency of choice for international trade." Meanwhile, New York Attorney General Letitia James issued an investor alert warning about speculative bubbles and abuse by criminals.

site_title: Asia: Stocks track US gains; treasuries steady
summary: Asian stocks rose, tracking a global equity rally, as investors ignored concerns about higher bond yields. US stocks surged overnight, with the S&P 500 reaching its biggest advance in almost nine months, while benchmark Treasury yields remained steady. Oil slipped to around $60 a barrel ahead of an Opec+ meeting. Investors piled into risk assets, driven by concerns about the economy overheating and the potential impact of stimulus. The dollar remained steady, and Bitcoin rallied after a bullish report from Citigroup.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as strengthened recovery hopes enliven markets
summary: Australian shares rose 1.1% to 6,860.70 on Tuesday, driven by hopes of a quicker global economic recovery and optimism over a US coronavirus relief package. Technology stocks led gains, with Afterpay Ltd advancing 6.6% and the mining sub-index climbing 1.5%. The Reserve Bank of Australia increased its daily quantitative easing programme, and the country's central bank is expected to keep key interest rates unchanged at a historic low.

site_title: Facing pressure, ExxonMobil names two new board members
summary: ExxonMobil has named two new board members, Jeffrey Ubben and Michael Angelakis, amid pressure from investors and environmentalists. The oil giant aims to increase shareholder value while playing a leadership role in the energy transition. The additions come after a tough 2020, including a $22.4 billion loss, and a recent earnings release that unveiled a new low-carbon business unit. The moves drew mixed reviews from activist investors, with one group, Engine No. 1, nominating four directors to the board. ExxonMobil's shares jumped 4.8% following the announcement.

site_title: Disney CEO says households without kids have boosted streaming success
summary: Disney CEO Bob Chapek revealed that households without kids have significantly boosted Disney+'s streaming success, exceeding initial projections. As of January, 94.9 million customers worldwide had signed up, with half living in households without children. This non-family appeal has led Chapek to rethink Disney's content strategy, focusing on broader appeal. The service's growth is attributed to popular shows like Marvel's WandaVision and Star Wars series, with Disney now expecting 350 million global subscribers across all streaming services by the end of fiscal 2024.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mark best day in nearly four months after bond-driven rout
summary: European stocks surged 1.8% on Monday, their best day in nearly four months, as bond markets stabilized after a sharp selloff last week. Travel and leisure stocks led gains, driven by optimism over Covid-19 vaccination programs and a large US stimulus package. Manufacturing activity in the euro zone picked up pace in February, sparking confidence in an economic recovery. Despite a separate reading showing German inflation held steady, investors remained upbeat, with the STOXX 600 index reaching its highest level since early November.

site_title: Report says Bitcoin could lose its shine in the longer term
summary: Bitcoin experienced its worst weekly decline in almost a year due to environmental concerns and tightening regulations. BCA Research Inc. warns that the energy consumption required for Bitcoin mining and potential government obstacles could lead to a significant loss of value over time. The report also suggests that environmental, social, and governance-focused funds may shun companies linked to Bitcoin, further exacerbating the decline. Despite this, Bitcoin is still up over five times in the past year.

site_title: Number of ultra-rich living in Singapore rose last year despite pandemic: Knight Frank
summary: Singapore's ultra-wealthy population grew 10.2% in 2020, reaching 3,732 individuals, the second-highest rate in Asia. Globally, Singapore ranks third for fastest-growing UHNWI population. The Asia-Pacific region is predicted to see a 33% increase in UHNWIs by 2025, with Singapore's ranks swelling by 31% to 4,888. The city-state remains an attractive destination for wealthy individuals due to its stability and low taxes, with 31% of Asian homebuyers ranking it in their top five list of investment locations.

site_title: US faces 'unprecedented assault on democracy', White House says, backing election reform bill
summary: The US is facing an "unprecedented assault on democracy" as the Biden administration backs Democrats' efforts to overhaul voting rules and redraw congressional districts to independent commissions. A sweeping election reform bill, HR-1, is set to be voted on in the House, but its passage in the Senate is uncertain. Republicans have raised concerns about powers being taken away from states and potential fraud, while Democrats aim to expand access to polls through early voting and vote-by-mail.

site_title: Instagram Live Rooms adds group streaming of up to four users
summary: Instagram has introduced Live Rooms, allowing up to four users to live stream together in real-time, similar to Clubhouse. This feature enables multiple participants to engage in simultaneous broadcasts that other users can tune into. Previously, users could only live stream with one other person. The move aims to expand Instagram's live streaming capabilities and compete with other group-broadcast platforms.

site_title: Zoom shares rise on strong current-quarter forecast, upbeat results
summary: Zoom shares rose 10% after the company forecast current-quarter revenue above expectations, with revenue between $900 million and $905 million. The forecast beat estimates and the company reported quarterly revenue of $882.5 million, with earnings per share of $1.22 beating estimates. The surge in revenue and earnings sent Zoom's shares up 9.6% on Monday and trading at $452 after the bell. The company expects strong growth in the coming year, citing its well-positioned position in the video-conferencing market.

site_title: World's first Covax jab injected as US eyes J&J roll-out
summary: Ghana's President Nana Akufo-Addo received the world's first Covax coronavirus vaccine injection, marking a milestone in the global effort to distribute vaccines to poorer countries. The Covax scheme aims to deliver at least 2 billion jabs by the end of the year. Meanwhile, US health workers are preparing to distribute nearly 4 million doses of the single-shot Johnson & Johnson jab. This rollout comes as concerns grow that rich nations are hogging vaccine doses.

site_title: World won't vanquish Covid-19 this year: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned that the world won't be done with the Covid-19 pandemic by the end of the year, citing rising global new case numbers. Despite efforts to vaccinate front-line health care workers and vulnerable populations, the virus remains in control, particularly in Europe, the Americas, and southeast Asia. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus emphasized the importance of basic public health measures and vaccination efforts, calling for universal access to Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, LMIRT, SBS Transit, Cosco, ISOTeam, FJ Benjamin
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) shares jumped 5.2% on Monday following a global airline stock rally, reaching an intra-day high of S$5.30. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) saw its distribution per unit plummet 92.3% to 0.04 Singapore cent due to pandemic-related discounts. SBS Transit appointed new CEO Cheng Siak Kian, while Cosco Shipping International reported a 13% year-on-year net profit boost. ISOTeam appointed former MP Teo Ho Pin as an independent director, and FJ Benjamin Holdings will begin trading again on the Catalist board.

site_title: Women making inroads on Wall Street, but still a long way to go
summary: Citigroup has appointed Jane Fraser as its new CEO, marking a milestone for women on Wall Street. However, despite progress, women still face a long way to go in achieving parity in the financial services sector. According to a Deloitte report, women made up 50% of employees in 2019 but only 22% of managers. The industry is gradually shifting towards diversity, with companies like JPMorgan Chase and Citigroup implementing programs to support women in their careers. Despite these efforts, sexist remarks and unequal pay remain a challenge, with women earning 17% less on average than their male counterparts.

site_title: Pfizer and AZ Covid jabs 'highly effective' in elderly: UK study
summary: The Pfizer and Oxford-AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccines have shown high effectiveness in reducing infections and severe illness among elderly people in Britain, with an 80% reduction in hospitalization among those over 80. A single dose of either vaccine is more than 80% effective at preventing hospitalization within three to four weeks. This study's findings come as France and Germany consider authorizing the AstraZeneca vaccine for people over 65, following concerns over its efficacy.

site_title: Japan's Q4 capex down for third straight quarter, jobless rate steady
summary: Japan's capital expenditure fell 4.8% in Q4, marking the third straight quarter of declines, amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Business expenditure shrank 0.3% quarter-on-quarter, and ordinary corporate profits dropped 0.7% year-on-year. Despite a preliminary estimate showing a 12.7% annualized GDP growth in Q4, the weak capex data may lead to a downward revision to GDP data. The jobless rate remained steady at 2.9% in January, with job availability climbing to a 2-year high.

site_title: Hedge fund boss takes home UK record pay of £343m
summary: Hedge fund boss Christopher Hohn set a UK record for the highest annual paycheck in 2020, receiving £343m (S$634.1m) from his company TCI Fund Management. This payout surpasses the previous record held by an individual in Britain. Hohn owns 100% of TCI Fund Management, which filed the documents at Companies House. The dividend payment is the highest ever paid to an individual in the UK.

site_title: US presses Saudis over Khashoggi killing amid calls to punish prince
summary: The US pressed Saudi Arabia to take further measures following the release of an intelligence report finding that Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman approved the 2018 killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. The report, previously classified, revealed that seven members of the hit squad were from the Rapid Intelligence Force, which answers only to the crown prince. The US is facing criticism for not directly targeting Prince Mohammed, with calls to punish him for the killing. The Biden administration has urged Saudi Arabia to take additional steps to hold those responsible accountable.

site_title: Tech players in GIC and Temasek's portfolios
summary: GIC and Temasek, two Singaporean sovereign wealth funds, are poised to reap significant capital gains from the tech IPO season. Notable tech companies in their portfolios include GoTo, OpenAI, and Manus. GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a US$2.2 billion sell-off, while OpenAI plans to release a web browser to challenge Google Chrome. Meanwhile, Manus is accelerating its move to Singapore amidst an intensifying AI race. These developments highlight the growing importance of tech innovation and the potential for these funds to benefit from the sector's growth.

site_title: UK top firms not cutting carbon emissions enough: survey
summary: A survey found that one-third of the UK's top listed companies are not cutting carbon emissions enough to meet global climate goals. 31 companies on the FTSE 100 index, including non-oil and mining giants, are emitting high levels of carbon dioxide, exceeding global temperature increases of 2.7% by 2050. Experts emphasize the need for businesses, especially the biggest firms, to lead the way in reducing emissions to meet the Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to below 2°C.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies on stimulus and vaccine hopes as bond markets calm
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, with the S&P 500 gaining 90.67 points, or 2.4%, to 3,901.82, its best day since June 5. The rally was driven by optimism over the US$1.9 trillion coronavirus relief bill and the distribution of Johnson & Johnson's newly authorized Covid-19 vaccine. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 603.14 points, or 2%, and the Nasdaq Composite added 396.48 points, or 3%, to 13,588.83. Bond markets also calmed, with US Treasury yields stabilizing and benchmark 10-year Treasury notes rising 8/32 in price to yield 1.429%.

site_title: South Korean tech firms shake up Japan's storied manga industry
summary: Two South Korean technology companies, Piccoma and Line Manga, backed by Kakao and Naver, have revolutionized Japan's manga industry by becoming the highest-grossing mobile apps outside games. Their online platforms have seen significant growth, with Piccoma's third-quarter transaction volumes tripling to 11.6 billion yen and Line Manga's volumes increasing by a third to 8.2 billion yen. The apps' "zero yen if you wait" model, where users must wait for a timer to unlock the next instalment or pay to read ahead, has disrupted the traditional manga sales model.

site_title: China Feb home price growth cools, finds survey
summary: China's new home price growth slowed in February, rising 0.2% from a month earlier, as demand cooled over the Chinese New Year and cities implemented stricter regulations. This marks a decrease from 0.37% in January. Major cities, such as Beijing and Shanghai, have introduced tighter regulations to curb speculative buying and contain illegal funds. Despite this, annual home price growth remains steady at 4.01%, and developers are expected to speed up housing supply in March. Home transactions and land sales also declined in February.

site_title: US dollar clings to three-week highs as yields steady
summary: The US dollar maintained its three-week high against major currencies, as US and euro zone bond yields steadied following a February sell-off. The greenback strengthened against peers, while riskier currencies like the Australian dollar rebounded.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Golden Energy and Resources reported a 18.7% decline in FY2020 net profit to US$8.1 million, due to consolidating subsidiary Stanmore Coal results and investing in the Ravenswood Gold project. The company will not pay a dividend and remains cautiously optimistic on the near-term recovery for energy and metallurgical coal demand and prices. Meanwhile, ISOTeam appointed former MP Teo Ho Pin as an independent director, and SBS Transit appointed Cheng Siak Kian as CEO.

site_title: Malaysiakini chief editor questioned on suspicion of sedition
summary: Malaysiakini's chief editor, Steven Gan, was questioned by police on suspicion of sedition after criticizing the conviction of his website for contempt. The news outlet was fined $120,000 for readers' comments critical of the judiciary. Gan maintained his innocence, stating his comments were in response to the court decision, not inciting sedition. The investigation has raised concerns about worsening press freedoms in Malaysia, where opposition lawmakers have also been questioned on suspicion of sedition for criticizing the verdict.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. The US stock market opened lower due to a fresh tariff imposed by the Trump administration on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Demand for hospitality courses rises as workers, companies eye recovery
summary: The Singapore tourism industry has seen a surge in demand for hospitality courses as workers and companies look to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic. Despite the downturn, polytechnic institutions like the Republic Polytechnic and Nanyang Polytechnic have reported stable enrollment, while private education providers have seen a decline in international students. The government's Enhanced Training Support Package has covered up to 90% of course fees for workers in hard-hit sectors, and institutions are adapting their courses to meet the industry's changing needs, including the growth of virtual events and digital literacy.

site_title: Spain suffers second-wost month for virus deaths
summary: Spain has suffered its second-worst month for coronavirus deaths in February, with 10,528 fatalities, surpassing the April 2020 figure of 16,354 deaths. The country's overall toll now stands at 69,609, with health ministry data showing a stubbornly high death toll despite a decline in cumulative cases. Spain has resisted a national shutdown, instead relying on regional restrictions and an immunization campaign that has vaccinated over 1.2 million people, aiming to reach 70% vaccination by the end of summer.

site_title: Bitcoin cannot replace the banks
summary: Bitcoin proponents believe it will eventually replace banks and become the sole currency, but a closer look reveals that it reinforces the existing banking system. Banks create new credit money by making loans, not just transferring existing funds. Bitcoin companies, such as BlockFi and Nexo, use similar business models to create new credit money, earning fees and interest on loans. Regulation and patient negotiation are needed to improve the system, but so far, Bitcoin lenders have not made significant changes to address issues like unstable credit supply and lack of cheap credit for small loans.

site_title: Commerzbank plans to exit HK, Luxembourg in restructuring
summary: Commerzbank plans to exit locations in Hong Kong, Luxembourg, and Hungary as part of its restructuring, according to an internal memo. Asia sales activities will be bundled in Singapore, and the Dubai branch will operate as a representative office. The bank will sell its subsidiary in Brazil and open a representative office in South America. This move aims to streamline operations and focus on core markets.

site_title: About 50 of Hin Leong founder's ships sold to repay debt: sources
summary: About 50 ships owned by companies controlled by Singapore tycoon Lim Oon Kuin and his family have been sold as part of efforts to repay billions of dollars of debt owed to creditors. The ships were sold at prices of $2-3 million each for coastal barges and $30 million each for very large crude carriers, mainly to Greek ship owners. The sale is part of a broader effort to repay debt, with the rest of the ships expected to be sold by late this year, although some are tied up in lawsuits.

site_title: Trump's Dubai golf expansion gets delayed until at least 2022
summary: The Trump Organization's 18-hole golf course in Dubai, designed by Tiger Woods, has been delayed until at least 2022, four years after its initial planned opening. The cause of the delay is unclear, but construction of the clubhouse is currently on pause. The project, part of the Akoya Oxygen community, will test whether Trump's corporate brand remains popular in the region, where he has enjoyed broad support. The delay comes as the company navigates its path forward with Trump out of office.

site_title: Australia home prices, job ads surge in February as recovery blitzes expectations
summary: Australia's economy rapidly recovered from its recession, with home prices rising 2.1% in February, the fastest clip in almost two decades, and job ads increasing 7.2% in February. New mortgage loans climbed 10.5% to a record high in January, and the Reserve Bank of Australia is likely to leave interest rates at 0.1%. The strong figures may not change policymakers' plans to wind back monetary stimulus, but economists welcome the central bank's flexible approach to unconventional policy.

site_title: GIC, Temasek poised to reap capital gains bonanza from tech IPO season
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC and state investor Temasek are poised to reap significant capital gains from tech IPOs, including those of Gojek and cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase. GIC's 8.37% stake in DoorDash has risen to about US$4.5 billion in value, representing a paper gain of almost 30 times. Temasek-backed companies like Gojek and Kuaishou are also set to go public, with a combined valuation of over US$18 billion. Despite Ant Group's cancelled IPO, GIC and Temasek have diverse portfolios and have seen significant gains from their existing investments.

site_title: Singapore's market cap up for fourth straight month, led by gains in local banks
summary: Singapore's stock market rose for the fourth consecutive month in February, driven by gains in local banks. The total market capitalization of 687 listed stocks increased 0.6% to S$843.1 billion, with the Straits Times Index rising 1.6%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB were among the top gainers, with their market capitalizations rising between 5.6 and 6.5%. The finance sector was the top gainer in February, with stocks adding S$9.38 billion in value.

site_title: Climate issues 'heat up' in boardrooms and remuneration committees
summary: Climate change poses significant risks to businesses, with physical and transition risks impacting operations and financial viability. Companies are adopting science-based targets for greenhouse gas (GHG) emission reductions and incorporating climate-related goals into performance management and executive incentive plans. Boards are increasingly aligning executive compensation with climate transition priorities, with nearly 78% planning to change their approach over the next three years. Hard targets and disclosures are crucial to encourage efforts towards a climate resilient future, with Singapore companies having a significant opportunity to lead the charge on climate resilience.

site_title: Job schemes: hiring with less risk
summary: Businesses are adopting job schemes to reduce hiring risks as they emerge stronger from the pandemic. These schemes offer companies a way to access skilled workers without long-term commitments. By leveraging job schemes, businesses can save on recruitment costs and mitigate the risks associated with hiring. This trend is particularly relevant for companies looking to expand their workforce without the financial burden of long-term employment contracts.

site_title: The Democratic and Republican big tents
summary: US politics is expected to remain a two-party system in 2024, with Democrats potentially fielding a moderate candidate and Republicans facing a divide between Trumpists and moderates. The unique US electoral system has contributed to the survival of the two-party system, as small parties are marginalized and unable to win national elections. Both parties have pragmatic approaches, with Democrats embracing a centrist agenda and Republicans seeking compromise. The 2020 presidential election saw President Biden win by appealing to moderate suburban voters, while the Republican Party's shift towards radical nationalism under former president Trump poses an electoral dilemma.

site_title: Exuberance over aviation stocks may be misplaced
summary: Singapore aviation stocks surged on Monday following the authorization of a third COVID-19 vaccine in the US, with Singapore Airlines' share price increasing 5.22%. However, experts warn that the vaccines are not a panacea for the industry, which is still reeling from the pandemic. The International Air Transport Association has estimated that the global airline industry will burn $95 billion this year, and it may take two years for the world to be largely immunized against the virus. Share prices may be "misplaced" and a "mismatch" with the industry's short-term outlook, according to aviation experts.

site_title: Singapore business loans in January up for 2nd month
summary: Business loans in Singapore rose 0.9% month on month to S$422.73 billion in January, marking the second consecutive month of growth. Loans to building and construction, financial institutions, and general commerce increased, while loans to others declined. Consumer loans grew 0.5% month on month, driven by a rise in housing loans. Housing loans extended their growth streak for the fifth consecutive month, up 0.4%. Year-on-year, total bank lending in January was down 1.1%.

site_title: Two more charges filed against Suu Kyi as protests continue in Myanmar
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi appeared in court via video conferencing, marking her first appearance since detention on February 1. Two additional charges were filed against her, including publication of information that may cause fear or alarm and licenses for equipment. Protests continue, with security forces killing at least 18 people on Sunday, and supporters marched in several towns and cities. The situation remains volatile, with the military crackdown intensifying.

site_title: Buffett singles out Apple among top three valuable holdings
summary: Warren Buffett's conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway, has amassed a $120 billion holding in Apple stock since 2016, making it one of its top three most valuable assets. This is a significant shift for Buffett, who traditionally avoided technology stocks. Berkshire's investment in Apple is now considered a valued franchise, with analyst Cathy Seifert crediting the company's resiliency and Berkshire's deal-making skills. The investment is a testament to Apple's enduring value and Berkshire's ability to adapt and expand its portfolio.

site_title: Mindef to spend S$90m to upgrade DSO biosafety lab to deal with more severe viruses
summary: The Defence Ministry in Singapore has allocated S$90 million to upgrade the DSO Biosafety Lab to Level 4 bio-safety standards, enabling it to handle more severe viruses and biological threats. This marks the first time the ministry's annual budget has seen double-digit growth since 1998. The upgrade is a collaboration between the Ministry of Health and DSO National Laboratories to enhance the country's defenses against infectious diseases.

site_title: Pent-up demand driving global factory revival in February
summary: Global factory activity rebounded in February, driven by pent-up demand, with the IHS Markit Manufacturing PMI reaching a three-year high of 57.9. However, a slowdown in China's factory activity, due to a domestic Covid-19 flare-up, tempered the overall growth. Despite challenges, analysts expect the outlook to brighten as companies increase output to restock inventory, with Asia's export-reliant economies benefiting from robust global trade. The recovery is still in its early stages, with household consumption not yet fully recovering.

site_title: UK mortgage approvals ease as end of tax relief approaches
summary: UK mortgage approvals decreased to 98,994 in January, down from 102,809 in December, due to the approaching end of tax relief on property purchases. The reduction was likely influenced by consumers continuing to repay debt and the expiration of a stamp-duty holiday saving buyers up to £15,000. However, speculation about an extension of stamp duty relief and easing of coronavirus restrictions may have boosted the property market, with Rightmove recording its busiest day ever on February 17.

site_title: ISOTeam appoints former MP Teo Ho Pin as independent director
summary: ISOTeam appoints former Singapore MP Teo Ho Pin as an independent director, bringing over 20 years of public service experience. Teo previously served as Mayor of the North West District, Chairman of the Holland-Bukit Panjang Town Council, and Coordinating Chairman of 15 town councils. He holds a master's and doctorate in project management and has worked with various government and university institutions.

site_title: Finland declares state of emergency as Covid-19 cases rise
summary: Finland declared a state of emergency on March 1, 2021, as COVID-19 cases rose, with 58,064 confirmed cases and 750 associated deaths. The move allows for tougher restrictions, including limiting restaurants to takeaway service for three weeks, restricting public gatherings to six people, and tightening controls on gyms and municipal buildings. Prime Minister Sanna Marin stated that the government is not planning to reintroduce a blockade, but will consider it if necessary and proportionate.

site_title: Hong Kong's Rosewood Hotel Group to file for SPAC listing, say sources
summary: Hong Kong's luxury Rosewood Hotel Group, a unit of New World Development, plans to file for a US$400 million SPAC listing, targeting the consumer sector. Enlisted by Credit Suisse and JPMorgan, the deal aims to raise funds for the company.
