Rosewood, run by Sonia Cheng, is the latest luxury brand to explore a SPAC listing, following other recent deals in the sector. The move comes as New World sells its China property assets after a loan deal.

site_title: SBS appoints Cheng Siak Kian as CEO
summary: SBS Transit has appointed Cheng Siak Kian as its new CEO, replacing Yang Ban Seng who stepped down in March last year. Cheng Siak Kian, 51, has held various leadership positions, including acting CEO since March 2020 and CEO of ComfortDelGro Australia from 2016 to 2019.

site_title: Canberra versus tech giants: Winning a losing battle?
summary: Australia's attempt to force tech giants Google and Facebook to pay for content has been met with mixed results. Google agreed to a deal with local media firms, while Facebook refused, leading to a significant drop in news site readership. The government backed down, allowing Facebook to reimpose a news blackout and walk away from the market. Critics argue that the law's focus on supporting local media may not be effective and could lead to the distribution of funds to shareholders rather than journalists. A more effective approach may be to tax tech giants on their revenue and use the funds to support journalism directly.

site_title: Round-the-world cruises selling out more than a year in advance
summary: Cruise lines are seeing a surge in bookings for round-the-world cruises, with many selling out in advance of departure. Viking Ocean Cruises, Oceania Cruises, and Seabourn have all reported strong sales for upcoming itineraries, with prices ranging from $50,000 to over $500,000 per person. Despite the ongoing pandemic and travel restrictions, passengers are eager to take advantage of the opportunity to see the world, with many citing cabin fever and a desire to make up for lost time. The industry hopes that by the time these distant itineraries set sail, Covid will be under control.

site_title: India's biggest oil retailers focusing on rural revival
summary: India's largest oil retailers, Bharat Petroleum and Hindustan Petroleum, plan to expand their rural presence, driven by the country's relatively resilient rural economy and government spending. The companies aim to increase the proportion of rural outlets, with Hindustan Petroleum looking to open new outlets in second-rung cities and rural areas. India's economy recovered from its worst recession since the 1950s, with rural India outperforming urban areas, and the share of rural service stations in fuel sales rose to 26.8% in January.

site_title: Brazil's Operation Car Wash not a magic bullet
summary: Operation Car Wash, a high-profile anti-corruption investigation in Brazil, has been exposed as flawed and potentially illegal. The operation, launched by magistrate Sergio Moro, resulted in the imprisonment of several high-level politicians and businessmen, including former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. However, it was later revealed that Moro used innovative methods, including plea bargains, to bypass the judicial system and secure convictions. The operation's dark side has also been exposed, including allegations of espionage and corruption within the judiciary. The investigation's failure to eradicate corruption has contributed to Brazil's current crises, including a fragile economy and extreme political polarization.

site_title: Diversity, Netflix dominate Golden Globes; Nomadland wins best drama
summary: The 2021 Golden Globe Awards honored "Nomadland" as the best drama film, with director Chloe Zhao becoming the first woman of Asian descent to win the best director award. Netflix dominated the awards, winning four movie honors and six for television. Chadwick Boseman posthumously won the best actor award, and "Soul" won best animated movie and best score. The ceremony also addressed the lack of diversity among the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, with some members acknowledging the need for change.

site_title: Thailand sees at least 300b baht investment in Eastern Economic Corridor this year
summary: Thailand expects to see at least $10 billion in investment in its Eastern Economic Corridor this year, a significant increase from 2020's $3.6 billion. The country's industrial east is expected to receive 46% of total project applications, with actual investment reaching at least 300 billion baht ($13.2 billion). The easing of the coronavirus pandemic has led to a surge in investment projects, with investors pushing forward previously held-up projects. The government aims for 2.5-3.5% economic growth this year.

site_title: Lincoln Center will head outside its closed theatres to perform
summary: Lincoln Center is planning to perform outside its closed theatres due to the coronavirus pandemic. The organization, known for its grand concert halls, is looking to utilize its 16-acre campus's outdoor space. This move aims to revive performances after nearly a year of closure.

site_title: Boutique mud houses change fortunes of Omani village
summary: Misfat al-Abriyeen, a small Omani village, has transformed its mud-brick homes into boutique hotels, drawing tourists to the region's hiking trails and tales of genies. The village, with 800 residents, opened its narrow streets six years ago, and now has 15 rooms, with plans to expand to 50. The hotels, which vary in price between $90 and $180 per night, have attracted 5,500 tourists in 2019, with an annual occupancy rate of 90%. The village's transformation is part of Oman's efforts to diversify its economy, with tourism expected to reach 11 million by 2040.

site_title: Hiring with less risk using job schemes
summary: Singapore companies are leveraging job schemes to reduce hiring risks during the pandemic, with 75% of firms tapping into the Professional Conversion Programmes (PCPs) and Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) to hire new talent. The schemes provide subsidies for skills training and wages, enabling businesses to expand their capabilities and grow beyond the crisis. Companies such as Scanteak Singapore, Gloo, and Kuok (Singapore) Ltd have benefited from the schemes, with some reporting that they would have still hired without them. The schemes have also encouraged businesses to hire older workers and explore new industries, with Minor Food Group hiring 100 staff over 40 years old.

site_title: Tom & Jerry draws US$13.7m in best debut this year
summary: Tom & Jerry's US$13.7 million opening sales in North America led the box office last weekend, the largest debut this year and second-best since the pandemic began. The Warner Bros remake of the classic cartoon took in US$33.1 million globally, with China being its second-largest market. Kid-friendly movies have performed well during the pandemic, with Warner Bros' result encouraging for Walt Disney Co's upcoming release of Raya and the Last Dragon. This is an over-performance by pandemic standards, with private theater rental bookings contributing to the success.

site_title: Singapore's independence imperative amid US-China rivalry: Vivian
summary: Singaporean Foreign Affairs Minister Vivian Balakrishnan emphasized the importance of maintaining independence and strategic autonomy in the face of great power competition between the US and China. He stressed that Singapore must navigate its relationships with both superpowers while upholding its sovereignty and adhering to international law. Balakrishnan emphasized the need for Singapore to be authentic, reliable, and trustworthy, rather than being a vassal state or influenced by either side.

site_title: Time for both sides to reset US-China trade relations
summary: The US and China are reassessing their trade relations, following the departure of Donald Trump's administration. The Biden administration is seeking cooperation and mutual gain, rather than confrontation, on issues like climate change and intellectual property. The US should work through multilateral forums and strengthen its research and development capabilities to achieve better results than trying to curb Chinese development. A reset in US-China trade relations could involve restoring the WTO's dispute-settlement role and rescinding Trump-era tariffs in exchange for Chinese reciprocity.

site_title: SoftBank said to write down US$1.5b Greensill Holding
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund has substantially written down its US$1.5 billion holding in Greensill Capital to close to zero, according to people familiar with the matter. The writedown occurred at the end of 2020, amid Greensill's efforts to raise capital and potentially go public. SoftBank's decision to write down the valuation comes as Greensill faces challenges in the supply-chain finance industry.

site_title: Fall in Singapore's January arrivals attributed to fresh flare-up of Covid-19 pandemic, seasonal factors
summary: Singapore recorded its first month-on-month decline in international arrivals since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 23,150 visitors in January, a 3.6% drop from December. The number of visitors was down 98.6% year-over-year from January 2020, attributed to a fresh flare-up of the pandemic and tightened social restriction measures. However, some markets, such as India and Europe, showed an upward trend, and vaccine roll-outs may support tourism recovery.

site_title: UIC secures green, sustainability-linked loans worth S$300m
summary: UNITED Industrial Corporation Ltd (UIC) secured S$300 million in green and sustainability-linked loans from UOB and DBS. The loans include a S$200 million sustainability-linked loan and a S$100 million green loan, primarily used to upgrade the Singapore Land Tower. The upgrading works, estimated to be completed by 2023, will introduce more green features to the 39-year-old building. The loans are three-year revolving credit facilities, allowing UIC to draw down or withdraw funds as needed. This move aims to balance business outcomes with environmental and social responsibilities.

site_title: Ex-French president Sarkozy found guilty of corruption
summary: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy was found guilty of corruption by a Paris court for offering to help a magistrate land a prestigious job in exchange for a favor. He was sentenced to one year in prison, but under the French system, he is unlikely to serve the sentence. The conviction marks a setback in Sarkozy's already struggling political career, and he faces further charges related to campaign spending limits.

site_title: DBS appoints new Malaysia head, sparks expansion talk
summary: DBS appoints Raof Latiff as its new Malaysia country head, effective June 1, marking the bank's entry into the Southeast Asian market. Latiff, currently group head of digital for institutional banking, will oversee the bank's expansion plans in Malaysia. The move comes as the country is keen to issue digital bank licenses, with Bank Negara planning to award up to five licenses. DBS may capitalize on this opportunity to expand its presence in Malaysia through digital banking, allowing for an asset-light operation.

site_title: Safe-management measures for workplace to be reviewed after Chinese New Year period
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 task force may adjust workplace safe-management measures after the Chinese New Year period, considering public health risks and employee interests. Work-from-home remains the default arrangement, with employers required to limit on-site workers to 50% of those able to work remotely. The government is also exploring a system of mutual recognition of vaccine certifications between countries to potentially relax border measures for vaccinated individuals.

site_title: Cosco Shipping International reports 13 per cent increase in net profit for FY20
summary: Cosco Shipping International reported a 13% increase in net profit for FY20, reaching S$8.33 million, driven by government grants and contributions from newly acquired subsidiaries in Malaysia. Revenue rose 8% to S$185.84 million, while gross profit fell 25% to S$30.06 million due to lower rental revenue. The company also obtained a partial temporary occupation permit for its Jurong Island Chemical Logistics Facility and aims to expand its logistics network in South and South-east Asia through acquisitions and investments.

site_title: US manufacturing expands most in three years as prices climb
summary: US manufacturing expanded at the fastest pace in three years in February, with a gauge of factory activity rising to 60.8, exceeding the median estimate. Supply shortages, rising costs for raw materials, labor force disruptions, and higher shipping rates are challenging the industry. Orders, production, and factory employment measures also expanded, but unfilled orders surged to the highest level in nearly 17 years, and delivery times were the second-longest since 1979. The expansion highlights resilience in manufacturing but is hindered by labor-market difficulties.

site_title: Ambani to partner Google, Facebook to seek India payments business licence
summary: Reliance Industries, led by Asia's richest man, plans to partner with Google and Facebook to seek a licence to enter India's digital payments business. The consortium, which also includes Infibeam Avenues, is developing a detailed plan to apply for a licence from the Reserve Bank of India. This move comes as other companies, including the Tata Group and Amazon.com, also apply for a licence to enter the market.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens in celebratory mode on vaccine news
summary: US stocks surged 1.7% in early trading on Monday, driven by news that a third Covid-19 vaccine will be available soon. The Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index all jumped, with the Dow reaching 31,459.94. The approval of Johnson & Johnson's single-dose vaccine and the House of Representatives' approval of President Biden's economic relief package contributed to the celebratory tone. The rally started the week on a positive note, despite ongoing pandemic challenges.

site_title: Thai Airways seeks US$1.65b infusion under debt revamp
summary: Thai Airways seeks a US$1.65 billion capital infusion under a debt restructuring plan to keep the airline operational. The plan, to be submitted to a bankruptcy court, aims to reduce liabilities from 336.7 billion baht and return to profit once the pandemic ends. Thai Airways has sold stakes and cut staff to cushion the blow from the global tourism and travel industry, which has been hit hard by the pandemic. The airline's Acting President will hold a briefing on the plan, which must be backed by hundreds of credit-holders and approved by the court.

site_title: Malaysian news site editor questioned for sedition
summary: Malaysian news site editor Steven Gan was questioned by police on suspicion of sedition after criticizing the conviction of his website, Malaysiakini, for contempt. The site was fined US$120,000 for readers' comments critical of the judiciary. Gan maintained his innocence, stating he only criticized the verdict, not the court. This probe adds to concerns about worsening press freedoms in Malaysia. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on Malaysiakini since its founding in 1999.

site_title: Construction spending hits record high in January
summary: US construction spending reached a record high in January, increasing 1.7% to $1.521 trillion, the highest level since 2002. Private construction projects rose 1.7% driven by investment in single-family homebuilding, while residential projects surged 2.5% and nonresidential construction increased 0.4%. Public construction projects also saw a 1.7% increase, with state and local government outlays gaining 1.3% and federal government spending rising 6.8%. This marks a significant acceleration from a 0.8% forecast by economists.

site_title: Prince Philip, 99, moves to another hospital for heart tests
summary: Prince Philip, 99, has been transferred to St Bartholomew's Hospital in central London for further treatment and observation for a pre-existing heart condition and an infection. The move comes two weeks after he was admitted to King Edward VII hospital, where he received treatment for an unspecified infection not related to Covid-19. The Duke remains comfortable and is responding to treatment, with no confirmation of the hospital transfer initially. He has required hospital treatment multiple times in the past decade for related health issues.

site_title: LMIRT Q4 DPU falls 92% to 0.04 Singapore cent
summary: Lipponia Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 92.3% drop in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter to 0.04 Singapore cents, down from 0.52 cents last year. Gross revenue declined 60.7% and net property income (NPI) fell 78% year-over-year due to pandemic-related discounts. LMIRT's manager expects uneven recovery in Indonesia, and the trust has started operating longer hours since January, reducing discounts. The DPU for Q4 FY20 is payable on March 31, with units closing at 6.3 Singapore cents.

site_title: Deals of the Week: GIC gets busy; Warung Pintar gets Bizzy
summary: Singapore's GIC invests in Indonesia's Bank Jago, a fully digital bank, and Warung Pintar acquires logistics startup Bizzy Digital for $45 million. Fintech startup ErudiFi raises $5 million in a Series A funding round to expand its education-financing services. These deals highlight Southeast Asia's growing tech funding scene, with a focus on fintech and logistics innovation.

site_title: Covid-19 outbreaks, seasonal trends stymie travel recovery in January arrivals: Analysts
summary: Singapore recorded its first month-on-month decline in international arrivals since the Covid-19 pandemic, with 23,150 visitors in January, a 3.6% drop from December. The year-on-year figure was down 98.6% from 1.69 million in January 2020. Recent Covid-19 cases and tightening social restriction measures in regional markets, such as Indonesia, are cited as contributing factors. However, some analysts suggest that seasonal trends may also play a role, with December being a more popular travel month. Vaccine roll-outs are seen as a potential upside for the tourism recovery.

site_title: 60% of Singapore taxis now run on cleaner energy
summary: Singapore has seen a significant increase in cleaner energy vehicles on its roads, with 60% of taxis now running on hybrid or electric vehicles, up from 18% three years ago. The private hire car sector has also seen a rise in cleaner energy vehicles, from 20% to 35% between 2018 and 2021. The government aims to promote the use of electric vehicles through new targets and incentives, including building 60,000 charging points and revising the vehicle tax structure to make EVs more affordable.

site_title: Hang Seng adopts sweeping changes to Hong Kong's stock gauge
summary: Hang Seng Indexes, Hong Kong's 51-year-old stock benchmark, has announced sweeping changes, including increasing the number of constituents to 80 companies and limiting a stock's weighting to 8%. The changes aim to reduce the influence of financial and property stocks and increase representation of Hong Kong firms. Implementation will begin in May and be completed by mid-2022, affecting tens of billions of dollars in funds tracking the index.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 10.61 points to 1,567.14. Volume reached 10.690 billion lots worth RM6.093 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 733 to 503.

site_title: ECB slows pandemic bond-buying despite bond-rout concerns
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) slowed its pandemic bond-buying pace to 12 billion euros last week, down from 17.2 billion euros the previous week, due to higher redemptions. Officials warned that rising global yields could derail the economic recovery. The decline in bond purchases is a departure from the ECB's previous commitment to continue its emergency programme despite concerns about inflation and economic growth.

site_title: United Airlines orders 25 new Boeing 737 MAX jets
summary: United Airlines has ordered 25 new Boeing 737 MAX aircraft for delivery in 2023, with the option to take an additional 5 in 2023. The airline is also accelerating the delivery of 40 previously ordered MAX aircraft to 2022 and 5 to 2023. This move is seen as a response to the economic rebound and travel demand fueled by the COVID-19 vaccine rollout. The 737 MAX was grounded in 2019 after two crashes, but has been cleared for return to flight by regulators in the US, Europe, and Britain.

site_title: Wanderlust stoked: Travellers locking in dates
summary: Travelers are booking trips for the second half of the year, with Japan being the top destination choice. High-end operators are seeing increased interest in peak travel periods, and travelers are opting for longer stays in one country, focusing on bucket-list trips and nature-driven holidays. Meanwhile, film-maker Chloe Zhao's Oscar-nominated film "Nomadland" is gaining attention, and glass artist Dale Chihuly is set to debut in Singapore.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares bounce back from heavy sell-off
summary: Hong Kong shares rebounded Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.63% to 29,452.57, following last week's steep losses. Asian markets also saw gains, with the Shanghai Composite Index up 1.21% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumping 2.42%. The rally was driven by vaccine optimism and bargain-buying.

site_title: Finland declares state of emergency as Covid cases rise
summary: Finland has declared a state of emergency due to rising COVID-19 cases, with 58,064 confirmed cases and 750 associated deaths reported. The move allows for restrictions to be placed on freedom of movement, including controls on restaurants, gyms, and public gatherings. The government has also announced tougher restrictions, including limiting restaurants to takeaway service for three weeks in some areas, and closing municipal buildings in areas with high infection rates. The state of emergency is expected to be debated in parliament, with the possibility of reintroducing restrictions if deemed necessary and proportionate.

site_title: Myanmar court files two more charges against Suu Kyi
summary: Myanmar's ousted leader Aung San Suu Kyi has been charged with two more crimes, including violating a natural disaster law and publishing information that may cause fear or alarm, according to a lawyer representing her. The charges were added to existing allegations of illegally importing walkie-talkie radios. Suu Kyi appeared in a video conference court hearing, looking healthy, and her next hearing is set for March 15. The military coup, which ousted Suu Kyi's government, has sparked widespread protests and violence, with at least 18 people killed and hundreds of thousands demonstrating. The international community has condemned the violence and called for a united response, with some countries urging a global arms embargo and sanctions against those behind the coup.

site_title: One third of Hin Leong founder's ships sold to repay debt: sources
summary: About one-third of the 150 ships owned by companies controlled by Singapore tycoon Lim Oon Kuin and his family have been sold as part of efforts to repay billions of dollars of debt owed to creditors. The ships were sold at prices ranging from $2 million to $30 million each, with buyers including Greek ship owners. The rest of the ships are expected to be sold by late this year, despite being tied up in lawsuits over cargoes. This sale is part of the Lim family's efforts to repay debt after their company, Hin Leong Trading, racked up $4 billion in debt and entered court restructuring.

site_title: Volkswagen admits marketing prank, pulls fake release on name change
summary: Volkswagen's US unit issued a false news release claiming it would rename its US operations as "Voltswagen of America" to draw attention to its electric vehicle efforts. The move was widely criticized on social media, recalling the company's 2015 diesel emissions scandal and years of misleading customers and regulators. The company later admitted the stunt was a marketing prank, pulling the release and apologizing for the misleading information.

site_title: Singapore's arbitration centre sets record in 2020 with 1,080 case filings
summary: The Singapore International Arbitration Centre (SIAC) set a record in 2020 with 1,080 case filings, surpassing the 1,000-case threshold for the first time. The centre administered 98% of the cases, with a total sum in dispute of US$8.5 billion. Parties from 60 jurisdictions chose to arbitrate at SIAC, with India, the US, and China topping the foreign user rankings. The milestones were achieved through careful planning and hard work, with the centre expressing gratitude for the trust of its users worldwide.

site_title: Pent-up demand driving global factory revival
summary: Global factory activity surged in February, with the Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reaching a three-year high of 57.9, driven by pent-up demand and vaccine rollouts. However, China's factory activity slowed to its lowest pace in nine months due to a domestic COVID-19 flare-up and soft demand. Despite this, other Asian economies such as Japan, South Korea, India, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Vietnam saw robust growth, with exports rising and manufacturing activity expanding for the seventh consecutive month in India.

site_title: Mindef to spend S$90m to upgrade DSO biosafety lab to deal with more severe viruses
summary: The Defence Ministry of Singapore is spending approximately S$90 million to upgrade the DSO Biosafety Lab to the highest bio-safety level (BSL-4), allowing it to handle more severe forms of viruses. The lab, expected to be operational by 2025, will be designed and constructed with the assistance of third-party and overseas experts. The upgrade is necessary to address the increasing threat of infectious diseases, with Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen citing the potential of future pandemics or biological attacks being worse than COVID-19.

site_title: SoftBank to merge PayPay and Line Pay apps in Japan
summary: SoftBank plans to merge its PayPay and Line Pay apps in Japan by April 2022, subject to regulatory approvals. The move combines the payment apps of SoftBank's telecom arm and messaging service owner Line Corp. The deal, which was delayed due to pandemic-induced market disruptions, aims to extract synergies from overlapping businesses. SoftBank Corp and Line's parent Naver Corp each own half of a newly created A Holdings Corp, which controls 65.3% of publicly traded Z Holdings Corp, taking SoftBank's Yahoo Japan and Line's operations under its umbrella.

site_title: Dozens hurt at weekend Thai protest as police use rubber bullets
summary: Dozens of Thai protesters and police were injured in violent clashes at an anti-government rally on Sunday, with 22 protesters arrested and 10 police officers hurt. Rubber bullets were used for the first time by police, with protesters claiming they started the violence. The youth-led movement demands the resignation of Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha and calls for monarchy reform, sparking a response from the Royal Palace. The clashes follow weeks of protests against the government, which has enforced an emergency decree since last year.

site_title: Hong Kong's iconic Rosewood Hotel Group to file for SPAC listing
summary: Hong Kong's luxury hotel group, Rosewood, plans to file for a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) listing, targeting the consumer sector. The listing, led by Credit Suisse and JP Morgan, aims to raise approximately $400 million. Rosewood, managed by Sonia Cheng, will issue shares at $10 apiece, following a trend of luxury companies using SPACs to expedite listings. The move adds to the recent rush for SPAC deals, as the company seeks to expand its presence in the US market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore visitor numbers dropped 98.6% in January to 23,150, compared to 1.69 million in the previous year. Bank lending rose 0.7% in January, driven by loans to businesses. DBS appointed Raof Latiff as new Malaysia country head, while Nanofilm aims to capitalize on electric vehicle growth. Retailers in the Asia-Pacific region are recovering with new growth plans. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed Monday's trading 0.81% higher.

images.alt_text: Singapore has recorded its first month-on-month decline in international arrivals since the Covid-19 pandemic hammered global travel early last year.

site_title: Veteran Hong Kong activists convicted over huge democracy rally
summary: Nine veteran Hong Kong activists, including prominent pro-democracy campaigners and non-violence advocates, were convicted on Thursday on unlawful assembly charges for their role in organizing a massive 2019 democracy rally. The defendants face up to five years in jail. The verdict comes as China continues a sweeping crackdown on dissent following seven months of democracy protests in Hong Kong. The activists, who organized one of the city's largest democracy rallies, were found guilty of defying police instructions and encouraging crowds to march without permission.

site_title: Oil falls 2% as fresh lockdowns, demand concerns weigh on Opec+
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Wednesday due to fresh lockdowns in Europe and a pessimistic demand outlook from Opec+ ahead of their meeting to decide on production curbs. Brent crude fell to $63.54 a barrel and US WTI crude fell to $59.16 a barrel. A downward revision of Opec+ oil demand growth forecast and a lack of formal recommendation from the Joint Technical Committee weighed on prices. The Opec+ meeting is set to decide on output policy, with options including an output roll-over and a gradual increase.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Investing in China's market - the case for retail investors (Ep 91)
summary: A recent episode of "BT Money Hacks" discusses the potential for retail investors to invest in China's market. The podcast highlights the benefits of investing in China's market, despite potential risks. Key points include the growth potential of the Chinese economy and the increasing accessibility of investment opportunities. The episode concludes that retail investors should consider diversifying their portfolios and exploring China's market as a viable option.

site_title: New vaccine, lower yields give equities a shot in arm
summary: Key regional markets rose due to lower yields and a new, single-shot COVID-19 vaccine authorization in the US. Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,973, up 0.81%, while Japan's Nikkei 225 Index rose 2.41%. Australia's S&P/ASX 200 gained 1.74%, boosted by economic data and central bank easing. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index also increased. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and amid US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hot stock: SIA soars 5.2% amid global airline stock rally
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) shares surged 5.2% on Monday, driven by a global airline stock rally, reaching an intra-day high of S$5.30. The airline's market cap has surpassed pre-Covid levels, and analysts attribute the price increase to fund flow into the sector. DBS Group Research maintains a "fully valued" call, while UOB Kay Hian has a "hold" recommendation. Despite concerns about overvaluation, SIA is expected to experience a steady recovery from the second half of the year.

site_title: Europe: Equities rally at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rallied at the start of trade on Monday, with London's FTSE 100 index jumping 1.7% to 6,592.45 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices advancing 1.4% and 1.5% respectively. The rally came after a global rout last week, driven by concerns over rising US Treasury yields and inflation. However, sentiment was boosted by the worldwide rollout of coronavirus vaccines and the passage of US President Joe Biden's stimulus through the House.

site_title: Round-the-world cruises are selling out more than a year in advance
summary: Round-the-world cruises are selling out more than a year in advance, with Viking Ocean Cruises' 136-day world cruise selling out in weeks in July 2021. The trend is driven by pent-up demand and favorable deals, with many cruisers eager to see as much of the world as possible. Several luxury cruise lines, including Oceania Cruises and Seabourn, have also sold out their top-tier suites for world sailings in 2022 and 2023. Despite the challenges posed by the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic, cruise companies are optimistic about the future, with many offering VIP perks and discounts to lock in bookings.

site_title: Australia's Macquarie Bank ordered to raise reserves after reporting breaches
summary: Australia's Macquarie Bank has been ordered to increase its cash reserves by A$500 million after breaching prudential standards regarding risk controls. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) cited material breaches in treating intra-group funding arrangements incorrectly when reporting capital and related-entity exposure. This announcement comes amid increased regulatory scrutiny for investment banks following recent risk management debacles.

site_title: 12 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: Singapore reported 12 new Covid-19 cases on March 1, all of whom were imported. The total cases now stand at 59,948. A locally transmitted case was reported on February 28, but all others were imported, with 10 cases being work pass holders and 2 dependant's pass holders. Seven patients were discharged from hospitals or isolation facilities, bringing the total recovered to 59,808.

site_title: WTO hikes 2021 trade growth forecast, but Covid-19 risks linger
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has raised its forecast for global goods trade growth in 2021 to 8% from a previous 7.2%, but warns of lingering Covid-19 risks. WTO Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala attributed the slight increase to the rollout of vaccines, which could boost the economy, but also noted that unequal access to vaccines could hinder progress. Short-term risks remain on the downside, primarily due to pandemic-related factors, and the organization is planning to meet vaccine manufacturers to address production and distribution concerns.

site_title: Germany to bar AstraZeneca vaccine for those under 60
summary: Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel has announced that the country will halt the use of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccine for people under 60 due to emerging severe blood clot cases. This decision comes after new data on potential side effects and is another blow to Europe's inoculation drive, already affected by delays, controversy, and political battles.

site_title: Rekindling of residential en bloc sales in 2021?
summary: A possible revival in residential en bloc sales in Singapore is likely to be modest, following a brief period of activity after 2018. The 2017-2018 en bloc sales boom has left policymakers cautious, having led to cooling measures. En bloc sales, which involve collective sales for development purposes, could raise hopes among owners but may also spark concerns. The market is expected to be more positive than the last cycle, which could be a healthier outcome.

site_title: AirAsia posts record quarterly loss
summary: Malaysia's budget airline AirAsia Group reported a record quarterly loss of RM2.44 billion (S$790.9 million) in the October-December period, driven by depreciation and impairments due to lockdowns. Revenue fell 92% to RM267.4 million, with capacity shrinking 88% compared to last year. The airline expects a full recovery in two years and hopes for international air travel to resume in the second half of this year. AirAsia has raised up to RM2.5 billion and secured RM1 billion in loans from Malaysian banks to weather the pandemic.

site_title: Indonesia weather agency sees delayed arrival of dry season in 2021
summary: Indonesia's weather agency has predicted a delayed arrival of the dry season in 2021, with La Nina weather conditions expected to last until May. Some regions, such as Sumatra and Java, may start seeing the dry season in May, while others may not until June. The agency warned of extreme rain and wind in April and May, posing a threat to rice production and potentially causing forest fires. Despite the predicted less intense dry season, authorities are still advised to take measures against forest fires, particularly in regions prone to haze.

site_title: CEO pay hikes won't sail through at British AGMs, investors warn
summary: British companies facing annual general meetings (AGMs) are expected to face opposition from investors over unreasonable CEO pay hikes and lack of diversity on boards. Investors are increasingly focusing on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues, citing the need for fairness and sensitivity to the broader context of the workforce. Companies with large-scale redundancies, government aid, or dividends may be less likely to receive bonuses, while some investors are also reviewing share plans and seeking more diverse board compositions.

site_title: Investors renew push for EU methane emissions standard on gas: letter
summary: European investors representing 36 trillion euros in assets are urging the European Commission to introduce mandatory methane emissions standards for natural gas. The EU, the world's largest gas importer, currently lacks rules to disincentivize importing gas from methane-leak prone infrastructure outside the EU. Investors are calling for a minimum 0.25% intensity of upstream supply for all gas sold in the EU by 2025, aiming to reduce the potent greenhouse gas's impact on the environment. A new legal framework is expected by the end of the year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 2.09 points to 1,609.19, with 649 losers outnumbering 414 gainers. Volume was 5.782 billion lots worth RM3.590 billion.

site_title: Mayor ends remote work for 80,000 in New York
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that the city will compel its 80,000 municipal office employees to return to work in person on May 3, ending remote work arrangements that have been in place for the past year. The decision represents a significant turnabout for the city, which was the national epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic. With virus cases stabilizing and vaccinations becoming more widespread, the move aims to signal the city's return to normalcy and boost its economy.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB reiterates 'add' on FEHT; expects accelerated recovery from FY2023
summary: CGS-CIMB reiterates its "add" rating on Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT), increasing its target price to 74.5 Singapore cents due to an accelerated recovery from FY2023. The trust received an outline advice from the URA for Central Square redevelopment, which could lead to reduced gearing and a lower distribution per unit. The analysts expect FEHT's hotel segment to be supported by master lease income and variable income to start in FY2023, driven by international travel recovery.

site_title: 17 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, all imported
summary: There were 17 new Covid-19 cases confirmed in Singapore, bringing the total to 60,253, all of which were imported and placed on stay-home notices upon arrival. The Ministry of Health (MOH) reported that viral fragments detected in wastewater at the National University of Singapore are likely due to a past infection among residents, with one test result still pending. The number of new cases in the community has decreased to zero, with 60,063 patients fully recovered and 25 remaining in hospital.

site_title: Hot stock: Khong Guan surges 15.4% after investment announcement
summary: Khong Guan's shares surged 15.4% to a one-week high of S$1.57 after announcing a S$1.5 million investment in SGProtein, a plant-based meat alternatives producer. The investment will make SGProtein an associated company to Khong Guan. The proposal is funded through internal resources and is expected to have minimal impact on Khong Guan's earnings. The investment represents a new growth opportunity for the company in Singapore and the region.

site_title: Razer turns profitable for FY2020, with revenue exceeding US$1b
summary: Razer, a gaming hardware and fintech firm, has turned profitable for the first time since going public in 2017, with net profit of US$5.6 million for FY2020. Revenue exceeded US$1 billion, growing 48% to a record US$1.21 billion. The company's hardware segment saw a 51.8% increase, while its software business saw a 53.8% rise in total user accounts. Razer's services business, including Razer Gold and Razer Fintech, contributed 22.3% to gross profit, up from 20.5% the previous year. The company plans to continue strong operating expenses discipline and introduce new hardware, aiming for outsized growth and continued profitability in 2021.

site_title: BOE says artificial sterling libor could continue for a decade
summary: The Bank of England has proposed publishing an artificial sterling Libor number for up to 10 years after the benchmark's retirement at the end of 2021 to help financial contracts transition to new benchmarks. The Financial Conduct Authority will consult on this plan, which aims to prevent a chaotic transition for bonds and securitisations. This approach differs from the US, which is pursuing legislation in New York to smooth the transition. The BOE will review the approach for dollar Libor tenors ending in mid-2023.

site_title: UK students, French seniors team up for lockdown chats
summary: UK students, aged 20, are paired with French seniors, aged 97, for weekly online conversations as part of the "Share Ami" programme. The initiative, launched in 2020, aims to combat social isolation during the pandemic. Since its inception, over 110 pairs have been formed, with nearly 50 students at Warwick University participating. The programme not only exposes students to language and culture but also provides a sense of connection for seniors, many of whom live alone.

site_title: Time to look at high-yielding corporate bonds
summary: Investors should take advantage of the recent fixed-income bond sell-off by looking for high-yielding corporate bonds in the SGD and USD markets. Rising bond yields, particularly in US Treasuries, are a sign of an improved economic outlook and inflation. Investors can find opportunities in high-yield, short-duration bonds, despite the overall market volatility.

site_title: Suez Canal diverts ships to old channel after giant container ship runs aground
summary: A 200,000-ton container ship, the Ever Given, ran aground in the Suez Canal on Tuesday, blocking traffic and diverting ships to an older channel. The incident, attributed to bad weather, has caused delays to shipping and is expected to impact 12% of global trade. The ship, owned by Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp, is being freed by tugboats, but its release is uncertain. The blockage has also affected oil and gas flows, with five LNG tankers waiting to pass through the canal.

images.alt_text: The Ever Given, which is 400 metres long and 59 metres wide, is suspected of being hit by sudden strong wind, causing the hull to deviate from the waterway and accidentally hit the bottom and run aground.

site_title: Wuxi court declares OUELH subsidiary 'rightful and legal' owner of Wuxi land plot
summary: A Wuxi Intermediate Court has ruled that OUE Lippo Healthcare's (OUELH) subsidiary, Weixin Hospital Investment Management (Shanghai) Co, is the rightful and legal owner of a 22,681 sq m land plot in Wuxi, Jiangsu Province. The court previously found the 2015 land-transfer agreement between two OUELH units to be legitimate and binding in November 2019. Weixin's appeal was withdrawn after the court accepted the application to dismiss it. The ruling resolves a land-litigation matter initiated by Weixin against OUELH's subsidiaries.

site_title: Former Japan bank regulator Endo to advise on digital currencies at cryptocurrency exchange
summary: Former Japan bank regulator Toshihide Endo will become special advisor to cryptocurrency exchange DeCurret on April 1, advising on digital currencies and potentially facilitating private sector efforts to build a common settlement infrastructure. Endo previously oversaw Japan's banking and financial regulation from 2018 to 2020, and his appointment reflects Tokyo's willingness to promote innovation in the cryptocurrency industry. The move also comes as the Bank of Japan considers studying the idea of issuing its own digital currency.

site_title: Australian ministers are targets in Telegram phishing scam
summary: Australian ministers are targets in a phishing scam using the Telegram messaging app. The scam, first reported on March 18, involves a message from an associate encouraging recipients to download a messaging app for further communication. Finance Minister Simon Birmingham confirmed he was targeted, stating his actual communication methods are secure. The Australian Federal Police and cyber-intelligence agency, Australian Signals Directorate, are investigating the incident.

site_title: Children have stronger antibody response to Covid: study
summary: A study published in JAMA Network Open found that children aged 10 and younger produce stronger antibody responses to Covid-19 than adolescents and adults, which may contribute to their lower susceptibility to severe cases. The study analyzed 32,000 antibody tests from New York City and found that children's median IgG antibody levels were nearly five times higher than those of young adults. The findings suggest age-related immune response differences may play a role in the varying clinical manifestations of Covid-19 in pediatric and adult patients.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares sharply down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.84% at open, mirroring Wall Street's sharp sell-off amid inflation fears. The Hang Seng Index fell 247.24 points to 29,158.48, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 1.13% to 3,423.87. This decline follows a broader market trend, with US stocks edging towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australia: Shares post first weekly loss as bond yields spike
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Friday, posting their first weekly loss in three weeks, as US bond yields surged and global risk appetite waned. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.6% to 6,708.2 points. Energy stocks were the biggest drag, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos losing 3.3% and 2.5%, respectively. Retail sales fell unexpectedly in February, but analysts expect consumer sentiment to remain strong due to ongoing vaccinations and labor market recovery.

site_title: The Place Holdings clears regulatory hurdle for proposed share consolidation
summary: THE Place Holdings has received regulatory approval for a proposed share consolidation, where each shareholder will receive one consolidated share for every five existing shares. The company has 5.88 billion shares to be consolidated into 1.18 billion shares. The move aims to facilitate future corporate actions and is subject to shareholder approval at the upcoming extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Driving sustainable growth for Singapore's top enterprises in 2021 and beyond, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Vietnam expressed surprise and disappointment over US President Donald Trump's announcement of tariffs on Vietnamese goods, which is expected to have a significant impact on the country's economy. The tariffs, which range from 10% to 25%, are set to be imposed on various Vietnamese exports, including electronics, footwear, and seafood. Vietnam's government has called for the tariffs to be reduced, citing the potential economic losses and damage to bilateral trade relations. The country is seeking a lower tariff rate to minimize the negative effects on its economy and maintain a stable trade relationship with the US.

site_title: China dominates Pentagon chief's first India visit
summary: US Pentagon Chief Lloyd Austin's first visit to India focused on shared concerns about China, with both nations emphasizing the importance of like-minded partnerships. The talks, held in New Delhi, came after tense talks between US and Chinese officials in Alaska. India is a vital US partner in the Asia-Pacific region, and the visit aimed to strengthen bilateral ties and address regional security issues.

site_title: Australia unemployment drops to 5.8% as recovery strengthens
summary: Australia's unemployment rate dropped to 5.8% in February, exceeding expectations, as the economy's recovery strengthened. Employment rose by 88,700, surpassing 13 million people, with the participation rate remaining at 66.1%. The jobless rate has fallen below the Reserve Bank of Australia's year-end estimate, highlighting a V-shaped recovery. However, the end of the JobKeeper wage subsidy on March 28 may pose headwinds for the labor market, but economists believe it won't derail the recovery.

site_title: Biden's China's policy is a work in progress in the Indo-Pacific region
summary: US President Joe Biden's China policy is centered on a multilateralist approach, mobilizing America's allies to counter Beijing's growing influence in the Indo-Pacific region. The Biden administration is committed to maintaining a tough stance on security and trade, but differs from former President Donald Trump's unilateralist approach. Diplomatic efforts, such as the Quad grouping with Japan, India, Australia, and the US, aim to project American power and reassure allies in the region. A high-level meeting between US officials and their Chinese counterparts in Alaska will test the diplomatic assertiveness of the Biden administration.

site_title: Family offices may drive SPAC growth in Singapore
summary: Family offices in Singapore, with approximately $20 billion in assets under management, may drive growth in special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) in the city-state. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) plans to consult on SPAC listings this quarter, but rules have not been drafted yet. SPACs, which have raised $70 billion in the US this year, could bring a buzz to Singapore's capital markets. However, the popularity of SPAC listings in Singapore will depend on the availability of viable companies and the rules governing their use.

site_title: Mining value from bauxite to pineapples, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Richport Technology is expanding its surface treatment offerings, further solidifying its position in the industry. The company has been refining its processes to enhance product quality and efficiency. Richport's surface treatment solutions cater to various sectors, including automotive, aerospace, and consumer goods. By continually improving its offerings, Richport aims to meet the growing demands of its clients and maintain its market leadership. The company's commitment to innovation and quality has positioned it as a trusted partner for surface treatment solutions. Its expanded offerings are expected to drive business growth and expansion.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at Tuesday's open, following a record close on Wall Street the previous day. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 6.97 points to 3,112.97, with Oceanus shares being the most actively traded, rising 7.3%. Local banks DBS and Keppel DC Reit also saw gains, while Jardine C&C fell 0.6%. The US market closed at record highs, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 rising 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively, amid optimism over Covid-19 vaccines and government stimulus.

site_title: Credit Suisse flags possible charge from Greensill fallout
summary: Credit Suisse warns it may incur charges due to the collapse of US$10 billion Greensill-linked supply chain finance funds. The bank has paid out US$3.1 billion in redemptions from the four funds and is working to recover US$140 million loan to Greensill. Credit Suisse's share price has fallen 10.6% since the funds were frozen, and the bank is hiring external firms to deal with regulators and insurers amid questions over the contracts that underpinned Greensill's security.

site_title: Mao Sheng Quanji looks beyond pandemic, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Richport Technology is expanding its surface treatment capabilities. The company is enhancing its surface treatment offerings to cater to the growing demand in the industry. Although the article doesn't specify the nature of the enhancements or the target market, it suggests Richport Technology is investing in its surface treatment division to meet the evolving needs of its customers. This move is expected to strengthen the company's position in the market and improve its competitive edge. Details on the specific enhancements are not provided.

site_title: Penguin's acquisition offeror garners about 59.71% of shares
summary: The offeror for Penguin International, Emet Grace, has garnered approximately 59.71% of shares in the company. This is conditional upon receiving enough acceptances to surpass the 50% mark. If the shareholding exceeds 90%, the offeror intends to delist the stock from the Singapore Exchange's mainboard. The counter closed unchanged at S$0.65 per share on Monday.

site_title: In the line of duty: On wealth taxes, Singapore must decide what it most wants to achieve; and know what it could cost
summary: Singapore is considering introducing wealth taxes, following global trends as countries seek to fund pandemic responses. The country has a growing super-rich population, with over 3,700 ultra-high-net-worth individuals, and has been compared to Switzerland, which has a wealth tax that works. However, experts warn that wealth taxes can be challenging to implement and may not be effective in reducing inequality. They suggest setting higher thresholds, limiting exemptions, and using tax transparency standards to make wealth taxes more sustainable. The government must weigh the benefits of introducing wealth taxes against the potential risks, including harming the wealth management industry and creating perceptions of instability.

site_title: Singapore shares finish flat on Tuesday amid modest gains in region
summary: Singapore shares closed flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping 0.02% to 3,105.51. The top STI gainer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, rising 4.9%, while Koh Brothers Eco Engineering more than doubled after announcing an investor's buy of 810 million new shares. Markets in Japan, South Korea, and China also finished higher, with the US$1.9 trillion stimulus package expected to boost exports and global recovery. However, the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting on Wednesday is expected to influence market sentiment, with markets in a holding pattern.

site_title: UOBKH downgrades Malaysia glove sector; Top Glove remains top pick
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) downgraded its call on Malaysia's rubber glove sector from "overweight" to "market weight", citing Top Glove as its top pick due to attractive valuations and potential lifting of the US sale ban. Top Glove shares rose 2.34% on the Singapore bourse. UOBKH expects the sector's average selling price to peak in Q2 and moderate by 3-5% until the end of the year. The brokerage also maintained "hold" recommendations for Hartalega and "buy" calls for Kossan Rubber Industries and Supermax Corporation.

site_title: Murdoch's News Corp reaches three-year deal with Facebook in Australia
summary: News Corp, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, has reached a three-year deal with Facebook in Australia, securing compensation for using their content. The agreement follows Australia's parliament passing a law requiring Google and Facebook to pay media companies. The deal expands on an existing agreement between News Corp and Facebook, covering The Australian national newspaper and metropolitan papers. This comes after News Corp struck a similar deal with Google in February. The agreements aim to protect local news media and set a precedent for other countries considering similar measures.

site_title: India widens coronavirus curbs as infections top 20,000 for sixth day
summary: India has reported 24,492 new coronavirus cases, marking the sixth consecutive day with over 20,000 infections. Total cases have risen to 11.41 million, with 158,856 deaths. The government attributes the surge to crowding and mask-wearing reluctance, ruling out virus mutations. Maharashtra has implemented curbs, limiting capacity in cinemas, hotels, and restaurants, while Gujarat has banned fans at a cricket stadium due to a spike in cases. India has vaccinated nearly 26 million people, aiming to inoculate 300 million by August.

site_title: Vista to merge Four Winds, Poppulo into US$1b company
summary: Vista Equity Partners' portfolio company Four Winds Interactive is merging with Ireland-based software provider Poppulo in a deal valued at approximately $1 billion. The combined companies will provide digital sign technology and internal communications software, aiding in the return to office plans post-COVID-19. The acquisition will help Four Winds' customers with workplace safety, security, and engagement, while Poppulo's software will improve workplace communications and employee engagement. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter and generate around $100 million in annual revenue.

site_title: Women across Australia march against sexual violence and inequality
summary: Women across Australia marched against sexual violence and inequality, with tens of thousands attending rallies in over 40 cities and towns. The #March4Justice protests were sparked by rape allegations against the government, including Attorney-General Christian Porter and Defence Minister Linda Reynolds. Protesters called for immediate change, including independent investigations and support services for staff, as critics argue systemic change is needed to address a "toxic" workplace culture. The government has ordered an inquiry into parliament's workplace culture, but organizers say it's not enough.

site_title: BR Metals turns trash to cash, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Richport Technology is expanding its surface treatment offerings, further solidifying its position in the market. The company has been actively investing in research and development, resulting in the creation of new and improved surface treatments. These enhancements are designed to provide enhanced performance, durability, and sustainability. Richport Technology's continued innovation and commitment to surface treatment solutions positions the company for long-term growth and success in the industry. The company's surface treatment offerings are now more comprehensive, catering to a wider range of applications and industries.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.23 points to 1,620.92 on Monday, with a 10.292 billion lots traded worth RM5.219 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 611-586.

site_title: Netflix tests feature that could limit password sharing
summary: Netflix is testing a feature that verifies users share a household with the account owner, aiming to curb password sharing. A small number of users are receiving a message asking to confirm their household relationship via text or email. Viewers can delay verification but may eventually need to open a new account. The test is part of Netflix's efforts to ensure authorized use of accounts, although it's unclear if the feature will be implemented widely. The company's terms of service already require users to live in the same household.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on US jobs data, stimulus boost
summary: Australian shares rose 0.8% to 6,766.80 on Friday, driven by hopes for a global economic rebound after the US signed a $1.9 trillion stimulus package and upbeat US jobs data showed fewer-than-expected unemployment claims. The S&P/ASX 200 index also rose for the week.

site_title: Sunseap, Amazon sign agreement for clean solar energy to be tapped from JTC's solar farms
summary: Amazon has signed an agreement with Singapore's Sunseap Group to tap clean solar energy from JTC's solar farms. The 62 megawatt solar project, set to be completed in 2022, will generate 80,000 megawatt hours of clean energy annually, powering over 10,000 homes. The project is part of Amazon's efforts to meet its goal of powering operations with 100% renewable energy by 2030, five years ahead of schedule. It is Amazon's first renewable energy project in Singapore and its latest investment in the Asia-Pacific region, contributing to a total of 411 MW of installed capacity.

site_title: Australia finds new home for barley in Saudi Arabia
summary: Australian barley farmers have secured a new major market, beating competition from other suppliers to secure a significant share of a 660,000-ton purchase from Saudi Arabia. This marks a significant turnround for farmers, who were previously hit by escalating tensions with China. The surge in global crop prices has made Australian barley competitive, opening up new destinations for the grain, including Saudi Arabia, Thailand, Vietnam, and Mexico. However, risks remain in the long term, as Saudi Arabia is set to phase out government tenders and potentially decrease barley imports.

site_title: Novo Tellus unit makes partial offer of 36.5 S cents for 51% stake in Procurri
summary: Novo Tellus, a unit of Procurri Corporation's largest shareholder, has made a partial offer to acquire an additional 27.91% of Procurri's shares at 36.5 Singapore cents per share. This represents a 32.7% premium over Procurri's last traded price of 27.5 Singapore cents. Procurri will remain publicly listed to allow shareholders to participate in its future financial performance. The offer is part of a larger stake acquisition by Novo Tellus, which already holds a 51% stake in the company.

site_title: 16-year-olds get early start in Singapore's hedge funds
summary: Singapore is experiencing a shortage of qualified professionals in the hedge fund industry, prompting the government and investors to cultivate the next generation of asset managers. A wave of 16-year-olds, including Cao Yi Ke, are being given internships at top hedge funds, such as Modular Asset Management, to prepare them for the industry. The government has launched training subsidies and retraining programs for existing executives to address the shortage. The goal is to build a strong cohort of investment professionals with deep knowledge about how the markets work, with a focus on Asia as the key region for the industry's future growth.

site_title: California drivers rev up petrol demand in biggest US state
summary: California drivers are boosting petrol demand after the pandemic, with traffic on toll bridges in the San Francisco Bay area rising 13% in February compared to the previous month. This early sign of recovery points to a potential rebound in the US oil market. Despite the increase, tollway use remains below 2020 levels, and petrol prices are rising due to tight supplies. The state's refineries are struggling to meet demand, with fuel production affected by a recent freeze on the Gulf Coast. This trend may indicate a gradual return to pre-pandemic petrol demand levels.

site_title: The Game doesn't have to Stop - if you enter the playing field with an edge
summary: GameStop's recent rally has drawn attention to various trading strategies and pitfalls. Early entrants, such as those who saw the potential for new console sales, benefited from the company's upward momentum. In contrast, day traders who entered and exited positions swiftly often relied on discipline and risk management. Social media-driven traders, however, were more prone to emotional decision-making, resulting in significant losses. To succeed, investors should focus on decent returns, good methodology, and knowing when to enter and exit the market.

site_title: US protesters demand justice in trial of officer charged over George Floyd's death
summary: Thousands of protesters in Minneapolis marched silently, bearing replica coffins, ahead of the trial of former police officer Derek Chauvin, charged with killing George Floyd, a Black man, by kneeling on his neck for nearly nine minutes in May 2020. The protesters chanted "No justice, no peace!" as a nationwide protest movement against racism and police brutality was triggered by Floyd's death.

site_title: US jobless claims hit lowest since November with more vaccines
summary: US jobless claims fell to 712,000, the lowest since early November, as Covid-19 vaccinations accelerated and states eased business restrictions. Continuing claims declined by 193,000 to 4.14 million. The drop in initial claims suggests a slowing rate of job cuts, with states like Texas, Mississippi, and Wyoming planning to relax pandemic-related rules. The US$1.9 trillion unemployment package, signed into law Friday, extends some unemployment benefits until September.

site_title: After S$24m redevelopment, Seletar Country Club a hit among golfers
summary: Seletar Country Club in Singapore has undergone a $24 million redevelopment and has become a hit among golfers. The club, established in 1930, was once a Royal Air Force gated-facility and has produced several top Singaporean golfers. After a redesign, the course was declared the Best Renovated Golf Course in the Asia Pacific 2020 Global Awards. With its unique design and playability, the club attracts both members and non-members, with a rate of $51,500 and limited membership openings.

site_title: Partnership management can enhance universities' project-based learning
summary: Universities are incorporating project-based learning (PBL) into their teaching pedagogies to prepare students for the challenges of the real world. PBL allows students to learn theory in the classroom and apply it in a real-world setting, fostering adaptability and agility of mindsets. Effective partnerships between universities and industry are crucial, with four key pillars of partnership management: value proposition, depth of collaboration, knowledge creation and exchange, and continuous feedback. Careful partnership management is essential to realize the full benefits of PBL for both universities and industry partners.

site_title: Oil extends slide on strong US dollar
summary: Oil futures declined over 3% in the past two sessions, adding volatility to the market, as the US dollar strengthened. The American Petroleum Institute reported a decline in US gasoline stockpiles and an increase in crude inventories. A stronger US dollar reduces the appeal of commodities priced in the currency, contributing to the price drop.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has updated its road tax for electric vehicles, merging the current bands and applying the current formula to the lower band. The country aims to have 80% of new buildings be Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings by 2030 under its refreshed green building masterplan. A new S$60 million agri-food fund will support the sector to increase productivity and meet the nation's target of producing 30% of nutritional needs through local farms by 2030. The public sector aims to peak carbon emissions by 2025, ahead of the national target.

site_title: US labour market added more jobs than forecast in February
summary: The US labour market added 379,000 jobs in February, exceeding forecast, and the unemployment rate declined to 6.2%. This marks a positive trend for the labour market after several disappointing months. Leisure and hospitality employment surged 355,000, contributing to the job growth. Economists expect job prospects to improve in the coming months as vaccinations and virus concerns ease. The labour market is being closely monitored by policymakers, who are considering another economic stimulus bill, including an extension of federal unemployment benefits.

site_title: The AIoT En-Visionary
summary: Sylvie Ouziel, international president of Envision Digital, believes that innovation will help humanity overcome the sustainability challenge. She attributes her background in science, technology, and engineering to her passion for change and her ability to drive innovation. Ouziel points to AIoT (Artificial Intelligence of Things) as a key solution to renewable energy challenges, enabling objects to analyze and interact with minimal human intervention. She cites the success of her company's work with Microsoft on the Zizhu facility in Shanghai, where AIoT-managed EV chargers multiplied the charging capacity tenfold without expanding the grid. Ouziel argues that Singapore's policymakers are taking a cautious approach to EV adoption, opting for low-intensity chargers to avoid grid congestion. She envisions a future where cities and environments are connected through technology, enabling continuous loops of energy and turning source into destination.

site_title: How clean is green?
summary: Singapore's push for electric vehicles (EVs) may not be as green as expected due to various factors such as production emissions, electricity generation, and battery recycling. While EVs can reduce emissions by 4% of total national emissions, they also increase energy demand, potentially leading to higher carbon emissions. The extraction of rare metals for battery production poses environmental concerns. However, experts suggest that a holistic life-cycle approach and advancements in battery technology could mitigate these issues. The government aims to deploy 60,000 charging points by 2030 and has set targets to reduce emissions and increase the use of renewable energy sources.

site_title: Get a Peloton-style workout without splurging
summary: A fitness enthusiast created a DIY Peloton-style workout at home for under $300 by modifying an existing exercise bike and using free online classes from YouTube and the Peloton app. She saved $1,900 by avoiding the luxury bike and class fees. Other DIY approaches include using an existing bicycle with add-ons like a bike trainer and heart-rate monitor, or buying an indoor exercise bike and tablet to stream classes. While the DIY setup may lack some features of the paid Peloton experience, it provides a convenient and affordable alternative for those looking to work out at home.

site_title: Grab weighs US IPO through SPAC merger: sources
summary: Grab Holdings is exploring a US initial public offering (IPO) through a merger with a blank-cheque company, a move that would expedite its listing process. JPMorgan Chase & Co and Morgan Stanley are advising Grab on the plan, which could also involve a traditional IPO. This follows talks with Indonesian rival Gojek collapsing, with Gojek now in discussions to merge with Tokopedia. The move is part of a trend in Southeast Asia's tech unicorns, including Sea Ltd, which went public in the US in 2017.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits one-month low as US futures slump
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 2.13% to 28,930.11, its lowest in a month, amid concerns over rising US bond yields and a slump in US futures. Global shares also declined as investors maintained a cautious stance. SoftBank Group and Fast Retailing were the biggest losers, with SoftBank Group dropping 5.19% after news of Greensill Capital's potential sale.

site_title: South-east Asia's manufacturing malaise
summary: South-east Asia's manufacturing sector is in a malaise, with many countries relying on foreign direct investment and lacking internationally competitive companies. Vietnam's success in attracting manufacturing is not being replicated across the region. The sector is characterized by sub-scale, lower-order activities, and high dependence on foreign capital and expertise. China's competitiveness is a major challenge, with its manufacturers having an advantage in innovation, productivity, and end-market proximity. The region's failure to develop homegrown manufacturers will lead to a decline in economic aspirations and a shift towards a more domestic and service-oriented economy, reinforcing Asia's emerging economic hierarchy.

site_title: GE nears deal with AerCap to create behemoth aircraft lessor
summary: General Electric Co is nearing a deal to combine its jet-leasing business with AerCap Holdings NV, creating a behemoth aircraft lessor with a potential value of over $30 billion. The transaction, expected to be announced as soon as Monday, would bring together the world's two biggest aircraft financiers and speed GE's push to streamline its business. The deal could be a "win-win situation" for both companies and the airline industry, with GE and AerCap seeing renewed interest in engine refinance and leasing in the post-Covid recovery backdrop.

site_title: Japan planning to ban overseas Olympic spectators over Covid-19 fears
summary: Japan's government is planning to ban overseas spectators at the upcoming Summer Olympics due to COVID-19 concerns. The decision, to be made this month, comes after a poll showed 91% of Japanese people want spectators kept to a minimum or not allowed at all. The country has already confirmed 431,250 coronavirus cases and 7,931 deaths, and the government is weighing options for domestic spectators, despite low infection numbers in Japan.

site_title: Future-proof insurance
summary: AIA Group's CEO Lee Yuan Siong believes digital transformation is key for the insurer to achieve new growth milestones and improve customer service. Under his leadership, AIA has successfully harnessed technology to spur policyholders to take action in terms of healthier lifestyles. The company's health platform Vitality has generated over 100 million customer interactions and has shown positive clinical outcomes for its members. Lee plans to recruit talent in technology, digital, and analytics, and to simplify its organization to work in a more connected fashion. He aims to build digital tools around the customer journey and use data analytics models to guide its service and sales staff. AIA's strategy is to "future-proof" the company and raise its game in customer service.

images.alt_text: "We can't assume that we'd forever be the market leader. We need to build up the foundations and capabilities to future-proof our leading position." - Lee Yuan Siong.

site_title: Monthly record of 23 million-dollar HDB resale flats sold in February
summary: In February, a new monthly record of 23 million-dollar HDB resale flats were sold, with prices rising 1.4% compared to January and 8.3% year-on-year. The flats, which make up about 1% of total resales, have the highest transacted prices, with an executive maisonette selling for S$1.21 million. Experts attribute the strong market to high demand, tight supply, and recovering market sentiment, with some predicting prices to remain resilient and grow 3-5% for the year.

site_title: Several EWL stations to be closed on Sundays to facilitate cable replacement
summary: Several East-West MRT Line stations in Singapore will be closed on Sundays between March 14 and May 23 to facilitate cable replacement along the Tuas West Extension. Six stations will be closed on March 14-21 and four on April 25-May 23. A shuttle bus service will operate during closures. The replacement is part of precautionary measures to prevent power cable faults, following a 2020 rail breakdown that stranded over 6,700 passengers. The works are expected to be completed by end-2021.

site_title: Top Glove Q2 net profit surges to RM2.87b on record sales; declares special dividend
summary: Top Glove Corporation reported a record-breaking Q2 net profit of RM2.87 billion, quadrupling its sales revenue to RM5.37 billion and increasing sales volume by 19% year-over-year. The company declared a special dividend of 25.2 sen per share, totaling 70% of the total dividend payout for the first half of 2021. Despite supply shortages and market fluctuations, the company attributed its strong sales to continued global demand for gloves.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HRnetGroup, Medtecs, CPO plays, Oceanus, Mary Chia
summary: HRnetGroup posted a net profit of S$46.9 million for its full year ended Dec 31, 2020, down 9.2% from the year-ago period. Medtecs International entered into a joint venture with ACO International. CPO plays saw lifted revenues due to recent price spike, with smaller counters like Bumitama Agri and Mewah International performing well. Oceanus Group shares plummeted 11.1% amid heavy trading. Mary Chia Holdings entered into a conditional debt capitalisation agreement for debt conversion and new share issue.

site_title: MAS bans four individuals involved in scheme to manipulate Koyo shares
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued prohibition orders to four individuals involved in a scheme to manipulate Koyo International shares. The individuals, including three former remisiers and one former insurance agent, were convicted and sentenced to jail terms ranging from three months to 20 months for their roles in artificially pushing up the share price. The longest ban duration is 10 years for Lau Wan Heng, who assisted the alleged mastermind in creating a false appearance of active trading in Koyo shares.

site_title: China 'worried' about bubbles in property, foreign markets
summary: China's top banking regulator, Guo Shuqing, expressed concerns about risks from bubbles in global financial markets and the nation's property sector. He warned that US and European market rallies are unsustainable and will eventually correct, potentially impacting China's economy. China's regulators are walking a fine line between curbing domestic risks and minimizing disruptions from abroad. The comments led to a decline in Asian stocks and a drop in Chinese government bonds, with yields on benchmark 10-year notes reaching a nearly three-week low.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government must not send "wrong signals" about the country's openness, said Chan Chun Sing. The government also aims to provide more access to innovation experts for startups and SMEs. Meanwhile, 8,655 online notifications for contractual relief have been submitted, with 66% related to commercial equipment or property. The number of ultra-high net worth individuals in Singapore rose 10.2% to 3,732 in 2020. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.03% to 2,973.87 points, while several Asian markets closed in the red.

site_title: Ambani's Jio biggest buyer in US$11b India airwave sale
summary: Billionaire Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Jio Infocomm emerged as the top bidder in India's $11 billion airwaves auction, acquiring airwaves worth 571.23 billion rupees (S$10.3 billion). The auction, India's first since 2016, exceeded the government's expectations, with some 60% of spectrum sold. Rival Bharti Airtel spent $2.6 billion, while Vodafone's India unit acquired spectrum worth 19.9 billion rupees. The sale is expected to boost the Indian exchequer and help the government jumpstart the economy after the pandemic-induced recession.

site_title: Democrats push Biden's US$1.9t Covid-19 bill through Senate on party-line vote
summary: The US Senate passed President Joe Biden's $1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief plan in a 50-49 party-line vote, giving Biden his first major legislative victory since taking office.
